course_title: Race and Public Health Crises: From TB to AIDS to COVID-19 001
best_comment: I think every public health student should take this class. So much of what we are taught in public health school is presented without much or any historical context, and this course was an incredible helpful corrective to that pedagogical practice. Also it was an honor to take a class from an amazing team of public health historians who did a great job of selecting excellent readings and other source material.
worse_comment: The course instructors don’t seem to have a solid grip on what  they want this course to be which led to a lot of confusion and frustration among the students in the course. I would not recommend this course if you are just starting out with the content matter, this course is better suited for committed AAAS concentrators

course_title: Race and Public Health Crises: From TB to AIDS to COVID-19 001
best_comment: I think every public health student should take this class. So much of what we are taught in public health school is presented without much or any historical context, and this course was an incredible helpful corrective to that pedagogical practice. Also it was an honor to take a class from an amazing team of public health historians who did a great job of selecting excellent readings and other source material.

I would not recommend this course if you are just starting out with the content matter, this course is better suited for committed AAAS concentrators

course_title: Sophomore Tutorial: Understanding Race and Racism 001
best_comment: Great class! Pretty much just an open discussion about the readings every class so it's super chill and just a good class to get to know other people in the concentration.

course_title: Chocolate, Culture, and the Politics of Food 001
best_comment: This is a PHENOMENAL class and I would highly recommend taking it. Carla is probably the best lecturer I've had at Harvard and she makes every lecture so captivating and entertaining. Sections are also super fun and we get to engage more critically with the readings and participate in meaningful discussions. Of course, getting to taste chocolate most weeks is also a huge plus (especially when they are so delicious)! The exams are very reasonable and the teaching staff goes out of their way to make sure that we are prepared. The projects were also super interesting and allowed us to delve into a topic of our choice. Overall, the class is so well executed and I was so impressed with the team. TAKE IT!!
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! Truly a gem, but genuinely an interesting and worthwhile course. I had never taken a class related to chocolate before, or even thought to much about chocolate and its history (like most people), but this course changed the way I'll go about consuming chocolate. Definitely engage with the course readings if you can! Professor Martin is so amazing and knowledgeable. One regret I do have is not attending her office hours. This course is a great fifth class, and you'll love the lectures (most days)! We also get to try chocolates in class some days!

best_comment: if you are an undergraduate, go to section its super helpful and you learn so much and you really get the chance to speak your mind and explore why you think the way that you do
if you are an undergraduate, go to section its super helpful and you learn so much and you really get the chance to speak your mind and explore why you think the way that you do

course_title: Tobacco and Sugar, Seminar in Caribbean Counterpoints 001
best_comment: I would emphasize that this class has very unique class structure. It is all about having every person in the class share one idea, one question, one reflection repeatedly throughout the seminar –– but without ever exchanging ideas or thoughts between each other. This means everyone will always participate multiple times –– which holds you accountable, in part, to the extremely long and difficult readings (sometimes running up to 100 pages of Spanish literature a week) –– but there is never any actual dialogue or conversation (because it is just going around sharing one thing per person), so the analysis is irritatingly minimal. Be prepared to spend at least 30 minutes total every class going around the room reflecting on what it was like to hear your classmates ask questions about the text, or what it was like to share a connection with the text with your peers. Doris will also not really lecture about any of the works; the emphasis is just hearing how your peers reacted to it for two hours each week.

There was very limited information about this class going into it so I didn't fully know what to expect. Overall, I really enjoyed this class and am glad that I took it. The class is focused on how racial hierarchies are created and perpetuated through art. It will expose you to dark truths that America often tries to ignore. I loved the lessons on art and indigenous Americans and art and the Japanese intonement and wish that there was more time spent focusing on this throughout the course. I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in the African American experience and race studies through an art history lens. Sometimes I felt the course was a little repetitive however Professor Lewis is a very caring lecturer who really takes the time to understand her students. I really appreciated how each class began with time sharing what we were grateful for that week. There was a lot of flexibility in the final project which was great for exploring.

This is a wonderful class that anyone can and should take who wants to learn more about or engage more deeply with Black feminist theory. Professor Perry is lovely and so is Imani. The mix of undergraduates and graduate students expands class perspectives and has a unique way of enriching discussions. The assignments allow you to reflect deeply on course themes without feeling burdensome. This class was truly always the highlight of my week.

course_title: African American Fraternal Associations in U.S. Society and Politics 001
best_comment: This is a great course, especially if you like to combine historical context with US political structures/systems. You have to be willing to challenge yourself and be innovative, ask a lot of questions as this is a still developing field. But Prof. Skocpol is extremely interested in this work and is super enthusiastic about it. If you show enthusiasm and curiosity, you will really get a lot out of this course.  But as Prof. Skocpol says, “this is not a gut.” She expects you to come into class with discussion questions and having done the reading.  So only take this class if you are willing to put in the effort and engage in lively discussion every week.

This is a fantastic primer on the history of the U.S. health care system. You'll learn about a variety of topics, mostly in chronological order: the early roots of the health and welfare system in widows' benefits and veterans pensions, the development of Social Security, the birth of Medicare and Medicaid, and the unfolding of the delegated/privatized state in the post–1960s era. George is a fantastic guide: he is unique in his attention to detail, and truly wants each student to leave the course a better writer and historical thinker than they entered it. He is also passionate and not afraid to offer his opinion on historical change in the health care system –– which I found refreshing. This class never bores. Take it!

course_title: W.E.B. Du Bois and His Critics 001
best_comment: No one should graduate from Harvard without taking a class from Professor Gates. It doesn't matter what class he is teaching––on W.E.B. Du Bois, on African–American literature, on underwater basket weaving––take it! He changed my life for the better, and he will do the same for you. He is an exceptionally insightful and creative mind who will teach you to think deeply and critically. He has a gift for making everyone feel welcome, accepted, and free to speak their minds, even on uncomfortable topics such as racism. Most important, Professor Gates is a person of extraordinary kindness, compassion, and generosity. I have seen many examples of his showing such grace to his students and staff. In our divisive world today, we need more people like Professor Gates. Taking a class from him is the first step!
worse_comment: Du Bois is a man whose ability to tell a story through his writing is profound.  Take the time to learn your own knee jerk reactions to his thoughts and see if they change throughout the semester.

course_title: Religion, Culture, and Society in Africa 001
best_comment: This was for sure one of my favorite classes I have ever taken at Harvard. I am a graduating senior who took this for an elective and I was genuinely not disappointed. For undergrads I would say for sure this is a class worth taking if you have any interest at all in African religion or just religion in general. Olupona is super interesting and has stories for days about how over the years he has directly interacted with the course material. I also think the course assignments are very doable and provide interesting opportunities to dig a little deeper into whatever interests you. They are quite open ended generally so maybe if you are someone that needs extreme guidance in your work then maybe you might find it challenging – but generally it does give you the freedom to write about what is interesting to you. Be warned there is a 20 page paper final so... do with that what you may.

course_title: African American Lives in the Law 001
best_comment: really amazing class! I learned a ton! Great for people thinking about entering a career in law.

course_title: Storied Lives: Methods in Oral History 001
best_comment: Take it! It's beautiful. A strong emphasis on method with rich thought–provoking readings and a professor who is thoughtful, warm, capable, and invested in your well–being. You won't be disappointed.
worse_comment: This course is incredible, it offered practical tools while pushing my critical and theoretical thinking. I highly recommend it especially for working with stories which are often missing from formal archives.

best_comment: Absolutely the best language class I’ve ever taken. It completely flips the traditional model of memorizing useless essays and rigid grammar rules, instead prioritizing real communication (ie what language is actually for). The environment is supportive, and the small class size makes a huge difference. Adriaan is brilliant at keeping lessons active and engaging without being overly strict. I couldn’t recommend a class more highly! Baie dankie!

Take this class! The professor is amazing and very supportive of students who are interested in learning Igbo. The theatre presentations were super fun as our class got to prepare a short skit for other classes and professors in the African Languages Department. Exams were very reasonable and homework assignments were very manageable. If you are at all interested in getting more immersed in the Igbo culture and language, then there is more than enough room for Igbo AB to fit in your course schedule.
This class is a good way to fulfill your language requirement. Professor Mugane is super nice. Sometimes the class can be a little disorganized.

As a non–native Swahili speaker, I was nervous about taking this class at first and about whether my foundational knowledge from the beginner and intermediate classes would be enough, but I greatly enjoyed it and learned so much! I highly recommend!
GREAT CLASS! Such a gem! The professor is great. As a Yoruba, my fluency in Yoruba increased.
best_gem_comment: GREAT CLASS! Such a gem! The professor is great. As a Yoruba, my fluency in Yoruba increased.

best_comment: This class is amazing! If you are looking to fulfill your language requirement with an amazing prof and fun classroom setting this is for you!!! I learned so much and LOVE Ntuli and Witness they are amazing teachers and truly care so much about their students :)

Mala and Myriam were great instructor and teaching fellow! Both are very kind and willing to explain concepts and ideas and elaborate when needed. The class allowed for great discussion and in–depth understanding since the lectures reviewed everything that is read and group work helps reveal areas of confusion. I loved the module assignments that allowed for creative expression and a break from more common rigid assignments like papers. Pushing you to think outside the box about something relevant to class topics with a partner was a fun challenge.
worse_comment: Take the module projects seriously, they do require a decent amount of theory and elaboration! You get as much as you give from this course!

course_title: Junior Tutorial for Thesis Writers in Anthropology 001
best_comment: I had an AMAZING TF, and I was lucky. Regardless of your TF, this class it truly what you make of it. If you're doing multiple readings a week and using assignments well, you'll be prepared for your prospectus. I would use the 4 assignments to scaffold to your prospectus (ex. #1 for me was a roundup of my sources from the first chunk of the semester, #3 was a draft of the prospectus lit review). Damina, Andrew, and Alex are key supports –– use them. And go to Andrew's workshops!

course_title: Thesis Tutorial in Anthropology - Senior Year 001
best_comment: If you are writing a thesis, I definitely recommend this course. The instructors are helpful and want you to succeed. Every assignment also works towards the goal of completing your thesis. There is no unnecessary busy work.

Take this course! Professor Warinner is a great lecturer and a great person. I genuinely learned so much from this class. Every lecture was very interesting, and I feel that I walked away from each class with a better understanding of the scientific method, archaeology, and the relationship between biology, chemistry, history, and anthropology. The midterm and the final (where they would give you an example of an archaeological site and you would have to write about methods to analyze it) were also very fair and honestly kind of fun to complete. Also, shoutout to Percy for being a such a kind and knowledgeable TF

This is a great class for someone hoping to explore archaeology and participate in interesting discussions about the organization of the discipline, the field of landscape archaeology, and the role of archaeology in society. The readings are interesting, though there are many, and the professor is very enthusiastic and fun.

I think this was an excellent class with two really knowledgeable and kind professors. The topic was so interesting, and while it's about the deep past, I think it's incredibly relevant for people to understand. There wasn't a lot of work outside the two exams and the final paper, which was nice. You do have to use Perusal, but it honestly didn't bother me much. I think it makes you engage more with the content of the readings and you get to hear what your classmates think. Most people in the class were very engaged with the topic and we had some great discussions. There were a few issues with the exams, but I don't think this will be the case for future versions of this class. I highly recommend it!

I think this was an excellent class with two really knowledgeable and kind professors. The topic was so interesting, and while it's about the deep past, I think it's incredibly relevant for people to understand. There wasn't a lot of work outside the two exams and the final paper, which was nice. You do have to use Perusal, but it honestly didn't bother me much. I think it makes you engage more with the content of the readings and you get to hear what your classmates think. Most people in the class were very engaged with the topic and we had some great discussions. There were a few issues with the exams, but I don't think this will be the case for future versions of this class. I highly recommend it!

course_title: Challenging Collections: Critical Reflections on Collecting Through Harvard’s History 001
best_comment: Definitely take this course, Diana is an amazing professor and you will learn so much about about the history of Harvard, as well as its institutional identity!

course_title: The Anthropology of Power: Sovereignty, Hegemony, Resistance 001
best_comment: It's such a shame that this class won't be taught again because it was truly so enriching and enjoyable. I've taken many Political Theory/Social Theory/Social Science classes, and this one was by far one of the most thought–provoking and useful ones. I feel like I really got to gain a deeper understanding of foundational texts I had read in other classes before, and got to learn so much more through the readings on the syllabus and Prof. Fierman's explanations. The syllabus for this class is excellent, and you will truly enjoy doing the readings/wish you could spend more time with them. Additionally, Julia Fierman is an incredibly kind, bright, and engaging instructor. She's great at commanding the classroom while staying open, warm, and on an eye–to–eye level with her students. In each class, she gave a mini lecture about the readings before starting our classroom discussion, which were incredibly helpful and easy to follow. The reading assignments were very useful for getting a closer understanding of some texts and took just the right amount of time.

This course was a great introduction to disability studies and anthropology of the body. Through the readings, you will learn different theoretical frameworks surrounding disability as well as lived experiences. Discussions were very thought–provoking and helped me think about disability through various perspectives. Dr. Az really cares about her students, is highly receptive to student feedback, and provides useful support and feedback.  I would highly recommend this class!

course_title: What Is Latin America? Politics, Culture, Identity 001
best_comment: One of my favorite courses at Harvard. The class was challenging –– not in the sense of busy work –– but rather relatively easy assignments with material that took a long time to understand, but nevertheless incredibly rewarding. I could not recommend this class more. Professor Fierman is awesome.
worse_comment: Every class I have ever taken with Professor Fierman has been a joy and absolutely life changing. I am so sad that she will be leaving Harvard, but if she ever returns any class she teaches is a must–take!!

course_title: Introduction to Social Medicine: Theory, Methods, Applications 001
best_comment: Take anything Marty teaches! Prof. Zeve (Marty) and TF Taylor are incredibly welcoming and dedicated to helping you learn and bring their unique perspectives working in global health to the table. This was an extremely well–balanced class (intended to be very high praise), all credit for which goes to Marty and Taylor This was a fascinating class that managed to successfully walk a very fine line between breadth and depth on such a broad subject. A lot of credit here to the teaching team –– the class was originally supposed to be a small seminar–style class, but then they had to adapt when 50 people registered.  Having listened to student feedback, they split the class in two each week with each of them alternating which half of the class they would lead in the original seminar discussion.In another example of the good balances the class struck, the readings generally skewed academic, but the assignments allowed you to go out into the real world and apply what we learned in class –– those who were interested could do an ethnography and an art project in lieu of traditional academic papers.I know Marty is an HMS professor, but I really hope she comes back for another course –– and I would be the first in line to sign up! She is an amazing professor and really cares very deeply for her students/To whichever gods read this: give Marty tenure!!!
best_gem_comment: The 9 am – 11 am was a bit rough on Mondays but the class was super interesting and a bit of a gem.

best_comment: Arthur Kleinman's last class at Harvard was truly a memorable one for me. The people he brought in every week to talk about their experience with medical anthropology were all extremely interesting, and he was an engaging interviewer and occasional lecturer. The readings were all great, and they all had nuanced and interesting views on various topics in and out of the field of medical anthropology. The section component was so interesting and facilitated some interesting discussion in the class, and I met some amazing people through this class!

course_title: The Everyday: Ethnographic Visions and Representations 001
best_comment: DEFINITELY TAKE THIS CLASS! ANTHRO 1853 is an amazing class, and Damina is an great professor. She is very supportive of her students, very kind, and accessible outside of class. Whether you are an anthropology concentrator or who is interested in learning more about anthropology or ethnographic writing, I would highly highly highly recommend taking this class. I feel like I learned a lot about the anthropology of the everyday, especially thinking about different aspects of it such as space and time, and learned a lot about ethnographic writing. The student–led presentations were great, and I also really enjoyed the ethnographic fieldwork notebook where we would practice ethnographic writing with the prompts Damina would give us. It is a great class, so I could not recommend it enough!

course_title: Ethnographies of Cities and the Urban 001
best_comment: I really recommend this class to students who are interested in urban studies or anthropology. This class was many of my peers' first anthropology class, and it was a really good introduction to what the department offers. It is clear that Professor Tamburo has a passion for teaching anthropology and has mastered the art of leading productive discussions. I would recommend any class by Professor Tamburo, especially those new to the field.

course_title: Anthropology and the Geopolitical: China and Africa entanglements in ethnographic perspective 001
best_comment: This is a great class to take. Afro–China is a topic consistently misunderstood in the media and even in a lot of the scholarship. This is a course that will truly update your view on the topic. The course is a survey of Afro–China literature, and you really do get a great sense with critical and nuanced perspectives. Dr. Tamburo is a great instructor. I'm not entirely sure if she will be here again, but if you ever encounter her, you should take a class with her or just chat. She is very well–versed in the topic of China and Afro–China, with a particular focus on real estate, urban space, construction, and infrastructure. She structures the classroom so that students can speak more without losing sight of what's important in the discussions. She makes herself available to students, even though she's incredibly busy with her own writing. I wish we had met more times to chat. The book review is nothing complicated and straightforward. Dr. Tamburo guides you through how to write a proper book review. The final paper is a little tricky, since it's an anthropological paper that you need to write without going to the field, quite counter–intuitive at times because you'd usually make arguments based on ethnographic evidence. For people who are using this paper as a pre–fieldwork paper, it might be a bit of a struggle if the topic of your research is not a heavily researched topic. I'd have really appreciated it if we could have the choice between a precis+lit review and an argumentative paper.  All being said, Dr. Tamburo is avail herself to chat about the paper – you should definitely go chat with her if you're feeling confused or stuck about it. She is a great source of help.

Biella's syllabus was very interesting and well–put, and it's an interesting class overall with class discussions and a final that allows you to engage with some course texts to write about a topic of your interest.

course_title: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001
best_comment: 209b is really fantastic, and the topics we discuss feel very relevant and current. I had mixed feelings about 209a, but I really enjoyed 209b. I'd say that while the general workload of the homework is roughly the same in 209b as in 209a, I found the homework in 209b to be more interesting and enjoyable to complete. I believe that 209a and 209b truly built the foundation for the SM in Data Science program, and I'm glad I took both. Pavlos, Chris, and Nitesh are all fantastic instructors, and I am grateful that I had the opportunity to learn from them.
worse_comment: You can learn a lot from the class but the experience is not easy.

course_title: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001
best_comment: 209b is really fantastic, and the topics we discuss feel very relevant and current. I had mixed feelings about 209a, but I really enjoyed 209b. I'd say that while the general workload of the homework is roughly the same in 209b as in 209a, I found the homework in 209b to be more interesting and enjoyable to complete. I believe that 209a and 209b truly built the foundation for the SM in Data Science program, and I'm glad I took both. Pavlos, Chris, and Nitesh are all fantastic instructors, and I am grateful that I had the opportunity to learn from them.
worse_comment: You can learn a lot from the class but the experience is not easy.

course_title: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001

I'd say that while the general workload of the homework is roughly the same in 209b as in 209a, I found the homework in 209b to be more interesting and enjoyable to complete. I believe that 209a and 209b truly built the foundation for the SM in Data Science program, and I'm glad I took both. Pavlos, Chris, and Nitesh are all fantastic instructors, and I am grateful that I had the opportunity to learn from them.
worse_comment: You can learn a lot from the class but the experience is not easy.

best_comment: *** Great class. Professor Smith and Garfinkel genuinely care for you to succeed as data scientists. You will write about 2 small papers (2 pages and then 5 pages if I recall correctly) at the beginning and the end of the course and a poster at the end of the year, in which you essentially predict the future of data science based on recent events in the news submitted by peers throughout the semester (one of the papers also shares this prompt).  You will make comments on readings before class, but these are quite manageable and do not take up much of your time. I did most of these a few hours before class and did fine.As for the majority of your assignments, the class is half split between individual and group work. The individual work is mostly writing participation reports, in which you write 2 page explanations on 3 ways you participated in class. These can be as simple as answering the professor’s questions or making comment threads on the reading assignments. Some miscellaneous tasks include getting a certification in ethics of human research, discussing ethics sections in technical papers, and creating a comic strip (these can be AI generated, if that gives you an indicator of the difficulty of the class).The rest of the work is group work. I’d assume this class’s course content changes from year from year to reflect the changing landscape of the field of data science, but this should serve as a good survey of what you might expect. We worked on implementing and showcasing differential privacy via Python (very surface level, so don’t worry if you’re not good with stats or math), image recognition projects, and a deepfake project.All of the Python needed for these assignments can probably be done with CS32 experience. CS109a experience is a definitely enough. CS50 + some individual Python experience works as well.The only issue I have for this class is that sometimes the rubrics/instructions can be vague.  At times, instructions for what was or wasn’t allowed during group work projects were unclear, but this was such a minor setback that was quickly resolved by just asking the professors that it was essentially insignificant.You will pass this class. And in fact, I’d be surprised if anyone got lower than a B–. Most people probably ended up with A or A–. If you put in just a tiny bit of work, you will do just fine. Again, these professors are awesome at what they do and I am so grateful to have taken a class like this as an undergrad. One of the best classes I’ve taken at Harvard.

course_title: Computational Science and Engineering Capstone Project 001
best_comment: This class has so much potential, and I was so excited to take it. Unfortunately, as it is being currently run under Weiwei, it will be a massive, massive disappointment unless something changes. A few years ago, the projects in this class would be exciting and from a number of different partners, including companies like Microsoft. This semester, unfortunately, almost every single project was healthcare related, because that is Weiwei's work.  It was quite clear that many of these partners had no interest in the class, and simply did not care about the projects. Many project teams that I spoke to did not receive data and necessary information from the partners until almost the end of the semester; this was also true for my team's project. There was a general sense of complete disengagement from the partners. The class was also poorly organized – there was hardly any context about assignments, and TFs / project mentors themselves did not know anything about the assignments and deadlines. We were supposed to have presentations and exciting guest lectures from industry partners, but not even a single one ever happened. Weiwei is also just so unresponsive – she simply didn't show up to our group's meetings  twice (and didn't even tell us that she wouldn't be coming). There was simply no communication about most things – we were not even told about the exact timings and details of the poster session until the day of the session. Ironically enough, Weiwei and the TFs did not even show up to our poster session – we stood there for 3 hours presenting to random people passing by. In our weekly check–ins with her, it was clear that Weiwei had no idea what our project was about and where it was headed, which meant that we never got any concrete advice or sense of direction from her. I know, of course, that the capstone is meant to be a class where you own a lot of the decisions regarding the project and are expected to do things independently. But the problem was that we had a completely unresponsive partner and a completely unresponsive instructor in Weiwei, who simply didn't do anything. Not to mention that we didn't even have data to work with for most of the semester. Overall, I think that this class under Weiwei is a complete mess. The CSE department really needs to figure this stuff out and make sure that this doesn't happen in the future. MIT has a similar capstone project, and I've heard from their students that that class is one of the highlights of their MIT experience. It is a shame that the Harvard version is anything but that. To be fair to Weiwei, she is extremely smart and a wonderful lecturer. And I'm sure that she is also really busy with other things. But that doesn't mean that the capstone project (which is described as a 'mini thesis' for our program) can be relegated to being an afterthought by the instructor. I really hope that the department finds a way to make this course better.
worse_comment: Be prepared to be confused about the deliverables and requirements

best_comment: A solid AM concentrator course!! If you're an AM concentrator and you're looking for a class where you can learn without being overworked and stressed out with incredibly hard PSETs and exams, this class is for you. Each week there's a PSET/lab, which is can be time–consuming but the problems themselves aren't terribly hard IF you have experience with python. This class says no coding experience is required, but I think they aren't revealing how dependent the work in the class is with coding. I was appreciative of my experience with Python (cs32). Not that you'll fail without it, but you'd likely need to go to office hours, the optional Friday sections, and consult online sources, so this class might not be as stress–free then. But the class meets 2x a week, and attendance is only mandatory everytime for the presentation and lab days, and some random time when he takes attendance during lecture days. However, after the first month of class, you truly don't know when attendance will be taken (even during "mandatory" days). I skipped a lecture class one day to study for an exam, and he happened to take attendance that day, so my grade when down. This was late March, and it was the last time he took attendance. So in total he took attendance 10x for the semester, and even though I didn't miss a class after that, my attendance grade was still a 90. Not to say he was wrong for that, but just to say, be careful because attendance it isn't very routine.As far as the material, this class was a cool intro to AM, but I wish the classes were more rooted in the code since the PSETs and Lab were so reliant on it. The small taste of the conceptual parts of different AM topics were hard to follow at times. But that's no reason not to take this class! You totally should! You'll likely get a good grade and learn some cool applications, so I def recommend for AM concentrators!
worse_comment: Lectures for this class are not very engaging, I won't lie. I found myself easily checking emails + doing other class work instead. However, I just ended up with a bad feeling that I didn't learn as much as I could and I wouldn't recommend that. Maybe try your very best to stay engaged, though its HARD to do so because its so BORING at times. It's somewhat like CS50 in the sense that its just a lot thrown at you and you aren't supposed to retain every bit of it (hence no final) but that just made me feel bad.

best_comment: I loved this course but make no mistake –– it is not a gem and will require time/effort. The problem sets are long, the content could be challenging, but that being said, I came in with an interest in differential equations and that interest was certainly satisfied. There is A LOT of content covered in this course and it is a grind but I would also say it was really rewarding. Additionally, this course is hard but the teaching staff is awesome and makes it super rewarding. Margo and the teaching staff are INCREDIBLE, which is extremely rare to come by and ultimately why I would recommend this course to AM majors. Margo LISTENS to her students (she doesn't have this attitude like "I taught it you should know it immediately"). She always stops after covering concepts to get a vibe check on how the class feels about a certain topic and if she needs to go more in depth. She also genuinely cares a lot about her students and wants them to succeed. Midway through the course I was struggling quite a bit but I met with Margo and she calmed me down a ton. As in any course, some lectures are more dry than others and sometimes it's hard to get yourself to class but seeing Margo made me excited and motivated to go everyday. The teaching staff will differ every year but this year they were AWESOME. I used the Ed stem a lot, asking a bunch of questions about the homework, midterms, etc., and they were always answered in a timely manner by a TF or Margo.Overall, while this course was a grind I would certainly recommend it for anyone who is interested in math, willing to commit some time, and seeks a rewarding experience taught by awesome staff.
worse_comment: Simply put, this course is not structured in a way that values students' time. The problem sets are outrageously long (my last problem set submission was 35 pages long) and not particularly challenging, taking longer to typeset appropriately than to solve. The grading is harsh, and the TFs look for any reason to take off credit on problems as opposed to any reason to give you credit like they do in other class. The problem sets after the horrible slog are just 15% of your grade which is enough that you have to do them but not enough that it really matters that you do well on them. Please get rid of the completion problems, quite frankly they're a waste of time for everyone and the flood of them makes the problem sets take 15–20 hours to do and write up. Also student choice being a second problem set every other week simply feels like more busywork in a class that's already long hours with little substance. 9am three days a week seems to suit no one except for Margo, and this combined with the occasional unsolvable integral on the midterm gives us the impression as students that the teaching staff don't think about us much at all.

best_comment: This class is excellent. It is rather proof heavy for an AM class, but this is definitely a great strength of the course. The concepts and tools we spend the semester building come together in an intensely satisfying and very beautiful way by the end, and your computational skills improve dramatically along the way. As long as you have a good understanding of linear algebra and at least a little exposure to / interest in proofs, you will be more than prepared for this class.Outside of the content we learn, Professor Seigal is truly amazing. She memorized everyone's names by the second day of class, and did an excellent job making the class interactive and fun. She does her best to welcome and answer questions both in class and at office hours. It is clear she really cares about her students.Even being the first iteration of this class, it was an incredible experience and will surely be even better next time around. Definitely take this!
worse_comment: It is difficult material conceptually but the work itself is manageable. 1 pset every other week, quizzes every other week, no midterms

best_comment: Great AM course. The kind of math that made us fall in love with the subject. The problems are fun and challenging with applicability to real world problems. I became a better math student able to problem solve and think creatively, as well as the skills and knowledge inherent to this course.
worse_comment: This course is great. There are two midterms and no final exam. There is usually around 9 problem sets. While the problem sets and midterms are very difficult because of the quantity you have more time to spend learning. The first midterm is on the first half of the course. The second midterm is on the second half of the course. This structure allows you to focus on individual topics without getting too overwhelmed. Personally I concentrate in computer science and to this course as a part of the formal reasoning to replace CS124. Much more manageable option if you’re not shooting for honors.

best_comment: This course is quite fascinating in terms of content, but stay on top of the workload, especially near the end. Also, to the best of your ability, choose a project topic that is personally interesting to you, as you will put a lot of work into it.

Take this course! Great way to satisfy your honors requirement, and Prof. Kuang is so amazing: he gives reassuring Dad in the best way possible! Do note that there are quite a few assignments – more so than I had anticipated, but they're all easily done with a good group (would recommend taking the class with at least 2–3 other people you know you'd work well together) and some of them are optional / count for extra credit. There are 3 major projects, two of which are group–based (with the same group) and the last is individual. In the moment, they were a little stressful, but it's actually really fun to create these modeling projects and take ownership over a small research study that you apply the concepts learned in class to. I definitely spent a reasonable amount of time on this class each week (around 7 hours, more or less depending on the week), especially for an APMTH class.

course_title: Applied Linear Algebra and Big Data 001
best_comment: AM 120 is one of the best math classes I have taken at Harvard. If you liked 21b, you will definitely also like this class (although 21b is a more conventional pure math class whereas AM 120 is heavy with applications as the name suggests). Eli is an awesome instructor—he's funny, he explains concepts well, his textbook is very thorough, and he is fair with the exams he writes. The problem sets can definitely take some time (especially with some of the hand calculations), but I never found the problem sets to be useless or tedious. I always walked away with a better understanding of the material because of the questions that were asked. This course contains some of the most useful applications of linear algebra (dimensionality reduction, unsupervised learning, supervised learning etc.) that are relevant to pretty much any focus field, so it's definitely worth taking whether you're an AM concentrator or not. Overall, this is definitely a class I would recommend to anyone who has the relevant preparations and certainly to any AM students. Work hard, learn a lot, and I hope you enjoy it as much as I did!
worse_comment: take it if you have the time in your schedule.. not easy though had me on the bathroom floor crying because everyone said it was easy but i was struggling

best_comment: Somewhat disorganized with Prof. Brenner. The course notes are good but incomplete, and the lectures are basically a repeat of the notes.  The material is pretty interesting, and the psets do help reinforce the material – I did learn a lot of cool techniques. James is an excellent TF, though, and with him as lecturer the class will probably be great.
worse_comment: If Michael Brenner is teaching the class: Don't take it if you don't have to.  Lectures are disorganized and unprepared, homework is sparse and focuses more on helping the professor with his personal research project than helping you learn, section is useless, and the TAs can't provide help on the homework when you need it.  If you really have to take it for your degree and Michael Brenner is teaching it:  Don't go to lecture and read the lecture notes and Bender & Orzag — you'll learn a lot more that way.

best_comment: Take this course if you can. The content is rewarding in a low–stakes environment. The final project is not something that feels so heavy since there are softer homework loads. Interact with the papers, as it helps people like undergrads transition from one–stop textbook learning to the graduate/professional sense of info gathering through papers and self–practice in code. This is a good class to mature in theoretical machine learning, and the offering is one that matches your enthusiasm and commitment. You can gain the world of knowledge from Melanie if you lock in, or you can complete the requirements and learn the standard amount. Definitely show up to class often and watch both Melanie and fellow students present. You learn something recent and relevant every single day.

230 has some really interesting material and could be enjoyed by somebody who puts the time in. Lectures are three hours long on fridays and are entirely chalk talks with some pretty in depth derivations. Problem sets are very bashy but sometimes interesting and are always quite long. Final projects are fun.
worse_comment: The goal of active matter is to find emergent behavior in systems with external energy input, kind of like temperature as an emergent property of quantum mechanical systems with lots of particles. The interesting part is how you handle external energy inputs, which takes the problem away from traditional stat mech and leads to interesting SDEs, fluid mechanics, and high (4th, often) order nonlinear PDEs. The problem sets are essentially linear stability analysis over and over on different biologically–relevant systems, which can be tedious but worth doing if your research is on these higher order equations. You get out of this course what you put in; you might learn some rote mathematics if you only do problem sets, but the lectures are necessary to really understand why the problems matter.

course_title: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part II 001
best_comment: APPHY 50B COURSE EVALUATION:As a student that has completed the full AP50 series, I have several thoughts on the course.First, for context, the structure of the class includes the following weekly assignments, as listed below:• Sunday by 11:59 PM – Reading Assessment: you read about 20–30 pages in the textbook and leave about ~10 comments to ‘stimulate conversation’ with your peers• Sunday by 11:59 PM – Readiness Assurance (Individual): you complete around 10–20 practice questions individually based on the topics you learned from reading• Tuesday by 9 AM – Tutorial (Individual): you complete an application–based assignment on Desmos consisting of about 20–30 slides on the weekly topics you learned from reading• Tuesday IN CLASS – Tutorial (Team): you review over the Desmos tutorial assignment with your team and complete check–ins with the teaching staff + correct your answers – ONLY THIS ROUND IS GRADED• Tuesday by 6 PM – Readiness Assurance (Team Round): you re–visit the Readiness Assurance from Sunday with your team and re–submit what you think is correct – ONLY THIS ROUND IS GRADED• Thursday by 9 AM – Challenge (Individual): you complete a 3 question problem set individually before class and submit to Gradescope• Thursday IN CLASS – Challenge (Team): you review over your challenge with your team and complete check–ins with the teaching staff + correct your answers – ONLY THIS ROUND IS GRADED• Thursday IN CLASS – Skill Session: you take your newly learned concepts from the week and put it into practice by completing different activities + a short Canvas quiz – ONLY THIS ROUND IS GRADEDAs it relates to grading and work, this class will make you WORK. However, this comes with the benefit that AP 50a/b does NOT contain exams, and only grades you on the TEAM component of assignments. As a result, you have a chance to correct all of your work before submitting it to be evaluated. Additionally, if there are still mistakes, you have the chance to do markups to correct it, ensuring that you perform well in the class.Overall, the reality is that AP50a/b will GUARANTEE you an A if you submit your work on time. The structure is outlined very early in the course, and the requirements are extremely straightforward. However, you must stay on track for all assignment and compete EVERYTHING on time. If you fall behind and either miss ONE assignment or have ONE dissatisfactory grade (and fail to make it up in a reasonable amount of time), it will automatically bump you down a full letter grade. However, as long as you complete all assignments on time and follow the course structure perfectly, there is no way you can go wrong.Notably, the learning atmosphere within AP50b remains one of the course’s biggest weaknesses, especially as it relates to specific members of the teaching team. While a majority of the teaching staff are supportive and work hard to create an encouraging atmosphere, there are very evident exceptions to this. Instead, the actions of some members of the teaching team continue to intimidate and discourage students, leading to the creation of an extremely toxic environment that fails to promote learning. One of the course heads, Robert Haussman, is the most unsupportive individual in the entire class. Although he seems to have a calm and encouraging personality when you first meet him, this is merely a facade. When students ask questions on Slack or in–person, he often responds in the most passive aggressive tone. For example, when a student asked about the progress of grade snapshots (a grade preview that the teaching staff typically provide at multiple time points throughout the semester to keep students on track), he chose to respond that he did not have sufficient time to fulfill this and told the student to go calculate it themselves, as the sheet to do so has “been there all year” long. This highlights his complete disregard of the needs of students and decision to blame students for a shortcoming of his own. Then, during check–ins, his discouraging personality is even more evident, with Robert often staying with groups for 30+ minutes on something that should realistically only take 10–15 minutes maximum. Beyond the questions asked within the assignment, he chooses to ask students follow–up after follow–up. While this would normally be acceptable (especially if used to try and further student understanding), he often becomes extremely disapproving and notably disgruntled when students have the smallest ounce of confusion. Having an instructor like this not only FAILS to create a helpful environment that facilitates student engagement and learning, but also TURNS STUDENTS AWAY from asking for help when they need it. Looking forward, this is an area that needs significant improvement, or AP50 will continue failing to meet the needs of its students. Unfortunately, this issue also persists with some of the course TFs. One TF in particular, Ri Dresser, is very similar to Robert and also leads to the creation of an unsupportive and toxic atmosphere in class. As one of the TFs that regularly does check–ins, they are known throughout the class as being one of the harshest graders, often giving VERY low scores to students for making simple mistakes. For context, check–ins are graded between 0–3, with 0 indicating no effort (or not completing the assignment), 1 indicating minimal effort, 2 indicating satisfactory work and effort (even if some of the work is wrong), and 3 indicating work that extends beyond the expectations of the class. With this in mind, 2 is the “normal” score that students should expect to receive as long as they present their work in a reasonable manner. However, Ri has a tendency to give VERY low scores, ranging from 1.3 to 0.8 to even 0.5, despite there being no valid reason for doing so. In fact, there are days where Ri was shown to give consecutive “failing” scores ranging between 0.5–0.8 to SEVERAL groups back to back, being the ONLY TF to do so. Beyond just the grading, Ri is also very unapproachable due to their attitude. In class, Ri oftentimes grips their head in agony and sighs loudly when students indicate confusion. In effect, this makes students extremely uncomfortable and creates an environment that appears to punish making mistakes (or being unsure about something), as opposed to encouraging learning and individual growth. Similar to the note above about Robert, the fact that members of the teaching staff act in this manner completely TURNS AWAY students from being passionate and wanting to learn physics. Instead, all it causes is students purposely trying to avoid these members of the teaching staff, knowing that asking them for help will only lead to further judgement and frustration. Despite my aforementioned complaints about AP50b, credit is due where credit is deserved – the saving grace for this course and silver lining amidst tons of issues is Kelly Miller, one of the new course heads. This semester, Kelly was introduced as one of the new instructors and began taking over the AP50 series. She will also be the primary course head going forward for both AP50a/b. As an instructor, Kelly is one of the most SUPPORTIVE individuals I have ever met, oftentimes trying to uplift students and encourage them to continue achieving higher. When students have questions, she acknowledges their needs and works to improve their understanding with compassion. As students bring up points of frustration with the class, she remains extremely receptive (and RESPONSIVE) to feedback, piloting new initiatives to try and fix the weak points of the course. Lastly, Kelly is just extremely positive – always seeming genuinely PASSIONATE about the course and as if she wants to see her students thrive. Knowing that Kelly will be permanently taking over the course gives me hope that AP50 will change going forward, with the intent of better supporting the needs of students. As a whole, Kelly should be seen as a role model to AP50 teaching staff on what a genuinely outstanding instructor looks like!Similarly positive things can also be said about the following TFs, who have gone above and beyond to make the class an enjoyable and learning class environment: Tayna Camargo, Alex Buzali, Soy Choy, and Anna Luong. Thank you to each of these amazing individuals for making AP50b more tolerable, and a better learning environment (despite the aforementioned flaws).With this in mind, I think AP50a/b is a great option if you are looking to ensure a good grade in physics and can accept the faults of the course. However, go in with a realistic expectation on the time needed to complete assignments, and an understanding on some of the weak points of the course overall. To any student choosing between PS 2/3 and AP 50a/b, good luck – I wish you the best of luck. Physics is a lot regardless of which course you choose, but work hard and you will get through it.
worse_comment: Be very careful taking this class. if you are a person who is not good with deadlines or a person who THINKS they are good at deadlines, think very critically about enrolling. I thought I was good at deadlines but realized that was for normal classes with normal types of deadlines and workflow. This class is insane and something is due EVERY SINGLE DAY. If you miss one thing you are at risk of your grade dropping an entire letter grade. The teaching staff does not teach nor provide any sort of teaching, guidance, or advice going into the various modules. They are also overly strict about meeting specifications in order to receive a particular grade.  It is really unfortunate that most students leave this course having learned nothing, being unclear about what they did or why, because there is no guidance from staff. If you actually want to learn physics, please take PS2/3/12 etc. I did not care to actually learn so I took it, but if I wanted to learn things I'd be very disappointed with this class.
