Although he seems to have a calm and encouraging personality when you first meet him, this is merely a facade. When students ask questions on Slack or in–person, he often responds in the most passive aggressive tone. For example, when a student asked about the progress of grade snapshots (a grade preview that the teaching staff typically provide at multiple time points throughout the semester to keep students on track), he chose to respond that he did not have sufficient time to fulfill this and told the student to go calculate it themselves, as the sheet to do so has “been there all year” long. This highlights his complete disregard of the needs of students and decision to blame students for a shortcoming of his own. Then, during check–ins, his discouraging personality is even more evident, with Robert often staying with groups for 30+ minutes on something that should realistically only take 10–15 minutes maximum. Beyond the questions asked within the assignment, he chooses to ask students follow–up after follow–up. While this would normally be acceptable (especially if used to try and further student understanding), he often becomes extremely disapproving and notably disgruntled when students have the smallest ounce of confusion. Having an instructor like this not only FAILS to create a helpful environment that facilitates student engagement and learning, but also TURNS STUDENTS AWAY from asking for help when they need it. Looking forward, this is an area that needs significant improvement, or AP50 will continue failing to meet the needs of its students. Unfortunately, this issue also persists with some of the course TFs. One TF in particular, Ri Dresser, is very similar to Robert and also leads to the creation of an unsupportive and toxic atmosphere in class. As one of the TFs that regularly does check–ins, they are known throughout the class as being one of the harshest graders, often giving VERY low scores to students for making simple mistakes. For context, check–ins are graded between 0–3, with 0 indicating no effort (or not completing the assignment), 1 indicating minimal effort, 2 indicating satisfactory work and effort (even if some of the work is wrong), and 3 indicating work that extends beyond the expectations of the class. With this in mind, 2 is the “normal” score that students should expect to receive as long as they present their work in a reasonable manner. However, Ri has a tendency to give VERY low scores, ranging from 1.3 to 0.8 to even 0.5, despite there being no valid reason for doing so. In fact, there are days where Ri was shown to give consecutive “failing” scores ranging between 0.5–0.8 to SEVERAL groups back to back, being the ONLY TF to do so. Beyond just the grading, Ri is also very unapproachable due to their attitude. In class, Ri oftentimes grips their head in agony and sighs loudly when students indicate confusion. In effect, this makes students extremely uncomfortable and creates an environment that appears to punish making mistakes (or being unsure about something), as opposed to encouraging learning and individual growth. Similar to the note above about Robert, the fact that members of the teaching staff act in this manner completely TURNS AWAY students from being passionate and wanting to learn physics. Instead, all it causes is students purposely trying to avoid these members of the teaching staff, knowing that asking them for help will only lead to further judgement and frustration. Despite my aforementioned complaints about AP50b, credit is due where credit is deserved – the saving grace for this course and silver lining amidst tons of issues is Kelly Miller, one of the new course heads. This semester, Kelly was introduced as one of the new instructors and began taking over the AP50 series. She will also be the primary course head going forward for both AP50a/b. As an instructor, Kelly is one of the most SUPPORTIVE individuals I have ever met, oftentimes trying to uplift students and encourage them to continue achieving higher. When students have questions, she acknowledges their needs and works to improve their understanding with compassion. As students bring up points of frustration with the class, she remains extremely receptive (and RESPONSIVE) to feedback, piloting new initiatives to try and fix the weak points of the course. Lastly, Kelly is just extremely positive – always seeming genuinely PASSIONATE about the course and as if she wants to see her students thrive. Knowing that Kelly will be permanently taking over the course gives me hope that AP50 will change going forward, with the intent of better supporting the needs of students. As a whole, Kelly should be seen as a role model to AP50 teaching staff on what a genuinely outstanding instructor looks like!Similarly positive things can also be said about the following TFs, who have gone above and beyond to make the class an enjoyable and learning class environment: Tayna Camargo, Alex Buzali, Soy Choy, and Anna Luong. Thank you to each of these amazing individuals for making AP50b more tolerable, and a better learning environment (despite the aforementioned flaws).With this in mind, I think AP50a/b is a great option if you are looking to ensure a good grade in physics and can accept the faults of the course. However, go in with a realistic expectation on the time needed to complete assignments, and an understanding on some of the weak points of the course overall. To any student choosing between PS 2/3 and AP 50a/b, good luck – I wish you the best of luck. Physics is a lot regardless of which course you choose, but work hard and you will get through it.
worse_comment: Be very careful taking this class. if you are a person who is not good with deadlines or a person who THINKS they are good at deadlines, think very critically about enrolling. I thought I was good at deadlines but realized that was for normal classes with normal types of deadlines and workflow. This class is insane and something is due EVERY SINGLE DAY. If you miss one thing you are at risk of your grade dropping an entire letter grade. The teaching staff does not teach nor provide any sort of teaching, guidance, or advice going into the various modules. They are also overly strict about meeting specifications in order to receive a particular grade.  It is really unfortunate that most students leave this course having learned nothing, being unclear about what they did or why, because there is no guidance from staff. If you actually want to learn physics, please take PS2/3/12 etc. I did not care to actually learn so I took it, but if I wanted to learn things I'd be very disappointed with this class.

course_title: Introduction to Quantum Materials and Devices 001
best_comment: This is a great class where you learn a lot about many topics in condensed matter. It's especially great if you want to learn more about experimental condensed matter. Professor Westervelt is great and the guest speakers are amazing!

course_title: Quantum and Classical Electromagnetic Interaction with Matter 001
best_comment: Donhee is a great lecturer and this class is super well designed. Homework generally aligns well with what we are learning in lecture and is often a repeat of derivations or calculations covered in class—usually very approachable save a few questions here and there. Definitely recommend having a strong background in quantum mechanics. There’s a lot of mathematical tools and notations (Dirac notation, phasors, etc) that you are assumed to be familiar with.

I highly recommend this class for anyone who wants to learn about state–of–the art qubit platforms. And as compared to 260, this is more relaxed and takes a hardware–focused approach. The workload is quite manageable. You get to learn from a professor who is extremely up–to–date on the field as well as an impressive set of guest lecturers who work on different platforms.The lectures are fast–paced confusing, though because the class tries to cover an immense amount of material, and it doesn't help that Giulia generally doesn't provide lecture notes or any supporting material.

course_title: Research Practices and Academic Culture in Applied Sciences and Engineering 001
best_comment: Definitely take this class, it is super helpful for research!

course_title: Research Practices and Academic Culture in Applied Sciences and Engineering 001
best_comment: Definitely take this class, it is super helpful for research!
Awesome way to learn electron microscopy! The labs are excellent and the final project is a great chance to work on your research.

Great course. Prof. Ham is a great lecturer, it's clear he cares a lot, puts a lot of effort into his presentation of the material. Very relevant to modern condensed matter, covers material at a very comfortable pace –– not too slow or too fast. Was a lot of fun, highly recommend.

This class is great! I really enjoyed learning how screen–printing works, and met all kinds of artists.The class consists of three projects which have little to no guidelines/restrictions. You get to choose yourself what you want to do. This semester we made many normal prints, like just artwork on the wall, but also other crazier stuff like a lamp that hung from the ceiling, a supermarket shelf, many sculptures, and even a huge tree with prints hanging off the branches. You get so much freedom (and support!) to explore whatever you want to do. Just be realistic and don't undertake an insane project that you'll have to rush to finish the day before critique.You learn a lot about silkscreening (obviously), and get to experiment with different techniques like CMYK or mixing colors on the screen itself, but a big part of what I took away from this class was the critique after each project. We all gather around one artwork at a time, hear the student explain their thought process or the meaning behind the piece, and then give our thoughts, compliments, and constructive criticism – what could have been improved, what could be changed to make the piece even better.All–in–all, I recommend this class. Very fun!

(for non AFVS students) Take this class if you can. I am an econ and computer science major but I have always had an artistic itch in my brain that I needed scratched. This class met once a week and the homework was always to prep materials for a painting session next week or finish a painting you weren't able to finish in class. It's very chill and during class we always talked shortly at the start then began getting into painting on our own with earpods in.  Definitely a great break from math and structured academia where you can enjoy creativity, perception, and the other side of you brain (all areas that are rarely touched if you are a hands on econ/CS/math person). I wasn't the only one. One of our best painters was Pre Med Track. Definitely the best and most rewarding way to take a class if you are a creative person and dont want to take a lame ahh gened and write a meaningless 10 paper paper. Atleast here, you actually train an untouched side of your brain, have fun, low stakes/workload, AND have artwork to take home at the end of the semester. I reccomend going to UPS and shipping your paintings buy paying for the fragile packing service (somewhat expensive but worth it if you made paintings you love).

This class is an excellent intro to digital photography. The best thing is that you get a camera for the whole semester and get to just go out in  life and take amazing photos. It's truly such a wonderful freedom. However, this doesn't mean there aren't any parameters for the photos you take––you have to be intentional with what you make, and be prepared to get your ass kicked a little during critiques by peers and your prof. It can feel a bit harsh at times, but take it all in respectfully and attentively, as the feedback you receive is all super useful and does truly make you improve. Also be prepared to be snapping lots of photos a week (144 every two weeks), if that's your thing.

10/10 recommend!! Amazing intro class for learning to use a camera and letting you go in your own creative direction. Sharon and Claude were very supportive, both creatively and technically. While there's an additional 2x a week meet up for digital lab where you work on editing your photos, the photography process itself is really a you get what you put in situation so there's a time flexibility to work with which was really nice during the busier moments of the semester.
worse_comment: I would warn them of the professor's teaching style – so disorganized yet highly passive aggressive and scrutinizing of any student errors, that were usually a reflection of her own disorganization.

course_title: Introduction to Photography: Looking In, Looking Out 1
best_comment: Take this class if you are genuinely interested in learning more about photography as an art, and with purpose. It is a time–consuming class, and requires lots of independent work doing photography during the week, editing the photos, and selecting the best ones, and doing so every week. It has the potential of being incredibly rewarding (which was the case for me, I walk away with strong technical foundations, a greater understanding of this art, and also a keen interest in pursuing my work in the future), but I would not take it if you don't have the time or desire to truly immerse yourself (otherwise it might backfire and make you not like photography). I took it just because I was curious and wanting something different in my schedule, and I walk away with a new hobby and passion that'll last me forever, so I am very grateful, and if that seems to be the case for you, then I would highly highly recommend it. Plus, Richard and Claude are amazing, they are available and helpful, and built a tight–knit class and welcoming learning environment.

Genuinely transformative course. If you go through Harvard AFVS without taking this course you are doing yourself and your education a massive disservice. This is one of those courses that reminds you why you go to Harvard. Teaches you everything about the crazy process of filmmaking. Will be a pretty huge and sometimes unexpected time commitment that sneaks up on you but the work is fulfilling and fun. Everyone in your class will feel like family by the end. Robb, Joana, and Vera are all truly incredibly instructors that will help you grow as artists. This is also a class unlike anything you could take anywhere else in the world, the opportunity to shoot such an insane volume of 16mm film and edit by hand on a Steenbeck is not offered at any film school anywhere. Even if you don't have an interest in documentary filmmaking, please please please apply to take this course, I am mainly interested in fiction and feel that I gained so much from taking this.

TAKE THIS COURSE!!! Without a doubt, this is the best introductory video/filmmaking course I could have asked for. Luis (prof) and Cecilia (TF) are both wonderful instructors and made every class session enjoyable yet educational. I had zero camera experience coming into the course (and to be honest, was uncertain of my interest in film/video), and I now feel so much more prepared, informed, and excited to continue making film/videos!! The class is involved but not stressful (which is a rarity for a studio/practice based course). You learn how to use a camera and how to edit, you receive extensive and useful feedback, you get to show your work and view your peers' work, and you meet/talk to professional filmmakers. Most of all, you come out of the class with a final project you can be proud of. Absolutely take this course with Luis and Cecilia if you get the chance!!

TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!! As a fundamentals/beginners class, you don't need any prior art experience or even need to know how to draw. This class is all about learning from scratch in all sorts of different mediums. Some of them are:– 2D animation (drawn)– sand– clay– puppets– paper on layered glass (very cool)– stop motionJust so so cool. Every week there are exercises (not assignments, and as far as I could tell, not graded) where you learn a new medium. So one class will be dedicated to learned how to use Adobe After Effects, and the exercise that week will be to create a short (maybe 30 second?) long video with some of the stuff you learned. You're not graded on how good the thing you made is, just the fact that you learned how to use anything at all. It's literally the perfect environment for learning because you're encouraged to just mess around.The second–ish half (or maybe last third? time has all muddled up for me now) of the semester is dedicated to the final project. So the first half is working on a specific new tool each week and the second one is mostly self–work. After each week you will have ended up learning a bunch of new techniques and you'll have so many new tools at your disposal, that you can start pitching and idea for a final project. Some people made films that were 2–3 minutes long, and others under a minute. Every single student, with or without prior art experience, made amazing works and I'm so glad to have been able to see them all (and see them being made!)There are weekly screenings every Friday from 12pm–2pm (unless the schedule changes, but it's roughly 2 hours) where we watch a bunch of short animations. Just so so cool. If you can't go, you can make it up by watching them on your own time and submitting your thoughts on each one, but I can't recommend enough to show up in person because 1. you won't have to write anything, and 2. the in–person discussions are just so great.Lastly, the 4–hour long class can seem daunting, but it really does fly by. We take breaks half–way through (I use mine to get lunch lol) and plus it's not 4 hours of intense work, you're mostly sitting around comfortably working on your animation or messing around with puppets or clay.I've learned so much from this class from specific skills to how animation works as a process in general. I feel so much more prepared to animate more in the future, and will be taking the intermediate class too next semester!Ruth is AMAZING, and so is Michael!! They are so kind, patient and knowledgeable and it was just an honor to have been able to learn so much from them. I had a hard time with my final project because I'm a perfectionist, completely overestimated how much I could get done in the time I had AND started way too late (horrible combo), but Ruth and Michael helped me so much throughout the process. They really guided me on how to make my animation better, what to cut, and just generally how to go about it. I seriously cannot recommend enough that you take this class. Even if you're not an AFVS concentrator, you'll have such a fun time taking this as an elective and you'll be able to say you made animations during college lol!ONCE MORE TAKE THIS CLASS IT'S AWESOME !!!!

course_title: Approaching Narrative: Introduction to Fiction Filmmaking 1
best_comment: I think this class can be really intimidating, but I think if you're interested in it, it's worth the time and struggle. My final film was definitely still somewhat rough and there are ways I could improve it, but I was proud of what I made, and I think it's a really cool experience that is hard to get outside of college, so I'd recommend it to anyone even slightly interested.
worse_comment: This is a good course for people who want to make a short film. The work is light at the start of the semester but does get heavier as you get closer to the final. If you don't want to make a film though, you will probably find this course frustrating.

course_title: Sight and Sound: Introduction to Narrative Filmmaking 1
best_comment: This class with Tala Hadid and Madison Howard (TF) is incredible. The mini assignments we have before working on our final films help a lot in developing our understanding of the filmmaking process with low stakes and super helpful feedback. They do a really great job of showing us a variety of films. And they’re super helpful as we work through the process of making our final films. Both Tala and Madison are incredibly kind and passionate about their work. If you’re interested or curious about filmmaking in any capacity (fiction or not) definitely enroll in this course. You learn the basic fundamentals of cinematography, sound, editing, and color correction while also learning how to best execute the story you want to tell. I’d say go into the class having an open mind and some ideas of what film you want to make. The last thing I’ll say is Tala brings incredible directors and producers as guests to speak with the class. If for nothing else, having the opportunity to speak to people who work in the industry full time is pretty awesome especially if that’s what you want to do.

The work outside of class isn't too bad, but it can be a bit boring. If you're really into film and analyzing conceptual films, you'll love this course. If you're more casually interested in film, probably don't take this if you don't need to. The screenings are very long, very late, and required. If you're taking this for AFVS requirements, it's not too bad.

just be prepared for it to be very chill in some aspects and not chill in others. Like creatively its very interesting and exciting, but then randomly there's the anxiety that if you miss a class your grade will tank. Idk, just stuff like that. overall enjoyable and chill, but expect to make your own timelines and deadlines. It's four assignments, but the how, when, where, and why of them is completely up to you. Also, class periods sometimes (NOT ALWAYS!) feel very much like "this could have been an email," so just brace yourself for that.
worse_comment: This course is not meant for seniors and I am disappointed it has not been modified to accommodate seniors. It is not a good use of time for anyone who has already spent multiple years in the AFVS department.

best_comment: Such an amazing course. If you have the opportunity take it. You have to put in the hours in the studio to make it worth it, but if you can you will gain so much out of this class.

It doesn't explicitly say in the course catalogue, but this is primarily an abstraction course, so don't be surprised! Maryam and Julia give great feedback, and this course is a nice chance to experiment with different mediums and a lot of liberty on assignments. It is not a main focus of the course, but there is also a nice discussion component.

Take it––this class is beautiful! Keisha is phenomenal and the course content is lovely. The readings are great––not too much but just enough to help you get a philosophical grounding. Keisha scaffolds but does not micromanage, she sees you and respects you as an emergent maker.You should also really be prepared to think about and invest time in this course––it's best when you can really devote the time to the intentional work it necessitates. Be ready to engage, email Keisha, go to lab a few times and have a real good chat with the TF, and enjoy yourself it's such such fun!

course_title: Ask the Dust: Advanced Studio Class (Photography) 1
Film Direction: From Script to Screen 001
best_comment: You should definitely take this class if you are committed to working with your ideas over the course of the year and learning from what does and doesn't work and forming close relationships with other filmmakers. Hopefully Alice and Kendra will teach it again sometime, they were a great team!!

AFVS is an amazing place. Classes like this where you use physical materials and get instruction from the BEST OF THE BEST, are what make it so. Robb will forever be my favorite professor at this school and one of my favorite people. He makes you feel insane and sane at the same time, makes you feel like you can be a filmmaker. I am forever grateful for the time I had with him.
Best class ever! Amazing break from academics and non–arts classes, made me reflect not just about art but life in general. I took it senior spring and it was a banger
worse_comment: Start thinking about your final project early on because you go from spending no time outside of class to a much more demanding schedule depending on what you choose to do. That might be hard because other classes ramp up as the semester progress too

course_title: Modernization in the Visual United States Environment, 1890-2035 001
best_comment: Honestly I don’t like writing course evals, and this one is essentially useless because Stilgoe is retiring and this is the last course he will teach. That said, I am writing this as a farewell and a thank you. This course was the most enjoyable experience I’ve had so far in my two years at Harvard. Stilgoe is such a brilliant lecturer and sees the world in a way that very few people today do. It was an honor and a pleasure to be in this course. If you see this, I wish you all the best in retirement.
worse_comment: Life changing. Read the handouts and just take in the stories. Don't think too much about what you're learning / talking about in the moment, everything comes together and you leave with a different view on the worls.
best_gem_comment: Professor Stilgoe is a true gem of the academic world. This course was beyond enriching on a personal, professional and all–round level. I am honored to be a student in this class and to take with me a robust mindset that is critical of the things and ways we see in the world.

course_title: The Matrix of the Visible: From Thought to Screen 1
best_comment: Tala is such a lovely professor. She truly went out of her way to help in whatever way she could. She genuinely cares about each individual student and their films.
Happy Retirement, Professor. This class was incredible!
worse_comment: Writing N/A for all as Stilgoe is retiring. Harvard will miss him.

best_comment: This is a very raw class. It's important to be super open–minded. You won't really know what to expect from the guest speakers or films analyzed and I think that's a good thing.

This course is incredible. The profs are so caring and enthusiastic and you will learn so much. I took this course with a background in science/ecology and loved the opportunity to study the environment in a new way. The more you put in (with office hours, time on the creative project), the more you'll get out of the course.

This course is incredible. The profs are so caring and enthusiastic and you will learn so much. I took this course with a background in science/ecology and loved the opportunity to study the environment in a new way. The more you put in (with office hours, time on the creative project), the more you'll get out of the course.

This course provides an amazing framework/accountability system to pursue a large artistic project during the academic semester. The teaching staff is incredibly open and supportive, and the class fosters a great artistic community among peers. If you're someone who would benefit from added accountability and structure in your artistic endeavors, I'd highly recommend taking this.

Take it. I am a humanities person, but this was my favorite class this semester. I was terrified at first, but the content and homework turned out easier than I've expected. If you put in effort, I'm sure you'll easily succeed. Psets might be hard to solve on your own, they aren't necessarily tied to the readings rather to lectures, but our TFs were extremely helpful (SHOUT OUT TO MATTHEW AND ABI WE LOVE YOU SO MUCH) This course's TFs are my favorite people on Earth. Extremely smart, kind and helpful. Overall, after every lecture I felt as if I've learned something new, and now I know a crazy amount of random facts about space (which was the initial goal).

TAKE THIS! One of the best courses I've taken. The class activities were super fun (we played d&d one time) and it goes beyond just talking about extraterrestrial life. I  feel like everyone in the class took something away that they could apply to their other courses and interests, no matter their concentration. The professor and TF were so great and made class very engaging. The readings were super interesting and not too complicated, and the weekly class discussions always broke them down very nicely.

Astro16 is one of my favorite courses I have taken at Harvard. Professor Johnson and the teaching staff are absolutely excellent. The format of the class is "flipped" and involves a lot of independent work in group settings through problems, usually after brief lectures by Professor Johnson to start you off and introduce a concept. Personally, since I learn best by doing, this was an extremely effective way to learn. It was so much fun to get to know and learn from and work with the other people in our group, and we formed a close bond over the semester. Also, working in groups to try to figure out ways to tackle these challenging problems is legitimately a really good way to learn. Homeworks were very reasonable on Professor Johnson's part and you always feel very supported throughout the class. I thought the labs were a little bit frustrating, mainly because it felt like we didn't have enough background to write the level of depth needed for the reports. Nonetheless, the night lab where you try to observe an eclipsing binary on the Clay Telescope is REALLY COOL. The midterm exam is a group midterm where you have to explain class concepts to a random person who knows nothing about astrophysics. This is an AMAZING exam format. It really forces you to go back through all the material and make sure you fundamentally understand astrophysical concepts, so you can't get away with just knowing how to use equations. This is not something that we do nearly enough of at Harvard, and I really appreciate Professor Johnson's approach to learning. Whether you are an astro concentrator (and have no choice) or just interested in astrophysics, I strongly recommend this class, and specifically taking it with Professor Johnson!
worse_comment: This class partially killed my love for astronomy. The class was solely based on these worksheets that my group always got behind on, because it was riddled with material never covered in class, where we'd have to jump to crazy conclusions to figure out. Our motivation in the class dwindled severely over time just because we had no support and no idea what we were doing, and other groups just breezed by us because they "got it". Even worse were the labs, complete disorganized messes and the lab reports were horrible. So many things on the lab reports were very complex or not even gone over properly or at all during the lab section, and the teaching staff was extra inaccessible when so many people needed help with the lab reports. I don't think I've ever been so disappointed in something I've submitted for a class than my second lab report. The labs were so separate from the class too, they could have just not existed, it's crazy.

best_comment: If you're excited by research, I highly recommend doing a senior thesis and taking Astro 191! The class is well–structured and provides you with support and guidance through regular check–ins, while being flexible. The final presentations are a great opportunity to present your work! Prof. Hernquist is very helpful!
worse_comment: Astrophysics theses are much less stressful than theses in other concentrations.

best_comment: This class was super interesting and Professor Connor is great. It is quite hard in some places but the lectures take you through the content well.
This is a very interesting and well–taught class! Lars is a great lecturer and Olga was an amazing TF!

This class has a fair amount of assignments, but they are very fair and completable within the expected time commitment 0 hours per week. Karin is a wonderful lecturer who focuses on the "big picture" of topics and some the details that matter the most. After taking this class, I feel much more confident calling myself an astrophysicist!

I highly recommend this course, especially to those with no background in ML! Professor Villar is a fantastic lecturer and did a wonderful job of decoding ML jargon to make it accessible to newbies like me. The problem sets are fun and interesting, and you have a lot of freedom to explore using ML in your research through the final project!

This class is quite interesting and is a great introduction to various diseases affecting the different systems of the human body. Lectures are quite informative (could be more engaging) and problem sets and exams are very fair! It's definitely a class where you get out as much as you buy into it. Nancy is great and super nice and understanding.

This class is quite interesting and is a great introduction to various diseases affecting the different systems of the human body. Lectures are quite informative (could be more engaging) and problem sets and exams are very fair! It's definitely a class where you get out as much as you buy into it. Nancy is great and super nice and understanding.

This course requires a significant time commitment, making it challenging to balance with other academic responsibilities. If you’re planning to take it, consider treating it as the equivalent of 2.5 courses in terms of workload. If you have prior experience with cell culture and a background in cell biology, the course will be pretty easy– but regardless of your experience level, you will spend a lot of time on this course. That said, you’ll gain a deep understanding of cell biology, and the course is both engaging and enjoyable!
worse_comment: This course is a hands–on meat grinder that teaches students highly applicable and relevant lab skills. If you are looking to hit the ground running as an undergrad with limited/no previous experience, this course will whip your ass into shape quicker than greased lightning.  The lab staff is supportive and available quite often, and TFs are highly invested in the course material, which helps to somewhat ease the demanding nature of the course. Admittedly, this course demands your time, but as an undergrad, the only way to improve your technique is to get reps at the bench, which takes time. This course is highly rewarding, and I personally feel as though I am walking away from this course with more takeaways than a majority of the other bio–related courses I have taken. As for Professor Parker, he is a somewhat polarizing man. He speaks with authority, and far more directly than other professors I have encountered. For some, this is a huge turn–off, especially if you are used to sugarcoated feedback and calm lectures that bore you to death. For others, myself included, direct constructive feedback is probably the most helpful thing I could ask for as a learning student. Bottom line: if you are doing something stupid, Parker will say "hey, stop doing that stupid thing" (sometimes in a more colorful manner).

course_title: Biomechanics of Movement and Assistive Robotics 001
best_comment: This is a great course. It's a really good opportunity to learn about the field of biomechanics, with Prof Patrick Slade, who's a fun, down to earth, and really invested in everyone's learning. It also has a good opportunity to experiment and build something of your own, fairly rudimentary but nonetheless a good way to do some actual building. It's less on the hardware and more on understanding human motion and human augmentation and touches on exoskeletons but not necessarily in the sci–fi way (the field is not that evolved yet). Regardless, it is a bit intense on the workload, but manageable, and a good experience. Great to do with friends, but also great to do solo and learn from others.

If you take this class, expect to dedicate a lot of time to it. There will be four papers assigned each week, each with a required discussion post. Papers range many topics in the biomedical sciences, so most of the articles will likely be out of your area of expertise, meaning they will take more time to read. It's not necessarily that the course material is difficult to understand, it is just that there is a constant stream of work throughout the semester – you will consistently have a paper waiting to be read for this class. At the end of the semester, there is a assignment to write a 5–page (~4000 word) proposal. The class unfortunately did not provide much context on best practices in writing a proposal, other than a tip sheet from a different university (which was helpful). The proposal will take a lot of time, as it is also required that you write it about something outside of your area of expertise. In taking this course, you will learn how to get the main ideas from a paper in a timely manner, and will gain experience writing proposals. While both of these are good things to learn,  you will have to spend a lot of time in order to do so.
worse_comment: If you are not a BIG student, this class would be an interesting way to be exposed to a wide variety of work being done in the computational biology/genomics space. The grading is not too harsh BUT it is quite a bit of work every week, especially towards the end of the semester when there is a large final assignment with no in class time devoted to learning about or working on it. I would not recommend this class if you are not very interested in this field and/or if you do not already have a strong background in biology, as there is no lecture and we go straight into reading scientific papers, which can be really challenging.

best_comment: If you take this class, expect to dedicate a lot of time to it. There will be four papers assigned each week, each with a required discussion post. Papers range many topics in the biomedical sciences, so most of the articles will likely be out of your area of expertise, meaning they will take more time to read. It's not necessarily that the course material is difficult to understand, it is just that there is a constant stream of work throughout the semester – you will consistently have a paper waiting to be read for this class. At the end of the semester, there is a assignment to write a 5–page (~4000 word) proposal. best_comment: This was, without doubt, one of my favorite classes at HSPH. It was uncomfortable, fast–paced, and I needed to work (very slowly) through the calculus and linear algebra to understand what Professor Wang was teaching. Doing the homework and exams was a truly humbling experience, but I came out of the course with a newfound sense of confidence in understanding advanced mathematical and statistical concepts, and with an insatiable desire to learn more. I loved that every morsel of knowledge in this class was earned – there was no other way to learn asymptotic theory without, for example, sitting down and understanding how Taylor series are involved. If you are in search of a class that is taught by a wonderful (and very funny!) professor and TFs, with ample support, and in a manner that will change the way you see models and estimation (the bread and butter of many public health disciplines), please do this class. It is so incredibly rewarding.

This class is a really strong course. It gives a very practical introduction to many important concepts in biostatistics. The workload is manageable and should not be too difficult for anyone coming from a stats background (familiar with linear regression, basic prob/inference, etc.). The teaching staff gives great feedback throughout the semester.

If you have an interest in machine learning in Python, this course is likely a great resource. Otherwise, this course is unlikely to be relevant to you. The assignments are long and the material is challenging unless you have a strong computer science background.

If this class is taught by LJ, take this class for an easy A and advanced doctoral credit. If you have a fairly solid understanding of Probability and Inference I, then this class shouldn't be hard at all. The most stressful component is a short in–class presentation that I believe is completion graded.  At worst you may be asked to make some modifications or improvements before your slides are shared on the Canvas. I think it's a blessing and a curse that LJ prioritizes teaching intuition.  Especially when it comes to the martingale theory, the in–class presentation of the material is mostly chalk–talk presentation where at times intuition is prioritized heavily over rigor.  This is great for seeing the material for the first time and maybe understanding how it was motivated before it was made rigorous, but I don't think anyone with a mathematical background would be satisfied with the presentation without going on to read the texts.  At least the texts alluded to throughout the class are quite rigorous.

I highly recommend this class to any student with an interest in causal inference, so long as one has the appropriate background (e.g., the first–year Biostatistics PhD core courses). I found that many of the concepts in this class were directly relevant to improving my own research. Overall, a fantastic way to get acquainted to the field to a surprisingly deep level within the span of a semester. As it is a newer course, some content is likely subject to change from year to year, but the core content of the course is extremely valuable.

I would only take this class if it is required. It tries to bridge the experimental and computational without quite effectively addressing either. Make sure you have a solid background in programming with R or python. The instructors are quite engaged and looking to improve the course, and it provides an overview of many genetic sequencing approaches, with a focus on the theory side, though assignments focus on application.
worse_comment: Probably a required course but not particularly useful. Lectures were technical but not applicable, homework required more coding experience than the prerequisites and office hours were not helpful, the packages used often had incompatibilities with Apple computers. The format of the journal club felt a little bit silly and the final project setup of people doing work then handing off makes it unnecessarily difficult to collaborate.

best_comment: I would only take this class if it is required. It tries to bridge the experimental and computational without quite effectively addressing either. course_title: Warriors and Wonders: The Folklore of Gaelic Scotland 001
best_comment: Absolutely take this course! Not only will you learn a lot of interesting insight into Celtic folklore and Scottish culture, but you will most definitely have fun as well! The teaching team is great, supportive, and enthusiastic. Overall, I loved this class and all the amazing guest speakers and events. I will miss this class a lot.

The workshops are quite helpful for keeping you on track and accountable, and the spring workshop in particularly was helpful for suggesting programs/software you could use to make your figures, and for giving you time to start working on them. It was also nice to be in the same space as other thesis writers, where we could share our struggles and feel less alone in the process. I will say that needing to email your PI the results of each workshop feels kind of silly, especially when it doesn't seem to merit any response from them – I feel like it would've been sufficient for me to email it to my direct mentor. It feels like the course's expectations of how invested your PI is is rather idealized in comparison to reality. In terms of the thesis–writing experience, I ended up hella grinding all my experiments in the two months before the deadline, and (other than the introduction I wrote in the fall/winter break) wrote most of it in like two weeks.  During the summer before, I should've realized how much harder it would be to get things done during the school year – if you can, get as much as possible done during the summer and don't bank on making too much progress during the fall. Also, if you're going to leave your writing to the last minute, at least pretend like your thesis is due a day before it's actually do – the extra 24 hours left gave me time to do so much editing, and to write a whole extra section in my results (using data with inconclusive results that I had previously decided I didn't have time to include).

Take this class. It was not easy, but I LOVED it. It's an amazingly well supported, well organized, well taught class. Logan is awesome and so are all the TFs and CAs. They're so passionate about chemistry and want to help you learn and succeed. There is a LOT of material to learn (including a fair amount of memorization), but the course also provides a huge amount of practice material. (This does make feel like there's always more studying you could be doing, but ultimately it's super useful.) Collaboration is highly encouraged –– in fact, psets and exams always have a group portion. It is a hard course and took a lot of time and energy, but I am so so glad I took it. Would absolutely recommend. Also, labs are super fun and you often get out early.
worse_comment: DO ALL THE PRACTICE PROBLEMS!!! The inly way you can succeed in this class is if you are exposed to different variations of questions and you continually practice the mechanisms. You cannot study for the exam 2 days before it, you must be doing all the practice problems as you learn the content.

best_comment: Take Chem 27! A difficult but incredibly rewarding class, particularly if you have a strong bio interest and want to understand the mechanistic principles of biology better. Make sure to prep consistently throughout the semester by reviewing lecture slides, Pollev questions, rewriting notes, redoing module + psets, etc. More memorization–based then Chem 17, but you can simplify all the different mechanisms down to their core principles, which makes the process much easier. Teaching staff are really supportive and there to help you succeed. As long as you don't procrastinate and have a consistent study schedule it should be fine.
worse_comment: Exams should reflect what is taught in lectures and the problem sets/practice tests given to students. Midterm 1 was fair, but midterms 2 and 3 were awful. It reflects quite poorly on the course and the instructors when the exams have extremely low averages, and students are dealing with severe mental and physical health issues as a result of this course. This year, they had to curve midterm 2 by five points, which they haven't done historically. Setting up students for failure and screwing them over isn't something that I expected from a course at Harvard, especially a course that is already supposed to be so rigorous and is a requirement for premeds to take. Sending thoughts and prayers if you're going to take this course next year, because after a certain point, there's not much you can do.
best_gem_comment: ****** ABSOLUTE GEM!!!! EASIEST COURSE EVER! You'll love every second of your 12+ hours of problem sets, labs and exam prep per week! Oh and don't forget the amazingly tedious labs that are pretty inconsequential to your studies. You'll love the random content on the exams that were covered in a single bullet point on one lecture slide and never mentioned again! In all honesty, If you're taking Chem 27 you don't really have a choice so idk why you're looking at the Q report for it...

best_comment: Watch the lectures online on 3x speed. Prof Mason is great at explaining things and very patient but easy to zone out in class as the pace is fairly slow. It's not an easy class if you're not a physics/physical chem person but definitely doable. Make sure you understand how to do all psets, or it will come to bite when exams come. There are no lectures slides and everything is written on a chalkboard, so you need to keep good notes and rewatch lectures before exams. Other than that great, Prof Mason is amazing and TFs are also great
worse_comment: Solid class. The language in the problem sets can be difficult to decipher at first.  Ask questions in office hours and read the textbook for more difficult concepts. From what I read in the last few year's Q Reports, they are working to make this class better and more structured every year and that pattern continued this year.

best_comment: If you like your orgo labs you will enjoy this class. We explored chemistry inspired by Harvard professors which was pretty cool. A few of them even came in to give us a presentation about their work. The class is very reasonable, as long as you come in ready to work, there's not much work outside of class. It cultivates a nice community of chem–oriented students and there's lots of downtime to talk to each other and the TFs about anything and everything. They do a lot to support you, you will not be left behind!

This class is GOATED. It was my favorite class that I took this semester, no contest about it. Here are some of the highlights of the class:1. The Teaching Staff is awesome. Richard is an amazing professor– he is incredibly smart, very friendly, easily accessible outside of class, and welcomes input. You will learn a lot in this class from him. The Head TF, Paul, was also super knowledgeable and a very chill and approachable guy, so it made seeking clarification accessible and easy.2. The class curve is very generous. We had extra credit on nearly all of the in–class quizzes, and the grading was quite chill on all of the assignments overall. If you do every assignment and just a little bit of review each week before the quizzes (not more than 3 –4 hours a week), you should easily be in the A range.3. You cover a lot of very interesting material, but in an intuitive and low–pressure environment. I took this class concurrently with Chem 40 (which is usually a prereq for this class) and I wish I had just used this class to fulfill my Inorganic requirement. The first 1/4 of the class is a speedrun of Chem 40 content going slightly more in depth into everything; the next 2/4 is an overview of all the elementary steps of organometallic chemistry followed by an in–depth exploration of the mechanisms of each; and finally, the last 1/4 is applying this new knowledge to learn new reactions. You will learn a lot in this class, but it will not be stressful because of the above reasons.TL;DR: Overall, this is an awesome class that I would highly recommend anyone studying Chemistry take when it is available. It is everything you could want in a class– interesting material, awesome professor and teaching staff, not too much work per week (3–4 hours), and a generous curve. Definitely take Chem 153 if you're considering it!!!

This is a decent and very straightforward class. I was intimidated at first because lectures can go pretty quickly and are essentially all complicated derivations, and the psets are usually tough, but the teaching staff is super understanding and supportive. If you decide to take this class for a letter grade, make sure you can make it to at least one weekly office hour because the psets are quite challenging and there aren't many office hours available. Tests are fair and easier than the psets, and the teaching staff seems to be pretty forgiving with grades. The only components of the class are the two midterm grades and the pset grades, which means you can miss lecture/section without penalty if you have things that come up.
worse_comment: I did not enjoy Chem161. If you have to take it for your concentration, I recommend taking another class for the requirement if at all possible. The TFs were very friendly and helpful and the best part of the class, but lectures are confusing and hard to follow, and I found the content to be dull and did not spark any interest in the topic. But I might just not like StatMech so your mileage may vary.

best_comment: Khaled is an absolutely wonderful instructor who cares an incredible amount about the students in the class and is willing to help them in whatever way possible – I cannot emphasize how much I appreciate the help that he gave me over the duration of the final project! All in all, the experience of being able to design,  execute, and present the final project is a wonderful experience that I had a really great time doing and recommend for anyone interested in pursuing an independent research project. You will truly have the freedom and resources to do any sort of research project you want.

Chem 171 is a great class overall, but it does have its quirks. Here are some notable pros and cons:Pros:– Professor Balskus is great! She is incredibly knowledgeable and friendly, and genuinely wants everyone to learn– The TFs are also quite good– they gave very useful feedback, held frequent office hours, and genuinely wanted everyone to succeed– The course material is quite interesting– the first 1/2 of the course is pretty much a speedrun of Chem 27 (how organisms make all kinds of biomolecules) but more in–depth and with some added categories, and the second 1/2 of the course is how to apply your knowledge of how biomolecules are made to do interesting science (such as identifying the genes responsible for making the molecule, identifying the molecule made by a set of genes, and using biocatalysis to engineer new ways to make molecules)– The class is a good mix of Undergrads and Grad students, so you will definitely meet new people– The class takes ~7 hours per week, which is pretty standard– There are a few guest lectures from people in Biochem / Biocatalysis who come and visit, so you will see industrial applications of the topics and maybe even build useful connectionsCons:– The sections are not very engaging. The sections are quite interesting in theory– each section, you learn about and use a new Bioinformatic tool, and in your final project, you use 3 of those tools you learned about. However, the sections do not have enough structure in my opinion, as most of the time was spent just playing around with the bioinformatic tool yourself– The grading on psets was incredibly harsh– multiple points are taken off for simple / non–understanding mistakes, such as not writing water or acid/base co–products. This detracted from finding where my understanding was lacking– The psets, tests, and projects took a while to be returned (but the feedback was good, so this is not the biggest deal)– No information was provided about the grading curve at any point in the semesterTL;DR: Chem 171 is a good class and I would recommend it to anyone interested in biochemistry. It has some quirks, such as the grading being harsh and the sections not having enough structure, but overall, I learned a lot and had a great time in the class!
worse_comment: The content is interesting, but I hated how a lot of the work felt like busy work to me. In a graduate level course, I should not be feeling that way. The grading was also overly harsh.

course_title: Quantum Chemistry: Theory and Practice LEC
best_comment: Beautiful and rigorous deep dive into modern electronic structure theory. Professor Lee is such an amazing and engaging lecturer, and for each class skillfully weaves physical intuition, mathematical rigour, and computational insight in a way that makes even the most abstract ideas feel tangible.  A special shoutout to TF Jinghong Zhang, who through every single section brought absolute clarity to all course materials. Consistently the highlight of my week, carefully constructed, conceptually elegant, and often more enlightening than any textbooks. His teaching elevated the entire experience and is truly the gold standard for a TF. Amazing course offering with no counterpart at MIT. For any cross–registering MIT students and absolutely for Harvard students, if you are interested in development for any production–level electronic structure code, this class is a MUST–TAKE. However, the difficulty of this class cannot be understated, especially towards the end for the final project, where you will get hands–on experience benchmarking real quantum chemistry methods with the legendary software Q–Chem.  The workload ramps up quickly, and the conceptual load is heavy, but the intellectual reward is immense. You’ll walk away not just understanding modern electronic structure theory, but truly thinking like a quantum chemist.

course_title: Practical Crystallography in Chemistry and Materials Science LEC
best_comment: I don't recommend taking this class until an extreme overhaul is done. The content is valuable but the quality of the teaching is frustrating and honestly subpar. If you are interested in learning about crystallography, you would be better off reading the textbooks assigned on the syllabus (because that's honestly the only place I learned anything anyway) or waiting until another instructor picks this course up/until you can take it at another institution.
worse_comment: This class is a must–take for anybody who will be reliant on crystallography for their current or future research. That being said, it is not a pleasant class and requires substantially more work than seems necessary to learn the important material. It is possible to learn a lot and pretty much be prepared to become a DIY user of the x–ray facility, however Shao is extremely harsh and frequently openly criticizes individual students, which makes for an unpleasant learning environment. Many assignments must be completed on a weekly basis with little guidance, though very little of it contributes to your grade and assignment of numerical grades seems very subjective or arbitrary.

course_title: Foundations and Frontiers of Modern Chemistry: A Molecular and Global Perspective LEC
best_comment: I like the exams. They are very fair. They reflect what we learned in class and also a good reflection of the practice exam. There has never been a problem on the exam that we have not seen a variation of on the pset or on practice exams. As someone who was taking 6 classes during the semester, I didn't put that much time in this class, but I still came out with a rudimentary understanding of chemistry and was not incredibly stressed. I think it is only stressful if you do things last minute. I have always started pset part I, the online portion, about 3 hrs before it's due. A 90% gives you full credit, so don't stress about making things perfect. There is a point of diminishing returns. Here is my work flow if you wish to have an understanding of the weekly workload: I start part II on Saturdays. I don't do anything before then. I go to the 2 hrs office hours and then the additional office hours with Joe, who won't be on the teaching staff next year, but I complete the most of the pset on Saturday. I leave Sunday and Monday for sometimes when the pset is longer than usual. This class really isn't supposed to be rocket science, and people that say it is so, they just want to be perfect, and you can't always have that. Find other things worth your time to be stressed about. You don't have to be perfect to get an A. There are also plenty of opportunities to savage your pset and lab scores. Lectures are fun. I enjoy Frank's way of presentation. We go through the mathematics, and there are also fun demonstrations. You just need to buy into this class in order to enjoy this. I am speaking as someone who has taken chem 20 before taking this class. This class is much easier than any of the orgo classes, but the two classes are completely unrelated. It's also more entertaining than any orgo class you will take. You don't have to take this class before orgo. So, feel free to take this class when you are junior like me. And like don't gatekeep. There is a mutual benefit with sharing and discussing answers. It's never that serious that you must hide your answers from your peers. You are not pitted against your peers. This class is not curved, so don't focus on strategizing against your classmates. There is always a bunch of people like that in every OH. Please do not be like those people.You will do most of your practical learning with your section TF. Go Elena!! Best TF ever. She does a great overview of the topics and then goes through the problems with us instead of forcing us to attempt it on our own. She lets us do that if we have multiple problems that have a similar set up, but she understands that there is a limited amount of time to get through all the problems, and she rather go through all the problems with us then make us try to go through the solutions by ourselves. kween behavior. For exam studying tips, I highly suggest going over pset part II problems. Never bother with part I. Then go over Lu's review study guides. Those videos are holy grails. If you don't have time for the full videos, I highly suggest watching the sections of the videos where she goes through some examples if you think you have a good grasp of the basic. There are some unique examples that may benefit you on the exams. You get a cheat sheet front and back for each exam, so fill it up with things that she says. My main gripe about this class is the wacky lab schedule. Like, this is genuinely my only issue with this class. It was genuinely so odd how there was an A  and B group. But then it wasn't consistent? So then what was the point? The idea was that group A students go first, then group B goes the next week. But sometimes, we had both groups going each week. Friday's section is the last to go for one lab, but for the next lab topic, they somehow become the first class to go. And then tell me why the prelab for the next lab is due before the lab report for the current lab. I think the Friday's lab sections got screwed over the most this semester. And then for the weeks that Friday's group goes last, every single group, no matter if you were monday's lab from the week before or friday's lab, everyone had the same due date. That's simply not fair for people who only had the weekend to put together the lab report versus someone who has the whole week.
worse_comment: Beginning before the semester started, I was surprised at how disorganized the course felt. Before the first lecture on the first day of classes, we already needed to watch a lecture, scan and submit a few pages of work, and complete Pset 0 Part 2 (but not part 1 yet). If I had not checked canvas in the middle of January, a week before classes started, I would have already been several hours behind on the first day. This pattern continued throughout the semester, with several things being due each week, all at different times. At the beginning, the head TF explained that many people fall behind in this course, so they split each assignment up into sub–parts with multiple checkpoints per week, BUT this method actually had the reverse effect by making me more anxious about all the little due dates. For example, there is a Pset Part 1, Pset Part 2, Pre–lab, and Lab Report due each week but on four different days (and across Canvas, Gradescope, and EdX platforms), so I needed to re–allocate my time each week depending on which of those assignments were due when. What's a simple solution to the scheduling problem? Create a class Gcal! Great idea. This course had a class Gcal that we were required to subscribe to as part of Pset 0 Part 2. HOWEVER, the Gcal was never updated and often contained outdated or flat–out incorrect information about due dates. Roughly once a week, I would need to email my section TF asking about the due dates for all these mini assignments because there could be up to THREE DIFFERENT dates given to us (Gcal says one day, Canvas calendar says another day, and the weekly PS11 newsletter says a third day). This course had several critical organizational issues that created unnecessary confusion for my peers and me. In addition, the way that the gradescope submissions work, a student will upload a scanned document and the computer will automatically assign each problem to a specific part of each page. Most of the time this saves the student a few minutes of needing to manually assign each problem to a specific page. However, on multiple of my Psets, the computer would incorrectly assign one part of a page to a specific problem (it thinks that Problem 3 is in the middle of Page 4, but it is actually a few centimeters farther down based on how I scanned my pages) and I would automatically get a 0 on that problem. The computer put a little box around where it thinks the problem should be, instead of where it actually is on the page, and the result is the TF grading that problem is given an incomplete or non–existent portion of my work. Super frustrating because then my TF said "sorry, there's nothing we can do about this because the computer does that automatically". Finally, many of the TF's are clearly not excited about this course, or have no idea what's going on. There were many times when I would be given an incorrect answer at office hours and then would need to go to office hours later that day to double check the first TF's answers. Several times, they made me feel like I was a burden to double check answers, even though it is not my fault that a previous TF had point–blank told me an incorrect answer.

course_title: Foundations and Frontiers of Modern Chemistry: A Molecular and Global Perspective LEC
best_comment: I like the exams. They are very fair. They reflect what we learned in class and also a good reflection of the practice exam. There has never been a problem on the exam that we have not seen a variation of on the pset or on practice exams. As someone who was taking 6 classes during the semester, I didn't put that much time in this class, but I still came out with a rudimentary understanding of chemistry and was not incredibly stressed. I think it is only stressful if you do things last minute. I have always started pset part I, the online portion, about 3 hrs before it's due. A 90% gives you full credit, so don't stress about making things perfect. There is a point of diminishing returns. Here is my work flow if you wish to have an understanding of the weekly workload: I start part II on Saturdays. I don't do anything before then. I go to the 2 hrs office hours and then the additional office hours with Joe, who won't be on the teaching staff next year, but I complete the most of the pset on Saturday. I leave Sunday and Monday for sometimes when the pset is longer than usual. This class really isn't supposed to be rocket science, and people that say it is so, they just want to be perfect, and you can't always have that. Find other things worth your time to be stressed about. You don't have to be perfect to get an A. There are also plenty of opportunities to savage your pset and lab scores. Lectures are fun. I enjoy Frank's way of presentation. We go through the mathematics, and there are also fun demonstrations. You just need to buy into this class in order to enjoy this. I am speaking as someone who has taken chem 20 before taking this class. This class is much easier than any of the orgo classes, but the two classes are completely unrelated. It's also more entertaining than any orgo class you will take. You don't have to take this class before orgo. So, feel free to take this class when you are junior like me. And like don't gatekeep. There is a mutual benefit with sharing and discussing answers. It's never that serious that you must hide your answers from your peers. You are not pitted against your peers. This class is not curved, so don't focus on strategizing against your classmates. There is always a bunch of people like that in every OH. Please do not be like those people.You will do most of your practical learning with your section TF. Go Elena!! Best TF ever. She does a great overview of the topics and then goes through the problems with us instead of forcing us to attempt it on our own. She lets us do that if we have multiple problems that have a similar set up, but she understands that there is a limited amount of time to get through all the problems, and she rather go through all the problems with us then make us try to go through the solutions by ourselves. kween behavior. For exam studying tips, I highly suggest going over pset part II problems. Never bother with part I. Then go over Lu's review study guides. Those videos are holy grails. If you don't have time for the full videos, I highly suggest watching the sections of the videos where she goes through some examples if you think you have a good grasp of the basic. There are some unique examples that may benefit you on the exams. You get a cheat sheet front and back for each exam, so fill it up with things that she says. My main gripe about this class is the wacky lab schedule. Like, this is genuinely my only issue with this class. It was genuinely so odd how there was an A  and B group. But then it wasn't consistent? So then what was the point? The idea was that group A students go first, then group B goes the next week. But sometimes, we had both groups going each week. Friday's section is the last to go for one lab, but for the next lab topic, they somehow become the first class to go. And then tell me why the prelab for the next lab is due before the lab report for the current lab. I think the Friday's lab sections got screwed over the most this semester. And then for the weeks that Friday's group goes last, every single group, no matter if you were monday's lab from the week before or friday's lab, everyone had the same due date. That's simply not fair for people who only had the weekend to put together the lab report versus someone who has the whole week.

course_title: Environment and Society in the Premodern World 001
best_comment: This class has expanded my understanding of "environmental history" by asking the very simple question: what was environment in the past, especially the pre–modern era? This has allowed us to consider as a classroom both today's environmental conundrums but also the very different demands of ancient and early modern environments and the variety of human adaptations to them. This has been a great opportunity to learn from peers across the Humanities and Social Sciences at Harvard, and I am immensely grateful for it.

course_title: Environment and Society in the Premodern World 001
best_comment: This class has expanded my understanding of "environmental history" by asking the very simple question: what was environment in the past, especially the pre–modern era? This class was so FUN! Went into it with no prior knowledge on Rome nor Archeology, but ended up loving it! Honestly my favorite class of the semester! First of all, prof Andrews is so cool! She is so passionate about the subject matter and it shows! I love the content that we discussed and everything in between! She's also so cool out of a class content if you ever stick after class and have a conversation you won't regret it! Also, all of the assignments were chill and fun. The map quizzes were more than fair the the papers were all creative based so you could write just about anything Rome related! I never really got to write anything creative in my time at Harvard so it was really refreshing. Also, the rest of the teaching staff are great as well, just as passionate and knowledgeable as the professor! I would HIGHLY RECOMMEND!!!! you WILL NOT regret it, a great class to balance out the rest of your semester!
worse_comment: It is a really good class, low stress.
best_gem_comment: This is a gem! The professor and TA's are very good and the subject is exactly what you'd expect.

best_comment: Professor Hudson is a very kind and compassionate person and a wonderful teacher. His weekly preparation was extremely thorough, and he provided us with excellent materials, including meticulous handouts that were painstakingly composed. What impressed me so much is his obvious passion for the texts and scholarship, and the depth of his knowledge. He would often go the extra mile to research questions he couldn’t answer immediately in class, and truly cared about his students’ opinions and took them seriously. He also facilitated excellent discussions, gave helpful feedback, and curated a very focused curriculum that was highly thorough but not overwhelming (a difficult feat!). He was also always happy to meet outside of classes, and made himself available to students in a generous manner. I don’t know if this course will be taught again by Professor Hudson at Harvard, but it has my strong recommendation!

course_title: Sappho and her Reception in the Ancient World 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE! Professor Nagy is truly a light in the Harvard world: he has so much experience in the academic universe of Harvard, and is specifically wise in this discipline of Lyric/Sappho. The class environment was so wonderful – Professor Nagy encourages the agency of the students who self select for this class. I sincerely appreciated his encouragement and flexibility for us students to engage in topics we are passionate about within the framework of the course, and share them with the class! In that way, only take this course if you are a self–motivated student with an idea of an individual framework with which to guide your study – most of your work will be self generated (which is wonderful if that is right for you – as it was for me!). Thank you Greg for the most amazing semester, I will certainly take a course with him again :)

course_title: Introduction to the Ancient Roman World 001
best_comment: Let me just preface this comment by stating that this is not an easy class.  Kathleen Coleman is definitely not an easy grader (though she is a fair one), not inflating assignments in the manner that most classes might do.  While this realization was at first difficult, in hindsight, I very much appreciate this approach to teaching.  I think that Coleman's approach could be described as a sort of "tough–love" –– she grades a bit more harshly not to be mean, but to spur growth.  After I got a lower grade than expected on one of my assignments, I met up with her, during which she told me that she gives students grades such that inspire improvement and push one to his full potential –– an approach that inspired me to learn much more in this course than I think I otherwise would have achieved.  Looking back on this course, I have fond eyes; in response to the higher expectations, all of us students formed deep bonds which I know will last far beyond this class.  Coleman is also an excellent lecturer.  Lectures are thematic rather than purely chronological (education, slavery, economy, etc), though she does include timelines in her lectures.  She delivers lectures in an engaging and memorable manner, making studying much more streamlined.   Assignments are very well thought–out and the expectations are clear (though demanding).  All in all, I highly recommend this class to any student who truly wants to learn about Roman history.  This course is by no means a gem, but anyone who puts in the work will enjoy this class and be glad that he took it.
