best_comment: The trip makes this class worthwhile and brings the readings to life! The first half of the class was a bit dry, but after we returned from Sicily, our discussions became much richer, and students were more willing to participate (since we had gotten to know each other much better during spring break).Readings are very archaeology heavy,  which can be frustrating. (I would have appreciated more historical/literary sources.)Overview of Sicilian history was a bit cursory, and class discussions were often repetitive. Professor sometimes seemed underprepared for lectures.Still, the trip and the final paper gave me a solid understanding of Sicilian history and culture and motivation to continue learning.

course_title: Identity and the Self in the Medieval Greek Tradition 001
best_comment: Dimiter and Alex are both wonderful. Best ratio of reading length to discussion quality. Twenty page paper isn't too scary, and they give you ample scaffolding.

course_title: Identity and the Self in the Medieval Greek Tradition 001
best_comment: Dimiter and Alex are both wonderful. Best ratio of reading length to discussion quality. Twenty page paper isn't too scary, and they give you ample scaffolding.

This is a good class about a very interesting topic! It was a very accessible introduction to ancient medicine for anyone with related interests. The course might have benefited from a bit more theoretical structure and analytical depth, but it was overall very well done, and Prof Schiefsky is obviously very talented and passionate. The rest of the course staff was kind as well. The group presentation was not a terribly high–stakes affair, and there was plenty of time to work on the term paper. We haven't taken the final exam yet, but the structure of it is a bit more intense with many term and passage identifications in addition to a written essay.
best_gem_comment: ** This is a great gem of a course if you have any interest in philosophy or medicine. If you already know a lot about ancient philosophy, expect some material to be review. However, there is also some obscure stuff to satisfy the curious and more advanced undergraduates. I especially enjoyed the sections on athleticism and women's health. Professor Schiefsky is really nice and a great lecturer. The class gets the gold star of RESPECTING your TIME. It lets you engage most with the parts of material that interest you the most, but you still come away with overall mastery because of the final exam.The one thing I did not like was a group project presentation. Groups projects are not the best already, and watching everyone else's presentations themselves every class dragged because (respectfully, and myself included) students do not really know how to give an engaging talk.

course_title: Do as the Romans Do: Roman Exemplarity in Antiquity and Beyond 001
best_comment: 100% TAKE THIS COURSE. I know that a lot of people put that on Q reports, but this is an absolutely amazing course that you should take. I came in knowing very little about  Rome or Classics, and have left with a wealth of knowledge. This course is really approachable, and I know people who are Classics concentrators who have also learned things from the course and enjoyed it. Not only is the work is incredibly manageable, but it's also super interesting. I expected to kind of superficially like the course content, but it ended up being so much more fascinating and engaging than I expected. Also, Dr. Love is the best professor I've had so far. I haven't written a research essay before this course, and she was so helpful. She took the time to meet with me multiple times to go over my topic and just generally how to write a research paper. So, yes, my honest review is to absolutely take this course!

course_title: Rhetoric, A User's Guide: from Ancient Greece to Contemporary America 001
best_comment: One of the best classes I have ever taken in my eight semesters here, no doubt. If you are at all interested in rhetoric and speeches (as you should be!) but want a more academic and historical treatment than Expos 40 can offer (or you didn't get into Expos 40), you should take it. Prof. Greenwood is one of the most phenomenal lecturers I have had the pleasure to experience: ridiculously knowledgeable and prepared, always caring and kind, and very encouraging. If you are scared off by the prospect of Latin and Greek, do not fret: you absolutely don't need to know any of it but you will certainly leave the class appreciating just how much ancient Greece and Rome have influenced rhetoric and culture in the U.S., Europe, Africa, and beyond. We were a small group of about 20–30 students from different Harvard schools which was really incredible, as people had so many different experiences and thoughts to share with the class. For the sake of the experience of the students who take the class, I really hope that it stays this way, although at the same time I want everyone to take this class.

This is a class if you are at all interested in learning Greek! Nadav and Alex were both fantastic — super engaging, interesting, and great at explaining grammar/history/etc. The class is pretty manageable work–wise, but I still feel like I learned a lot.

Greek 10 is a wonderful way to secure your Greek and get more fluent, especially if the texts are as interesting and fun as they were this semester. Sarah is wonderful––she really cares about her students and has great insights into reception especially, but is also very helpful with and good at explaining grammar.

course_title: Ancient Greek Literature: Texts and Contexts 001
best_comment: Though the texts and content of this course are wonderful, Prof. Greenwood's teaching was by far the best part. Greenwod prepared comprehensive handouts for each class which guided class discussion and served as great resources for revising the content. Greenwood's expectations of us were reasonable, and, I believe, gave ample opportunity for success in all aspects of the course. For example, passages for the midterm and final were taken from a set of passages from the term rather than the whole reading list (as in 112a). These are just a few things of many more, but taking this class under Greenwood is an absolute delight and by far the most stimulating and productive intellectual experience I have had thus far at Harvard

Take this course if interested in Latin at all! The course was extremely well organized and taught exceptionally well. It was clear that Ivy has an impressive grasp of the course content and was able to effectively teach complex concepts, while also managing to keep the class engaging. I really appreciate all the effort put in for the games / slides / fun activities throughout the course. Hannah was an amazing TF who was extremely effective at teaching us more advanced translation best tactics and its clear that she cares a lot about the students. I found her advice and teaching to be extremely useful and it made me a much better student. Also really appreciated the enthusiasm she brought to each class.

Definitely picked up from Latin I, but as long as you had a solid foundation and keep up with vocab and new concepts, it is a very fun and engaging class. The teaching staff genuinely wants to see you succeed and is very willing to help you and maximize your experience. Come to class prepared because it is very interactive and you are expected to know that week's concepts before class on Monday so that you can actively practice it. No shame (most of the time) if you don't know the concepts but it isn't the most fun having to be talked through questions you find out later on are fairly trivial in front of all your peers. Nonetheless, it's all part of the learning process, and you get to learn a lot about ancient greek gods and roman history. Super cool!
An amazing experience! If you have done some Latin before and are looking for an interesting and engaging course that doesn't break the bank time wise then I highly suggest this.

If you have an opportunity to take this class, take it!  I came into this course having never taken an upper level translation course, and I think that this may be one of the best first upper–level classes one can take.   Professor Thomas is not only one of the most brilliant professors I know at Harvard, but he is a genuinely kind individual who truly cares for the growth of his students.  Mandatory office ours periodically throughout the semester really help to break the initial barrier, and, by the end of the semester, he seems more of a friend and mentor than an imposing top scholar in the field.   At the same time, every single class was filled with fascinating information about the odes we covered, and I am leaving this class with just enough knowledge to know how much I don't know about the odes and how much more I want to learn –– something which I receive more rarely than you might think.  One piece of advice is to stick to the readings each week as much as you can.  If you slack, it is very difficult to catch up since there are over 80 odes to review by the time of the final (speaking from experience, it is not fun to review so many within a couple days!).  That is not a problem of the class as so much as a problem of time–management, however.   All in all, this was an excellent course that I highly recommend to anyone with a solid understanding of Latin.

Professor Love is a really amazing professor and lovely person. She can be a bit hard to reach via email though. If you have questions or want feedback on an outline or something, I recommend going to see her in person at office hours rather than emailing. The readings are a little long and sometimes, new authors you haven't read before take some getting used to, so just keep that in mind.

Absolutely fascinating class! I highly recommend! This course was incredibly well thought–out: all components, from translation assignments to our Houghton visit to exploration of Greek grammars and dictionaries really complemented one another.  In particular, the Greek and English materials were fascinating, informative, and adequately challenging. I am leaving this class with a strong grasp of the evolution of medieval Greek and the historical and cultural forces that influenced/accompanied this development. Also, Alex is a wonderful professor––very very knowledgeable but simultaneously down–to–earth, friendly, responsive, and encouraging.
Take this course! I entered it not at all familiar with Medieval history, but this did not hinder me at all. The texts are very interesting and increase in difficulty at a manageable rate.

I really really enjoyed this course. I love the humanities and learned so much from Professor Roilos. If you don't like philosophy or history, I would steer clear. It is manageable and the TFs were amazing

This was such a fantastic class!! If you’re not sure about comparative literature as a field or where your interests will lie within the field, this class will get you up to speed. You get experience with reading an incredible variety of genres and time periods, and learn how to read literary criticism with an informed eye. Matylda facilitates in–class discussions beautifully, and is particularly adept at highlighting both the strengths of your responses and places to develop your ideas further. I always walked away feeling both supported and challenged. Christine gives fantastic, very thorough feedback on your weekly assignments. Even though I felt as though I had a lot of experience with academic writing and thinking about literature, she always found new ways to challenge me and push me to grow as a scholar.

course_title: Contemporary Southeast Asia through Literature and Film SEM
best_comment: Take this class! It was super interesting — we go through a lot of different types of literature and media, from poems, novels, to movies and documentaries. You will learn so much about Southeast Asia, and as someone from the region, I found myself learning so much more about the rich cultures that surround me. Prof Lienau is great, and very passionate about what she does. She asks interesting questions for discussion and we had several mini–teaching sessions with language preceptors and so I enjoyed that a lot!

This class is one where you get out of it what you put into it, but I really enjoyed the discussions, and find taking an active part in them go be the best way for me to engage with the materials though not everyone had a super active role in the discussion, which was also okay! The material for this courses is fantastic.!
worse_comment: You really get out what you put into it; there's a lot of grade uncertainty because it's all weighted on the final paper

course_title: Why Braille Matters: A Radical Revision of Literary Theory and World Literature SEM
best_comment: One of those really unique classes at Harvard. Such an amazing opportunity to learn about braille and tactile reading systems. Katie and Prof Shell make a great team.

course_title: Music, Literature, and the Voice LEC
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!! Professor Hamilton is the definition of a compelling lecturer – his expansive and intricate knowledge of this topic specifically made this class such a gift to take. I left every lecture feeling as if I'd gotten closer to the meaning of life, and energized about what it means to be a student. Specifically, Professor H's lecture notes are so carefully crafted and truly a huge treasure to have the chance to interact with as a student of this course. The side notes on the board of words in Latin, Greek, French, and more now populate my well–loved notebook from this course. As a lover of literature and a classical singer I can say with certainty that this class was formative to my life as an academic as well as artist. I hope this course will continue in the years to come – I would even come to audit it again because of how comprehensive and dense the literature is (in the best way!) – and that the humanities/german department will continue to generate and support classes about the role of music in literature, in addition to the rich canon of literature about musical genius. If you are a true academic, take this course – it feels like a graduate seminar simultaneously in Classics/Greek/Philosophy/Music/German/English and more which makes it truly a special experience to participate in. :)
best_gem_comment: Can't recommend this enough! I joined late because I was figuring out my schedule and I was instantly glad I joined after the first lecture. Hamilton is an amazing lecturer and we need more lecturers like him! This class is a gem. I highly recommend engaging with the materials and showing up to lectures ready to soak it in because every week was a roller coaster in the best way possible. You can tell he's so passionate about what he teaches and it's awesome

course_title: Homer and Beyond: Theory and Comparative Methods in Studying Oral Traditions SEM
best_comment: Definitely a gem, but that certainly doesn’t mean you can’t engage deeply with the material. You get out what you put in—you can easily coast through, or, as some students have done, take a vested interest in the course and take advantage of the opportunity to learn from a true expert in the field. What you take away from the course, and how rigorously you apply yourself, depends entirely on you.
best_gem_comment: Definitely a gem, but that certainly doesn’t mean you can’t engage deeply with the material. You get out what you put in—you can easily coast through, or, as some students have done, take a vested interest in the course and take advantage of the opportunity to learn from a true expert in the field. What you take away from the course, and how rigorously you apply yourself, depends entirely on you.

best_comment: *You must take this course* if you are interested in anything humanities or social sciences in general. This course is extremely well structured, guiding you step by step without being didactic. In the end, you find yourself gaining a holistic knowledge about global media in general, and hopefully, your particular focus as well. It's not a difficult class if you just listen in class and at least read most of the material. There really aren't that many things to read, and it's not difficult at all. If you want the full experience, you should just read everything.The person who makes all these great learning experiences possible, Professor Weigel, is a fantastic professor and, all in all, just a wonderful person. She is very knowledgeable about what she is teaching and beyond. She is able to weave everyone's comments together to produce a very generative conversation. She is great at facilitating discussions using concrete questions and ad–lib comments that are somehow just as insightful. On top of that, she runs her class with a great structure/scaffold without being rigid at all. She provides a recapitulation of the previous classes, and these summaries help everyone to wake up and weave things together. She is overall a very organized person – her course website is so easy to navigate. She makes herself available to students despite her own responsibilities – I don't know how she does it! Go to her office hours: she will surprise you with a constellation of knowledge, and at the same time, remain humble and never pushy. She really wants you to explore your own interests, and she's there to provide detailed, concrete, and theoretical feedback wherever you need, without trying to enforce her opinions on you. She is also very good with both humanities research and social science research!

course_title: Media, Technology, and Social Change SEM
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Professor Weigel is truly so amazing, passionate, and funny! The course material was genuinely SO interesting, especially if you have ANY interest in media, tech, or social movements and activism. Very light/ manageable course load, and Professor Weigel is very understanding. We learned about everything from the Black Panther Party, the Young Lords, TikTok, and so much more! I really enjoyed the fact that we got to watch movies as assignments and visit the Houghton Library to view archives and media related to our course topics. I definitely wish I had contributed more to our class discussions, they were truly so insightful! We also had amazing guest speakers, one of whom worked at Facebook and Meta, and another who did research about TikTok and activism on the platform. I couldn't recommend this class more.

course_title: Sappho and her Reception in the Ancient World SEM
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE! Professor Nagy is truly a light in the Harvard world: he has so much experience in the academic universe of Harvard, and is specifically wise in this discipline of Lyric/Sappho. The class environment was so wonderful – Professor Nagy encourages the agency of the students who self select for this class. I sincerely appreciated his encouragement and flexibility for us students to engage in topics we are passionate about within the framework of the course, and share them with the class! In that way, only take this course if you are a self–motivated student with an idea of an individual framework with which to guide your study – most of your work will be self generated (which is wonderful if that is right for you – as it was for me!). Thank you Greg for the most amazing semester, I will certainly take a course with him again :)

I really enjoyed the course and the professor is super intelligent, insightful, and lovely. I think your experience in the class will depend on the rest of your peers. If people are silent/shy/reserved, it'll take a bit to feel engaged and have good class discussions.

This class is incredible. The professors are so wonderful and smart, hearing them speak is probably the best part of it. They really foster an open and safe environment where people can feel comfortable speaking on difficult topics. The class was very warm and felt almost like a family. It’s a great class.

This class is incredible. The professors are so wonderful and smart, hearing them speak is probably the best part of it. They really foster an open and safe environment where people can feel comfortable speaking on difficult topics. The class was very warm and felt almost like a family. It’s a great class.

course_title: Comparative Literature in Theory and Practice SEM

best_comment: Definitely take CS1! I am extremely glad that this was how I chose to fulfill QRD. Python is such a great coding language to start with, Professor Leitner is an incredible resource, and I never found the workload to be unreasonable. If you come to lecture, you will be fine. You will want to come to lecture, too; Leitner is fun! As a humanities major, this was the perfect way to (finally) take QRD.
worse_comment: use this course as a gateway to cs for students who are uncertain

best_comment: Definitely take this class! Rebecca is an amazing instructor and all of the course staff are very supportive and good at helping you. If you've never written proofs before, you get pretty good at it because you write so many of them, so it's also good prep for other classes like CS120.
worse_comment: This class seems necessary for future CS courses, but it was not taught tell at all, and I learned very little from taking the class. I don't think the content itself is incredibly difficult, but the format of the class makes it quite difficult to comprehend what we are learning.

best_comment: Definitely take this class! Rebecca is an amazing instructor and all of the course staff are very supportive and good at helping you. If you've never written proofs before, you get pretty good at it because you write so many of them, so it's also good prep for other classes like CS120.
worse_comment: This class seems necessary for future CS courses, but it was not taught tell at all, and I learned very little from taking the class. I don't think the content itself is incredibly difficult, but the format of the class makes it quite difficult to comprehend what we are learning.

best_comment: Take this class if you want an easy A! To get the concentration requirement for CS and a pretty much guaranteed A, I would highly recommend this course. Definitely better to tka eif you know people or have friends in the class because then you can work together. If you really want to learn scientific code needed for engineering, I found that I actually learned more in PS12 than in CS32... Regardless, this class teaches you how to think like a coder and pushes you to think in new ways. If you put in the work, do all the psets, go to office hours, attend lectures, you will learn in this class. However, it is really easy to not go to lecture, barely do the homeworks, and barely do the psets so I would suggest being mindful of that when it comes to learning to code vs just getting a good grade. Also Mike and Kitty are awesome. When people participate in lecture it's much more fun!!
worse_comment: I would not recommend this class. This is the first cs class I took here and while I found the material reasonable and easy to understand, I was incredibly disappointed with how boring and unrelated to the psets the lectures where, how useless the skills the psets were based on where. If you go to office hours, you will get through the class but unfortunately I do not consider myself knowledgable in python when that was the goal
best_gem_comment: This class is an absolute GEM! If you have taken AP CSP or similar, or even have basic knowledge of how programming works, this course is an easy A. No finals, only a free–form project that you are allowed to use GenAI on, and lots of OHs for PSETs. Course staff is super understanding, and you can even work on problem sets during section. Attendance isn't even mandatory. Please, if you do not know how to code, TAKE THIS COURSE! Though easy, it will make you very proficient in Python and how computers think. Unlike CS50, it teaches you ONE language, but does it in greater depth and makes it SUPER FUN!!!

best_comment: Take this class if you want an easy A! To get the concentration requirement for CS and a pretty much guaranteed A, I would highly recommend this course. Definitely better to tka eif you know people or have friends in the class because then you can work together. If you really want to learn scientific code needed for engineering, I found that I actually learned more in PS12 than in CS32... Regardless, this class teaches you how to think like a coder and pushes you to think in new ways. If you put in the work, do all the psets, go to office hours, attend lectures, you will learn in this class. Also Mike and Kitty are awesome. When people participate in lecture it's much more fun!!

Unlike CS50, it teaches you ONE language, but does it in greater depth and makes it SUPER FUN!!!

course_title: Incentives in the Wild: from Tanking in Sports to Mining Cryptocurrencies 001
best_comment: I think this is a great course, content–wise at least, and gives you much insight into the mechanisms around you. Yannai is a great lecturer and is very helpful throughout the semester. Having said that, if the same TFs teach this course next year, I recommend that YOU DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE. While it looks manageable, the TFs responsible for grading your material are of little to no help. In fact, office hours sometimes felt like an inconvenience to them and they aren't helpful at all. The course grading is super subjective (well it seems that way because there's no rubric) and despite being a CS course you will get subjective answers as to why they don't like your work. There are other courses at Harvard that may be of much better overall value than this course.
worse_comment: This was by far the worst course I have ever taken.

best_comment: Highly recommend taking CS50 off cycle! Being able to watch the lectures on my own time (and on 2x speed) was great, and still having the section component was very helpful. I had no coding experience prior to this course, and while I did struggle at times, it was very worth it. I had a great time working through the psets and doing my final project.
worse_comment: Make sure you have the space in your schedule and mental capacity for the demands of this course. If you already have a full plate or you are not in a good space mentally, this may not be the course for you.

best_comment: Highly recommend taking CS50 off cycle! Being able to watch the lectures on my own time (and on 2x speed) was great, and still having the section component was very helpful. I had no coding experience prior to this course, and while I did struggle at times, it was very worth it. I had a great time working through the psets and doing my final project.
worse_comment: Make sure you have the space in your schedule and mental capacity for the demands of this course. If you already have a full plate or you are not in a good space mentally, this may not be the course for you.

best_comment: This class is time consuming, but it is incredibly fulfilling and worth it. It's perfectly reasonable to take it with no programming experience – they do a really good job of teaching everything from the bottom up.

This class is time consuming, but it is incredibly fulfilling and worth it. It's perfectly reasonable to take it with no programming experience – they do a really good job of teaching everything from the bottom up.

Obviously it's CS50, it's not going to be the easiest class ever. David Malan is a great lecturer. I really was able to pick up a lot from lectures and I feel like sections were great as well. Its. a lot of content and you learn a lot. I honestly would recommend this class with enthusiasm. I really liked taking it off–cycle as well. I could never sit through two–three hour lectures, but I know I would still try to go. Being able to watch the lectures on your own time makes it a lot easier for me to retain the information and the quizzes were helpful to make sure you understood what was going on.

Obviously it's CS50, it's not going to be the easiest class ever. David Malan is a great lecturer. I really was able to pick up a lot from lectures and I feel like sections were great as well. Its. a lot of content and you learn a lot. I honestly would recommend this class with enthusiasm. I really liked taking it off–cycle as well. I could never sit through two–three hour lectures, but I know I would still try to go. Being able to watch the lectures on your own time makes it a lot easier for me to retain the information and the quizzes were helpful to make sure you understood what was going on.

Be prepared for super long hours on a couple weeks. I think taking it in the spring is totally fine, but also be prepared to not have as much fun as your fall peers due to lack of events, and to potentially have less access to office hours due to the smaller class size. On the whole though, TAs are super amazing and communicative, and you'll be totally fine.
worse_comment: The grading is ridiculous. I had to take this as a very senior CS undergrad because I needed one more requirement. Any advanced programming technique is strongly discourages (I would lose points). Similarly, the checks for understanding are graded so arbitrarily.

best_comment: Be prepared for super long hours on a couple weeks. I think taking it in the spring is totally fine, but also be prepared to not have as much fun as your fall peers due to lack of events, and to potentially have less access to office hours due to the smaller class size. On the whole though, TAs are super amazing and communicative, and you'll be totally fine.
worse_comment: The grading is ridiculous. I had to take this as a very senior CS undergrad because I needed one more requirement. Any advanced programming technique is strongly discourages (I would lose points). Similarly, the checks for understanding are graded so arbitrarily.

best_comment: This is a really good class, but it is also uniquely old–school, which is sort of what everyone is really complaining about. Classes in Harvard CS no longer *really* need you to read the textbook, or go to class, or really meaningfully engage with the material in any way, and instead hold your hand all the way through (yes, even 124, where the only thing you really need to pass the class is religious devotion to office hours). CS51 is specifically designed to avoid this, and therefore forces you to do all of these things: I think this is great pedagogy, and it is a fantastic way of learning (even as one of the older students in the class, I still feel like I came away with a ton), but I can see how students who come in just having taken CS50 and expecting a similar experience may be a bit blindsided.The hours/week are not bad: PSETs are themed, which makes them pretty interesting to complete (there's music generation, epidemic simulation, and cryptography, among others) and really don't take that long (I rarely had to go to office hours, for instance). The downsides are the two exams AND a final project, which is honestly a bit much; I'd be in favor of dropping a PSET, going down to 7, moving the final exam to be during finals period, and moving the project down to be due the last day of classes.Prof. Shieber is also amazing: he is, like the class, old–school, but this is not a bad thing –– he genuinely wants to see you grow in the class, and is generally a very knowledgeable, approachable guy even though he is one of the titans of the field. Overall, a pretty fun class, I'd take it again.
worse_comment: If you are not super comfortable with programming, don't take this class. CS50 is set up to help you succeed. CS51 is not. I have only finished two semesters at Harvard, but I can say with confidence that this is the most disorganized class I've taken here so far. For the first half of the class, office hours weren't available until Saturdays (the lengthy psets are due every Wednesday). There are no office hours on Wednesday, but that's because you are expected to start early, yet no office hours until Saturday. I will say, they eventually added Thursday office hours, though they were cancelled half the time. It also became clear that office hours were also set up so that less people would go (quad at 8pm, quad at 10am on a Sunday). There are other office hours though, but just know you may be waiting a very long time to ask one question. As for the exams, the first exam was nothing like the practice exams and the solutions were never even posted on the course website (good luck if you have a regrade request!). The second exam was definitely more fair, though there was a derivation question that wasn't like anything we'd learned in the course, but I will be reasonable and mention that it was on a previous practice exam, but it's more like something you'd do in CS124, so I don't understand why it's on this exam. I know some people loved this class, but I hated it personally. It took up so much time for no t much return, and prevented me from focusing on classes that are actually decently structured like math and expos. If you already have limited time, DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. If you require a strong support system and are very frustrated by disorganization, DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. Pset grading takes forever. And even then, once it's graded and you can see the autograder results, you can't see how you lost points on the autograder. Oh and there's a midterm on the last day of class (a final basically) and still, there's a final project. I also think it says something that so many people switched to pass–fail after the first exam, which had a mean that was not a passing score, but hey, curves are a thing so take that w a grain of salt. Anyways I hated this class and the horrible organization and assignments but there is a chance you may like it.

CS51 is specifically designed to avoid this, and therefore forces you to do all of these things: I think this is great pedagogy, and it is a fantastic way of learning (even as one of the older students in the class, I still feel like I came away with a ton), but I can see how students who come in just having taken CS50 and expecting a similar experience may be a bit blindsided.The hours/week are not bad: PSETs are themed, which makes them pretty interesting to complete (there's music generation, epidemic simulation, and cryptography, among others) and really don't take that long (I rarely had to go to office hours, for instance). Overall, a pretty fun class, I'd take it again.

The second exam was definitely more fair, though there was a derivation question that wasn't like anything we'd learned in the course, but I will be reasonable and mention that it was on a previous practice exam, but it's more like something you'd do in CS124, so I don't understand why it's on this exam. I know some people loved this class, but I hated it personally. It took up so much time for no t much return, and prevented me from focusing on classes that are actually decently structured like math and expos. If you already have limited time, DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. If you require a strong support system and are very frustrated by disorganization, DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. Pset grading takes forever. And even then, once it's graded and you can see the autograder results, you can't see how you lost points on the autograder. Oh and there's a midterm on the last day of class (a final basically) and still, there's a final project. I also think it says something that so many people switched to pass–fail after the first exam, which had a mean that was not a passing score, but hey, curves are a thing so take that w a grain of salt. Anyways I hated this class and the horrible organization and assignments but there is a chance you may like it.

best_comment: I think that when you look at a Q guide review, you should gauge how much your background matches that of the people who write these. For reference, I went into this class not having taken very many CS classes (only AP CS and CS 50 online), but I had learned about functional programming with Haskell in high school. I have more background in pure math and math competitions, and I briefly did coding competitions in high school.Honestly, I think the content presented in this class is very solid and gives you a good overview of different programming paradigms. I think OCaml really lends itself well to this, and I would agree that the course is more about programming than it is about OCaml. However, I think that the way the content is presented, in the textbook or the (absence of) lectures, makes it hard to fully recommend this class. The flipped classroom format doesn't really work for me, and I feel that more content could be covered if lectures were spent discussing new concepts. The textbook contains all of the material needed,  but it can also be unnecessarily dense at times, with the professor adding his own anecdotes and extra–complicated words (and I mean truly words that have no application to computer science or anything else) that make the course feel a little slow.I took this class to satisfy my Prog 2 requirement (since I didn't take CS 50). In hindsight, I think I had enough CS background to skip CS 51 and take CS 61 and something else like CS 109a. Still, I think this class is a solid introduction if you don't have experience from CS 50 or took CS 50 and want to see a little more CS before diving in. You should also check https://cs51.io/college/syllabus/ to view the average time per pset each week.
worse_comment: FIRST YEARS, DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. The name CS51 implies that it is a continuation from CS50. It is anything but. This class covers concepts entirely unrelated to CS50 and it is much more difficult. Furthermore, not that many first years are in this class bc many people take this second sem sr yr or at random points throughout undergrad and I think having more CS experience is helpful for the class. I had read many q reports that said not to take this class but I brushed them off because I had years of CS experience and thought that CS50 was really easy so I didn't think this class would be that hard. However, OCaml is such an unintuitive language and the class almost seems designed to make learning it more difficult. The flipped classroom style is painful, the textbook does not explain things well, the videos (prob the only saving grace) don't cover enough content, the labs are nearly useless, and the psets are impossible without going to every single office hours. This class is truly horrendous, but it didn't have to be . If you are a first year deciding between this class and CS20, take CS20 –– it is a pre req for a lot of higher level CS classes (whereas CS51 is not) and is much better taught. I didn't take CS20 and I now regret it, and I also regret taking CS51.

best_comment: For all of you who are paying for this university out of pocket, in terms of being efficient for your tuition, this is negatively efficient for your tuition. This course's prerequisites are that you have done a CS internship, but CS 1060 reteaches you the least important concepts in the most confusing way possible or YouTube–able way possible. As it's the first time this course is being offered, I want to give the course staff the benefit of the doubt as they have a large task at hand –– managing a ton of student teams and ensuring that they all work together and work well to create a fully tested and developed product. However, the course itself can do with a lot of restructuring and improvements to narrow down the scope of what is taught and in handling the assignments in the course. To begin, the homework is extremely wordy and most of the time difficult to understand (with points taken off arbitrarily for things like naming, etc). The biggest investment you have to make in this course is the number of times you have to re–log into Canvas after Harvard changed their login to Okta to open the 10 tabs you'll need to understand a single portion of the poorly worded homework problem where you'll be spending 2.5x the time you actually spent on the homework on deploying your app. The in class attendance reading quizzes were inconsistent at best and extremely undoable at worst, specifications for the final projects were given late, the lecture topics weren't planned well, and the TFs were unknowledgeable about fundamental grading criteria regarding projects, and feedback itself was generally unspecific and SAT/UNSAT homework assignments, although well intentioned, encouraged team members to just 'get the work done' regardless of the quality of the code or work. The extra credit for talking in class, responding on Ed, etc. was vague and there's not a great way to track this.Harvard is in desperate need of an industry standard software engineering course especially with all of the theoretical and research focus in the degree, and it's great that we're moving towards a more application direction outside of the systems and HCI courses (61, 161, 178, 262, 265, etc). This class attempts to tackle a lot of topics, and although a prerequisite of the course is having done multiple CS courses or an internship, the course has a fault of either introducing fundamental topics such as git way too late in the semester, assuming an understanding of fundamental software engineering concepts (i.e. code reviews, testing, deployment, etc), or in having a hard time finding a balance between teaching software engineering and generative AI. Until we have a more robust foundation for software engineering concepts in the coursework at Harvard, it can be difficult to assemble groups and assume that everyone is on a similar knowledge level on engineering concepts. I was surprised that even some general architecture / writing usable code (concepts such as KISS, SOLID principles, factories, etc) weren't covered, although this is more on the general software engineering side rather than software engineering and generative AI. I wish there was a focus on more fundamental topics in order to help teammates as people are coming from different backgrounds, and being in a team where half of the team doesn't know how git works can doom you to merge conflict hell.Regardless of all of this, this is one of the most useful CS courses that you'll be able to do if you want a good understanding of software engineering or just want to be forced to work a LOT with generative AI (if you haven't been doing so already.) It introduces people to something that will be very important to know for the future, ticketing with Linear, working with Git with many other people, and more. It's a very well intentioned course that can be successful and a fundamental one to take for every CS student in future iterations. Christopher, although he can be a bit of a personality that some people may not like, is knowledgable, helpful, and always available and understanding. Christopher clearly cares a lot about the course and is a great person to get to know –– we do need more courses like this at Harvard. However, for the course as it is now, going in with a good team that's excited to work together on a project idea will make or break your experience. The actual experience of working with different generative AI tools and learning how to prompt engineer, debug, and write tests is extremely helpful for the future. However, if you're less familiar with some software lifecycle concepts or are going in alone, I'd be cognizant of taking this course if you don't want to be hunting down teammates to submit assignments.

course_title: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001
best_comment: 209b is really fantastic, and the topics we discuss feel very relevant and current. I had mixed feelings about 209a, but I really enjoyed 209b. I'd say that while the general workload of the homework is roughly the same in 209b as in 209a, I found the homework in 209b to be more interesting and enjoyable to complete. I believe that 209a and 209b truly built the foundation for the SM in Data Science program, and I'm glad I took both. Pavlos, Chris, and Nitesh are all fantastic instructors, and I am grateful that I had the opportunity to learn from them.
worse_comment: You can learn a lot from the class but the experience is not easy.

best_comment: This might be the best course I've taken. Obviously this is a hard class. I recommend making this your only hard class tbh to give it the time and attention it deserves. As someone who got an A without a cracked background (took CS50 & 51, etc.) who didn't take CS20/120/121 before this class (I did do Math101, which I thought was really great prep for proofs), I think it is very possible to succeed in this class if you put in the time. I think going to lecture is very helpful. Watching recordings is almost always a worse way to learn. Doing the problem sets yourself and not trying to cheat your way through them is the single most important thing to succeed in this class. You learn this stuff by thinking really hard about it, getting really frustrated, and then going to OH to understand what you're not understanding. Course staff is great and full of cracked people that are very open to help you. Kitty, Maxwell, Collin are all especially amazing. Overall one of my favorite and most useful classes I've taken at this school, and Madhu + Sitan are both really great. Good luck!
worse_comment: Take it bc are you a real cs major if you don't? First half of the course is interesting but the later half is a drag. All throughout the course materials are incredibly confusing, misleading at times, and the slides are just so boring and made with no effort at all. Professors are nice and actually help out with pset problems but pedagogically have not made a lot of effort.

best_comment: You will learn fundamental results like the G–S theorem: that it is mathematically impossible for a voting rule to have all three following properties: free from manipulation, any candidate can theoretically win, and voters are incentivized to report honest rankings of their preferred candidates. Or that for two–sided matchings, it is mathematically impossible to have a rule that incentivize both sides to be honest–reporting, while resulting in a matching that is stable (where pairs won’t want to switch partners). Or that for allocating schools to students, it’s impossible to have a mechanism that satisfy all the following properties together: incentivizes honest–reporting, equal treatment of students with equal preferences, and doesn’t result in a subpar matching that a better matching exists. Incredibly fundamental results with extremely practical results.Probably the best class I have taken at Harvard (but this is conditioning on me as a junior and after taken some proof classes, and is interested in voting and allocating resources and fairness) (I am not a 55 kid though)Time split by week, rounded up by hour2, 5, 4, 2, 13, 6, 3, 7, 5, 7, 8, 4, 13, 2, 5, 3The two spikes are 2/23–3/3 (one week before midterm) and 4/20–4/28 (one week before reading period, last pset, I think I was doing some catching–up studying during this week).Lectures are required, but Ariel’s lectures are the best I have had at Harvard. I really like the pace, and I can understand everything at that pace without feeling bored. Attendance is monitored through in class quizzes about new material, which are honestly quite fun. The slides are also well–made and beautiful. The material is well–motivated and presented logically, with definitions clearly defined, and examples to illustrate. Ariel is also very responsive Ed.I think the value to effort ratio is pretty high, given that I spend <7 hours per week. Note that the value is intellectual value though.All in all, highly recommend!
worse_comment: Solid course. Lectures and psets are fun, but the tests are just a few very memorization based question which just feels a little bad.

best_comment: Overall: CS 1430 works its way from the basics of network layers to the concepts and protocols underlying modern networks, including wireless networks, satellite networks, and blockchain. It culminates with your final project that will build on an advanced topic of your choice. Topics and course structure are subject to change year–to–year with emerging trends, particularly in AI (in both your learning and in AI learning).Professor: HT is lovely. The class is quite concept–driven (especially in the era of generative AI), with HT making sure you understand “why” protocols are designed the way they are, “where” a protocol applies, and “what” assumptions are behind the protocol, beyond just “how” it is implemented. Textbooks: Kurose and Ross is useful for nitty–gritty protocol details (particularly for the first programming assignment), though don’t get too caught up in the nitty–gritty. Kurose and Ross, Computer Networking: A Top–Down Approach, Eighth Edition. Topics covered: Network layers and protocols (Physical layer, link layer, network layer, transport layer, application); L1–to–L3 interactions; L2 switching and L3 routing; routing protocols (distance vector, link–state); L4 transport protocols (TCP, UDP); TCP congestion control; wireless networking (antennas, RF, ALOHA, CSMA CA/CD, CSMA backoff, ns–3 simulation); internet from space (LEO, inter–sat links, HARQ), software–defined networks; network security (public key, Diffie–hellman, RSA, hash chain, DNS); blockchain/bitcoin (decentralized distributed ledger, public key encryption and authentication, ownership transfer, double–spending prevention, proof–of–work consensus, bitcoin mining and incentives), AI–assisted networking (reinforcement learning (RL) based random access channel protocol vs. slotted ALOHA, RL–based congestion control vs. TCP). Course structure notes: Two programming assignments (one individual, one group), two open–note midterms, group final project presentation and write–up on an advanced topic of your choice.
worse_comment: This is the worst class I have taken at Harvard. The professor mumbles and cannot teach the subject in a coherent manner. It was very boring and attendance was arbitrary. Never in my life have I experienced a professor consistently disrupt me and dismiss my ideas instead of giving constructive criticism. I cannot recommend this class. The material can be interesting but there is a lack of support and the professor expects the world from you despite not being able to teach the subject well. Unfortunately, this is the best networks class we can get here at Harvard. It is so upsetting to be talked down upon when presenting your final project and constantly being dismissed.

best_comment: if you're on the edge about taking this, and you're not super interested in networking, don't take this course. this class is offered to the extension school, which isn't bad, but there ends up being 5 people in lecture all the time, so lecture isnt very engaging even though prof minlan is very nice, understanding, and an overall good lecturer. the topic is very niche and unironically not very applicable to swe work unless youre a senior level swe (even then idk), and u can pick up 75% of the content by reading the textbook (which is p good for this course). all in all, im not sure how much i took away from this course. its not hard to get an A due to the generous extra credit (u can get like a 160/100 on one of the projects if u do the extra credit), and it seems like the TFs just check to see if the tests pass on your code and if they do, you get a 100 for the project. section is pretty helpful, Ed support is meh, TFs are nice but grading is slow. no final; just a final project which is pretty simple. memorize the slides and read the textbook for the midterm, i think the mean was around 48/60 this year

This has been a crazy (in a great way) class, and I've really enjoyed it. The material is very, very abstract, so it may be a bit unintuitive at first, but there are a lot of tidbits here and there that make for very interesting material –– some really weird math is sometimes sprinkled in to formalize things, and it's always quite fun. I think this class plays a complementary role to CS121: if your CS education is a brick wall, 121 is the grout, and 152 is the finishing coat, filling in the few details that really make everything work together. As someone who has never cared at all about systems, for instance, the framework given in 152 has really inspired me to go think about the implementations of programming languages in compilers, etc. in ways I'd really brushed off before.The class itself is not a huge amount of work: to be sure, it's backloaded, so be careful about the amount of work at the end of the semester, but the exams were fair, the TFs very helpful (shoutout to my personal GOAT, Jonas), and Prof. Amin is incredibly knowledgeable about the material and friendly. Her knowledge of the material is a bit of a double–edged sword: she's clearly incredibly smart and a fantastic researcher, but this means she assumed we all are, too, so a lot of the examples given in class are a bit too difficult to pick up on the fly, and I think they could benefit from a tad more hands–on time with the material over pure powerpoint lecture (she live–codes in a really impressive way, though, I have to give her that).I thoroughly enjoyed this class, and would highly recommend it to folks looking to round out their theoretical CS education or looking for a good bridge between theory and systems, because you really see both come alive.
worse_comment: There are not many good spring classes, so this one is one of the only ones that is relatively chill. Not a lot of good options tbh.

best_comment: If you enjoy systems (taking CS 61 will probably help you make an informed opinion about systems), enjoy long hours of programming and debugging and not having a life, this is the class for you :DIn all seriousness, I loved 161. I think it's truly a transformative and fun experience working on low–level systems programming. Assignments were long but definitely very enjoyable and give you both a lot to learn and the opportunity to really sharpen your skills as a programmer and solidify your understanding of lecture concepts. Mickens is an incredible instructor and lecturer and there is not a single dull moment in his lectures. Remember to appreciate his incredible PowerPoint skills as you explore the lecture slides with great awe. There are diagrams – quite a lot of them. But fear not, they'll become your friends (maybe). You'll be acquainted with quite a few recurrent characters, such as the pagetable walk diagram, Bob and Alice, angry/condescending Linus Torvalds, The Internet™©, the great address space VOID, struct proc, the Duolingo streak and Bitmoji James. All characters that you will remember in the years to come as you smile and reminisce about an unforgettable 161 experience. This class is definitely legendary to me and I am thoroughly glad I had the opportunity to take it. Highly recommended!

Professor Doshi–Velez is amazing! Prof. David Alvarez–Melis is very kind and makes the class fun and is very personable. I am a bit biased towards Doshi because she was my first female CS professor, but learning from her was an absolute privilege. She is passionate about her work, and sharing her knowledge and excitement with student.  I'm ngl this class is hard. Imo, not 124 hard, but the exams are nothing like the psets. The psets are fun, lectures are understandable and you learn a lot, but exams are a whole different beast. Be prepared to really exercise your brain linear algebra wise. Could not recommend this class enough! Very glad I took it. Also I've had friends take 182 over this but I would highly recommend 181 because I think what you get from will truly make you a better computer scientist when you come out.
worse_comment: This course is, frankly, an embarrassment to the Harvard CS program. While the material is both essential and fascinating, it is being held hostage by disorganized instruction and inexcusable sloppiness. I’m a graduate student, and when I reflect on the best courses I’ve taken, I usually favor the ones that have challenged me. This course did challenge me—but for all the wrong reasons.The course started out promising. After the first lecture, I assumed the harsh Q–reports from previous semesters had been exaggerated. But there were early warning signs: major typos in the homework assignments that required several corrections and derivation mistakes during lectures. Unfortunately, after the midterm, the course completely unraveled. The midterm itself was a mess, and the quality of the lectures sharply declined afterward.–––––––––––––––––––––––TL;DR–––––––––––––––––––––––This course feels like a slap in the face to Harvard students. It is shocking that it has been allowed to continue in such a dysfunctional state for multiple semesters, despite consistent and negative student feedback. If you take this class, you’ll likely survive it—but you’ll be learning in a disorganized and chaotic environment. It is high time that the CS department intervene. I would strongly consider taking the course at MIT if you are able to. –––––––––––––––––––––––Homework–––––––––––––––––––––––Typically, I start homework assignments the day they are released. In this course, I delayed by a week to avoid the initial wave of typos, broken code, and vague or poorly phrased questions. Even waiting didn’t always spare me from those issues. Content–wise, the homeworks are average. Grading, however, felt inconsistently nitpicky—not the biggest problem in the class.–––––––––––––––––––––––Teaching–––––––––––––––––––––––It is no wonder that the lectures aren’t recorded. There can’t be video evidence of this slop.  Finale is a capable lecturer, but David was an inconsistent mess.  His insecurity and incompetence are a large part of what is making this course so frustrating. His motto should be “good catch,” because that is what he says when a student points out a glaring error in his math.  At this point, I don’t trust what’s written on the board until I verify it against the textbook myself. I don't fully trust the textbook, but at least it's a concrete thing I can refer to. It's clear Finale is delegating much of the professorial work to David because of her demanding schedule. It is also clear David is not rising to this challenge. –––––––––––––––––––––––Midterm–––––––––––––––––––––––The midterm was a disaster. It was far too long, riddled with typos that had to be corrected in real time, and included poorly constructed questions. Nearly everyone I spoke with didn’t finish it in time. I left the exam demoralized.What was the pedagogical reasoning behind assigning an exam that most students were bound to fail? Was it some kind of hazing ritual? A test of ego? Why not simply assess the material as it was actually taught?Before the exam, I overheard Finale mention to David that a particular question “really made me think” and “took a while to work through.” I’d ask the professors to reflect on how long it took them to solve that problem—and then consider how long it might take a student seeing it for the first time under strict time pressure. How is that pedagogically sound? What is being accomplished? –––––––––––––––––––––––Final Exam–––––––––––––––––––––––The final exam was also long and very difficult. I read the entire textbook, reworked every problem, and reviewed the lectures multiple times—and still received a poor grade. At least the time limit wasn’t as much of a constraint as during the midterm.–––––––––––––––––––––––Final Thoughts–––––––––––––––––––––––As of now, final grades have not been released. Without a curve, my grade is around 75%, despite earning A–level marks on all non–exam material. I genuinely have no idea what my final grade will be, because the course team has failed to communicate that information. That lack of transparency reflects a broader disrespect toward students.

There can’t be video evidence of this slop.  Finale is a capable lecturer, but David was an inconsistent mess.  His insecurity and incompetence are a large part of what is making this course so frustrating. His motto should be “good catch,” because that is what he says when a student points out a glaring error in his math.  At this point, I don’t trust what’s written on the board until I verify it against the textbook myself. I don't fully trust the textbook, but at least it's a concrete thing I can refer to. It's clear Finale is delegating much of the professorial work to David because of her demanding schedule. It is also clear David is not rising to this challenge. –––––––––––––––––––––––Midterm–––––––––––––––––––––––The midterm was a disaster. It was far too long, riddled with typos that had to be corrected in real time, and included poorly constructed questions. Nearly everyone I spoke with didn’t finish it in time. I left the exam demoralized.What was the pedagogical reasoning behind assigning an exam that most students were bound to fail? Was it some kind of hazing ritual? A test of ego? Why not simply assess the material as it was actually taught?Before the exam, I overheard Finale mention to David that a particular question “really made me think” and “took a while to work through.” I’d ask the professors to reflect on how long it took them to solve that problem—and then consider how long it might take a student seeing it for the first time under strict time pressure. How is that pedagogically sound? What is being accomplished? –––––––––––––––––––––––Final Exam–––––––––––––––––––––––The final exam was also long and very difficult. I read the entire textbook, reworked every problem, and reviewed the lectures multiple times—and still received a poor grade. At least the time limit wasn’t as much of a constraint as during the midterm.–––––––––––––––––––––––Final Thoughts–––––––––––––––––––––––As of now, final grades have not been released. Without a curve, my grade is around 75%, despite earning A–level marks on all non–exam material. I genuinely have no idea what my final grade will be, because the course team has failed to communicate that information. That lack of transparency reflects a broader disrespect toward students.

best_comment: Professor Doshi–Velez is amazing! Prof. David Alvarez–Melis is very kind and makes the class fun and is very personable. I am a bit biased towards Doshi because she was my first female CS professor, but learning from her was an absolute privilege. She is passionate about her work, and sharing her knowledge and excitement with student.  I'm ngl this class is hard. Imo, not 124 hard, but the exams are nothing like the psets. The psets are fun, lectures are understandable and you learn a lot, but exams are a whole different beast. Be prepared to really exercise your brain linear algebra wise. Could not recommend this class enough! Very glad I took it. Also I've had friends take 182 over this but I would highly recommend 181 because I think what you get from will truly make you a better computer scientist when you come out.
worse_comment: This course is, frankly, an embarrassment to the Harvard CS program. While the material is both essential and fascinating, it is being held hostage by disorganized instruction and inexcusable sloppiness. I’m a graduate student, and when I reflect on the best courses I’ve taken, I usually favor the ones that have challenged me. This course did challenge me—but for all the wrong reasons.The course started out promising. After the first lecture, I assumed the harsh Q–reports from previous semesters had been exaggerated. But there were early warning signs: major typos in the homework assignments that required several corrections and derivation mistakes during lectures. Unfortunately, after the midterm, the course completely unraveled. The midterm itself was a mess, and the quality of the lectures sharply declined afterward.–––––––––––––––––––––––TL;DR–––––––––––––––––––––––This course feels like a slap in the face to Harvard students. It is shocking that it has been allowed to continue in such a dysfunctional state for multiple semesters, despite consistent and negative student feedback. If you take this class, you’ll likely survive it—but you’ll be learning in a disorganized and chaotic environment. It is high time that the CS department intervene. I would strongly consider taking the course at MIT if you are able to. –––––––––––––––––––––––Homework–––––––––––––––––––––––Typically, I start homework assignments the day they are released. In this course, I delayed by a week to avoid the initial wave of typos, broken code, and vague or poorly phrased questions. Even waiting didn’t always spare me from those issues. Content–wise, the homeworks are average. course_title: Planning and Learning Methods in AI 001
best_comment: This was a difficult class (maybe not as bad as CS 124 but honestly pretty close) but a valuable one –– the content is obviously very relevant and applicable in today's world. I'd recommend the Math 21 series and Stat 110 as minimum prereqs and taking another CS course or another AI course will def make things easier too. Since things were restructured recently there was a lot of parts of the course that felt a bit disorganized, but that will hopefully be better next time. Biweekly psets (in different phases –– group coding, individual coding, and theory –– with the chance for a "second pass") were manageable but because basically everyone got perfect scores on them with the second pass it created a lot of pressure for the exams. I did poorly on the midterm but well on the final so I have no idea what my grade will be. OH and section support was good, especially the undergrad TFs, and professors were accessible at their own office hours too. Super interesting content overall (although perhaps went a bit quickly through some of the most modern methods) and I'm glad I took the class!
worse_comment: Horrible class. DO NOT TAKE.Strange pset system in which it's "bi–weekly" but each week you need to submit something and on the second week it's like having two psets, group and individual. Very poorly organized and staff is not accommodating at all, this class is horrible.  They try to put it as if you participate in the class, you will do well, but this is not true. I would not recommend participating. It is a waste of time and they do not care whatsoever. They only care about the exams. Papon is also super rude. You're supposed to do a "second pass" on psets to fix your mistakes, before they even grade it, and without a rubric to evaluate yourself.I am left with a very bitter experience from this class. If you're forced to take this class I feel sorry for you. I hated this class and you will too.

best_comment: Harry is retiring RIP, but this course was genuinely one of my favorite things I have ever done in college. This course made up for all of the true academic conversations I wish I had in other courses across other disciplines, and is both light on the workload but so so so rewarding on the development as a Computer Scientist and understanding what CS research actually is, which is a nebulous void for most people before taking this class. Although Prof. Lewis is retiring, this class is much more than the sum of it's parts and I hope thatin the future someone half as amazing as Harry Lewis can revive this class because it has been truly a life changing experience for me.
worse_comment: Take this class. But you can't. Cuz Harry Lewis is now retired :(
best_gem_comment: THIS CLASS IS A GEM! please take if you need to balance other classes. you have the option to use the first submission period for your final video project and if you like your grade in the class you're done with major assignments by mid–april which was so nice as my fifth class

course_title: Designing K–12 Computer Science Learning Experiences 001
best_comment: AMAZING COURSE! This class provides a robust overview of different tools and topics in the K12 CS space. Each class they follow a different structure discussing the case studies. All resources and classes are incredibly well–thought out and fascinating. KB and Brian (sad that he's left) really make this course special. They're endless support for each person's projects and each person's progression through life is truly incredible. They foster an amazing class community, and really embody great teaching. If you can get the opportunity, I would highly encourage anyone interested to take this class. It's so worth it! The final project has a lot of freedom and I really encourage you to pick something you really want to learn about and to run with it. Make sure to make progress each week :)

course_title: High Performance Computing for Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: This is the best course I've taken at Harvard and I strongly recommend taking it if you're even curious. The lectures are engaging, and difficult. The material is technically complex, but the assignments are incredibly reasonable (much easier than the material I found), which made me feel like I had some extra time to dedicate to reviewing the harder concepts from the lectures. The project topics are admittedly a bit constrained, and come project time I was spending probably 20–30 hours a week on just the project, but we chose a bad topic, so invest meaningful time early in a project design. Your peers are also likely to be...unaccommodating... on the cluster towards the due date of the project, so plan accordinglyThe teachers are incredible – I think Chuck, Ignacio and Chris all have a unique flavor of HPC they bring to the lectures, and the lectures are an awesome balance of material and practical coding or demonstrations.  They know their stuff and are truly receptive on the Ed board to fairly technically difficult questions if you're stuck. If you ask for help, they don't let you struggle alone, which is really cool. If you're curious, take this class.

This was an interesting course. Prof. Vadhan is clearly very knowledgeable, and has done much interesting work in the area. The course itself is not particularly technical, but rather focuses on applications and discussions. Many of the readings are journal/magazine articles regarding opinions of privacy, and privacy from various viewpoints. There is an introduction to the basic technical details, e.g. definitions of DP, elementary mechanisms, and properties such as post–processing, etc. Overall, the course does well to provide a broad introduction of DP, both from a theory and application standpoint. Nonetheless, I feel that there could have been more depth and pace to the class. For instance, the introduction to DP–ML discussed some elementary algorithms such as DP–SGD and their implementation, but did not go further beyond (whereas in the literature there are both many optimization algorithms, as well as various proof techniques). Class sometimes consisted of discussions, which were nice, and going over code, which probably could have been omitted (probably reading a 100–line jupyter notebook could be assigned as homework). There are weekly problem sets, which take a relatively short (but still not completely trivial) amount of time. Lastly, there is a final project, which I quite enjoyed. Prof. Vadhan's feedback is quite good, and the field of DP contains a significant amount of interesting theory and application. The poster presentations at the end were interesting and allowed us to see the breadth of work done by other groups. I would probably encourage taking cs226 for a more theoretical side of this course, but if you are interesting to knowing the basics of privacy and learning an overview of where privacy mechanisms are applied, this would be a fitting course.
worse_comment: lectures are pretty bad imo. The textbook is OK, but not superbly written (it's a disappointment, since it's published recently and perhaps the fancy cover page would make you think that it's good). Attendance is mandatory, which makes the bad lectures even more resentful. I also think that the material taught by this class can be condensed into half of the semester. Psets are a pain and the grading is harsh, so I wouldn't even recommend taking this for a good grade easily. Readings can be interesting and practical, but apart from this, I would suggest you look elsewhere to learn differential privacy. (Cynthia Dwork who literally created the field is in Harvard! Maybe take her class instead). I also didn't go for sections. Depending on the TF, maybe sections can be good.Time breakdown by hour per week1,4,5,30,10,14,5,0,6,3,6,1,2,16,2
