course_title: Algorithms at the Ends of the Wire 001
best_comment: This course is definitely not the most deep, thorough, topic focused course in the CS department, but it covers a really interesting and broad spread of topics. You get to read some really cool and fundamental papers on bloom filters (and variants), ranking algorithms, compression techniques, and more, which are kind of old but still very relevant to the techniques we use today and definitely increased my understanding of these topics. There's also this focus on how to read a paper and how to do research in this class, which is definitely helpful if your just starting out and want some advice or direction. The program committee bit of the class at the end was also a lot of fun, since you got to ruthlessly evaluate papers and get a better understanding of why it's so hard to get a paper published at all. Lectures are a mix of discussing the paper and more traditional lecture–y style for explaining certain topics, and sometimes can be dry but generally are pretty good. I definitely think this is a class where you get out what you put in – if you don't really read the papers or just kind of sit through class without listening, you won't get much, but if you do read the papers and listen in class you'll probably learn some neat stuff about the history of common cs techniques.
worse_comment: Not the biggest fan

best_comment: You’re probably debating between this course and other theory courses if you’re a concurrent master’s student, and I recommend taking this one. It might not seem like the typical graduate–level class, with three psets and a take–home final, but although the psets are challenging, there’s usually a three–week gap between them, which makes the workload manageable. Overall, I’d say the difficulty level is moderate in terms of time commitment. The TFs are great and provide strong support, and the final project is a good opportunity to apply what you’ve learned. All in all, I’d say take it, you won’t regret it.
worse_comment: This course was a big disappointment. To be fair though, the Q reviews from previous years were not great, but I expected better and discarded the reviews. I was wrong. The course was pretty bad. Lectures are extremely dry, psets can literally be solved without any knowledge from the course (I.e. you can look up things in the textbook). Hence, the psets were a waste of time since I don't really think I am finishing this course with a better understanding of learning theory. I think many harvard CS courses suffer from this problem, but sometimes the teaching is so bad that you are better off learning the material on your own (or even better, take a similar course at MIT).  This course was a very good example of this.

best_comment: This is overall a strong CS grad course! I think you should have a strong or at least reasonable interest in formal methods to get the most out of this class, since most lectures focus on applying formal method x to analyze [insert some security issue], and if this sounds exciting for you, this class is great! Professor Chong is an extremely down–to–earth, engaging, and kind professor that is very accessible outside of class and I've really appreciated getting to know him better this semester. The psets had some pretty cool, fun problems. This course's emphasis is on the final project, so make sure you stay on top of your final project work throughout the semester.
worse_comment: TL;DR: I will describe this class using a Hoare triple.{Happy} CS 2540 {Sad}Now onto the details.This class is bad. Like, really bad. I wish “CS2540 says I speaksfor CS2540” so that I could make CS2540 say all the problems about itself. I want to robustly declassify and transparently endorse the pain of this class to the rest of the world while maintaining nonmalleable information flow.Starting with the lectures. They are not informative. On a lattice, it feels like Steve’s lectures are secret untrusted and I am public trusted with how difficult it is to make the lecture information flow to my brain. But when you ask a question, it flips; you suddenly become secret untrusted and public trusted as you can’t get any meaningful questions to Steve.It feels like Steve assumes too much during lectures. The prerequisites that he states (Good CS student and taken Formal Reasoning before) is nowhere enough as Steve will sometimes just skip over details and assume you know them when he has never taught them before. This creates problems; eventually he will just lose you unless you have studied this topic before, which is unfair to the students who took the listed prerequisites in good faith. Even with some knowledge of PL, a lot of his lectures are indecipherable. Steve says HisLectures speaksfor Steve, but the problem is that HisLectures says Indecipherable speaksfor HisLectures.Onto the homework. Why do they exist? What is the line between a “check” and a “check–plus” grade on the homework? Nobody knows. The line is so nonexistent that it will make you question whether you know the line using epistemic logic. What world are you in? Are you in a world where the line is clear? The homeworks say no. Are you in a world where you know that the homeworks are meaningful? The homeworks say no. In fact, using epistemic logic, you will eventually come to the conclusion that K_{You}(CS 2540 is a bad class). Of course, the only way you will know this is if you experience what set of worlds you may be in by taking the class, but I hope that this observation is enough for you.In fact, the class can be written in Tamarin like this. [CS2540()]––[]–>[Out(BadClass)]. Which, speaking of, is the worst homework I have experienced. No instructions, just pain. No practice in class, just pain. Steve gives you zero preconditions, and somehow expects your postcondition to contain happiness of working with Tamarin. Give us those preconditions. But given that the prerequisite list is terrible, is it a surprise that the preconditions are lacking?The project. Nothing but pain. Lack of instructions. Lack of rubrics. Lack of basis on grading. It’s so arbitrary that you can’t ever know if Steve is grading fairly or not. In fact, it seems likely that he isn’t. “Steve will always grade fairly” is a safety property, and if Execution Monitoring tried to enforce this property on this class, the class would have been canceled as soon as Steve began to grade. “Steve will eventually make good lectures for CS2540” is a liveness property, but it remains unsatisfied. No well–founded relation can be found to save this class.If you are still considering taking this course, think of a model of CS2540 that we will reason with. Reasoning through, we find that the class is vulnerable to a side channel. Through the pain it inflicts on its students, a side channel characterized by the stress of its students is created. Even when you have exploited this side channel, why would you try to experience a class of this exploitable model yourself? CS2540 and a class where you struggle and don’t learn much are contextually equivalent.To this end, remember that you have your secrets. With how public the pain of CS2540 is, if you want to enforce noninterference, you should not take this course and begin the transfer of information from a secret source to a public source. You might think you are going to take a fun formal reasoning course, but you have actually been exploited by a Man in the Middle Attack. You are communicating with a terrible class that is pretending to be a good formal reasoning course that has purposefully set up a Needham–Schroeder protocol to abuse this attack after throwing away Lowe from its protocol.Do not take this class. 1/5.

best_comment: Just take any class with Eddie. It's really that worth it. I think Eddie is that professor that makes me find a love for computer science in every class. Eddie made me love computer science in 61, and every class after that. My advice is, don't take advantage that Eddie is nice – really put in the work, participate in class and on projects. I wish I could have worked even harder than I did in this class – It is one of those you get what you put into it classes. I think I feel more comfortable with research, and I really found out that parts of papers which I am overly critical sometimes (evaluation) are so hard to get right. If you love CS, take this. If you want to love CS, take this. I think the biggest benefit for me is that after such a exhausting semester with many project failures(ish), there was so much warmth in this class that I feel that even if my project did not turn up how I wanted, I was happy with how the semester went and what I learned. Also, go talk to Eddie if you take this class!! Ask questions! Have opinions in class! Talk to your classmates!

I will be very surprised if this class is still offered, but if so, please try to avoid taking this class, even to fulfill the systems requirement for the SM. If I could go back in time, I would rather have dropped out of the SM and avoided taking this class. Please note that the following is my opinion, and in no way supposed to be an ad hominem critique of any of the course staff. The anecdotes I include are important to understanding why I have the opinion of the class I do.My background: CS61, 120, 124, AC209ab, other 2000–level CS, stat classes…I will touch on a couple points:0 – the readingsWaldo usually puts up 2–3 links for a lecture. One is usually an old paper, sometimes written in a very specific research group, assuming familiarity with terms no one has familiarity with. One is usually a link to a recent whitepaper/documentation (e.g. https://protobuf.dev/). No guidance on how much one should read into one or the other. Some are 60 or more pages, some are just a webpage. 90%+ of the class does not read the papers. When he asked in lecture, "how many of you think you understand how Paxos works," no one raised their hand. When he asked "how many think they do not understand," again no one is bothered enough to raise their hand. His reaction: "That's because none of you have read the paper." He is right. This kind of atmosphere sums up the attitude of students towards the class, and the atmosphere that lectures have.1 – lectures, the form:I attended nearly every lecture, kept notes, and still feel like I learned next to nothing. As you probably have heard, the slides are one word each. Ostensibly, this is to remind the professor what the flow is of what he wanted to cover. However, it seemed as though he has forgotten why he put some of the words on the slides, and thus, though he tries to find a way to weave from one word to the next in the context of what is being discussed, the lecture feels like a ramble, rather than us learning anything systematic about a distributed systems topic. This is the case throughout the semester.  The most interesting class was when the professor got the CEO of a small Boston area tech company and alum of the class to give a lecture about distributed systems in practice. This was a nice addition. The take–away from this class, ironically though, was "don't build distributed systems unless you really have to."2– lectures, the contentI think none of the material was particularly relevant to modern distributed systems– though I am still not proficient in them. You come to learn that most of the terms ("RPC, wire protocols, message passing, testing, byzantine failure") are just describing common sense design aspects you will learn anyway when building any larger–scale project. Learning about some obscure aspects of Java was not useful. You do not learn anything about networking, though this layer seems important for really understanding the design of wire protocols. The lectures that actually cover an interesting algorithm/content, like Paxos/Raft/Blockchain, are not well delivered. I learned more from a YouTube video on Raft than from the attempt at explaining the algorithm, which I felt did not cover the basic notions of how a 'quorum' works, for example. These classes felt as though the content was assumed to be known, and only the professor's (usually strong) prior opinion of Blockchain/Raft was being discussed. No real theory of distributed systems is built through the class, it is hard to see how the topics connect to each other. Most people stopped showing up to lecture pretty quickly.3– the assignmentsNearly everyone in the class used AI to complete the three assignments, the 'design exercises,' as the syllabus allowed. After I coded it myself, I found that ChatGPT O1 could pretty close to one–shot the design exercise based just on the design instructions given. The rest of your task was then to iron out tedious bugs. Many peers reported that they felt like there was "no point in trying to do the coding yourself anyway", because the implementation was mostly just nitpicky design details that didn't teach much about the distributed aspect (e.g. for the distributed messaging app, "If the recipient is logged in, deliver immediately; if not the message should be stored until the recipient logs in and requests to see the message.") This left the in–class demo–days devoid of much interesting discussion. Everyone had pretty much done the same thing, and many groups were just trying to show one another up, or pass something that AI had coded for them off as worthy of extra credit for the peer grading component of the course. Even these opportunities to show off one's work felt demoralizing, unfortunately.Miraculously, around 3 times more students showed up on demo day than on lecture days. This goes to show that lectures were not necessary to complete the assignment.The first of the assignments basically was most of the work of the class (though this was not clear from the start) one whole pset was just to redo how messages were communicated for the first assignment. One assignment was to implement Lamport Logical clocks that talk to each other, and most students agreed that they did not see the use in this assignment, that this felt largely like busy–work.If any feedback was given on assignment, it was usually a couple sentences based on a skim of your work.The extent of guidance given on the final project was not much more than that we should "demonstrate what we learned in the course" and a couple sentences of feedback on a proposal document. On group size, the professor discouraged any groups larger than two by saying "My general rule is that the difficulty of the final project should be proportional to 2**n, where n is the number of people on the team." This announcement came somewhat late. We were asked to create both the code with testing and documentation, a poster, and a 10–page write–up on our final project. It was not clear why all the different formats were necessary, as only the write–up was looked at it seems like.Despite all this, I still probably spent around 10h a week on the class.4 – the gradingPositive: Waldo and the course staff were supportive and gracious of late days for medical emergencies and other valid excuses.Negative: You are supposed to get enough information from your peers' 15–minute code reviews to give them a grade out of 5. The actual criteria by which you are to grade them are only released a day before the class. In one case, the criteria included that the lamport clock servers that communicate each be their own process, and that this be verified in the code review. This was a minor detail/unclear in the original spec, and many people rushed to redo their implementation, though it was not clear why this was at all important. You were also graded on how well you graded, with the stark warning that your grade would be impacted if your assigned grade was further than 1 point away from the grade the teaching staff give the project…A friend of mine had a Canvas grade of over 96% in 4 graded aspects of the class, coming down basically to two points missed out of 25 based on a misreading of their final project write–up. When the friend wrote an email to the course staff to inquire about some feedback on the final project that could only have been due to a misreading, the professor wrote back to them and said that due to his participation, he would raise their grade from an A– to an A in the class. It seems like grading is essentially up–curved at the very high mean grade that students have in the class (because everyone has done the same on the assignments) and your class grade mostly comes down to the impression the course staff get of your final project. It is still mind–boggling to me that a 96% could equate to an A–. Waldo was unwilling to release information on grade cut–offs:doing that means I get to deal with an large number of "you gave me three points less than I think I deserve" which is neither productive for learning nor a good useexe of time."5– the TFsthey did their best and were very approachable. no one showed up to their office hours for the most part.Please stay away from 262. You will feel unfulfilled at best, very pissed off at worst.
worse_comment: Problem sets every other week or so, and you do “demo days” where you present your findings/ code/ experiments to a group. Probably the most “software engineering” adjacent class you will find at Harvard.

best_comment: Reading the recent research papers and presenting to the class was initially intimidating, but it was a fantastic experience. The first half of the class is basically just looking at what is happening at the DASlab, their research, and an introduction to the systems project, which was so amazing that I wanted to implement both of them. The second half is where students present research papers; each group is responsible for presenting papers. Choosing a good group, prep for it. This class is a no–brainer; take it. I loved this class. Probably one of the best CS classes I've taken at Harvard.

course_title: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture 001
best_comment: Very useful and interesting class!

course_title: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture 001
best_comment: Very useful and interesting class!

course_title: The History and Evolution of Life on Earth 001
best_comment: Both professors are good lecturers and are engaged with the class. If you're interested in OEB, it's probably a good introductory class to the history of life. I had literally zero OEB knowledge going in which made some of the content basically roll off me because I had no background/frame of reference for it. The class isn't too difficult or time consuming—there's no pset, just lab assignments that are sometimes basically a pset. Labs were hit or miss. Some involved looking at cool fossils, and some were mostly googling what the differences between two random extinct plants are. I discovered about halfway through the class that I am not a history of plants and animals enjoyer, which unfortunately led to me going "why do we care?" about a lot of the later content (which is mostly that) despite the lectures being good. So if you're considering taking this to fulfill an EPS sub–discipline requirement, I'd recommend thoughtfully assessing how much the evolution of life actually interests you.
worse_comment: This class is interesting, and it is a pretty decent balance between biology and EPS. The work load is fair and the teaching staff is supportive, but make sure you stay up to date on the lecture notes and actually attend class. If you don't, thdings can start becoming a lot because such a large time span is covered. While the midterm and final are fair, they can become difficult if you do not spend enough time reviewing. Overall, this is a good course that teaches you a lot about how the Earth has evolved and changed over time. It is not super easy or super hard, but it requires consistent attention and effort to thrive.

course_title: The History and Evolution of Life on Earth 001

best_comment: Writing a thesis was one of my most rewarding undertakings at Harvard! Do not be afraid, choose a topic you care about, and embrace the ups and downs! Some advice I have for future thesis writers … 1. Choose a project or topic that means something to you (i.e. a physical location / earth system you’re interested in, a project with policy implications you care about, a methodology that would be challenging but rewarding for you to master). I found this went a long way in energizing me to work on my thesis. 2. Think about when you’ll have pockets of time to really focus on your thesis. For me, it was helpful to carve out designated days or couple day stretches to put other things aside and really focus on my thesis (senior year winter break was an especially important stretch for me). Also, choose a designated thesis cave location (thank you Peet’s Coffee and Ernst Mayr library)! 3. Reading as much of the existing literature on your topic as possible will help you gain confidence and feel like the project is your own. I felt like I gained the most traction with my thesis when I started actively bringing new ideas and questions to meetings with my advisors. 4. Lean on other people (even in other concentrations who are writing a thesis) — it is a communal experience and it is fun talking / learning about other people’s little intellectual worlds!

Lean on other people (even in other concentrations who are writing a thesis) — it is a communal experience and it is fun talking / learning about other people’s little intellectual worlds!

Be prepared to do the work, if you stay on top of it, you will cruise. I wasn’t a fan of the in class format personally but I could see how it works well for some. Eli is a fantastic lecturer, very entertaining and open minded. I would recommend this course for anyone interested in climate change and the math behind the science.
worse_comment: As someone who came into Harvard as a pretty committed climate activist with the intention of pursuing a full–time career in the environmental sciences, I’ll admit that I never thought it was possible to overstate the dangers of climate change. But this course challenged me to reconsider that assumption. I came to understand that there are real weaknesses and risks on both ends of the climate activism spectrum, whether through alarmism or denial. At the same time, the course helped me engage more deeply with the data itself, and I learned that while the evidence clearly supports the reality and urgency of climate change, it does not necessarily point to an immediate, apocalyptic collapse. That nuance was crucial.

best_comment: This class was definitely an experience. This class is a decent bit of work: I found the labs to be kind of confusing, and the exams were definitely harder than expected. BUT the benefits of the class ARE SO WORTH IT.  I switched to Pass/Fail after getting the lowest grade in the class on the midterm, but I would still strongly recommend this class. The content is SUPER INTERESTING, the professor is SO GOOD, and the TFs are THE BEST (I had Kristen and I can't recommend her enough!!!). I am a CS concentrator and I only took EPS 10 as preparation which definitely wasn't enough – I was hella out my comfort zone lol . Kristen was so helpful and literally guided me through the labs, which were quite fun once you got the hang of them. The labs were super interesting and useful, I definitely needed more help than a lot of my peers.This class was definitely one of my most memorable classes: the field trip to Pennsylvania was FIRE. We went to an oil rig, a coal mine, a wind farm, and a hydroelectric power station. I recommend this class SO SO MUCH: it's definitely hard, but it isn't too much work, and the teaching staff and field trip make it so worth it!!!!
worse_comment: Take this course!! Professor Shaw is an incredible lecturer and you learn a lot! The only draw back is that the labs use some software that can be a bit tough to work with at times.

best_comment: Great thermodynamics course that can be applied across most disciplines. Thermodynamics is often perceived as a difficult topic to comprehend, but I definitely think that Scot made it seem endurable and easier to understand.  Some concepts felt a little blurry, especially when you're looking at diagrams.  However, the books and lectures are mostly helpful. Section and office hours are definitely a key component of the course because that is where most of the application occurs. Also, be prepared to present every 2–3 weeks in this course. Most presentations are around 3 minutes and not too difficult if you put in the effort to learn the topic you want to discuss. Scot also likes to use cold–calling to induce classroom engagement.  I personally learn better in smaller sections/courses so definitely take this course if you need or are interested in thermo.

This is an extremely enjoyable and worthwhile class.  Professor Jacob is thoughtful, engaging, and very knowledgable; he clearly cares deeply about the course material and wants to make sure that his students not only understand but also care.  Problem sets are useful and manageable; the final presentations are a low–stakes opportunity to dive more deeply into a topic of personal interest. I took this class as my last engineering elective and am very glad I did.
best_gem_comment: A gem of an EPS class! Really interesting and engaging and relevant to a variety of environmental and chemistry topics. Daniel is a wonderful lecturer and the structure of the class is really great! More about how much you learn than about how much you can memorize.

best_comment: Take this class to understand how pollution issues manifest in our society! The class definitely leans more heavily towards being an EPS/ESPP class than an ESE one but there are still some strong foundations in math and environmental science (understanding differential equations, chemistry, fluid transport will help a lot). Elsie is an awesome instructor and expert in the field and is super approachable and willing to engage/empower students.  The course covers a lot of very important topics in the field of environmental toxicology/ pollution and I consider it an essential to anyone interested in the field of environmental protection!

course_title: State-of-the-Art Harvard Climate Observatory and Associated Instrumentation 001
best_comment: Professor Jim is amazing, truly one of a kind. He creates a supportive and encouraging classroom environment and always provides thoughtful, constructive feedback. He genuinely cares about his students’ growth and makes sure you understand how to improve. His teaching goes beyond the material, he helps you become a better thinker and learner.

This was one of my favorite classes I’ve ever taken at Harvard. It broadened my knowledge of our climate systems and I feel I have a grasp or general understanding of the basic climate dynamics that drive our earth system. This is definitely a challenging course for an undergraduate, mostly in the problem sets, but manageable with the right preparation. It isn’t too big of a time commitment outside of the difficulty of the psets (which again might be easier or harder for you depending on your math background). Eli is a wonderful professor, very excited about the material, and one of the best to teach the course. Strongly recommend taking this course, just know it would be one of your more intermediate to hard courses on your schedule.
Fun project–based course. You really get out what you put in. Great vibes and Steve is fantastic.
worse_comment: I would like to tell future students that the course can be very chaotic and frustrating, so it's important to be prepared for that

course_title: Topics in Mineral Physics and Chemistry: A Tour of the Solar System 001
best_comment: Rebecca is an excellent professor! She did such a good job facilitating student–led discussions, I feel like I learned so much so effortlessly in this class.

course_title: Sea Level Change and the Human Experience 001
best_comment: I enjoyed this class. The content is very interesting and provides insight into both earth science/physics of sea level change as well as its paleo and modern human implications. I appreciated our discussions of archaeology and the chance to look at sea level implications for archaeological sites in our projects. Professor Mitrovica (Jerry) is an engaging lecture and is very approachable and willing to answer questions and provide further clarification. Natasha is also fantastic – she helped guide me through understanding how the concepts from class are applied in sea level codes.

course_title: An Introduction to Computation for Contemporary Science 001
best_comment: This course is super beginner–friendly, and I like that it was application–driven, so all of the problems that are focused on are highly relevant and are similar to scientific problems and tasks you would probably encounter in the future. That being said, some of the content does get kind of dry –– the lectures do a good job of covering the basics, but a lot of the material could be compacted together, as the lectures/sections usually just consisted of reading through code to different graphs and problems. However, there are in–class exercises and some hands–on work, which were helpful for practicing some of the concepts that are talked about in class, and the teaching staff are so kind and open to questions and helping students out.One thing, though, is that this class also focuses more on learning how to code without as much insight into the logical problem–solving that comes with breaking down a problem into its different steps, so that can be a bit of a challenge. However, SCI–5 is quite manageable in terms of workload, the homework assignments are quite interesting and can be challenging, but they don't eat up a ton of time to do. I would probably recommend this course to someone over courses like CS 50 for people who want to learn a bit of Python and want to see how to apply it for scientific research, but if you want a more comprehensive and rigorous overview of Python, I would recommend looking into another course.
best_gem_comment: Take this class before CS50 or AM10. Highly recommend to freshmen (or other classes to balance your workload). If you are afraid of coding and math, this class is a great stepping stone to get your feet wet without ruining your GPA. As long as you attend section and TF office hours, you’ll probably do well. Pretty much a “gem” (reasonable workload, good teaching staff, learn skills you can put on your resume).

course_title: An Introduction to Computation for Contemporary Science 001

Pretty much a “gem” (reasonable workload, good teaching staff, learn skills you can put on your resume).

best_comment: Be enthusiastic and have specific goals for the class!

TAKE THIS CLASS!!! The teachers are ALL SPECTACULAR!!! They are so fun, so understanding, and so so helpful in learning Chinese. There is no other class and no other teachers I would have rather learned Chinese from, because they are that incredible. The class is definitely a bit of a time commitment, but it is so worth it, and this class has probably had the most payoff of any class I’ve taken at Harvard so far. Off–cycle (spring semester) is kinda nice because the smaller number of students makes a really personable class environment, but whether on– or off–cycle, the class is just an absolute joy and a great learning environment. Guo, Chen, and Zhang Laoshi are incredible teachers who understand so deeply well how teaching Chinese to English speakers work. They try so hard to make the class as good as it can be, and it absolutely works. There is no other language I would rather take here than Chinese because the department is incredible and BA is definitely in my top 5 favorite classes I’ve ever taken throughout my life! Also, I knew 0 Chinese coming in to the class, and I still got by really well! As long as you do the work, you absolutely don’t need to have taken Chinese previously to do well in this class. SO WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR??? TAKE BA!!!!

Like Chinese Ba, this class is so excellent, and you will be shocked just how much you learn even in a semester! When I started this semester, I could hold a relatively short conversation in Chinese (the super basics), but Bb adds a lot of useful grammar that you can use in most daily settings. The course was significantly easier for me than Chinese Ba, to the point that I did not quite pay as good of attention as I should have. But, nonetheless, you will learn so much and be so surprised by just how much your speaking/listening will improve.Also, two pieces of advice: (1) make sure to go to office hours as much as possible, especially if you hope to speak Chinese in conversation; and (2) find ways to keep your Chinese solid over winter break (or whatever break) prior to taking Bb, because your skills will fall off fast!

Great continuation of Chinese Ba! It does ramp up quite a bit but the teaching staff definitely are very supportive and I think the course is designed pretty well to accommodate where you are, with many opportunities for extra credit. If you put in the work and time, you will definitely be where you need to. As always, the teaching staff make the class so fun and enjoyable.

I loved Chinese Ba and I loved Chinese Bb! The teaching staff is excellent – I love how enthusiastic they are and how they incorporate humor into the lessons. There are plenty of resources, from the textbook to Quizlet to the weekly grammar/vocab lists. They are also experimenting with a Chinese learning GPT assistant, which I didn't really use, but I heard was helpful. Your grade is not majorly impacted by a single assignment or test, so make sure you're just showing up consistently and don't fall behind. If you do, they allow late submissions for homework. I found Quizlet and the textbook really helpful for prepping for dictation!

The course content can be tough, but you have so much support that it is easy to learn to be comfortable with the content! Go to class every day! Ask questions! The Chinese Language Program at Harvard is AMAZING!

This course is excellent but VERY HARD –– in my view it was graded much harder than 120A. All the usual pros and cons of Chinese language courses at Harvard apply: great preceptors, lovely discussions, Vanserg, meets 5 days per week, two quizzes per week, etc. I noticed that Huang lao shi tended to grade significantly harder than the other instructors. But overall, all the instructors were excellent and very kind, as always! It is a LOT of work though –– roughly equivalent to a pset class. I would strongly recommend doing all the extra credit assignments!

The Chinese classes here have been my favorite classes at Harvard! The teaching staff is super kind and supportive, and in class you learn a lot and become a much more capable speaker, reader, writer, and listener. Chinese 120B in particular had a lot of fun assignments such as playing board games with classmates and giving a tour of Harvard in Chinese for a final project. 10/10 course, would definitely recommend!

It is hard class no doubt. If you don't keep up with the coursework, it is very overwhelming as the material continuously builds up on each other and there are very frequent assessments and homework. However, it was also a very rewarding course. My Chinese improved by so much from the beginning of the semester to now that it's truly incredible. All the instructors are incredible teachers and just fun people to be around and the Chinese Department is such a great community. If you want to learn the language, stick with the Chinese Program here––if you just want a fun language class, I'd recommend against taking this course, it requires serious commitment/buy in.

course_title: Intermediate Modern Chinese for Advanced Beginners 002
best_comment: If you're heavily deciding whether or not to take CHNSE 123XB, I would highly recommend if schedule allows! I decided to take this course despite having already placed out of the language requirement as I really wanted to improve my Chinese, not to mention my consideration of wanting to pursue a citation. This decision is definitely one that I don't regret making! Not only did I improve my Chinese, I also got to meet amazing people, including the amazing teaching staff of the Chinese department. While the walk to class may be long and there may be many vocabs and grammar structures to memorize, they will all be worth it!

course_title: Intermediate Modern Chinese for Advanced Beginners 003
best_comment: This course is absolutely amazing. Du Laoshi is a wonderful teacher along with the others (this year we had Huang Laoshi, Xiong Laoshi and Lu Laoshi), and the teachers are very passionate about helping students learn the course content. I feel like my Chinese reading and writing/typing abilities have massive improved this semester. The smaller class size also is great for building community: some of my best friends were made in this class. One of the only detracts is that it meets really often (every day), so you'd better understand how the class will work with your schedule. Otherwise, amazing course, 1000% recommend.

Take this class! Although meeting every day can be a hassle, the professors make it all worth it. Grading is lenient and the professors are all extremely understanding. It's definitely a good class to take when you need a breather from STEM/humanities classes. While the class isn't necessarily difficult, I found there to be more work than expected, although much of it was just studying for the two review quizzes every week (although they aren't necessarily difficult either if you take the time to sit down and go through the textbook) and weekly homework. The professors are also all extremely interactive and engaging throughout each class

Chinese never fails to be my favorite course every single semester, and 130 is no different. I think it is very on par to the difficulty of CHNSE 120 (vocab/grammar is definitely more difficult than 120's still, but class itself is similar in difficulty). The teachers have always been phenomenal and it is so absolutely worth taking this course if you are looking for your citation. A little review every day goes a long way, the Quizlets are always up to date, grammar sheets are super helpful, all is good.
worse_comment: If you have the chance, take this course! It can definitely be a time commitment with the bi–weekly quizzes and daily walk to Vanserg, but the teaching team is absolutely phenomenal and will make getting through the semester much more doable. Office hours are during odd hours of the day, which can make them difficult to attend, but professors are very attentive towards student concerns and learning.

best_comment: Chinese 130b was an excellent continuation of Chinese 130a. The course staff are very understanding and supportive and will be there to help you and listen to your concerns if you're worried about any of the assignments. The Chinese language instructors are always some of the quickest to respond to emails out of any other course I've ever taken at Harvard. The quizlets were extremely helpful for preparing for the in–class quizzes and exams. Pay attention in class and you learn most of what you need to do well on the assignments. It was fun to chat with actual students from China through the Chinese language mentor program and a great low–risk practice opportunity.

course_title: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 002
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU WANT TO HAVE LOTS OF FUN AND LAUGHS WHILE ALSO RAISING YOUR CHINESE PROFICIENCY AND FLUENCY!!! Definitely one of my favorite courses I've taken at Harvard. Not only you'll become more confident and skillful in using formal chinese to discuss more complex and interesting topics, but you'll also be able to engage with your classmates in various group activities. While this is primarily a language course, you'll also talk about chinese culture, history, internet trends, social issues, and much more. The smaller class environment allows for a bit more personalized learning experience and you really get to know your classmates. Overall, it's an amazing course that I would highly recommend if you're looking to fulfill your foreign language requirement, working towards your chinese language citation, or just want to take chinese in general!
worse_comment: This course is an excellent course for students wishing to learn Chinese. It's everyday but that really simulates immersion. There are a few difficulties — like, you can't miss many classes which seems unfair for having it everyday.

course_title: Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 001
best_comment: If you are serious about improving your Chinese, take this class! The workload was personally very manageable and all the Chinese teachers are so kind, so you are bound to have a great teacher. You will learn a lot of new vocabulary and Chinese sentences.
TAKE THIS CLASS! The teaching team is amazing, the business case studies and cultural components we learn are so interesting, and the class is always engaging.

The course provided a wonderfully rich and immersive experience for learning the Chinese language (lots of practice for reading and writing, and weekly opportunities to engage in one–on–one conversation). The top highlight of the class, besides the lovely professors and TF, is the unique opportunity to study real–world texts and engage in academic study using the original language. The courses provided an in–depth introduction to modern Chinese literature, from Lu Xun to Hao Jingfang. Each week had a keyword theme, which I find super helpful to orient myself in a new unfamiliar context, and the authors built upon each other so you could feel the origins and energies that inspired the next work. It is definitely a rigorous and challenging class, but it is structured in a way that supports you even if you didn’t understand the text the first time. The class itself attracts a relatively wide range of language levels so it didn’t feel too daunting and I made strong friendships through the class. The course materials are outstandingly well–made. Extensive vocabulary lists are provided for each week’s reading. However much you put into the class, you will get out tenfold. Beyond the readings, the assignments are also not just busywork; they are designed to get you to think about the text, check your understanding, and further your understanding. Sometimes when studying a language it can feel difficult to know just how much you have learned. But through the semester–long research paper, it feels as though I have accomplished something very tangibly significant that I can be proud about. This was the best language learning experience I’ve ever had!

course_title: The Modern History of Rural China 01
best_comment: Take this class! This class has everything you could want: great content where you will actually learn a lot, fun assignments that are challenging in a good way, fair and clear grading, amazing lectures, and interesting discussions in class and in section. This is really a class that does everything right, so I highly highly recommend.

course_title: Gender, Body, and Boundaries in Chinese Culture 01
best_comment: I really loved the readings in this course. Professor Li makes class discussions so engaging that the two hours just fly by. The other students also bring great perspectives, making discussions even more enriching. This class is accessible to people outside the concentration, and you’ll learn a lot if you keep an open mind. Writing papers and discussion boards was surprisingly enjoyable, especially since you get to share your thoughts. There’s no class quite like this one on this topic, and I’d highly recommend it if you get the chance!

LOVE the class and Dr. Bu!! If you're interested in Korea and art, it's definitely a class worth taking! Korean language classes were a bit too much for my schedule and there weren't many Korean history classes offered but this class was a great balance of history, culture, and art. Dr. Bu is a great professor to talk through your projects/assignments with and so supportive, so go to office hours! ***

This is a great class. Its content is invigorating and a fantastic overview of the field of media studies and area studies, with the most recent/important texts. It's very refreshing to see media studies taught NOT from an Euro–American centric model. Prof. Zahlten is extremely nice and approachable. He will make extra effort to meet with you outside of class, regardless of how busy his schedule is. He is very knowledgeable about the field without being pretentious at all. A fantastic teacher to have. One thing to notice is that he is very keen on the open–ended student–led discussion, which at times might leave the class in slight confusion. I do really wish there were slightly more lecturing/introduction from him, since he's actually a fantastic teacher.

This course is an absolute MUST–TAKE for anyone who's vaguely interested in film/media/documentary studies. The readings are diversified and intellectually engaging––the class keep referring to each week's reading throughout the semester, which demonstrates not only how foundational they are (and how motivated the class are to read them carefully!), but also how deeply they resonate with our ongoing concerns with the social issues. The course is thoughtfully designed, rigorous enough for graduate students while offering a rewarding introduction for undergraduates coming from a totally different field. Professor Bu is a real gem and an inspiring scholar to study with. Because the topics introduced in the course were so interesting and intellectually challenging, all of us approached weekly posts with essay–level depth and the discussion section becomes such a valuable space for reflecting on not just our own but each other's thinking.
best_gem_comment: This course is an absolute MUST–TAKE for anyone who's vaguely interested in film/media/documentary studies. The readings are diversified and intellectually engaging––the class keep referring to each week's reading throughout the semester, which demonstrates not only how foundational they are (and how motivated the class are to read them carefully!), but also how deeply they resonate with our ongoing concerns with the social issues. course_title: Major Religious Texts of East Asia 01
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! It is absolutely fantastic, low pressure, and INCREDIBLY REWARDING. It feels like a book club where every single book is enthralling to read. I thoroughly learned the fundamentals of Buddhism, Daoism, and Confucianism from a classical doctrinal lens to a modern literary lens. It made me really reflect on my own values and how I hope to keep a sense of peace and flexibility while living my life. Professor Abe is an incredibly knowledgeable and worthwhile teacher to learn from. You can’t go wrong with taking this class.

course_title: East Asian Religions: Traditions and Transformations 01
best_comment: Really really big fan of this class, and would highly recommend to anyone interested in learning about East Asian religions (which I've long heard about but never had a chance to properly study).  Professor Robson gives perhaps the most interesting, educational, and compelling lectures I've ever witnessed –– I actually felt motivated to go to each one out of fear that I would be missing (probably goes hand–in–hand with finding the subject matter interesting). Also, Trevor was a fantastic TF and lead sections that really highlighted the most important content to remember. Class assignments are two take–home quizzes and a final paper –– a chill workload, and it was actually kinda enjoyable.

This course is an amazing and relatively chill course to learn a lot about Buddhism and a bit about Japanese arts and culture (specifically theatre arts like Noh dramas, though there is a bit about writing and a bit about Japanese visual art at the end). It does focus more on the Buddhism than art, but I still found learning about all the different concepts from all the different schools really interesting, even if it wasn't why I originally chose the course. The course was also super accessible, understandable, and interesting even for a CS/Stat concentrator like me with basically no experience in Buddhism or arts analysis at all. Also Professor Abe is just super sweet, understanding, and passionate about the topic, which was always a delight to listen to. The final project is super flexible and you can basically write either an essay connecting something to Buddhism or a creative piece. Would definitely recommend if you're looking for a beginner level course or elective on this topic.

course_title: Advanced Readings in East Asian Art and Literature 01
Advanced Readings in East Asian Art and Literature 01

best_comment: I wish I had started taking Japanese a year sooner because the class and the whole teaching staff is amazing and felt like a community. I enjoyed being able to come back after one semester to familiar faces, and to know that there's ample support for me here. This course is also the perfect blend of challenging and interesting and keeps language learning fun. You will have to put in the consistent daily work to get the hang of the language, and I feel like there are plenty of opportunities for you to do that –– through homework, drills, and the frequent Office Hours with any of the instructors.
Lovely teachers and you learn so much

This is an amazing class. Yes, it's a lot of work, you have to memorize kanji and vocabulary on a weekly basis, you have a lot of assignments, and you can only speak in Japanese in class, but it's amazing. Having been in the same class with the same teacher and a lot of the same classmates for two years, you're all in it together, and it's really a great time.  The teacher is a great teacher and also very understanding and there are a lot of assignments to pad your grade, so as long as you show up to class, do all the assignments, and submit everything on time, you will not have to worry about your grade. Of course, if you actually want to do quite well speaking Japanese in class, you will have to put in more work memorizing and practicing grammar and vocab, but most people don't put in that work, so you all kind of suck together sometimes but it's fun and it's part of the vibes. I highly highly recommend this class – Japanese has been my favorite class at Harvard every year so far.
Amazing class, as always! Very rewarding, and you take away what you put into the class

Japanese 140b with Asakura先生 and Higurashi先生 was an absolute blast! I had so much fun in this class because (1) the homework assignments are pretty straightforward and fast, (2) the content is genuinely interesting (rakugo, traditional Japanese stories, subculture, dialects, short stories), (3) I had SOOOO many friends in the class (since I continued from 130ab), and (4) the outside–class events were insanely fun (making mochi, presenting final reports, end–of–year party). Both the teachers are great at engaging the class and sparking interesting discussions. Even tho I took this class mostly 9 am, I never felt sleepy or bored, and I always got a chance to speak. For me, I feel like Japanese language classes have been a consistent highlight of my time at harvard.

course_title: Gender and Art in Japan and Beyond 01
best_comment: This course is tough as an undergrad because it is dominated by PhD students, who made up about 3/4 of the class. They had extensive specific background knowledge that made some conversations difficult to follow. That aspect of the course is not ideal, but Professor McCormick is awesome and does her best to make discussions accessible to all backgrounds. She clearly cares about her students and wants everyone to succeed, and that is why the class is enjoyable.

Lean into the awkwardness of the language classroom. It's one of the few places at Harvard where you are expected to mess up, and indeed celebrated for doing so, and the Korean Language Program instructors do an excellent job of setting that standard. Maybe it's the intensity, but I felt very close to my classmates and the teachers. Try to bring that enthusiasm to the slightly scarier assignments, especially the oral presentations.

This is Korean BB, if you are reading this it's likely because you took Korean BA or are planning to take Korean BA. When I took the sequence the most common student was a Korean–American who wanted to learn the language after having heard it at home growing up. This means they are usually not starting from scratch but rather have pretty good listening skills at the very least, but sometimes have good speaking and/or good familiarity with the vocabulary already. This is not a huge deal as the course itself is not tailored to these types but rather accessible for a total beginner so don't worry about it if you are a total beginner. I mention this to characterize the position from which I am writing the review, as a total beginner and as a non–Korean person. The main thing I'll say about Korean BB is that the workload is quite a bit higher than that of Korean BA. I felt like I cruised through BA for the most part but from the first week of BB I (and others) felt the significant uptick in the pace and amount of stuff we were doing. The workload itself is very similar to that of BA and follows the same weekly patterns, but the volume of new content is higher which makes it tougher. That said, if you want to learn Korean this is the place to be and I think BB is the more important part of the first year sequence as we covered things that are closer to real world use. For example, this is the semester where we learned to ask if people want to do things like get dinner etc, so if you are on the fence about whether you should take BB after taking BA in pursuit of actually getting to a point where Korean is useful for you, definitely take it.

Take this class if you want to improve your Korean––it does move very fast and there's quite a bit of work every week! It is super rewarding though to improve at the language and the teachers try to keep it fun and engaging!
This class is very demanding of time and energy (like the workload is truly foul at times), but you can get a lot out of it and make good friends too. The 선생님 are great.

This is a fast paced course, but it's super fun and engaging. The teachers are very nice and make a great class environment. I feel like I really got a lot more confidence in speaking and writing in Korean.

worse_comment: Ba/Bb and 120a/b are much better courses and are more organized. I feel like this class was extremely messy and many of the assignments were not helpful in expanding my Korean knowledge. Most people take this class in order to complete a citation, so if you are reading this, you are probably going to take the class anyways, but just know I did not enjoy it.

best_comment: Great breadth and depth of Choson covered in this course. Engaging atmosphere with instructors who care lots about you and the content. While Choson history seems long ago, it is super relevant to understanding Modern Korea!

Just as great as Vietnamese BA – a low–stress and fun way to keep learning the language. The teaching staff (cô Hoa and cô Thư) are amazing as usual and work hard to make class engaging and relate to real life! You'll learn lots of new vocab with a greater emphasis on grammar structures, so you'll feel more confident in Vietnamese after your second semester. And the Vietnamese language community is second to none!

Very great and manageable course! You'll be engaging in a lot of discussions, giving presentations, and writing in your homework. As long as you keep up with the new vocabulary, you should be good. It's a very comfortable and supportive learning environment, and the Vietnamese teaching department is absolutely amazing.
Great class with caring professors. As long as you put in effort they will be there to guide you along the way. They truly just care about creating a comfortable place to improve your Vietnamese!
This course can be a lot of work so make sure to not fall behind on the homework assignments. The community and fun you get out of this course is immensely worth it though.

It's pretty good! There is a lot of work compared to Ec10a in the fall, as you have more writing (Deep Dives can get especially cumbersome), and while you don't have problem sets (which is nice), you do have section write ups, which also take a while, but sometimes you can get through most of them in section which is really nice. Anne is great and super enthusiastic about the content of the class, and altho it's kinda early, she really does try her best to keep everyone awake and engaged! The smaller class was kinda nice too and felt more approachable and personable. I will say though, the midterm and final are tough, so definitely be aware of those and really really study hard for them
worse_comment: This class is not the same as on cycle Ec10a.  Anne is a good lecturer but I found the slides to be hard to follow, and this made studying for midterms/finals difficult. Know that most of your grade will come from entirely multiple choice assessments (for us, midterm+final were 60% of the grade, and they were both entirely multiple choice). This is the same as on cycle ec10, but you also have a bunch of other random assignments that they do not. For example, the deep dives and final project. Deep dives are every two or three weeks, and they are a big time commitment. That is what makes the course so hard to follow; you can't plan out how much time you need per week because it is always changing. The deep dives and final project also have very little relevance to the exams, so it is a frustrating mix of needing to still do the assignments but knowing they are not helping for the main chunk of the graded part of the class. It is a fine class, but I wouldn't recommend if you aren't considering an econ concentration. Just take it on cycle; this class is inconsistent and harder than I feel it should be.

best_comment: Ec10b was a great course. I have a much better understanding of how the macroeconomy functions, from the role of the Fed to the effects of tariffs to the stock market. The lectures were well–developed. The course did not include much fine detail and instead focused more on developing our intuition about macroeconomics; without prior experience in macroeconomics, I valued this approach. It allowed me to understand macroeconomics as a whole before deciding whether I want to explore the area in more depth. However, if you have taken macroeconomics in the past, this course might not be challenging enough. Additionally, some of Jason's lectures felt dry and dragged on a little. The content was interesting, but I think he could have presented it with greater tonal variation and expressivity.The guest lectures were incredible. When David and Jason discussed topics in class, they mentioned some of the most important research on that topic, and the guest lectures were usually part of that research! I felt lucky to be exposed to such giants in economics!However, I would have liked a more diverse range of guest speakers. Most of them were academics or politicians, and I would have liked to hear from more industry experts, such as bankers.The psets improved my grasp of the content. I especially liked how they reflected present–day events, like the effects of Covid and tariffs. Through them, I applied what I had learned in class and became more confident with the material.The problem–solving sessions are an incredible resource. The CAs helped me work through the psets and understand the concepts involved. They were all nice and supportive. The unit review program is also quite valuable. By studying for them, I consolidated my understanding of the material. The feedback I got after taking them showed me how well I had learned the content and where I should focus my studying. Because the problem–solving sessions and unit review program are so useful, I would highly suggest attending themThe tests do a good job of testing our understanding and problem–solving skills. The practice tests are a very useful resource to study for them; in fact, I think some of the questions were essentially identical to the tests.
worse_comment: FOR HUMANITIES STUDENTS:If you're on the fence about this class, take it!!!!! Cannot recommend highly enough. Gives you real world knowledge you're not gonna get elsewhere. Highly, highly recommend.

worse_comment: FOR HUMANITIES STUDENTS:If you're on the fence about this class, take it!!!!! Cannot recommend highly enough. Gives you real world knowledge you're not gonna get elsewhere. Highly, highly recommend.

course_title: Using Big Data to Solve Economic and Social Problems with Laboratory Component 001
best_comment: Take this class!! This class is perfect for people of all levels in economics, coding, and data science.  I highly recommend taking Stata, the TF in the class Karen is so supportive and patient, and honestly the entire teaching time is amazing and super helpful throughout the entire course. There isn’t a lot of work outside of class aside from watching lectures, and you will finish the labs in class for most weeks. Highly recommend overall!
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS if you are not interested in research. There is a lot of memorization of what certain professors, such as Raj Chetty, have done in the past. One question literally asked "what did X research identify Y variable as?" and for this, you have had to memorize the name and label of the variable.

best_comment: This is absolutely the section to take for Ec 970. Haiyang is a phenomenal instructor and very flexible when other things come up. It is going to be very work–intensive but so is every other section, so you might as well take one that is interesting with a good teacher. Also prepares you very well for a career after Harvard if you are interested in the corporate world.

This is an excellent elective. The readings are all very interesting while still being relatively manageable, and Dr. Baranga is an incredibly dedicated instructor. He provides detailed feedback on all assignments and makes class very engaging while ensuring that the material is accessible and easy to understand. I liked how the course brought in the real world — this semester was one with a lot of trade policy news, and we got a chance to discuss current events in the context of what we had learned. In sum, I'd highly recommend this option for your sophomore tutorial.

This is an excellent elective. The readings are all very interesting while still being relatively manageable, and Dr. Baranga is an incredibly dedicated instructor. He provides detailed feedback on all assignments and makes class very engaging while ensuring that the material is accessible and easy to understand. I liked how the course brought in the real world — this semester was one with a lot of trade policy news, and we got a chance to discuss current events in the context of what we had learned. In sum, I'd highly recommend this option for your sophomore tutorial.

This is a required class for the Economics Concentration, so you don't really have a choice whether to take it or not. But there are many options of topics, so you should be able to find one that is of interest to you. Besides for the final paper, the other papers are relatively short and don't take too much time. There are readings at least twice a week, but often times you can get the relevant information from the abstract/by skimming the results/conclusion sections. The final paper is definitely an intense assignment, but if you take the prospectus seriously, you will have at least a good outline going into reading week. It's a small class (no more than 8–12 people) so you can get a lot of support from your professor if you need it.

Great topic for 970 and a very passionate instructor. The papers selected for discussion are very interesting.

TAKE THIS COURSE. Taylor is awesome, not just as an instructor but as a person as he only gives you work that is helpful for your academic and professional career. The material is also super engaging and I loved getting to learn about the cross–section between history and economics. Again, take this course, it is so worth it.

TAKE THIS COURSE. Taylor is awesome, not just as an instructor but as a person as he only gives you work that is helpful for your academic and professional career. The material is also super engaging and I loved getting to learn about the cross–section between history and economics. Again, take this course, it is so worth it.
This course is a great way to understand the ins and outs of economic research and learn more about a specific field. I would look for topics that you find interesting!
This course is a great way to understand the ins and outs of economic research and learn more about a specific field. I would look for topics that you find interesting!

This is a great course to learn how to understand + write Economics papers! Make sure to choose a subject that you are passionate about because everything in the class (the papers + dicussions) revolve around that specific niche. Do some preliminary research on your course head as well as you will spend signficant time with them. Finally, if you want to write a senior thesis, this course will be absolutely essential to your preparation.
worse_comment: The psets are annoying, but depending on your TF, the smaller assignments can be very doable.

best_comment: Cirrus is the absolute best tutorial leader, in my opinion and in that of friends that have preceded me as his student. Rank this section first. You can do and find no better. An exceptional mix of intellectually fulfilling / fascinating yet never overburdened. We learned a great deal without having to do an exceeding amount of unnecessary work, which is unfortunately true of most other tutorials.

Cirrus is the absolute best tutorial leader, in my opinion and in that of friends that have preceded me as his student. Rank this section first. You can do and find no better. An exceptional mix of intellectually fulfilling / fascinating yet never overburdened. We learned a great deal without having to do an exceeding amount of unnecessary work, which is unfortunately true of most other tutorials.

Landoni's behavioral finance tutorial is AWESOME. The material is extremely interesting and Landoni is an excellent teacher.  It is clear that he is excited about the material and is always extremely well–prepared for class. He is a unique professor, and I mean that in a good way. The right amount quirky! His grading is clear and he always gives lots of feedback. Make sure to do the readings and start your final project early! TAKE THIS CLASS! Definitely one of the best tutorials.

Landoni's behavioral finance tutorial is AWESOME. The material is extremely interesting and Landoni is an excellent teacher.  It is clear that he is excited about the material and is always extremely well–prepared for class. He is a unique professor, and I mean that in a good way. The right amount quirky! His grading is clear and he always gives lots of feedback. Make sure to do the readings and start your final project early! TAKE THIS CLASS! Definitely one of the best tutorials.

Mattia is a tough grader. He is pretty fair, but I think you will find him harsher than expected, and you have to work pretty hard to improve grades. I was able to, and it did improve the quality of my work, but I think it should be a fair warning that this class IS hard. You have to spend time on your submissions and carefully think through your reasoning on what you wrote. You must do the readings and you have to think of things to say to get participation credit. Just asking questions is not enough think of something to contribute. Mattia makes you start the paper way earlier than most sections and that is the best because you can just put all your past assignements together (with some editing and expansion of course) and then your final is already done. But, be mindful that you have to as a result pick a topic early and plan ahead when you submit proposals. Simple proposals are better.

BEST CLASS I'VE TAKEN AT HARVARD and this was due to our incredible instructor, Omar. I absolutely loved this class. Our tutorial focused on managerial decision making, and the readings that Omar selected tied into important business and technology problems and helped me to critically think about real–world business challenges. I found this to be much more applicable than many other courses I've taken here, and it's a course I feel confident will shape the way I think about business problems for many years to come. It also drastically improved my ability to read research papers, understand econometric methods, and write essays, largely because of the way that Omar broke down these topics, provided in–depth feedback, and always made expectations clear for assignments. He is incredibly knowledgeable about econometrics, business, and technology, and he knew the papers very well and helped our class think about them on a much deeper level. Not only that, but we had many engaging class activities that I really enjoyed and that helped me learn in a more hands–on way.  This course could have doubled as instruction about how the ideal class should be taught. I've never felt this sad for a course to come to an end; it was truly an amazing class and I feel very lucky to have been in it, especially with Omar as my instructor.As far as other advice, I'd recommend at least concurrently taking econometrics, as this will really help understand the methods of papers. I'm not sure if Omar will teach another tutorial, but if he does I'd highly recommend taking one with him. I'd also say to choose a topic you're interested in, as this will make it easier to get through the readings and stay engaged during the class discussions. Additionally, the PSETs provide a lot more support for Stata than R, so I'd recommend Stata if you're choosing between languages. Finally, don't underestimate the workload, as you will have to complete PSETs, do many readings, and write papers, including a very long final paper. All of this can lead to a pretty significant workload, although I don't think that any of the work ever felt like busy work which I appreciated.

Take the Melkonian Section!! Any sophomore tutorial you take is going to be a lot of work; this one definitely had its fair share, but Melkonian is phenomenal! His rubrics are very straightforward, so if you simply do your work with the rubric, you will have success. He is accessible outside of class and understanding of needs. Strict on little points on essays but all around not an incredibly harsh grader! He wants you to succeed!! If this is offered again, you should definitely take it.

I’d recommend this class with Coly with enthusiasm. The readings can be long and dense, but I think this is in line with most sophomore tutorial classes. The papers we read are super interesting and concern the US but also more global climate economics. Assignments are very easily manageable. I was also lucky to have a great class that was very happy to discuss papers.

I took the Economics of Homelessness with Patrick Power and I strongly recommend you to take this class! Patrick leads sections with great care, ensuring everyone truly understands the material. He also assigns relevant and interesting coursework, so I truly enjoyed taking the course. He also takes the time to meet with you in office hours to make sure you are on track for the course. The hard part of the course lies in the PSets. The Office Hours are not that frequent and the staff are not always that helpful. I struggled through the PSets, but everything else in the course was absolutely great. Patrick was very fair in his assignments and workloads, and understands we all have very busy lives. Patrick is awesome and has the best 970 Section hands down!

I took the Economics of Homelessness with Patrick Power and I strongly recommend you to take this class! Patrick leads sections with great care, ensuring everyone truly understands the material. He also assigns relevant and interesting coursework, so I truly enjoyed taking the course. He also takes the time to meet with you in office hours to make sure you are on track for the course. The hard part of the course lies in the PSets. The Office Hours are not that frequent and the staff are not always that helpful. I struggled through the PSets, but everything else in the course was absolutely great. Patrick was very fair in his assignments and workloads, and understands we all have very busy lives. Patrick is awesome and has the best 970 Section hands down!

Ec 970 is great because it puts your Economics degree together. First, you learn how to read a research paper in–depth, with discussions that help you understand along the way. Then, you learn how to write each individual component of a paper. Finally, you put it all together writing a paper of your own. If you can take Economics of Cities, please do. Andrés is as fantastic of an instructor as he is a person, and will help you grow and learn throughout the semester. The classroom environment he creates is extremely fun, which helps get through an otherwise–difficult economics class.

Ec 970 is great because it puts your Economics degree together. First, you learn how to read a research paper in–depth, with discussions that help you understand along the way. Then, you learn how to write each individual component of a paper. Finally, you put it all together writing a paper of your own. If you can take Economics of Cities, please do. Andrés is as fantastic of an instructor as he is a person, and will help you grow and learn throughout the semester. The classroom environment he creates is extremely fun, which helps get through an otherwise–difficult economics class.

This class is a big time commitment with many long readings each class and frequent papers but sooo worth it and rewarding. Prof Felter is absolutely amazing and so committed to each of his students individually. He also knows about literally anything law–related, making this class an amazing intro to studying law. It's really cool to see how economic concepts can be applied to law, and this class really forces you to think in a new way that combines logical reasoning, economic intuition, and the way lawyers think.
worse_comment: PLEASE DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE. I am warning you and trying to save you a semester of pain and suffering. Professor Felter and grading of this course was very subjective and frustrating. After meeting with the professor multiple times, working everyday in Lamont for long hours, getting support from additional staff members (Ec970 office hours, librarians, writing center, etc.), I received the same bad grade and extremely discouraging comments every single time. Myself and others felt we could never improve, no matter what we tried. Professor Felter chooses who he likes in the beginning of the year and sticks with it. Some people may have loved this class, but they were probably his two favorites, and the majority  of the class holds the same opinion as myself.  I also felt shut down at times as Professor Felter is not the easiest to talk to, and towards the end of semester was very booked for his office hours. Furthermore, the bar and workload of the class was way higher than any other Econ Tutorial that I know of. We had papers and PSETs due on the same day multiple times, and readings were extremely lengthy and boring. All our draft papers were letter graded as short essays, whereas I know other classes were graded as completion. Lastly, the class discussion was very mundane and you could tell no one in the class cared or was participating. As someone interested in law, this class actively disuaded me against it. I would not recommend this class to anyone. The amount of work is insurmountable, and I had nothing to show for it but a bad grade and comments that made me feel very poorly about my academic abilities. In the end, this course discouraged me immensely and was my worst class of the semester and professor I liked the least.
