best_comment: This course was wonderful! Christina is very helpful and is available to answer any questions you have about the course, the readings, or economic research in general. I would say to start the papers (especially the final project) early because it is a lot of work.
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THE FINANCE AND PROGRESS SECTION. IT WAS ABSOLUTELY TERRIBLE.

best_comment: This course was wonderful! Christina is very helpful and is available to answer any questions you have about the course, the readings, or economic research in general. I would say to start the papers (especially the final project) early because it is a lot of work.
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THE FINANCE AND PROGRESS SECTION. IT WAS ABSOLUTELY TERRIBLE.

best_comment: You should take your Econ 970 seminar with Professor Ulusoy. He is very child and there to help you. All of the sections will be a lot of work, but he made it so much more fun. He has some amazing stories about Turkey and the political landscape which are very interesting and engaging. WOULD HIGHLY RECOMMEND

You should take your Econ 970 seminar with Professor Ulusoy. He is very child and there to help you. All of the sections will be a lot of work, but he made it so much more fun. He has some amazing stories about Turkey and the political landscape which are very interesting and engaging. WOULD HIGHLY RECOMMEND
I don't know if this has been my favorite class at Harvard, but it's definitely top three. Katz is a kind man, and I enjoyed his teaching. Victoria is one of the most helpful TFs I've ever had.

This is a small, advanced tutorial which has lectures that focus on macroeconomic theory. Prof Barro tries his best to make the content digestible. He knows a lot and is happy to talk to students. Overall, you take away however much you put into it, because there is a lot of freedom and not a lot of structure, besides 2 presentations (one paper, then your paper) and your final paper. This can be good or bad depending on your preferences. Independent research with lectures and student led presentations, basically. Fun class!

This was one of the most fun and interesting courses I have taken at Harvard and highly highly recommend to any ec concentrators or anyone interested in research! In core economics classes, they always throw around the term "RCT" but rarely ever look at experiments in practice. This class is super interactive because you actually get to design those experiments and think through all the logistics as if you were going to conduct them. If you love problem–solving, this course is definitely a great fit for you. You also get to know your peers as a lot of work in class is in groups, and I have made friends through that. Finally, a significant portion of this class is presentations. People get really creative with them, and they are a ton of fun to listen to! Professor Pallais and Wilbur were amazing and always made themselves available through email and office hours, so you have a ton of support too.

I highly recommend this course. If you have any interest in finance, psychology (how it interacts with finance), or finding interesting exogenous variables and natural experiments (somewhat in the style of Freakonomics), then I strongly recommend this course. I came into it with no finance experience or background and Professor Stein does a great job of explaining basic concepts while discussing important papers in the field. I had little to no trouble keeping up. Further, the final project is a great opportunity to test out if you'd like to write a thesis or if you enjoy economics/finance research; it is super free form and Professor Stein has no expectations for how it turns out, only that you work hard on it and demonstrate effort. The weekly discussion papers initially intimidated me since I have no experience reading academic papers, but after just 2–3 weeks I enjoyed reading the papers and writing my thoughts about them and could get it done in an hour or so. I think this course is perfect for anyone interested in finance, considering writing a thesis senior year, or interested in the intersection of psychology and economics. Truly cannot recommend it any more; certainly my favorite economics course I have taken so far at Harvard. P.S. Alex, the TF, is super accessible outside of class, is great to work with, and gives amazing feedback and resources for the final project.

Take some more time to clearly plan out your research question in the beginning. If you can finish most of data analysis before winter break, your pacing will be great for the spring semester before you turn in your thesis. If possible, more regular meetings with your advisor would be ideal!
If you have a reasonably sized question that excites you, you should write a thesis! Though it can be (incredibly) painful in the moment, I believe the reward is worth it.

I had an unconventional thesis timeline and my section leader was very accommodating. Make sure you have a section leader that is accommodating if you expect to be on a different timeline than most other students. Good course overall. Doesn't meet weekly.

You have to take it if you're writing a thesis, so you don't really have a choice. But it will be a helpful way to get feedback from your classmates and especially your preceptor, who is there to really help you refine and work through your thesis, from the empirical strategy to the presentation of results. I'm glad I had this scaffolding to keep my work on track.
Write a thesis! Sign up for Leslie's section, it's the best! Yay!
Write a thesis! Sign up for Leslie's section, it's the best! Yay!

Finding an advisor who is also invested in your project is very important, second only to getting your hands on data as early as possible.  Not much accountability with this seminar in particular so it really has to be self–directed/self–motivated to stay on track.  Have fun with it!

Theses take up a lot of time but can be rewarding if the question you are researching is important to you in some way, you have a good advisor and thesis instructor. I was lucky to have all three and so even though doing a thesis did change the make up of my senior year tremendously I feel proud of the piece of work that I was able to produce.

The actual presentation of your thesis is as important as the research you are doing. If a thesis reader can't grasp exactly what it is that you've done in a quick glance, then you're setting yourself up for failure. In a perfect world, all thesis readers would take the time to read every page—but this is not the reality, especially since we have no control over who reads our work. In order to have time to work on the actual structure and writing of your argument, CONTINUE WORKING OVER WINTER BREAK! I did this, which provided a lot more wiggle room to inevitably make mistakes. Something that is little talked about is the honors exam. It creeps up quickly—unlike what you may expect, it doesn't happening during finals period. If you take spring break off to decompress from thesis writing, then you only have two weeks to study. That's simply not enough time. If you can, try to start studying earlier. That being said, this a big critique of mine of the Economics Department, and I hope that this will change soon. Good luck to all thesis writers! As long as you stay diligent, you'll make it out on the other side!

course_title: Economic Growth and the Social Issues of Our Time 001
best_comment: This class was super super interesting, and not incredibly difficult! The readings were useful (though long sometimes), and Professor Friedman is a great lecturer who knows so so much about this topic. You'll definitely learn, if you put in some effort. You could get by not doing too much outside of class, but I would strongly recommend doing the readings for the exams. The other assignments (2 op–eds and a small pset) were not super difficult and were kinda fun to do. The exams were a little hard, just because they are no–note essays...
worse_comment: This course is not particularly challenging, especially if you have taken any sort of economics or development class before. I felt that most of the things taught in class were things I had learnt before.

best_comment: This class is great!! Melitz is an amazing lecturer, and he is genuinely interested in teaching. He is always available to answer questions, and he makes a point to stay after lecture and talk to anybody that wants to (there is often a line, as he gives attentive responses). The class is supposedly a lot better off cycle, and I would agree. There are not as many study groups or class resources, but they post good information to use for studying and the textbook (written by the prof) is a great way to clear anything up. If you read the textbook and do the assignments honestly, you will learn the material without much outside work on your end. An A is a little tough, but can be done with attentiveness and studying for the exams. Would recommend!
worse_comment: Keep up with the material and study well in advance for the exams!! They are difficult

best_comment: I LOVE THIS CLASS!!!! I am an Econ concentrator, but usually economic concepts and classes are very hard for me because I'm not too much of a STEM/numbers person. But, this was BY FAR my favorite economics class I've taken so far at this school...including the electives which is saying a lot. Professor Foote I ADORE. He was so engaging (adding jokes in between slides) and made the macro topics very relevant and applicable to real life. He was ALWAYS willing to help outside of class and answer questions (I showed up at 8:30 on multiple occasions...) and the problem sets were incredibly reasonable content–wise and length (doing them made me understand the material much better!). I love how the sections/p–sets are optional because it gives you flexibility but also resources when you need them. The midterms (which I know two can be a lot and it lowkey stressed me out, but it was beneficial in forcing me to study and review all the material throughout the course rather than all at once at the end) and final adequately reflected the teaching in the class and there were so many resources to help with preparing like office hours, practice exams, etc. TAKE THIS CLASS DON'T BE SCARED! You do just need to put in time and effort.
worse_comment: Study a lot for the exams, don't dwell on optional psets too much, just make sure to really master the practice exam questions. And pay attention to any tangent Foote goes off on, those topics are likely to show up on the exams. He is an amazing person and a great lecturer, but the course structure is quite poor. 90% of your grade being dependent on multiple choice exams means most of your knowledge won't fully be tested and you will simply struggle a lot if you are bad at MCQs (i was).

best_comment: Different parts can make all the difference in this class. I'll try to organize my review in three parts: the good, the bad, and the ugly. The good: The material is fun and reflects the real world. Rarely will you see a model and think, "I'm never going to see this." Many of the models we discussed were, in fact, reflections of the real world, and we felt like we could see how well the models did at explaining recent stuff. OTOH, the class is up to date with the stuff covered, and does not rely on ancient papers or historical macro, but instead employs many modern Macro models. YMMV for this, but Psets were graded on completion and not necessarily correctness. Office hours (WITH THE PROFESSORS) were helpful.  Whenever we worked with data for Psets, it was very simple stuff and nothing too difficult. I was a big fan of the Professor for the first half (Ludwig). This man was energetic, fun, kind, and super approachable. He made the content for the first half interesting, and I feel like I learned a lot from him. If you put in the work, I am sure you can get a good grade. The bad: The Psets have a lot of variance in terms of difficulty. Some Psets can be done in a few hours, and are just the same (or slightly different) problems from the Lecture. Other Psets were too long (and thus, too difficult) or simply put, way too hard. There is a discussion board where you can ask for help and get questions answered. This was helpful, sometimes. It depends a lot on which TF answers the question.The second half of the course was, unfortunately, the weakest. It was more difficult, but in my opinion, made to be more difficult. The professor for the second half (Gabriel) is not bad, he's just outshone by Ludwig. His lecture style was off. He was very monotone, kept his hands in his pockets, and perhaps the worst was that he would throw a lot of math up in the slides and expect you to follow along. Again, he is not a bad professor, but there's a huge contrast between the first and second half, especially in teaching quality. They decided to make the final cumulative, and it was a mess. I would have preferred a much different structure for exams. They also knew they needed to curve grades, but wouldn't say how. Exams carry a lot of weight in this course. The first exam was substantially easier than the second one. Oh, and they said that "everything we covered in class was fair game"The ugly: Nothing was worse than one of the TF's. Two PhD students were TFs, and one of them was atrocious. The other one was awesome and genuinely much better. He took over section towards the end, and thank God he did. I wish I had switched to his section sooner. His sections in the SC basement were miles ahead.However, the other guy was disrespectful, unhelpful, inattentive, and rude. His sections were a waste of time, going to his OH would be useless because he wouldn't try to help, and the list can go on. I think TFs change with the years, so perhaps you'll be luckier. I can't speak for the undergrad TFs. For exams, they may ask any bullet point from the slides or any model. They will not tell you what to focus on. Your best bet is to try and memorize as much as possible, but good luck! TLDR: It's not an easy class, and if you feel like you struggle, it's not on you! However, the course can be improved. Make exams easier. Make the teaching staff (TFs) better. Make the second half more similar to the first half.
worse_comment: I did not like this class, but as AM/Ec this is a requirement and there's no getting around it. There are 8 psets spread throughout the semester, which is nice cause it's not necessarily weekly and some are much shorter than others. Latex is required though which is incredibly annoying. The exams are also very tough. Many kids come from 1011a and it's relatively easier for them, but for the other half of the class it's a learning curve. The midterm averages were quite low and what's so annoying is that they'll have 1 question with parts a–k. Not only is that half the alphabet, but also you're fucked if you don't get something earlier on.

The exams are also very tough. Many kids come from 1011a and it's relatively easier for them, but for the other half of the class it's a learning curve. The midterm averages were quite low and what's so annoying is that they'll have 1 question with parts a–k. Not only is that half the alphabet, but also you're fucked if you don't get something earlier on.

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Professor Fryer is the most brilliant professor I've ever had. He is unbelievably smart –– but, perhaps more importantly, he is a fantastic, charismatic lecturer. The three hour class totally flew by. The midterm and the final were not hard if you studied –– it's just about memorizing a lot of content, but the tests were all multiple choice. Be aware that the class is very poorly organized. Readings were unclear, and would vary from 0  (multiple times) to 500 (twice) pages a week. Some weeks you didn't have to do the reading, some weeks it was more important. To me, the class was definitely well worth the disorganization. But if that's not for you, that's fine. But cannot emphasize enough how much I loved this class. It is so so so so worth taking this course. Please do it.

course_title: Using Markets to Solve Social Problems 001
best_comment: Amazing class. Professor Fryer is super engaging and always makes lecture super fun! Also, the lecture topics are pretty interesting. The midterm was a little rough, but as long as you put in some effort into this class you will do great on it. Also the final project is designing a startup and it was so cool. 10/10 would recommend
worse_comment: Do NOT take this class. The structure is embarrassing to the Harvard name. No class at this institution should be so horrible organized, unfair and left up to chance. Friar is an interesting lecturer, but was entirely uninvolved in any content besides his own lecturing, in which he was quite repetitive and focused mainly on his own research. The mid–term was a dumpster fire, the content was not taught in the class and was barely addressed in the textbook. I studied everything from lecture, the singular (horrible) review session and the textbook, and it was not applicable to what they decided to test on. The test itself had content errors, typing errors and closed early causing different students to have different amounts of time on the test which was extremely unfair. Capstone project was interesting, but the presentation was extremely poorly organized as well.  The participation part of your grade is basically fake–they took attendance twice and said that asking questions during the capstone presentations would count, but then proceeded to disregard any questions that were asked.

best_comment: Would definitely recommend this class to fulfill the theory requirement for ec. The content was super interesting even if you aren't very familiar with mainstream sports. The lectures could get boring sometimes, but overall Judd is super nice and is super helpful if you want help brainstorming project ideas or just to talk about sports. The AI policy is also super nice.

Professor is great, and the class was very interesting and so much fun. We got to play games in class, and the prof gave us actual money when we won, that was pretty cool. He is also one of the best talkers that I have seen.
worse_comment: Keep up with the material as it scales in difficulty quickly. P–Sets take a deceivingly long time.

course_title: Incentives in the Wild: from Tanking in Sports to Mining Cryptocurrencies 001
best_comment: I think this is a great course, content–wise at least, and gives you much insight into the mechanisms around you. Yannai is a great lecturer and is very helpful throughout the semester. Having said that, if the same TFs teach this course next year, I recommend that YOU DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE. While it looks manageable, the TFs responsible for grading your material are of little to no help. In fact, office hours sometimes felt like an inconvenience to them and they aren't helpful at all. The course grading is super subjective (well it seems that way because there's no rubric) and despite being a CS course you will get subjective answers as to why they don't like your work. There are other courses at Harvard that may be of much better overall value than this course.
worse_comment: This was by far the worst course I have ever taken.

best_comment: I think this class is a great introduction to econometrics. Psets are hard but reasonable and clearly tell you what material you should know. The midterm is a big time crunch but the final is much better on time. I think sections are good, but lectures could be better – it feels kind of unorganized, easy to tune out. I wish that the material we need to know was better laid out somewhere, but overall good class. Just make sure u study for the midterm and final a lot. Psets are graded pretty harshly, but apparently the course has a generous curve – not sure how generous yet since grades aren't done, but supposedly it's good.
worse_comment: This class is the worst. The lectures are boring, the PSETs are harshly graded, and the textbook is bad. It feels like if you actually try in this class, you're still going to do worse than people who are engaged in an economy of sharing PSETs. This class feels like learning the rules to a meaningless game that hurts to play and also will sink your GPA. This is the worst class I have taken in my life. God I hate this class.

best_comment: Definitely definitely definitely take this course! Initially, I found a lot of the course pre–requisites really scary because there's statistics, linear algebra, and multivariable calculus. However, a lot of the course material doesn't require extensive knowledge of these topics. As someone who was very curious how econometrics works from a statistical and theoretical perspective, I found this class very interesting. I had taken EC50 a year prior, so I was familiar with the R implementations for various causal inference observational studies and wanted to understand the math behind them. If you're more so interested in getting very comfortable with applying these techniques in R, then EC1123 would probably be better for you. This class goes in–depth into derivations and mathematical assumptions, which gets really interesting as you progress. Also, the material nicely builds on top of each other, and there are cool topics that the Professor will discuss without them being tested on the final, giving students an opportunity to just enjoy the material. If you are thinking about doing EC1126 vs STAT 111 and EC1123, I'd say that EC1126 does a nice job in providing all the relevant statistical insights that you need for econometrics with good pacing. The course textbook is really good, the slides are very insightful, and the sections have nice R code implementations. The homework is also very close to the lecture material, which contrasts other classes where you might need to go OH to OH to even understand what a problem is stating let alone how to approach it. Lastly, Professor Viviano is amazing and genuinely wants you to succeed. He designs assignments close to the lectures so that the focus is on understanding the core class material. The exams were all very fair, equally weighted, and you were allowed a cheat sheet, so there are definitely opportunities to succeed. TLDR: Take this class :)
worse_comment: One of the worst classes at Harvard. Only take it if you need to.

course_title: Economics of Mental Health and Homelessness 001
best_comment: This class is on such a fascinating (and underresearched) topic and has such an incredible team of teaching staff! Professor Basilico truly cares for your wellbeing and wants to make sure that you're both learning but also maintaining a strong work–life balance, and his office hours are such a great time to chat and learn about him as a person! The course lectures can get a long at times, but I think the class discussions help break it up and the papers we read are genuinely so interesting. The final paper is such a great chance to sharpen your economist thinking skills and actually put the economics content you've been learning in college into practice, and I think it was my favorite part of the entire course!~!

This was potentially the best class I have taken at Harvard. For someone who's serious about economics, this class and 1011a are next to none in gathering a community of people who care about the field beyond a career in the world of finance. The weekly readings aren't that serious to actually do, but are worthwhile especially for the guest lectures. Class itself is great, Andrei is highly respected for a reason and all the topics are interesting and engaging, but the bulk of the class is the project. Be prepared to work and work hard since you can't mail this in. Shleifer is big on finding "interesting correlations", which essentially means finding a niche or heretofore unexplored dataset and finding something worthwhile in that dataset. If you're going to take the class, you might as well try your hardest to come up with something cool, especially since everyone in the class—likely due to selection bias—does a really good job. If you're thinking about taking the class, definitely apply and see what happens. If you're able to take the class, you will not regret doing it.
best_gem_comment: This is one of the best courses I've ever taken at Harvard. Andrei is really a gem, and his commitment to all his students is unmatched. He is such an advocate of exploration and really gives you free will on the paper. Plus, he is such a great mentor! Take this course if you have the chance.

best_comment: This is a very interesting class with a relatively low workload! If you're curious about the intersection of religion and economics, it's a perfect fit. The lectures can sometimes feel a bit dry or hard to follow, especially if you haven’t done the readings in depth, which can be challenging given the large volume assigned for each session. I do wish the professors provided more background context, particularly since some students are completely unfamiliar with certain religions.One of the best aspects of the class is that there are only three papers and no exams. Start your papers early and make sure to ask for feedback from the professors. Once you revise accordingly, I found the grading to be quite fair. Dr. McCleary and Dr. Barro are both incredibly knowledgeable and helpful. I'm not sure the sections are entirely necessary (since the lectures are discussion–based), but Caileigh was lovely and supportive.

This is a very interesting class with a relatively low workload! If you're curious about the intersection of religion and economics, it's a perfect fit. The lectures can sometimes feel a bit dry or hard to follow, especially if you haven’t done the readings in depth, which can be challenging given the large volume assigned for each session. I do wish the professors provided more background context, particularly since some students are completely unfamiliar with certain religions.One of the best aspects of the class is that there are only three papers and no exams. Start your papers early and make sure to ask for feedback from the professors. Once you revise accordingly, I found the grading to be quite fair. Dr. McCleary and Dr. Barro are both incredibly knowledgeable and helpful. I'm not sure the sections are entirely necessary (since the lectures are discussion–based), but Caileigh was lovely and supportive.

course_title: Economics of Climate Change and Environmental Policy 001
best_comment: I’m writing from the undergrad perspective, ESPP concentrator who took EC10A and went to all lectures, sections, and review sessions for this course: For students: I found this class very meaningful, helpful, and thought provoking. Everyone wants to come out of a class feeling the course expanded their thinking, exposed them to new ideas, and that they’ve built skills and knowledge within the course useful elsewhere—I feel this way about the course. I find the afternoon lecture time hard and Professor Stavins lectures in a relatively tranquil / monotone way for most of the time so try and energize yourself before coming to the lecture as it can sometimes be hard to maintain focus — many students did not come to lecture but you should go!! Stavins has many interesting and relevan stories to share form his experiences with the content we discuss and is humorous — lecture really grew on me throughout the semester as the class got to know one another and we got a better background under us for learning more content. Microeconomics background helpful, but do not be concerned if not! You will be expected to do some quantitative problem–solving on exams, so know that it’s not entirely policy / qualitative analysis. If you haven’t looked at the syllabus, be aware this course grades almost solely on the exams so basically all your learning through the semester is graded through two tests. I will say that the exams felt more quantitate / problem solving like in comparison to lecture — I don’t think lecture prepares you for a lot of the thinking required on the exam and you build your exam abilities more through the problem sets and practice exams — lecture is more high level and qualitative. Lectures felt more like a gov class, while exams felt more like a Ec10 exam. Go to office hours with Stavins! He may seem intimidating but he’s happy to talk to you and you should take advantage of the opportunity to learn about his experiences.

I'll preface this by saying that you should probably look at reviews from Spring 2024 rather than Spring 2025 if you're considering this course, as it was taught by a visiting professor (Weiling Liu) this year while Professor Gabaix was out. I think those reviews will be more representative than for this year due to the different professor, but I'll still give my views on the course this semester as most should still be applicable.This course is a very nonintimidating introduction to fundamental financial concepts (stocks, bonds, derivatives) and I think it would be beneficial to everyone, not just econ majors or those considering finance. It delves much deeper than EC 70 (personal finance) into these concepts and would be useful knowledge for everyone, as you will eventually need to decide what assets to invest in with retirement accounts and savings.The class is not terribly theoretical, much less so than the main 1010/1011ab sequences. It's mostly just applying formulas and some basic intuition and is honestly very straightforward, especially if you have a stats background (e.g. Stat 110). You really won't be too surprised by exam questions (though I think they're probably a bit harder under Gabaix than Liu). You're given plenty of practice materials, and since this is such a plug and chug class (applying formulas), the fact that you can use a cheat sheet on the exams means that you really don't have to memorize that much information and should be able to do well on the exams with not that much preparation.The homework assignments are very light and essentially graded for completion. You only have to complete 6 of the 9 to receive a full homework grade, so it's essentially a 6 pset class, which is roughly one every other week if you use all 3 of your drops. Office hours are helpful for psets, but ChatGPT can also help to explain concepts very well since the material isn't that advanced. Using ChatGPT to help on homework assignments actually taught me a lot and helped me gain a better understanding of the concepts since you can ask it to elaborate and relay your points of confusion, so I'd recommend trying that. This class shouldn't take any more than 5 hours a week if you use your resources, though this might pick up again right before the midterm and final. There are also weekly optional sections that can help you review concepts, though ChatGPT did a good enough job of helping reinforce topics to where I didn't need to go to section and I did well on the midterm and final (the curve is quite generous, by the way, though I don't know how it will be under Gabaix).Weiling was a great professor, though she probably won't return next year. I assume Gabaix is just as good, but I'd again recommend reading Spring 2024 reviews if you want the closest parallel. But I would say that any econ major should definitely take this class to fulfill their theory prereq requirement and learn quite useful and applicable information.
worse_comment: I would not really recommend taking this class without prior knowledge. Lecture is very theoretical whereas the problem sets and exams are highly mathematical/problem–solving based, and I don't think that mismatch helps students learn. If you're thinking of taking this course because you want to go into finance, save yourself and your GPA the trouble and take some other class instead (I particularly liked Corporate Finance). You really don't learn much practical knowledge relevant to whatever it is in finance you want to pursue. The professor this year was a substitute so I can't really speak for how this will be run next year, but I gathered that most students didn't really enjoy lecture as they weren't the most engaging/interesting nor were they helpful for completing the problem sets.

course_title: The Financial System and the Central Bank 001
best_comment: MY FAVORITE COURSE AT HARVARD – cannot strongly advocate for it enough!! This is coming from a finance bro background admittedly but it is the perfect blend of the holy trinity of 1) not too much work (a light assignment due every other week) & 2) learning a ton 3) & amazing lectures/professor! This is definitely the best finance undergrad course offered at Harvard – you gain a really strong understanding of debt overhang/restructuring, the limits of arbitrage, good history on the Great Depression and GFC, the role of the central bank’s balance sheet, QE, inflation mandate and even private credit. This course is a real emphasis on credit markets and the importance of credit in the economy so the way it talks about finance is from that lens – not at all about equity markets. You realize how important credit markets are to a functioning economy. Prof Stein is the most engaging, kind and humble lecturer I’ve ever had and probably ever will have at Harvard – cannot highly recommend his teaching enough. You can ask him even the most simple questions and he doesn’t judge you at all – great also at encouraging class participation. Get to know him through office hours or going out to dinner with him! Admittedly, you’ll want to have some basic financial background going into the course cause it will be helpful for getting up to speed and knowing the content – how bond yields move inversely to prices, the dual mandate of the Fed, basic restructuring. The first couple courses – especially the second one on debt overhang feels very overwhelming – basically an intro to RX, but trust me it gets easier from there and the first few lectures shouldn’t scare you if you have doubts on taking the course. Prof Stein is very helpful in answering any question you may have during or after class and you can go to the optional sections as well if you want further clarification of the material.
worse_comment: I would really have some prior knowledge before taking this class, because most students do and you will be at a disadvantage if you don't. The lectures are very engaging but the notes are not comprehensive, detailed, or very coherent which makes studying for the final quite difficult. This class is one of the few classes where having a final exam really does not make much sense. Almost all the assignments are papers/essays critiquing academic literature re: banking. I honestly thought it was unfair that we were not given some sort of practice test for the final; I'm a senior and I have never had a class not provide any sort of practice material for the final exam. Particularly since there is no midterm nor do the assignments mimic the format or style of the final, it felt a bit unfair. I will say, though, that the lectures are very interesting and you develop a very deep understanding of the financial system as a whole. Just be a bit wary about the other components of this course.

best_comment: There are definitely easier Econ electives out there, but I personally found this class to be very interesting! You learn some of the most foundational models in urban economics (even if they appear very stylized), and just hear about a host of issues facing cities today — as well the successes of cities. Both professors bring a wealth of experience, and really made the lectures very engaging. For grading purposes, you can probably get by just by understanding the models (which the sections really help for) and nothing else, but the interesting content is all in lecture so make sure to go to lecture!
worse_comment: Fascinating class that broadly describes what makes cities great (and sometimes not so great). Not an easy A, but psets don't require too much effort and exams are very manageable if you study the models. GO TO SECTION—lectures are not good at teaching the math!

best_comment: There are definitely easier Econ electives out there, but I personally found this class to be very interesting! You learn some of the most foundational models in urban economics (even if they appear very stylized), and just hear about a host of issues facing cities today — as well the successes of cities. Both professors bring a wealth of experience, and really made the lectures very engaging. best_comment: Loved it!!! Not too much work but is totally what you make of it. This class taught me so much about economics of discontinuous change. Not just prior discontinuous change in history, but the change that is happening all around us. Made me think so much about the world around me and loved the class experience. Was also so fun to do a specialized research study.  Meet and speak with professor freeman as much as you can. He is a great and very knowledgable guy.

I would highly recommend the first half of the class and I would not recommend the second half of the class. In the first half of the class, I learned a lot of stuff that is very relevant for every economist. In the second half of the class, I learned very little and the material seems mostly irrelevant.

I would highly recommend the first half of the class and I would not recommend the second half of the class. In the first half of the class, I learned a lot of stuff that is very relevant for every economist. In the second half of the class, I learned very little and the material seems mostly irrelevant.

I would highly recommend the first half of the class and I would not recommend the second half of the class. In the first half of the class, I learned a lot of stuff that is very relevant for every economist. In the second half of the class, I learned very little and the material seems mostly irrelevant.

I guess this is compulsory for the graduate students, but if you are an undergraduate thinking about taking this class, I would recommend it if you are interested in understanding what graduate macro theory is like. The math is harder than undergrad macro so you might have to spend more time, but the concepts you learn are really interesting and it's very cool to see the models from undergrad macro like the NK model more fully fleshed out. Opens up a lot of exciting research fields, and I felt more comfortable reading macro research/theory papers after taking this class.

I guess this is compulsory for the graduate students, but if you are an undergraduate thinking about taking this class, I would recommend it if you are interested in understanding what graduate macro theory is like. The math is harder than undergrad macro so you might have to spend more time, but the concepts you learn are really interesting and it's very cool to see the models from undergrad macro like the NK model more fully fleshed out. This course is excellent.  Some PhD theory courses have the feel of "more than you can handle, 80% material mastery is good benchmark," but not so with this course.  You really do have a chance to learn everything, and you have the materials and guidance to understand it all.  Bravo to Chris and Sam for an excellently designed and equally well–delivered course on game theory and equilibrium analysis.  The lectures are engaging, sections are also very useful, problem sets are fun, and the supplemental materials (Chris had shared draft textbook chapters that were just fantastic) bring you the rest of the way.  I recommend the course very highly, you will enjoy yourself and find challenges that are approachable, encouraging, and fulfilling to tackle.
worse_comment: Take it! You will learn a lot and become a more critical thinker.

best_comment: This course is excellent.  Some PhD theory courses have the feel of "more than you can handle, 80% material mastery is good benchmark," but not so with this course.  You really do have a chance to learn everything, and you have the materials and guidance to understand it all.  Bravo to Chris and Sam for an excellently designed and equally well–delivered course on game theory and equilibrium analysis. worse_comment: Take it! You will learn a lot and become a more critical thinker.

best_comment: As with many graduate–level courses, I would recommend taking this class only if you have a clear sense of your research interests in economics. That said, if you are at all interested in behavioral economics, this course is a must. You’ll be learning foundational theories from the very people who helped develop them.There are certainly ways the course could be improved, but most of these feel like second–order concerns. What matters more is that the class provides an excellent platform to explore key ideas in behavioral economics and to ask meaningful questions.I highly recommend doing the readings—they are essential for fully understanding the material. I also strongly encourage students to ask questions during class. Both professors are extremely generous with their responses, and I personally learned more from their answers than from the lecture slides themselves.This course is especially valuable for students who want to build a strong foundation in behavioral modeling, and who are comfortable with microeconomic theory at the level of a solid undergraduate course.
worse_comment: Do not take a course with Matthew Rabin. I cannot emphasize that enough. He is a wonderful person and a great economist, but a bad teacher in every way. He rambles in lecture and does not explain most things clearly. His problem sets are badly designed, take too long, and have not much pedagogical value — they are often quite disjoint from lecture.David Laibson is amazing — I took this course hoping to learn behavioral economics from him, and it turned out that he was forced to give 2/3 of the course to Matthew so that Matthew could satisfy a teaching requirement. Three hour lectures of Matthew Rabin are very hard to sit through.IN SUMMARY: This is the only class at Harvard that I regret taking.

That said, if you are at all interested in behavioral economics, this course is a must. best_comment: This course is fantastic—I think it's the best course I've taken at Harvard. I think you should take this course if you're interested in exploring a discipline where the distance between mathematics and the world is small: i.e., if you're interested in questions about strategy, behavior, or the world, but find yourself interested in math, this is exactly the right course.I came into this course with significant mathematical background, but little economics background (only 1011a). It was approachable for me, but I was also very excited about the material, and I found myself thinking about the ideas all the time. If you're an undergraduate with some good math background (i.e. you've taken some upper level math courses), then this course will likely be accessible to you. For reference, I found the problem sets in this course harder than the problem sets than the ones in upper level undergraduate math courses (i.e. they are not relatively routine exercises), and closer on par to the graduate ones. It is really inspiring stuff, and Shengwu is a great expositor of the material, as well as a lovely person to talk to about all things economics.

As with many graduate–level courses, I would recommend this class to students who already have a clear sense of their research interests in economics. This course will be especially valuable for those interested in economic theory and formal modeling, or for those studying relationships—formal or informal—that involve issues like moral hazard, adverse selection, or contractual incompleteness.The course offers an excellent overview of core models in contract theory, and Oliver Hart is an outstanding lecturer. The lectures are delivered using chalk and board, which I found particularly effective—it allows students to follow the material step by step and helps the pace stay clear and thoughtful.I strongly recommend keeping up with the readings, as they are important for fully understanding the material. That said, the course can sometimes give the impression that the theory of contracts is largely settled. Personally, I don’t believe that’s the case. To get a better sense of current research, I’d suggest supplementing the course with some additional reading on recent work in the field.

A useful addition to your econometric toolbox, grounded in classic causal inference methods, with some exposure to frontier developments.  Not too stressful if you've taken any econometrics in the past.  More focused on application than theory.  I say this positively — and don't worry, theoretical motivation is still provided and you will run through some of the standard potential–outcomes derivations.  A useful opportunity to code a bit and think through the many assumptions incumbent with various approaches to inference.  You'll walk away with a better understanding of the bread–and–butter of economic analysis!

If you are required to take it, then that's that—but there are reasons to take the course even if it isn't strictly required!  It's a great opportunity to broaden your analytical and econometric horizons.  The scope of the course and variety of estimation/analytical techniques are very ambitious.  Keep a realistic mindset about what you want to take away from the course and you will be fine.

This class was a bit more focused on research in econometrics than I originally thought, which was initially a bit jarring as a primarily applied person. That said, Davide is a fantastic teacher and the topics covered are really interesting and feel relevant. I am really glad that I took the class, and I feel that I learned a ton that I will take with me to future problems.
This is a great class. Jörg and Vincent are outstanding teachers — generous, insightful, and deeply engaging.
This is a great class. Jörg and Vincent are outstanding teachers — generous, insightful, and deeply engaging.

course_title: Public Economics and Fiscal Policy II 001
best_comment: Worth taking to get a good understanding of optimal tax theory and seminal topics in public.

course_title: Public Economics and Fiscal Policy II 001
best_comment: Worth taking to get a good understanding of optimal tax theory and seminal topics in public.

Before taking this class, I had always thought of health economics as a primarily empirical field, focused on applying microeconometric tools to health–related questions. This course completely changed that impression. It offers a rigorous, theory–driven framework that helped me see health economics as a coherent and scientific discipline. I was constantly challenged and inspired by the material. I often stayed after class to ask questions, and the conversations—whether in person or over email—with Professor Cutler were incredibly helpful. Listening to other students—many of whom are PhD candidates—debate and dissect the material during lectures was also one of the most intellectually stimulating aspects of the course. Professor Cutler is not only a world–class economist but also a generous and thoughtful teacher who truly cares about student learning. Even as an undergraduate, I felt welcomed in this PhD–level class. If you’re willing to put in the effort, this course will not only expand your academic toolkit but also fundamentally change how you think about economics. I couldn’t recommend it more.
Read the annual review paper and the JPE paper words by words and you will find the material easier. It takes a relatively large fixed cost, but don't be afraid of investing in this fixed cost!
This is a great class, and I learned a lot about dynamic structural models. Myrto is a fantastic teacher, and the content, while difficult, is quite interesting.

course_title: Theoretical and Empirical Perspectives on Entrepreneurship and Innovation 001
best_comment: If you are at all interested in the academic side of entrepreneurship, take this course! Would especially recommend if you are a junior who is thinking about a senior thesis.
worse_comment: I'm an entrepreneur and student founder and this class was horribly run and a part of my week that I actively dreaded. The reading is interesting but lectures are dull and the TFs do not care about you. Sure, the work load is not too crazy but it's not worth sacrificing one of your classes at Harvard with this one.

course_title: Theoretical and Empirical Perspectives on Entrepreneurship and Innovation 001
best_comment: If you are at all interested in the academic side of entrepreneurship, take this course! Would especially recommend if you are a junior who is thinking about a senior thesis.
worse_comment: I'm an entrepreneur and student founder and this class was horribly run and a part of my week that I actively dreaded. The reading is interesting but lectures are dull and the TFs do not care about you. Sure, the work load is not too crazy but it's not worth sacrificing one of your classes at Harvard with this one.

best_comment: A great class for seeing how econometrics is actually used in research. The methods covered are modern and framed in the context of real–world applications, especially financial research. The course emphasizes when and why to use different tools, highlighting how messy applied work can be.That said, much of the content builds on graduate–level econometrics, so to get the most out of the class, you'll want at least a strong undergraduate metrics background. The assignments are not designed to teach the techniques from scratch. Rather, you're expected to apply them in open–ended, research–like settings: tasks like reproducing tables from papers using public datasets and libraries, writing referee reports, and completing a final paper or presentation.Even if your grad–level econometrics is rusty, the structure of the course still allows you to engage and succeed. Even if half the lectures are over your head, you'll still learn a lot and be able to complete the assignments.The workload was reasonable overall, but Assignment 3 (constructing equity factors using WRDS) was challenging, requiring a WRDS account and working with SAS code. Overall, the TA and professors were responsive and helpful, so definitely reach out if you get stuck or if the instructions aren't clear.

A great class for seeing how econometrics is actually used in research. The methods covered are modern and framed in the context of real–world applications, especially financial research. The course emphasizes when and why to use different tools, highlighting how messy applied work can be.That said, much of the content builds on graduate–level econometrics, so to get the most out of the class, you'll want at least a strong undergraduate metrics background. Overall, the TA and professors were responsive and helpful, so definitely reach out if you get stuck or if the instructions aren't clear.

course_title: Labor Economics and Labor Market Institutions 001
best_comment: You truly get out what you put into this course. There's much to cover and certainly not enough time to cover it all in great detail, so it will be on you to follow through with outside reading and other exploration if you're interested in learning more. That said, it's worthwhile to do, and a great course overall!

course_title: Early Stage Research and Discussions on the Economics of Health Equity 001
best_comment: This reading group is very fun and positive! Interesting to speak to an interdisciplinary group from across the university.

course_title: Early Stage Research and Discussions on the Economics of Health Equity 001
best_comment: This reading group is very fun and positive! Interesting to speak to an interdisciplinary group from across the university.

course_title: Graduate Student Workshop in Economic History 001
Graduate Student Workshop in Economic History 001
Graduate Student Workshop in Labor Economics 001
Graduate Student Workshop in Labor Economics 001
Graduate Student Workshop in Labor Economics 001
Educational Outcomes in Cross-National and Cross-Cultural Perspectives 001
best_comment: It's a great class! It's chill but really fulfilling and sparks interesting conversations. The TFs and professor are also really cool to learn from. It is a flipped classroom though so you may need to go out of your way to hear your TFs or professors' views on certain topics. Overall, it's a fun class though!
worse_comment: Please do not enroll in this course if you are not interested in education at all. It was disappointing that some students were clearly only interested in this course because it was "easy" and it brought down the quality of discussion.

course_title: Children with Learning and Developmental Differences 001
best_comment: This class is good! It's kind of an awkward size (not lecture, not seminar), which makes participating kind of challenging. You get to do some fun activities in class (IEP simulations), the assignments are really cool, open–ended, and manageable, and Professor Gaab is really awesome!

course_title: Education in the East and West 001
best_comment: Very easy course that can also be very personally fulfilling. Class is long, but they try ot make it engaging. Assignments are easy and also pretty fun if you are genuinely interested in the topic. I think personal interest in the subject of education is really important for how much you enjoy and get out of this class. I had very strong personal reasons for being interesting in the subject, which I had many opportunities to explore through class assignments – that is a really valuable and hard to find opportunity!!The class definitely has an objective in mind, which is to make you more culturally sensitive. I think that's important, but if you aren't interested in learning about that, this class will be annoying to you.

course_title: Flavor Molecules of Food Fermentation: Exploration and Inquiry 001
best_comment: Chances are you’ve been referred to this class by someone, and your eyes are wide open at the blueness of the Q Guide.This class was an absolute privilege and a blast to take. Pia and Alex are incredibly talented, friendly, and passionate about what they do—they’re the kind of instructors I wish every science class had. If you’re looking to engage in profound yet low–stress science while also having fun and learning how to make (and understand) fermented food, this class is for you.This is also very much an “only at Harvard” kind of class: the dedicated teaching space, overqualified and deeply engaged teaching staff, ample resources, exciting field trips, and guest lectures all come together to create a one–of–a–kind experience—an ideal bookend to your senior year.My only regret was not having more time to devote to it. That’s actually the one piece of advice I really hope you take: try to keep your schedule clear before and/or after class. I didn’t do this, so it’s definitely not a requirement—but if you can, it makes the cooking sessions feel much more relaxed (since you’re not rushing off to your next class), and it gives you the chance to stick around afterward and talk with the teaching team. That extra time also helps with the final project, which requires some work outside of regular class hours. Regarding the project, make sure to plan ahead, coordinate well with your group, and give the it your full effort—it’ll make the experience that much more fun and rewarding.Other than that, just come to class with energy and a willingness to get your hands dirty. If you do, this will be one of the highlights of your Harvard academic experience.

course_title: Humanity and its Futures: AI and Human Cognition 001
best_comment: This class is super interesting! It is more philosophical than technical, but still super interesting! Homeworks are group conversations on readings and one group presentation a semester! Workload is manageable and material is super interesting!

This class was an absolute trip, but the good outweighs the bad for the right type of person. I took this class as a prospective EE concentrator to test my interest in the different areas of EE. The class is split into two halves. Before spring break, we learned about analog circuits (taught by Gu) and after spring break, we did digital circuits and logic (taught by Reddi). The course content is very overwhelming in its pace and without a section (which would have been life changing) it is very easy to fall behind. Fortunately, Gu and Reddi are extremely accessible and helpful in office hours and answered all of my questions, even basic ones, without making me feel stupid or incapable. Get to know them if you can because they are so knowledgeable and willing to help or just chat! My experience in office hours affirmed my decision to concentrate in EE because once so many challenging concepts made sense to me, I realized that I loved learning about EE (particularly the digital side) more than anything else I have ever learned and I found the challenge very satisfying to work through. PSETs are long (as in 20+ pages) so you MUST start early.Things that could be improved:–From my understanding, the professor that normally teaches ES50 was on sabbatical so a lot of the course structure was very unorganized or changed at the last minute.–They promised us 3 weeks to work on our final projects, but we only got 2. Many, many hours were spent in the SEC getting it to work on a very rushed schedule.–I have never been mansplained to and talked down to so much in my life. It got to the point where I dreaded labs where I should have been looking forward to learning hands–on skills. If you are a woman taking this class and something bothers you, fix it right away. My biggest regret is not saying something as soon as it bothered me early in the semester. It would have been nice if resources about this were highlighted because I was not the only person with this experience.–I did ES50 without an extensive technical background or direct hands–on experience. My lab partner had already taken circuits classes and had had the opportunity to do many hands–on projects before ES50. Due to this mismatch and him wanting to do the labs as quickly as possible, I did not get as much out of the labs as I wanted to. Do not be afraid to switch lab partners. Best resources:–Mega OH on Wednesday nights–Gu and Reddi themselves (But Reddi will be the only one teaching ES50 next year)–Upperclassmen–Langa and Roderick’s OH (both graduating unfortunately)
worse_comment: I would not recommend this course as a first glimpse into EE, purely due to the teaching style and structure. Gu’s lectures were slow and inefficient—he often spent two full classes explaining what could’ve been covered in half a lecture. This left us consistently behind, making it difficult to keep up with labs. VJ was the opposite: fast–paced and concise, but sometimes too much so. He’d call something “very important” and then move on after five minutes, leaving no room for questions or deeper understanding.Exams were stressful with the new shorter time limit. The previous 6–hour format allowed for more careful work; bringing it back would reduce unnecessary pressure. Labs were hit–or–miss—partner work often meant one person dominated, making it hard to learn independently.PSETs were thorough and aligned well with exam material, but the workload was intense—20 pages in a single week is tough.The final project was a rushed endeavor and hard to power through when previous weeks were filled with PSETting and midterm studying – the midterm really put our group behind. Overall, it's the TFs who really made the course tolerable. It's a horrible course, but seek guidance from TFs who really want to help you.

best_comment: I know everyone will say that this course heavily depends on your teammates, and it is true. If you have teammates that contribute and put in some amount of work, it makes life 50x easier. I will say my year was particularly amazing because of how all the students in the class trauma bonded. I don't know if its always like that, but it would make sense if it did. I made some new friendships from this class, and made some amazing memories. I am a mathematics and electrical engineering major, but I believe this is still a useful class, as it helps you get 1. hands on experience, and 2. understand the steps that go into producing something like a robot. This is a skill I will continue to develop and definitely use in the future. The TAs are amazing(Taylor you are amazing the best Lab TA ever), they will help you with every pset, and lab work, they are very understanding. The professor is pretty good, very passionate when you get to talk to him about other things besides ES51, and is also just an amazing grader. The tests are a lot better with him grading them. You will need to lock in a little bit sometimes, especially towards the latter half of the course, but if you spend 5 to 8 hours per week on this course, it should be fine.
worse_comment: I think it is important for the student to understand that this class is very doable and you can perform well in it but there will be periods of time in which the class picks up and gives you an extreme amount of work which will be stressful.

course_title: Entrepreneurship and Innovation: Case Study Perspectives 001
best_comment: It's pretty good. not a life changing class or anything, but you'll learn 2–3 bulletpoints worth of ideas by the end of it. You don't get any feedback on papers, and in general not too much structure. 20% A, 70% A–, 10% B+ curve, so free A– but you have to participate every day and write good essays + good final project for A. If you are working on a startup, this might just be a good space to meet new people. You can have office hours with HBS professors and Kent who's a partner at Bessemer. They also bring in pretty cool guest lecturers from startups, so that gives you an opportunity to meet them too. I feel that the learning opportunities are moreso with interacting with the very knowledgeable staff than the cases and stuff, though those are cool and fun to read too. Overall I'd recommend it.

course_title: Entrepreneurship and Innovation: Case Study Perspectives 002
best_comment: This is one of the best courses I've taken at Harvard. The material is interesting, the professors really care about the material and inspire excitement, and the guest speakers are world–class. The case–style method really encourages classroom engagement and paying attention, which I like better than just sitting in a lecture without discussion.
best_gem_comment: The class is an easy one if you put no effort into it, but it's potentially really impactful if you actually do the readings and participate in class. Most people take this as a gem, but the final project is actually super long. If you take this class, you'll only get anything out of it if you do the readings and participate; don't go to class just to do your emails or play games on your laptop.

best_comment: Very helpful class, but super unstructured. Awesome projects to learn about from your peers, though!

course_title: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project 001
best_comment: This course provides a good opportunity to apply the concepts learned in engineering courses, solve a real world problem, and collaborate with other engineers. Make sure to work together and stick to a well–defined timeline to ensure that the project is completed to a high level and in a timely manner.

course_title: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project 002
best_comment: Overall, this course was deeply unsatisfactory. The teaching staff were highly disorganized—assignment deadlines were often announced the night before, and we weren’t informed about a major 100–page report until less than two weeks before it was due. It often felt like the instructors forgot we had other classes and commitments, expecting ES96 to take up our entire week.That said, I did appreciate that our section was at least able to accomplish something meaningful. I’ve heard from peers in other groups that they would sit in the SEC for hours with no direction or progress. Our industry client’s frequent visits and helpful feedback were a definite highlight and made the experience somewhat worthwhile.Still, ES96 has a well–known reputation in the department for being chaotic, and this iteration only reinforced that. The lack of structure and clear communication pushed a disproportionate amount of responsibility onto a few highly involved students, which was unsustainable and exhausting.This course desperately needs a clearer curriculum, better planning, and more respect for students' time and bandwidth.
worse_comment: Here is what I wish the teaching staff said on day 1: "Sometimes as an engineer, you are presented with a specific problem and must design a solution. That is the exercise of ES 100. Other times, however, the question is just 'how do we make more money as a company?' That latter question is more difficult in that you need to first find a problem that exists in the world or a hole in the market that you think you can fill. That is essence of ES 96: can you develop a product by first finding a question and then developing solutions. There are three phases to this process: research, making a problem statement, and prototyping a solution. But these phases are not one after the other. Instead, you will spend the first month of the class just researching problems in this specific industry. Then for the two weeks after that you will start writing problem statements AND doing research as you are developing your research. Then the last 6 weeks of the class will involve prototyping AND modifying your problem statement AND doing research. You develop a problem statement but realize it is not supported by research in which you have to modify the problem statement. You may develop a solution that works, doesn't address your problem statement, but could address another problem. So by the end you are bouncing between all three of these phases: research, problem statement, prototyping."

best_comment: You should thesis. All engineers should thesis. I learned SO much about the engineering design process and anyone who studies engineering can do a great job at their thesis if they put the time into it. Chose a topic that you are passionate about and chose an advisor that is encouraging, preferably someone you have done research with. Don't shy away from new topics and softwares, but you have to be willing to put the work in. It's pretty incredible watching your friends reach their dreams as they develop their projects and realizing that you are doing the same for yourself. VERY cool opportunity to work alongside incredibly impressive Harvard staff.
worse_comment: Your thesis advisor matters a LOT. But if you're already at this point for the second semester of ES100, just make sure that you get as much done before spring break as possible to make your post–break experience a lot less miserable.

best_comment: ES105hfr is systemically unfair. Not only does this course satisfy the junior engineering design requirement for only electrical engineering students, but it also imposes a strict grading system and enrollment process.Firstly, the grading system is harsh. While you will most likely leave the course with an A, the professor is just one of those teachers who refuse to give out a 100. It all boils down to the instructor's pedagogy, which I do not agree with. On the syllabus, it says that "Everyone can’t be doing a great job with everything, all the time. It’s just not possible." I find this comment to be a bit pessimistic. The course also has an enrollment cap that is very unfortunate – EWB chapters all around the world allow any student to contribute to ongoing projects. Even though our chapter is structured as a class, I  firmly believe that this course should be enrollment–cap free. Let students who would like to support humanitarian causes participate.ES105hfr counting as a junior design course only for electrical engineers is unnecessarily selective. Why EE majors in particular? If anything, the skills learned in ES105hfr are more aligned with civil/mechanical than electrical engineers. This course should satisfy the junior design requirement for all engineering students. I find myself discussing the structure around ES105hfr more than the content of the course itself – the work you do is great, there's no doubt about it. The students are incredible, and they are the reason why this course works in the end. But I cannot seem to remain quiet about the structure around the course, which I hope to see improve in the future.

Great thermodynamics course that can be applied across most disciplines. Thermodynamics is often perceived as a difficult topic to comprehend, but I definitely think that Scot made it seem endurable and easier to understand.  Some concepts felt a little blurry, especially when you're looking at diagrams.  However, the books and lectures are mostly helpful. Section and office hours are definitely a key component of the course because that is where most of the application occurs. Also, be prepared to present every 2–3 weeks in this course. Most presentations are around 3 minutes and not too difficult if you put in the effort to learn the topic you want to discuss. Scot also likes to use cold–calling to induce classroom engagement.  I personally learn better in smaller sections/courses so definitely take this course if you need or are interested in thermo.

Take this course! Great way to satisfy your honors requirement, and Prof. Kuang is so amazing: he gives reassuring Dad in the best way possible! Do note that there are quite a few assignments – more so than I had anticipated, but they're all easily done with a good group (would recommend taking the class with at least 2–3 other people you know you'd work well together) and some of them are optional / count for extra credit. There are 3 major projects, two of which are group–based (with the same group) and the last is individual. In the moment, they were a little stressful, but it's actually really fun to create these modeling projects and take ownership over a small research study that you apply the concepts learned in class to. I definitely spent a reasonable amount of time on this class each week (around 7 hours, more or less depending on the week), especially for an APMTH class.

course_title: Introduction to the Mechanics of Solids 001
best_comment: This was an interesting and enjoyable class, I thought the lectures were comprehensive and understandable –– Dr. Coughlin usually derives the equations during them, but he also makes sure to do quite a few examples to show how all of the concepts are applied. The problem sets were also doable and fair; they aligned well with what was taught in class, and they were a good amount of challenging without being too frustrating. I do wish that there was some more discussion about the relationships between different concepts and how to utilize them to inform them when designing (and not to just do calculations on a given design), so that we have more of an idea of how we would apply these in the future. The exams were also fair, and they were similar to the format of the homework questions, so it was not too stressful studying for the exams, although the two midterms were a time crunch.I liked the bridge competition at the end of the semester, but it would have been nice to get more guidance on how we can make sure that we're optimizing the strength–to–weight ratio and design tricks/lessons for it. I also wish the labs were more hands–on, usually, we just watched the experiment being done and then just recorded the data. Also, the lab reports were sometimes tedious to do, but there are only two of them for the semester, so it's not too big of a deal. Overall though, ES 120 will teach you a lot, and the content will teach you a lot. Hopefully, Dr. Coughlin keeps teaching this course because he does a great job, and it's also clear that he cares about the students and wants to make sure that we understand the content.
worse_comment: Combination of office hours and textbook are absolutely necessary to completely the psets. The exams are fair but lectures are incredible unengaging and difficult to follow because Mark will oftentimes go through a problem, realize he made a mistake be really shaky about it. Only 3 office hours per week so make sure to plan your time accordingly.

course_title: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics and Transport Processes 001
best_comment: This is a solid class. The professor is great and super good at explaining things. The problem sets are fair and there are plenty of TFs to help out. Also, something I really appreciated about this class is that the exams are manageable after reviewing the HW and provided practice exams. The computational fluid dynamics labs with COMSOL were also super fun. I really liked how this class goes over examples spanning everything from aerospace and jet propulsion to fluid dynamics in the human body. However, it is fluid mechanics so it can get pretty math heavy especially when you start solving Navier–Stokes in non–cartesian coordinate systems. Overall, this is one of the most well taught engineering classes here along with ES125.
worse_comment: Read the textbook chapter before lecture. It will help you understand what happens in lecture. Attend lecture. The examples covered in lecture are very helpful for problem sets and exams.  Start problem sets early, on your own, then go to office hours when you get stuck. Wrap up the problem sets on your own, rather than just writing down what you're told at office hours and submitting. In this way you will get a better grasp of the material, which can be confusing until you work through enough problems, setting them up by yourself.

best_comment: Wonderful class and highly recommended! Yue is a wonderful teacher and I thought the lectures were incredibly helpful. Workload is super light for a STEM class (I took this alongside CS 161, so you can probably trust me on this). 1 homework assignment per week that was fun, not too long and helped you understand the topics and didn't take more than 2–3 hours (unless you insist on LaTeXing all your assignments the way I do, in which case expect to spend slightly more time :D). 1 lab every two weeks that also takes ~1–2 hours to complete (don't worry about knowing Python, as the labs require very basic command of the language and there's an ungraded lab 0 that will help you learn the basics you need). Exams were reasonable and weren't too easy/difficult, and there's always a ton of practice material. Smaller class–size (compared to the massive Stat 110). I never needed to go to OH for this class, but even in the case you do it's probably a relief to know you won't have to wait in a long OH queue :)  Overall, loved this class and I'm very glad it's offered as another option for the CS probability requirement. Highly recommended!

Take this class!! Evelyn is such a great professor and she cares so deeply about her students. This class was great to learn more about the application of EM concepts and to learn how to best utilize different concepts to develop new technologies. Also, the class is structured well. You will either have a lab report or a homework due in a week, not both in one week. Also, a large portion of the class is also dedicated to getting to know your classmates, which I feel like is very rare in a STEM class. Definitely take this if you are looking to learn a lot and have hands on practice!

This class is great, but you do have to put in consistent effort. Flavio is amazing and very supportive, but be sure that you go through all of the lecture notes and content to gain a conceptual understanding of the ideas. I think this is a great class and you will learn a lot! The grading scheme is also decently generous, with an optional final project that can boost your grade significantly. In terms of some cons, the teaching staff was not as robust as it could have been. Only having 2 TFs with limited time made it difficult to gain feedback on assignments in a fast manner and get the necessary help to learn. Definitely would have learned better having more staff and office hours. It was also difficult to study for exams without solutions to the practice exams. I think having the solutions to some of these problems would have helped immensely.

ES177 is a great course. Throughout the semester, you have 4 labs (each ~4 hours), 4 lab reports, and 1 final project review (or final project if you take ES277). The four–hour lab can sound intimidating, but it was honestly a good time. A lot of the time, we finished early. If we went past dinner, the class had a budget and got food afterwards as a group.This course is a great way to get ISO–5 cleanroom experience, especially with microfabrication. Getting microfab cleanroom experience is typically not offered for undergrads, so this is a great opportunity to try something new. I recommend the course!

Take this class if MECHE concentrator, especially if professor Wicks is teaching. Do not let the quizzes put you off. They are graded very generously and makes the studying for the midterms and finals much easier (as you already know a lot of the material already from studying for the quizzes). Also professor Wicks focuses on intuition a lot and real word application, which is great.

course_title: Using First Principles to Reverse-engineer Complex Biological Systems 001
best_comment: ***prof cluzel is so kind and knowledgeable! the content itself is very interesting and insightful (kind of ls50–core), but the assignments are very straightforward and approachable. class was part lecture part doing out derivations on the whiteboards which i found to be really fun. cluzel has a ton of interesting anecdotes and perspectives and is just overall a great guy to talk to and get to know.

Going to office hours and interacting with teaching staffs and peers are very helpful. Take detailed notes and make sure you understand/remember the derivation, even though derivation is not emphasized in the class.

This course requires a significant time commitment, making it challenging to balance with other academic responsibilities. If you’re planning to take it, consider treating it as the equivalent of 2.5 courses in terms of workload. If you have prior experience with cell culture and a background in cell biology, the course will be pretty easy– but regardless of your experience level, you will spend a lot of time on this course. That said, you’ll gain a deep understanding of cell biology, and the course is both engaging and enjoyable!
worse_comment: This course is a hands–on meat grinder that teaches students highly applicable and relevant lab skills. If you are looking to hit the ground running as an undergrad with limited/no previous experience, this course will whip your ass into shape quicker than greased lightning.  The lab staff is supportive and available quite often, and TFs are highly invested in the course material, which helps to somewhat ease the demanding nature of the course. Admittedly, this course demands your time, but as an undergrad, the only way to improve your technique is to get reps at the bench, which takes time. This course is highly rewarding, and I personally feel as though I am walking away from this course with more takeaways than a majority of the other bio–related courses I have taken. As for Professor Parker, he is a somewhat polarizing man. He speaks with authority, and far more directly than other professors I have encountered.
