For some, this is a huge turn–off, especially if you are used to sugarcoated feedback and calm lectures that bore you to death. For others, myself included, direct constructive feedback is probably the most helpful thing I could ask for as a learning student. Bottom line: if you are doing something stupid, Parker will say "hey, stop doing that stupid thing" (sometimes in a more colorful manner).

course_title: Biomechanics of Movement and Assistive Robotics 001
best_comment: This is a great course. It's a really good opportunity to learn about the field of biomechanics, with Prof Patrick Slade, who's a fun, down to earth, and really invested in everyone's learning. It also has a good opportunity to experiment and build something of your own, fairly rudimentary but nonetheless a good way to do some actual building. It's less on the hardware and more on understanding human motion and human augmentation and touches on exoskeletons but not necessarily in the sci–fi way (the field is not that evolved yet). Regardless, it is a bit intense on the workload, but manageable, and a good experience. Great to do with friends, but also great to do solo and learn from others.

Do not be afraid of previous Q–guide reviews regarding this class. It is not as bad as it seems. It is indeed very time–consuming, but I found much of the work to be spent on research and/or documentation, and working with a team certainly helps a lot in terms of splitting up the workload.  If you want to go into the medical device industry, you should definitely take this class. This class is one of the closest things at Harvard that will give you exposure to what it's like to work as an engineer––– from constant feedback, collaboration, iterative prototyping, design validation/testing, working with clients, presentations to documentation. The experience and skills you gain in this class will look great to have on your resume or grad school applications. What you gain out of this class makes all the time and sacrifices spent worth it. The professors have high expectations of you, and you will sometimes have to scrap ideas and projects you were working on and start over. If you have a bad team, communicate with your teammates your expectations maturely and take some measures to improve the team dynamics immediately. You will be spending most of your semester with them.
worse_comment: Good exposure to medical device design, but it does take a lot of work, especially at the end. Bring some physical and electronics prototyping experience and you’ll be good, the difficulty lies in narrowing your design at the beginning with your team and managing your time at the end.

best_comment: Do not be afraid of previous Q–guide reviews regarding this class. It is not as bad as it seems. It is indeed very time–consuming, but I found much of the work to be spent on research and/or documentation, and working with a team certainly helps a lot in terms of splitting up the workload.  If you want to go into the medical device industry, you should definitely take this class. This class is one of the closest things at Harvard that will give you exposure to what it's like to work as an engineer––– from constant feedback, collaboration, iterative prototyping, design validation/testing, working with clients, presentations to documentation. The experience and skills you gain in this class will look great to have on your resume or grad school applications. What you gain out of this class makes all the time and sacrifices spent worth it. The professors have high expectations of you, and you will sometimes have to scrap ideas and projects you were working on and start over. If you have a bad team, communicate with your teammates your expectations maturely and take some measures to improve the team dynamics immediately. You will be spending most of your semester with them.
worse_comment: Good exposure to medical device design, but it does take a lot of work, especially at the end. Bring some physical and electronics prototyping experience and you’ll be good, the difficulty lies in narrowing your design at the beginning with your team and managing your time at the end.

best_comment: This course is a must–take for anyone interested in the energy/electricity sectors – it offers a very thorough treatment of virtually all energy–related technologies, spanning both fossil fuels and renewables, as well as other relevant topics like energy economics and power grids.  I feel like this is the one class in particular I've taken at Harvard that has best informed/reshaped my understanding of the broad landscape of energy and power.Regarding work, the textbook is the linchpin of the course and strikes an excellent balance between breadth and technical detail; the lectures largely follow the same structure as the book.  As such, my main advice is: the more time you put into reading the textbook before each class, the more you will get out of this course.  It's a lot to take in, but you won't regret putting in the legwork here.  This also goes for the final project: start early and pursue something interesting, and it will be a highly rewarding experience.  Finally, definitely go to Prof. Aziz's office hours or otherwise discuss the content/projects with him, and also definitely try to make all of the guest lectures!

This course is a must–take for anyone interested in the energy/electricity sectors – it offers a very thorough treatment of virtually all energy–related technologies, spanning both fossil fuels and renewables, as well as other relevant topics like energy economics and power grids.  I feel like this is the one class in particular I've taken at Harvard that has best informed/reshaped my understanding of the broad landscape of energy and power.Regarding work, the textbook is the linchpin of the course and strikes an excellent balance between breadth and technical detail; the lectures largely follow the same structure as the book.  As such, my main advice is: the more time you put into reading the textbook before each class, the more you will get out of this course.  It's a lot to take in, but you won't regret putting in the legwork here.  This also goes for the final project: start early and pursue something interesting, and it will be a highly rewarding experience.  Finally, definitely go to Prof. Aziz's office hours or otherwise discuss the content/projects with him, and also definitely try to make all of the guest lectures!
It's a good class and worth the time for anyone interested in mechanics in general (not necessarily fracture mechanics).
Be prepared to get out what you put in, this course will not force you to spend a lot of time on it, but if you are willing to put energy into it, you will get a lot out!

Overall: ES 255 combines people from an electronic circuit design background (Team E) and from a photonic circuit design background (Team P) to create electro–optic transceivers, modulators, and devices. You do not need to know both domains! The point of the class is to expose you to both domains and how they can work together to create electronic–photonic circuits that leverage the strengths of both electronics and photonics (Team PE/EP). The course is largely structured around components and trade–offs of an electro–optical transceiver for communication in data centers. Professor: The same Gage we’ve known and loved from ES 152 and CS 1480/2480 <3 Textbooks: N/ATopics covered: electro–photonic integrated circuit transceiver overview (memory and sequential electronic logic, VCSEL and driver, optical coupling, optical fiber channel, photo–detector array, bandwidth/data rate/BER, optical receiver); optical waveguide model; electro–optic phase shifters, interferometers, and modulators (plasma dispersion effect, Pockel’s effect, digital/analog/linearized MZM, intensity/quadrature); transmission line impedance matching; directional couplers and micro–ring resonators; analog/digital/mixed signal simulation and design (a la CS 1480/2480) and photonics PDK; power/performance/bandwidth estimation/simulation of FETs, drivers, and receivers; VCSEL vs. MZM modulator comparison; optical network switches, active optical metamaterials, optical computing. Course structure notes: Two psets plus a final presentation and project deep–dive on a topic of your choice. Though a lot can (and will) change since the course is brand–new my year.
Fun project–based course. You really get out what you put in. Great vibes and Steve is fantastic.
worse_comment: I would like to tell future students that the course can be very chaotic and frustrating, so it's important to be prepared for that

best_comment: This class was definitely an experience as an undergraduate. On one hand, the content is unique; Professor Capasso (if he's teaching it) is a juggernaut in the field and you'll learn concepts in the latter third of the class that don't have textbooks written on them yet. So, from a pure novelty perspective, I think it is worth considering. On the other hand, I didn't think Capasso was a very effective lecturer; he is someone who is highly intelligent, but not very aware of the level at which everyone else is at (especially undergrads) and either doesn't know how to communicate to us or simply doesn't care to do so effectively (I personally think it is the former).  The bulk of my learning in this class came from the TFs, Nicholas and Andrea (these two really made the class for me and if at least one of them is teaching the class, I think you'll have a fine time), and doing the homework assignments and exams. I will say that you should take my words a healthy amount of salt: this is a graduate level course and my only real preparation for the class was Physics 15B and Physics 143A and I've never taken an optics course of any kind in my life. I believe I got the majority of the content I was supposed to from the class, but I definitely felt out of my depth half the time. I highly recommend that you become very comfortable with E&M before taking this course (especially E&M in dielectric materials) and give yourself at least a little exposure to ray optics.

ES177 is a great course. Throughout the semester, you have 4 labs (each ~4 hours), 4 lab reports, and 1 final project review (or final project if you take ES277). The four–hour lab can sound intimidating, but it was honestly a good time. A lot of the time, we finished early. If we went past dinner, the class had a budget and got food afterwards as a group.This course is a great way to get ISO–5 cleanroom experience, especially with microfabrication. Getting microfab cleanroom experience is typically not offered for undergrads, so this is a great opportunity to try something new. I recommend the course!
best class in the MSMBA!
best class in the MSMBA!

course_title: Humanity and its Futures: AI and Human Cognition 001
best_comment: This class is super interesting! It is more philosophical than technical, but still super interesting! Homeworks are group conversations on readings and one group presentation a semester! Workload is manageable and material is super interesting!

course_title: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: This class is SO great. I made so much progress on my manuscript, and I learned a ton about how to write a good scientific paper. Beyond just the paper, I grew as a person and a scientist. Suzanne and Jenny are great professors for this class, and the students in the class are wonderful and open about their struggles and experiences as we all wrote papers together. I couldn't recommend it more!

course_title: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: This class is SO great. I made so much progress on my manuscript, and I learned a ton about how to write a good scientific paper. Beyond just the paper, I grew as a person and a scientist. Suzanne and Jenny are great professors for this class, and the students in the class are wonderful and open about their struggles and experiences as we all wrote papers together. I couldn't recommend it more!

This course was great; however, it would have been even better if it had included more students with a genuine and serious interest in film. Screenwriting has a distinct and highly specific form, and choosing to write a screenplay, rather than a novel or short story, should be a deliberate and intentional decision. For many students, it felt like that choice wasn’t grounded in a true engagement with the medium, but rather in a desire to take a light or "fun" creative writing course. Without a strong interest in film, important conversations around cinematic form, structure, and visual storytelling tend to fall by the wayside. As a result, much of the feedback focused primarily on plot, which made the experience feel less like an exploration of screenwriting as an art form and more like a general storytelling workshop. This limited the course's potential to offer a truly transformational creative experience rooted in the unique language of screenwriting. If you're looking for a fun and creative writing course, this one absolutely fits that description. But if you're seriously interested in becoming a filmmaker or screenwriter, particularly for feature films, it may fall short of expectations. Personally, I found that much of the peer feedback I received was fairly one–note, and I came away wishing I had gotten more out of the experience. However, the teacher is amazing and you can get a lot out of him with those things if you engage with him outside of class.
Sam is awesome! You're gonna write a play. Whether it's good or bad doesn't matter, but it's still gonna be super fun. :)

This course is excellent! Josh is the best mentor for poetry at Harvard. He is attentive, cares about your work and shows genuine enthusiasm for your growth. My writing has improved significantly, and I feel so much more grounded in my poetic voice. I have taken other poetry workshops in the past with other professors, but Josh is most definitely top–tier!

This is an incredible class. Laura is super knowledgeable in the craft of writing and the writing/publishing world too. Her feedback is so thoughtful and insightful and the classroom environment is welcoming and kind. This class nurtured my love for the craft and nurtured my desire to keep writing fiction in the future.

this class is half grad students and half undergrads and I loved it a lot! I had a lot of qualms about english classes at Harvard where discussions are cursory and not focused on close–reading. The first half of the class is spent on close–reading short stories where I really felt like everyone was engaged (the no screens policy helped as well) and I loved reading everyone else's stories and having time to workshop my own. I always wanted to find time to write but haven't had the chance in college and this was a super fun way to really produce works that I always wanted to write

This has been one of my favorite classes at Harvard (and I have taken a lot of classes here). The structure of the class is very simple: you begin by reading and discussing published short stories for the first few weeks, before moving into discussing only student work. Everybody writes 2 stories, a short one and a longer one. But what makes the class so great is the depth with which you discuss each piece of writing. Teju gets you to intensely analyze everything that the author of each work does, and in doing so, you gain a very strong understanding of how to be a successful writer. Even when the work we were discussing wasn't my own, I felt that the lessons Teju and my classmates were conveying via their feedback/analysis to be very helpful to my writing. This was my first writing workshop, and I'm sorry I didn't take it sooner.

If you can take the class with Reginald Dwyane Betts, do it. He's funny asl. He's like Kanye's like–able long lost brother ( I mean this in a good way, Dwayne is very cool). Course load was easy and he didn't make his class toxic by making it the first priority and workload on everybody's to do list. Dwayne was a busy man (and so were we as students ) so it was like a well constructed and beneficial and chill poetry club that met once a week. We just talked about poems, hip hop, the 90's, basketball, and anything in between. The class itself felt long but in terms of hours a week this is the lowest time commitment you can go. 2:45 hours a week and thats it point blank period. No section. No nothing. Maybe write a few poems on the weekend, but thats extremely slight if you ask me. He wants so succeed and will give you a good grade as long as you show up and add to discussion. As long as you aint visibly taking naps and snoring in class while drooling on the professors bookbag, you will get a good grade, so def take if you like poems and chill workloads.
worse_comment: Dwayne is a bit unorganized and I feel that we did not have much time to workshop our poems and get feedback unless we signed up for additional time through office hours. I also wish that he paid more attention to each student — he didn't really learn our names until the end of the semester and there were a few students he would mistake for each other/not remember from previous classes. I also wish we had learned more about the craft of a poem — I think learning about literary devices (which we would spend at least an hour each class doing) is not as helpful as actually having to write poems in different forms/employ those devices in our own writing. However, I learned a lot about modern poetry and about what makes a good poem, and alternatively, what makes a bad poem. It's also always very helpful to be working with a practicing artist to see how they approach their craft and learn from their story.

best_comment: Best class at Harvard. This workshop is the perfect opportunity to hone your craft and thoughtfully contribute to your classmates’ work. More than any other workshop, this class gives you great feedback, especially critique and suggestions for improvement. Josh is the GOAT.

course_title: Getting the Words Right: The Art of Revision 001
best_comment: This is possibly my favorite course I've taken at Harvard. It's just amazing and such a rare and unique experience. Laura is phenomenal and I felt like I grew exponentially as a writer. My peers were so thoughtful and passionate and it was such a wonderful space to be in this semester. I cannot recommend this course enough!

course_title: Play and Games: The Art of Sportswriting 001
best_comment: I think that your writing improves over the semester since you're able to write in several different styles. You pick up different methods from other students as well, which is really helpful. Super chill environment, and final paper is a lot of fun to write. Louisa is a fantastic instructor as well. Would definitely recommend.

This is a great class! Musa is awesome, and I feel like I'm leaving the class with a strong foundation in screenwriting. The class environment was really lovely, and we got to watch short films about a variety of topics.

course_title: Creative Nonfiction Workshop: Comedy and Creative Nonfiction 001
best_comment: Melissa was delightful, and she cultivated a very lighthearted, generally lovely space!Like most creative writing workshops, you get out what you put in. My goal was to learn how to get personal with my comedy, and by pushing myself to get personal with each essay, I was able to fulfill that. If you are interested in comedy writing and want to get personal in the written form, I say do it! If you are taking this class cause you can do stand up for the final, just hit an open mic! The focus of the course and feedback is certainly on the written form.

It's sometimes difficult to feel like you can write organically when there are a lot of high–stakes and pressure. This class creates a relaxed environment to freely work on your writing as you wish. To be noted is that it is a memoir–heavy class, so if you're trying to improve other types of writing (academic writing, very reflection–heavy writing, etc.), then this maybe is not the class for that. However, it is the class to help you own your voice in your writing and become better at writing anecdotes. Melissa also has been incredibly aware and understanding of the other things going on throughout the semester, so she is receptive to student concerns, which makes it easier for students to fully commit to the class, as opposed to rush through the material as if it is busy work.

This was my second time taking a class with Louisa, and I can say that she is undoubtedly one of the most empathetic and fantastic instructors I have had the opportunity to learn from in my time at Harvard. The thoughtfulness, care, and structure she brought to the class were excellent, as was her selection of students, which made me look forward to coming to class each week so much. Our readings were engaging and very accessible and I come away from this semester having learnt so much and genuinely grown so so much as both a reader and writer. Can't recommend this class enough to anyone considering!

This semester was taught by Maggie, not Darcy, so I'm not sure how that will factor into the Q Guide (?) but Maggie was a wonderful instructor—always super kind, welcoming, and enthusiastic. I will say that this semester at least was very focused on personal essays as opposed to reporting or criticism when it came to the readings, so if that's your thing, definitely consider taking this course!
worse_comment: I think what was hard about the class this year is that it was Darcy's syllabus but Maggie was teaching. By no fault of her own, this meant the course was a little wonky.

best_comment: This is one of my favorite classes I've taken. Paul is leaving Harvard, but I'm sure the class is (almost) just as good with other professors! I am a biology major who had never taken anything remotely creative at Harvard, so I was nervous going in, but SO glad I took this class. A great low–stakes way to get back into creative writing and get some awesome feedback. The class community was great

TAKE THIS COURSE. It is truly such a gift to hear Leilani talk about craft, and I felt like I learned so much through just reading short stories with her guidance and notes. Not the most feedback–oriented creative writing workshop (I'd say it was more focused on craft and generating a good number of stories than really polishing a couple), however, this was not necessarily a bad thing. If you'd like to come out of a workshop with three to four first drafts, then this is the workshop for you — most other fiction workshops will probably be better if you're aiming for one to two polished stories, though.

A writing workshop is such a valuable experience, and I feel incredibly grateful that Harvard offers them. This course was well–structured with a mix of craft lectures and workshops of classmates’ writing from the very beginning. If you’re at all interested in creative writing, I’d encourage you—like I’ve been telling everyone who asks about my classes—to apply to writing workshops!!

This was a great class! I loved the readings, and Maggie was a thoughtful, kind, and such an amazing teacher. I learned so much about the magazine world in this class, and the discussions she facilitated were so interested and fruitful. I also gained so much confidence in myself as a writer, editor, and reader. Definitely recommend!

Obviously if you concentrate in English, you have to take this course. But regardless, it is SO. MUCH. FUN. You do a lot of work with genre, and I absolutely loved every second of it. Professor Whittington is a great teacher, and she takes the time to get to know each member of the class. Section is the best section I have ever had in a course at Harvard. The reading is entirely manageable, and the assignments are well–paced and never too onerous. The readings are also just... fun? Like things you would read for fun anyway.
worse_comment: Whether ye be an English concentrator or one who has never even SEEN a book, please take this class! Professor Whittington will enrich and enliven not only your appreciation of English and American literature, but your appreciation of LIFE!

course_title: The Art of Minor Feelings: Asian American Emotional Lives in Contemporary Literature 001
best_comment: Best class I've ever taken. Sophia is such a thoughtful and engaging person who truly made this class the highlight of my week, every week. Our readings were so fun and our discussions were even more fun. There are four journal entries and a final reflection paper. The midterm is a 15–minute check–in. We were constantly encouraged to take time for rest and take a break from the Harvard grind lifestyle. I can't recommend this course enough.

Take this class! I had no poetry experience but the environment of the class was so calm and it was great to slow down and engage deeply with the material. Prof. Ravinthiran is so kind and balances teaching with facilitating discussions really nicely.

TAKE THIS COURSE. As a very very heavy stem person i was worried i wouldn't fit in in this course, but it truly is made for everyone and all experience levels. I felt a lot of freedom to explore theater and drama, and felt it was a really safe place to try new things! I'm very personally glad I took this course, and really grateful to David and Elinor for putting on this course!

This class is a gem. 12/10 would recommend. The course is so easy, you just do a weekly discussion post. The plays are great, (maybe Love's Labour's Lost is the one meh one) but it's so fun to act out scenes with no stakes. It's super engaging to watch your classmates enact the death of Richard II, or to goof around as the comedic clown characters, but all in all this is my favorite course at Harvard. Professor Teskey is a gem of a human being and not only is he super knowledgeable and insightful about Shakespeare/plays, he is super open to hearing your ideas. I'm a bio concentrator and took this course for fun and lowkey makes me want to be an English major now.

TAKE IT! I'm so serious, you won't find a better teacher at Harvard. Prof. Miller really reads your discussion posts and actually replies to them, sometimes with thoughtful refutes. He finds ways to work what you wrote in your posts into discussion and credits your ideas. He conducts seminar with meaningful discussions using the readings. All his course material is carefully selected to contribute to your positive learning experience. He has so many different types of assignments to choose from, which encourages students to try new writing skills. He's available to answer questions. He truly cares about your education. You will be so lucky to take any course he teaches.

One of my favorite seminars taken within the English department. Professor Scarry is so welcoming, engaging, and attentive to her students, and the overall class engagement felt very genuine and exciting. It is, of course, on the heavier side with reading — but it's run almost as a book club, in the sense that it encourages you to read genuinely interesting literature every week, and sets a great motive for reading consistently throughout the semester.  The professor leaves detailed feedback on all of the reading responses, and encourages you to follow your own niche areas of interest; it's overall a very encouraging class, could not recommend enough.

The syllabus for this course was fantastic and Prof. Menand is really excellent at facilitating discussion in seminar (probably the best instructor I've had for this). Menand is a great writer and provides super helpful feedback on written work. The main problem with this class was that group presentations occupied about half of seminar time every week and were not very helpful except for the people doing them in a particular class.
worse_comment: The class is lowkey hard, during the semester its presentations which feel fine but theres SO much content and Menand is not super helpful about going over everything. The final was hard. But he tries to give everyone a good grade.

best_comment: This is a wonderful class. It is heavily focused on discussion, which I liked, and Professor Miller is really kind, knows a lot, and is happy to talk about whatever we are interested in talking about. There is lots of theory, which I found fascinating and the assignments are all good.
worse_comment: Unfortunately, this course was not one I enjoyed taking. The seminars were unproductive at best, boring at worst. The bent of the course seems to be quasi–anti–intellectual: the more general and imprecise your statements, the better. Discussions in class were sub–spark–notes–level. One only remembers that one is at Harvard upon leaving the room.

best_comment: I'm someone who likes analyzing texts a lot more than I like theory, so I didn't think I would really like this class, or that it would necessarily be a good use of my time. In the end, I felt it was worthwhile. Even though sometimes the theory felt theoretical to the point of being slightly ridiculous, this course gave me a really good overview of the types of topics that are being studied in English today and made me much more confident in reading scholarly articles. I gained a much better understanding of literary scholarship, and feel well equipped to continue my English studies. This course introduced me to some really influential thinkers and their basic ideas, like Foucault, and to some really interesting areas and modes of literary study that I hadn't known about before, like archives. We also got introduced to fields of theory that are relevant not only in English but in all of the humanities (for instance, feminist theory, queer theory, postcolonial theory) so if you would like to gain  a better understanding of what those phrases actually mean this class will help with that. We also got to go see old rare books from the Houghton, which was cool. While I don't think that I would take another class with so much theory, I think that being forced to take this one class on it was good for me after all.

worse_comment: Start your final paper early (which, I know, everyone says)!!!! But seriously, it will save you so much last–minute stress and torment.

best_comment: It will be rewarding if you invest into it!

I definitely recommend this course. Professor Wilson is great and super understanding. The grading in this course seemed a little harsh at first, but overall it was not too bad. Lectures were mostly interesting, and there was a nice balance between group discussions, Professor Wilson's Speaking, and time for individual comments. Sofia was an amazing TF and super helpful during the SSGK portion of the course. I will say that you definitely get out what you put in; the course is not unreasonably demanding, but you cannot do absolutely nothing and still pass.

I loved this course! Would definitely recommend. Professor Teskey is a preeminent scholar of Milton and his expertise on and love for Paradise Lost is clear. This is a text that begins popping up everywhere you reading has commenced and you begin to see how foundational the story of Adam and Eve, especially as recounted in Paradise Lost, is to western society.  A very worthwhile class!

Such a good course!! Professor Lynch is such a great teacher with super engaging lectures. You can tell she really cares about what she teaches and has so many insights to share. She is also super friendly and loves when people stop by her office hours, so please do if you can. Harry was also an amazing TF – very willing to provide feedback and create fun activities for section discussions. The reading list for this class is also really great. As someone who hadn't had much exposure to early novels like Jane Asuten prior to this class, I really enjoyed the novels we read that were really interesting and conducive to strong classroom discussions.
if you are an undergraduate, go to section its super helpful and you learn so much and you really get the chance to speak your mind and explore why you think the way that you do
if you are an undergraduate, go to section its super helpful and you learn so much and you really get the chance to speak your mind and explore why you think the way that you do

I've never taken an English class before, and I've never engaged with Asian American literature before, so this was actually such an eye–opening class, especially for me as an Asian American myself. Readings are all so well–chosen and felt like I was just reading a book I myself picked out and simply wanted to read at leisure – didn't feel like assignment at all! The class itself was also so calming; Sophia is an incredibly empathetic and understanding prof, and whenever she spoke in class, I just immediately felt calm and at peace. I think this class certainly changed my perspective of Asian American lives and backgrounds; for someone who's only experienced and really witnessed one narrative her whole life, this expanded my viewpoint so much and also served as a very healing experience. Assignments were minimal, and Sophia was super understanding and sympathetic about mental health so I never felt like this class was a burden. Would highly recommend to all!!!

Take this course! You will not regret it. Not only will you get to read a deeply interesting set of novels –– and watch a deeply interesting set of films –– but you will also get to know Professor McCarthy, who is a fantastic lecturer and is highly accessible to his students. Speaking as a graduating senior who had never taken a course in the English department, I highly recommend this course to anyone who wants to "dip their toes" in the world of the novel (and learn some literary theory!).  As are his materials, Professor McCarthy's lectures are consistently engaging; I left every lecture feeling like I had learned something that would stick with me. Plus, Professor McCarthy infuses his syllabi and lectures with pop culture, which makes every class session even more interesting.

PLEASE TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Even if you're not an English major!!! I had a BLAST. Professor Wood is so funny and British and all things good. He spends a great deal of time carefully curating the reading list for this class, which is FANTASTIC. I am an Econ + Social Studies major that dabbled in writing in high school and this class taught me so much about personal writing style and has inspired me to write more, even casually/in my free time. I am such a big fan of this class. Yoojung was a great section leader and they all seem very supportive and kind. The essays are not difficult to write, especially if you have any experience with critical/creative writing, and if you don't, the TFs are accessible in office hours to help you figure it out. A great way to fulfill the div distribution requirement, and a great course overall!
best_gem_comment: Take this class!!! As a STEM concentrator who hasn't taken an English class since high school (excluding freshman expos), the essay is approachable and well–suited for my shortening attention span. Prof. Wood is AMAZING, and the way he is able to deconstruct an essay in terms of both content and form is extraordinary to witness. This was a wonderful gem to take senior spring – highly highly recommend!

best_comment: Definitely take! Anna is a fantastic teacher and the class is a great exposure to fun and generative texts

course_title: The Representation of Labor in the 19th-Century Novel: Seminar 001
best_comment: Definitely take this class if you're at all interested in the topic, or adjacent topics! Professor Scarry is amazingly well–read, intelligent, and gives helpful and kind feedback. A true pleasure—but be prepared for long, long readings.

Take this class if you want to get to grips with major texts in the African American literary tradition, if you're fascinated by how people write under oppression, if you want to parse the literary techniques black voices have used over time to write themselves into being.

This is a fantastic seminar that introduces you to a wide range of South Asian poetry from the 1950s, covering poets writing in South Asia and South Asian American poets as well. You will learn to love reading and discussing poems!
worse_comment: Those without much background in poetry, South Asian history, and/or postcolonial literary theory may find themselves very, very lost when the specialist students make their contributions. But don't let this intimidate you, as everything you really need is going to be in the text itself.

best_comment: This class is incredible. The professors are so wonderful and smart, hearing them speak is probably the best part of it. They really foster an open and safe environment where people can feel comfortable speaking on difficult topics. The class was very warm and felt almost like a family. It’s a great class.

This class is incredible. The professors are so wonderful and smart, hearing them speak is probably the best part of it. They really foster an open and safe environment where people can feel comfortable speaking on difficult topics. The class was very warm and felt almost like a family. It’s a great class.

Be prepared to do the work, if you stay on top of it, you will cruise. I wasn’t a fan of the in class format personally but I could see how it works well for some. Eli is a fantastic lecturer, very entertaining and open minded. I would recommend this course for anyone interested in climate change and the math behind the science.
worse_comment: As someone who came into Harvard as a pretty committed climate activist with the intention of pursuing a full–time career in the environmental sciences, I’ll admit that I never thought it was possible to overstate the dangers of climate change. But this course challenged me to reconsider that assumption. I came to understand that there are real weaknesses and risks on both ends of the climate activism spectrum, whether through alarmism or denial. At the same time, the course helped me engage more deeply with the data itself, and I learned that while the evidence clearly supports the reality and urgency of climate change, it does not necessarily point to an immediate, apocalyptic collapse. That nuance was crucial.

best_comment: This class was definitely an experience. This class is a decent bit of work: I found the labs to be kind of confusing, and the exams were definitely harder than expected. BUT the benefits of the class ARE SO WORTH IT.  I switched to Pass/Fail after getting the lowest grade in the class on the midterm, but I would still strongly recommend this class. The content is SUPER INTERESTING, the professor is SO GOOD, and the TFs are THE BEST (I had Kristen and I can't recommend her enough!!!). I am a CS concentrator and I only took EPS 10 as preparation which definitely wasn't enough – I was hella out my comfort zone lol . Kristen was so helpful and literally guided me through the labs, which were quite fun once you got the hang of them. The labs were super interesting and useful, I definitely needed more help than a lot of my peers.This class was definitely one of my most memorable classes: the field trip to Pennsylvania was FIRE. We went to an oil rig, a coal mine, a wind farm, and a hydroelectric power station. I recommend this class SO SO MUCH: it's definitely hard, but it isn't too much work, and the teaching staff and field trip make it so worth it!!!!
worse_comment: Take this course!! Professor Shaw is an incredible lecturer and you learn a lot! The only draw back is that the labs use some software that can be a bit tough to work with at times.

course_title: Ecosystem Patterns and Processes: Parallels in Natural and Built Environments 001
best_comment: I would 100% recommend this course with enthusiasm. I loved my experience in it, it was one of my favorite classes I've taken due to the small size making it easier to learn and the professor's ability to teach to all of us on a more individual level. The labs were also fun and I learned a lot of new skills. This class gives you great perspective of the complexity of nature and why it is challenging to come up with good solutions and the thought that needs to go into it. It was also a great review of topics I had learned earlier in my time at Harvard!

This is an extremely enjoyable and worthwhile class.  Professor Jacob is thoughtful, engaging, and very knowledgable; he clearly cares deeply about the course material and wants to make sure that his students not only understand but also care.  Problem sets are useful and manageable; the final presentations are a low–stakes opportunity to dive more deeply into a topic of personal interest. I took this class as my last engineering elective and am very glad I did.
best_gem_comment: A gem of an EPS class! Really interesting and engaging and relevant to a variety of environmental and chemistry topics. Daniel is a wonderful lecturer and the structure of the class is really great! More about how much you learn than about how much you can memorize.

best_comment: Take this class to understand how pollution issues manifest in our society! The class definitely leans more heavily towards being an EPS/ESPP class than an ESE one but there are still some strong foundations in math and environmental science (understanding differential equations, chemistry, fluid transport will help a lot). Elsie is an awesome instructor and expert in the field and is super approachable and willing to engage/empower students.  The course covers a lot of very important topics in the field of environmental toxicology/ pollution and I consider it an essential to anyone interested in the field of environmental protection!

course_title: State-of-the-Art Harvard Climate Observatory and Associated Instrumentation 001
best_comment: Professor Jim is amazing, truly one of a kind. He creates a supportive and encouraging classroom environment and always provides thoughtful, constructive feedback. He genuinely cares about his students’ growth and makes sure you understand how to improve. His teaching goes beyond the material, he helps you become a better thinker and learner.

course_title: The EV Revolution: Outlook, Environmental Impact, Policy, and Challenges 001
best_comment: It is an interesting course and I enjoyed learning about it, but it does require you to be prepared before class. You have to do the readings since it is a seminar with a more intimate setting. Be ready to get cold called every now and then, and make sure to participate a lot to get what you want out of the course.
worse_comment: Elaine is very intense. You learn a lot about how to work with a boss who you might not agree with or work well with, which is a useful skill for going into industry. She provides a lot of feedback which is a great opportunity to become a better writer and researcher, but I felt that she also made some comments that were unprofessional, e.g. criticizing students' clothing, commenting on their appearance/weight. The TF, Taha, seemed to put very little effort into this class – lecture slides were not posted on time and he repeatedly showed up late or missed scheduled meetings with students.

course_title: The Technology, Economics, and Public Policy of Renewable Energy SEM
best_comment: This class is seriously awesome — you learn so much about renewable energy and the related ideas (ex: electricity markets, grid, EVs, storage, etc.) that you can come out with a solid understanding of each of the major types of renewable energy and their PROs/CONs. Definitely not a class for "general interest" but if you have any background energy, sustainability, etc. this is a fantastic class. Prof. Baker is such a gem — incredibly bright, full of great stories, and a great gusto in teaching. The course assignments (weekly discussion papers, participation, and a final project) are extremely manageable and despite it not being a very course–work heavy course, you honestly learn more from it than most courses at Harvard. Come to class prepared to learn (and with coffee since the 3 hour sessions can get a little tough at the end). Grading wise, it's a bit unclear how the course is graded — but I think Prof. Baker doesn't want us to worry about grades and rather about learning and being active participants. TLDR; if you have any interest in energy, this class is for you!
worse_comment: Prof. Baker is cool and it's a great survey on renewable technologies / related economic, environmental, political conversations, but the course is terribly organized. For context: none of us ever got feedback, and we only got our first grade of any kind after 9 weeks, so I have no idea how I did in this course besides intuition.
best_gem_comment: This class is seriously awesome — you learn so much about renewable energy and the related ideas (ex: electricity markets, grid, EVs, storage, etc.) that you can come out with a solid understanding of each of the major types of renewable energy and their PROs/CONs. Definitely not a class for "general interest" but if you have any background energy, sustainability, etc. this is a fantastic class. Prof. Baker is such a gem — incredibly bright, full of great stories, and a great gusto in teaching. The course assignments (weekly discussion papers, participation, and a final project) are extremely manageable and despite it not being a very course–work heavy course, you honestly learn more from it than most courses at Harvard. Come to class prepared to learn (and with coffee since the 3 hour sessions can get a little tough at the end). Grading wise, it's a bit unclear how the course is graded — but I think Prof. Baker doesn't want us to worry about grades and rather about learning and being active participants. TLDR; if you have any interest in energy, this class is for you!

course_title: US Environmental Policy and Policymaking: The Role of Congress, EPA, Stakeholders, and Courts 001
best_comment: I HIGHLY recommend this course to anyone who has any interest in government structures, climate mitigation/adaptation,  and the environment. Professor Jenks, though very thorough in communicating the various obstacles and challenges of environmental + public health protection, maintains an optimistic, forward–thinking outlook that's incredibly refreshing compared to the doom and gloom that sometimes pervades environmental science courses.  The once–a–week section allows you to engage deeply with the material and spend more time thinking about issues and solutions rather than completing assignments as a means to an end.  Additionally, the different perspectives of weekly guest speakers offer a view into the practical applications of everything you learn about. The assignments are challenging, but feedback is very helpful and grading is fair. I walk away from this course not only feeling more confident about my ability to engage with big questions and complex solutions but also more prepared to engage with challenging source materials and write policy memorandums. Take this course if you want to grow in your understanding, to grow as a writer, and to grow as an aspiring agent of change!
worse_comment: Take this course! If you are interested at all in how law and regulation works at the federal level in all branches of government then this course is for you. It can get a little confusing and complex, but Professor Jenks does an incredible job at clarifying any confusing topics.

course_title: Global Rebellion: Race, Solidarity, and Decolonization 01
best_comment: I loved this class. I loved my classmates, I loved Soham as a professor, I loved the EMR department. This course is a great space for leftist conversation on campus, especially as someone who has struggled to find those spaces.

course_title: Critical Afro-LatinX Studies in the United States 01
best_comment: Take this course! I cannot recommend it enough. Professor Bouso–Gavin is a wonderful instructor and takes the time to get to know you so that you can best succeed in the course. Given the small class size Professor Bouso–Gavin does a good job of cultivating a community within the course. I made so many new friends taking this class. The course content and discussions are enriching and help you get a grasp of both foundational texts in this underdeveloped field of study as well as new scholarship, visual arts, and literature that all work to give you a good understanding of Afro–Latinx studies past, present, and possible futures.

course_title: Narrating the Border: Migration and Media 01
best_comment: My favorite class I have ever taken at Harvard. The professors care so much about the course, the topics it covers, and their students. The class is so interesting, and the assignments are so fun to do. The conversations we have are so important, and you learn so much. I loved it and would take it a million times again.
worse_comment: I didn't like the class. The professors were unorganized, and grading was weird as they arent available on canvas

course_title: Narrating the Border: Migration and Media 01
best_comment: My favorite class I have ever taken at Harvard. The professors care so much about the course, the topics it covers, and their students. The class is so interesting, and the assignments are so fun to do. The conversations we have are so important, and you learn so much. I loved it and would take it a million times again.
worse_comment: I didn't like the class. The professors were unorganized, and grading was weird as they arent available on canvas

best_comment: Great class with interesting readings. Jacinda is an amazing professor with lots of knowledge about and passion for the topic. Not too much work weekly.

course_title: Decolonial Healing in LatinX Literature and Visual Arts 01
best_comment: PLEASE TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Aitor is such an amazing teacher and person who not only cares about you as a student, but as a human being!! He is genuinely concerned with your wellness and your ability to engage with the course materials. This course was genuinely so fun and I learned more than I have in many courses here. Even if you have no background in Latinx studies, he does a great job introducing you to core concepts and making sure you are able to participate.  The best part of this class is that it can also be used in your personal life –– showing you different ways to engage with art for the purposes of healing, both yourself and your community.

course_title: Korean and Korean American Literature, Media, and Culture 01
best_comment: 10/10 MUST TAKE COURSE!!! As someone who came into the course with very little knowledge of Korean history and film, this course was truly transformative in allowing me to gain so much perspective and understanding. It has been a great privilege to have Professor Choi as an instructor as she appreciates all of her students and always makes the classroom setting so welcoming. All of the works included in this class is the perfect mix between reading and film and no matter what, you will always end up liking the materials. Truly, you can tell how much thought professor Choi has put into handpicking all of the course material. Being a part of this course has been a highlight of my year and I can confidently say, one of my favorite classes within the EMR Department. Definitely a fantastic experience that everyone should have!!! RECOMMEND RECOMMEND RECOMMEND!!!!!!!!
worse_comment: If you don't enroll in this course, you will regret it!
best_gem_comment: This is a true gem. Professor Choi is a little strict in terms of technology use and deadlines, but she is very very kind and understanding. You become a family with the class.

course_title: Space, Place, Belonging: (Re)Locating the Asian/American Experience 01
best_comment: One of the coolest classes I've taken at Harvard. It's a pretty demanding course because the readings/films are super interesting, but can be pretty dense and time–intensive. The grading is also pretty conservative and can lean on the harder side. However, if you're passionate about Asian American studies, this is the best class you could take. I couldn't recommend this enough. Prof Remoquillo is absolutely incredible–––very engaging and helpful professor. She is so passionate about the topic and super dedicated to all of her students.

I would highly recommend this course, especially to anyone hoping to get more exposure to global perspectives on indigeneity and settler colonialism. The readings are all incredibly interesting, and we got to explore a wide variety of topics and contexts (US, Australia, etc). Lewis is incredibly passionate and knowledgeable about the subject which made our discussions very rich and generative.

TAKE THIS COURSE. Dr. B is UNDOUBTEDLY the BEST Expos professor you can have!! Okay I may be a little biased, but she is so so funny, open to new ideas, kind, and just overall a great professor. Her writing feedback is incredible and I genuinely don't regret taking Expos with Dr. B for a SECOND. Now, aside from the Dr. B glazing, one thing you should know about Expos is that you should try to start the assignments EARLY. This class would keep me up until 2–4am (or even later) at times because I was a big procrastinator. Don't be like me. Start assignments early. Start your draft essays early. Start revising early. The more time you revise, the better your essays will be. And lastly, enjoy this class and treat Dr. B nicely :)

I loved this section of Expos. I just loved it. Professor is an amazing person who is literally always there for you and is SUPER perceptive, super engaged, and ready to help. Assignment feedback is super helpful and detailed (even with jokes and notes) and if you have any questions you are more than welcomed during office hours. The class starts with a narrow out of pocket question, like "What is Love?" or "What is the next animal that humans should domesticate?" to engage and make sure that everyone is present. The professor is very friendly (honestly, it is a very, very, very good experience) and really wants to make this course as interesting as possible. There are a lot of discussions, very little boring readings, and it just so pleasant to take a part in. Please choose this expos if you can – an amazing experience.

This course is excellent. Mr. Bafford is an amazing preceptor who you will honestly begin to look forward to talking to in class. Make sure to take advantage of his office hours to discuss papers or any other topics from class. He really is a wealth of knowledge and incredibly kind. The only judgement that I will pass on his grading (what everyone seems to care about) is that it is fair. You won't receive a paper back and be confused about why you got the grade you got. You need three things for this class: Don't procrastinate. Engage with Mr. Bafford. And bring the right mindset. Take it and you will have fun.

This is a really good course that will strengthen your ability to write high–quality analytical papers. Selection of texts was a lot of fun, and you have a good deal of agency over what you get to write about. The only thing I would caution about this class specifically is that when writing an essay, make sure your thesis is as good as possible before submitting the first draft, because if it's weak, Professor Brown may not give much feedback on the rest of the essay.
worse_comment: this class is incredibly difficult despite it being expos20. the class is not structured well. there were little to no student–facilitated discussions and it was mostly dr. brown talking while going on tangents. he looks for very specific things in essays, and when you do not provide it, you're kind of cooked. despite that, he is unclear about his expectations and provides very vague comments. if possible, i would suggest taking a different expos course.

best_comment: Yall take this expos fr like I felt like not only the topic of learning is really interesting but I think compared to the traditional expos grading scheme of 25,35, and 45 for the essays its more split here so its not so much high stakes. Also Tad is so chill and I think my fav prof of the semester. However, for the class to be enjoyable please participate so the discussion aint awkward.

NOT A GEM. Someone told me this and I was lied to. We write a close reading essay, a lens essay, and then a research essay. Before most classes, there were either readings or response exercises, often both, and these were often tedious to keep up with. Very standard expos class. Not easy but definitely not one of the hardest ones. Usually very lenient about grading but it is very hard to get an A. If you are thinking of this Expos because conspiracy theories interest you, know that the first one is niche, historic, and gory and the second is niche, irrelevant to the world at large, and literally a Netflix episode (which was fun to watch). You will not be theorizing about JFK or uncovering hidden modern truths unless you choose to do so in the third essay where we had free rein over the topic. Often, feedback was vague and we received very little guidance on the second essay. The Writing Center was a must and I wish I could have gone more often. Garcia is a very nice instructor and usually accessible by email and would often end class 15 minutes early (which was so nice!). TLDR: If you need a light Expos then this is not the one for you but if you just need to get through it and are able to put in the time, you'll be fine.

TAKE THIS EXPOS. Obviously a required class but as someone who scavenged Q Reports for a good one and talked to lots of friends throughout the year, this is definitely the best one. Fair grading and great interesting content and Professor Garcia is amazing.

I would warn that the grading for this class is definitely harsher than other Expos classes; but that being said, if you are truly passionate and interested in the topic, it is very much worth it. It is also a very rewarding experience to take a stringently graded writing class like this.

Honestly, this was my 6th choice Expos—but it ended up being my favorite class of the semester! I gained such an appreciation for different types of literature and general publications as well. This course made me think in a new way about how authors form ideas and reuse content in their own vision. The books we read were especially engaging and my final paper was a lot of fun to write. Professor Gauvreau was incredible and the class had a great time in sections getting to know each other and hang out. Highly recommend!

I TOTALLY recommend and LOVED this course. This class will challenge the way you think about history, ownership, and the stories we choose to preserve. You’ll dive deep into questions that don’t have easy answers—like who has the right to possess cultural objects, and how institutions like museums shape our understanding of identity and memory.What makes this class special is how it blends intense academic writing and concepts with real–world current ethical dilemmas. You won’t just be writing to meet a requirement—you’ll be exploring questions that I believe genuinely matter and can help you intellectually across disciplines. The discussions are engaging, the readings are rich and provocative, and Professor Given creates a space where your voice and perspective are truly valued.Come ready to challenge your assumptions, engage with complex topics, and grow as a thinker and writer. This class stays with you long after it ends!!!

While this is not necessarily an “easy A” course, it is very possible to do well if you are willing to put in the work. My biggest piece of advice is to take your time really reading Greg’s feedback on drafts/assignments and to come to your one–on–ones with him prepared. These one–on–ones are super short, but I was able to clear up a lot in the 10–20 minutes allotted and always came out feeling a lot more clear about the direction of my assignments. Take his feedback into account and don’t be afraid to radically change the direction of your papers between the draft and the final. Do the readings before the class! Not only will this benefit your participation grade, but it will make the class a lot more enjoyable as you will be able to engage with your peers. It will also give you a strong base to work off of when creating your paper, and you will not have to scramble when the time to write arrives.
worse_comment: Just try to get through it’s difficult but it’s required and you only have to take it once.

best_comment: This is an amazing Expos course to take. The readings and films are all very interesting. The feedback Dr. Goldberg provides is incredible. There is so much freedom on what to write about as well, so it is perfect for students who enjoy exploring their interests.

This is probably one of the best Expos classes out there, definitely would recommend doing it! Expos is slightly draining by the fact that it is mandatory, but this class made me enjoy my experience through it a lot. The class gives you a lot of freedom when deciding what to write about, and Dr. Goldberg is super chill and helpful. You can tell he puts effort into his Expos, and it pays off a lot. The section is lots of fun and if, like me, English is not your first language, provides lots of information on how essays are structured. You're never pushed to conform to a universal style, everything is more of a suggestion of what works best, but Dr. Goldberg always makes sure to include exceptions that work in order to show how anything can be effective if you know how to write it. We were given lots of resources, and the literary sources we analyzed and talked about were not only cool but also were brimming with possible discussions that could lead to different theses, so they were good places to practice your writing on. I don't know if any of that makes any sense (I am very burnt out at the moment), but the class does a wonderful job at what it's supposed to do and is also super pleasant and enjoyable. Definitely rank it high when you sign up to the lottery!!

TAKE THIS CLASS! If you are at all interested in wealth inequality, the ruling class, the education system, robber barons, elites, etc., you will love it. Dr. Herron is a fantastic professor and the discussions are really interesting.  It is worth it to invest/annotate the reading so you can fully participate in discussions, but annotations are not a required assignment. The essay drafts are a great way to have an environment of less pressure since they are ungraded. Also the conferences with Dr. Herron are very helpful. I highly highly recommend.

This was my FAVORITE class I have taken at Harvard so far (other than Gov 1290)! Professor Kennedy is truly amazing. I have learned so much from her, and I hope to stay in contact with her in the future. The class subject was super interesting–negotiation and the art of negotiation is something I didn't know I would want to learn about, but I am walking away from this class having learned a lot. There isn't a lot of work overall, but I would say when she does assign a case to read, you should read it because it makes class much more engaging. Also, the readings are pretty short and like once every other week, so there is literally no reason not to do them. The papers are not bad either because her feedback is extremely specific and helpful on drafts, so unless you don't take her feedback, it is pretty hard not to do well. Overall, I learned a lot because I loved the course material, but she is also the sweetest woman, and she helped my writing so much. TAKE HER CLASS! Not because it's easy, but because she is the GOAT and I learned a remarkable amount about negotiations worlwide.

I really enjoyed my experience in this course– I particularly loved getting the chance to think deeply and critically about various cases we studied including the Northern Ireland Troubles case and the Santa Clara Pueblo people land case. This was a great course for allowing you to consider multiple perspectives on an issue, and consider external factors that may impact the success of a negotiation or the goals of different groups. This course changed the way in which I view negotiations in multiple contexts, and has taught me the importance and value in "moving North–East" to reach an agreement that can benefit both groups. I would say that it is important that you make a schedule for yourself, and start your essays far in advance to ensure you can put together strong drafts. It is also really useful to book appointments with the Writing Center as they can go through your essay with you and give you specific advice.
worse_comment: Instructor did not seem welcoming of extenuating circumstances such as illness or religious observances. The course also included a lot of reading and was quite a harsh class when it came to grading. Do not take this course unless you are already a very skilled writer.

best_comment: This is definitely one of the better Expos's in term of courseload and content. If you like environmental studies or advocacy, then this is DEFINITELY the expos for you! Dr. Lane is so down to earth and approachable, and is just generally the best! Ask her about her work with the course material–– it's pretty interesting.

This is easily the best Expos class. You have two papers and one capstone project (which is making a zine). Readings are super interesting, and class discussion is so easy and inviting. Instead of response papers, you have a field journal, which is so fun to write in (you can make collages, drawings, etc.), and they help you think about your writing and the course materials. Dr.Lane provides really great feedback and is so educated in the topics we discussed. You also get to watch The Hunger Games, and some classes will have snacks! Overall, this expos class was not super stressful, and I feel like I really improved my writing.
worse_comment: Take only if you really like environmental science otherwise you will be bored and have a bad time. It definitely is easier than some other expos however this was probably my least favorite class of the entire year and I took some other pretty brutal classes. Found the work painful, and unclear. Again not as bad as some other expos you will get graded fairly and at the end of the day the teacher is nice and wants to help you. Just think this class could have been more informative, and better structured.

best_comment: Taleen is actually SO GOATED. Like genuinely. The readings yes are a little confusing from the start, but the fact that those are the hardest readings out of the entire semester is actually so nice. The comments that Taleen will leave on your paper is exactly what she expects you to fix, so as logn as you conference with her and elaborate on your ideas, she will provide an amazing grade on your paper. I think the main thing is that you can’t expect an A on your paper without constant feedback. Continuously expressing your concerns in the class and underestanding what your weaknesses are will show Taleen a greater effort when you finally submit that essay. TALEEN IS SOOO GOOD 10/10 RECOMMEND and shes so funny and caring and nice!!! Be respectful of coutse, but have fun and she will show a lot of her great personality!

If you think you might be interested in the topic, it's worth considering this course — because Expos is a class you have to take, it's worth looking for one that you feel like you would enjoy. Taleen is an excellent preceptor, offering thorough feedback in conferences. However, something I did not really consider when ranking my Expos choices that I think makes much more of an impact on your experience than the topic is the type of essays you will be asked to write. If you really want to write an op ed, for example, or like the idea of getting to do a research paper on a topic you chose, Tongue Tied is a great choice. However, for me personally, I wish I'd gotten the opportunity to explore different kinds of essays that I know were covered in other Expos courses. Because the course really is more about the writing than the topic, I think that focusing on what kinds of writing you will be asked to do is more important at the end of the day.
worse_comment: Take this course! Taleen is such a sweet and helpful preceptor who provides plenty of feedback on the essays. You might not receive an A in the class, but the criticism is mostly reasonable. There are weekly readings and two main essays plus a capstone project.

best_comment: BEST!!! EXPOS!!! EASILY!!! rare combo where you get to both learn about writing and a fascinating topic at the same time ––– a) dr. ross gives the best, most in–depth feedback on your writing assignments. he pushes you to construct more complicated, sophisticated arguments, to write more concisely, to dive deep into close analysis (with the level of detail he was expecting, we were basically writing literary criticisms of supreme court decisions and it was awesome). be warned that he does take pride in this being considered the most difficult expos ––– and i think he probably also takes pride in grading rigorously ––– but he also provides so much feedback. he is so willing to answer all of your questions via email or after class, he is always flexible about due dates / is always pushing back deadlines, and he very obviously cares about us as individuals beyond the classroom. b) you will get to learn so so much about not only supreme court decisions but also supreme court history. dr. ross's approach to the course is to question mainstream assumptions about every case and dive deep into their language in order to reveal their complexity. tbh his interpretations + historical knowledge were always so smart + fascinating that sometimes i would rather listen to him than participate myself, but he also really valued student input + was good at facilitating discussions/classroom camaraderie, so our class always had fun vibes even as we ended up probing a variety of philosophical questions about abortion, meritocracy, and more.take the course. it is so worth it. one of the highlights of my freshman year, for sure.

TAKE THIS CLASS if you have even the slightest interest in the law and want an expos experience with the kindest, most knowledgeable professor! Even if you're not prelaw, Prof. Martin makes the content relevant and accessible to students of all backgrounds and interests. Although the readings of actual Supreme Court decisions may seem daunting at first, by the end of the semester, you will be extremely confident and proficient in reading and writing about legal documents. In–class discussions are also lively and enjoyable, largely thanks to the "name game" at the start of each class which fostered an excellent class community. I truly looked forward to attending this course each week. Professor Martin truly revolutionized my writing skills for the better,  particularly when it comes to "close reading analysis" and essay structure/organization. His feedback, written in the most incredible handwriting I have ever seen, is extremely detailed and productive. And by far the best part of this course is Professor Martin himself, who is the most considerate, thoughtful instructor I have had at Harvard. He is the rare professor who truly cares for his students as he would his own children –– he understands our schedules, workloads, and stressors and is incredibly accommodating and willing to adjust schedules, content, and deadlines to allow for an enjoyable and educational experience for all. Ultimately, do not pass up the chance to take this wonderful and fascinating course with one of the best professors at Harvard. Is it hard at times? Yes. But you have so much support throughout it and will inevitably emerge with not just a much stronger set of writing skills, but also some wonderful friends.
worse_comment: This course will be very rewarding, but you will be challenged and pushed. To get the most out of the course, you need to put in the work. Otherwise, it won't be great and your grade also may now be great. However, Dr. Martin does a terrific job  in facilitating open class discussion. There are no mini writing assignments, so if that is your cup of tea this is not the Expos for you. Your writing will improve a lot and you will have a great time!

best_comment: Keating's Expos has to be one of the most chill Expos available. His feedback and class structure makes it really interactive and lets students feel that they can really say anything in the class and have it considered by Keating with an open mind. Workload is steady – sometimes it does feel like a bore and busy work to do the readings, but I will say that the final essay was a deeply fulfilling project for me, and Keating's help with resources was much appreciated. I got to dive into a really random topic loosely related to activism, and Keating welcomed my ideas very vividly. Expos is always a bore for most students, but I am very happy that I was placed into this particular section. Yes, I did feel like a confident writer before I came to Harvard, but this course really prepared me for writing at this institution. As long as you do the work, you'll get through Expos!To cap off, I really enjoyed being in a classroom with Keating this semester. He definitely made what would've been a deeply boring class into at least something I was excited for each week.

I came into this class expecting it to be a dumbed down Expos option, recommended by teammates as light on work. But it turned out to be the best class I could have taken, especially as an athlete passionate about sports. Dr. McKeon is truly one of the orators of our time. He is the most articulate and thoughtful instructor I’ve met of his age and has a PhD in classics and philology and a bachelors degree from Columbia: could be considered overqualified to some. McKeon brings a depth of knowledge that makes every class intellectually rich as he often ties our discussions back to that of the ancient Greeks. He’s also one of the kindest and most reasonable professors I’ve encountered—fair with deadlines, generous and thoughtful with feedback, and deeply committed to helping students grow as writers to benefit them after they leave the walls of Sever. The discussions are lively and welcoming, and he makes it easy to participate through open–ended questions and genuine enthusiasm. While the class, like many at Harvard, leans progressive, it remains a space where respectful debate and personal voice are encouraged. I will miss this class greatly and cannot recommend this section more if you have any interest in sports and their ties to the real–world.

I loved this class! Readings were super cool – we read about everything from cyber warfare to Orwell getting shot to Marguerite Duras tricking a member of the Nazi secret police. We also got to go to the Harvard Art Museum to look at German prints from WWI. The final project also introduced me to Hollis and I went into the stacks for the first time, which was super fun. Dr. Monaghan has an amazing amount of knowledge about pretty much every war that has ever happened.Definitely make sure you meet with her for conferences and office hours in order to succeed on essays. Try to get started on essays early – the deadlines come really quickly. Though I've heard this is one of the harder Expos offerings, it was very worth it for me and I highly recommend it!

This course is, accurately by reputation, challenging. But it's worth taking because it has a lot of depth, covers really fascinating material, and Dr. Monaghan is a terrific instructor.  I felt like I improved a lot as a writer and enjoyed the fact that I was doing something intellectually stimulating with my time in Expos. If that sounds like something you want from your first–year experience, you should take this class.
worse_comment: Do not take this class except if you are an experienced writer who could have taken Hum 10 but couldn't fit it into their schedule. Although interesting material, it is a heavy dedication course with harsh grading. This is not an easy class and it expects a lot out of you. Feedback is not this course's strong suit, with the professor having very strict rules about what she will or will not review or help you with. This is not an easy A course, but you will DEFINITELY become a better writer. I felt thrown into the fire with the class, but look back I am happy that I took it because it will serve me well in future courses. The professor is very qualified!

best_comment: Dr. Pietras is a great professor with deep interests in queer studies (sounds quite generic but what I mean is he has great expertise and insights in this topic and can be helpful if you have the same interests). I would not say this is a gem, as I gradually got brought into genuine interests as this class proceeds, so I feel passionate about doing my work (hence, easier for me). However, even if you do not care about the topic, Dr. Pietras still gives out very very generous grades and provides REALLY great feedback. All I want to say that I literally love this class so much and you can also meet the queer fellows of your life. (TAKE IT)

I put this class as my first choice and do not regret it at all. Dr. Quigley is an amazing instructor,  sections are always interesting, and everyone in the class was super nice. I really appreciate that Dr. Quigley takes a more STEM–like approach to writing, which made the writing process way more enjoyable as a STEM concentrator. I feel that my writing has definitely improved since the beginning of the semester. She's also such a great person and super transparent and funny. Would definitely recommend this Expos section.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! This is one of the best classes to discuss core theories as they apply to contemporary debates on gender and mental health and personal stories. You will learn to question what it means to be sick, what it means to receive a diagnosis,  and what it means to develop a disorder.

best_comment: I LOVE THIS CLASS SO MUCH!!! Dr. Quigley is one of the best writing teachers I've ever had, she's super understanding, knowledgeable, and kind. Not only is she a great teacher, she's also a wonderful person. I learned so much in this class as someone who is a STEM concentrator with no background in psychology. Every topic that gets covered is very interesting and relevant, and Dr. Quigley creates such a great, safe environment for discussions to occur, even ones about heavier topics like trauma. I had a really fun time with each essay. Dr. Quigley gives us a lot of freedom to explore what we find interesting and she's SUPER reasonable with deadlines and assignment flexibility + gives amazing, detailed feedback. As a queer kid, this was such a fantastic, safe space for me to improve my writing, learn about how psychology intersects with my identity, and interact with a really welcoming and insightful writing community. Highly, HIGHLY recommend!

Highly Recommend! I've heard horror stories from other expos classes, but Dark Matter, Gray Matter with Emilie is chill, interesting, and fun. I did wish for a little more specific feedback on my essays, but otherwise, Emilie is an amazing preceptor, my classmates created the best atmosphere, and the questions/content was fairly interesting.

This is one of the best expos sections in my opinion. The topic is super interesting and the readings are not dense or lengthy. The professor is so supportive and genuinely cares about all of her students. After hearing many expos horror stories from friends in other sections, I am so glad that I had such a great experience in this expos.
