You will learn and grow a lot, and the course challenges you to improve your abilities as a thinker and communicator.

This class is indeed difficult. Ian can be a tough, but fair grader. However, he is not looking to fail students rather teach and improve their writing. He fosters a welcoming culture where students feel comfortable sharing their points, opinions, critiques, and questions. Thus, while students have two free absences, it is rare for anyone to utilize that grace. Moreover, the topics themselves are interesting. Covering real and fictional con artists, the course prompts students to analyze the base characteristics of society and people that allow for the prevalence of scams. All of this occurs while truly growing as writers. That being said, time is necessary for papers. Regardless of the skill of the writer, multiple drafts are necessary to have a good final product.

This course does earn it's reputation for being graded difficultly, but it is well worth it, and students can expect to do well with a little bit of effort. The con stories we learned about on were extremely interesting. As someone who generally is not a big reader, I thoroughly enjoyed the essay readings as well as some of the other cons we looked at in this course. Most importantly, Ian is an amazing instructor. He is very funny and makes the course fun, but is also excellent at teaching the material in an understandable way. As someone who was not thrilled about expos, I was shocked to find that this was my favorite course this semester. Circling back to grades, it is true that this class is not a free A. However, Ian provides value feedback and is always willing to help, so good grades can be achieved through taking in his assistance and thinking hard about the essays. This class is not difficult in an hours/week way. The readings are generally short, and I never felt bogged down by the work. We had 3 essays, but work outside these was sparse and ungraded. Rather, the course is difficult because it challenged me to break my bad writing habits and change the way I approach academic essays, which proved to be surprisingly enjoyable. I recommend this course to anyone, especially to those that are not excited about their expos requirement.

If you are interested in free speech, take this class! The conversations and topics are very engaging and applicable to current issues. In my opinion, Prof. Sinnott grades fairly and gives great feedback in the conferences. There are high expectations for clear argumentation in this course, but it definitely helped improve my argumentation skills. Overall, I found this to be a great Expos section...just do the readings!
Please take this. Best expos ever. Chill class, great writing experience. Perfect, just try hard.
worse_comment: Will you learn about the "Science" of Science Fiction? No. You will, however, learn about the science of low essay grades.

best_comment: This is a fabulous expos section and I couldn’t recommend it enough. Professor Spencer is very kind and chooses some awesome sci–fi to read (maybe I just have a soft spot for Ursula K Leguin and Ted Chiang). The draft—>essay progression of the class felt very natural; response assignments we worked on prior to submitting first drafts provided helpful information and got us thinking about our essays before we started writing them so that, when the draft due date came along, we had already developed thesis statements and roadmaps for our papers.The grading in the class is very fair and follows the clear statement in the syllabus; for individual essays, submission of a first draft that is imperfect but has stuff to work with is essential, but, if you can get that in, Professor Spencer provides thoughtful feedback that can help turn the draft into a very effective final piece.I know that Expos has accumulated a certain reputation that I care not to get into, but I felt that this class was always interesting and enjoyable, even when the semester got busy. There was a certain ebb and flow to the structure of class meetings and in–class discussions that I really loved. If you love sci–fi, you belong here.
worse_comment: Don’t take this class Stephen Spencer is the worst teacher I have had out of both my semesters so far

best_comment: Strauss is a lovely human and great teacher. Overall, this is a nice expos course, and you will learn how to analyze movies and connect them with other topics and mediums. She grades very fairly, and gives you alot of good comments after your first draft. If you take her comments seriously, you will be rewarded with a good grade. I also really did enjoy the final capstone video, which felt way more exciting and less intensive than a third essay

Prof. Strauss is an incredibly kind and gracious teacher! She will make the class feel warm and wants you to be your genuine self. The theme of persona for me was an interesting one throughout the semester to follow and I thought each unit was compelling. Using films as a lens for analysis was fun, however, there is one week where you will have to watch three films, but that is the heaviest this class gets in terms of homework. It is super manageable and Prof. Strauss is also very understanding. I thought the two essays + capstone was a perfect distribution, and each essay did not feel rushed for time since it was rolled out early on before the deadline. I had a great time in this class and would recommend, especially those who like psychological films.

This is a fantastic Expos course that gives you back exactly what you put into it. If you make the most of this class, you will not only learn how to write rigorously but also interesting readings and fascinating discussions. Dr. Sweeney truly cares for and tries to do the best for all his students, and he is so understanding about any issues that you may be having and is willing to work with you in order to find solutions for these problems. While the course is a little rigorous in its pace, Dr. Sweeney guides the class discussion in a way that makes it far easier to 'keep up' with and takes the time to check in with the class to see how everyone is feeling. He is extremely fair in his grading and gives copious reasoning for the grade that he gives. This course truly taught me how to write at the college level, and I think that it was one of the most enjoyable experiences so far at Harvard. This is truly a fantastic Expos course!
worse_comment: Very harsh feedback and grading is not that generous. Fun class but one of the hardest ones I've taken here

best_comment: I think this is probably one of the better expos classes to take. The subject is kind of niche so I would only take it if you like the materials on the syllabus. That being said, I did enjoy the materials on the syllabus. Expos is just annoying, but I do feel like this class made me a much stronger writer. Dr. Sweeney gives extremely useful feedback that will help you improve. He is really encouraging and wants you to do well and work hard.

To be honest, the class was okay overall. If you go into it expecting a funny and entertaining experience, you might be a bit disappointed—the professor even mentioned this himself. It’s not necessarily a “funny” class because you’re analyzing humor rather than simply enjoying it, and that can take some of the fun out of the topic. That said, the class isn’t difficult. The professor is fair and not a harsh grader, and the workload is manageable. The readings were reasonable and not nearly as overwhelming as those in some other Expos classes.
worse_comment: Hard if you are not super interested in the topic. It goes very in depth into humor and may be difficult if you are not passionate.

best_comment: First off, go to as many draft conferences as you can! This class is a great experience overall, and though it won't exactly make you funnier, it ends up being quite interesting to read about the different theories of humor. You might be wondering what you'll gain out of this class if it doesn't actually make you funnier, so just know that what you read about in this class actually makes for pretty good conversation with friends or your curious parents. Prof. Turley is a great guy and really does care about his students improving over the course of the semester. His comments are very helpful and he encourages everyone to contribute to class discussions. Grading is decently rigorous and I wouldn't call the class a "gem", but I do feel that Prof. Turley makes expectations for papers pretty clear. Generally, I'd recommend the class given that Prof. Turley is truly an expert in humor studies who  evidently enjoys teaching , there are two major papers as opposed to three (plus a capstone, but I'd say it's better than a third major paper),  and that the readings (of which there will be a decent chunk in any expos class) actually happen to be enjoyable.

Best Expos, hands down. This is the transformative Harvard experience. The material is so relevant and engaging. You do have to be invested in the topics, but it is not at all hard to be given the nature of the course content and instruction offered.The first unit, meaning in language, is quite technical but a highly valuable field to learn as it gives you a foundation for what gives words meaning—something you don't really stop to think about and appreciate. This transformed my perspective on human communication and large language models while giving me a great introduction to important linguistics theories. The second unit, meaning in literature, is also intriguing and extremely worthwhile. It questions things like the role of an author in a text and rules that govern writing (prescribed grammar rules vs. describing how people naturally speak)—something of interest to any reader/writer of texts (aka you!).As if these two weren't amazing and so relevant to our own lives enough, the third unit covers meaning in life! We all question this topic, and the readings offer wonderful theories that can help guide your own independent thoughts on this topic. None of the readings are prescriptive and are meant to give you new perspectives to draw from and better inform your own outlooks into these critical topics. I felt so much more assured and informed on this topic, which affects everyday experiences with life, after this course.Essays are very reasonable, and feedback is meticulous and always helps your next draft be much better in structure, argumentation, etc. The final research paper is the final boss that requires your proper attention and time commitment. The first two essays are more easily paced and structured.Last thing, the students were a significant part of what made this class the wonderful experience it was. My section always had amazing discussions that led to many classes going overtime and time flying by so quickly—it was always so fun and insightful to engage in class discussions about what people thought about meaning (in various contexts, of course).Expos was the highlight of my week—my favorite class by far. I learned so much this semester, and it has transformed how I want my college career to look. Cannot recommend this course enough. Just make sure you want to commit to this course and are ready to fully engage with readings, discussions, and critical thinking. You will get so much out of this course!!!
worse_comment: Don't take this course unless you're interested in philosophy. Rob is also lowkey weird and kooky.

best_comment: You should take this class. Most expos classes are very specific and kind of random, but this one is pretty legit. If you are at all interesting in taking a philosophy course at Harvard, you might as well bang it out along with the expos requirement in one fell swoop. This is a great course. We first talk about the meaning in language (how is it that words can transmit meaning, and what is that meaning/how is it determined), literature (what role does an author play in the meaning of a text? How important are language rules for meaning?), and then life (is life meaningful or absurd? How can we find meaning in our lives?). The readings were, albeit long and dense at times, overall super interesting. We read David Foster Wallace, Frankl, Barthes, Wittgenstein, Hegel, Grice, and more. Rob is very knowledgable and smart; this means that he is not very lenient on essays and will both clock as well as comment on any inaccuracies in your writing. I appreciate that in a teacher – he doesn't take bs. Still, Rob is very kind. He wants us all to feel good in class and he likes to joke around with us. He's funny and he is not mean at all – he is just smart and wants us to understand the concepts well. Class can be tedious at times but is generally super interesting with a fair amount of discussion, group work, and class chats. Rob takes the time to explain any confusing readings to us in a very detailed and helpful way. There is usually a fair amount of time left for people to comment on readings and give different takes. Rob is organized in terms of class content, but disorganized in Canvas. Comments take a while sometimes but they are thorough. All in all this was a great class and I learned so so so much. I am very glad and grateful to have taken it.
worse_comment: I honestly didn't love this class. If you're really into philosophy, then go for it. But I wasn't as interested in the content as some other kids were. The readings can be difficult, especially at the beginning of the semester. But I don't feel like the class helped my writing at all, and it was mostly centered around talking about different philosophies. So, if you're not into that, then I would go for a different expos.

best_comment: This expos section was not my first choice, but ended up being fine. The work was not too difficult, even though the readings were sometimes super long, and Mande is a lovely woman who clearly cares deeply for the topic. It was nice to reflect on my own experience with craft, and I enjoyed getting to know my peers in the section! As far as expos goes, you could do worse than this.

This course is interesting and definitely not a bad option for expos. Dr Zecca is lovely and really enthusiastic about the course content. Her feedback is somewhat unclear and does change between the conference and final draft (something that was great in conference will not be explained enough in the final). You really have to buy into the topic, even if talking about craft for a semester does get a bit difficult. The capstone is nice.

HIGHLY RECOMMEND. if you want to take a fun, not difficult expos, this is it. kimcriag is WONDERFUL, incredibly sweet, accomadting, and INTERESTING. the topics discussed are so interesting and kimcraig allows us to explore our own interests within kinship studies. 10/10 recommend.

AMAZING CLASS! This was the first anthropology class I've ever taken, but it made me much more interested in the subject and all of the course material was super interesting. Although you don't need any prerequisites for the course, the class will be much more enjoyable if you are already interested in families, relationships, reproductive technologies, or cultures. Having an interest in the subject made the essays actually fun to write, and the class discussions entertaining. The instructor has lived in six continents and has really interesting lore and research that enriches the subject matter regarding kinship. She will question your pre–existing beliefs and encourages everyone to discuss their perspective. The classroom environment is academic yet informal, and students feel comfortable voicing their opinions on the content, which makes the seminars fun to attend. Of course, the class is still rigorous and requires attentive reading and participation. Overall, I loved this Expos! Highly recommend.

The material was genuinely engaging without being overwhelming, and you can clearly tell how passionate Dr. Brown is about the subject. If you’re interested in literature, you’ll definitely enjoy this course—but even if you’re not, the class had a majority of STEM and Economics students, which actually fostered unique and compelling discussions.
worse_comment: The subject matter and core texts are very interesting. I do feel, however, that the focus on trauma is very narrow and hard to apply to the papers that you will have the write, especially because Dr. Brown chooses such obscure and specific lenses. The instructions for the unit essays are also very ambiguous, and Dr. Brown's grading is not sympathetic in that respect. We had many short stories and films to watch, however classroom discussions on those works were very stagnant, and Dr. Brown was often the only voice in the classroom. I heard that his past EXPOS class, Wastelands, was much more enjoyable, but I would not strongly recommend this section.

best_comment: The content of this class is very interesting. Your writing will improve based on how much effort and time you are willing to put into this class. It's very valuable to meet with the instructor and discuss her feedback in more depth — this will help you better understand what you are doing wrong and how you can improve your writing.

Dr. Musselman is an amazing preceptor! Her course is well designed, interesting and great for improving your writing. Compared to what I heard from peers about their Expos courses, this class is not only great at spreading out the readings and 3 essays in a way that gives you plenty of time to work on them, but it also is vastly more interesting in terms of its content. Who wouldn't be interested in learning about cults!? Here are my tips for how to do well in this class: – Do all of the readings! It may seem like a lot, especially towards the beginning of the semester when in Unit 1, but the readings are fairly simple and should not take you a lot of time. Once having done them, be sure to write your discussion comments, these also should not take a lot of time to do. – Participate in class discussions: I felt hesitant at the beginning of the semester, but Dr. Musselman does a great job at facilitating open and inclusive discussions. Your comments don't have to be profound or sound sophisticated– just say what you are thinking about the readings and likely many other students will agree with you or have their own ideas to add on. – The most important components of each paper are: your analytical question and your thesis. SPEND A LOT OF TIME ON THIS PART!!! If you don't have a good thesis and idea of where you want your paper to go, you will find yourself lost throughout the process. Be sure to use the in–class opportunities Dr. Musselman provides such as thesis workshops, peer editing, etc. to really revise and settle on something you are happy with. – Take advantage of the conferences and office hours. Have a rough draft prepared before you go into them. This helps you and the instructor better work through the improvements that can be made and where the paper can go. More importantly, don't be scared if you have to change entire paragraphs or even your whole paper. There is a lot of time built into the essay writing process, enough for you to be able to do either of those things without needing to panic. – The final research paper is the most hefty one. It also makes up the largest portion of your grade. PICK A SUBJECT YOU ARE ACTUALLY INTERESTED IN!!! Don't just pick a subject that has the most research or sources, genuinely go with something that you can see yourself researching and writing about for a month. – Utilize the Academic Writing Center, especially for the first or second unit. They offer a lot of support, and it's better if you go at the start of the writing process, rather than later. This course is not easy, but Expos is not meant to be that. What differentiates this class is that you have a lot of opportunities to ask for help, you get fantastic detailed feedback on almost everything you turn in, and your writing will truly improve by the end. Good luck learning about cults!!!

This class can be a slog to get through at time. Only take this class if you are genuinely interested in the successful life. If not, I suggest you find something in the other standard expos you would be passionate about
worse_comment: Take the course if you are not confident in your writing. However, you may have numerous small reading assignments and annotations to do before each class, which is annoying as you may not even use some of the sources in your paper.

best_comment: Amy is a really great instructor who really cares and listens to your ideas and will give you great ideas to make those hard–to–write ideas malleable. This course is really good, even though studio 10 was not as enjoyable; studio 20 makes the writing process fun because it is entirely self guided and allows you to write what you want to write but now in an academic setting.

TAKE EXPOS STUDIO. Especially if you're a pre–med cause you need a year of English anyway. Studio is honestly so much better than standard because there is more time for feedback, you have more time to focus on your papers ––– and it is better writing. For standard, I saw all of my friends worry and rush through everything, while for Studio, even with taking 5 classes, I was rushing but I felt like there was always time to improve papers. I loved my papers and its topic ––– there is a lot of flexibility in choosing topics which I feel like sometimes standard expos might lack.
worse_comment: This class is a little boring at times, but if you are willing to participate, you will get a lot out of conversations with your classmates.

best_comment: Jonah is the best Expos teacher by far. The environment in class felt to me as if I am hanging out with friends. We could talk with Jonah about any topic and he is super curious to know each and every one of us personally. Take this class with Jonah!
Better than standard ( trust me )

Expos 20 Studio with Professor Jody is a truly engaging class that you want to attend. The readings in the first half of the semester were quite interesting, and I genuinely enjoyed participating in the discussions, as they were relevant to us, the students. Many of the response papers were useful for the final essay, so they are also worth paying attention to. Of course, Jody's feedback and help with writing were essential for me, and these feedbacks was very, very good. Detailed, with examples, and overall very useful. Jody is a master at leading discussions, and his sense of humour, combined with his expertise in many areas, made the class more than interesting. He is a very understanding and flexible professor who puts his students first. So even though the course itself may need some editing in places, Jody made it as engaging as possible.
Hannah is very cool. The discussions in her class are really nice. Her feedback on the assignments make sense, and she is always happy to help. You should definitely consider Hannah.
worse_comment: If you took 10 and are deciding between studio or standard 20, take studio! Your instruction is so much more individualized and I feel like this course is much less stressful than many standard expos sections.

best_comment: This class was totally reasonable and a good class. Pace is slow and steady – you really work through the modules piece by piece. This means that the class DOES NOT provide unnecessary stress – huge points for that. You only need to write 2 papers over the course, and they are both super chill and you build the skills up and write them over time as opposed to simply being told to make a paper appear from nothing in a few days. I'm English and had decent writing experience before this class in high school, and I genuinely vouch for it as a great option instead of normal Expos 20. Much more laid back, and you get out precisely what you put in. I learnt a TON about myself as a writer through this more methodic approach to writing, and in the end I feel as though this knowledge has made me a far more reflective and competent writer in return. Every single person SHOULD CONSIDER EXPOS STUDIO. It is a GREAT choice for everyone. Very chill, very interesting. Hannah Kauders IS AN ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE PROFESSOR. She is the SWEETEST human I've ever met and she is so caring and helpful and attentive to her students and she will make you feel so at ease throughout the entire class AND WILL MAKE IT FUN. She's hilarious and class was genuinely amazing vibes WHILE we were learning and working hard. Nothing else you could possibly ask for in a class.
The class is not too bad. It is pretty low stress
Take this class! The class is interesting and set up in such a good way! People in Standard 20 were always complaining about work but this class was always more laid back

Take this class! This course taught me how to effectively evaluate sources, pick a good research topic, how to form a hypothesis and counterargument, and how to effectively incorporate historical evidence into a paper. Expos studio 20 was definitely worth my time in terms of learning research skills, and the environment from the professor to my fellow classmates was extremely supportive.

If you are unsure on whether you have a very strong writing background, definitely take it. However, take into consideration your possible major, I think it is a great class, however, there are other courses I would have liked to take too, instead of taking Expos two semesters. If you do not mind, then definitely take it. Sections are small so you get the chance to get close to other students and I think you can form friendships from it too, I still talk to my friends from Expos Studio 10, which makes me not regret anything from the experience. If you are choosing between Studio 20 or regular 20 (if you already took Studio 10), I think definitely choose Studio 20, you get more feedback and more time to really perfect your essays for the same writing credit.
Choose the topic of research for your paper that you really like and would enjoy exploring
If you are going to take this class, take it with MG!!! She is amazing and hands one of the best professors I have had during my time here.

This class is amazing and should be taken, especially with John. I was heavily debating changing into Standard 20 after my first semester of studio and I do not regret staying with the studio track. You get to explore so many topics that you could be interested in, whereas your friends who go into standard are forced to stick to their class topic. Additionally, the readings are enjoyable and don't feel like a chore to get them done at all.
Great class! The assignments were super interesting!! Definitely would recommend!

This CLASS AND PROFESSOR WAS GREAT! If you're able to take this class, I would encourage you to do so. The studio series has genuinely become a game–changer in terms of my confidence and writing abilities.

worse_comment: Make sure you just keep up with work. You can cram a response paper every now and then, but take the drafts and revisions very seriously.

best_comment: My favorite class I've taken at Harvard! So fun and class–time flies by, I actually wanted to go to class and never dreaded it. I showed up like all the time because I wanted to be there. Can't recommend enough– someone in a previous Q guide said "lottery early and often" for Expos 40 and I completely agree. Nick is an awesome preceptor too! So smart, helpful, kind, and flexible! You'll become a much more confident public speaker and make new friends in your class :)

IF YOU DO ONE THING BEFORE LEAVING HARVARD, TAKE THIS COURSE!!!! Public speaking is necessary for everything you do in life. And, this course may be scary to you. But I absolutely promise that this has been one of the most welcoming, most rewarding, most wholesome courses of my college career. Everyone comes into the course at different levels — some are naturally better public speakers, other are a bit more unrefined. None of that matters. Everyone is so, so welcoming and wants to hear about your life story through the speeches you give. Ultimately, what you get out of this course is directly proportional to what you put in. Some might say that this course isn't worth your time, but I'd disagree. I found myself spending hours and hours on each speech, perfecting it to be just right, because I cared about getting better and putting my best foot forward. I learned how to think on my feet and speak impromptu. I learned how to better tell stories and craft narratives. I learned technical public speaking skills that will serve me for life moving forward. And, I made so many new friends. This is a senior–heavy class, so if you're a senior taking this in the spring, it'll be a way to build community and have a tight–knit group before parting ways. If you take this as an underclassman, you'll hear so many stories and persepctive–altering speeches that will help shape the rest of your undergraduate career. Truly cannot recommend this course enough!

TAKE IT! Truly so important for life skills. Terry is a great instructor and generates so much enthusiasm. The assignments are fun and you can take your own spin on them, he encourages creativity and for you to stay engaged! Go in with an open mind and you will improve so much!

This is a great class for a lot of reasons. For one, public speaking is a really useful skill if you're in a field where you need to present a lot, like the sciences or performing arts. Two, it really improves your general social confidence and communication skills: it helped me speak up in a 350 person lecture class I was also taking this semester, and even empowered me to participate in a debate in front of the entire lecture hall.  I did a much better job and felt a lot more comfortable than I would have prior to taking Expos 40. Finally, it's a small and social class, so you get to make a lot of friends! Our whole class made a group chat and hung out a few times just for fun :)
worse_comment: Take the exercises seriously

best_comment: Expos 40 is a fantastic course! There were many, MANY opportunities for feedback, the class environment was supportive with room for experimentation, and it was a fun way to practice a practical skill while getting to know a group of people you otherwise probably wouldn't. James is fantastic –– he's very knowledgeable, and really encourages us to lean into the at times silly nature of the class while making sure we always knew the concrete reason why we were were doing whatever we were doing.
worse_comment: Absolutely take this class! Could not recommend it more highly.

best_comment: This is an incredible couse, and James Montaño is the best teacher! One of the best courses I have taken as Harvard, it truly challenged me in a fun and engaging way. Please take this if you have the chance, you won't regret it.

This course was one of the BEST I HAVE TAKEN AT HARVARD!! Very light workload, but learned so much! The sections with the small group of 10 people make it engaging, and Professor Stuart is one of the best and one of my favorite Professors at Harvard! At times, the class topics for speeches – of course something that people chose – would get controversial in the sense that there was plenty of discussion and push back from peers who had opposing views but Professor Stuart made sure to keep it light and fun; everyone had different perspectives whether religion/politics/etc but we were all very united as a section by the end of the semester.  I would not change ANYTHING about the course! If you could take it with Professor Stuart, DO IT! YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT! He is easily the best professor in the Writing Department that I've seen/heard of! He's leaving Harvard I believe but if by some miracle he stays, please take it with him!
worse_comment: Do not take Zach's section. He doesn't give any feedback and is constantly forcing political discussions with no credibility.

best_comment: This is a great class!!! I really enjoyed my Expos40 section! My class really got to know each other well, and I made a lot of friends, even as a second semester senior! Zach was a phenomenal preceptor, he did a great job of fostering our growth and facilitating class unity. I really got better a public speaking, the speeches were a great way to practice and grow. 10/10 would recommend!

course_title: Building a Resilient Community: Dialogue and Deliberation for Civil Discourse 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! It honestly changed my worldview and the way I interact with others. I believe I am a better listener and friend after taking this class. The two hours fly by because it's so enjoyable, and we are constantly on our feet, moving into different groups, and really engaging with everyone else in the class. The environment was extremely safe and welcoming and it made me feel comfortable enough to talk about topics I was unsure about because I knew everyone was willing to be respectful as we all learned together. The assignments and different aspects (negotiation, controversial topics, improv, speeches, group projects, serial testimony) were so unique and creative. I LOVED THIS CLASS TAKE IT IF YOU CAN!! Also, Kate and Erika were the kindest, most empathetic and wonderful teachers ever.

course_title: Building a Resilient Community: Dialogue and Deliberation for Civil Discourse 002
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! The best class I have taken at Harvard hands down. Amazing professors. Amazing assignments. Amazing lessons. Such a safe space. This should be a required class!!!

If you're thinking about a first–year seminar, take this one. It's super interesting and very informative, but never so much information that you can't process it. Prof. Farrell is amazing, and he facilitates great discussions about the readings in class that make the long periods seem super short. The final presentation is also great, as it allows you to choose your specific field of interest within the overall topic and do a deep dive into it. Overall, a fantastic class that will make you excited about everything it talks about.

course_title: Medicine in Nazi Germany and the Holocaust—Anatomy as Example for Changes in Medical Science 001
best_comment: This is a wonderful seminar to take. Sabine Hildebrandt is a wonderful seminar leader, and is just the most knowledgeable person out there in regards to this subject. You will constantly be amazed by the stories she tells (and then she'll proceed to tell you that she is the one who first learned about it in an interview or in her research!). Take this if you are interested in the subject matter–– the content can be incredibly heavy sometimes, but that should be expected. If you take this course, you MUST participate. Dr. Hildebrandt would often ask questions to no response. Please do the prep work (it took maybe an hour per week, if that) and please participate in class. She loves hearing what people have to say, and will sometimes even follow up after class to hear more about your thoughts. I've never met a professor so interested in what her students thought.This course isn't just for pre–meds! No matter what you plan on studying, I would still recommend this seminar. The content, though sometimes heavy, will teach you so much.
worse_comment: This class is eye opening and deeply emotional and disturbing. Dr. Hildebrandt has such a unique perspective and is incredibly knowledgeable. This is is a very important class to take.

best_comment: This was my favorite course I've taken at Harvard, and one of my favorite educational experiences ever  — it's a perfect blend of medicine, ethics/philosophy, and literary/journalistic analysis,  so there's something for everyone and you get to meet all types in this class. Dr. G is so kind and knowledgable, and is an incredible guide, mentor, and resource. I would 100% recommend this course to anyone — regardless of if you're interested in medicine, you'll get something really meaningful out of it.

Professor Alcock is super nice and a great guy! He is a quiet guy but has so much enthusiasm for the topic and could probably yap about asteroids and comets forever. He also brings in a lot of his friends/colleagues to speak almost every week and these are super cool/important people. We also got to do a lab where we look at meteorites which is super cool!

course_title: “How Did I Get Here?”—Appreciating “Normal” Child Development 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!!!! It's a wonderful addition to any course schedule with everything you could ever ask for: light course load, interesting and engaging assignments, free food every week, minimal class meeting time, an intimate section environment with cool people, and the best professor. Take this class if you have any interest in psychology, neuroscience, or children and child development; it has wonderful lessons and life lessons for everyone.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! You will not regret it. However, I would say that you shouldn't take this class just because it seems like a gem. The class is so much more fun when everyone in it is genuinely interested in the material, especially since it was such a small group.

course_title: Changing Our Mind: Evolving Thoughts on Brain Regeneration 001
best_comment: Take this class!! It's so fun, it was probably my favorite class this semester. All of the material is super interesting and engaging, but it's very approachable. If you want to put in extra work outside of class to gain an even better understanding of the material you can, but it's by no means necessary
worse_comment: ABSOLUTELY TAKE THIS COURSE!!!!It was such an amazing seminar. Getting to learn from Dr. Arlotta and discussing cutting edge research in the field is so enriching! It has a very nice reading list and gives a lot of perspective not only on the current research but also the criticism it faces and the direction it is going in!

course_title: Borges, García Márquez, Bolaño and Other Classics of Modern Latin American Fiction and Poetry 001
best_comment: TAKE IT!!! Prof. Siskind has a passion for this subject that I had never seen before, and he will pass it on to you. Not only that, but he's also an extremely kind and understanding man, and genuinely wants the best for you (he teared up on the last class!). The readings are lovely and mostly very low commitment, so you get to read as fast or slow as you'd like. You can really invest any amount of energy into this class and you will still enjoy it, although because of how great the books are, I recommend you invest time into all of them. The discussions in class are great, and Prof. Siskind loves to share his knowledge on the subject with others. The final project is super fun to do too, and is the only thing that will require more time from you. The class opened my eyes to Latin American literature and helped me gain a new appreciation of its intricacies and close relationship with LATAM's history. You can also read the books in Spanish if you know the language, which is a huge plus.

DO WHATEVER YOU CAN TO TAKE THIS CLAS!!! ITS AMAZING!! One thing is it is more work than any other semnar I have heard of, but it is so worth it.  It takes a group of diverse students from Harvard's first year class and brings them together to debate relevant topics. Getting to meet and hear different people's perspectives was extremely beneficial for my semester and my learning overall. This course is the best example of academic vitality that I have experienced while at Harvard. I felt comfortable expressing my views and I think others did as well.  Furthermore,  I felt like I was surrounded by the nation's best and brightest and I learned as much from them as I learned from the course material.  I think this course also did a great job of fostering interpersonal relationships between students, and I feel like I gained several friends from taking this course. Honestly, I think university officials and professors across the university should look to this course as the epitome of what a Harvard course should be. Professor Hart is so funny and is a great facilitator of discussions. To be honest, I think I was not passionate about some of the topics, and some of the topics felt a little less relevant to me. For example, I didn't love the weeks about government nudges or citizens assemblies, but overall the topics were so intersting. Professor Hart is actually the best he is just so wholesome and has an English accent which makes the class really fun to listen to.

course_title: Where are you from? Ancestry in the Age of Genomics 001
best_comment: Overall, I think I would recommend this first year seminar. I found the content of the course very interesting and the discussions to be wide–reaching. It was also a very laid back course but remained  very interesting. My only real critique is that I think the course would have benefitted from more student driven conversations.. I think there is a lot of value in professor led discussion but I also think it would've been cool to be able to talk more directly student to student.

course_title: The Secrets of Stradivarius or What Makes the Violin Sound Beautiful? 001
best_comment: This is a great exploratory class. It's very free and very much what you put in. You could spend 10 hours a week doing what you want with your violin or you could spend 0 hours outside of class. Professor Cluzel is a lovely, funny instructor.

course_title: Changing Perspectives: the Science of Optics in the Visual Arts 001
best_comment: If you are interested in art and the science behind it, take this class!! Professor Samuel knows so much about the topic and is so enthusiastic about it.  You get a chance to go on so many cool field trips, meet with art conservators, artists, and so many cool and interesting people. It is a great combination of hands on approach, testing out how the science of optic can help you make better and more realistic art and professor's presentations about the topic. Genuinely such an interesting class!!

course_title: Science and Technology Primer for Future Leaders 001
best_comment: Hongkun was truly the sweetest professor and I loved being in his seminar! He truly spends a lot of effort to get to know his students on personal levels to understand what they're interested in and encourage them to pursue their interests. During seminar, office hours, and seminar meals, he is always open to questions and having interesting discussions. He is a passionate lecturer and has lots of expertise to share in the field too, so I would definitely recommend this as a class to get to know more about various fields that you might not be as exposed to. As a Social Sciences concentrator, this seminar was accessible for me to get to know about the scientific community in slightly more depth, and clarified many technical details for me!

course_title: The Quantum Revolution: from Computing to Time Crystals 001
best_comment: If you have any interest in quantum computing TAKE THIS COURSE!! I came in as a student with a slightly less advanced physics/math background (I'm planning to do engineering, not pure physics) and I had a great time. Prof Yao is very accommodating for students of different backgrounds, and I found all the lectures to be very interesting and exciting. This first–year seminar is challenging in the sense that it opens your mind up to new concepts and ideas, but it wasn't stressful to complete the assignments and do well. Prof Yao does a great job at creating an environment where you can focus on learning new topics and trying to understand new things without a ton of pressure to fully master everything that is covered. If you're interested in quantum and want to learn about it in a way that is engaging (without being academically stressful) and fun (without having too shallow of a syllabus), this is the class for you!! Prof Yao is a fantastic, understanding teacher who's always ready with great jokes, helpful explanations, and tasty free pizza.

course_title: Learning How to Think Like a Scientist: An Introduction to Scientific Research 001
best_comment: From all the classes I took as a first–year at Harvard, this has been my favorite.  Truly, Dan and Sien are such amazing teachers. Not only do they have so much wisdom and expertise in the sciences, but they are also such a joy to be around. Class was never boring, and at times, I wished we met more than once a week. Although I haven't participated in the summer research program associated with this seminar yet, I'm super excited because I know I'll learn more. Dan and Sien went above and beyond when it came to preparing readings and materials for class and facilitating class discussions, and even bringing great scientists as guest speakers to talk to us in class. The final project of giving a chalk talk sounds daunting at first, but the course is structured so well that you take little steps at a time, and you will be prepared for it before you even realize it. This class was an absolute gem, so please consider taking it if you're interested in research and have not done it before!!!!

course_title: Learning How to Think Like a Scientist: An Introduction to Scientific Research 001
best_comment: From all the classes I took as a first–year at Harvard, this has been my favorite.  Truly, Dan and Sien are such amazing teachers. Not only do they have so much wisdom and expertise in the sciences, but they are also such a joy to be around. Class was never boring, and at times, I wished we met more than once a week. Although I haven't participated in the summer research program associated with this seminar yet, I'm super excited because I know I'll learn more. Dan and Sien went above and beyond when it came to preparing readings and materials for class and facilitating class discussions, and even bringing great scientists as guest speakers to talk to us in class. The final project of giving a chalk talk sounds daunting at first, but the course is structured so well that you take little steps at a time, and you will be prepared for it before you even realize it. This class was an absolute gem, so please consider taking it if you're interested in research and have not done it before!!!!

course_title: Unlocking the Power of Immunology – From Fundamental Principles to Innovative Research Routes 01
best_comment: Kaz is the sweetest professor! It was an honor to be a part of his inaugural seminar. I can only imagine that his class will become better as he gains more teaching experience :) TAKE THIS CLASS!!

course_title: Fun With Writing… or, Writing for Weirdos 01
best_comment: I'd recommend this class with reservations. If you think this is going to be a writing class or that you'll learn a lot about writing, don't take it.It's a very silly unserious class that takes itself very seriously. During class exercises we at one point ended up drawing a family tree for an assignment, we ran around and played tag, we made our own games and we drew comics. Honestly not super related to writing, more creating in general. This is more of a theatre class, so if you're into that, I WOULD recommend it!The class ended up being 6 students, and I now feel kinda trauma–bonded to all of them. I say this lightly because the class WAS fun, but it was wacky at times.One warning that I hope is changed in the future is that the homework is a little intense. Well – maybe not really, but it feels like it compared to the class. During class we'd sit and talk and draw and laugh and maybe run around and share snacks, but then get assigned 200–pages of reading with a 1–hour podcast to listen to that might not even get brought up the next week. There are weekly writing assignments that do not get brought up during class, and I don't think I ever really received feedback for them. I DID receive awesome feedback for stuff I did DURING class, or assignments that will be specifically relevant to class, but it felt like I was writing into a void sometimes.So a lot to consider – this class was definitely a lot. But overall, as much as I may have complained, I am actually glad I took it. It was VERY fun. Even the many many readings were super interesting, and we got to meet one of the authors we were assigned to read, too! We had little field trips throughout, which were awesome (going to museums, exhibitions, etc). The class environment was really fun and a few times I found myself red in the face laughing incredulous. Just great in general.So yeah, keep all this in mind and enjoy the class if you decide to take it! It will definitely create core memories

Great class and a fantastic introduction to the department! As someone who was only considering concentrating in History of Art and Architecture (HAA), this class truly made me want to pursue it further. Maybe it was the small seminar setting, which encouraged in–depth discussion and allowed for a close, thoughtful engagement with the works. Or perhaps it was the course content and readings themselves. Either way, this class is a testament to how well the department utilizes its resources. I would honestly recommend taking this class even if you’re not planning to concentrate in HAA. Our group included students from a wide range of fields—from Applied Math to English—which really enriched the classroom dynamic.

course_title: Making the Self: Poetics of Authenticity 001
best_comment: DEFINITELY TAKE THIS FIRST–YEAR SEMINAR!! Come to this class with an open mind and a willingness to be vulnerable. This course will ask you to reflect honestly on your identity and what it means to be authentic, which can be challenging but also incredibly rewarding. Take advantage of the small class size to build genuine connections with your peers, as those conversations are some of the richest parts of the course. Embrace the creative assignments—they’re designed to help you express complex ideas in new ways and deepen your understanding of the readings. Through this seminar I learned that authenticity is not about perfection or a static ideal; it’s a journey of self–discovery that this class helps you explore thoughtfully and poetically.

course_title: Creature Feature: Fantastic Animals in Myth and History 001
best_comment: I won't lie and say that this is an easy First–year seminar, but it is definitely an interesting one. There is a significant amount of reading per week for a seminar (100–200 pages) but only one short discussion post. The content is incredibly interesting, and Prof. Patton is passionate and knowledgeable about the topics, so you will definitely learn a lot about mythical creatures. If you are interested in the content and can commit to the reading, then you will get a lot out of the course. I, personally, devoted time to doing all of the reading and found the course very rewarding, but I also know that there were some people who only read enough of the reading to do the discussion posts, and so didn't get very much from the course. This is definitely a course where you will get out what you put in.

course_title: Law and Social Change: How Reform Movements Leverage the Law 001
best_comment: Take this course!!!! Brown–Nagin is a one–of–a–kind professor. Her professionalism and demeanor are so intimidating, but if you have useful insights and do the readings, she will love you. The coursework is light, so its a great class if you have a more intensive schedule.

course_title: Fat Talk and Thin Ideals: Culture, Social Norms and Weight 001
best_comment: Dr. Becker is an amazing professor with so much life and career experience! Her stories from Fiji and working with Dr. Paul Farmer are fascinating. It was truly a pleasure and honor learning from such an accomplished person. Beyond her accomplishments, she is a genuinely sweet and supportive person.I initially went into this class worried that the scope would be too narrow: weight ideals in Fiji. But this course does a great job of incorporating various topics, so it is good for anyone who is interested in medicine, public health, and also government, policy, and more. I really enjoyed this class!

Take this class. It is so relevant today, the readings are long yet extremely interesting and you get the chance to meet some notable people in the U.S–China landscapes such as politicians, businessmen and more.

This class was a great first year seminar! I feel like a learned cool material in a very chill and friendly environment. The trips were a lot of fun, and I got to see some parts of Boston that I haven't seen before. If you are interested in maps or history or cities or just want to learn something new, you should totally take this class.

course_title: Fieldwork and Ethnography in Folklore: A Tutorial in Cultural Documentation and Community Engagement 001
best_comment: This is a fantastic class if you're interested in learning how to engage with people during fieldwork, how to conduct interviews, take notes and interpret site experiences . The class also functions as a survey course, even if you're already familiar with ethnography and anthropology, it presents a broad review of how folklore fits within a larger academic discourse.

Wonderful course! Dr. Craycraft is amazing (she is so funny and kind, super cool)! There were a broad range of people in the class, and I learned a lot from everyone. I would recommend this course to anyone interesting in learning more about the topic, even if you are not from the region!

course_title: Introduction to the Indigenous Oral Literatures of the Northwest Coast of North America 001
best_comment: THIS WAS SUCH AN INCREDIBLE CLASS!!! This was definitely the highlight of my three years at Harvard. The topic and material is extremely exciting, the structure of the class made it both a rigorous and an intensive introduction, and also very low–stress. The essays we had to write could virtually be on any topic we found interesting. The readings for each week were a balanced mix of fascinating and mysterious tales and secondary sources that explain many things one would not see on their own. DANIEL IS AN AMAZING PROFESSOR!!! He is extremely knowledgeable, passionate, friendly, approachable, and understanding. He facilitated amazing discussion during class while also including mini–lectures and sharing his experience. He always found new and fun ways for us to engage with the topics, ranging from in–class close–reading activities, to coming up with fun questions that make you think, for example, what part of indigenous culture would we want to explore if we had access to a time machine, or in–class exercises where we try to make the best argument to back up a thesis proposed by certain author. I feel I learned so much not only about the culture of the Northwest Coast, but also about literature and academic writing and research, too. The class also included guest lectures and a visit to the Peabody Museum. I just can't express how extremely happy I am that I took this class. And I am not even a humanities concentrator. I took this class as an elective, and this is by far my best decision at Harvard! DEFINITELY TAKE THIS CLASS!!!

course_title: Elves, Fairies, and UFOs: Dangerous Encounters with Otherworldly Beings in Folklore 01
best_comment: Great class to take if you are interested in folklore or UFOs and enjoy writing papers. I had a great time in this class discussing the readings and our own thoughts on folklore, superstitions, aliens and more. The feedback Daniel provides is really amazing and has definitely made me a better writer. If you are ever considering dabbling in the folklore and mythology department, I think this class is a great choice!
best_gem_comment: Definitely take this class! It's a gem. There are just 3 essays which are super chill. Daniel is a very supportive and understanding person, never makes anyone feel uncomfortable and he takes a lot of interest in what people have to share. The topics are fun (although some of the UFO stuff got a bit repetitive at the end), and it was pretty cool to look at things with a folklore lens. The readings are functionally optional since you don't get quizzed on it during class or anything, but for your own benefit and enjoyment of the class, do the readings so you can participate and better appreciate what's going on.

best_comment: Everybody should talk FolkMyth 172 if you get the chance to! This is a rigorous academic treatment of quilt history, and I have learned *so much* about quiltmaking and its significance throughout the course. Felicity has a *staggering* knowledge of quilt history, and it is so wonderful to hear her speak during lecture. The section part of the course is also *incredible*—I had absolutely *no* background in *any* form of needlework, yet I was still able to be successful in lab, even making a full quilt as a final project. This class is no joke, and there is a *lot* of reading and writing to do each week, but I found this class to be so rewarding, and I highly recommend it to anybody with an interest in learning a new skill and a lot of *fascinating* art and American history! Felicity puts so much care into the class, and you will be successful if you put in your best effort.

course_title: Stories from the End of the World 001
best_comment: Amazing class! Worth taking if you are able to go to the 9am lectures, since you can only miss two the entire semester. The class is set up to be very simple with its assignments and the final, and you can usually get by pretty easily if you put in the slightest effort. If you just want to get the GENED requirement, you can do so easily, but if you are genuinely interested in the class, you can get so much more. Lectures with Bazzana are great, and the guest lectures towards the end of the semester can be fun. The class seems less fun at the beginning with the weekly quizzes, but it is so much better after the midterm. The assignments are very fun to do and allow you to get back what you want from the course, and you are able to put your own creative spin on anything that you want. Worth taking even if you do not need the GENED requirement, and if you are taking it for that reason, this is supposedly one of the best courses in the aesthetics and culture field.
worse_comment: This course requires attendance, with makes it feel like the students do not want to engage with the content. The course is interesting for the first few weeks but quickly losses content that makes it unique. The structure of the gened was not great so I would not reccomend this course.
best_gem_comment: Take this! This is a GEM if you like Arts and are an artist. The final project is a great exercise for your artistic skills

best_comment: I enjoyed this course, but if you care about everyone being as dedicated as you, this isn't the course to take. You really will interact with a wide range of people in this course, which has its upsides and downsides. I loved the readings, loved the deep discussions we had in class, I loved Hamilton's lectures, but not everyone had the same excitement for learning, and it was a bit disappointing. Also, Sam is the BEST TF EVER definitely aim to be in his section. Super kind and super understanding.
worse_comment: I feel genuinely awful saying this because Professor Hamilton seems so kind and passionate, but this is probably my least favorite class I have taken at Harvard. It's just really unclear what the course is actually about. The lectures are very long and rambly and don't seem to come to a specific conclusion, and I often sat there wondering what specifically I was learning. A lot of the TFs are really harsh for no clear reason.  I genuinely am not sure what I learned in this class :(
best_gem_comment: Gem!! Excellent class. A topic that is much more interesting than you might think, plus a brief intro to philosophy. Great lecture once a week that is actually interesting and engaging. Readings are not terribly dense and all are covered in lecture. Assignments are very low key. Easy A/A–.

course_title: Pride & Prejudice & P-values: Scientific Critical Thinking 001
best_comment: This course is a really great GenEd, especially for anyone who is interested in scientific inquiry, asking philosophical questions when it comes to science, and just having a general desire to better evaluate scientific claims. No background is necessary for this course. My advice to do well: – Go to all lectures and sections, it may seem as if attendance is not mandatory, but it really is and will affect your final grade – Put effort into the midterms and the assignments. They give you plenty of time to go through the steps of each assignment (roughly 3 weeks per assignment and 30 hours for each of the two take–home midterms). You will need that time, so please use it. Go to office hours and present your work, the sections leaders will tell you exactly what you can do to change/improve – Do the readings / discussion comments. It's literally one comment and will get you points for your final grades – It's really easy to do well in this course, as long as you put in the work for it! Be sure to stay engaged in lecture and group discussions – The final project is a really fun one, you get to be really creative with it!

course_title: Pride & Prejudice & P-values: Scientific Critical Thinking 001
best_comment: This course is a really great GenEd, especially for anyone who is interested in scientific inquiry, asking philosophical questions when it comes to science, and just having a general desire to better evaluate scientific claims. No background is necessary for this course. My advice to do well: – Go to all lectures and sections, it may seem as if attendance is not mandatory, but it really is and will affect your final grade – Put effort into the midterms and the assignments. They give you plenty of time to go through the steps of each assignment (roughly 3 weeks per assignment and 30 hours for each of the two take–home midterms). You will need that time, so please use it. Go to office hours and present your work, the sections leaders will tell you exactly what you can do to change/improve – Do the readings / discussion comments. It's literally one comment and will get you points for your final grades – It's really easy to do well in this course, as long as you put in the work for it! Be sure to stay engaged in lecture and group discussions – The final project is a really fun one, you get to be really creative with it!

course_title: Human Evolution, Human Health, and Climate Change 001
best_comment: This class is the most general GENED you can take, which definitely makes it out to be a lot. This class is barely any work during the semester, but the 40% cumulative final is definitely insane for a GENED. This class is going to be incredibly interesting for the first few weeks, but after the midterm gets to be incredibly repetitive and you often find yourself writing the same thing on the assignments. This GENED is definitely one of the nicer science GENEDs you can take – its really chill until you need to learn all of human evolution and climate change in two weeks. I would definitely recommend this class if you arent a STEM major; if you are a STEM major (especially bio) its an incredibly easy GENED and will cover things you learn in all your other classes so it gets to be redundant. For a humanities, or non bio major, I would definitely recommend this class cause it teaches you a lot of important things about your health and human evolution. TL; DR; NOT A GEM BUT ONE OF THE BETTER SCIENCE GENEDS – TAKE IF NOT A BIO MAJOR

course_title: Human Evolution, Human Health, and Climate Change 001
best_comment: This class is the most general GENED you can take, which definitely makes it out to be a lot. This class is barely any work during the semester, but the 40% cumulative final is definitely insane for a GENED. This class is going to be incredibly interesting for the first few weeks, but after the midterm gets to be incredibly repetitive and you often find yourself writing the same thing on the assignments. This GENED is definitely one of the nicer science GENEDs you can take – its really chill until you need to learn all of human evolution and climate change in two weeks. For a humanities, or non bio major, I would definitely recommend this class cause it teaches you a lot of important things about your health and human evolution. TL; DR; NOT A GEM BUT ONE OF THE BETTER SCIENCE GENEDS – TAKE IF NOT A BIO MAJOR

I DONT UNDERSTAND THE REASONING BEHIND BANNING LAPTOPS AND ELECTRONICS. I UNDERSTAND SOME TEACHERS ARE OLD–SCHOOL AND WANT EVERYONE TO USE PEN AND PENCIL FOR NOTES , OR DONT WANT ANY STUDENT LOOKING AT SOMETHING ELSE RATHER THAN LECTURE MATERIAL , BUT I THINK ITS IMPORTANT TO NOTE THAT MOST OF THE STUDENTS THAT  ARE  PRESENT THERE IN LECTURE IS BECAUSE THEY HAVE A REQUIREMENT TO CHECK OR ARE BLATANTLY JUST VERY INTERESTED IN THE SUBJECT MATTER AND WHAT IS GOING ON WITH THE WORLD POLITICALLY SPEAKING. JUST LET STUDENTS TAKE NOTES ON COMPUTERS OR LAPTOPS IF THEY WANT TO .  THE PSYCHOLOGICAL STUDIES THAT KEEP BEING MENTIONED BY TEACHERS AS TO WHY PEN AND PENCIL NOTES ARE BETTER ARE JUST STUDIES FROM A POOL OF PEOPLE AND A LIMITED TYPE OF LEARNING ABILITY AND DOES NOT, I REPEAT, DOES NOT REFLECT THE REST OF THE WORLD.....   I ALSO DONT UNDERSTAND THE REASONING BEHIND HAVING TUTORS AND TFs  WATCH YOU CONSTANTLY  DURING THE ENTIREEEE TIME DURING LECTURE TO MAKE SURE YOU HAVE ACCOMMODATIONS FOR AN ELECTRONIC DEVICE OR JUST WATCH YOU  LIKE IF YOU WERE IN PRE–SCHOOL AND JUST WAIT FOR YOU TO MESS UP OR SOMETHING..... . IVE NEVER HAD THIS EXPERIENCE AT HARVARD BEFORE, IT WAS VERY ODD. YOU CANNOT EVEN PAY ATTENTION TO THE LECTURE WHEN THE TUTORS ARE CONSTANTLYYYYYY  WATCHING YOU FROM BOTH SIDES OF THE LECTURE HALL. ITS VEEEEERRRY DISTURBINGGGG .  THERE WERE LIKE TWO TUTORS THAT WOULD CONSTANTLY CALL PEOPLE OUT DURING LECTURE AND QUESTION THEIR LAPTOP AND PHONE , EVEN IF STUDENTS WERE JUST CHECKING THEIR PHONE TO LOOK AT WHAT TIME IT WAS . THIS ONLY DISTRACTED EVERYONE ELSEEE IN LECTURE. LIKE  THE TUTORS WERE CRACKING DOWN ON SOME STUDENTS LIKE IF THEY WERE POLICE  OR SOMETHING . I TOOK THIS CLASS BECAUSE I HEAVILY CARE ABOUT POLITICS AND THE CONTENT BUT BEING IN THIS WEIRD MILITARY–LIKE COLLEGE SETTING IS NOT IDEAL AT ALLLLLLLLLLL.   THE IRONY IS THAT THE CLASS IS CALLED " WHAT IS A REPUBLIC" AND THE WHOLE LECTURE SETTING WAS DISTURBING AND NOT VERY REPUBLIC LIKE..... AS A STUDENT, I DONT BELIEVE IN COERCIVE MEASURES TO MAKE SURE SOMEONE IS PAYING ATTENTION  TO THE LECTURE. I CAME IN WITH SO MUCH ENTHUSIASM FOR THE SUBJECT AND LEFT DISTURBED BY THE TEACHING SETTING.  SECTION AND THE READINGS WAS THE ONLY GOOD THING ABOUT THIS CLASS . THERE ARE BETTER GOVERNMENT CLASSES OUT THERE FOR YOU. GOOD LUCK. I HOPE THIS CLASS GETS BETTER IN THE FUTURE. :(
worse_comment: Do not take this class. It is the WORST class you will likely ever take. They will publish a paper prompt and deadline less than a week before it is due,  and there is no information about assignment due dates or prompts beforehand on the syllabus or canvas. The teachers are all stuck up and refuse to actually teach you. Take this class if you like to get a letter grade taken off for using your computer in a 400 person lecture hall or if you like to get a 50 on an open–ended midterm where they look for a single word.  The professor is a rambling idiot. Worst class. Again. DONT TAKE
best_gem_comment: This class was a gem but it seems like they are starting to crack down on it. The lectures are a bit dry (coming from a STEM person, so take it with a grain of salt) so I'd only recommend this course if you are super interested in history and government.

course_title: Great Experiments that Changed Our World 001
best_comment: A good class for those with an interest in the history of science. Lots of hands–on projects which were the biggest highlight of the course (build a motor, make a microscope, etc.). After having spent a couple semesters in heavy science classes and research labs, this course definitely helped rekindle my love for science and how it can be taught in an accessible, interactive way for people from all backgrounds (STEM and non–STEM). However, psets definitely took some time to do (~1–2 hours), and readings were a little heavy at times. The final project was interesting and relatively fun, but did take up a significant amount of time and could have been run a lot smoother with better support from the staff. That being said, staff were always very friendly and supportive, and have a genuine interest in the material and your questions. If you are willing to put in the work on the weekly psets and the final project, and enjoy hands–on activities, this is a good gened for the science requirement.

Amazing class. Yes, less of a "gem". But it is simply a little more time consuming now – NOT more difficult. I think that is the key thing here: there are just a few more components to this class now, but they only check that you have an absolute basic baseline comprehension of what is going on. So long as you are making an effort below 0, it's perfect and you'll do amazingly. Most of the graded components are just following instructions and you'll get close to 100% on them! Super interesting course material and an easy yet SUPER enjoyable class that I am so grateful I took!!!! Katie McCullar is an AMAZING TF. IF YOU CAN CHOOSE HER, YOU WON'T REGRET IT. She is SO nice.
worse_comment: They have made this course significantly more difficult after the administration has cracked down on "gems." So, this is NOT a gem. This is a large amount of work for a gened (reading quizzes before every lecture, reflections on the readings every week, etc.) The final is 24 questions, all long answer response. I found this class to impact my sleep behaviors for the better. However, I wish they spent more time on the actual science behind sleep, and less on the negative consequences of sleep. For the second half of the class, it is just them telling you how sleep deficiency leads to obesity, high blood pressure, higher mortality, cancer, etc. and it can feel quiet depressing sometimes as a college student (who is in a moment of their life where they are probably most sleep deprived) to me learning all of this. Ironically, the semester I took this Sleep class, my sleep duration was the worst due to the highly challenging classes I was taking besides for this class. If you put in a lot of effort in this class, you can get an A because the material really is not that difficult. But do not expect this to be a class you can just sit and not pay attention in and do the bare minimum, and then you will get an A. You will be setting yourself up for disaster.
best_gem_comment: Amazing class. Yes, less of a "gem". But it is simply a little more time consuming now – NOT more difficult. I think that is the key thing here: there are just a few more components to this class now, but they only check that you have an absolute basic baseline comprehension of what is going on. So long as you are making an effort below 0, it's perfect and you'll do amazingly. Most of the graded components are just following instructions and you'll get close to 100% on them! Super interesting course material and an easy yet SUPER enjoyable class that I am so grateful I took!!!! Katie McCullar is an AMAZING TF. IF YOU CAN CHOOSE HER, YOU WON'T REGRET IT. She is SO nice.

best_comment: Prof. Yoda’s Anime GenEd was extraordinary. I learned so much not just about anime, but about arts and culture as a whole, especially through the lens of how we consume entertainment. Prof. Yoda knows what she’s talking about, and it shines through in every assignment and lecture she gives. The course materials are fun and engaging, the lectures and sections are great, the TFs are exceptional, and the class just goes above and beyond in all aspects. I especially loved the section component of the course—we all got really close in section, and our TF (Mari) was an awesome alternate perspective on what Prof. Yoda taught in class, and just an incredible teacher, mentor, and collaborator overall. This class was so good it helped inspire me to study abroad in Tokyo this upcoming summer, and all the TFs have been so helpful in my preparations. To make a long story short, if you need an Aesthetics and Culture GenEd and are at all curious about anime (I came in with very little experience with the medium), take this class!!!
worse_comment: This course is harder than you will expect and will demand a significant chunk of your time even while the subject, which could be taught in an interesting way, is unfortunately quite pedantic and repetitive. I would not recommend this course.

course_title: Evolving Morality: From Primordial Soup to Superintelligent Machines 001
best_comment: This class was INCREDIBLE. Josh is an amazing professor – he makes each lecture fascinating and he sparks really interesting conversations and questions with the audience (and ON THE SPOT counter–argues every single point – the man is a genius). The first class of my life that I have genuinely shown up excited for each and every time. Don't undervalue the first half of the course – it sets SUPER fascinating foundations in evolutionary biology and philosophy with regards to human morality. I wasn't sure what to expect from it (I was particularly excited for the second half involving AI), but I literally loved the first half too and found it so interesting. The papers are so reasonable and chill – not long at all, but you must be concise and therefore deliver your ideas clearly. With the right attitude, they are incredibly fun and honestly not so time consuming. Kat Angier is a phenomenal TF –  I absolutely loved her and she was super sweet and helpful. I highly recommend choosing her as your TF. TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! SO INTERESTING AND NOT SO INTENSE!!
worse_comment: Oh my – I hated this class, I shouldn't have taken it.
best_gem_comment: Really interesting actually and definitely a gem. Just go to lectures and listen – the conversations are pretty interesting and just from that and section you'll have a good enough understanding for the papers to get a good grade. Two midterm papers 1 final paper both really easy to write.

best_comment: This class can be very fun if you are interested in acting (or even if you've never thought about it but are willing to try). However, do be warned that it is a fair amount of work for a GenEd. Each week, we had to do a few things: watch a movie (~2 hrs), do readings that were often very complex to understand and philosophical (~3.5 hours), film a few videos or write a reflection, often both (~1 hr), and sometimes on top of that we had to hang out with our subject (~1hrs). So it was definitely time consuming and sometimes hard to keep track of all of these components. And the in–class quizzes were pretty difficult, open ended questions. Even doing all the readings, I would often not get them exactly right, although the grading was very lenient so they would give me full marks. On the other hand, I feel this course was very fun and a great way to meet people. The weekly workshops are super fun and through getting to know your subject and the person whose subject you are, you also get to create real bonds with people. By the end of the semester, our section had actually gotten pretty close.
worse_comment: This ended up being one of the most time–consuming courses in my course load, which seems extremely counterintuitive for a GENED. The readings are extremely dense, especially for those who don't have a philosophy background, and you watch a 2 hour film every week. You are then expected to recall extremely specific details from the readings for the weekly reading quizzes. The course is also extremely unorganized. Be warned that the final exam/performance is during reading period (and that there is a final paper), which was announced very late in the semester.  The head teaching staff are unaccommodating in general as well. Would not recommend this course.

best_comment: Decent gened– not a gem but manageable. I really enjoyed the content (in section, essays, and exams not so much in lecture). They were a bit anal about essay grading and the exams actually required a good bit of studying. Also they were VERY strict about attendance, like, excessively so, in both section and lecture. I had to get a doctors note from HUHS to miss a section when I had a bad cold which I feel like has been largely phased out because it overloads HUHS employees unnecessarily. Hopefully they relax the attendance policy a bit. But, section was awesome! You just debate topics in bioethics which is fun and very intellectually stimulating. I'd recommend this gened if you're interested in the content, but maybe look elsewhere otherwise :)
best_gem_comment: If you are interested in the topics covered, definitely take this class!! Section is actually interesting because you debate topics from class and get to learn how to argue different perspectives. This class isn't quite a gem, but my interest in the topic and its relevance more than made up for that. Steve genuinely cares––please go to his OH. My horizons were definitely broadened and I learned a lot about our understanding of the brain and how that can be applied to fields like the criminal justice system.

best_comment: Pretty chill course! Interesting material and live experiments in lecture are fun. Professor Sasselov is great.
worse_comment: Very disorganized class. There were times where I showed up to a section discussion and no TF even showed up or times where in the discussion we did not have the materials to complete worksheets. I also found that barely any of the material that was taught in lectures had anything to do with what we were being tested on.

course_title: What Is a Book? From the Clay Tablet to the Kindle 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!What an amazing Gened, and what great teaching staff. I'm a CS guy, and I don't really like books: this class was out of my comfort zone. But it was so engaging and informative. This is the transformative college experience they tell you about. This class was so well taught: the professor is so knowledgeable and engaging. There is one short writing assignment that you do before each lecture. The readings for this class are a bit lengthy, but you can get by with skimming them as they're not too difficult to understand. Section for this class is so engaging: you get to see and interact with so much of Harvard's campus.The final project was also incredibly flexible. You can combine your background with the things you learned in this class to challenge the idea of what a book is: I coded an immersive online book and it was so fun. Great way to top off the semester.The teaching staff is honestly amazing. I was in Deborah's section (couldn't recommend more), and you could tell that she cared so much about the content.All in all, great class. No complaints whatsoever. TLDR: Good workload, great teaching staff, interesting lectures, fun sections, awesome final project.

course_title: Pyramid Schemes: What Can Ancient Egyptian Civilization Teach Us? 001
best_comment: This is a highly underrated GENED. It was the only one that interested me in what's clearly the worst category of GENED (histories, societies, individuals–––so many uninteresting offerings). This class has a manageable workload and ancient Egypt is REALLY cool. This class is easy to succeed in letter–graded IF you are good at memorization. The exams really do require you to memorize an enormous amount of content, but it can be crammed pretty easily within a couple days.
