That's what I did at least and it worked out pretty well, but I also am good at memorizing things so mileage may vary. Honestly, the content is really cool and it will make you really want to visit Egypt and appreciate the insanely long and rich history of this civilization. The class is pretty well run with great fields trips to museums in section and interesting discussions about the context of the discoveries. I had a pretty positive experience and would take it again. The lectures did get a bit boring at times so I mostly learned content outside of lectures, but there were some interesting discussions that spawned from in class polls. The weekly Perusall readings and 2–sentence lecture responses sound a lot more annoying than they actually are. The workload really isn't so bad outside of preparing for the midterm and final exams.TLDR: It's an interesting course with a manageable workload, but does require a fair bit of memorization for exams. Very nice and enthusiastic course staff, cool museum components, and a unique offering in an otherwise bland GENED category
worse_comment: This is a class where you'll learn a lot as you prepare for the exams and through the field trips. Unfortunately, lectures can be a little dull and hard to follow at times; everything only really felt like it was 'coming together' at the end of the class

course_title: Prediction: The Past and Present of the Future 001
best_comment: I loved this gened. Genuinely a very very very good class, especially for not very sciency people who would still like to learn more about science (btw, not about a specific discipline) without worrying about the grade aspect of it. It is definitely a class where the professor and teaching team do care about the students, with a lot of attention spent on making a long (it does feel long) class more entertaining. We shot arrows around the rooms, navigated the yard without phones and comparing them with coordinates, looked in the telescopes, and much more. We also had snacks!!! And a small break. Like you can basically see in these details that the teaching staff is very–very into making this class as fun as possible. Loved it.

course_title: Human Trafficking, Slavery and Abolition in the Modern World 001
best_comment: This is an excellent course! Professor Patterson is truly a world–class academic and policy mind, and it was a true pleasure to learn from him. The course staff was accommodating and kind, as well. This course really gives you an important overview of a pressing issue in an accessible way. There are weekly discussion posts that are very manageable and keep you accountable to the material, a final paper, a midterm exam, and a final exam, all of which seemed very fair. This is definitely a great way to satisfy the GenEd requirements!
worse_comment: I would tell you not to take this class, but most people in it already know that and don't have a choice. If you have one, run. If you don't, be prepared for occasional moments of brilliance, and a lot of boring lectures, busy work, and general annoyance. The exam preparation can also be unnecessarily stressful because expectations are unclear. This course is not what it should be. Everyone cares, but it's just a complete mess. Expectations all–around are not clear and they care more about the appearance of GenEd "rigor" than actual learning, substance, and discussions. Sad to say this, but most of the class just feels like a waste of time. Good luck.

course_title: Power to the People: Black Power, Radical Feminism, and Gay Liberation 001
best_comment: This class is not difficult, but take it with caution.  Everyone is always on the hunt for a gem, but make sure you're genuinely interested in not just the content, but the kinds of conversations you will be having. For context, I'm a white straight woman who took the class. I will say my experience was not overly transformative. I've always been interested in activism, especially feminist activism. A lot of the time, though, I felt like a lot of conversations did not really require my perspective but I had to speak in section anyway for participation's sake. I found that the feminism module was a little bit diluted and heavily scrutinized in the class. However, the entire midterm paper did focus on it.The workload is not crazy. Weekly discussion post, midterm paper, final project. Do with the readings what you will. If you want to indulge for academic vitality's sake, definitely do that. If you don't have the time, don't stress. Major tips:– GO TO THE ARCHIVES EARLY. It takes a while to find materials that jump out at you when you're searching through so many boxes. The process is very foreign to me as a STEM concentrator (and most people in general) so make sure to give yourself some wiggle room and at least a solid hour to sit in the archives and flip through. I had to go twice since I ran out of time. I also waited until after spring break to go. Don't do that.– Go to lecture. They do take attendance and the Gened policy is strict.Final verdict: Take the class if (a) you are interested in activism AND want to discuss difficult topics in section and/or (b) you identify strongly with one of the three social movements. If you're just trying to fill the Aesthetics and Culture requirement, maybe explore some other options first.
worse_comment: Take the class! It is interesting, but if you do not enjoy readings, don't take it.

best_comment: This is a GREAT course—probably one of my favorites, if not the favorite learning experience I’ve had at Harvard. The no–computer policy really pays off—people are attentive and fully engaged in discussions, and Prof. Coleman knows exactly how to make the most of that dynamic. Be prepared to engage with deep, often difficult themes and to get emotional—I certainly did in many classes, which honestly was a wonderful experience to have at 9 aM! I felt like it set the tone for my day in a meaningful way (though I’ll admit it was sometimes hard to stay fully alert that early). Be ready to work with art, especially poetry—we read and analyzed a lot of poems. I loved that, but if you’re not a fan of poetry or aren’t open to learning how to appreciate it, I’d offer a gentle caution. That said, I struggled to understand poems before this course and now am leaving with a deep appreciation for them. Overall, BEAUTIFUL COURSE! Prof Coleman is so committed to it and it's inspiring to witness. Sections are super interesting too... just take it!!!!
worse_comment: Take this class! Beware that it is not a GENED with light work, as the readings, lecture, and sections each week take up a lot of time. However, the content covered will carry with you for years to come, and even after your time at Harvard. Grief and loss are incredibly challenging to teach and to understand, and this class does a fantastic job at doing just that.
best_gem_comment: I think Loss is definitely worth taking! I LOVE Professor Coleman—she cares so much about everyone in the class and obviously puts a lot of effort into the class. Section was great, and you go on a lot of fun field trips. It isn't necessarily a gem, but there are lots of opportunities to get graded, and if you put in the work it will be really rewarding and meaningful. Also, if you really hate classics, maybe don't take this.

course_title: Is the U.S. Civil War Still Being Fought? 001
best_comment: Awesome class, especially for a GenEd. Reading list is extensive, but the texts are interesting. The review sessions prepare you very well for the midterm and final. Sections were a highlight, and the material leads to some very thoughtful conversations. Professor Stauffer is wonderful. He truly wants students to do well in the course and meaningfully engage with the material. Especially if you have a humanities background, this is a great class for bringing in your other scholarly interests (ex: religion, race, literature, education, etc.) Super timely course to take right now, and your understanding of US history and politics will benefit greatly. Highly recommend!
worse_comment: This class unequivocally does not discuss in great detail the present political climate in the US; it does not teach you about how the Civil War impacts the US today; you will not discuss current events or spend a lot of time thinking about the current state of the union, so to speak. But you will learn a lot about slavery and the impact and meaning of the Civil War in 19th and early 20th–century America.

course_title: The Challenge of Human Induced Climate Change: Transitioning to a Post Fossil Fuel Future 001
best_comment: This is a fantastic class, and I would highly recommend it if you are at all interested in climate change. I had very little knowledge about the mechanics of climate change, but I feel like I have left this class with a strong understanding of how climate change works. I took this to fulfill the science and technology gened requirement, and could not recommend it more as a way to fulfill this category, or as an elective. Professor McElroy is a leader in the field, and it is incredible to be able to learn from him. The rest of the teaching team is fantastic as well. The assignments are very manageable, and you have plenty of time to complete them.
worse_comment: This class was so disorganized and I didn't learn much at all.  The prof and section leaders droned on and did not engage with students.

best_comment: There's a qguide review from Fall 2022 that was super long and listed a lot of concerns with the course. After taking the class, I agree with that review in its entirety – I would recommend going back to read that review, as that student explains the issues better than I do. To reiterate some points and to contribute my own experience:1) lack of diversity of opinion. All of the texts and the lectures effectively drilled in one viewpoint: borders are bad, and all the solutions we've tried so far to make it better are also bad. We especially bash on nationalism and vaguely suggest that imperialism was better. It seems like the takeaway is that humanity should all embrace each other as brothers in arms and magic away all the borders, with little to nothing about the real logistics of this.  Classmates have expressed to me that they don't feel comfortable raising their hands in class to ask about realistic/logistical issues with reducing borders, because it runs contrary to the messaging of the class.2) the assignments don't teach you to think. There's a midterm where the entire point is to word vomit everything you can remember the professor saying in one specific lecture. There's a memo you have to write using only the sources they give you, with little to no context and without being able to search up anything yourself, "because it's realistic", so you end up sort of summarizing and rephrasing what the sources say with no new synthesis or insight of the information. The point of this assignment is apparently to realize that if we were the colonizer, we would also have made the same terrible biased decisions. The final project is a podcast and it has to be 5 minutes long. This is at best 750 words. This project feels like it's encouraging us to do a cursory investigation into a random border, and then to create a short, quick, easily digestible product spouting a clear, un–nuanced argument for popular consumption. Sure, maybe "real change is done by podcast episodes" (?????), but I personally feel that as a course, it would be much more of an engaging and intellectual exercise for us to just write a paper, where we can fully engage with all the gray areas. It's lowkey harder to learn how to edit sound, than to do the research and form an argument for this.3) no historical cohesion. The syllabus jumps all over the place (U.S. to Europe to Asia, etc.), with vanishingly little historical context. We go to section and we're expected to have an intelligent conversation about these borders while knowing nothing about the history of the peoples who lived there or primary sources from them. I'm a STEM major and the last time I thought about the Samoan experience under the League of Nations was never. Understandably, everyone just lands on the same, ground–breaking argument: although Samoans aren't white, they're people too, and should be treated as such. This is about how deep the discussion gets across the course.4) my enjoyment of this class was genuinely reduced by the professor's management of the lectures and her passion for speaking. Every time we play a video or open the presentation or something, the entire lecture needs to be put on pause while we hear about the step–by–step procedure of opening a browser window. Meanwhile, although the guest lectures are excellent and delivered by professors knowledgeable in the field, the Q&A section is a bit odd. We're asked to submit questions the night before, and then the professor reads them out loud herself. One time, she said "I'm just going to read ALL of these out loud and then you can pick one to answer", and then the guest professor stood there and we all sat there while she rattled off a whole list of questions. Another time, she distributed index cards and suggested that anyone too shy to raise their hands could write the questions down there instead.  At the beginning of the Q&A section, she walked around the class verbally asking each table if there were any index cards for her to collect (there were none), requiring us all to sit and wait for her to walk around the entire classroom narrating her journey rather than allowing us to start asking questions while she checked.The silver lining: You don't really need to do the reading. The readings assigned are always super long and complex, but we don't actually unpack any of it. In section you might be expected to discuss it with a partner and the TF might walk around, but it's nothing a general skim and maybe a closer reading of the intro/conclusion won't solve. It's not the worst class to take if you just need to knock out a gened requirement and have a great deal of patience.
worse_comment: One of the WORST classes I've ever taken here. The lectures are so hard to follow, and the topics discussed in class have no logical relation to one another. The professor does not provide any substantial commentary on the border issue nor does she do a good job at facilitating discussion. The class feels like a bunch of meaningless tasks for the sake of having something to do and no lectures. Do not come into this course expecting to have any historical context provided for the borders discussed and do not expect the readings to be discussed in section. The midterm and final project are fair and not too much work. However, the professor's lecture are so inadequate, and sections are so not productive for talking about the course material. Definite pass for me!

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! I am a freshman studying either ESPP or IB (ecology), and I found this course super super interesting! The professor is easy to listen to, TFs are available for help, and the course work is very very manageable. That being said, you should still LISTEN TO THE LECTURES! I did minimal studying for the exam compared to other peers because I had detailed lecture notes that I could look back on. Also, the exam review sessions and practice exams are super super helpful! Readings are recommended by the course instructors, but honestly I did not do any and I was totally fine–– but if you want background they might be helpful. My only advice is to start assignments EARLY!! They are not difficult, but doing them last minute (like I did) is not a good move–– start early and get help from TFs, the work should be super easy to manage with help! This class is super super interesting, I absolutely recommend!
worse_comment: This course was disappointing in what it covered. It portrayed itself to be at the intersection of current events, historical uses, and science of water. I found that instead most of the lectures talked about how thermometers worked, a control volume, and sometimes scientific concepts about the water cycle. I think on my end it was just a let down of what was expected.
best_gem_comment: This course is definitely a gem. The professor as well as the TFs are all super nice, especially Chloe. You can get away with not reading but the readings are really important for the midterm. In terms of assignments, you have a short discussion post every week. Throughout the semester, you also have 3 event analyses (2 pages single–spaced each), an art analysis (2 pages single–spaced), and a final project.

best_comment: This class is a great introduction to the art and culture of the middle ages! It's not a course on medieval history, although that is touched on heavily throughout, but rather focuses on the materiality and literature of the time. As a result, the readings are compelling, the assignments are interesting, and the lectures are wonderfully detailed and enthusiastic.In general Prof. Smail is an amazing lecturer, and he really encourages student participation and engagement. The course TFs as well – Andy Chen and Angela Zhang – are awesome, and in talking with them, you get the feeling that they care deeply about their students.This class isn't a "gem" or whatever people call it, but it's not overwhelming, and is a great A&C gened imo!

course_title: The English Language Today, Yesterday, and Tomorrow 001
best_comment: first of all, i am an english concentrator (this class double counts), so i think i probably would enjoy this class more than most really in and of itself. however, i also knew my tf and the professor beforehand (and i adore them both), so i guess take my review with a grain of salt or whatever. content–wise, this class is awesome. it can be pretty stressful when you're trying to remember the third–person feminine genitive singular pronoun, or when you're having to recall the ipa chart in your mind and remember whether a letter is alveopalatal or palatal, and there are a billion tiny things to remember with dates and dictionaries and the diphthongs that also undergo vowel shifts (i sometimes felt like i was losing my mind a tiny bit), but at the end of the day, i feel quite fulfilled with this class. being able to look at something written in old english and understanding even one or two words or pronouns is a large and tangible change from the version of me that existed before i took this class, and that is so incredible. i dont know how to describe how cool that feeling is.but of course, if you dont really care about that, then honestly, this class is quite a bit of work. if you are in one of the years that can still p/f geneds, then you can definitely get by with doing minimal work since they dont check homework, but if you're taking the class for a letter grade, you will be doing a ton of studying. the average for the midterm was in the seventies, and i dont know what the final will be –– though they did say that people tend to do better on the final. in any case, this is probably not what you would consider a gem.however, the teaching staff are the most wonderful people on this planet. daniel donoghue is my icon, emily is the most incredible tf to ever walk this planet (and also probably the best person ever), and sam p is the absolute nicest. at least in my section, people were OUTWARDLY mean to my tf, so if you end up taking this class, then okay yeah sure it might be a little bit disorganized sometimes and sometimes the homeworks won't make much sense, but please dont be a jerk. i feel like i shouldnt have to write this because this is just general human decency, but apparently, some people cant find it in themselves to be nice to others. anyway, teaching staff? top–tier. dont be mean to them. tl;dr if you take it for a letter grade, be a bit prepared for more work. p/f you should be fine! a little disorganized sometimes and all that, but overall a great course, TONS to learn, and the absolute most incredible teaching staff. much love
worse_comment: This is my least favorite class I’ve taken at Harvard as a graduating senior. Generally I was upset at the general education department because I had exactly 2 options for which course to take for the HSI requirement. However, I also had to spend many many hours memorizing information that I didn’t find that interesting (old English inflections, 30+ English history dates) and doing really stupid busywork for section that was only sometimes checked (and of which, my TF openly would decide didn’t seem that relevant to what we “had” to know). It is a shame to me that what little interest I had for English linguistics was pretty quickly squashed by the inordinate amount of information shoved down my throat (and forced to stay there by memorization–heavy exams and section checks). I would say just to complete each week’s assignments, even poorly done, would take at least 8 hours, and then most of it wouldn’t matter anyway. Lectures sometimes also dragged because the professor wanted to demonstrate his old English pronunciation 3–4 times for some scarcely understandable poem.

course_title: Worlds Beyond: The Past, Present and Future of Our Solar System 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE. If your interested in space, you will love this course. You cover lots of different complex topics, but Robin makes them very easy to understand. Robin is also great! His lectures are very engaging and he clearly enjoys teaching. The TFs are also all great.
best_gem_comment: This class is a gem; it's low stress but allows a great opportunity to learn about outerspace and discuss these interesting topics!

course_title: Rise of the Machines? Understanding and Using Generative AI 001
best_comment: If you’re looking for a gened to fulfill your science and technology in society requirement, take this class! It was a wonderfully paced class that really made great use of all the class time and homework assignments each week to teach you about how to use and apply generative AI tools. I really enjoyed the lectures, assignments, and readings and thought that they were all well designed and picked with care to help you build an understanding from the ground up in an accessible way no matter what your background was. There were many interesting guest lecturers throughout the course that offered unique perspectives from academic and industry points of view. You have a lot of creative freedom to explore and challenge yourself with GAI tools for many of the assignments and the course staff would happily meet you halfway to help you achieve your goals for your final project. It was a great class that didn’t feel like it was wasting your time with busy work; every assignment felt meaningful while also managing to be low stress and often open–ended. You can definitely learn a lot and get a lot out of this class. Personally, I felt that it taught me how to use GAI tools in much more creative ways than I thought it could be used, and as the tools continue to evolve, I think it’s a fantastic course to take to get a baseline understanding for how AI might shape the future.
best_gem_comment: GEM!!!! so so so much fun and really easy workload. even the final project and exam felt definitely not as difficult as other classes' finals. overall had a lot of fun in lecture, section, and outside of class experimenting with AI. I really loved this class, probably one of my favorites.

course_title: U.S. K-12 Schools: Assumptions, Binaries, and Controversies 001
best_comment: Fret not the 9am!! Although the class may seem long, it is very interactive. The class never bored or dragged. Every morning, I was grateful that I rolled out of bed to go to the best class on campus. The classroom environment was so welcoming! Names and labels are powerful, which was reflected in the way we approached our topics. I think, because the course explicitly opens itself up for "Assumptions, Binaries, and Controversies", we were not afraid to explore other points of view or the unknown. The A, B, Cs were the perfect way to acknowledge our own biases and show that we can always go an "and" route instead of "or".The teaching staff is absolutely amazing! This team has completely changed the way I thought collegiate learning had to be done. Everyone has personality, is passionate, light–heartedly disagrees, and welcomes questions. The book club week is an opportunity to chat with a TF about a book that interested themBonus: Sometimes, we had special guest appearance from THEE Ms. Heaven Joy, the very opinionated, canine student of GENED 1189.
worse_comment: if you're looking for an easy ethics, this one is okay, but not the best. this class is incredibly tf dependent–– my tf angelique was the absolute sweetest, but some of my friends' tfs were not the best. grading varied wildly depending on which section you were in. 9am lecture is also brutal. this class is okay i guess, just be careful.
best_gem_comment: This class is a gem! Even if you aren't already interested in education, the teaching staff's passion is infectious –– this class will make you want to take a greater interest in K–12 education! Keep up with the readings and your attendance (it's hard, lecture is at 9 AM, but worth it) and you will get a lot out of the class.

course_title: Philanthropy, Nonprofits, and the Social Good 001
best_comment: Take this class. It really isn't as bad as the syllabus makes it out to be. You don't need any prior experience; just the motivation to partake in a venture and a nonprofit. You will need to work in a group, and these people will be from your section, so don't expect to work with your best friend.Firstly, do some of the readings. Don't need to read all of them but have some readings where you can ask a great analytical question. You will end up doing FIVE of these for a semester, which is a short paragraph about your question towards the author. Secondly, decide whether your group wants to work together both on the nonprofit or venture, or you can separate each other into either group. You will do a paper on a venture idea or a nonprofit. You will randomly select a topic from a drawing hat, so you will have no control over your topic. For us, we got literacy intervention, so we focused on intervening for children in struggling municipalities.For nonprofit, you will reach out to multiple nonprofits and select one to represent for your final presentation. You will do extensive research and interview the team members about their nonprofit structure, finances, mission, etc. From there, when finals arrive, you will pitch your nonprofit and whoever receives the most votes gets the largest grant prize out of everyone. First place gets $25,000 from the Philanthropy Lab. For the venture side, you will design your own nonprofit in which you do market research (not too complex), competition, costs and projections, and even interview stakeholders. You will be expected to run a survey or experiment to verify the effectiveness of your venture. You can design anything, even an app. The winning venture team receives a small grant of $700 to get started on the venture which can pursued post–class. Overall take this course if philanthropy interests you. Professor Dromi is very great and engaging! This course will require a bit of work but it isn't as bad as it seems because it is a semester–long project.
worse_comment: It is an easy course, but be weary of the final paper. It is worth a LARGE portion of your grade and is 10–pages, so it all kind of hits at once at the end of the semester to an otherwise extremely light semester. It balances it out, to most people, but if you are already anticipating a heavy plethora of final exams and papers, maybe this isn't the best course.

course_title: Philosophy of Technology: From Marx and Heidegger to Artificial Intelligence 001
best_comment: this class was super fun and there's not many good geneds anymore but this was one was great. professor Risse is super engaging and my section made the class awesome. Never had a better section at Harvard honestly.  I love how applicable it is to the real world of technology and how we could express thoughts/concerns about the future of tech and AI versus humanity. I think lectures can sometimes be a little boring but the content and section portion were quite enjoyable. super low amount of work: 12 discussion posts and 3 papers
worse_comment: This class is okay. It is a bit frustrating at times to hear very ridiculous takes on technology and basic human decency. The professor approaches this class well. There are a lot of subjects squished into a semester so it is sometimes overwhelming. The professor is a bit rude sometimes. He says he is German and laughs off his rudeness, but I do not want to see my professor mad and have an attitude towards the cameramen doing him a favor.

course_title: Eating Culture: Past, Present, and Future 001
best_comment: Professor Nagy is such a great storyteller. He keeps things entertaining and says some really unexpected things sometimes. Class is never a bore with him. He might go on a short tangent, but he has a lesson plan that he gets through in less time than the 75 minutes, and that is why we have these really good snacks before class and he releases us early too! The snacks that he brings for the entire class are really good. My favorite were the ube flavored things, ice cream, mango lassi, and malted eggs. There were others like stinky tofu, matzo unleavened bread, dates, dove bread, crackers, goat milk, soy milk, etc... He actually uses his own money to get us these snacks!! I feel extremely grateful that there is a professor here who enjoys the class they are teaching the way Professor Nagy enjoys teaching. His love for this topic shines. You can just see it in the way he presents the topics. He discusses the different relations food has with history, religion, commerce, societal norms, etc... in a way you don't expect. There is a heavy focus on etymology of foods. He juggles fun entertainment representation of food and topics that food has a connection with, such as hospitality. I didn't expect to watch bollywood, dracula, johnny appleseed, and teen titan clips in this class, but here we are! He brings back movies from the old days to show. Professor Nagy is extremely excellent at grabbing our attention. I also love the speakers that get invited to speak. They bring different perspectives to food that Professor Nagy talks about. I especially like the speaker who were an advertising expert and the speaker who spoke on unsustainable agricultural farming. The speaker on noodles was entertaining, and there was also a food writer, not to mention the course's TF's that took turns presenting on their topics of interest. Assignment–wise, homework is non existent in this class except for the occasional section assignment which takes 30 minutes to complete. Assigned readings were hefty at the beginning of the class, but it was a little bit less towards the end of the course. Everything is chill in this course except, this GENED had in total 5 essays to complete. 2 for each midterm/final, and a research paper. It was kind of strange that the final exam, which has 2 essays, was due 4 days before the research paper, but also, we knew about the research paper for awhile, and Professor Nagy gives us over a week to do the take home 2 essays. So, while strange, it is not a tall task. Just manage your time well, incorporate things in lecture and readings, and you will surely get a good grade. The midterm had 14 essay prompts, if people can't choose two, I don't know what they were doing. You could truly write about anything food related. The final was a little bit harder because it was argumentative based, and there were only a few prompts. Additionally, I want to mention that this class has a large focus on incorporating your own experiences with food into the writing. That means, you could just be introspective with some of your writing with some sprinkle of assigned reading evidence, and that's passable. Grading is based on your TF, and all of this class's TFs are truly very understandable across all sections and are chill as so I have heard. I think if Professor Nagy teaches this course again, he may not be able to get the same TFs, in which case, grading might change, but truly this group of TFs was immaculate.I have Molly. Best TF ever! Molly truly made section an interactive experience. So many sections I have had at Harvard, I leave the semester without knowing my peers' names, but Molly makes an active effort in getting everyone to participate and enjoy each other's work. I love the exercise where we worked with model magic and also when we had to create out own advertisements. She brings snacks as well to section, kinder, dried fish, etc...
worse_comment: This course is not worthy of the Harvard name. This course has no concrete guiding themes. Lectures feel like a ramble and it is difficult to know what to take away. Lecture topics are surface level, which is disappointing because I think the subject matter of this course could lend itself to a very interesting gened. This course convinced me that geneds are a waste of students' times. Take this course only if you need filler or if you need to complete the art and aesthetics requirement (and find nothing else remotely interesting). This is a disappointing course.
best_gem_comment: This is a gem for sure. Definitely a fun and very interesting class and assignments aren’t hard

course_title: Grimm's Fairy Tales: Echoes of the Past, Reflections of the Present 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE RIGHT NOW! This class will surprise you by how deep it gets into societal implications and more abstract themes, but it is one of my favorite and one of the most fun courses I have taken at Harvard. Prof. Pirozhenko cares SO MUCH about her students and is the kindest professor I've had. The TFs are super dedicated, too. Lectures are always fun and engaging in multimedia ways, and the only "drawback" (if any) for the course was that you actually need to study for the midterm since you'll need to memorize fairy tale plots (and honestly, the tales you read are super fun so that's not even a downside). Besides that, it was very chill and low effort, but you could also get as much out as you put in. Bonus, we went to see the live–action Snow White in theaters!! Big fan of this course :)
best_gem_comment: The class is a great way to close the aesthetics gened. Reading the fairy tales is super fun, and they are very useful when you can put them in a cultural, historical, and social context in class. Professor Pirozhenko's lectures can seem a little bit dry as she mainly just reads off the script, but she puts a lot of effort into engaging students with the material in the classroom and facilitates a lot of discussion. She also very clearly cares about the class and its content, making her a great professor for this class overall. Bastian is a gem of a TF; you will be so lucky if you get into his section. I unironically was running to his section every week as it was super engaging and fun. Every section hour flew by really quickly. Overall, the class is very interesting, especially if you have time to put into it. The assignments are super introspective, and you will get a lot out of them if you decide to put effort into them.

best_comment: I highly recommend this course. I took it as a second semester senior with a desire to try something new, and I absolutely loved it. It requires a good amount of time and commitment to language learning outside the classroom, but the teachers are so lovely and supportive, and I learnt so much in such a short period of time.  Professor Chip is just incredible. He is so engaging, makes sure that everyone is included, and challenges us constantly to improve our German. He teaches us a lot about German culture too, which adds so much texture to our learning. He also takes such an interest in our lives, such that our German becomes authentic, true, and un–formulaic. Take this course :)

Take this class! I am a Computer Science concentrator, and I spoke some German beforehand through cultural interest and a long streak on Duolingo, lol. I kept putting off taking German, because I thought the intensive classes would be too much because of the daily attendance and the pace of the regular ones was too slow. So glad I ended up taking German 10ab! The people in my section were friendly, and we had some lively discussions about all sorts of things. Our professor, Sina, is the kindest and most supportive instructor I met since coming to Harvard. She put in effort to make sure we understood all the material well, but there was still room left for self–learning, which I value a lot. I will definitely be taking more German courses at Harvard!

This course delved deeply into the grammatical intricacies of the German language, and I also greatly appreciate the incorporation of notable German–language texts throughout this course (Kafka, Goethe). The writing assignments in the course were definitely beneficial to my grasp of difficult grammatical structures, and I am extremely happy with the method of instruction and pace of the course. This course changed my understanding of the grammatical structures of the German language by contributing new information that allowed me to compose more complex thoughts.
worse_comment: This is not an easy language req. Requires lots of work and not always fair with grading.

best_comment: This course is a lot of work, but worth it and an amazing way to get to feel more comfortable with German. The class is challenging and I would say that spending time on homework is important to come prepared, which means that you're doing something every day of the week to prepare. Christina is a wonderful teacher, she never gave up on making people engage even when they were unsure and kept the activities varied and interesting.
if you love working with kids this is a great class to take. Dr Parkes is amazing and cultivates a great classroom environment, and you get to inspire young students to learn German.

course_title: Introduction to German Literature, History, and Thought 1
best_comment: Very chill way to get to study German literature, history and thought systematically! It was extremely helpful to read everything with a historical understanding and to see how thoughts evolved through time. The course materials were interesting and encompassed lots of different media. And the essays are not too taxing. If there's anything, I think I would prefer to have more of a discussion in class, as well as perhaps one or two longer papers to explore my interest as opposed to three 1500 words essay, which is a bit short to actually delve into anything.

Wonderful course! Professor Dymek is brilliant and fosters a refreshing environment of original thinking and openness. It is quite abstract by nature, as it builds off of Kant's transcendental idealism so be prepared for a new way of thinking and discussing.

A seminar like no other––keep in mind this section was taught entirely in German and felt like a rigorous humanities course in a German university. It is difficult? Of course. But all you should focus on is getting as much out of the material as possible. I certainly did not understand all of the concepts we discussed––our wonderful lecturer, Anne, didn't either! That's part of the joy of the section. We all truly wanted to be there and would not rather be in any other place, and the enthusiasm really showed. I haven't written my final project yet, but I know there's so much content I can use that we've learned that I want to include in it. I am so excited for that culmination of the course. As a side note, if you can ever take a class with Anne, please do––it's unlike anything else you've ever learned. She has such an eccentric, unique style that makes every section a true delight. There's so many stories of her life you can try to tease out of her, from her stay in Afghanistan to her time at the Sorbonne.

The amount of reading is not light by any means, but it does get easier to do over time. Your German reading skills will improve tremendously, and you will be prepared to read most any text, old or new. Overall, I'd really recommend this class — you get to choose which weeks you have a writing assignment due, so you can build a schedule that works for you, and the discussions are really edifying.

Professor Dymek is an amazing lecturer with a profound understanding of all the theoretical film texts she discusses in class. Pay attention in class and absorb her analysis like a sponge because her conceptual breakdowns of various theorists like Freud, Butler, and Laplanche, etc. help you parse out rather complex and dense texts and ideas you read about beforehand. She is incredibly intelligent and passionate about what she teaches, and you cannot help but be inspired to write, create, and have honest conversations about queerness and social constructions of various kinds, including gender and sexual repression/freedom. Take this class even if you are not queer, and maybe even especially if you are not queer!! There is so much to explore about why we act the way we do due to intrinsic natural factors or environmental ones. I went into this class with rather concrete ideas of queerness and social operation in my head, but came out with certain beliefs I've had challenged or reconstructed. She makes sure to ground her ideas in theoretical texts, and the film repertoire alone is a reason to take this class! Every film is carefully chosen, and if you are aspiring to be a screenwriter, or filmmaker, this class is also for you. There is so much to learn from the directors of the films we watched: their choices for different shots, the mise–en–scene, etc. Professor Dymek also discusses these choices and their affects in class. There was no section, so it's weekly recurring and that is also just such a plus if you have an otherwise pretty packed schedule. All in all, take this to be inspired by Professor Dymek — she's awesome and by the end of class you will be inspired to go out there in the world and make change –– to tell new stories and share new perspectives. Even for final projects, she's receptive to different ones: the classic essay format, or you can write a script and/or make a film and accompany it with a shorter essay –– of varying lengths depending on what you choose. She's accommodating because at the end of the day she wants to encourage her students to put things out there for the world to see (for example, publish a paper or post a short film on YT), and in my humble opinion that is what Harvard professors ought to do more of.  She also makes herself available and will also support you throughout your process at every step of the way!!
worse_comment: Interesting ish class. The Professor is very kind, but discussions were confusing and all over the place. Workload was very reasonable though. If you're into weird movies, this is the class for you.

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!! Professor Hamilton is the definition of a compelling lecturer – his expansive and intricate knowledge of this topic specifically made this class such a gift to take. I left every lecture feeling as if I'd gotten closer to the meaning of life, and energized about what it means to be a student. Specifically, Professor H's lecture notes are so carefully crafted and truly a huge treasure to have the chance to interact with as a student of this course. The side notes on the board of words in Latin, Greek, French, and more now populate my well–loved notebook from this course. As a lover of literature and a classical singer I can say with certainty that this class was formative to my life as an academic as well as artist. I hope this course will continue in the years to come – I would even come to audit it again because of how comprehensive and dense the literature is (in the best way!) – and that the humanities/german department will continue to generate and support classes about the role of music in literature, in addition to the rich canon of literature about musical genius. If you are a true academic, take this course – it feels like a graduate seminar simultaneously in Classics/Greek/Philosophy/Music/German/English and more which makes it truly a special experience to participate in. :)
best_gem_comment: Can't recommend this enough! I joined late because I was figuring out my schedule and I was instantly glad I joined after the first lecture. Hamilton is an amazing lecturer and we need more lecturers like him! This class is a gem. I highly recommend engaging with the materials and showing up to lectures ready to soak it in because every week was a roller coaster in the best way possible. You can tell he's so passionate about what he teaches and it's awesome

course_title: Artificial Intelligences: Body, Art, and Technology in Modern Germany 1
best_comment: I think the way I described this course most to my friends was: weird. But I mean that in a good way. We talked about a broad range of topics and artists which was cool and challenging, and usually quite enjoyable. A lot of the material is performance or visual art like photographs, so that made the assigned content fun, but there was also a lot of dry reading which you should probably spend some time with (although I definitely didn't comprehend a lot of it). There's enough range in the subject matter that you can still participate in class without having a solid grip on the readings. You don't need any German background to take this course, although it can be nice if you want to connect more deeply with the German artists. The class also attracts a wide range of concentrations, so it's cool to take a small course with such a diverse group of scholars. Professor Stewart is extremely passionate about the subject matter and does a good job of facilitating discussion and encouraging everyone's ideas.

course_title: One Hundred Years of Scandinavian Cinema 1
best_comment: This is an awesome class. We watch scandinavian films together and then have revealing discussions about them. I really enjoyed seeing films I probably wouldn't have watched otherwise, and getting large takeaways from them (for example, Phantom Carriage, The Seventh Seal, Persona, Insomnia, Joan of Arc). The discussions were very comfortable, and it was clear that everyone found the films interesting, as we rarely ran out of things to say. I like how the course culminated with the opportunity to create a film of our own. The small size of the course creates a community where people are very comfortable talking to each other and sharing ideas.
worse_comment: Midterm graded very hard and with the high percentage of the overall grade it is not very easy to get a good grade in this class. If you take it p/f though it is very chill

best_comment: Tonje is a wonderful teacher who clearly cares deeply about her students. She wants you to succeed and will help in whatever way possible to ensure you are getting exactly what you need from the course.

This course is fantastic! Professor Broome is phenomenal! This is exactly how a language course should be taught. I had 4 years of Spanish in high school but sadly didn't have AP Spanish and so couldn't test out of Harvard's language requirement. I've always had an interest in traveling to Sweden though and had heard that this was a great course. If you take it, I can almost guarantee the following: you will learn a shocking amount in just a short time and you will have a great time  doing so – despite the 9AM time slot! Professor Broome is engaging, funny, brilliant, patient, and doesn't judge when you might be having trouble grasping some of the tougher aspects of the Swedish language. The exams are tough but fair (study hard for a few days, not just the night before and be sure to stay up on the vocabulary). The creative project as a final exam is a great low stress (but high effort, learning intensive) way to finish off the semester. Highly recommend!! Definitely a highlight of my time so far at Harvard.

course_title: Maternal & Reproductive Health and Health Policy 001
best_comment: One of the best courses I've taken ever! We learned a lot of maternal health in terms of global health and health policy. Jessica is a great lecturer and kept things interesting by bringing in amazing guest speakers from many different fields from OBs to Health Ministers from Sierra Leone to researchers from the Public Health School, they were so relevant and fascinating to hear from. Readings each week are very manageable, very interesting and actually helps for lecture the next day. Three assignments overall, which are pretty chill and Marema (TF) will help you if you ever have questions. I highly recommend this course, it was such a fun time!

course_title: Humanitarian Response to Conflict and Disasters 001
best_comment: AMAZING CLASS!!! This class was such a unique environment where you are surrounded by people from all walks of life who share a common interest in humanitarian aid and learning about the strenghts/weaknesses of these systems. Dr. VanRooyen, Matt Jelacic, and Dr. Michelle Gonnet Gonzalez showed genuine curiosity for our interests and goals, and made sure to format the class in a way that fulfilled the whole class's interests. They are extremely well connected in the humanitarian field and care about their students well–being first and foremost. I took this class because I knew I wanted to work in the humanitarian sector and this sentiment was very apparent throughout the rest of my classmates. Short responses and readings were very manageable. The group projects were great. I appreciated having the opportunity to get to know my classmates better outside of class and all of the presentations are amazing since they are all on different world issues. My only complaint was that it was difficult to prepare for the in–class quizzes since the slides were not regularly posted and they really push for discussion over note–taking in class. I also would've appreciated small–group brainstorming sessions throughout lectures since this class attracts such varying perspectives and background education that you learn a lot very quickly from discussion with your peers. This was by far my favorite class that I have taken for Harvard and it's the first time I felt a class was actively preparing me for my career aspirations. I couldn't recommend this class more!

course_title: Research in Global Health and Health Policy 001
best_comment: AMAZING class!!! excellent way to cap off the GHHP secondary

course_title: Research in Global Health and Health Policy 002
best_comment: This course is a great way to fulfill the GHHP research requirement. I quite enjoyed the cadence of the assignments –– effectively prepared students for writing the final paper. Becca's section was great –– very thorough feedback and great discussion in class
worse_comment: This is an incredible class to delve deep into a global health topic of your choosing for an entire semester. I highly suggest picking a topic you are very passionate about because you'll spend the entire semester researching it, so you'll end up learning a lot on your topic. For classmates who aren't very interested in their topics, it can get boring and dull throughout the semester.

course_title: Research in Global Health and Health Policy 003
best_comment: THIS CLASS IS AWESOME ESPECIALLY WHEN TAKEN WITH JOSEPH HNATH AS A TUTOR. HE IS VERY KNOWLEDGEABLE AND WILL HELP YOU WRITE A GREAT POLICY PAPER!! :)

course_title: Research in Global Health and Health Policy 004
best_comment: Overall a great course and a cool way to dive into a topic and learn more. Grading is just very TF dependent, so I would try and get to know your TF well.

Without question, GOV 10 was one of the best courses I have taken while at Harvard.While readings were sometimes dense, theory isn't something that you should just skim over. It should be digested meticulously and internally debated. Therefore, this sometimes made doing the weekly readings/Perusall assignments take longer than some may like, but it's ultimately 100% worth it and will pay off when you exit the course with a rich, newfound understanding of the world.In my personal opinion, theory is one of those topics where some just "get" it while others may have to work a little harder. I absolutely fell into the latter, particularly due to not having any prior experience with theory or philosophy. However, the course is set up in a way that allows everyone to grow, fulfill their true potential, and eventually exceed the standards.Both section leaders were absolutely amazing, and a specific shoutout to Savannah for hosting sections that always propagated unique debates (side note: taking this class during the onset of AI is a once–in–a–lifetime opportunity).I left every single lecture and section thinking to myself, "Wow. I'm surrounded by some of the most amazing minds in the world." There are several classes I've taken at Harvard that I believe truly feel changed my life, but this one takes the cake, by far.

While this class is organized very poorly, it's a great introductory government class. Chaudoin loves what he does, making his lectures engaging and interactive. Definitely a lighter workload (1–2 readings per class), however homework assignments ramp up out of the blue toward the end of the semester. There's no midterm or final, however there are two tests that feel like such. Make sure to study hard for these, they're weighted heavily. The section component is helpful in maintaining the material taught in lecture, however involves a lot of active participation. Lastly, be patient in trying to find where the readings are/where you're supposed to submit homework... the Canvas page is a mess lol. Have fun!
worse_comment: This class is not what I expected it to be. Yes, we talked about wars, but the focus was more on models, theories, and predictions than the actual wars and conflicts between states.

best_comment: The first few weeks may feel overwhelming, but it really gets better. It is a challenging course if you don't have a strong quantitative background, but there is a lot of support available. I came out of the course with stronger quantitative skills, I highly recommend it if this is something you want to work on.
worse_comment: Personally did not enjoy this class. PSETs and midterms were centered around coding but lectures and sections were quite conceptual so there was a disconnect which made working on the PSET quite difficult. My TF was not helpful when it came to questions (related to lecture material) and whenever I asked I usually got a roundabout response that did not directly answer the question and I had to figure it out on my own. I began going to other TFs for help because I felt unsupported in my section. The feedback process throughout this course is very weak. We spent a month on a final project with four check–in points but only received feedback on the first draft (which was due a week before the final and consisted of a sentence). The grade on my final project came with no feedback whatsoever. It's not the hardest material to get a handle of but there was not a lot of support. Love Pranav though he is super helpful.

best_comment: I've loved this class! I think it is incredibly helpful for anyone planning to (or even thinking about) writing a thesis. Professor Hagopian and Professor Ternullo are both amazing people and wonderful instructors who really want to see you succeed. I loved hearing their lectures because I thought they were very insightful, summarized the key content well, and were highly relevant to our theses. My 2 nitpicks with the class are (1) I wish the first research assignment was just graded for completion and with written feedback (it is due pretty early in the semester before most students have a good idea of what direction they want to take their thesis and (2) I did not find the activities at the end of lecture to be all that helpful. I thought lecture itself had much greater returns and I honestly would have preferred a longer lecture than working through some of the activities.
worse_comment: Whoever reads this, I highly recommend you evaluate why exactly you want to potentially write a senior thesis. It is a difficult venture to embark on, and through the semester, you will research your topic of interest in great depth. However, the structure of the class can make it overwhelming, and the canvas is a bit disorganized and tedious. If you have taken previous research methods, this class won't be that useful. I felt that most of the information presented to me was common knowledge, and don't even get me started on the reading. The readings are so tedious that you would be unmotivated to continue with them. Additionally, you have the pressure of obtaining a senior thesis advisor, and finding an advisor is difficult. However, even if you fail to have a senior advisor, you can find someone later on your senior fall, just don't fall.  The section was also simply a repeat of what we discussed in class. The class is also boring if you are familiar with the content. If you want to learn something new, take the other variant of Gov 62 which is Theory.

best_comment: I've loved this class! I think it is incredibly helpful for anyone planning to (or even thinking about) writing a thesis. Professor Hagopian and Professor Ternullo are both amazing people and wonderful instructors who really want to see you succeed. I loved hearing their lectures because I thought they were very insightful, summarized the key content well, and were highly relevant to our theses. My 2 nitpicks with the class are (1) I wish the first research assignment was just graded for completion and with written feedback (it is due pretty early in the semester before most students have a good idea of what direction they want to take their thesis and (2) I did not find the activities at the end of lecture to be all that helpful. I thought lecture itself had much greater returns and I honestly would have preferred a longer lecture than working through some of the activities.
worse_comment: Whoever reads this, I highly recommend you evaluate why exactly you want to potentially write a senior thesis. It is a difficult venture to embark on, and through the semester, you will research your topic of interest in great depth. However, the structure of the class can make it overwhelming, and the canvas is a bit disorganized and tedious. If you have taken previous research methods, this class won't be that useful. I felt that most of the information presented to me was common knowledge, and don't even get me started on the reading. The readings are so tedious that you would be unmotivated to continue with them. Additionally, you have the pressure of obtaining a senior thesis advisor, and finding an advisor is difficult. However, even if you fail to have a senior advisor, you can find someone later on your senior fall, just don't fall.  The section was also simply a repeat of what we discussed in class. The class is also boring if you are familiar with the content. If you want to learn something new, take the other variant of Gov 62 which is Theory.

best_comment: This was a difficult class, but a good one. Professor Rosen is clearly very brilliant and so helps to understand concepts in political theory. Doing readings each week is key, but they are oftentimes a bit long. I think this class is most helpful if you are preparing to write a political theory thesis.
worse_comment: Per spring 2025, I do not believe this is ACTUALLY a methods course. We read different thinks on various topics related to theory, sure, but, this course taught me nothing about how to think through political theory, approach researching/writing, or developing an argument. If you're hoping to take this to prep for writing as thesis (as the course intends to be), I'd suggest just taking a different political theory course. Again, this course simply taught me 0 about political theory methods. Highly disappointing.

best_comment: This is a great class if you enjoy a survey course where you read a solid canon! I enjoyed it. Assignments were very reasonable, somewhat open ended so a it was lot of fun writing them. Jordan is a great guy, who knows a lot about the subject and makes the conversations engaging. I would recommend this to fellow political theory/philosophy lovers, it is a good gov94.

course_title: Politics of Inequality in Latin America 001
best_comment: I absolutely loved this course. Professor Holland is very accessible and is very helpful in guiding both the research process and understanding important concepts within the course. At times readings can be heavy, but if you have some interest in the topic they are really interesting and helpful in understanding many of the problems present in the Latin American context. The final paper felt daunting at first, but Professor Holland does a great job of breaking downs the process and even has individual meetings to help you through your process. I would recommend this course to anyone with any interest in international government and inequality.

course_title: The Governance and International Politics of World Regions 001
best_comment: ** This is a great and accessible class for students interested in the topic, but it does require a good amount of reading and consistent participation in weekly discussions. Since the class meets only once a week for about two hours, it’s not demanding in terms of in–class time – but you do need to come prepared to engage with the readings each week. Discussions are super chill, but you need to do readings to participate effectively because the readings are niche. Professor Colton is incredibly knowledgeable and always happy to share insights and support students. His lectures tend to be long and information–dense, so bringing a coffee to stay focused is a good idea, though that’s pretty standard for a once–a–week, 2–hour 45–minute seminar.While the final paper is challenging because of its length, the biweekly response papers are quite short and nice. Aside from the reading load, the course is fairly light in terms of written assignments, so when you focus on this aspect, it is definitely worth taking to balance your semester workload and enhance your GOV experience here at Harvard. Grading is perfect and top, as long as you actually show that you read the assigned readings via response papers and in–class discussions.

Gabe is one of the best professors I have had at Harvard and this Gov 94 is one of the best classes I have taken (and his other Gov 94 is another one of my favorite classes as well). This course is everything you could want: the reading isn't too consuming, but it's immensely engaging and you learn a lot from it; the discussions are rich, very related to real world events, and they push your thinking; the material is exciting to think about especially if you're interested in the American legal system; Gabe is an encouraging instructor who provides great feedback and makes himself very available for office hours; Gabe also uses Poll Everywhere to direct class discussion quite often which I think is very effective. In short, being a part of both his seminars was a highlight of this past school year and I think anyone would be really lucky to take this class. I hope you will enjoy it as much as I did!

course_title: Sino-US Relations in an Era of Rising Chinese Power 001
best_comment: Professor Johnston is as good as they come, and it would take 2–3 faculty to replace him. Super knowledgeable of course, but also has clearly worked hard to make the class interesting for those with any level of previous knowledge on the topic. A top 3 class I've taken in college, as a second–semester senior.
worse_comment: Incredible class—Harvard will miss Professor Johnston.

course_title: Democracy in Practice in the Global South 001
best_comment: This is a great option for a gov94! Julie Weaver is an excellent professor, and the readings and discussions in this course were particularly interesting and engaging. The weekly workload is manageable, and assignments allow for flexible exploration of research interests.  The final paper may seem intimidating, but assignments in this course build upon each other and support is readily available and super helpful – I would definitely recommend taking this course!
best_gem_comment: Take this class with Prof.. Weaver! She is very nice, and the reading can be a bit tedious, but it is worth it. Please don't think it is a gem, but as a class to learn more about the global South and democratization. It is a comparative government class where the information is presented clearly in class, and then we synthesize our thoughts in class. You will be expected to do a lot of work in this role.

best_comment: There are better Gov94s and better IR courses. Unless you have a very specific interest in International Security, this course is not worth it. Even if you do have an interest in security studies, I would encourage you to take a second look at the QGuide and see if you could take something more applied. The flow of this course is circular and you generate the intuition through independent reading, rather than assignment feedback or quality discussion

Take this course! The material is extremely interesting, the assignments are very manageable, and learning from Skocpol is a once in a lifetime opportunity you will not be disappointed by. I would highly recommend going in with a final paper topic you are curious about as well. This is also a great option if you are considering writing a thesis and want to get a jump on the process. I cannot say enough good things about my experience.

course_title: Artificial Intelligence: Sociolegal Dilemmas and Policy Design 001
best_comment: This course fundamentally challenged the way I understand technological innovation and specifically in AI. Taking this course enabled me to have so many great conversations about AI in and outside of the classroom this year, giving me a more solid grasp of what the biggest dilemmas facing AI innovation is in the modern age. The workload is quite manageable, and Prof. Liviatan makes the course so engaging! The second half is all group project research, which I felt like was a fun way to learn from my peers. There's no other class like this at Harvard. Especially as a Gov kid, it was so enriching to take this and learn about the intersection of tech and regulation.

TAKE THIS CLASS!! Jordan's wonderful, and the course material is incredibly fascinating — a great way to fulfill your theory requirement. You cover many of the foundational thinkers in political economy (e.g., Smith, Marx, Keynes, Jevons, Weber, etc), which is useful for future coursework. Jordan has this amazing ability to break down and explain dense texts; bless his heart for trying to make Keynes understandable. You don't need a background in economics or anything like that for this class. I really looked forward to class every week and could not recommend this more.

The GOV Department doesn't have courses on immigration policy and the ones that exist outside of the department are largely U.S.–focused. I'd recommend this course because of its deep dive into assessing immigration policy and its impacts on multiple dimensions, while using a comparative perspective that looks at the application of immigration policy globally. You will learn a lot about the ways immigration is talked about and governed across the globe. While there is a Western lean, I think what makes this course stand out is its engagement with scholarship from the Global South which unfortunately isn't common enough in the GOV Department. If you're interested in immigration policy enough to write a robust final paper on it, take this course.

course_title: E&L Safra Undergraduate Ethics Fellowship Seminar 001
best_comment: Please take this course. It is not easy, and it is not all smooth, but it is a fantastic academic experience. You will learn a lot, including valuable academic skills, and you will gain an inquisitive perspective into many issues. Professor Applbaum will push your limits but he cares a great deal about his students doing well, is very insightful, and is incredibly kind. He challenges his students in a unique way that might feel overwhelming sometimes but it is incredibly thoughtful, thought–provoking, and helpful.
worse_comment: The Safra workshop is an island in the sea of Harvard's confusion about what a liberal arts education is for.

best_comment: Professor Saha was incredible. She is so kind and passionate about the subject. Discussions were interesting and the readings/format of the class were great. I learned so much. Harvard is going to miss her!
worse_comment: It's a great course if you want a relatively light experience that teaches you policy presentation. But, the discussions are sometimes unfocused.

best_comment: ABSOLUTELY take this course. Prof. Wang is a wonderful professor and human being, so incredibly patient in facilitating class discussion and making you feel validated while also pushing you to expand your intellectual horizons and really grapple with the texts. Going in as someone with not that much experience in political theory, I definitely felt that Prof. Wang facilitated discussion in a way that made readings comprehensible. The scope of the course is also a genuinely perfect overview of state development and will change how you understand governance. Highly recommend
worse_comment: TAKE IT!!! It is a class you will learn so much from. Teaches you all the foundational studies you should just know as a human. Can't recommend enough.

best_comment: Gov 97 is such a weird class and isn't structured enough. Matthew is a great teacher to have, though, and he's a good choice. Public opinion is a very interesting and topical issue, so that helped make it more worthwhile. But in truth this class is just like 2 hours of discussing the readings.

MATTHEW DARDET IS THE SWEETEST! This class really dives deep into public opinion and it's amazing how well the class is structured that it doesn't feel like much work at all. I loved the in–class discussions about the readings, so make sure you read them, so you can participate. Also, going to office hours for the assignments were helpful!

Noah is awesome! He is always so friendly and available to chat during office hours. He also brings a wealth of knowledge to political geography/mapping, so definitely talk to him about that as well. I also felt very comfortable sharing my opinions during class as we had such a variety of student backgrounds and political affiliations. Overall very satisfied with this course, the readings, and course instructor

The GOV 97 curriculum is pretty reasonable, and covers the elements of writing a through research paper well (sans any data analysis).  Writing said paper was not too difficult, but I would recommend choosing a topic you're genuinely interested in, as I delayed coming up with one until pretty late, and ended up writing about something fairly esoteric that I wasn't terribly excited about. I enjoyed Noah's "Political Geography" section, if it's still being offered in the future. He's a super chill guy who takes what you have to say seriously (and also is a pretty generous grader, based on what I expected to earn haha). His weekly assignments didn't really require much work, and were kind of abandoned half–way through the course anyway. Political geography ended up being a really interesting topic, as it kind of covers just about anything as long as you can geographically orient it. The readings were pretty varied but all interesting.

This topic was super interesting, it just felt like the section and some of the assignments weren't the most organized. I always really enjoyed the readings and felt like the class discussion was really great, I just wish the instructor was a bit more prepared and could've given stricter guidelines for some of the assignments.
worse_comment: so terrible at giving rubrics.

best_comment: Tutorial is obviously hard because of the complex assignments. But I will say, it enlightens you and makes you think in a way you never did before.  Brian's section in particular had me not being able to sleep because the questions were so fascinating and important. I think overall no matter how much this course challenges you, you learn so much and engage in deep thought that you never expected. I fell in love with government all over again through this course.
worse_comment: This course was a difficult experience for me. The topics covered in the course were interesting but at times felt disconnected and random. The course was quite disorganized and we often did not get instructions on completing assignments until days before they were do. Directions were vague and I found it hard to figure out what exactly was being expected of me from most assignments. If you have some interest in local government the course topics are interesting, but the organization of the course made it quite difficult to follow.

best_comment: I loved Abbie's section :)

Taegyun was AMAZING! He is a little picky so just make sure you understand the expectations of the assignment. If you follow the rubric and put some time in you will do well. Be present in class and engage. This class is really what you make of it. Economic Statecraft was such an interesting topic and was structured great!

Gov 97 is a pretty good course. It can take a good amount of time but the assignments aren't too bad. YOU CAN SKIP Gov 97 by taking Social Studies 10a and 10b. I took Gov 97, Social Studies 10a, and Social Studies 10b. Social Studies is definitely more interesting and probably easier, so I would recommend taking those and skipping Gov 97 if you can.
worse_comment: listen the material of this course was great but the TF clearly did not want to teach a seminar, literally, on the first day he said he was not fond of seminars. majority of the classes was just the TF lecturing for 2 hours and the feedback on assignments was vague & stress inducing.

best_comment: content is cool and you can learn about non–WEIRD societies. not a lot of fun, tho.  despite being a seminar, it sometimes was more of a lecture than dicussion–based, though that shifted a bit in the latter part of the course. you can experiment with ideas for a possible thesis in the final paper, which is nice.  however, the final paper feels like little: the final paper is an introduction. an iNtRoDuCtIoN. sure, it's an 8–9 paper introduction, writing a proper introduction is quite some work, and it sets the ground for the rest of the paper. but still, it's an introduction. it would be more interesting to have the opportunity to develop a mini–study. if you've already written a Government research paper before, the course might feel a bit redundant but you can take the opportunity to consolidate the skills needed to write a good research paper and do the readings for fun (because they can be quite interesting). the class can be a sort of a breath of fresh air in the Govenrment department because it doesn't focus on the US – we don't need to discuss the Congress or the President of the US ever. take it as a chance to learn about other cultures and not the typical DC–obsessed Gov kid. assignments are doable and not a lot of work. Julio is great TF and allows us to be flexible in choosing the topic for the final paper – he guides us in pursuing a topic of our own choice, that is fitted to our interests.
worse_comment: The experience of this course is totally dependent on your section leader. It is a pity that the gov department does not have its tutorials with professors rather than TFs. In my case, my section was perhaps the worst experience I've had so far at Harvard, with seminars that were taught more like lectures, horrible and inconsistent feedback on assignment, a general lack of enthusiasm, and no encouragement of discussions. However, do not let this discourage you completely as you might be lucky and get a great section leader.

best_comment: This was a great course, especially if you choose a tutorial for a topic you're really interested in as it'll make the weekly readings and assignemnts far more interesting. The assignments are all really fair and not overly time–intensive or tedious. Grading is extremely fair and transparent.
worse_comment: The grading is tough.

best_comment: You don't necessarily have to read the full reading that you are assigned per week. What I recommend is skimming the readings and trying to find something that interests you. A puzzle, perhaps, that has you questioning why political actors act in a certain manner given a certain context. You will be trained a bit on how to identify this yourself and don't expect the section leader to give you everything. The thing about poli sci is you need to train yourself in doing this and being curious is the answer to finding a research topic. I took the climate change section, but it wasn't what I initially wanted. I recommend that you take a section topic that you are greatly interested in because (1) it will make your life easier, (2) it will be more interesting and geared towards something your passionate about, and (3) it can serve as a potential senior thesis. The assignments will prep you on your lit review and research design. Together it helps you streamline your final paper. So don't worry about this class being that time consuming. Just be prepared for the first paper and prepare early.
worse_comment: Don't take this section if you don't deeply care about climate policy –– as in climate policy isn't near the top of your list of social issues. I was miserable for most of the semester and dreaded coming to class because I literally could not care less about the topic. The TF is great and you can learn a lot from him and the other students, but it's not worth the mental struggle, in my opinion.

best_comment: This is a great class if you're really interested in climate change and, more importantly, the policymaking process as a whole. You'll learn a lot about the steps of the policymaking journey, as well as the different stakeholders involved. If you're not interested in public policy and are more interested in political science phenomena that are outside of the policy process.

This is an excellent course for anyone interested in how data science can be applied to real–world political challenges. That said, it’s not for complete beginners—if you have no prior coding experience, especially in R, the learning curve can feel quite steep. You start with the basics in the first lab, but by the end of the semester you're expected to work with advanced tools. The course is rich in real data and grounded in political applications. I was genuinely impressed by Professor Schneer’s thoughtfully designed materials. He’s approachable, supportive, and brings clarity to complex ideas—just like the TA.This class is worth it ;)

This was my second GIS course I've taken that was taught by Dr. Chen, and I truly have nothing but amazing things to say. I went from having ZERO ArcGIS Pro experience at the beginning of the year to building complex and quantitative–based analyses that I used for several research projects. It's overwhelmingly clear that Dr. Chen holds an immense passion for the field and her students, and she's truly one of the brightest minds in the department. This course challenged me to step out of my comfort zone, yet was simultaneously manageable. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!
