professor harrison himself has a great amount of enthusiam for the subject and i respect that but somehow not an ounce of it rubbed off on me throughout the entire semester. the only interesting component is the survey project so make sure to pick a topic that you are actually passionate about.
worse_comment: If you want a chill class, this is for you. If you want something rigorous, especially from a methodological and statistical perspective, this is not the best use of your time. I found this class really frustrating because I didn't learn much, I especially didn't learn much in the field of government and statistics, and yet there is plenty of busywork.

best_comment: This course is great! One of the few courses where you can learn such a significant tangible skill (that helps with both research skills and employment prospects) with such straightforward work. The teaching in this course and the materials that the teaching team puts together are truly top notch, and as long as you have at least a basic understanding of ArcGIS Pro and can navigate basic technology, you will definitely learn a lot in this course. Professor Chen is also an amazing educator. She is not only extremely capable in her field, but also very skilled at transferring her expertise to students who wish to learn. This is also a cool course to meet students from all of the schools at Harvard: there are students from the college, GSD, HKS, public health school, phd students, and more. Definitely recommend this course! Start thinking about final projects early too ––– it's possible to tie in almost any interest, but the final project goes better if you can work out where to get data early because the poster presentation comes up quickly and the deadline for that is very firm.
worse_comment: Take this class if you are interested in GIS. My only reservation about this class is the discussion component. It is very difficult to have discussions on the readings we read for class.

best_comment: Dani Rodrik and Roberto Unger are some of the best professors you will ever learn from at Harvard. I mean, Dani Rodrik alone is a superstar celebrity in the field of political economy and the leading thinker on globalization. It does not get much better than that, except for adding Roberto Unger, whom is incredibly impressive in his own work in the legal and political thought fields. Not even to mention the fact that they bring in Daron Acemoglu (Nobel Prize Winner) for several guest lectures. Such a star–studded lineup. Despite this, though, the lectures themselves can be a bit inaccessible and somewhat dry. Sometimes, Unger would sit down and go on a three–hour stream of consciousness about the petty bourgeois or out–there ideas about putting all capital in a trust that people have to bid on with ideas. You have to suspend your disbelief when engaging with much of Unger's part of the course, which I now understand is sort of the point. Unger believes that (a) the market needs a drastic reorganization in structure, (b) this reorganization is possible but only if we imagine it first.  As someone who is a bit less theoretical, I resonated much more with Rodrik's elements of the course, which I thought were outstanding. However, someone a bit more philosophical and theoretical in nature would love Unger's part, as well. The workload is definitely manageable for an undergraduate. It consists of three main assignments, all papers, and all graded by the TF (so grades widely depend on who is TFing it). Some economics background is helpful in writing the papers and understanding the content but not required. I would, however, wait until you've taken Expos to take this course (so sophomores and above).

Dani Rodrik and Roberto Unger are some of the best professors you will ever learn from at Harvard. I mean, Dani Rodrik alone is a superstar celebrity in the field of political economy and the leading thinker on globalization. It does not get much better than that, except for adding Roberto Unger, whom is incredibly impressive in his own work in the legal and political thought fields. Not even to mention the fact that they bring in Daron Acemoglu (Nobel Prize Winner) for several guest lectures. Such a star–studded lineup. Despite this, though, the lectures themselves can be a bit inaccessible and somewhat dry. Sometimes, Unger would sit down and go on a three–hour stream of consciousness about the petty bourgeois or out–there ideas about putting all capital in a trust that people have to bid on with ideas. You have to suspend your disbelief when engaging with much of Unger's part of the course, which I now understand is sort of the point. Unger believes that (a) the market needs a drastic reorganization in structure, (b) this reorganization is possible but only if we imagine it first.  As someone who is a bit less theoretical, I resonated much more with Rodrik's elements of the course, which I thought were outstanding. However, someone a bit more philosophical and theoretical in nature would love Unger's part, as well. The workload is definitely manageable for an undergraduate. It consists of three main assignments, all papers, and all graded by the TF (so grades widely depend on who is TFing it). Some economics background is helpful in writing the papers and understanding the content but not required. I would, however, wait until you've taken Expos to take this course (so sophomores and above).

Decent course. A lot of the content lives in a somewhat ideal plane, and it is hard to get a sense of how to translate the principles into the real world. Prof. Allen aims to dedicate the second half of the course to this by inviting interviewees who embody different aspects of power sharing liberalism, which I found to be a very nice idea! Yet Prof. Allen largely steered away from addressing this aspect herself concretely, instead pushing students to think about this for themselves. This approach has its benefits and shortcomings. All interviews were also conducted by students, which was a good experience, but as far as developing a strong picture of real–world power sharing liberalism, left it feeling a little disjointed. If you are comfortable with a course where you can think about a philosophical paradigm, and then independently try to apply it to the world yourself, you will like this class a lot. If you want to more formally think about applications of power–sharing liberalism to current society, this may not scratch that itch. Also recommend briefly looking over her book "Justice by Means of a Democracy" –– the course is based upon it, and so if you like that style of philosophy, this course is largely a deep dive into the book, with the author, so will be great for you!Note: this class in the past has been taught combined with HKS and the college, but this year they were separate courses. So be sure to check that before enrolling. I think it would have been nice for them to be combined, but you will have to check how it is offered year–of.Prof. Allen is very thoughtful and accessible. Definitely a good person to talk to!All course staff were very kind and accessible. There was some variability between sections though –– different TFs come from different backgrounds, and so you should be able to pick a section that is a good match for your interests.
worse_comment: I constantly felt like banging my head against the table in this class. Much of the concepts you spend months discussing are so blatantly obvious you wonder if you're regressing in intelligence. Gemmy but a you don't really get anything out of it. Virtually zero feedback and structure; the poor TFs carried

course_title: The History of Modern Political Philosophy 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS!! Especially if you're interested in political theory (and obviously the history of political theory).  Prof March is an excellent lecturer, and engages questions & discussion throughout the class period.  take time to engage with the readings (which are fair & manageable) , and ask questions in class. i found every lecture intellectually stimulating and i actually wanted to go to class each week. awesome course
worse_comment: March is unfortunately quite outspoken in his views –– I don't think he would be biased in terms of grading if it came to an appeal, but it is unnerving to consistently hear it only from one side.

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! No assignments, lectures are super interesting, and sections are engaging. I am a CS person so was quite apprehensive going into this class, but I found it easy to participate and the course is perfectly designed to give you a nice intro to a philosophy–esque course. Professor Imparato is SO AWESOME and he truly cares about each and every student. Definitely take advantage of his meals and office hours! He is sooooo amazing.
worse_comment: Do all the readings with an open mind and ready to disagree (and agree). Prof. Imparato will introduce philosophical theories, but you do not have to agree with all of them. He does this to provide you with the tools to shape your moral argumentation and there will be theories you support and believe in while there will be some you will disagree with (often times using the theory you agree with to argue against the one you disagree with).

course_title: The Success and Failure of Protest Movements 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE! Professor Hummel is super knowledgeable about protest movements and structures the course super well! The workload is super manageable and you really get to learn about a lot of different protest movements! The materials are well thought out and truly a great mixture of course materials: memoirs (a few chapters which are super enjoyable), research papers (2 articles a week)! Assignments are reasonable, there's a lot of flexibility in what assignment prompt you can do! Section is amazing and the abstract theories become applicable! Grading is fair. Lectures are very interactive and would recommend getting to know Hummel! This is by far one of my favorite courses that I have taken here!!

This is a fantastic course for anyone interested in exploring the war in Ukraine in depth. However, be prepared: it’s quite reading–intensive and requires a significant time commitment. The grading throughout the semester can feel tough – especially if you’re used to consistently receiving A–/A grades at Harvard – but the detailed feedback is incredibly constructive and will genuinely help you improve as a writer. If you submit a good paper, you get a good grade. It is quite fair, IMO. While mid–semester grades might be lower than you expect, the final grades are curved, so most students end up doing very well overall. Don’t let early grades discourage you, just improve based on the feedback.Sections are engaging and often the highlight of the course. Nancy, you are the best!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Professor Epstein is highly accessible and supportive, but also a demanding grader—strong work is rewarded, and weaker submissions receive appropriately lower marks. Unlike some other classes, this isn’t one where everyone automatically gets a B or higher for assignments , BUT it does not mean you will not end up with a final grade of A if you improve and actually show that you care about the class.
worse_comment: If given the opportunity, I unfortunately would probably not take this class again. I loved the material, but the grading was very harsh and I felt that Prof. Epstein had unrealistic expectations for us. My GPA has suffered, and I am not the only student who feels this way.

course_title: Politics and Power in Post-Soviet Russia 001
best_comment: This is just not a good course to be taking. The lectures are three hours straight during lunch time, with only a very short break. The professor quite literally reads the entire time. I remember him saying once: "This is obviously very bad for Russia." Then, he looked down at his notes. Looked back up. "Sorry I said here, this is extremely bad for Russia." Not only does he not put any effort into the delivery of the class, the content itself is not designed for an undergraduate class. Sometimes, he would put the photographs of 10 influential people in XYZ affair and then describe all their lives in excrutiating detail. In my notes, somewhere buried, I know where the mom of some business tycoon grew up. This is the kind of information that makes up this class – mostly trivial. And even when it wasn't trivial, but quite interesting in fact, there was often no thesis/point the professor wanted to make. So the class was essentially a three–hour long amalgamation of details.Now, I need to also acknowledge that the readings for this class were AMAZING and I learned so much about Russia through them, and section. I really feel better equipped to discuss Russian politics. So, if you want to learn everything there is to know about Russia, do most of the work piecing things together yourself and do not mind boring lectures, this is the class for you. If you do all the readings (of which there are an insane amount), I guarantee this will be a positive experience. But you could be taking so many other classes at Harvard that you could be absolutely loving instead of this one.

I loved this class. If you are interested in gov, you must take a Levitsky course, he is a PHENOMENAL lecturer––and I think this is the one to take. I came away from this course with a really solid understanding of different theories of democratization and the state of democracy in our world. The topic could not be more relevant for the current moment. You do not need to do all of the readings, maybe split them with friends or just try to do the ones he mentions in lecture and/or what you need for the case memos. Important thing is you get the main ideas, no need for details. Take copious in class (he talks really fast!).  For the exam, the prompts are pretty easy and the terms are pretty general, so instead of getting bogged down in the details try to review some case studies in depth but just make sure you get the main ideas. My TF was pretty easy with grading so I felt like I lucked out with easy grading and getting to take a course with Levitsky, but can't promise the grading will be easy with future TFs (Levitsky tells the TFs to give a B+ average on papers but I don't think the enforcement is super strict).  I took this course because I am interested in politics and wanted a basic understanding of the histories of different countries, and I felt like I came away from it with a pretty solid background of the political histories of various countries around the world (dinner table knowledge, if you will), just from lectures. Overall, this class was great and I can honestly say I learned A LOT, so I would definitely recommend (and if you are too scared to take it for credit, maybe even just audit it because you learn so much in lecture). This is honestly what I expect for a good college course.
worse_comment: Take it pass fail as an elective if possible!

best_comment: Sadly, this will be the last time that Professor Hagopian teaches this absolutely wonderful class. By doing the readings, you will immerse in a fantastic literature that will equip you with a great toolkit to analyze the political, social, economic, historical issues of Brazil. More importantly, by paying attention in sections, you will discover how to combine a vast amount of scholarship into an organized argument. Professor Hagopian is absolutely the best professor at giving feedback and she goes above and beyond to make your writings and arguments better. Even though she won't teach this specific class again, make sure to talk to her because she made this course a great learning experience

I would say that this class has very interesting theoretical concepts about representation, but the data–driven analysis falls flat because it is insanely predictable. A friend and I both said things along the lines of "we could have come to this conclusion ourselves, the data is just something extra that proves we are right." This is not to the fault of Costa, I found her to be very nice and engaging with the class. However, it makes the class less interesting than others, so consider this if interest is a priority.  The assignments were reasonable, and the grading was fair. Overall, solid class but not the most mind–blowing thing you will take.

As a senior, I was looking for a course that offered me something new that I hadn't yet studied during my time at Harvard. I think this course did a great job providing a general view into food issues in the U.S., and I really appreciated how it wasn't just a "become vegan" class.  It definitely made me think about how I can make small changes in my life to help the environment.
worse_comment: This course is really interesting and chill, but might not be worth it if you're looking for a rigorous food system evaluation. It's very micro–targeted to the issue of animal agriculture and doesn't really do more than throw paint at the wall in terms of solutions.

best_comment: I loved this course, but think it can be even better. Strengths: Carpenter is just awesome, so friendly and SO smart. The guest lecturers were consistently incredible and were probably the highlight of the course (LOTS of credit to Dan for this pedagogically, too, it just makes a lot of sense for such a topic centering the work of Native Nations).  Opportunity to work with a Nation rather than have a discussion section, incredible. WHERE TO IMPROVE: I think the project I was working on was thrown together semi–last minute, and as a result, the work that my small group did over the course of the semester was incredibly minimal, and was something realistically we did in 3 hours. I think other projects seemed more engaged, but ensuring a similar level of depth in each project I think could help really make this course shine in helping students to more deeply apply what they are learning in lecture (granted, I think this course had a surprisingly high enrollment  which probably contributed to this). ALSO, I really appreciate how central the lectures were, but if there is a better way to make the readings more tied in, I think that would be great. The readings are kind of general/abstracted Native history stuff that is helpful context, but you did not need to do at all. Maybe just have less readings but make them much more central? All in all, this was a very pragmatic/grounded course which I loved, I just think the student participation part could have been a little more fleshed out. To that end, I would suggest LOOKING at the HKS Native Nations Course (I think you can take it as an FAS class) because it seems like that structure is much more built out and the engagement is probably a little deeper.
worse_comment: Course didn't have much structure and can see it changing in the future. It was overall more on the low stress side, but the syllabus changed multiple times which is why I have reservations of it in the future.

course_title: African American Fraternal Associations in U.S. Society and Politics 001
best_comment: This is a great course, especially if you like to combine historical context with US political structures/systems. You have to be willing to challenge yourself and be innovative, ask a lot of questions as this is a still developing field. But Prof. Skocpol is extremely interested in this work and is super enthusiastic about it. If you show enthusiasm and curiosity, you will really get a lot out of this course.  But as Prof. Skocpol says, “this is not a gut.” She expects you to come into class with discussion questions and having done the reading.  So only take this class if you are willing to put in the effort and engage in lively discussion every week.

course_title: Tech Science to Save the World 001
best_comment: Take this course! Professor Sweeney is such an engaging speaker and has such great knowledge and experience on the topics we discuss. Our unit projects were a great way to explore the topics deeper, but also allowing us to tie in our own interests. The support for our final projects was great, and I loved the final project fair where we got to see what other peers had found for their research projects.

course_title: Tech Science to Save the World 001
best_comment: Take this course! Professor Sweeney is such an engaging speaker and has such great knowledge and experience on the topics we discuss. Our unit projects were a great way to explore the topics deeper, but also allowing us to tie in our own interests. The support for our final projects was great, and I loved the final project fair where we got to see what other peers had found for their research projects.

course_title: The Politics of War and Peace in the Middle East 001
best_comment: This was a very good course. The topics were great and I truly feel like I learned a lot about the politics of the middle east. The teaching staff was amazing and very knowledgeable, both prof. Sener and Khaled. Thank you for an amazing semester!

course_title: Political Communication Breakdown: Causes, Consequences, and Solutions 001
best_comment: It's a great class and super interesting. A great one to fill your "American Politics" requirement for the Gov concentration. The workload is pretty light if you get paired with a good and efficient group for the project.

course_title: Evaluating the Impacts of Public Policies: How to Design and Implement Randomized Controlled Trials 001
best_comment: PLEASE TAKE THIS CLASS!! Michael Hiscox is an amazing professor. If you like RCTs and if you like public policy and care about the implications of what RCTS can have on policy, this is the class for you. I know this year was somewhat unprecedented especially since this class is much smaller and there was a huge influx of those who enrolled into the course, so I wonder if Professor will cap this class in the future, but despite that, I still highly encourage you to take this course. I found the weekly section presentations so intersting, especially with the array of presentations that we had that touch all subjects of policy and how RCTs can actually have such an impact on policies that can be made. I will say, from what I've heard, there were definitely some interesting TFs on the team, but Niharika is amazing and absolutely loved her enthuisiam for the subject! Take this class for an amazing professor who is so so passionate about the course material and for fun vibes :)
best_gem_comment: ****gem, great addition to a schedule that already has 3 hard classes

best_comment: This course is excellent, especially for those who liked and did well in Gov 1790. I loved the material. It was substantive, engaging, and delivered well. The reading and difficulty level are about the same at 1790, but expect more participation due to the small class size. The smaller space means that the class is more engaged and interactive, and you will have to keep up with readings and the possibility of being cold–called. I personally enjoyed it a lot. If you haven't taken 1790, I'd recommend doing a brief preparation in the standard IR theories as having that baseline helps you appreciate how the psychology aspect is different and complementary. This is a class that you should take with the intention of putting effort in.Professor Kertzer is a gem. One of the best professors I've had in my four years, and the only one who makes the effort to remember the names of all his students no matter if it's a small seminar–style class or a large lecture class. He brings a sense of liveliness, humor, and juice to his lectures. He's very sharp and informative when it comes to answering questions.  If you're interested in government, you'll be missing out if you don't take a class with Kertzer at least once before you graduate.
worse_comment: This course is very difficult. The final exam itself covers the whole semester and the amount of concepts and readings you have to remember is just insane. start studying for the final early. The two papers are graded not too bad though. Do the readings, revisit past lectures, attend office hours, participate in section and all the basic stuff. the key is doing everything that is required of you – this is not the course you get away with doing everything in the last minute. readings are heavier and more complex than other courses.
best_gem_comment: This course is interesting if you like psych. Kertzer is a gem though, so you'll have fun in lecture even if you don't.

course_title: Behavioral Insights and Public Policy: Nudging for Good 001
best_comment: If you need an easy Gov class take this!! it is very easy but also super interesting. Prof. Hiscox is so amazing and makes lectures super fun.
worse_comment: The course is not too demanding, but the exams are long and there is little to no preparation for the long responses, and I did not get any feedback on the midterm exam beyond the score. Also, the presentation is one of the main components of the course, yet no preparation for how to go about the presentation is provided. There is a template, but it did not feel like enough, and it impacted the final grade.
best_gem_comment: take it! it's a gem and enjoyable

best_comment: Naijia is a very kind and accommodating instructor; you can tell that she really cares about the course and her students! It was a joy to learn from her. The material was difficult especially towards the second half of the class because it became very technical. But I think it was nice that the exams were take home, and it tested the concepts fairly, so I didn't feel too much stress. There were also only 4 psets staggered biweekly which ended up being very well balanced for me, as I was taking 2 other challenging pset classes simultaneously.

Great application of GOV 2005 material. We cover a variety of applications of political theory, and after taking this class, I feel like I could pick up any paper in the field, and have a good grasp of its arguments and proofs.

This was a phenomenal course, one that is undoubtedly the only of its kind in the department and is likely unique across all political science departments, at least those of which I am aware in the United States. Our knowledge of political science would benefit greatly should such a course be made mandatory for all graduate students. This course covers a vast expanse of interesting and rather rare literature across the social sciences, including the philosophy of social science. The reading list was structured around difficult questions that researchers should yet often do not ask themselves, such as "what are we trying to do here?", "why?", and "how might it best be done?" The second week, which covered Popper, Kuhn, and Lakatos was particularly fascinating and provided a great foundation for thinking about the social scientific research enterprise more broadly. The third (on theory–building) and fourth (causality) weeks were also fantastically interesting and novel to me. After delving into these broad questions (and providing a groundwork for conceptualization and measurement), the course tackles specific methodologies—observational studies, experiments, and many weeks on qualitative methodologies that were very interesting as someone whose training in political science fell nearly exclusively into the quantitative camp. This literature and the discussions surrounding it alone provide, in my opinion, sufficient motivation for taking the course. Yet there are two, perhaps even more beneficial aspects of the course that I will now overview. The first key benefit consists of the number of research skills and advise one picks up throughout the course, primarily from Professor Hall's immense experience and erudition, but also from collective discussions of prominent work with colleagues. These tips concern how to write and frame a paper, which elements to prioritize, how to advance an effective and novel argument, what to focus on in your research, how to discover and expand upon initial ideas, etc. All of these are extremely valuable and almost never packaged so precisely and powerfully as they are in this course.  The second key benefit is the remarkable, almost miraculous quantity and quality of feedback you receive on your work from Professor Hall. There is a good deal of work involved in this course (as there should be in a graduate course at our esteemed institution), and essentially all of it is worth your time. In a fraction of the time you are allotted to complete the assignment, Professor Hall will return penetrating feedback on your work that is often longer (and more insightful) than what you originally submitted. His feedback has helped my research immensely and will have altered the direction of my dissertation research for the better. Feedback from kind and sharp peers was also very helpful throughout the term.In sum, the benefits of this course are manifold and unparalleled. Not to avail yourself of such a course would be sheer folly. I am much obliged to Professor Hall and my colleagues, who provided interesting, learned, fun, critical–but–respectful interlocution, for the most enjoyable and fruitful course of my graduate career.

Prof. Allen is an excellent instructor who is able to carry discussions of the calibre required in helping students connect a broad range of sources. You really get an idea of what good engagement with political philosophy looks like when it is able to take the materials available in existing literature, put it under a critical lens, and produce wide–ranging insights as a result. This is a course for those eager to construct new things!

Great course for achieving an orientation to political theory and political philosophy, particularly for political scientists. The course serves as a useful basis for further exploration, engagement, and study.

Great course for achieving an orientation to political theory and political philosophy, particularly for political scientists. The course serves as a useful basis for further exploration, engagement, and study.

This was the best course I have taken so far and will probably be the best throughout my PhD. It had engaging discussions and instructions, classic and contemporary readings, and a great environment for learning and discussion.

This was the best course I have taken so far and will probably be the best throughout my PhD. It had engaging discussions and instructions, classic and contemporary readings, and a great environment for learning and discussion.
Great class if you are interested in this kind of stuff

course_title: The Radical Right in Europe and Beyond 001
best_comment: Take a seminar class with Professor Ziblatt. He is a kind and caring Professor

course_title: Proseminar on Inequality and Social Policy II 001
worse_comment: Don’t worry so much about getting into the weeds, the main concepts are what matters.

best_comment: Josh is such an amzing instructor in class – he conveys ideas and difficult concepts in such an engaging and fun way. The syllabus is also very detailed and thoughtfully put together and is a great resource.

TAKE THIS!! This has been one of the most transformative courses I have taken. It was so cool to work with immigration attorneys and help them in such tangible ways. The discussions about the case were a bit hard sometimes, but the instructors really supported us and created such an intimate environment in the classroom. I really loved getting to work in our groups and feel like I made such great friends from the course, despite the work we were doing being so high–stakes and stressful at times. We went beyond the asylum system and really got to know the histories and cultures of the countries we were researching.
worse_comment: This course is a unique experience that you probably can't get at any other undergraduate institution in the country; that alone is reason enough to want to take it. However, despite its incredible premise and intention, the course is highly disorganized. There are weeks at a time when there will be no assignments, followed by us being notified that we have a few days to finish a major deliverable. There are always issues with Canvas, and assignments are somehow simultaneously overly specific and vague. For a course that has been taught for over a decade, it should be in much better shape!That being said, the world has been crazy this past semester, and immigration in particular has been a sensitive issue for many. For that reason, I believe that the course and teaching team should be given some grace. It's hard to teach a class on a topic like this in the current political and social climate!

course_title: Protest and the Press in the Postwar US 01
best_comment: Truly liked this class. Sage was an amazing teacher and I really enjoyed all the different components of the class. Loved that the final paper was way earlier to focus on the digital media project, which I had so much fun doing

course_title: A Cultural History of Argentina: From Tango to Messi 01
best_comment: This is an excellent history seminar to take if you're interested in cultural history approaches, Argentina, nation–building, or just the various interactions of gender, race, indigeneity, class, and more. Professor is super knowledgeable and kind, and really spurs discussion on the topic. It really makes you think more about various important processes in the pursuit of nation–building. Highly recommend. Readings are nicely seleced and paint an excellent, complicating picture about the various social forces and processes that went through Argentina between its colonial period and the modern day. The readings are long, and there are also weekly response papers, but come on, this is a history class.

Amazing class! Prof. Sternhell is super passionate about the topic and loves it when we engage with the material, even if that means we're critiquing the readings. The class was small but the environment was super welcoming. Learned a lot in this class!

VERY fun and interesting! This won't be life changing, but if you're a History (or Social Studies, Hist & Lit, etc) concentrator and you want to work on a big project over a semester, then this course is perfect for getting to drive your own research project. (You do have to be VERY self–guided because the project is intense.)The readings are varied–––some are very interesting, others are very academic and dry. Overall, a fun course, but be prepared for readings and lots of research!

course_title: Capital in Crisis: A History of U.S. Economic Emergencies 01
best_comment: Fantastic course overall. Dr. Kuchinski is accessible and a fair professor, and wants the students to succeed. Readings may sometimes seem overwhelming and a lot of content but  are absolutely necessary to complete to be successful in the course. Not a course where you can skip the readings and glide by. I've now taken multiple courses on the history of financial crises in my time as an undergrad, and it's nice for one to be more History focused as opposed to be purely Economics. Would recommend with enthusiasm, particularly to Economics concentrators who are looking to fulfil their seminar requirement for a secondary in History.

course_title: The Civil War and Reconstruction in History and Memory 01
best_comment: I really enjoyed my time in this course. The content was really well designed and the flow of material felt natural. Rather than focusing on the details of various wars, I felt like I learned a lot about the history of the question, "what caused the civil war". I would encourage anyone remotely interested in the subject to take the class!
worse_comment: Take any course with Professor Jacobs!! It really feels like he's your friend. His goal is always to maximize your learning, and he's open to changing anything about the course if you can show that it would make everyone's experience better. Look somewhere else for in–depth discussion of the actual fighting / battles, but this course will teach you fundamentally why the war was fought. Spoiler alert, the answer isn't just "slavery."

best_comment: *** This class is AMAZING. Highly recommend to all. Danny is an amazing teacher, one of the best I have had during my time at Harvard. He really engaged the class and encouraged all to speak their mind. Kept all conversations and classes relevant and value–add. Really really really enjoyed this class.

course_title: Asian American Women in the Archive: Schlesinger Library Immersive Course 01
best_comment: This class is great — I was a fan of Erika Lee before class, but an even bigger fan at this point. I'm so grateful she also brought in a curator at Schlesinger Library, Victor Betts, to teach this course as well. I learned so much about the challenges and discourse around the archive, and can easily talk about that with anyone at this point. I loved the final project and the incredible opportunities Erika would drop for the class. This is a class like no other at Harvard, and I was so lucky to take it.

course_title: The United States and China: Opium War to the Present 01
best_comment: I learned so, so much about US china relations. I think you should only take this class if you are ready to write the final research paper (as in you, have the experience in historical research and/or are ready to put in the work). This is not to deter you from taking the class, you should definitely take this excellent class, but you really only get out what you put in. The workload is generally not very high, so the onus is on you to put effort into the well–selected texts, engage in discussions, and workshop your paper. As an aside, prof Manela is an awesome teacher. I always looked forward to going to class.
worse_comment: Excellent course, but frustrated at times with Prof. Manela's approach & needs some more guidance for the 'original research' component.

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Prof. Blair is one of the best professors you'll get to meet at Harvard. She's super knowledgeable about a variety of topics (even tho she specializes in French intellectual history) and has always been so delightful and willing to help. Saffron is a wonderful tutor and this class is much more fun and approachable because of her. One thing I really appreciated about this class was the amount of feedback you get. First you attend a 4–person peer review session every 3 weeks and get feedback from your classmates and very detailed comments from Saffron. After you submit the draft you get another detailed feedback from Prof. Blair before you actually submit the final version of each essay. The final paper also allows a lot of freedom when you choose the topic because intellectual history is super broad. Really happy that I was able to spend about 2 months on a topic I'm super interested in and eventually craft and polish it with my classmates, Saffron, and Prof. Blair.

This is a tough class but it is still one of the best history tutorials. They are all structured similarly and the deadlines are pretty unreasonable imo. But Jasanoff is a genius and our tutorial leaders were great.

I loved the micro–history approach of this class. The readings were highly interesting and engaging and the exercises we did in section reinforced our understanding of the material. Niko is also an amazing TF and very helpful and available. However, the work does build up — at one point we had an essay every other week and an entire book. One week was annotated bibliography, a historiographical essay, a primary source essay, a final paper draft. Some of the assignments felt a bit like teaching you the methodical approaches so if you already had background, it can feel a bit pointless. I did love reading all my peers final essays though — they were so amazing and I genuinely loved it.

course_title: What is the History of Capitalism? 01
best_comment: If you can take this course with Professor Bondioli, do it! Professor Bondioli is an absolutely amazing, kind, informative, passionate and exemplary Professor, truly. I learned so much from this course, skills and content wise and Professor Bondioli as well as TF's Joshua and Charlotte never left us in the dark. That is, expectations were always clear, class and section was well organized, tailored to our evolving needs and requirements, and helpful. I could not have gotten a better experience as well as TF's,  they are amazing.

course_title: What is the History of Emotions? 01
best_comment: Penslar is fantastic and this is such a good course. History of emotions is a great lens to look at history through and Penslar is an expert and so kind. This course really changed my writing and made it so much better.
worse_comment: This is so difficult and also the history of emotions is weirdly specific yet abstract.

best_comment: Theses aren't for the weak, but it's one of the most rewarding things you'll do in college. Carla + Will are EXCELLENT supports.

course_title: One Land, Two Peoples: The Modern History of Israel/Palestine 01
best_comment: This is a great class. If you are interested in the topic, I highly, highly recommend it. Professor Penslar is a wealth of knowledge and brought in fascinating and renowned guest lecturers. The readings are all very interesting. I learned so much, and I am so grateful to have had the opportunity to take the class. The class does require work, but a very reasonable amount, and each assignment felt like a valuable way to be spending my time (not busy work). I will say that the course veers on the more progressive side, but that's not necessarily a bad thing –– just something to keep in mind. As someone who leans progressive myself, I would have liked to read more nuanced perspectives to have been prevented to challenge my own views, but I still learned so much.
worse_comment: This course forced me to correct histories I had been taught in my household. I feel it is impossible to leave Penslar's mentorship without an appreciation for nuance in these conversations. He is a phenomenal lecturer, an accessible professor, and a mentor who is committed to your academic growth.

best_comment: Hello history concentrators looking for a pre–1750 requirement! This is a pretty good option – Prof. Angelov is such a sweet professor, I honestly would take it again just for him, because it was a great time. Andy is actually an amazing TF to get to know, so also would highly recommend just for him. To be honest, I don't know if Byzantium is my thing after this class, HOWEVER I honestly had a great time. The assignments aren't too difficult and neither is the midterm or final. They are very generous and are not trying to trip you up – just know the material and what they expect of you.
best_gem_comment: Tbh didn't have time to do many of the readings, just crammed before the midterm and final... Wish I had more time to do them, though they seemed very interesting and well–picked.For the response papers, GO TO OFFICE HOURSE BEFOREHAND. sometimes the section leader can be a bit more stringent on formatting, it's good to check in before to see what they want.Overall solid class, wouldn't say gem (if you put in the work), but if you've got a busy schedule it's still a doable class. Prof Angelov is very funny sometimes and Andy is wonderful!

best_comment: I think this course is awesome, especially Professor Bose's lectures. Professor Bose is definitely passionate about the course and is very knowledgable about the region. As a Southeast Asian I think I learned quite a lot of new things. I would really recommend this course as it gives a very good overview of Southeast Asian history, and talking to Professor Bose in office hours had been a great experience. You should do the readings as they are really good. But I think TLDR as long as Professor Bose keeps teaching this class the quality of his lectures is a very strong reason to take the class!Caveat:My major complaint is the grading that is unreasonably harsh and quite baseless. I love criticisms and feedback that actually help me grow as a writer, like I get in another class I am taking this semester, but the criticisms and feedback for the essays in this class doesn't really make sense, and even after meeting during office hours to clarify I am still not satisfied. Some of the "feedback" and point deductions just simply feel made up. There is also a lot of criticisms about my grammar or this single typo, both for the written midterm and for the review essay assignment, and I heard from others in the class they got that too. After I pointed out it is not a grammar class but a history class they seem to switch gears and argue my "argument" is weak etc but it all seems more like an attempt to justify the harsh grading instead of actually having substantive criticisms.I guess another thing is that the perspectives given on some Southeast Asian country seemed quite Western and does not really reflect how people in that country see the events, which sometimes is fine as perspectives differ but sometimes some data are just omitted which gives a distorting picture on some episodes in the country's history. You probably won't notice if you are not from the region but I think they are quite minor and overall it is still a good class. It is just that some ideas about race or gender are really Western impositions on stuff people from the region see very differently, but I guess that's not surprising.
worse_comment: Lectures are boring. Assignments are also kind of boring. Professor is a big name. You are probably better off taking other history courses.

course_title: Conspiracy! A Possible History of U.S. Politics and Culture 01
best_comment: At Harvard, there are some classes that promise interesting material but fail to deliver. This class is the epitome of those classes. You would learn more, have a more structured learning experience, and all–in–all have a better time if you simply sat down with your friends, perused these readings, and had a thoughtful discussion about them – Professor Jacobs provides no instructive help, and in some cases is an active hindrance. If you must take this class, do so with friends who are interested in the subject matter, and take it pass/fail – assignments are guesswork at best considering Professor Jacobs' inability both to describe what he wants or to provide any coherent feedback. It's a shame, because he clearly also has a passion for the material – but passion isn't enough when you show up each week with a half–written legal–pad page's worth of notes and some half–remembered slides.
worse_comment: This class is not very focused, and did not really get to what I expected it would. The relevance of many of the readings and a few of lectures was unclear. Guest lectures were not very valuable. Somehow the course covered too much and not enough material. Started off really strong, but fell off after the Klan lectures.  Lecture was hard to follow, and I didn't really come away with any valuable information besides a few isolated incidents.

best_comment: Professor Gordon is a phenomenal(ogy of spirit) lecturer and makes even the densest sections of the Philosophy of Right come alive. It's also an intellectually serious course, though, which in practice partially means that you have to spend a lot of time wading through boring stuff like sense–certainty and Marxist economics so that you can enjoy fun stuff like Hegel's philosophy of history and Marx's theodicy. I enjoyed hearing about different readers of Hegel and Marx and about the generous ways to read older thinkers who aren't straight–up analytic philosophers, and also about a thinker's responsibility to they way their ideas get used. I will say that, especially in the beginning sections of this course, I felt like we were just throwing around these big opaque concepts like "dialectic" and breaking them down into component parts without really making clear what they were. Like I still don't see how the three paradigms illuminate what the dialectic really is. Also, as many people have commented, you either are taking this course for Hegel or you're taking it for Marx. A fun game is guessing which of your classmates fall into which bucket.

course_title: The United States and World Order since 1900 01
best_comment: This is the kind of class you come to Harvard for. I cannot say enough good things about this course. Professor Manela is a fantastic lecturer. I would recommend going to office hours at least once just to chat. Jesus is an amazing TF. His feedback on assignments (of which there are only two the entire semester) was always constructive and helpful. The section for this class was amazing. Although the topics could get very heavy, people were always respectful and engaged with the subject matter in a way that constantly made me rethink my own opinions. If you are even slightly interested in history, take this class. If not, take it anyways.
worse_comment: Overall: HIST 1465 centers on the US as an actor on the world stage and how the US has influenced world order, from US empire to decolonization, from Cold War dynamics between the US, the USSR, China, and the so–called Third World to the unipolar moment after the collapse of the Soviet Union. There is a particular focus on the US interaction with the world, starting with the beginnings of the US overseas empire in the late 19th century and leaving off at the US response to 9/11. Professor: Manela is a wonderful lecturer. He does a tremendous job of painting the picture of the period through maps and media while balancing these with timelines and biographies. He is also keen to point out relationships between historical figures across periods and how that may have affected the thought processes of those at the helm, as well as historical figures and historians with ties to Harvard. Textbooks: Required for both primary and secondary source readings. Other secondary source readings will be provided. Dennis Merrill and Thomas G. Paterson, Major Problems in American ForeignRelations, Vol II: Since 1914, 7th ed. (Wadsworth, 2010). Topics covered: World order in the 1890’s; US joins the fray, Americans as colonizers; empires at war and revolution; envisioning and making a post–WWI world order; fragility and collapse of the post–WWI order; road to WWII; WWII as a race war (TA lecture, subject to change); remaking world order… again; Cold War order emerges; Korean War, Cold War goes global; rise of the “Third World”; decolonization and development; wars for Vietnam; global 1960’s; bio–orders: people, food, germs (TA lecture); 1970’s “shock of the global”; end of Cold War order; unipolar moment; 9/11 and its aftermath; a new Cold War.  Similarities were also drawn to the shift in the US approach to world order that is associated with the early months of 2025, though they are not the focus of the course.Course structure notes: Weekly readings and section; two essay assignments; two midterms and a final exam.

best_comment: This class is fantastic! It gives a great overview of the region and is very much connected to the present as you are able to draw lines from earlier historical processes. While there are quite a bit of readings, each reading was carefully selected and I enjoyed every single one. Definitely take this class, you will not regret it!There is also so much room for creativity with your research topic!
worse_comment: Kind of an APUSH–style course but for Latin America: the level is not super difficult maybe because the class has a lot of non–history/social science concentrators and a lot of freshmen. There are a ton of readings each week but in practice you just need to read the primary sources and go to lecture if you don't have a lot of time.

best_comment: This class gives a great sweep through modern Chinese history! At first, it was a bit overwhelming, coming from a background of little Chinese history, but by a couple of weeks in I was able to more clearly navigate lectures and readings to advance my knowledge. One of the highlights of the class, for me, was the Survey of China Mainland Press Project, where we got to look through the different books and do group research on a topic. Xiaorui was a WONDERFUL TF and went out of her way to answer questions, offer guidance, and make section as fun as possible. Besides being brilliant, she is always superbly kind and welcoming, without a doubt adding to the course with her intense knowledge. The review guides/outlines were immensely helpful in preparing for the exams and consolidating the topics covered.

I must say this is one of the best courses I have taken throughout my time at Harvard! The content is carefully curated to give a very comprehensive picture of historical energy transitions in the US, UK, China and beyond. Yet, it still successfully delivers rather individualized narratives of such transitions, such as labor conditions for female workers, etc. Professor Miller is truly the best professor you could ever ask for. He teaches with a true passion for the subject at every single lecture and makes himself available. It's very rare to find such a professor here, and you would greatly appreciate that. Take this course!

I highly recommend this course for anyone interested in learning about the history of Africa. I was a bit skeptical about joining a new course without a q report, but I am so glad I did. Professor Glovsky does a great job of keeping us engaged, and Dana is great at facilitating conversations in the section.

course_title: Beyond the Game: A History of U.S. Sports and Society 01
best_comment: Professor Kuchinski is great! She is super understanding of students and is always trying her best to get class engagement. My only reservations would be that the topics may get stale if it is taught the same way. For periods in the semester it felt like we were talking about the same thing even though we were in a new decade. Overall, the course is great for discussing American sports!
worse_comment: It's interesting in theory but a bit less–organized than most history classes are/should be. I don't think it truly reflected how integral the topic was to the general public at times (primary sources felt a bit basic at times) but you get out of the class whatever you put in.

course_title: Racial Capitalism and the Black Radical Tradition 01
best_comment: Take this class!! Professor Brown and Professor Johnson are amazing, I loved taking a course with two professors because they had such a great rapport and were able to bring great insights into discussions, bouncing off of one another. Assignment–wise this course is pretty chill, only one large paper at the end of the semester (which is super flexible) and then weekly discussion posts. Nothing is graded in the class, you just receive a grade in the end, but I anticipate they will not be harsh graders. I took this course as a young undergrad (this was actually technically my first history class of college), and I got a lot out of sharing an intellectual space with so many advanced undergrads and graduate students, but I will say that a lot of the material likely flew over my head because of a lack of background in things like Caribbean history or the history of capitalism. It may be more beneficial to take this course with a bit more foundational knowledge under your belt to make the most of it; however, it is definitely doable with less background if you are okay with figuring things out as you go. Go to office hours––I was intimidated at first but they are so open and want to guide you! The reading load is HEAVY (200–400 pages a week) so I ended up spending a lot of time on this class this semester. It was frustrating at times when I spent hours on a complex reading and felt like I walked away with a low understanding of it, but the other students a are likely just as confused by some of the readings. This is a class where you get out what you put in, especially when it comes to the readings. Overall, this class is a great way to get to know some INCREDIBLE professors and engage in a super intellectual environment with a ton of cool students, talking about some of the most relevant themes of capitalism, African American history, intersectionality, organizing, etc.

course_title: Racial Capitalism and the Black Radical Tradition 01
best_comment: Take this class!! Professor Brown and Professor Johnson are amazing, I loved taking a course with two professors because they had such a great rapport and were able to bring great insights into discussions, bouncing off of one another. Assignment–wise this course is pretty chill, only one large paper at the end of the semester (which is super flexible) and then weekly discussion posts. Nothing is graded in the class, you just receive a grade in the end, but I anticipate they will not be harsh graders. I took this course as a young undergrad (this was actually technically my first history class of college), and I got a lot out of sharing an intellectual space with so many advanced undergrads and graduate students, but I will say that a lot of the material likely flew over my head because of a lack of background in things like Caribbean history or the history of capitalism. It may be more beneficial to take this course with a bit more foundational knowledge under your belt to make the most of it; however, it is definitely doable with less background if you are okay with figuring things out as you go. Go to office hours––I was intimidated at first but they are so open and want to guide you! The reading load is HEAVY (200–400 pages a week) so I ended up spending a lot of time on this class this semester. It was frustrating at times when I spent hours on a complex reading and felt like I walked away with a low understanding of it, but the other students a are likely just as confused by some of the readings. This is a class where you get out what you put in, especially when it comes to the readings. Overall, this class is a great way to get to know some INCREDIBLE professors and engage in a super intellectual environment with a ton of cool students, talking about some of the most relevant themes of capitalism, African American history, intersectionality, organizing, etc.

This course, for such a massive subject matter, is an incredible way to learn about a. different part of the world and decenter American understandings of the rest of the world. The readings are fun and interesting, and the course is a great introduction to the Pacific.

Take this class! Not only is it super goofy to tell people you took a course on poop, but it's actually interesting too. You learn about the history of poop recycling and waste management across the globe, and where it leaves us today. This is such a relevant course because everyone poops. Professor Howell is great and also has a sense of humor, so you're in for a good time. Readings are tough on some weeks but all in all the work is super manageable, this was such a light and fun course to finish out senior spring with.

course_title: Varieties of Fascism: Histories, Theories, Controversies 01
best_comment: Peter Gordon is an extraordinarily thoughtful professor (Michael Mango is also an excellent TF!) and the reading list was really wonderful. However, I think the format of the class sessions wasn’t the best. This class was one of those weird middle–grounds where it was meant to be a seminar but then they didn’t want to put a cap on it so it was too big for a normal seminar and became like a pseudo–lecture with a big emphasis on class discussion. I thought this format was a little bit “worst of both worlds” because you don’t get the classic, Gordon lecture which people rave about nor did you get the benefits of a small seminar where everyone’s coming really prepared to talk about the material. That said, I’m still glad I took the course and particularly enjoyed the thoughtful conversations we had about Trump/everything going on on campus this semester.

The class is great in that you are exposed to the key lit. and get to engage with Prof. Beckert who is an expert on global capitalism. While the research is really really independent, Prof. Beckert and the TF made themselves avaible.

course_title: Literature and Urban History: Views from Brazil and the United States 01
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. If truly has the most interesting readings I have ever read for any class. If you're even remotely interested in Brazilian history, urban history, urban literature, or 19th–century literature, take this class. The weekly discussion posts are super chill. The midterm paper had very interesting prompts to choose from and you receive solid feedback. Final paper also gives you ample space to branch out a bit. Cant stress enough how amazing the readings are and discussions in class! The profs are amazing.

course_title: Literature and Urban History: Views from Brazil and the United States 01
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. If truly has the most interesting readings I have ever read for any class. If you're even remotely interested in Brazilian history, urban history, urban literature, or 19th–century literature, take this class. The weekly discussion posts are super chill. The midterm paper had very interesting prompts to choose from and you receive solid feedback. Final paper also gives you ample space to branch out a bit. Cant stress enough how amazing the readings are and discussions in class! The profs are amazing.

course_title: Slavery, the Environment, and Public History 01
best_comment: One of the best history courses I have taken as a senior concentrator. Prof. Miles and Hannah are an incredible pair. Taking a course with Prof. Miles is a must, but especially a seminar, as she is truly fantastic at leading one – beginning with some time to know each other (not ice–breakers, but really understanding your "why" for the course and for caring about history in general...it built trust between us quickly, which showed in our discussions), setting high expectations for the rigor of our conversations off the bat – asking follow up questions, synthesizing our conversations, and pushing our ideas. She is truly the best at cultivating conversations that not only bring the readings to life while also pushing your critical thinking skills.Discussions were genuinely rigorous, readings were always relevant and illuminating, and the final project was a fulfilling challenge to actually put our seminar discussions into practice our discussions by having to think critically in an applied way (since the final projects were shared with the Arboretum to be implemented). If you want to be challenged in a new way as a history concentrator by being pushed to think creatively and practically (I would not recommend this to freshman/sophomores or anyone not already familiar with history), then absolutely take this course. Prof. Miles is one of the few professors on this campus who really cares for you as a person. Yes, she brings snacks to class (which is genuinely a gesture to be grateful for), but she also wants you to come to know yourself more through this course – the course challenged me to think critically about my own morals and future as a historian, because of Prof. Miles's genuine care for how history does, can, and should exist for the public. There were a few times when she asked us at the start of class to reflect about what we want to contribute to the world, and it honestly makes me emotional to remember. It's easy to lose sight of why you're studying at Harvard, but Prof. Miles will not let you forget it. This class shifted the way I think as a historian, but it was also was philosophical in a way that was fulfilling for me beyond being a historian. I will continue to think about the questions raised in this class as I go throughout my life, which is not something I can say for many courses at this school.

This is a fantastic primer on the history of the U.S. health care system. You'll learn about a variety of topics, mostly in chronological order: the early roots of the health and welfare system in widows' benefits and veterans pensions, the development of Social Security, the birth of Medicare and Medicaid, and the unfolding of the delegated/privatized state in the post–1960s era. George is a fantastic guide: he is unique in his attention to detail, and truly wants each student to leave the course a better writer and historical thinker than they entered it. He is also passionate and not afraid to offer his opinion on historical change in the health care system –– which I found refreshing. This class never bores. Take it!

course_title: Identity and the Self in the Medieval Greek Tradition 01
best_comment: Dimiter and Alex are both wonderful. Best ratio of reading length to discussion quality. Twenty page paper isn't too scary, and they give you ample scaffolding.

course_title: Identity and the Self in the Medieval Greek Tradition 01
best_comment: Dimiter and Alex are both wonderful. Best ratio of reading length to discussion quality. Twenty page paper isn't too scary, and they give you ample scaffolding.

This is the first class at Harvard where I feel like I’ve really made a difference in any tangible way. Prof. Chaplin is fantastic, the course gives you a lot of great landscaping and design ideas, and i know my future backyard will thank me for this. Take this class. Most fun 2 hours of the week every week.

course_title: Learned Cultures in Early Modern Europe 1
best_comment: This course was a great way to learn about a range of different topics and to survey the work being done in early modern European history generally. It's rare to be in a course with peers who have such wide–ranging interests but this is precisely what made this course so enriching! Ann is also a wonderful, caring professor whose dedication to the course was evident. The year–long format felt like a big commitment but it was one I'm glad I made.

course_title: Readings in Native American and Indigenous Studies: Seminar 01
best_comment: Take this class—you will grow in ways you can't yet imagine. Professor Deloria creates an environment that is challenging, inspiring, and deeply meaningful, and you will come away with a richer, more thoughtful understanding of Native American and Indigenous histories and futures.

course_title: Digital Methods and Primary Sources: Seminar 01
best_comment: Highly recommend if taking for AM Digital Humanities credit; Pizzorno is very kind and flexible.

course_title: Eastern Europe: Peoples and Empires: Proseminar 01
best_comment: This class will train you to consume a large volume of readings efficiently; provide you with an excellent foundation in historiographical analysis; and teach you a lot about the history of Eastern Europe. Professor Plokhii is phenomenal and it is worth taking the class, in addition to all the content you will learn, in order to get to know him as a scholar and person.

course_title: Readings in the U.S. in the 20th Century: Proseminar 01
best_comment: I didn't realize how greatly this class would impact me. Because I don't specialize in 20th Century US History, I assumed I'd learn more about theories and methods that I can apply to my own work—and to be sure, I did—but I thought that would be the extent of the class's enduring mark on me as a scholar. Instead, the patterns and theories we discussed (especially Gramsci), as well as the in–the–weeds–content, helped me better understand the communities I engage with for public/activist work, as well as my own family. Before this class, I often felt frustrated when trying to understand their views and unable to communicate effectively. But when Professor Suarez and Johnson so thoughtfully helped us walk through the 1910s through present, I suddenly see my own family and community in the changing contours of political thought. As a result, I've been able to communicate with them more effectively and also engage with advocacy in a more meaningful way. This course changed my life and is really going to stick with me going forward.

course_title: Readings in the U.S. in the 20th Century: Proseminar 01
best_comment: I didn't realize how greatly this class would impact me. Because I don't specialize in 20th Century US History, I assumed I'd learn more about theories and methods that I can apply to my own work—and to be sure, I did—but I thought that would be the extent of the class's enduring mark on me as a scholar.
