This course changed my life and is really going to stick with me going forward.

course_title: Legal History Workshop: Technology and the Law 01
best_comment: Do not underestimate the depth of the readings. It is usually a decent amount, but they can be incredibly dense as well as quite long. Also, get started on your essay early. DO NOT WAIT UNTIL READING PERIOD. The amount of citations alone will take you several nights to do.

course_title: Legal History Workshop: Technology and the Law 01
best_comment: Do not underestimate the depth of the readings. It is usually a decent amount, but they can be incredibly dense as well as quite long. Also, get started on your essay early. DO NOT WAIT UNTIL READING PERIOD. The amount of citations alone will take you several nights to do.

course_title: Readings in Modern Latin American History 01
Readings in Modern Latin American History 01

best_comment: This course is what you make of it, you can coast and not let it touch you or really engage with the materials and questions it poses, it's up to uou

Morgan is such a great teacher and is so engaging. The class really felt like a book club, where we were all able to share our thoughts, synthesize them, and discuss big themes of the era in interesting and applicable ways. Great content, great structure, great teacher. Would recommend.

course_title: Contesting Citizenship in the United States 001
best_comment: This was one of the best courses I've taken at Harvard. The materials were so well–curated, and Lila is a gem of a teacher. I left every session feeling like a new world had opened up. Please take if you get the change! The arguments we learn about are also so helpful to know in the Trump era.

course_title: Contesting Citizenship in the United States 001
best_comment: This was one of the best courses I've taken at Harvard. The materials were so well–curated, and Lila is a gem of a teacher. I left every session feeling like a new world had opened up. Please take if you get the change! The arguments we learn about are also so helpful to know in the Trump era.

Dr. Sylvain is great and facilitates interesting discussions. You have to take this course to really understand the depths of its title. Very enjoyable material and the small group setting is great for exploring the topics.

course_title: Hollywood’s Seventies: The U.S. on Film, 1970-1980 001
best_comment: One of my favorite classes at Harvard and I am a CS major who took this as an elective. The film choices are excellent and found myself loving almost all of the films we watched. Even the couple of films that may have been on the slower side or weren't as good as some of the classics we watched, had very rich themes that led to great class discussions. This is a class where you get as much as what you put into it. The readings, while some weeks were a bit long, were very interesting and insightful, especially about such a rich period of American history that was the 70s. We read about the Vietnam War, New Hollywood, 70s disillusionment, crime, violence, family, feminism, and so much more. Professor Biel is also amazing. He facilitates really fun and interesting discussions, where you do a deep dive into the films you watch, and gives incredible feedback on your short essays. I couldn't recommend this class more and if you like watching film, then this class never feels like work

course_title: Magic and Mythology in Latin America and the Caribbean 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! The course materials are so interesting, meaningful, and must be treated with care. The group of students are wonderful and the work you do in the class is truly special and super self–led in that you get a lot of creative freedom.  I was able to learn so much about my own culture and identity, and this is all due to the wonderful teaching of Professora Cristina Garcia Navas. I am so grateful that courses like this exisit!

Professor Izadi is the BEST professor at Harvard. She’s so kind, funny, and supportive. You’d not regret taking a class with her. Take this class and all the other classes she’s offering. She’s truly an angel.

course_title: Music, Politics, and Protest in the United States 001
best_comment: This was a wonderful class! The seminars were varied and interesting, though I do wish we did more historical analysis rather than just a survey of many different types of sonic protests. The highlight was the assignments; the term paper and final project were both fascinating and really rewarding experiences, and Caitlin did a great job of ensuring we gained the background to make such ambitious works.

The two short paper assignments were fun because you got to draw blueprints of buildings, but otherwise, I did not find the material that engaging or interesting. Definitely depends on the person, but this class showed me architecture is not one of my passions, of if learning about various historical buildings and the intricacies of them, then its for you. Be prepared to sit through lectures of professors speaking for the entire class with little detail in slide,s but if you're fine with that, then class would suit you.  Exams are really just rote learning so be prepared for that.
worse_comment: Good class to take if you need to add something to a busy schedule. You can get away with skipping lecture, but the only downside is that the midterm + final are all about material covered in lecture (that is not really gone over in section). It's a chill class but just very boring.

best_comment: The two short paper assignments were fun because you got to draw blueprints of buildings, but otherwise, I did not find the material that engaging or interesting. Definitely depends on the person, but this class showed me architecture is not one of my passions, of if learning about various historical buildings and the intricacies of them, then its for you. Be prepared to sit through lectures of professors speaking for the entire class with little detail in slide,s but if you're fine with that, then class would suit you.  Exams are really just rote learning so be prepared for that.
worse_comment: Good class to take if you need to add something to a busy schedule. You can get away with skipping lecture, but the only downside is that the midterm + final are all about material covered in lecture (that is not really gone over in section). It's a chill class but just very boring.

best_comment: Please, take this course. I’m not an architecture student, nor do I even study History of Art and Architecture, but this was easily one of my favorite classes at Harvard. Professor Lippit is extraordinary. His lectures are among the best I've experienced here: intellectually rich, deeply engaging, and delivered with genuine kindness and support.This course goes far beyond architectural fundamentals but  offers a rare and  intimate exploration of Japanese history, culture, and religion. I left with a completely new framework for thinking about beauty, lived experience, and art. Please consider taking this class, it really represents what a Harvard education should be about.
best_gem_comment: Everything about this course was amazing, it's so clear that the lectures, assignments, readings, and sections were thoroughly thought about and structured. Professor Lippit is an absolute gem of a person; every lecture was so engaging, and it's so clear how much he cares about the material and how knowledgeable he is. He's also so incredibly kind and cares about his students! I liked that this course was also so much more than just about architecture, as it covered engineering, environment, urban design, history, and so much more, which gave the class a holistic look at Japan's built environment in its totality. The workload is also not too bad; there are response papers every week, and they do require some thought and some time with the readings, but the grading system for them makes them not too stressful.There are not really any shortcomings with this class, I think my one thing is that there is not a lot of facilitation for your own analysis and reflections on the architecture outside of what is given in lecture and the readings. I do wish that were was more space for discussion or writing towards more open–ended questions about the architecture, but because there's just so much content, it makes sense why there isn't, since there's just so much to get through. The exams aren't too stressful, but it does take time to remember the dates and locations of each site and not mix them up. Overall though, this is a class that's wonderful because it caters towards students of all types of backgrounds and exposures to architecture (including having no prior experience), and you will come away with a larger understanding of not just architecture in Japan, but also how architecture is shaped by the culture, politics, and traditions of the past and present.

best_comment: Take this class!!!! prof georgentelli is the absolute best. she truly loves her students and makes such an effort to get to know everyone in the class. Honestly would recommend any class she teaches but money matters is the absolute best. As someone from an econ backround this was such an interesting perspective to learn about the art and political function of money before heading into the finance world. Readings can be long but you don't really need to complete all of them. section is the best. essentially just handling several ancient and valuable coins that harvard has in their collections.  Truly a once in a lifetime opportunity and made me so grateful to be a harvard student.
worse_comment: I would say only take this class if you are just starting out in HAA or aren't super interested in art history because there it can get super economics–heavy lol, not a ton of deep art historical analysis goes on
best_gem_comment: This class used to be a gem, but now there is definitely more busy work to it.  The professor is so sweet, you should go to office hours and spend time getting to know her... There seems to be organization disconnect between professor, TFs, and students.... You get no feedback on your discussion posts throughout the semester, so you have no idea how you're doing in the class.

course_title: Introduction to Buddhist Arts of Space and Place 001
best_comment: It was a very fun course to take. I went into it knowing very little about Buddhism, and I feel like I learned a lot

High workload, high payoff. As an HAA Architecture Studies concentrator, I needed to take this class, but I am glad I took it regardless. It totally took over my semester and was often very frustrating with late nights in the studio and early mornings scrambling, but I loved it and became friends with pretty much everyone in the class. Truly think I came to a new level of understanding of architecture, design, and the creative process as a whole, with every little consideration that goes into it. Was very cool to feel that happen in real time, which hadn't happened to me before.
worse_comment: Know that you're not bad at architecture just because the only kind of feedback you get is negative critique, that is just the structure of the GSD so that's how the course operates. Also, be prepared to work a lot. Personally I didn't have much of a life outside of this class this semester and had to pull a few all–nighters (as someone who had never done an all–nighter before). It felt like an unsupportive introduction class because it didn’t feel like an environment where you could make mistakes, ask questions, or not be knowledgeable. There was some active eye–rolling when I asked questions even though it was an intro class and so of course you would have questions. They also don’t teach how to use of the software in a very clear way which makes the assignments stressful and hard to figure out. For reference, a metaphor someone else in the class came up with was that this class is like having a paper due before every single class (meets Mondays and Wednesdays) but each time it’s in a new language and instead of being taught the grammar of any of those languages you’re just told everything you did wrong. It’s quite a stressful process but you will become very capable even though there's quite a learning curve.  I wouldn't recommend this class unless you have to take it but you will feel proud of yourself afterwards.

best_comment: Great course! Really brought together more what we learned in HAA96A and fine tuned our architectural drawing skills (esp drawing with Rhino and Photoshop which we didn't do much in the previous course). I feel like i learned so so much through the structure of this course that was more conceptually continuous from beginning to end than 96A. We were given a topic in the very beginning that pretty much stayed through all the various assignments and built up more and more later into the semester which is really enjoyed! Very happy with my last semester of studio, and prepares great for various skills needed for senior thesis!

Be prepared to engage meaningfully with very dense art historical scholarship paired with contemporary discourse and scholarship. This course will make you a better art historian, give you a better sense of art history's stakes, and is applicable far beyond black art as you will be able to understand a multitude of art objects through a deep orientation with a specific scholarly lens. You will leave this course with a deep understanding of the history of race as an aesthetic construct, as well as with a better grasp of a plethora of methodological approaches to art history that expand upon the foundation built through intro art history courses.

I'm glad I took this tutorial. You will get as much out of this class as you put in. Putting effort into the assignments, doing the readings, and participating in class makes for a good course. This is the type of class that becomes lackluster when not everyone participates.

Even though you might not study the field, I’d still recommend taking HAA100r. It’s such a great opportunity to meet other concentrators and really get to know them well – I’ve become close friends with many of them since the excursion. It was also so nice to know the professors who are all really kind and approachable!

Even though you might not study the field, I’d still recommend taking HAA100r. It’s such a great opportunity to meet other concentrators and really get to know them well – I’ve become close friends with many of them since the excursion. It was also so nice to know the professors who are all really kind and approachable!

Even though you might not study the field, I’d still recommend taking HAA100r. It’s such a great opportunity to meet other concentrators and really get to know them well – I’ve become close friends with many of them since the excursion. It was also so nice to know the professors who are all really kind and approachable!

course_title: Topics in Arabic Art and Culture: Art of the Qur'an 001
best_comment: Professor Roxburgh's class is challenging but well worth it. I would recommend this course to any who are even remotely interested in the arts of the Islamic book as well as the Qur'an as an art object. You can survive without Arabic, but any Arabic training will definitely prove useful!

course_title: Artisanal Modernism & the Labor of Women 001
best_comment: Such a fun class! This obviously depends on your classmates to some extent, but Professor Gough and my peers made the class conversations so lively and engaging.  I also appreciated the structure of every class, which often (not always) started with a quick presentation by Professor Gough that provided an overview of the topic as well as can supplement any gaps in understanding the denser readings. This is then followed by looking at objects and art in the study center. We had a trip to the MoMA in April which is a great experience to speak to curators and other Harvard faculty.

course_title: Color in the Era of the Colony 001
best_comment: This class was one of my favorites I have taken at Harvard. The class trip was amazing and allowed the students to bond, but also was so insightful to the course material. I could not recommend more taking a class with Professor Lajer–Burcharth; she is knowledgeable and all of her feedback in and out of class is useful and constructive. She leads the class extremely well and makes us feel comfortable with the material and sharing our opinions. She treats the material with care and it is evident she is passion about these topics, which is infectuous. The course is structured wonderfully and we get to look at different material each week.

Prof. Kelsey is great and this course is super interesting if you're interested in photography and art history. I would definitely recommend taking this class, especially to expand your concept of art history and modern art. Some of the readings and photography analysis in the modern era requires keeping an open mind to what photography should/can look like, so I would especially recommend if you're interested in modern art and how photography can move into the present day.
worse_comment: If you see a class with Professor Kelsey, take it!! You may not get an A, but you will come out a more precise speaker, writer, and thinker.  Don't let your GPA stop you from taking this!

best_comment: There was very limited information about this class going into it so I didn't fully know what to expect. Overall, I really enjoyed this class and am glad that I took it. The class is focused on how racial hierarchies are created and perpetuated through art. It will expose you to dark truths that America often tries to ignore. I loved the lessons on art and indigenous Americans and art and the Japanese intonement and wish that there was more time spent focusing on this throughout the course. I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in the African American experience and race studies through an art history lens. Sometimes I felt the course was a little repetitive however Professor Lewis is a very caring lecturer who really takes the time to understand her students. I really appreciated how each class began with time sharing what we were grateful for that week. There was a lot of flexibility in the final project which was great for exploring.

course_title: Gender and Art in Japan and Beyond 001
best_comment: This course is tough as an undergrad because it is dominated by PhD students, who made up about 3/4 of the class. They had extensive specific background knowledge that made some conversations difficult to follow. That aspect of the course is not ideal, but Professor McCormick is awesome and does her best to make discussions accessible to all backgrounds. She clearly cares about her students and wants everyone to succeed, and that is why the class is enjoyable.

course_title: Architecture, Urbanism, and Design in a Global South Asia: 18th century to the present 001
best_comment: Highly recommended! Professor Khandelwal structures each weekly seminar to be both collaborative and engaging. I learned a great deal about Global South Asia and of art historical methods through this course.

Highly recommend this class! Professor Blier is a phenomenal teacher who is well versed in the subject and presents it in an interesting way. The material spans across many years and regions giving you new and interesting material to work with. You also get to focus on your favorite subject for the final paper.
worse_comment: I would recommend taking this class if you have some basic knowledge of African architecture and native building material, because if not, lectures could be disorienting or confusing. The class material is also very broad and expansive, and it could be difficult to follow along with all of the content because of how the material is structured weekly. It is also not very structured.

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!!! It is truly a once–in–a–lifetime opportunity! You will get to go behind the scenes and see things that many museum staff don't even get to see (a few examples from this semester: seeing a John Singer Sargent painting which had NEVER been displayed, seeing the other *half* of the glass flowers collection which is in storage, and getting to touch a David Drake pot). Conservation labs are endlessly fascinating, and we got to go on field trips almost every week! Profs Roberts and Ballard were wonderful complements to each other––Prof. Roberts provided the academic art historians' perspective while Prof. Ballard provided the working curator's perspective. And both of them were wonderfully creative and supportive of students' work!

course_title: The Object in the Art Museum 001
best_comment: Take this class (please please please remember to apply on time – it is popular and hard to get in but if you demonstrate your own interesting perspectives you stand a great shot!)! This class had about 5–6 undergrads and the rest (8) were grad students across HAA, HKS, HLS, and the Divinity School. Everyone brought such interesting ideas and perspectives to every class. Joachim and Kate are incredible professors and you will gain a totally new appreciation for art and art museums by learning everything from art dealers to provenance to restoration and everything in between.  The weekly assignments and readings aren't too long but to get the most out of the course you should do them. The major project of the course is a 10 page paper on an object you pick (that will be going into an exhibit – our kunstkamer objects go on display in July 2025, more on that later) and it's super interesting.On the objects, this was mainly about Dutch 16–17th century art. Since our collection is going up I'm not sure what the focus will be but it's worth reaching out and asking because if you aren't at all interested in the theme you won't get as much out of the course as someone who is – like we all became experts on Dutch 16–17th century art. All in all, my favorite course at Harvard and my only Arts and Humanities course and what an incredible way to finish up college.

course_title: The Object in the Art Museum 001
best_comment: Take this class (please please please remember to apply on time – it is popular and hard to get in but if you demonstrate your own interesting perspectives you stand a great shot!)! This class had about 5–6 undergrads and the rest (8) were grad students across HAA, HKS, HLS, and the Divinity School. Everyone brought such interesting ideas and perspectives to every class. Joachim and Kate are incredible professors and you will gain a totally new appreciation for art and art museums by learning everything from art dealers to provenance to restoration and everything in between.  The weekly assignments and readings aren't too long but to get the most out of the course you should do them. The major project of the course is a 10 page paper on an object you pick (that will be going into an exhibit – our kunstkamer objects go on display in July 2025, more on that later) and it's super interesting.On the objects, this was mainly about Dutch 16–17th century art. Since our collection is going up I'm not sure what the focus will be but it's worth reaching out and asking because if you aren't at all interested in the theme you won't get as much out of the course as someone who is – like we all became experts on Dutch 16–17th century art. All in all, my favorite course at Harvard and my only Arts and Humanities course and what an incredible way to finish up college.

course_title: Works of Art: Materials, Forms, Histories 001

best_comment: this course is so wonderful! you learn so much about history of science and how various subjects /topics overlap. i highly recommend !
this course is so wonderful! you learn so much about history of science and how various subjects /topics overlap. i highly recommend !

This course is a tough one to figure out. The structure is a little strange, with overlapping assignments, but fully manageable. I highly recommend taking this course before HS100 if you like learning in lecture form, as a lot of the material overlaps. If you like being the section kid, then post–HS100 for sure. I think the problem with this course is that it accomplishes some goals and fails at others. The in the boxes project sets you up nicely for archival research, and I think it really changed the way that I approach archives at Harvard. But, the lectures are long and don't actually have that much content in them. It is a 2 hour plenary block where a class full of students pretends to have done a reading we didn't really do. The readings are easy to fake having done, so very few put in that extra effort. Grading wise, it is super fair, and the course staff is incredibly kind. The professors and TFs are AWESOME, and I really loved the final presentation aspect. It is definitely a low pressure environment in which to test research ideas and thoughts on your Junior paper topic.
worse_comment: This class is boring, but a requirement. You can kind of slack off and be fine — just do quality work on the assignments. You can basically sleep through class. I have no idea what was ever discussed in this class; the content is kind of useless.

best_comment: This course is a tough one to figure out. The structure is a little strange, with overlapping assignments, but fully manageable. I highly recommend taking this course before HS100 if you like learning in lecture form, as a lot of the material overlaps. If you like being the section kid, then post–HS100 for sure. worse_comment: This class is boring, but a requirement. You can kind of slack off and be fine — just do quality work on the assignments. You can basically sleep through class. I have no idea what was ever discussed in this class; the content is kind of useless.

best_comment: This course gets progressively harder as the year goes on and the deadline for the final paper approaches. It is helpful to have a topic in mind beforehand, or at least a general idea of what fields or time frames you are interested in researching , but it is definitely not necessary. The course is designed to leave more than enough time for a person to explore different ideas and hone in on one. Additionally, the course is designed to where the assignments consistently build off of each other. During the last few weeks of the course, the time I spent working on the course significantly skyrocketed as I was consistently reading, writing, or revising. However, the course is an overall positive experience as you create a final paper that relates to a topic of interest. Also, the course has a lot of built in support and feedback!

This course gets progressively harder as the year goes on and the deadline for the final paper approaches. It is helpful to have a topic in mind beforehand, or at least a general idea of what fields or time frames you are interested in researching , but it is definitely not necessary. The course is designed to leave more than enough time for a person to explore different ideas and hone in on one. Additionally, the course is designed to where the assignments consistently build off of each other. During the last few weeks of the course, the time I spent working on the course significantly skyrocketed as I was consistently reading, writing, or revising. However, the course is an overall positive experience as you create a final paper that relates to a topic of interest. Also, the course has a lot of built in support and feedback!

Writing a thesis is a rewarding process. You get to explore any topic and become an expert in it. Start your thesis EARLY. My best advice is to finish two chapters before winter break, rather than just one –– you will be grateful during break and in the second semester. Set firm deadlines and tasks for yourself to make sure you stay on track and don't procrastinate until the end (for example, I wrote 500 words, 4 days per week –– this meant each chapter was drafted in ~3 weeks, giving me ample time to edit and continue research, and I didn't feel the need to work on my thesis every single day. Do what is manageable and makes sense to you!) Seek extra feedback in the beginning as you craft the outline and proposal so that you have a strong foundation as you start writing.

Writing a thesis was a lovely experience — it was definitely a huge project, and I did get crunched at the end, but I don't have any regrets. The tutorial part of this class is not the most stringent, so make sure you're keeping up with your own work and maintaining a good relationship with your advisor. Good luck!

course_title: Modern Life Science: From Pasteur to CRISPR 001
best_comment: Take this class. Professor Kochhar is one of the kindest, most thoughtful instructors I have ever had at Harvard, and I always looked forward to having class with him. The readings are fascinating, and even if you are not into the life sciences from a technical perspective, the classroom discussions often focussed on the broader cultural or societal implications of science, which meant anybody with an interest in how science impacts our daily lives and values had a valuable perspective to contribute. This was one of my favorite classes I took at Harvard, and I was seriously impressed that this is only Professor Kochhar's first year teaching — he is an incredible asset to the department and he has a unique ability to connect with students and foster an inclusive and open classroom environment where everybody's opinion is valued.

course_title: Race and Public Health Crises: From TB to AIDS to COVID-19 001
best_comment: I think every public health student should take this class. So much of what we are taught in public health school is presented without much or any historical context, and this course was an incredible helpful corrective to that pedagogical practice. Also it was an honor to take a class from an amazing team of public health historians who did a great job of selecting excellent readings and other source material.
worse_comment: The course instructors don’t seem to have a solid grip on what  they want this course to be which led to a lot of confusion and frustration among the students in the course. I would not recommend this course if you are just starting out with the content matter, this course is better suited for committed AAAS concentrators

course_title: Race and Public Health Crises: From TB to AIDS to COVID-19 001
best_comment: I think every public health student should take this class. So much of what we are taught in public health school is presented without much or any historical context, and this course was an incredible helpful corrective to that pedagogical practice. Also it was an honor to take a class from an amazing team of public health historians who did a great job of selecting excellent readings and other source material.

I would not recommend this course if you are just starting out with the content matter, this course is better suited for committed AAAS concentrators

course_title: Food, Science, and the Invention of Global Hunger 001
best_comment: This is a fascinating class–Professor Soto Laveaga is one of the best professors I've learned from while here, and she does a great job of encouraging discussion and designing an interesting syllabus. The class has great flow. You'll always be making connections with prior weeks as you move throughout the semester, and it's a wonderful learning experience.

One of the best classes I've taken! I took this senior spring, and it is super chill. Professor Robinson is one of the most funny and engaging professors ever. His lectures are not boring at all, so informative, and relevant to the readings we do before class. Readings can get a bit long on weeks when you have other work especially since we have to comment on them through Perusall, but it is usually manageable and I learned a lot from reading and responding to comments from my classmates. The take–home midterm is also long, but managable and reasonable if you start early. Final project is very creative or a paper, but very up to you and again fine if you start early. The TFs are nice and answer any questions you have. Professor Robinson and the TFs make it known that they really want us to succeed and if we let them know we're having a stressful week then they are usually very understanding about it and flexible as long as you get your work done. As a senior spring pre–med, this course was incredibly useful for connecting almost all the ideas and concepts I've learned in my time here. It approaches everything I've seen from a different perspective. It was my first time taking a HistSci course, and it was great. I don't love history, so at times the readings and lectures got a bit dry, but Professor Robinson as a lecturer really fixes that and keeps things new and engaging. The readings really taught me a lot and to see and think about things in a different way. Amazing course, highly recommend!
best_gem_comment: Definitely wouldn’t take if looking for a gem. It’s a lot of work and a lot of hours outside of class. However, the teaching staff is very passionate and really care about the students so while a lot of work it’s still a good course and most times easy to stay engaged with if interested in any of the three: race, war, or medicine.

best_comment: Pretty interesting class and somewhat well structured, but assignments are graded super strictly and arbitrarily. On the blog posts, you're given feedback at the halfway point, but the feedback makes it seem as though they were looking for one particular thing all along when they told you at the beginning of the class that the blog posts are designed to be flexible and for you to write about whatever content feels meaningful to you. Same goes for the final essay; they frame it as if you can be flexible and do what you want with it, then their comments make very clear that you had to do very specific things in your essay in order to do well. Because there's only a few assignments, there's not really a buffer. For the final essay in particular, there wasn't a set rubric and their grading seemed very arbitrary. Don't get me wrong — this is a decent class with super interesting content at times, and decently well taught, but keep in mind it can bite you in the foot very easily if you care about your grade. (It's the type of teacher who will tell you great job and then give you a B+).

course_title: Open Minds, Wired Worlds: Computers and Cyberculture 001
best_comment: I highly recommend this course for anyone interested in the history of technology.

course_title: From Steam Engines to Silicon Valley: Science and Capitalism in History 001
best_comment: Was a STEM major before this course, but after taking it I became a HistSci major. Torracinta's a great instructor! Love his presentations and engagement with the topic –– rich with content but easy to comprehend as you piece together history through the lens of the course. Readings are 50–100 pages a week and the unit reflections are the main tests of your comprehension as you move through the units. It's definitely course that you get more out of the more you put into it, and I'd recommend even if you aren't quite sold on history of science.

This is a great course that introduces you to new ways of thinking about information and information technologies! Professor Csiszar really cares about tailoring the course to student interests. Class is very discussion based and often led to very insightful conversations. Assignments were very flexible and give a lot of room to explore topics you are interested in. I highly recommend!

Great class! Not too hard but definitely gets you thinking. Great balance of consuming material and synthesizing your own thoughts, and a lot of fun to read and watch influential examples of science fiction in popular culture.

course_title: Bias, Hype, and Objectivity in Science 001
best_comment: Ask bigger picture questions through the combination of the readings. It takes time to reflect but the approach is definitely valuable. Prof. Richardson is also very open to discussion. brainstorming ideas, not just about assignments but also the content in general, is really helpful and stimulating experience.

course_title: Agnotology: The History of Knowledge and Ignorance 001
best_comment: This class quickly became one of the best courses I have ever taken at Harvard. This class is DIFFICULT. You are expected to read, comprehend, and succinctly summarize 300–1000 pages of reading per week. But this, I have come to realize, is gold–standard pedagogy. Our discussions felt electric and vital, because everyone came to class with such a strong grasp of the material. Professor Oreskes is an engaging, thought–provoking seminar leader. This was an intellectual feast!!! It was challenging in the best way, and full of fascinating case studies. The study of ignorance is incredibly important, and this class will shift the way you think about knowledge and power. EXCELLENT class.

course_title: Environment and Society in the Premodern World 001
best_comment: This class has expanded my understanding of "environmental history" by asking the very simple question: what was environment in the past, especially the pre–modern era? This has allowed us to consider as a classroom both today's environmental conundrums but also the very different demands of ancient and early modern environments and the variety of human adaptations to them. This has been a great opportunity to learn from peers across the Humanities and Social Sciences at Harvard, and I am immensely grateful for it.

course_title: Environment and Society in the Premodern World 001
best_comment: This class has expanded my understanding of "environmental history" by asking the very simple question: what was environment in the past, especially the pre–modern era? This has allowed us to consider as a classroom both today's environmental conundrums but also the very different demands of ancient and early modern environments and the variety of human adaptations to them. This has been a great opportunity to learn from peers across the Humanities and Social Sciences at Harvard, and I am immensely grateful for it.

This class is incredible and I’m so glad I took it! The material covers a thorough range of Cold War topics from all sorts of interesting perspectives. The readings always surprised me, and I learned new, mind–blowing things every week. It made me draw connections between many ideas I’d encountered in science, economics, and daily life that I would never have thought about otherwise.Prof. Wilson is a really excellent professor. He is skilled at guiding discussions towards interesting questions without controlling the conversation. He challenged and elaborated on students’ points in a productive way that made me think more critically, all in a welcoming and encouraging environment. His feedback throughout the final paper process was super helpful, and I appreciated that he was always happy to talk more about anything vaguely history of science or Cold War related.The course was well–structured and the readings were interesting. There was a reasonable workload of weekly readings and discussion posts, which made me feel prepared for class discussion without feeling over–burdened. The class discussions leaned on the variety of expertise in the room from everyone’s different backgrounds, and this made the conversations really insightful. I left each class more curious than I was before, in a way that I have not experienced in other courses. That was a genuine highlight of my semester. This is one of the best courses I’ve ever taken at Harvard, and I would highly recommend it!!!
worse_comment: Prof. Wilson is phenomenal and considerate—if you are interested in the relationship between government and the university, the role of professional science in war (cold or otherwise), or twentieth–century American foreign policy... take this class!

best_comment: This class brought together students from different disciplines but to me proved that interdisciplinarity is not necessarily an end in itself. Even though a lot of the texts were densely theoretical, many in the class had never read things of the sort in the past, so there was a limit to the common language we had during class discussions, which I wish had engaged more deeply with the material.  The group paper was 50% of the course grade, in the spirit of collaboration, but could be quite frustrating at times due to aforementioned problems with common language and experience with researching and writing papers adjacent to the history of science and the kind of original work that was expected.Still, Prof. Galison put together a very interesting syllabus and navigated as deftly as he could the various disciplinary backgrounds present in the class. I learned a lot from people who studied everything from literature to biology to physics that I certainly wouldn't have learned if not this course and the conversations it facilitated. Galison is also just such an interesting scholar, and this class is a great excuse to read some of his work and get to talk to him about it.

course_title: The Human Brain in the Animal Kingdom 001
best_comment: This course had excellent material and a great teaching staff. The topics were interesting, and the lectures were great. I loved my experience in this course. I take away a new appreciation for neurology and a deeper understanding of how brains and brain regions work and have evolved. This course made me realize that there is a lot more to biology than my concentration and what I had learned in previous classes. I feel more well–rounded after this class and I am so glad that I took it. I recommend doing the readings because they are fun, and please pay attention in class. Erin has wonderful things to say, and this really is a great class. It is a lot easier to do well if you pay attention. Because of the note sheet we get on exams, it is easy to think you don't have to learn, but by taking in the information as you go, tests are easier, and this helps build a stronger backbone for the final project components. I recommend this course very highly, and though my concentration in biology is not HEB, I truly loved learning everything in this course. If you enjoy learning, and are interested in an almost intro to neurology course, this is definitely an excellent course for you. I had so much fun and I wish I could have taken all of Erin's classes (as a senior, I'm leaving). Truly truly a magnificent class that was really fun as well!

Great class. Andrew is great. This is the first time this course has been run so it will NOT be the same next year as it was this year so whatever I would can say is likely going to change. Probably even better next year. Andrew wants to add some fun labs and other stuff so it should be pretty cool.

WOW! This class was a bit crazy! HEB 55 is not for the faint of heart! This is the second hardest class that I have taken at Harvard behind Chem 30. Know that if you are taking HEB 55 and want to do well, this class will have to be your highest priority! From attachments, insertions, innervations, and actions of dozens of muscles, to all the bones in the human body, to biomechanical concepts, to physiology, to evolutionary ideas, there is so much content to learn in every unit that it is overwhelming. YOU WILL STRUGGLE AT SOME POINT no matter how good of a student you are, but THAT IS OK. I really learned what I was made of in this class, especially at these moments. From what I understand from other students in this class who had taken LS2, this class is much harder, so be cautious before just treating HEB 55 as a replacement, which is what I thought it was. Here is my advice to succeed. 1. YOU HAVE TO STUDY AT LEAST 3–4 DAYS A WEEK. Make Anki flashcards with the lecture slides and muscles on them and practice them over and over and over and over and over and over and over! I mean it! YOU CANNOT STUDY FOR THESE EXAMS THE WEEK BEFORE!2. Don't waste time learning all the muscle attachments unless you understand everything else in a lot of detail already. The muscle attachments matter for so little that understanding the evolutionary concepts, the physiological conceots, what the muscles look like, and what the muscles do is much more important.3. Do well on the first two exams because the limbs exam is WAY HARDER than the other two, so you will not be able to do well at the end of the course. 4. Go to office hours and ask questions! Cary and Jo are great teachers, so definately use them as a resource._______________________That said, this course does have some problems.1) The course is a bit outdated. In the age where the internet is so accessible and everyone uses AI, there is really not much of a need to learn the muscle attachments. Anyone can look that up in 5 seconds. The emphasis should really be on what the muscles look like and what they do. Because both instructors have a PhD in anatomy, I understand that theythink everything is important, but as a result of focussing on a lot of the more useless material that can not simply be looked up online or asked to Siri, some of the important biology concepts were lost.2) This course focusses too much on anatomy and not enough on physiology. I understand that the course is titled Human Evolutionary Anatomy, but what the instructors don't realize is that 90% of the class is looking for a physiology class like LS2 in the spring because they couldn't fit it into their fall class schedule. That is why I took the class too, and I was a bit dissapointed because I was hoping to learn a bit more physiology that I could use in Med School and beyond. I think this class should focus more on physiology, and if students want to learn about anatomy exclusively, they can cross–enroll at the Med School. 3) There are small inconsistencies between the lecture slides and the section handouts and the muscle tables, which is a little bit annoying. Often the start of the next lecture would be correcting mistakes on slides in the previous lecture. This was frustrating, as I was trying to learn the material along the way. It would be great if the instructors tried to avoid this issue going forward. 4) Finally, the grading policy for this class is kind of brutal, with the difficult exams making up 60%. That doesn't sound bad, but that means that if you want to get an A– or A in the class, you are gonna need upper 80s or higher on the exams, which is hard considering there are 75–100 questions on each exam and there is very little (if any) partial credit on these questions. You either know it or you don't. I appreciate that this year the instructors only had 3 exams rather than 4, but even so it was still brutal.Good luck if you decide to take HEB 55
worse_comment: If you're unsure about med school/PA school/whatever career in healthcare, I suggest that you take this course (over LS1A/Chem/whatever). HEB55 most highly resembles what it'd be like to take courses in med school/PA school/whatever. It is very, very difficult and really shocks you into understanding the stakes and amount of hard work required.

course_title: Sophomore Tutorial in Human Evolutionary Biology 004
best_comment: 1. Clearer prompts. For essays worth such a large portion of the grade, the prompts are impressively ambiguous. Going to office hours just to figure out what they're asking for is a must, or else you're just cooked. I went to writing center once and my tutor read the prompt and literally asked me "do you know what this is saying?" and I'm like "If I knew I wouldn't be here."2. The structure of the class just doesn't make sense, the first essay is due way before any kind of writing activities are done in class, so if you've never written a scientific paper before you're on your own. Research only helps so much. Same for the writing center. A majority of the tutors are philosophy/English/hist&lit etc. so they most likely have never encountered much scientific writing either. There's a lot I learned about scientific writing in this class (which is great, because this is a seminar meant to teach scientific writing!). Unfortunately, it was at the cost of my grade, as there is no other guidance aside from just the feedback and grade on your paper after you already turn it in. 3. I love my preceptor, don't get me wrong, she is so sweet but the course setback is just not that ideal.

course_title: Sophomore Tutorial in Human Evolutionary Biology 005
best_comment: Sophomore Tutorial is definitely time consuming, but you'll learn a lot! I feel much more prepared to enter other HEB courses after completing Sophomore Tutorial. The readings are occasionally difficult, but it's cool to see yourself having an easier time with them over the course of the semester. I will say that your experience of the course is likely to vary quite a bit depending on who your instructor is, but they are all good just different from one another. The essays can be a bit daunting at first (or, at least, were for me because I wasn't quite sure what was expected) but you get very strong feedback on each of the papers and they become easier. Also: I highly recommend taking HEB97 and GenEd1027 in conjunction with one another. The two courses complement each other quite well and information from one carries over to the other.

course_title: Research in Human Biomechanics and Physiology 001
best_comment: This class is a great way to get started in HEB and science research, especially if you're interested in Prof. Lieberman's work (which is wide–ranging and varies by semester, so feel free to ask). You get to have your own project (as part of a larger one of a grad student or completely new one), collect data, and present the results in a very casual, low–stakes setting. There isn't much class structure since everyone is working on different timelines, which adds nice flexibility to your weekly schedule. Only point is that research does not care that you're taking a class. I had no presentable/publishable data at the end, though it was still good practice to write an intro and methods and present "results."

course_title: Research in Human Biomechanics and Physiology 001
best_comment: This class is a great way to get started in HEB and science research, especially if you're interested in Prof. Lieberman's work (which is wide–ranging and varies by semester, so feel free to ask). You get to have your own project (as part of a larger one of a grad student or completely new one), collect data, and present the results in a very casual, low–stakes setting. There isn't much class structure since everyone is working on different timelines, which adds nice flexibility to your weekly schedule. Only point is that research does not care that you're taking a class. I had no presentable/publishable data at the end, though it was still good practice to write an intro and methods and present "results."

course_title: Evolution, Anatomy and Physiology of Sleep 001
best_comment: This is a really fun way to improve your scientific research skills! The expectations earlier in the semester aren't super high, so it's manageable with some harder classes. Be prepared however to write a long research paper for your final assignment. As a biologist myself, I liked that this class allowed me to improve my coding and quantitative research skills. Quite important for a thesis if you haven't done much computational work before! It also is a great opportunity to work on your scientific writing. I would also add that I'm really not too interested in sleep/neuroscience/etc, and I still got quite a bit out of this class.One more comment: A handful of class members took this as their science distribution. I wouldn't necessarily recommend this class if you don't have any science experience. You have to code a decent amount and write an original research paper on a study of your own design. It's not absurdly rigorous for students who have done scientific research before (unless you're interested in turning your work into a thesis or something), but it seemed to be pretty overwhelming for people who had never seen a p–value before.

course_title: African Climate: Earth's history, humanity's future 001
best_comment: RUN AND TAKE THIS CLASS! This class not only engages you with interesting perspectives on the origins of climate change in Africa, but also is taught by a very interesting, fun professor with A BREADTH OF KNOWLEDGE!! He does research in Kenya every summer and is very informed, and is a helpful resource if you wanna get into the field. He is also very, very approachable and has an open mind, and welcomes new ideas into discussions. Come ready to engage because the readings are so interesting. The final project is also very fulfilling, and the professor looks out for opportunities for students to keep engaging with the subject matter. Daniel Green is truly an invaluable asset to Harvard, and I was privileged to know him!
worse_comment: Green is quite a particular teacher, will score you low sometimes.

best_comment: THIS WAS MY FAVORITE CLASS AT HARVARD KRIS IS AMAZING!!!!! The assignments were few and far between but you HAVE to do the readings and stay on top of everything, especially for the final project. This class is a bit of work but so dang rewarding. I have never learned more.

TAKE THIS CLASS! It is such an amazing class if you have even the faintest interest in learning more about cultural evolution. The intimate class size makes it such a welcoming environment and Cammie is such a caring instructor who is truly passionate about the subject matter. The proposal and going through the process of writing it is so insightful and I highly recommend this class.

Great class. You get what you put in. Not an easy A, but definitely achievable. Some points are taken off on assignments for no good reason, but you can earn them back by doing the extra credit assignments. Do all the assignments well and on time and you will succeed and have a great time in this class!

This course is great if you are a curious person and genuinely interested in human evolution, psychology, sociology/anthropology, etc. The lectures are interesting but long, and the assignments are infrequent and pretty straightforward but worth a lot of your grade. I would recommend taking this if you have a cognitive trait or two that you are interested in studying and have some background to build off of! The written assignments definitely benefit from having some background or personal interest. For example, i wrote about a cognitive trait that is realted to somethign i study from a basic science perspective in my thesis,
worse_comment: This course is a good option for fulfilling a divisional distribution requirement, but be warned—expectations for the assignments are kind of opaque. If I could redo the course, I would ask a ton of questions before turning things in, because without any clear rubrics I got penalized for things I didn't even know were being evaluated.

best_comment: An interesting course to take, but definitely not a gem. The topics covered were interesting, and you would probably enjoy this class if you're really into human population genetics or ancient population genetics. The article discussions were interesting and there weren't too many assignments throughout the semester although the final paper was very long. The professor was clearly very enthusiastic about the subject and easy to reach outside of class.Given all this, lectures were very dry – the lecture format was the professor reading off very dense slides, which were almost word–for–word taken from the textbook, for the entirety of the class period. Tests did not feel representative of the material covered at all, and there was no guidance given for studying – essentially, the only way to do well was to memorize the hundreds of lecture slides, since some questions asked things covered by one or two lines in one lecture slide. The grading wasn't harsh but it felt like the professor always took points off of every assignment and wasn't very specific about how to improve. Not a bad class to take but not very engaging.

I think this was an excellent class with two really knowledgeable and kind professors. The topic was so interesting, and while it's about the deep past, I think it's incredibly relevant for people to understand. There wasn't a lot of work outside the two exams and the final paper, which was nice. You do have to use Perusal, but it honestly didn't bother me much. I think it makes you engage more with the content of the readings and you get to hear what your classmates think. Most people in the class were very engaged with the topic and we had some great discussions. There were a few issues with the exams, but I don't think this will be the case for future versions of this class. I highly recommend it!

I think this was an excellent class with two really knowledgeable and kind professors. The topic was so interesting, and while it's about the deep past, I think it's incredibly relevant for people to understand. There wasn't a lot of work outside the two exams and the final paper, which was nice. You do have to use Perusal, but it honestly didn't bother me much. I think it makes you engage more with the content of the readings and you get to hear what your classmates think. Most people in the class were very engaged with the topic and we had some great discussions. There were a few issues with the exams, but I don't think this will be the case for future versions of this class. I highly recommend it!

Take this course!! Really useful AND interesting, and Dr. Alex is an incredible professor. Also, you leave the course having worked on a document that is meaningful to you (i.e. grad/med school application essay), with very helpful comments from both Dr. Alex (such a gift!) and your talented classmates.
best_gem_comment: Dr. Alex is a gem of a professor! She is kind, wise, and thoughtful and will change the way you understand how science journalism is produced. This was definitely one of my favorite courses from my time at Harvard.

best_comment: I would recommend taking this class if you enjoy small discussion–based courses and feel comfortable with reading and talking about scientific papers. The class felt very engaging and everyone freely expressed their opinions. I definitely learned a lot about a topic that is becoming increasingly more popular, and enjoyed the class! Dr. Allen–Blevins is also awesome!!

course_title: A Humanities Colloquium from Homer to Joyce 001
best_comment: A really amazing course. 6 professors lecture on books they've spent their careers on. If you are remotely interested in the humanities, even if you don't think you'll concentrate in the humanities, take hum10!!! Some of your hum10 peers will be a little crazy (lots of classicists with latin, greek, and hebrew knowledge) but everyone is incredibly interesting and brings unique perspective I haven't found in any other class so far. Seminars are by far the best part of hum10. Professors, not TF's lead them. It seems like they (the professors) intentionally let you go a little crazy 1st semester and provide little guidance, but 2nd semester is more structured which I like more. Overall an amazing, albeit difficult class. I came into Harvard with almost no humanities education, just read a couple books I really liked outside of school and having never written a paper over 5 pages in length. Hum10 made a good writer out of me and will make a good writer out of you too, just meet with your tf often. They're 're also really interesting people.
worse_comment: This class is spectacular, but in spite of its students and some of its lecturers.

course_title: A Humanities Colloquium from Homer to Joyce 001

Some of your hum10 peers will be a little crazy (lots of classicists with latin, greek, and hebrew knowledge) but everyone is incredibly interesting and brings unique perspective I haven't found in any other class so far. worse_comment: This class is spectacular, but in spite of its students and some of its lecturers.

best_comment: Great course with Nora! Very inclusive environment that focuses on repeated practice and language immersion. Go to Deaf events, they're quite fun, and you pick up a lot more vocab that way. Not very time intensive, but enough to get pretty good at ASL if you put the work in :)

Take this class!! Nora is awesome and you learn so much. The class splits time between learning new vocabulary and practicing by having conversations with your peers, which I feel helped me learn so much in a relatively short time frame in a way that felt managable. This is a great class, you'll learn a lot of vocabulary and also learn more about Deaf culture!

Take this class!! Nora is awesome and you learn so much. The class splits time between learning new vocabulary and practicing by having conversations with your peers, which I feel helped me learn so much in a relatively short time frame in a way that felt managable. This is a great class, you'll learn a lot of vocabulary and also learn more about Deaf culture!

Prof. Frances and Prof. Nozomi have done an incredible job building a strong ASL community at Harvard this year. There were so many great events, coffee chats, and guest lectures. They also kept us informed about external opportunities, which helped us stay connected to the broader ASL and Deaf communities. The class itself was engaging, and both professors were very responsive to student feedback and concerns. It was clear that they genuinely wanted students to succeed, which can be rare at Harvard. The SignPal Pals program was an amazing addition to the course and made the experience more immersive and collaborative.My main concerns were with the Signing Naturally platform and the consistency across course sections. We did not find out until several weeks into the semester that there was a way to complete the assignments without paying. This should have been clarified before the course began, ideally during winter break. Because of this delay, some students paid while others did not, and there was a lot of confusion about which assignments were required. These expectations were never clearly communicated, as there were some discrepancies between the two professors, and Canvas was not updated to reflect what they were saying. Additionally, there were four different course sections with different lecturers, and there was a noticeable lack of alignment. Some sections fell behind or covered different material, and the assignments and assessments varied across sections. This created an uneven learning experience. The issue was apparent from the start of the semester, as students entered ASL 2 with very different levels of prior knowledge depending on their section in ASL 1. It would be helpful if the course could be more standardized across sections to ensure that all students are receiving the same quality of instruction and opportunities to succeed.
worse_comment: Is a fun break from the typical courses at Harvard. The community events also add to the course. However, you spend a lot of time in class, and the homework/weekly journals/community hours can take a lot of time. You also don't get any feedback throughout the semester, so it can be stressful at the end of the year when you have no idea what your grade is or how you are doing.

best_comment: This is the best class I've ever taken. If you are thinking about it...DO IT. Conlin is so funny, so awesome, and a really great teacher. We learn not only ASL, but really interesting stuff about Deaf culture and Art. We play fun games essentially every class, and Conlin is a very flexible and kind teacher. I ended up learning way more than I thought I would, and I would consider myself very conversational at this point.
worse_comment: EVERYONE SHOULD TAKE ASL!!! You will learn so much in this class, while simultaneously never feeling overwhelmed with the amount work as the majority of learning happens in the classroom. If you are unfamiliar with Deaf culture or the Deaf community this class is extremely eye opening and will introduce you to an entire world you knew nothing about.

best_comment: This class is super supportive. Nozomi does a wonderful job of helping students learn in an engaging way. She always is responsive to students, and I feel very lucky to have been in her class. She has so much knowledge, and while it can be hard at times, Nozomi pushes us to continue to grow as signers.

I always had a fascination with linguistics, and well, I wanted to go ahead and learn a little more about it. I feel a little dissatisfied after taking this course, however. It sometimes felt like lectures were more about reading off of the note slides than actual teaching. Some of the demos in class were nice though, but I don't feel like I really learned a lot during them. I feel like the course really gets interesting towards the very end. My favorite classes were the ones where subjects got very philosophical. Also, topics on language acquisition and theories regarding language evolution are where the course really begins to shine. Some lectures really can leave you thinking, and if you are willing to let them pique your curiosity, they certainly will. That being said, a part of my does regrets taking this class. Though work was certainly not overbearing, it was definitely not as light as I had hoped it would be. There were some psets that I felt less prepared for than some of the math and physics psets that I had to do over the semester. Teaching staff is usually helpful, though, so that is a plus.
worse_comment: This class has so much potential and the content was genuinely interesting, but lectures were not very engaging (lots of superfluous, technical details and reading off slides) and the psets were frustratingly tedious. For instance, on one of the assignments, I spent at least an hour trying to transcribe a three minute video for conversation analysis. There were approximately 30 other questions on that pset to complete. In addition to frustrating assignments, the grade breakdown was never published or even mentioned in class, and the course felt quite disorganized overall. The take–home final, for example, was supposed to be due on May 13th, but was moved up to May 8th the week prior which caused a significant amount of stressful rescheduling. Overall, this was not a hard class by any means, but it was a bit annoying, and I honestly didn't get a whole lot out of it.

best_comment: Be aware that this was the first time this class was offered so the feedback you see will look very scary. This class was made for the linguistics nerds who are interested in sign language and have skills in sign language. For the advanced ASL students coming into this class, we were expecting something totally different and it feels like our skills didn't really get better. A lot of my development came from outside of class.
worse_comment: This was a pretty horrible course overall. It was very messy, poorly planned, and overall a very flawed idea. This year instead of teaching normal ASL 6 they mixed the class with LING175 and made "Linguistics of Sign Languages" for both signing ASL students and non–signing linguistic students. the course never found its feet and seemed to be a sinking ship for the entire semester. I hope that they revert back to how ASL6 used to be taught, because this was a sad way to end the ASL program after 6 semesters.  Kate Davidson was a particular low point of this course, as she frequently violated ASL ethics by doing things like simultaneous–communication (or sim–comm) regularly

best_comment: Be aware that this was the first time this class was offered so the feedback you see will look very scary. This class was made for the linguistics nerds who are interested in sign language and have skills in sign language. For the advanced ASL students coming into this class, we were expecting something totally different and it feels like our skills didn't really get better. A lot of my development came from outside of class.

This year instead of teaching normal ASL 6 they mixed the class with LING175 and made "Linguistics of Sign Languages" for both signing ASL students and non–signing linguistic students. the course never found its feet and seemed to be a sinking ship for the entire semester. best_comment: fun class, low stakes and honestly not that much effort required. make the most of it, ask questions and talk to your classmates (everyone there likes something about language!)

if you're wondering whether this would be a course worth taking, just go for it. I initially thought this was going to be boring (as someone more interested in semantics), but I ended up being pleasantly surprised by the amount I actually enjoyed the course. The first few weeks were actually somewhat boring, and you kinda don't really need to remember much from this part cuz its all building up to how syntax works today (for the most part). However, once we got to the free work session part of the class, it ended up being more fun in my opinion because we get to choose which assignments to complete, and you have to defend your answers to one of the course staff –– while initially daunting, getting one on one time to talk about my answers really reinforced my understanding and they were always nice enough to help us through it or give us hints to keep working. Felt sorta like a game at time since in order to get the next harder assignment in a specific topic, you had to complete the earlier assignments first. overall really enjoyed this class, and you should consider taking this class even if you aren't a ling concentrator
worse_comment: I would recommend against this class if taught by Professor Holladay. The content may be intresting to some but it is buried undernearth so many confusing assignments there is really more frustration than engagement with the curriculum. The course is catered towards non–linguistics people, but its structure ends up being frustrating for all students, regardless of experience.

best_comment: This class has been one of my favorites at Harvard. I study linguistics because I like languages and math and this class is the perfect combination of the two. Semantics is all about applying logic to language to derive meaning. The teaching team was super knowledgable and kind. The material was very much manageable (think 10–40 pages of reading and one problem set per week). The exams were fair and open note. Kaden wants students to learn and enjoy the course and it shows. I recommend this class to anybody with a vague interest in linguistics, math and/or logic because I ensure that you will find it enjoyable.

I'll preface by saying that it's hard to review this course knowing that Jay is leaving because he truly MAKES the course. With that out of the way, this is the transformative college experience that Harvard advertises on its website: you are learning from a living legend in the field and every lecture is a testament to that fact. The PSets are sometimes arduous, but fun –– they also build on themselves nicely, so by the end of the semester they take less conscious effort to complete. It's not an introductory course; even though it has no pre–reqs, I would only recommend this to linguistics concentrators or those who are willing to put a fair bit of effort into learning preliminary linguistics topics (if you're planning on taking this, you should either already know basic phonetics or become familiar with it in the near future). It's a fast–paced class, but super manageable (especially if you frequently attend sections, which are not mandatory but ought to be if for no other reason than for how genuinely lovely TF Anabelle is). Your perspective on PIE is going to expand so much over the duration of the lecture series and there's lots of fun "reveals" baked into each class as well, including hands–on activities and fun etymological histories that you can share as fun facts to all those inclined. Intro to Indo–European makes you put in the work, but it's so, so worth it! We'll miss you, Prof. Jasanoff!
worse_comment: You won't get to take this class. You also live in a world that our ancestors have irreparably damaged through climate change. Being in the future generations sucks. Deal with it.

best_comment: This class was fun, but it was very poorly organized. Although the course requirements indicate that students need to know either ASL or linguistics, I wouldn't recommend taking the course if you don't have experience with both. Don't bother to look at the syllabus because it does not reflect the actual workload. According to the syllabus, we were to have twelve journals, three quizzes, and two exams. We had six journals, two quizzes, and one exam. The content of the class is either very surface level introduction to Deaf culture (not helpful for the ASL students) or surface level linguistics (not helpful to the LING students). Overall, the class was enjoyable, but it was so poorly organized that I can't recommend it without warning. If you are a person that likes structured course with clear goals, this is not the class for you. If you are pretty go–with–the–flow, you might enjoy it. The professors are very kind and they are really excited about the content, which is nice. All the students, ASL and LING, are struggling to understand at some point or another. If that's your vibe, go for it.
