If that's your vibe, go for it.

course_title: Mathematics of Biological Systems: a Calculus-Based Approach 020
best_comment: If you are pre–med and don't need/want to take math further than the Ma/Mb sequence, TAKE THIS CLASS OVER MB!!! I have had the best time this semester! Janet is AMAZING and so so helpful. You can tell that she wants you to succeed!! Also, they pick the best CAs for this class! Not only are they there to help you with the math, but they are prob pre–med too so they provide really useful insight on pre–med stuff at Harvard. with all that said TAKE THIS!! If you are going between LS and Mb pls pls choose LS! I have applied myself 100 times more than last semester in MA and I lowkey think its because i'm interested in what is going on. If I am doing math using a situation I will most likely encounter as a doctor of course I'm going to pay more attention. My test scores are better, my pset scores are better, my life is better. I have friends who switched to LS from Mb and they also love it!! Come join the LS fam!!

course_title: Mathematics of Biological Systems: a Calculus-Based Approach 040
best_comment: TLDR: MATH LS IS AMAZING! SO TEA!if you're slightly considering this class, then please go for it! for a course taught for the first time ever, it didn't feel like i was a guinea pig (if that makes sense lol). janet (instructor), raunak (TF), and the CAs are so amazing, knowledgeable, and so helpful if you're ever stuck with something and struggling to understand a concept. this class also introduced me to coding (which we do with ChatGPT and Google Colab, so do not worry!) to model biological systems which was novel and cool. not a CS girly so i didn't have the full appreciation but i definitely respected and admired that we could get a better understanding of bio through math and coding. shows that these areas are more interconnected than we think and even learn! the content itself is so cool. as a student who loves biology, this class made me love it more. every section, we're learning about a real–world biological phenomenon, from HIV to testosterone injection, all with math! this course has deepened my appreciation for math too, which has been amazing to experience. the content can be a bit more difficult at times, as it's more application–based and not just straight problems like Math MA. however, this course, hands down, has been one of my favorite classes here at Harvard. it's amazing all–around, from the teaching staff, to the content, to what you walk away with. i'm so proud to say that i was one of the first students to take this class yayyyy cause they properly ate thattt. so yeah, math LS on top!

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 000
best_comment: Take this class only if you have a concentration/secondary requirement OR are planning to take Math 1B. There is no other reason to take this class. It does not have major practical applications. There are three psets a week that will take at least 2 hours to complete. This class also has skill checks and two mid–term exams. If you want to be successful in this course, I would highly recommend going to MQC a few times a week, especially if you have no calc background besides Math MA.  The textbook is really not necessary to study for the exams, provided you complete most/all of the practice exams. Try to get a good CA if you can as well, I had a Doug and he was great! Would recommend.

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 001
best_comment: PLEASE take this course!!! The teaching team is super supportive and very accessible outside of class (go to office hours or don't hesitate to reach out to them)! They are very enthusiastic and intentional and you WILL improve not just your math, but your problem solving skills! If anything is just not making sense don't worry! You don't even have to have a specific question, but if you just go to office hours and say "Can you explain this whole concept," you will get answers! Just hang in there :)

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 002
best_comment: Great maths class, stay on top of psets and you’ll do well.
worse_comment: Don't fall behind on the course content–––– it will hurt you come exam time.

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 010
best_comment: Super great class. Teaches you all of integration and more calculus concepts super well. I found it much easier than math MA and recommend it to everyone. The three psets a week is a lot but MQC is always a fun time so you should use it to your advantage.

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 010
best_comment: Super great class. Teaches you all of integration and more calculus concepts super well. I found it much easier than math MA and recommend it to everyone. The three psets a week is a lot but MQC is always a fun time so you should use it to your advantage.

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 020
best_comment: I think this is a good course! It breaks down everything really well, so though you need to REALLY understand it, I prefer that to having a surface level understanding. Go to MQC for your psets and study in advance for the tests.

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 021
best_comment: I would recommend this class even if you think you are above it. Listen to the course recommendations! They know how your math knowledge will be applied to their courses better than you do. I am so happy that I took math M because I learned that I was lacking some fundamental algebra skills that I would need to make math easier for me. Learning them was more like review, but was a good refresher that made the class enjoyable and easier for me.

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 030
best_comment: Assuming that you have already taken Ma, Mb is the second course of the M series. Throughout this two–part course, I have contemplated many times whether I should follow through with the M series or to switch to another math course—and I am sure a few other peers of mine were on the same boat. I chose to stick to Mb in the end, and I do not regret as it has surely given me a boost of confidence in my math skills. I believe that Math Mb was very well–taught—just make sure to take advantage of the resources provided (that is, go to office hours)!

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 040
best_comment: Math MB is great. The staff and CAs are fantastic. A lot of people complain about the Math department at Harvard because they teach things differently than most people are used to, but as someone who hadn't taken a Math class in like 8 years I thought it really allowed me to understand what I was doing rather than just following a set of rules to spit out correct answers. Like any other Math class it's 3 PSETs a week. Yeah it kind of sucks but most of the time they take like 1–2 hours and if you do it right after section it's not so bad. There's 3 skills checks and 2 mid–terms. None of them are particularly difficult as long as you've payed attention in class and done your PSETs. That's the really nice thing about Math here is there's no real way to fall behind as long as you're doing the bare minimum. If you have already taken Math MA then you're probably choosing between MB and Math LS, Q, etc. If you plan on or are even considering concentrating in anything that requires a higher level math course (1b, 21a, etc.) take this course. If you're Econ or Pre–Med and you don't need more Math take Q or LS respectively. You learn a lot of the same concepts but they get applied to your actual field of study rather than being straight math classes.
worse_comment: PLEASE AVOID AT ALL COSTS UNLESS YOU ARE FORCED TO TAKE THIS CLASS. IF YOU ARE FORCED TO TAKE THIS CLASS, SERIOUSLY CONSIDER CHANGING CONCENTRATIONS!

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 040

course_title: Quantitative Analysis for Economics and the Social Sciences I 000
best_comment: I would tell students that the class is run much better thn Ma, taught at a great pace with learning base blocks and building. This course is very challenging at times with having to figure stuff out on your own as designed, that did enhance my skills overall. The teaching team led by Brendan is incredible and he cares so much about the student and their individual learning needs.

course_title: Quantitative Analysis for Economics and the Social Sciences I 020
best_comment: Take this class but be aware of the fact that it is newly established and has less resources than other math courses. I didn't hate my time in this class and feel that it is the best option for those that need to fulfill it for Econ or anything else, but be prepared to spend at least 5 hours on PSETs when you have a coding component, if not more. You are expected to write code on your own which is incredibly difficult without decent exposure to it in class. Brendan and Matt are great, but they have limited office hours and CAs are only helpful if they have had coding experience before and can actually explain it to you. Make sure to know EVERYTHING in detail for quizzes and the final exam. This course is a good alternative if you want to avoid more intense math, but be aware that it is actively being shaped. GO TO OFFICE HOURS.

course_title: Quantitative Analysis for Economics and the Social Sciences I 020
best_comment: Take this class but be aware of the fact that it is newly established and has less resources than other math courses. I didn't hate my time in this class and feel that it is the best option for those that need to fulfill it for Econ or anything else, but be prepared to spend at least 5 hours on PSETs when you have a coding component, if not more. You are expected to write code on your own which is incredibly difficult without decent exposure to it in class. Brendan and Matt are great, but they have limited office hours and CAs are only helpful if they have had coding experience before and can actually explain it to you. Make sure to know EVERYTHING in detail for quizzes and the final exam. This course is a good alternative if you want to avoid more intense math, but be aware that it is actively being shaped. GO TO OFFICE HOURS.

course_title: Quantitative Analysis for Economics and the Social Sciences I 030
best_comment: As someone who had no prior experience with data analysis, I was a little apprehensive about taking Math Q at first but I loved it! Granted, this was the first year that it was being taught in this format so some parts of the course were a bit disorganized but the course logistics will definitely smooth out over its next couple of iterations.If you’re at all interested in data analysis or a future in finance then I would highly recommend taking this course; I found that it provided a pretty low stakes introduction to coding and working with spreadsheets. Like many of the other introductory math courses, there are ample resources available for Math Q. I spent a lot of time in MQC and office hours over the semester which paid off when we had to come up with projects based off the work that the we did in class and on PSETs. It’s definitely possible to skate by without using those resources but  I think that if I didn’t understand the code or basic concepts that we learned in class, it would have been much harder to come up with a unique project. Learning how to code in Google Colabs was definitely the most challenging part of the course. There were MANY problem sets with coding elements that I wouldn’t have been able to figure out on my own unless I went to MQC or office hours. That being said, we were allowed to use the AI helper in Google Colabs on tests and quizzes which definitely saved me multiple times during the semester. The quizzes and final were extremely fair and, in my opinion, very manageable given the way that they’re structured (each quiz corresponds with a unit and the final was broken up into the four units). Lastly, I just wanted to highlight that Matt and Brendan, the two course heads, are probably the most caring and genuine teachers that I’ve met at Harvard so far. They clearly want to see their students succeed (two examples: staying longer than their scheduled office hours and curving a quiz when nobody finished on time), are excited about the course material, and are extremely receptive to feedback. Although some parts of the course were challenging, I ended the semester with a newfound interest in data analysis and familiarity with basic coding and modeling in spreadsheets. TL;DR: If you’re deciding between Math Mb and Math Q, take Math Q!!! ESPECIALLY if you already took calculus in high school.
worse_comment: It is a great course to learn real world mathematics, but the coding is difficult and the class is poorly organized.

course_title: Quantitative Analysis for Economics and the Social Sciences I 030

worse_comment: It is a great course to learn real world mathematics, but the coding is difficult and the class is poorly organized.

best_comment: For context on what I'm about to say, I had taken AB Calculus in high school before this class. Matt was a great, super effective instructor. PSETs were harder at first but got easier as the semester went on. Class is structured well toward learning, but it felt a bit fast at times. There are a lot of PSETs which took me about 3 hours each doing them in one sitting (so ~9 hours a week) which can feel like a lot to balance on top of other classes, though the PSETs themselves were not super hard and definitely helpful in solidifying your understanding of the material. But tbh I preferred this over 1 PSET due at the end of the week as someone who would've definitely procrastinated until then. Sometimes PSETs took forever to be graded—like I'd notice that maybe a couple days before a midterm I'd have the last 6 PSETs ungraded (which was not horrible because the solutions are always posted 1 day after the due date). All of the CAs were super nice and helpful. Having 9am 3x a week was not great, and got hard towards the end of the semester, though Matt is super energetic and all the math turns ur brain on. All in all a good class that is more time intensive than it is hard imo.
worse_comment: Matt Demers (the course head) was excellent. I had not met a better math teacher in my life. On the other hand, the Math department needs to do a better job at screening undergraduate course assistants for this class. The course assistants were often unable to explain concepts covered in class and would regularly make mistakes in grading problems sets. I understand the sheer volume of grading load imposed upon them (3 psets / week) can be tough, but some of the mistakes were truly appalling.

best_comment: This class has been the hardest math I've taken. I've put in an immense amount of time into it but did not get the results I wanted. The grading is super hard, and the direction of the course is pretty tough. The teaching staff is also willing to help and are very nice.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! The class is challenging, but in my experience, AP Calc in high school leaves you with spaces not covered by Math 1b; you can avoid Math 1b, but I will say that you most likely would end up with gaps in your learning. DO NOT SKIP MATH 1B BECAUSE YOU FEAR IT; IT IS NOT AS BAD AS PEOPLE SAY!!!

best_comment: The material for Math1b is pretty interesting, even for someone who is not a "math–person" per se. However, your learning experience depends on the TF you will have. Not all sections are taught with the same quality. Therefore, your best bet would be to attend office hours for different TFs (especially the head TF's office hours) if you feel like you're not understanding something from your section. Use ARC tutoring if you're still confused.

Not as bad as people say. If you actually go to class it is pretty easy honestly, and you should be able to do well with some hard work. Going to MQC is honestly kind of a cheat code, and it makes your PSET average go way up since you are told how to do things in a way that will make the graders give you more points. If you are looking at skipping this and going straight to 21, look into the course material and see how well you know it, beause this class sets up both 21A and 21B in a lot of its material.
worse_comment: Synopsis:This course is an example of a toxic ex. You give all of your time, energy, love, and youthful optimism, only to get nothing back but emotional damage and a GPA that looks like a cry for help. Math 1B doesn’t test your knowledge—it tests your will to live. And I failed. Because this class isn’t just a class. It’s an experience. A curse. A shared trauma for anyone foolish enough to walk through the gates of “Integration, Series, and Differential Equations.”Every week, you are served steaming piles of content that no freshman should have to digest. Every concept, every formula, every theorem is introduced at breakneck speed and then abandoned like a broken toy. You're told to understand series convergence tests, Taylor polynomials, differential equations, integration techniques, arc length, surface area, volumes, slope fields, Euler’s method, the logistic equation, parametric curves, polar coordinates, and three other topics I don’t even remember because I was too busy trying not to cry in Lamont.You walk into class thinking, “This will be hard, but I can handle it.” You leave every lecture with a thousand–yard stare. The TFs say things like “intuitively obvious” and “just differentiate both sides,” and you start to question not just your intelligence but your entire existence. It’s trivial how trifling this course is with how useless it is to anything that comes after. Math 21A doesn’t care what your radius of convergence was in April. No one will ever again ask you if a series converges absolutely or conditionally, but here, it’s life or death.The structure of this class is not designed to help students learn. It is designed to break them. No real examples. No real support. Just a firehose of math, and then a midterm where your only calculator is your fingers and your last three brain cells. You get PSETs with scores in the 90s and 100s and then turn around and get 59s on the exams like you’re living in an academic episode of Punk’d. You don’t know what’s real anymore.And then there’s Erica Dinkins. The Course Head. President of Pain. CEO of Suffering. She’ll look at you in office hours, explain a convergence test like you’re a PhD student, and then walk away. No follow–up. No check–in. Just a lingering air of “you should already know this.”The exam questions? Insane. They make you write 50th degree Taylor polynomials by hand. I am not exaggerating. Fifty. Terms. Handwritten. On paper. Without a calculator. You flip to the second page and it’s a nonhomogeneous second–order differential equation with variable coefficients. You flip again and it’s a Taylor series about a point that defies basic physics. You flip once more and see a convergence problem so cursed it might’ve been written in a fever dream.You try to focus, but around you, people are breaking. Someone is blinking in Morse code. A girl is whispering “p–series” under her breath like a prayer. A guy stands up, mutters “I’m done,” and walks out. You sit there, still pretending, still trying, still thinking maybe—just maybe—if you suffer enough, the math gods will reward you.They don’t.You open Gradescope, see “58% – Conduct Penalty Applied,” and all you can do is laugh. Because it’s over. Because it’s finally over. Because now you know the truth: Math 1B was never about calculus. It was about testing how much trauma you could endure before you started seeing Taylor series in your sleep.I lost a lot in this class. My confidence. My time. My sense of joy. But I gained something too: a warning. A purpose. A message to send to the next brave soul who thinks they can handle Math 1B.Don’t. Skip it. If you can. Run. Don’t walk. Take 1A. Take 21A. Take a nap. Take literally anything else. And if someone in the Math Department tells you “It’s better to go in order,” they are lying. Do not let them do to you what they did to me.Math 1B isn’t your ex because it ended. Math 1B is your ex because it left scars.✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦The TFs weren’t just apathetic—they were prophetic. One time I asked how to evaluate the convergence of a series and the TF looked me dead in the eye and said “By the Divergence Test” like he was delivering a funeral sermon.Another time, I stayed up until 4AM trying to solve a differential equation that turned out not to have a solution. That was the moment I realized this class wasn’t about math. It was about resilience. About how long you could stare at a problem without bursting into tears.No calculator, no partial credit, no emotional support. Just vibes and integrals.You ace a PSET and feel that flicker of hope—maybe I can do this. Then the midterm hits you like a truck made of Taylor series expansions and betrayal. You go to check your grade and it says 59% “Good Effort.” You sit on your bed, motionless, eyes fixed on the wall like the first five minutes of a Netflix true crime documentary.You try to recover. You print out study guides. Watch every lecture on 2x speed. You stop seeing friends. You skip birthdays. You drop hobbies. You start sketching slope fields in the margins of your notebooks just to feel something.You reach the final exam and it’s not even a test. It’s a live–action betrayal.Octonauts. Ready for action. Because legends never die. Only their GPAs do.✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦THE MIDTERMS: A TWO–ACT TRAGEDYMIDTERM I: THE INTEGRAL INQUISITIONTwo hours. Just two hours to question everything you ever thought you knew about calculus, your academic self–worth, and maybe even your childhood. It started with a deceptively gentle warm–up problem—something simple, solvable. And you think, “Okay, I can do this.” You settle in. You exhale. And then the rest of the exam hits you like a freight train filled with definite integrals and deeply personal betrayal.There were improper integrals that required more substitutions than a World Cup roster. One question involved a fraction so grotesque it looked like it had crawled out of the LaTeX version of a horror film. You spend twenty minutes trying to remember whether to use trig substitution or just lie down on the floor and accept your fate.Then there was the arc length question that ate 45 minutes of my life. I used every formula I had memorized, guessed, and even invented some that looked legitimate enough to be real. And still—no final answer. Just a page full of crossed–out regret.I remember the moment the room shifted. A collective silence settled in. Pens slowed. People looked up, dazed. I saw one girl start to cry. Another guy whispered “oh my God” and stared at his paper like it had betrayed him. The TF proctor just stood there, motionless, watching the unraveling like it was a wildlife documentary.When I handed it in, I caught the eye of someone across the room. We didn’t speak. We just nodded. It was the kind of nod soldiers give each other after surviving a battle.MIDTERM II: THE SERIES SLAUGHTERI had prepped for this one. I watched lecture replays at 1.75x speed until my brain buzzed. I built a deck of convergence test flashcards. I went to every review session. I prayed. And yet...That exam. That godforsaken exam.The first problem was deceptively short—just a series and the instruction to “Determine convergence.” Easy, right? Wrong. It was a triple–agent series. Alternating, conditionally convergent, disguised as a p–series, wrapped in logarithmic mystery. You could’ve handed it to a math PhD and they’d still hesitate.Then came the multi–part monster. A Frankenstein of nested series and approximation intervals. One part asked for the nth term. The next asked for the error bound. The next—get this—asked for a Taylor expansion of an already approximated expansion. That’s when I knew we were in the endgame.And then—yes, then—the 50th–degree Taylor polynomial.Hand. Written. With. No. Calculator.Do you understand what 50 terms of a Taylor polynomial looks like? It looks like the last thing you see before death. It looks like a punishment invented during the Spanish Inquisition. By term 12, I was laughing. By term 20, I was crying. By term 30, I had transcended time. My pencil moved, but my soul was elsewhere.The final moments were cinematic. Someone dropped their pencil and just stared at it. Another person put their head down and didn’t move. I looked over and saw someone write “f(x) ≈ please let me pass” and I knew then—we were all done.I walked out not because I was finished, but because the war had ended and I had lost. I saw a classmate outside the exam hall just pacing, whispering to himself, “I don’t even know what a series is anymore.”I went back to my room and lay flat on the floor in silence. My roommate came in and thought I was unconscious. I told him, “No, just defeated.”Grades came two weeks later. 61%. Better than Midterm I. Worse than dignity.“Reflect. Learn. Improve.” That’s what the feedback said. As if what I’d just experienced was a group project that needed tweaking. No. What I needed was an exorcism.These were not assessments. They were acts of academic violence.Stay tuned. Because the Final Exam is not a test. It is an execution.✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦Harsh Exam Grading:MIDTERM GRADING: THE ART OF BEING JUDGED BY A VOIDEvery error—every single one—was penalized. Repeatedly. If you made the same mistake across parts (a), (b), and (c), you didn’t lose points once—you lost points thrice. The TFs graded like they were charging interest. One missed negative sign? Minus 2. You do it again in the next part? Minus 2 again. By the end, you weren’t just wrong. You were in mathematical debt.One student asked during office hours if points could be recovered for consistency in error. The TF responded, “This isn’t a personality test.”You start to think maybe you’re being haunted by your earlier mistakes. You see the same comment show up four times. “Wrong bounds.” “Wrong bounds again.” “Still wrong bounds.” “Really?”At this point, it’s not grading. It’s punishment layered with sarcasm. Each red mark a scar. Each deduction a reminder that math is not merciful. It remembers. And it deducts accordingly.You turn in Midterm I with a trembling hand, praying for a shred of mercy. You checked your bounds. You showed your work. You even boxed your final answers like the TF said. But the paper comes back looking like it was marked by a sleep–deprived poet with a vendetta against optimism.“Your method is novel, though not correct.” — minus 6“This integral doesn’t converge. Much like your hope.” — minus 8“Your bounds are... interpretive?” — minus 4“This is not the unit circle’s fault.” — minus 5One student wrote “I used WolframAlpha” in pencil next to a graph. It got crossed out with, “So did I. Still wrong.”Midterm II was worse. Not just because of the math, but because you genuinely thought you were improving. You walked in with notes. You’d made your own convergence cheat sheet. You believed in yourself.The TF did not.“You seem to be confusing conditional convergence with emotional instability.” — minus 6“I am unsure what this sentence is trying to prove, mathematically or spiritually.” — minus 7“This looks like a Taylor series. It is not.” — minus 10“You forgot factorials. The factorials did not forget you.” — minus 12Someone else wrote a haiku instead of solving the 50–term expansion:Infinity loomsThe terms grow ever longerWhy are we still here?They received no points, but the TF underlined it and added: “This spoke to me.”Midterms weren’t assessments. They were confessions. And you were guilty.THE GRADING: A PSYCHOLOGICAL EXPERIMENT IN ABSURDITYWhen the final grades were released, you already knew it was over. But what you didn’t expect were the comments. The point deductions. The creative, soul–crushing notes left on your work like rejection letters from math itself.Here is a non–exhaustive list of actual phrases allegedly scrawled in red ink across student papers, accompanied by their corresponding point deductions:“This is not how cosine behaves.” — minus 5“You’ve summoned something dark here.” — minus 3“Technically not wrong, but also not right in any meaningful way.” — minus 7“Why is there a pirate metaphor in your radius of convergence explanation?” — minus 10“Are you okay?” — minus 2 (emotional concern but still penalized)“Octonauts ready for action.” — minus 40 (conduct penalty)“I’ve never seen someone integrate backwards before.” — minus 8“Creative, but cursed.” — minus 6“I’m giving partial credit out of pity.” — plus 2“No calculator does not mean write down vibes.” — minus 12One student included a small doodle of a slope field crying. It earned no points. Another wrote, “Please curve,” and it was underlined with a single word: “No.”You scroll through your exam. You see 58%, and next to it, a single note: “Good effort.” That’s it. Not “nice try.” Not “see me after class.” Just “good effort,” like you tried to bake cookies and burned down the kitchen.This isn’t grading. This is performance art.✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦The 12–14 weeks of pain:WEEK 1: The Flirtation.You're doing substitution problems like it's a first date. Easy. Fun. You're smiling. You're posting your 10/10 PSET scores like they're thirst traps. You tell your friends, “I actually like this class.” You are innocent. You are foolish. You are doomed.WEEK 2: The Gaslight.The integrals start getting long. But not terrifying. Just enough to make you squint. Erica starts tossing out notation you haven’t seen before. A little mysterious. A little spicy. “Just remember your u–substitutions,” she says. You do. You try. You fail. But you think maybe it’s your fault. It always starts like this.WEEK 3: The Silent Treatment.You start asking questions in section. They don’t get answered. The TF writes something incomprehensible on the board and walks away. You're told “just review your notes.” But the notes are cryptic, half–written spells. You start to realize no one's coming to save you.WEEK 4: The Lovebomb and Withdrawal.You're handed a worksheet with 20 problems due the next day. You complete it. You get it right. You feel proud. You think maybe things are looking up. Then, next class, Erica pulls a full 180: infinite series. 10 new tests. No warning. No transition. Just pain.WEEK 5: The Gas Explosion.Ratio test. Root test. Alternating series. Absolute convergence. Conditional convergence. Everything converges—except your understanding. You try to memorize all the tests. They start blurring together. You make a chart. The chart lies to you.WEEK 6: The Breakdown.Your PSET takes 13 hours. You cry during office hours. You email your TF and get a reply that says “Try the Comparison Test.” You eat lunch while watching a Taylor Series video at 2x speed. You forget how food tastes.WEEK 7: The Taylor Spiral.You’re asked to write a Taylor polynomial about a point that doesn't even exist in the real world. You’re finding derivatives of transcendental functions using formulas you’ve never seen. “Just generalize,” says Erica. You generalize your sorrow.WEEK 8: The Identity Crisis.You start thinking maybe you were never good at math. Maybe you were never meant to be here. You think about switching majors. You think about dropping out. You wonder if Taylor series would converge faster than your GPA is falling.WEEK 9: The Philosophical Turn.You start agreeing with Nietzsche. God is dead, and Erica killed him with a radius of convergence. You find yourself contemplating existence in lecture. You raise your hand to ask, “What does it mean for a series to truly converge?” and the TF writes a summation sign and walks away.WEEK 10: The Hollowing.You are no longer a student. You are a vessel for confusion and half–finished differentials. Your dreams are narrated by series expansions. Your nightmares are slope fields. You sit in lecture and simply accept. Acceptance is the final stage of grief. Math 1B has won.WEEK 11: The Differential Descent.The word “differential” used to sound vaguely scientific. Maybe even elegant. Now, it triggers a full–body reaction. Erica walks in, picks up the chalk, and says “Let’s solve a second–order linear nonhomogeneous differential equation,” and you start to see colors that aren’t there.You thought integrals were bad. You thought convergence tests were painful. You had no idea. Now it’s y double prime plus y prime plus y equals e^x times a cosine. You’re supposed to use undetermined coefficients. Variation of parameters. The method of annihilators. You try to look it up, but Google says “Did you mean: you’re screwed?”WEEK 12: The Breakdown, Redux.The problem sets now involve three layers of differential logic. You’re solving for particular solutions, homogeneous solutions, general solutions—at this point, you just want a solution to your life. You stare at the DE on the board and think, “This must be what it feels like to go insane slowly, beautifully, with a pencil.”You try to ask a question, but it comes out as a sound. Just a noise. Erica responds with a formula that looks like a summoning spell. You copy it down because you’ve stopped resisting. Your notebook is no longer for learning. It’s a place to document the decline.WEEK 13: The Rage.You’ve stopped suffering in silence. You curse aloud during problem sets. You type “Why does Taylor do this” into Google. You threaten to drop a major just to spite this class. You write “Help me” in your notebook and underline it 30 times. Your TF makes eye contact and flinches. You get into a fight with a friend who says, “It’s not that bad.” You cut them off. You were never that close anyway.WEEK 14: The Surrender.The final approaches. You don’t study. You prepare spiritually. You walk into the lecture hall like a condemned soul. You look around and see your classmates in various stages of denial, numbness, and caffeine–induced hysteria. Someone sharpens a pencil like it’s a sword. You nod. This is the end. You whisper “Octonauts ready for action” not as a joke—but as a prayer.✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦THE FINAL EXAM: A LIVE–ACTION BETRAYALThey told us no food, no water, no calculator. I brought a cough drop. I was sick—sick in the way only Math 1B can make a person sick. Coughing, shaking, cold sweating through an exam that was colder than the room. A proctor approached me like I’d brought contraband. I was almost kicked out. For a cough drop. For daring to attempt basic respiratory survival during this academic deathmatch.Had I been removed, I think I would've finally cracked. The breakdown was brewing. Missing one more thing—one more community dinner, one more org meeting, one more birthday, one more final—might’ve been the end. This course had already taken too much. Had they removed me for that Ricola, I would’ve started speaking in series notation and crying Taylor terms.The lecture hall was quiet. Too quiet. You could feel the tension in the air as students filtered in—not chatting, not joking, just solemnly setting down mechanical pencils like weapons before a duel. You weren’t here to succeed. You were here to survive.The moment the clock hit 9:00 AM, the final exam was passed out, and the room collectively exhaled their last hope. You flipped the first page. It was already over.A second–order linear nonhomogeneous differential equation stared back at you like a death sentence. You tried to remember your method of undetermined coefficients. Your brain gave you a flashback to crying in office hours instead.By page two, someone had put their head down and wasn’t moving. By page three, you heard quiet sobbing. Page four had a parametric curve question that looked like a Rorschach test. Someone stood up, walked out, and never returned.A student in the back threw up. Another cursed audibly. The proctor didn’t even blink. This was normal. This was expected. This was Math 1B.You reached the Taylor series expansion and just stared. It wanted a 40–term expansion centered at a point that might not exist. You wrote four terms and then—without hesitation—wrote “Octonauts ready for action” at the bottom. Because what else could you do? Pray? Cry? Beg for mercy from a function?The last problem asked you to analyze convergence in a series that looked like it had been cursed by a Victorian child. You wrote “I’m sorry” in the margin.And then, somehow, it was over.You stumbled out of the lecture hall into the blinding daylight. Someone was weeping on the steps. Another was making a TikTok about the experience. You stood there, hollowed out, stripped of ego and energy—and smiled.Because it was done.Because you survived.Because despite everything—despite the conduct penalty, the sleepless nights, the cursed slope fields—you finished Math 1B.And for the first time in months, you felt joy. Real, tangible joy. The joy of walking away from the wreckage with your sanity mostly intact. Of knowing that you would never again have to write a Taylor series. Of knowing that Erica Dinkins could no longer touch you.Octonauts. Ready for freedom.EPILOGUE: A LETTER TO FUTURE FIRST–YEARSIf you’re reading this, it means you’ve heard the whispers. The legends. The rumors about Math 1B. Maybe you’re a freshman—bright–eyed, determined, ready to take on Harvard’s STEM courses with the energy of a caffeinated golden retriever. Maybe someone told you it wasn’t that bad. Maybe you believed them.Don’t.Math 1B is not just a class. It is a gauntlet. A psychological operation. A semester–long fever dream of integrals, infinite series, and unspeakable differential horrors. It is a trial by fire in which you will be burned, branded, and broken—and if you’re lucky, you’ll crawl out the other side with a C+ and a ghost permanently whispering “Taylor approximation” in your ear.But you don’t have to do this. You have choices. If you can place into 21A—do it. If you can take 1A instead—bless yourself and do it. Do not let the advisors lie to you. Do not let the siren song of “everyone takes it” lull you into the abyss. If someone from the department says “it builds character,” understand they mean it in the same way a collapsed bridge builds swimming skills.And if you’ve already committed—brace yourself. Arm yourself. Find your people. Make a meme folder. Go to office hours, even if only to sob quietly into your notebook. Watch lectures on 2x speed and let the confusion wash over you like a wave. Drink water. Sleep when you can. Mourn what you lose, celebrate what you finish.You will forget the math. But you will never forget the madness.Sincerely,A survivor of the series.–ON TF Trainor & CourseHead DinkinsLet’s not pretend. Let’s not tiptoe. Let’s talk about what it actually feels like to be in Math 1B, sitting under those godforsaken fluorescent lights while Erica Dinkins—the Course Head, the CEO of Cold Disdain, the Grand Inquisitor of Convergence—waltzes into the room with the emotional warmth of a malfunctioning Roomba.From the moment she steps in, the temperature drops. I’m not kidding. It physically feels colder. She has that presence—icy, distant, surgical. She doesn’t walk, she glides, like some sort of cryptic math spirit summoned by the cries of struggling freshmen.And you? You, sitting there with your notebook open and a half–chewed pencil in your hand, think to yourself: “I have a question. A real question. A good–faith question.” And you raise your hand. Slowly. Nervously. Hoping this will be the day the room finally turns human.But she turns to you. And that look—God, that look—is something you feel in your bones. Like she’s already done a triple integral of your soul and found it lacking. She doesn’t ask you what your question is. She doesn’t encourage. She just says, with that edge in her voice, “We already covered that.”Or worse: she answers your question with another question—abstract, symbolic, disembodied—and you’re left even more confused, now deeply ashamed, and maybe even wondering if you imagined the whole lecture.There were moments—moments burned into memory—where she’d write a horrifying expression on the board and say “this should be clear” while half the room was blinking like hostages. I saw people sweating, physically sweating, while trying to follow her derivation of a power series expansion around a point she pulled from the underworld. She once solved an entire differential equation in what I can only describe as emotional Morse code—rapid, hostile chalk movements—and when someone asked her to explain step three, she turned and looked like they’d just spit on Euclid.It’s not that she didn’t teach. It’s that she didn’t teach us. She taught ghosts. She taught theoretical students who already took Math 21A in the womb. If you weren’t in the top 5% of math fluency, you didn’t exist to her. You were an inconvenience. A background hum. Static in the calculus frequency she operated on.I started doubting myself in that room. Started shrinking. Started losing my voice. You don’t realize it at first, but it chips away at you. A comment here. A sigh there. A refusal to acknowledge the question that was maybe your one shot at getting it. And by the time Week 8 rolled around, I wasn’t asking anymore. I wasn’t engaging. I was surviving.But then there was Charlotte.And if I talk about Erica with fire, I talk about Charlotte with full–hearted, tear–streaked reverence.Charlotte is the kind of TF you write novels about. The kind of academic mentor you remember forever. She didn’t just help me understand the material. She helped me remember that I wasn’t stupid. That I still had value as a learner. That even though I wasn’t writing 40–term Taylor series in my sleep like some math cyborg, I was still worthy of kindness. Of patience.She never made me feel small. She never looked at me with that Erica–brand scorn. She would pause—pause mid–sentence—to make sure you were following. And if you weren’t, she wouldn’t move on. She’d go back. She’d re–explain. She’d ask what step lost you and trace it out carefully, like she was untangling a knot she wanted to help you loosen.There were nights—real, painful nights—where I would come to her with PSETs that looked like they’d been through a shredder. And she didn’t flinch. She’d say, “Okay. Let’s figure this out.” And those four words? They saved me. She made math feel like something I could try again. Not conquer. Not master. Just try.Charlotte made it safe to fail. Erica made it shameful.And that’s the difference. That’s the core of it.One woman walked in each day with an arsenal of equations and an air of silent judgment. The other walked in with a whiteboard marker and a heart.I don’t know what would’ve happened without Charlotte. I genuinely don’t. Because by Week 10, I was losing it. I was losing myself. But she reminded me that Math 1B didn’t get to define me. That I was more than a percent, more than a boxed final answer with a red X. She reminded me that learning is a process, not a punishment.So yeah—Erica ran the show. But Charlotte? Charlotte saved it.And if no one else says it, I will: give that woman a raise. Give her tenure. Give her the course. Because she taught with grace in a system built to break us.And I’ll never forget that.

best_comment: Not as bad as people say. If you actually go to class it is pretty easy honestly, and you should be able to do well with some hard work. Going to MQC is honestly kind of a cheat code, and it makes your PSET average go way up since you are told how to do things in a way that will make the graders give you more points. If you are looking at skipping this and going straight to 21, look into the course material and see how well you know it, beause this class sets up both 21A and 21B in a lot of its material.
worse_comment: Synopsis:This course is an example of a toxic ex. You give all of your time, energy, love, and youthful optimism, only to get nothing back but emotional damage and a GPA that looks like a cry for help. Math 1B doesn’t test your knowledge—it tests your will to live. And I failed. Because this class isn’t just a class. It’s an experience. A curse. A shared trauma for anyone foolish enough to walk through the gates of “Integration, Series, and Differential Equations.”Every week, you are served steaming piles of content that no freshman should have to digest. Every concept, every formula, every theorem is introduced at breakneck speed and then abandoned like a broken toy. You're told to understand series convergence tests, Taylor polynomials, differential equations, integration techniques, arc length, surface area, volumes, slope fields, Euler’s method, the logistic equation, parametric curves, polar coordinates, and three other topics I don’t even remember because I was too busy trying not to cry in Lamont.You walk into class thinking, “This will be hard, but I can handle it.” You leave every lecture with a thousand–yard stare. The TFs say things like “intuitively obvious” and “just differentiate both sides,” and you start to question not just your intelligence but your entire existence. It’s trivial how trifling this course is with how useless it is to anything that comes after. Math 21A doesn’t care what your radius of convergence was in April. No one will ever again ask you if a series converges absolutely or conditionally, but here, it’s life or death.The structure of this class is not designed to help students learn. It is designed to break them. No real examples. No real support. Just a firehose of math, and then a midterm where your only calculator is your fingers and your last three brain cells. You get PSETs with scores in the 90s and 100s and then turn around and get 59s on the exams like you’re living in an academic episode of Punk’d. You don’t know what’s real anymore.And then there’s Erica Dinkins. The Course Head. President of Pain. CEO of Suffering. She’ll look at you in office hours, explain a convergence test like you’re a PhD student, and then walk away. No follow–up. No check–in. Just a lingering air of “you should already know this.”The exam questions? Insane. They make you write 50th degree Taylor polynomials by hand. I am not exaggerating. Fifty. Terms. Handwritten. On paper. Without a calculator. You flip to the second page and it’s a nonhomogeneous second–order differential equation with variable coefficients. You flip again and it’s a Taylor series about a point that defies basic physics. You flip once more and see a convergence problem so cursed it might’ve been written in a fever dream.You try to focus, but around you, people are breaking. Someone is blinking in Morse code. A girl is whispering “p–series” under her breath like a prayer. A guy stands up, mutters “I’m done,” and walks out. You sit there, still pretending, still trying, still thinking maybe—just maybe—if you suffer enough, the math gods will reward you.They don’t.You open Gradescope, see “58% – Conduct Penalty Applied,” and all you can do is laugh. Because it’s over. Because it’s finally over. Because now you know the truth: Math 1B was never about calculus. It was about testing how much trauma you could endure before you started seeing Taylor series in your sleep.I lost a lot in this class. My confidence. My time. My sense of joy. But I gained something too: a warning. A purpose. A message to send to the next brave soul who thinks they can handle Math 1B.Don’t. Skip it. If you can. Run. Don’t walk. Take 1A. Take 21A. Take a nap. Take literally anything else. And if someone in the Math Department tells you “It’s better to go in order,” they are lying. Do not let them do to you what they did to me.Math 1B isn’t your ex because it ended. With. No. Calculator.Do you understand what 50 terms of a Taylor polynomial looks like? It looks like the last thing you see before death. It looks like a punishment invented during the Spanish Inquisition. By term 12, I was laughing. By term 20, I was crying. By term 30, I had transcended time. My pencil moved, but my soul was elsewhere.The final moments were cinematic. Someone dropped their pencil and just stared at it. Another person put their head down and didn’t move. I looked over and saw someone write “f(x) ≈ please let me pass” and I knew then—we were all done.I walked out not because I was finished, but because the war had ended and I had lost. I saw a classmate outside the exam hall just pacing, whispering to himself, “I don’t even know what a series is anymore.”I went back to my room and lay flat on the floor in silence. My roommate came in and thought I was unconscious. I told him, “No, just defeated.”Grades came two weeks later. 61%. Better than Midterm I. Worse than dignity.“Reflect. Learn. Improve.” That’s what the feedback said. As if what I’d just experienced was a group project that needed tweaking. No. What I needed was an exorcism.These were not assessments. They were acts of academic violence.Stay tuned. Because the Final Exam is not a test. It is an execution.✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦Harsh Exam Grading:MIDTERM GRADING: THE ART OF BEING JUDGED BY A VOIDEvery error—every single one—was penalized. Repeatedly. If you made the same mistake across parts (a), (b), and (c), you didn’t lose points once—you lost points thrice. The TFs graded like they were charging interest. One missed negative sign? Minus 2. You do it again in the next part? Minus 2 again. By the end, you weren’t just wrong. You were in mathematical debt.One student asked during office hours if points could be recovered for consistency in error. The TF responded, “This isn’t a personality test.”You start to think maybe you’re being haunted by your earlier mistakes. You see the same comment show up four times. “Wrong bounds.” “Wrong bounds again.” “Still wrong bounds.” “Really?”At this point, it’s not grading. It’s punishment layered with sarcasm. Each red mark a scar. Each deduction a reminder that math is not merciful. It remembers. And it deducts accordingly.You turn in Midterm I with a trembling hand, praying for a shred of mercy. You checked your bounds. You showed your work. You even boxed your final answers like the TF said. But the paper comes back looking like it was marked by a sleep–deprived poet with a vendetta against optimism.“Your method is novel, though not correct.” — minus 6“This integral doesn’t converge. Much like your hope.” — minus 8“Your bounds are... interpretive?” — minus 4“This is not the unit circle’s fault.” — minus 5One student wrote “I used WolframAlpha” in pencil next to a graph. It got crossed out with, “So did I. Still wrong.”Midterm II was worse. Not just because of the math, but because you genuinely thought you were improving. You walked in with notes. You’d made your own convergence cheat sheet. You believed in yourself.The TF did not.“You seem to be confusing conditional convergence with emotional instability.” — minus 6“I am unsure what this sentence is trying to prove, mathematically or spiritually.” — minus 7“This looks like a Taylor series. It is not.” — minus 10“You forgot factorials. The factorials did not forget you.” — minus 12Someone else wrote a haiku instead of solving the 50–term expansion:Infinity loomsThe terms grow ever longerWhy are we still here?They received no points, but the TF underlined it and added: “This spoke to me.”Midterms weren’t assessments. They were confessions. And you were guilty.THE GRADING: A PSYCHOLOGICAL EXPERIMENT IN ABSURDITYWhen the final grades were released, you already knew it was over. But what you didn’t expect were the comments. The point deductions. The creative, soul–crushing notes left on your work like rejection letters from math itself.Here is a non–exhaustive list of actual phrases allegedly scrawled in red ink across student papers, accompanied by their corresponding point deductions:“This is not how cosine behaves.” — minus 5“You’ve summoned something dark here.” — minus 3“Technically not wrong, but also not right in any meaningful way.” — minus 7“Why is there a pirate metaphor in your radius of convergence explanation?” — minus 10“Are you okay?” — minus 2 (emotional concern but still penalized)“Octonauts ready for action.” — minus 40 (conduct penalty)“I’ve never seen someone integrate backwards before.” — minus 8“Creative, but cursed.” — minus 6“I’m giving partial credit out of pity.” — plus 2“No calculator does not mean write down vibes.” — minus 12One student included a small doodle of a slope field crying. It earned no points. Another wrote, “Please curve,” and it was underlined with a single word: “No.”You scroll through your exam. You see 58%, and next to it, a single note: “Good effort.” That’s it. Not “nice try.” Not “see me after class.” Just “good effort,” like you tried to bake cookies and burned down the kitchen.This isn’t grading. This is performance art.✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦The 12–14 weeks of pain:WEEK 1: The Flirtation.You're doing substitution problems like it's a first date. Easy. Fun. You're smiling. You're posting your 10/10 PSET scores like they're thirst traps. You tell your friends, “I actually like this class.” You are innocent. You are foolish. You are doomed.WEEK 2: The Gaslight.The integrals start getting long. But not terrifying. Just enough to make you squint. Erica starts tossing out notation you haven’t seen before. A little mysterious. A little spicy. “Just remember your u–substitutions,” she says. You do. You try. You fail. But you think maybe it’s your fault. It always starts like this.WEEK 3: The Silent Treatment.You start asking questions in section. They don’t get answered. The TF writes something incomprehensible on the board and walks away. You're told “just review your notes.” But the notes are cryptic, half–written spells. You start to realize no one's coming to save you.WEEK 4: The Lovebomb and Withdrawal.You're handed a worksheet with 20 problems due the next day. You complete it. You get it right. You feel proud. You think maybe things are looking up. Then, next class, Erica pulls a full 180: infinite series. 10 new tests. No warning. No transition. Just pain.WEEK 5: The Gas Explosion.Ratio test. Root test. Alternating series. Absolute convergence. Conditional convergence. Everything converges—except your understanding. You try to memorize all the tests. They start blurring together. You make a chart. The chart lies to you.WEEK 6: The Breakdown.Your PSET takes 13 hours. You cry during office hours. You email your TF and get a reply that says “Try the Comparison Test.” You eat lunch while watching a Taylor Series video at 2x speed. You forget how food tastes.WEEK 7: The Taylor Spiral.You’re asked to write a Taylor polynomial about a point that doesn't even exist in the real world. You’re finding derivatives of transcendental functions using formulas you’ve never seen. “Just generalize,” says Erica. You generalize your sorrow.WEEK 8: The Identity Crisis.You start thinking maybe you were never good at math. Maybe you were never meant to be here. You think about switching majors. You think about dropping out. You wonder if Taylor series would converge faster than your GPA is falling.WEEK 9: The Philosophical Turn.You start agreeing with Nietzsche. God is dead, and Erica killed him with a radius of convergence. You find yourself contemplating existence in lecture. You raise your hand to ask, “What does it mean for a series to truly converge?” and the TF writes a summation sign and walks away.WEEK 10: The Hollowing.You are no longer a student. You are a vessel for confusion and half–finished differentials. Your dreams are narrated by series expansions. Your nightmares are slope fields. You sit in lecture and simply accept. Acceptance is the final stage of grief. Math 1B has won.WEEK 11: The Differential Descent.The word “differential” used to sound vaguely scientific. Maybe even elegant. Now, it triggers a full–body reaction. Erica walks in, picks up the chalk, and says “Let’s solve a second–order linear nonhomogeneous differential equation,” and you start to see colors that aren’t there.You thought integrals were bad. You thought convergence tests were painful. You had no idea. Now it’s y double prime plus y prime plus y equals e^x times a cosine. You’re supposed to use undetermined coefficients. Variation of parameters. The method of annihilators. You try to look it up, but Google says “Did you mean: you’re screwed?”WEEK 12: The Breakdown, Redux.The problem sets now involve three layers of differential logic. You’re solving for particular solutions, homogeneous solutions, general solutions—at this point, you just want a solution to your life. You stare at the DE on the board and think, “This must be what it feels like to go insane slowly, beautifully, with a pencil.”You try to ask a question, but it comes out as a sound. Just a noise. Erica responds with a formula that looks like a summoning spell. You copy it down because you’ve stopped resisting. Your notebook is no longer for learning. It’s a place to document the decline.WEEK 13: The Rage.You’ve stopped suffering in silence. You curse aloud during problem sets. You type “Why does Taylor do this” into Google. You threaten to drop a major just to spite this class. You write “Help me” in your notebook and underline it 30 times. Your TF makes eye contact and flinches. You get into a fight with a friend who says, “It’s not that bad.” You cut them off. You were never that close anyway.WEEK 14: The Surrender.The final approaches. You don’t study. You prepare spiritually. You walk into the lecture hall like a condemned soul. You look around and see your classmates in various stages of denial, numbness, and caffeine–induced hysteria. Someone sharpens a pencil like it’s a sword. You nod. This is the end. You whisper “Octonauts ready for action” not as a joke—but as a prayer.✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦ . 　⁺ 　 . ✦THE FINAL EXAM: A LIVE–ACTION BETRAYALThey told us no food, no water, no calculator. I brought a cough drop. I was sick—sick in the way only Math 1B can make a person sick. Coughing, shaking, cold sweating through an exam that was colder than the room. A proctor approached me like I’d brought contraband. I was almost kicked out. For a cough drop. For daring to attempt basic respiratory survival during this academic deathmatch.Had I been removed, I think I would've finally cracked. The breakdown was brewing. Missing one more thing—one more community dinner, one more org meeting, one more birthday, one more final—might’ve been the end. This course had already taken too much. Had they removed me for that Ricola, I would’ve started speaking in series notation and crying Taylor terms.The lecture hall was quiet. Too quiet. You could feel the tension in the air as students filtered in—not chatting, not joking, just solemnly setting down mechanical pencils like weapons before a duel. You weren’t here to succeed. You were here to survive.The moment the clock hit 9:00 AM, the final exam was passed out, and the room collectively exhaled their last hope. You flipped the first page. It was already over.A second–order linear nonhomogeneous differential equation stared back at you like a death sentence. You tried to remember your method of undetermined coefficients. Your brain gave you a flashback to crying in office hours instead.By page two, someone had put their head down and wasn’t moving. By page three, you heard quiet sobbing. Page four had a parametric curve question that looked like a Rorschach test. Someone stood up, walked out, and never returned.A student in the back threw up. Another cursed audibly. The proctor didn’t even blink. This was normal. This was expected. This was Math 1B.You reached the Taylor series expansion and just stared. It wanted a 40–term expansion centered at a point that might not exist. You wrote four terms and then—without hesitation—wrote “Octonauts ready for action” at the bottom. Because what else could you do? Pray? Cry? Beg for mercy from a function?The last problem asked you to analyze convergence in a series that looked like it had been cursed by a Victorian child. You wrote “I’m sorry” in the margin.And then, somehow, it was over.You stumbled out of the lecture hall into the blinding daylight. Someone was weeping on the steps. Another was making a TikTok about the experience. You stood there, hollowed out, stripped of ego and energy—and smiled.Because it was done.Because you survived.Because despite everything—despite the conduct penalty, the sleepless nights, the cursed slope fields—you finished Math 1B.And for the first time in months, you felt joy. Real, tangible joy. The joy of walking away from the wreckage with your sanity mostly intact. Of knowing that you would never again have to write a Taylor series. Of knowing that Erica Dinkins could no longer touch you.Octonauts. Ready for freedom.EPILOGUE: A LETTER TO FUTURE FIRST–YEARSIf you’re reading this, it means you’ve heard the whispers. The legends. The rumors about Math 1B. Maybe you’re a freshman—bright–eyed, determined, ready to take on Harvard’s STEM courses with the energy of a caffeinated golden retriever. Maybe someone told you it wasn’t that bad. Maybe you believed them.Don’t.Math 1B is not just a class. It is a gauntlet. A psychological operation. A semester–long fever dream of integrals, infinite series, and unspeakable differential horrors. It is a trial by fire in which you will be burned, branded, and broken—and if you’re lucky, you’ll crawl out the other side with a C+ and a ghost permanently whispering “Taylor approximation” in your ear.But you don’t have to do this. You have choices. If you can place into 21A—do it. If you can take 1A instead—bless yourself and do it. Do not let the advisors lie to you. Do not let the siren song of “everyone takes it” lull you into the abyss. If someone from the department says “it builds character,” understand they mean it in the same way a collapsed bridge builds swimming skills.And if you’ve already committed—brace yourself. Arm yourself. Find your people. Make a meme folder. Go to office hours, even if only to sob quietly into your notebook. Watch lectures on 2x speed and let the confusion wash over you like a wave. Drink water. Sleep when you can. Mourn what you lose, celebrate what you finish.You will forget the math. But you will never forget the madness.Sincerely,A survivor of the series.–ON TF Trainor & CourseHead DinkinsLet’s not pretend. Let’s not tiptoe. Let’s talk about what it actually feels like to be in Math 1B, sitting under those godforsaken fluorescent lights while Erica Dinkins—the Course Head, the CEO of Cold Disdain, the Grand Inquisitor of Convergence—waltzes into the room with the emotional warmth of a malfunctioning Roomba.From the moment she steps in, the temperature drops. I’m not kidding. It physically feels colder. She has that presence—icy, distant, surgical. She doesn’t walk, she glides, like some sort of cryptic math spirit summoned by the cries of struggling freshmen.And you? You, sitting there with your notebook open and a half–chewed pencil in your hand, think to yourself: “I have a question. A real question. A good–faith question.” And you raise your hand. Slowly. Nervously. Hoping this will be the day the room finally turns human.But she turns to you. And that look—God, that look—is something you feel in your bones. Like she’s already done a triple integral of your soul and found it lacking. She doesn’t ask you what your question is. She doesn’t encourage. She just says, with that edge in her voice, “We already covered that.”Or worse: she answers your question with another question—abstract, symbolic, disembodied—and you’re left even more confused, now deeply ashamed, and maybe even wondering if you imagined the whole lecture.There were moments—moments burned into memory—where she’d write a horrifying expression on the board and say “this should be clear” while half the room was blinking like hostages. I saw people sweating, physically sweating, while trying to follow her derivation of a power series expansion around a point she pulled from the underworld. She once solved an entire differential equation in what I can only describe as emotional Morse code—rapid, hostile chalk movements—and when someone asked her to explain step three, she turned and looked like they’d just spit on Euclid.It’s not that she didn’t teach. It’s that she didn’t teach us. She taught ghosts. She taught theoretical students who already took Math 21A in the womb. If you weren’t in the top 5% of math fluency, you didn’t exist to her. You were an inconvenience. A background hum. Static in the calculus frequency she operated on.I started doubting myself in that room. Started shrinking. Started losing my voice. You don’t realize it at first, but it chips away at you. A comment here. A sigh there. A refusal to acknowledge the question that was maybe your one shot at getting it. And by the time Week 8 rolled around, I wasn’t asking anymore. I wasn’t engaging. I was surviving.But then there was Charlotte.And if I talk about Erica with fire, I talk about Charlotte with full–hearted, tear–streaked reverence.Charlotte is the kind of TF you write novels about. The kind of academic mentor you remember forever. She didn’t just help me understand the material. She helped me remember that I wasn’t stupid. That I still had value as a learner. That even though I wasn’t writing 40–term Taylor series in my sleep like some math cyborg, I was still worthy of kindness. Of patience.She never made me feel small. She never looked at me with that Erica–brand scorn. She would pause—pause mid–sentence—to make sure you were following. And if you weren’t, she wouldn’t move on. She’d go back. She’d re–explain. She’d ask what step lost you and trace it out carefully, like she was untangling a knot she wanted to help you loosen.There were nights—real, painful nights—where I would come to her with PSETs that looked like they’d been through a shredder. And she didn’t flinch. She’d say, “Okay. Let’s figure this out.” And those four words? They saved me. She made math feel like something I could try again. Not conquer. Not master. Just try.Charlotte made it safe to fail. Erica made it shameful.And that’s the difference. That’s the core of it.One woman walked in each day with an arsenal of equations and an air of silent judgment. The other walked in with a whiteboard marker and a heart.I don’t know what would’ve happened without Charlotte. I genuinely don’t. Because by Week 10, I was losing it. I was losing myself. But she reminded me that Math 1B didn’t get to define me. That I was more than a percent, more than a boxed final answer with a red X. She reminded me that learning is a process, not a punishment.So yeah—Erica ran the show. But Charlotte? Charlotte saved it.And if no one else says it, I will: give that woman a raise. Give her tenure. Give her the course. Because she taught with grace in a system built to break us.And I’ll never forget that.

best_comment: Completing three psets a week is definitely time–consuming, so expect this course to require a significant time commitment. My best advice is to do your psets at the MQC—the CAs are super helpful, especially if you are stuck/don't know what the question is asking. Putting a decent effort into the psets will also make studying for exams much easier.
worse_comment: I would only take this course if you actually need it. This class is a bit of a hurdle to get over, and talking to other students, it seems to be one of the more difficult math course. Something to be mindful of is that this class is weighted heavily on exams, which can really affect you at the end. This course wasn't something that I was worried about in the first semester, and turned up to be the class I worried about the most ending off the semester. I by far spent over 15 hours on this class doing problem sets, learning the material, studying, and still wasn't able to succeed in the course. I'm not sure what background you need, but the exams aren't fully representative of the materials taught in class. With the problem sets, you're expected to learn new topics on your own.

best_comment: The horror stories you hear about this class are not real. While there are three psets a week, they are manageable and the content is important; I definitely plan to use what I've learned in Math 1B in future classes and other pursuits. That said, this class does have some major flaws. The main issue is that CAs grade psets while TFs grade exams. If your experience in this class is anything like mine, you'll receive many perfect scores on psets from lazy CAs, and while this is a great problem to have, you'll be convinced that the work you do on psets is correct and therefore should be applied to the exams. Wrong... the TFs grade harshly, and you'll be forced to go back to every lesson on your own and correct your current logic. Moreover, my TF had very poor time management, and we never finished worksheets in their entirety. Safe to say, you'll have to do a bit more work outside of class than you'd like. Still, I never felt too overwhelmed  with the workload. I'd recommend this class, but be wary of what I've mentioned.
worse_comment: don't fall behind, it will be very hard to catch up, do a lot of practice problems

best_comment: Take this class. It's not easy and it'll push you, but if you have a math brain you'll be fine. However, if you are like me and it takes a long time for certain topics to click, it's challenging because there isn't enough time to nail the concepts between exams. The tests will have you going into it thinking "yeah I know how series work and what they are" and then leaving thinking "nevermind." I think the way they test is very true to the "ability to apply concepts" and I quickly realized I had a hard time applying concepts. Don't be discouraged because there is a lot of support for this class but I would say don't expect an easy A at all.

Review the worksheet solutions after every class. There were times when there would be something that we had to include in the answer to receive full credit that wasn't mentioned in section at all and was only included in the worksheet solutions. On the first exam I got an insane amount of points off for not fully explaining my answers even though they were correct because I answer the questions the way that we did in class without looking at the worksheet solutions.
worse_comment: I understand if you need to take this class, but whatever you've heard about Math 1b, it's all true. Go to MQC and Office Hours early if you have to take this class. The lack of curve may kill your GPA

best_comment: This is a hard math class. Simply put. It is something you are going to have to go through if you are a STEM major and I think it is doable but be ready to make this your number 1 priority class, maybe 2 if you're great at math. This is a difficult course conceptually and is very fast–paced. It also has a big workload with 3 PSETS a week. Be ready to ALWAYS have something to do for math.
worse_comment: It's a basic intro course teaching you the fundamentals of calculus. It can be time consuming, so if you're taking it for a reason besides fulfilling requirements I wouldn't say it's worth it.

best_comment: This is a hard math class. Simply put. It is something you are going to have to go through if you are a STEM major and I think it is doable but be ready to make this your number 1 priority class, maybe 2 if you're great at math. best_comment: It's definitely not as bad as people say. That being said make sure you actually understand why things work the way they do. The concepts build gradually on top of each other, so if you have that understanding makes the class very doable, if you don't I can see how it can be very hard to stay on top of things. The 3 PSets can be a lot because there is always something to do for the class, but they also make sure that you stay engaged with the content. Before exams, take all of the practice exams and go step by step through the solutions to make sure you understand what you are doing right and what you are doing wrong. Don't let negative comments about this class discourage you from taking it, I wish I had taken it earlier and had the potential to take further maths courses. Amadeus is also amazing! Very understanding and helpful course had and section leader who always has the best interest of his students in mind.
Great class! Fun concepts and great real–world connections and applications of the content. The 3 psets per week can be a little overwhelming, but go to MQC and ask your friends for help.

This course is intense. By the end of the semester, you'll eat, drink, and speak math. PSets and worksheets keep you busy daily, as do AI assignments. The quantity of material covered is so much that it might seem (and it is true) that at times the material is not being learnt too efficiently, but that is okay once you get to exams. Exams (4 of them throughout the semester) are a way for you to go over all the material you covered in class, so by doing the practice tests (i.e. doing them in a timed environment, checking answers, reattempting them) you'll learn everything. It always strikes me that unfortunately, at Harvard, course support is decreasing in difficulty of the course itself. That is to say, this course has a ton of support material, MQC, office hours, fun TFs that are very good at explaining, so you'll never run out of options to consider when doing work for the class. But this is jus because this class is introductory. Overall, the course is well–structured, intense, and prepares you well for courses in other concentrations that you might approach in your time at Harvard, so I recommend this (especially over 22B. I took 22A and it was just the worst experience I've had at Harvard).
worse_comment: I wouldn't take this course unless you are unbothered by constant PSETs or it is a requirement. You get a PSET every couple days so there's no way to get ahead, which is tough if you have a busy schedule.

best_comment: although i took it as a req, it was actually okay. also there’s a lot of group work which i don’t really like but it was highkey very helpful to work on the boards
worse_comment: Pay attention and understand the psets because if you do not it is easy to get behind because everything builds on the prior topic.

best_comment: If you take this course, go to MQC and Office Hours – even if you understand the content. These are great resources to discuss broader course concepts and to get exam advice from CAs and TFs. This is a difficult course, but it is completely manageable. The 3 PSets a week are difficult (especially if you are taking other PSet classes), but they are good prep for exams. Put forth your best effort, and you will do well in this course.

I originally took Multivariable Calculus at my local community college in high school and found the course here to be significantly better. Taking Math 21a allowed me to have a solid understanding of the content, and I appreciate the amount of effort put into teaching the material. It meets 3 times a week in small class sections, which is by far the best part of the course. Your TF will lecture, and you solve problems with others at your tables or on the chalkboards in small groups – repeating this with the next iteration of new content multiple times in each lecture. This makes it helpful to follow and understand the material. I think you only need AP Calculus AB (or Math 1a) and some self–studying of integration by parts to take this course. It is not hard as long as you take the time to understand the material before the next lecture. The most important piece of advice I have is to not fall behind!The midterm exams were very fair. I never left feeling like I had not studied enough. However, the PSETS and AI Assignments, which I believe were new this semester, were my least favorite part of the course. I am very detail–oriented and try to understand everything for an easier study period when exams come up. As a consequence for me, I spent 4–5 hours on average for most of the PSETS in this course. Some people I know were able to get them done faster. The AI assignments were problematic because the AI tutor simply refuses to tell you if you are on the right track with your answers.Overall, this course is great!

if you have taken math 1b, math 21a will feel like a natural continuation. to me, it felt even easier, given that, by then, I was used to the way math is taught at Harvard. if you like rigor and proofs, don't take the class, you will find neither. but the class does well what it promises: a good overview of multi for stem (non pure math) concentrators. as you will know, the experience in the class will depend largely on your TF. Eva was great and made every single section very enjoyable and engaging. exams were super fair, definitely easier than practice tests.
worse_comment: This course gets so confusing and the tfs aren't teaching you how everything connects, which makes it so hard to actually understand. Also, we just speed through everything and barely get through half the worksheet in class so then you are lost on the pset. Only take this class if you are proficient in math and ready to spend hours on it each week.
