Also, we just speed through everything and barely get through half the worksheet in class so then you are lost on the pset. Only take this class if you are proficient in math and ready to spend hours on it each week.

best_comment: Take this class! It's taught very well (depending on your TF). Amadeus is really great, and I think the content is actually really interesting and fun to learn. Sections were super effective and although it's 3 psets a week, you can finish one in less than 2 hours. If you want to learn multivariable calculus, this is such a great class. Definitely take advantage of all the practice materials when exams come around. The first midterm was pretty chill and the second one was slightly harder. Start studying relatively early and take all the practice exams, and you will be fine.
worse_comment: This class made me love math. I thought math was my least favorite subject and was dreading taking this class, but I genuinely enjoyed this course so much that I enrolled in two more math classes next semester. If you are scared to take it because you feel that your calculus skills aren't good enough, they are more than likely sufficient. I took Calc BC in my senior year of high school, and took this course my sophomore spring as my first math class at Harvard. I was terrified and was confident that I would need to drop down to Math 1b; however, the content is taught so incredibly that I did really well in the class. I am not amazing at math, and, honestly, I am probably a little bit worse than the average Harvard student, but I am finishing the class with a good grade and a new interest in math. I can't recommend this course enough.

best_comment: I loved this course. Even though you will likely not have a choice as to whether you take it or not, it is a great class that you should be excited to take either way. If you can see which TF takes which section before enrolling, pick Jonier's section! You will meet lots of new people so it is a brilliant course for first years in my opinion too. The psets really aren't too bad, and they are very fair with grading and midterms.
worse_comment: WARNING ⚠️! This class is SO HARD. Especially if you do not come from a math–intensive background. A lot of people in these QReports will say that it is fine and that the class was manageable, but these are people who have already taken multivariable calculus in the past. There are two clear distinctions of people in this class: (1) those who are doing well and do not study much for the exams and still ace them vs. (2) those who have not taken multivariable calculus before and are struggling. My biggest advice is to find friends and understand that you will struggle. You will feel lost but push through it because I am assuming you don't plan on taking this class just for fun but you need it for your major. Talk to your TF (and make sure you like them and they like you) and ask your friends to study with you so you can all solve problems together. The exams can also be extremely difficult. Midterm 2 for us was so bad. Most of me friends and I got horrible grades (aka < 60%) but it's consistently this trend of people who already know the material getting A's and us who studied for weeks (genuinely) and getting screwed over with the unrealistic expectations. I am writing this at a time where I haven't taken the final yet, but this class has been MISERABLE and it will be MISERABLE if you are like me, coming from a non–math extensive background and a high school with limited resources. Know you are not struggling alone and take up all the resources there are. Goodbye MATH 21A, I hated you.

best_comment: I loved this course. Even though you will likely not have a choice as to whether you take it or not, it is a great class that you should be excited to take either way. If you can see which TF takes which section before enrolling, pick Jonier's section! You will meet lots of new people so it is a brilliant course for first years in my opinion too. The psets really aren't too bad, and they are very fair with grading and midterms.

best_comment: Background: Freshman who took 22a in the fall, and decided to take 21a in the spring. In HS, did AP Calc BC in Junior Year & Multi/Linear Algebra in Senior Year.Thoughts: Very solid class. Excellent teaching staff and environment. You learn a decent amount but it's super reasonable. PSETs aren't too hard. [ALSO] I made the decision to take 22a in the fall because it was 1 pset and was more challenging than some classes I thought were a little easy. 22a was taught poorly so I made the switch to 21a. The 3 psets aren't bad. In fact, I spent more time in 22a doing a pset than maybe like 4–5 psets in 21a.

Math 21b is a very rigorous but very rewarding course. I would recommend to take this course because I feel like I learned a lot of mathematical skills that will be helpful for other STEM courses. However, when the course description says it is fast–paced, it's telling the truth. If you're taking this class it will be your main class for the semester, and you will be booked 7:30–10:30pm Sunday–Thursday (MQC).  The bright side is that you make a lot of friends trauma–bonding through MQC as you struggle to make Mathematica work so you can finish your PSet (only to have another one assigned the very next day). Three PSets a week is no joke. Yes, this class is very hard, but if I were to go back to course registration, I would still choose to take it because of how much I got out of it. The material is very challenging, but the teaching staff is amazing, and the small–section teaching model makes it a lot easier to learn the content. There are also so many opportunities to get support when it is needed. If you are debating taking the class, I would urge you to, just be mindful about the time commitment when choosing your other classes.

Take this class if you’re willing to put in the work! If so, you’ll really enjoy it—one of the coolest math classes I’ve ever taken, with a lot of great applications to everything from population dynamics to sound production. The psets and exams are quite fair, and although the 20 True/False questions on each exam can be brutal, the rest is totally doable if you study! Make sure to take advantage of office hours, CA help, and the video resources that they post on Canvas :) As a person who isn’t usually a fan of math, I’m pleasantly surprised by this class!

21b is an amazing class. Math instruction at Harvard is overall incredible. Taking linear algebra is something that will make you a smarter person and a better abstract thinker. It is challenging but also pretty satisfying and rewarding. Definitely stay on top of the worksheets and psets. And start preparing for the tests way more in advance than you would usually for other classes. If you are an econ concentrator and considering graduate studies, I strongly recommend this class over the other linear algebra classes. The 3x a week plus small sections situation is actually really helpful in terms of learning and accountability.
worse_comment: This class is genuinely difficult. The material can often be hard to understand and it all builds up so if you don't understand something at first, CLARIFY DOUBTS! Otherwise you will be confused for the rest of lectures. For exams, study with time, it's dreading at first but when everything clicks it makes sense (to an extent).

best_comment: 21b is an amazing class. Math instruction at Harvard is overall incredible. Taking linear algebra is something that will make you a smarter person and a better abstract thinker. It is challenging but also pretty satisfying and rewarding. Definitely stay on top of the worksheets and psets. Otherwise you will be confused for the rest of lectures. For exams, study with time, it's dreading at first but when everything clicks it makes sense (to an extent).

best_comment: Spend 20 minutes before each class reviewing the reading materials because it will allow you to better absorb information in class and you'll feel more confident approaching the worksheets. After class, finish the worksheets in OH or on your own to prepare for the Psets. Space out the Psets across two days each so you have time to ask questions in OH and aren't overwhelmed by them. Do the extra steps like warmups and extra credit problems, you'll thank yourself later because they further your understanding of material that you otherwise wouldn't get. Conceptual understanding is INCREDIBLY important in this class––I cannot stress enough how memorizing formulas/rules will take you like 30% of the way there but you need to develop a flexible understanding of things beyond that. Space out studying with practice exams, it took me two days per exam to first take it then review it deeply, redo questions, and come to OH. If you don't do well on a question lean into that concept––review textbook, handouts, videos, write down even the most minute questions you have about it to make sure you cover your bases. The weekly quizzes are relatively helpful but the free late days from them are definitely worth it. If you are historically not confident in your math ability, like me, try to come into the class with a positive mindset and take advantage of as many of the resources as you can and I truly think you'll be okay. 21B was a wonderful course for me and I'm so glad I took it, I also found it a lot more approachable than 21A (my calc background is pretty weak).
worse_comment: Listen, if you're taking this class you probably have to so it doesn't make a difference what the feedback is. BUT. This class is very difficult so do not pack your schedule. The second half of this class is brutal, the instructors do not grant extensions even with serious illnessess, the tests are often very difficult even with a lot of preparation, and this class might make you regret coming to this school. That being said, you can find a community of people who are also struggling and all study together which makes it slightly better. If you at all can avoid taking this class I would.

That being said, you can find a community of people who are also struggling and all study together which makes it slightly better. If you at all can avoid taking this class I would.

best_comment: The learning curve is steep at first but the concepts were built on each other very nicely. The support system is very strong, with a lot of materials and office hours/mock sessions to help you understand the material and prepare for exams. Also, the practice exams are a lot harder than the actual exams. This might depend on the course head, but a lot of math puns which lightened up the mood!! This course lowkey made me find my love for math again. The struggle was real, but linear algebra is so cool. Daniel Hu is a great TF (such a cool and relatable person)!! He explains things step–by–step, such as how the previous concepts lead to the current one, and the different chart organizations to help remember them.
worse_comment: This class is harder than Math 21a, but it's still very doable. Pay attention in class. Start studying early for the midterms. Go to the quiz sessions and utilize the MQC if you find a pset particularly challenging. With the proper time management, this course is not that bad. However, the problem sets do take longer than Math 21a problem sets!

best_comment: This is a good class to take if you don't want the proof–based approach to linear algebra. The three psets a week honestly aren't that bad (I would recommend doing them right after your class if you can!)  Exams were pretty fair, just make sure to take the practice tests before and hone your conceptual understanding (the true and false questions could sometimes be annoying). Overall, I feel like the pacing of this class was good, the teaching staff was amazing, and the concepts we covered were really interesting and SO applicable to a lot of the more advanced science/math classes that you will take at Harvard.

Review for those coming from 21A: Now that you have experienced a higher level of abstraction, it is time to take another step in that direction with this course. I think you are more than ready, but be prepared to wrestle with these concepts. Ultimately, I would recommend that you create a schedule to frequent office hours; this not only helps you with your pset grades, but also ensures that you ask questions to the teaching team that aid in your conceptual understanding of the material, as having agency over it will be valuable in courses that use linear algebra. In that schedule, I would also suggest reading the prescribed textbook sections before section and after, and reviewing the worksheet solutions. THEN work on the PSet during office hours. This will likely ensure a close to 100% uptake of the material with lasting and intuitive understanding. Review for incoming first–years: Depending on the high school you are coming from, this may be vastly different or similar to what you are used to, so give yourself some time to try out different study techniques, especially for this course, as the three psets a week can really grind your gears. If you have a decent understanding of multi, then you are more than ready for this course. It will refer to multi concepts a few times for specific lessons but some review should suffice. I mainly want you to be informed of the abstractness of the material and the amount of time this will take out of your week (10–16 hours outside of class). Good luck!

After taking 4 intro math courses at Harvard (1a, 1b, 21a, 21b), I can certainly say this is one was the hardest. It was the second most enjoyable after 21a and definitely built off of a bit of 21a, so I'd just recommend starting with 21a. The PSETs for this class are long and having three of them a week is annoying but it really does make you learn the content. Overall, like every intro math class, very solid but again highly dependent on your TF (I had Roderic and he was awesome!!), so don't be afraid of jumping around sections in the beginning to find the right TF for you. My only pet peeve with this class is the T or F, I understand that it allows you to cover more content in a very short format but I feel like there have got to be better ways of doing that than testing corner cases of theory. I don't think students will remember a specific counter example for something about the kernel in an nth dimension vs what a fourier series was and how it is applicable. I just think that isn't very conducive to learning, especially if it can come down to just a 50/50 chance and you not even having to explain your train of thought. Idk. I think if you get them right without knowing you got free points, but at the same time it's very difficult to study and be prepared for those corner cases. Also, perhaps changing the format of the weekly quiz sessions again so that maybe 4 quiz session attendances (so a month) is equal to one pset drop with a max of two extra pset drops or something because I feel like late hours for psets really isn't useful because there is already immediately another one breathing down your neck. The exams were relatively easier than the practices but you learn so much from the practices and they really humble you so you go in prepared for the exams. Overall, great course, content is super interesting but difficult, same old of doing the psets with a pset group, paying a lot of attention in class, and grinding a lot before exams by doing all the practice exams.
worse_comment: Honestly more interesting than 21a but I will say that the tests are slightly more difficult. First exam in this class is much worse than the second so don’t be scared if you don’t do well initially.

best_comment: This course is so much better than the other intro math courses, and genuinely emphasizes learning and a flexible understanding of the material. The exams are easier than the practice exams, and none of the work challenges expectations or leaves you feeling lost and unprepared the way I have felt with 21a and 1b.

An amazing class that you should take if you want to get an intro to linear algebra and differential equations. My TF was great, meaning sections were super productive and the CAs made the experience very fun and enjoyable. There are three psets a week, which seems intimidating, but if you sit down and focus on them it is definitely doable even with a packed/busy schedule. Tests were reasonable throughout the semester, and I met some really close friends through the class. Would really recommend!!
worse_comment: Do NOT take this class if you can avoid it. The three PSETS a week are a grind and often take away from the learning experience since youre more focused on completion rather than really learning the material and its applications. This class, because it is not lecture style, is super TF dependent. If you end up getting a TF whos not really great at explaining, BELIEVE ME, youre going to have a bad time (This is what happened to me)! So my piece of advice is that if you can take 22A instead it, you definitely should!!!! I understand the proofs are an added aspect to the course, but what you add to the rigor of the class, will be outweighed by the lack of structure, bad TF's, and the three PSETS a week which kills the learning process and makes this class an absolute nightmare. I am an engineering concentrator so I had the choice between 22A and 21B, but due to my plan of study timeline I had to take this course at the time I did, if I could have I would have avoided it.

best_comment: This class is fantastic! Take it for sure. It's a reasonable workload, interesting material, really strong teaching staff. I don't have any notes about improving this course.
worse_comment: This class will not be easy. Go to MQC and office hours, the material builds on itself heavily!

best_comment: This class is fantastic! Take it for sure. It's a reasonable workload, interesting material, really strong teaching staff. I don't have any notes about improving this course.
worse_comment: This class will not be easy. Go to MQC and office hours, the material builds on itself heavily!

best_comment: I seriously recommend this course with reservations. To start off with the good, I think that the material in 21b is extremely interesting, enjoyable, and applicable to real life. I think this course was even better than 21a, which I took in the fall. I also think that for the most part, this course was much easier than 21a, but this is a controversial opinion. 21a felt much more methodological while this is just brute force problem solving, which I personally enjoy. Additionally, this class is taught in small sections, so this more intimate setting is helpful for asking questions and getting to know your peers. I especially enjoyed working on the boards. With that said, there were also a bunch of things I didn't like about this class. First, I feel that three PSets a week is so much, especially given how long most of them were. There were several PSets in which we had 4+ problems with parts A through E or F. This was extremely time consuming, and it almost felt counterproductive to my learning because sometimes I just needed to get the PSet done, and I couldn't take as much time as I wanted to truly understand the material since we were constantly moving. I would estimate that each PSet took between 2–6 hours, with the majority probably taking 3–4. I'd definitely consider how this much time out of class fits in with your other classes before adding this to your Crimson Cart.Additionally, I was in the 3 PM section, and there were hardly ever office hours after 4:15 when class ended, which meant that I had to wait until MQC at 7:30 to get help since I had 4 classes Mondays, Wednesday, and Friday starting from 9:45 and stretching all the way until the end of math until 4:15. This would be even worse on Fridays because I would have to wait all the way until Sunday MQC to get any help, so this was incredibly frustrating since I also had PSets for two other classes due around the same time each week, and I needed to get support for those as well. I think the exams were relatively fair, but there were 20 true–false on each exam and no partial credit was given. That felt a bit excessive.  As a student looking to study CS, I honestly wish I took 22a or a higher numbered course instead because I would've gained more mathematical maturity from taking one of those courses, which is integral to CS. But I still enjoyed this class, and I still think you would get a lot out of it. I would recommend only taking the 21 series if your intended concentration recommends it over any other level (I came in as engineering, where 21 is sufficient) . However, I think that with the right people, the problem sets and the studying are very doable. I basically lived at MQC this semester, but I think I learned a lot from my peers while I was there and the CAs were also helpful.
worse_comment: I want to tell them to take the weird and intricate aspects of the class seriously as they can seriously hurt your grade if you're not careful.

I basically lived at MQC this semester, but I think I learned a lot from my peers while I was there and the CAs were also helpful.
worse_comment: I want to tell them to take the weird and intricate aspects of the class seriously as they can seriously hurt your grade if you're not careful.

course_title: Vector Calculus and Linear Algebra II 001
best_comment: This class was great! 22a got a lot of hate last semester, but keep in mind that was Prof. Wood's first time teaching the course. That being said, he made a significant number of improvements based on feedback. Here are a few; there are not longer random extra days of class, section is optional now, lectures feel better paced with a bit more time for problems, attendance sheets were simplified and make more sense, the random extra coding/math projects are gone, and so on. It is also clear from the syllabus that Prof. Wood read through the Q guide, identified resources that were particularly helpful to students last semester, and emphasized them this semester. Perhaps the only note I have about this course is that students should really take 22a first, as a lot of 22b draws on concepts from 22a (especially at the beginning of class).  It helps to brush up on 22a materials also, especially if you may have forgotten over winter break or took 22a longer than a semester ago. Other than that, this course is pretty straightforward – grading is to your benefit, classes are easy to follow, and the prof cares a lot and so makes the material interesting (therefore making it easier to learn). This course has 3 midterms (they weren't bad, were graded pretty leniently and the questions made sense). It is proof based, so much of the homework involves writing proofs instead of explicit calculation. Especially compared to 21, this class has only one pset and one brief online assignment per week, making it by and far less stressful (source; the pained looks on the faces of my friends in 21). Teaching staff are nice and available when needed. I felt that I took a lot away from this course, and I would definitely recommend it! (Bonus note; if you are free, the best office hours to go to are Wood's own – he explains stuff better (more effectively and more efficiently) and is super nice. I had classes during his OH this semester, but if you can, definitely go and say hi)
worse_comment: You'll come away from this class proficient in applying Stokes' Theorem, but without much understanding of why we're using said theorem or why we took a certain approach to prove it. You'll learn to perform the calculations, but not truly understand the structure governing multivariable calculus — which is concerning, considering that this is a proof–based course (for reference, I attended every lecture and kept up with the material; I still felt somewhat lost as to the "why"; maybe also because there are almost zero real–world application problems to see theorems in action). There are also issues with organization. Problem sets have little to nothing to do with exam material, and often require leaps of thinking that necessitate going to office hours to find a very specific approach. Points are also taken off arbitrarily by CAs who were perhaps grading carelessly — but if you confront Dr. Wood about a possible grading mistake, he's extremely unlikely to change it (he'll just try to retroactively justify why the choice was made, even when it's clear that it was a mistake). Exam practice materials are posted extremely late and often come with no solutions and many errors.With that said, the course pack structure — in which Dr. Wood lectures and students follow along in a set of notes containing theorems and practice problems — works well, and the exams aren't unreasonable. A decent option for those looking for a somewhat more rigorous approach to multivariable calculus but aren't interested in spending 20 hours/week on Math 25 or 55.

course_title: Theoretical Linear Algebra and Real Analysis II 001
best_comment: Wes is THE GOAT. He is a phenomenal lecturer who is capable of explaining complicated material in a very accessible way. His enthusiasm and devotion to his class and the students in it are very inspiring. That being said, 25b is a hard class, definitely harder than 25a and one that is likely to kill your GPA, but you come of it with increased mathematical maturity and independence as well as proof stamina. Personally, I preferred the content of 25a, but I am more of an algebra guy, so take this as you will. If you're on the fence between 25b and 55b, I would definitely shop both especially given that next year's 25b will be taught by a different instructor. But personally, I feel like I gained a better understanding of real analysis in 25b than I would have in 55b. All in all, this was a great class with a fantastic community and an incredible instructor.

course_title: Studies in Real and Complex analysis 001
best_comment: PLEASE TAKE THIS CLASS! If you're reading this, you probably took 22a or 25a last semester, and considering moving up because of whatever. If so, please please please take the class. I was in the exact same situation having not taken 55a last semester, and wanted to challenge myself further with more math. Switching to 55b was probably the absolute best decision I made this semester and I have absolutely zero regrets about doing so. Yes, the workload was pretty insane at points (prepare for a LOT of all nighters), but you will definitely get through it. You also won't need much content from 55a. There's a bit of algebra when it comes to algebraic topology, but it is completely learnable when you get to that point. There was an in person midterm which was pretty brutal, but it was a small percentage of the grade so it really didn't matter in the end. Most of your grade will be from psets, so if you invest a lot of time into those and find a good group of friends to work on them with, you will be absolutely fine. Prof. Auroux gives really good lectures, and I would try go to them as much as possible, but the lecture notes are also a very very good resource (pretty much all I used).Basically, if you took 22a or 25a and want more, just take the class and don't think about it anymore. The first few weeks might be a bit rough as you get used to the workload and find people to work with, but once things settle down, it will probably end up being your favorite class, as this is exactly what happened in my case.  Taking the class allowed me to meet who I now consider my best friends, so I owe so much to the class for that.Just try it! You won't regret it!
worse_comment: Take the class if you really love pure math. If not, you might end up disliking some parts of pure math by the end. Personally, I really liked the analysis section but disliked the algebra section from 55a. Be ready for a lot of homework. The problem sets can be a drag and some problems might have proofs that span several pages.

course_title: Reading Course for Senior Honors Candidates 001
best_comment: This is a great class if you want a lighter course load to concentrate on your math thesis.

If the 99r has an interesting topic, by all means take it! Our year there were completion–graded weekly PSets to help you along.The paper isn't too stressful.Another major benefit is that the grad students are very available outside of class, and are very kind and receptive to questions about anything math related!(and Wyatt was amazing this year)
worse_comment: My one recommendation is don't just think 99r classes are going to be a joke. 99r are different every year but this iteration was a very serious math class covering content no other undergraduate course covers. We covered more material per lecture than any other class I had been in.

best_comment: This is a great class. I took it as an introduction to proofs because there are some more advanced cs classes I wanted to take that required a proof knowledge but I really enjoyed it. Prof Brazelton was really understanding and en effective lecturer, really helpful when you needed help without being overbearing when you didn't need help. The smaller size was really great for engaging with the material and asking questions. Overall psets were not bad at all. The first half of the semester was really really easy, got more difficult toward the end but still definitely manageable. A really great introduction to pure math, I had never taken a pure math course before and was really intrigued by the different way of thinking. Definitely recommend!
worse_comment: This course could be so interesting if it was well taught. Unfortunately, that was not the case this year. If Brazelton teaches, I would highly NOT recommend this course. The course content is so interesting and you really learn a lot, but that's in spite of the fact that the teaching staff is basically incompetent. Some of the TFs were amazing, but Brazelton was unorganized, unempathetic, and just seemed to really not care about his students' learning experience. The homework problems came out of left field and we were NOT equipped with the tools to solve problems, leaving us to go to OH to solve it. That would be fine if the OH weren't being cancelled every single week, or Brazelton answered his email within the day. Unfortunately, this class was horribly taught. I would recommend you take it only if it's taught by someone else. Shoutout Victor on the TF team because he is the goat and would hold extra review sessions and OH just to make sure we understood the material.

best_comment: This will be said again and again, but math department courses HEAVILY DEPEND ON YOUR INSTRUCTOR!! If they have unfavorable reviews in past courses, it's not likely that there will be significant change later on. This review is only applicable to you if you're being taught by Park in a future class (I'm not sure how much longer he's in the dept. since he's a post doc). In this class, everyone I talked to was confused and didn't know what was going on. The content isn't necessarily the most riveting thing on Earth, but it certainly can be taught with enthusiasm. There was no enthusiasm from anyone in this class. I'm glad I took it to get my analysis req. out of the way, but certainly taking a more interesting class would have done me better. Grading wise, since the class is literally 70% Psets, don't worry about that. Instead, worry about your own intellectual vitality. And be wary of the instructors at this school who will snuff it out.
worse_comment: Math 112 may suck, it may be great. Likely it will suck. It all depends on what new grad student the math department dredges up to teach the course—they find a new one every. single. semester. My semester, the grad student—through no fault of his own—wasn't a good teacher, so the course wasn't good. The previous semester, the grad student was a good teacher, so the course wasn't good. If you have to take the class, you have to take the class. In retrospect, however, it might have been wiser to drop the class after the first few lectures, and hope that the randomly selected grad student was a better teacher next semester.

best_comment: Complex analysis is very cool class, at least the first half of it was cool. As we got toward the end of the semester, it lowkey became a real analysis class—we talked about infinite series and products for weeks, and I didn’t find that very fun. We could’ve learned so many more cool theorems in complex analysis than spending too much time on things we could’ve learned in real analysis. But what this meant was that the PSets were very easy in the second half of the semester. As long as you get through the pretty tricky proof questions as the course starts, things get significantly more straightforward at the end. The professor was also very relaxed with giving assignments. We had a lot of breathing time—sometimes we wouldn’t have PSets for a week, sometimes we would have an extremely short PSet. I think people should take this class for sure because it still gives you the mathematical vocabulary that you wouldn’t otherwise know.  Complex analysis is pretty thought–provoking and I hope in the future, it could use time better to teach more interesting results in the complex world.
worse_comment: I took this course without any experience with topology or real analysis, and found it very challenging. Would recommend taking 112 and / or 131 beforehand. I ultimately did fine, but there were many problem sets that took me several hours longer than they would've had I been able to apply some basic theorems from topology.

course_title: Probability and Random Processes with Economic Applications 001
best_comment: It's an interesting class that has some interesting content, but a lot of it is very similar to some other stat courses (110 and 210 mostly superset the material in the class, aside from the stuff about Black–Scholes). There are some special concepts like hedging that you won't see in the other stat classes, but they're pretty simple and you could probably understand some of them in about ten minutes—probably not worth taking an entire course for. It's also unclear if this class will be run in the future by a different professor, since I think Bamberg is retiring soon (?) so maybe it'll be less scuffed in the future.

Very easy class. Spent too much time on discrete dynamics IMO since it was the instructor’s expertise. Learned interesting things but overall felt like we missed very important things, for example we never learned normal forms, continuous time bifurcations,  limit cycles, and other fundamental concepts. As an R class, it felt more like we were covering random topics related to dynamics and less like a structured introduction to the topic. Although I really appreciated the low workload, the class was a little too easy to learn much from and the textbooks were also very easy, however for a low–workload senior class it worked nicely especially paired with reading Wiggins on my own time.
This course is great! And Gage is an amazing lecturer.
worse_comment: Gage Martin is a very nice person and was lovely to get to know, but I would not recommend this class if she is teaching it. For reference, I have not ever learned any kind of proofs. She used all of the materials from the previous professor(Dr. Chen) and there are things on the syllabus that are not offered like "problem sessions". She posted Dr. Chen's syllabus, but never her own. Even worse, the homeworks reference worksheets sometimes in problems. I had to skip over a problem because you needed the worksheet reference to do it. Gage used these worksheets to structure her classes, but never handed them out to us or even posted them on canvas. I just do not understand why. Having something to look at and follow along with keeps me engaged in the class and it also gives me another thing to go over when studying and doing assignments. When I asked about the worksheets, I was told that she could send me the ones that I asked for instead of offering to just post them. Overall, I do not think that the teaching style was for me. It was very disorganized and all over the place. You don't really have to go to class. I tried to because I was a little lost, but it did not help at all.

course_title: Algebra I: Theory of Groups and Vector Spaces 001
best_comment: An interesting exploration of introductory group theory! The material towards the end (patterns + crystallographic groups) were perhaps the most enlightening parts of the course and I'm keen on pursuing the algebra sequence further. Hopkins is a good professor, a bit disorganized, but very kind. He definitely loves when students come to class and has a lot more grace for the students he knows that show up to class and office hours.

course_title: Algebra II: Theory of Rings and Fields 001
best_comment: Math 123 is a fantastic class, and a great choice to learn more in–depth concepts of algebra. Gammage is unfortunately leaving, but he was amazing — a great lecturer, super enthusiastic, and very helpful (also quite funny). This isn’t the most difficult math course, but it is still very rewarding and you will learn a lot of cool math.
worse_comment: I'm iffy on this class. It has important material that you can't miss, but honestly it doesn't seem like you get your bang for your buck. Course outline is very wishy–washy/inconsistent, and I found it hard to feel like there were underlying themes and an ultimate goal, it seemed all over the place mathematically

best_comment: This was a very solid geometry course. Very intro friendly, and the professor was a good lecturer.
worse_comment: Straightforward class, not very problem–solving focused, mostly follows textbook

best_comment: I can't speak to how this class will be with future professors, but it was really tough. The lectures went super fast and the content is quite difficult. I have no idea how the grading will shake out, but I'm guessing the percentage of straight As will be not that high. However, I learned a lot and that growth was rewarding. It's an interesting topic and definitely expands your brain, especially if you've never seen topology before (and probably even if you have). Was it worth it? Maybe not. Am I grateful for the experience? Yes!
worse_comment: This course is an important one, but I personally found Professor Ballinger's instruction a bit hard to follow and Guillemin and Pollack is not the best textbook. The CAs were wonderful for this course, but you may want to self–study a bit before coming to class. It is not a particularly challenging, but can feel a bit disorganized and hard to follow.

best_comment: This was maybe my favorite course of college so far. The material is absolutely beautiful. The beginning of algebraic geometry is a lovely and fairly cohesive theory, making for a very nice class. Throughout the course, the work feels very motivated and reasonable. If you are looking for a challenging, interesting, abstract course, this is a great option!
worse_comment: The psets will be hard, work together. Also, try to find textbooks online to read.

best_comment: This is a wonderful course, and it is a shame that it is not offered every year. Alejandro is a wonderful lecturer who is only there to help you. The material itself is challenging, but the psets are manageable and the grading is lenient, since Alejandro is most interested in you learning the material, rather than particularly struggling. If you have even the slightest interest in set theory, I highly recommend this course, but even if not, if you are interested in immersing yourself in a fascinating math course, I feel that this is a must take, when offered.
worse_comment: This class was AMAZING under Professor Poveda but he is leaving :( Be warned that it has the potential to be wildly difficult under anybody else, but the content is sincerely extraordinary.

best_comment: Oliver is a true joy. He's an amazing person and a great lecturer (he just knows). However, the lectures in this course cover a lot of content in a short amount of time so it can be overwhelming and hard to follow at times. I think that I could have gotten more out of this course if I studied more outside of class. It goes into much more content than stat 110 but with much less rigor. I considered it as more of a survey of probability and measure theory than an in–depth course. The psets are either easy and unrelated to the core concepts of the lectures or extremely hard and related.

If you want a chill math class this is a pretty good one. You still have psets so it is harder than many humanities but if you know math they are all easy. If you are looking for a serious course obviously you wouldn't be on the page so this class is pretty much what you would expect.
worse_comment: The course is essentially quant interview prep: number theory that's essentially logic puzzles, probability in the style of Stat 110, combinatorics. There was a weirdly large amount of information theory. The concepts don't take a lot of effort to understand, and most of them will be familiar if you're a mathie. Some of the weekly problem sets can take a while... the later ones took me upwards of 12 hours.

best_comment: If you are interested in analysis, you should definitely take this course. It gives a great introduction to some more advanced topics in real analysis, primarily functional analysis, operator theory, and partial differential equations (note: the latter two areas are presumably a result of Prof. Taubes' version of this course). The content is broadly very useful to learn, both if you are primarily interested in analysis, or looking to learn analysis for other subjects in mathematics. The final project was great, especially for giving a more holistic view of the course.
worse_comment: This course was quite bad. In fact the worst math class I have taken at Harvard. The content itself is not sophisticated, but the lectures were very poorly given. They were really confusing, and hard to follow what even the professor was talking about. Many students learned the material from other sources themselves since the lectures were totally useless. In fact, the lectures made me forget the things I already knew. Grading on the problem sets was extremely slow. They really took their time to grade so you did not get frequent feedback on how you are doing. Also, the scoring was extremely inconsistent (across psets and students). Overall, I would NOT take this course unless you are 100% confident in the ability of the lecturer and the CAs. This was not the case for this year, so it was a pretty bad experience.

best_comment: I had a lot of fun in this class. Freed goes really fast, so be prepared for something tough – but he also makes the content SO interesting and is great at communicating it. The final paper was really fun too, very exploration–minded. My regret is that I was really too busy to devote much time to the course. Grade–wise, it's not a problem; he's super chill and basically says at the start of the course that you should do the psets to the extent you can and you don't have to finish them. But if you want to really learn from it, make sure you have a solid number of hours each week to devote to it.

This is a great course when taught by Prof. Senger. His lecture style (+ Miller's notes) makes the logic of the course flow very smoothly, and you can really see how each idea leads to another. At the end I felt I had a very intuitive grasp of most of the material, and even if I did not fully understand something, I felt that I at least intuitively understood what the underlying principles were. Great class!
worse_comment: I'm not sure how hard it will be when Andy's not teaching it, but just make sure to spend time to just sit down and think about the ideas.

best_comment: I think you should take this class if you are interested in game theory and have a project idea in mind. Martin is the goat of this field and is a great lecturer so it is very enjoyable. I think the lectures themselves are kind of scattered and often unrelated to specifics. Its really a project course kind of like a sandbox to try some research/project.
worse_comment: Future students should be aware that this course is extremely unstructured, with minimal guidance, few assignments, and very limited instructor involvement. There are no weekly problem sets, and lectures often end early. Grades are based largely on a final project and class participation, with very little substantive feedback provided. If you are looking for a rigorous, supportive environment to deeply learn evolutionary dynamics, you may find this course disappointing. If you are looking for a low–intensity course requiring minimal ongoing work, it may meet your expectations.

best_comment: Looks like this is the only time the course will ever be offered, so it's not like my feedback is super helpful here. However, highly recommend watching out for Prof. Borodin's course at MIT to see if you're interested. He's a fantastic lecturer.

Houcine Ben Dali is one of the most considerate and thoughtful professors I have had at Harvard. As well as knowing the material inside–out, he lectures with genuine enthusiasm and will offer countless opportunities to take questions. Any questions asked are followed by a response tailored to the pace of those who the questions applied to. As a result, few queries were left unanswered as each lecture ended. Also, if you are a fan of good board work, he is pretty good at that too! Most importantly, Houcine is a great person. Not once did he say no to a request for additional office hours. There is a genuine drive from Prof. Ben Dali for all students to understand the material and have fun while doing so. The class itself was definitely more challenging than previous courses I have been involved in, but I never once felt unsupported or as if the class was impossible. Houcine played a great role in that. I cannot recommend Prof. Ben Dali more highly. I have taken away so much from this course and it is all thanks to him.

It is super helpful to have an excellent grasp on scientific literature prior to beginning this course. There are a lot of assigned readings and they can get lengthy and complex, so having a general understanding of the layout and rhythm of scientific papers beforehand will allow for more efficient learning. Also, pay attention to what the professor highlights about each reading in the weekly email. The themes he emphasizes often appear on the quizzes, worth a large portion of your final grade. That being said, as long as you read each reading in full and understand their implications, you will do well on the quizzes. There are no tricks.

I would highly recommend this course for anyone interested in metabolism. This course provides an excellent overview of human metabolism and dives deep into special topics in metabolism. It is highly interactive and features many guest lecturers.
worse_comment: I would tell them to start the final project earlier than they think they need and also that if they aren't interested in a high level overview of metabolism with deep dives into the mechanistic aspects of it then they probably shouldn't be enrolled.

course_title: Principles of Drug Action in People 001
best_comment: Take this class!!! The first few weeks are a bit rough because you're focused on the fundamentals of small molecules (Kd, experimental assays, etc), but the class really builds into an amazing survey of key high need areas in drug discovery. The speakers are super cool, and most are willing to chat with you after class or go for a coffee. I wish I had taken this class earlier!
worse_comment: This class has the potential to be very good and some lectures are very interesting and well delivered. However, most lecturers are not effective and the course itself is very poorly run. At the time of writing this, only 1 of 3 problem sets have been graded. We also received only 5 days warning to prepare a final (group) presentation during the last week of class. I would not recommend taking this class unless you have to.

course_title: Biophysical and Biochemical Mechanisms of Protein Function 001
best_comment: I would say that if you are interested in performing biophysical studies in the future this course acts a good primer to introduce you to concepts and topics in that field.

course_title: Biophysical and Biochemical Mechanisms of Protein Function 001
best_comment: I would say that if you are interested in performing biophysical studies in the future this course acts a good primer to introduce you to concepts and topics in that field.

This class offers a low–stress environment to learn about the fundamental unit of biology. Without too much time spent outside of class, I felt that I learned a good deal. The class–make–up has a lot of different expertise across DMS, and brought out interesting questions. The faculty were very helpful and accommodating, offering specific "expert hours" to help with the experimental analysis pieces of the problem sets.

course_title: Biology of the Cancer Cell: From Molecular Mechanisms to Therapeutic Implications 0001
best_comment: It's a great class! If you have a strong background in cancer or cell biology, you'll be able to engage more actively during lectures. If not, you may need to put in some extra effort to keep up, but the material is very interesting and worthwhile. The primary project is a grant proposal, and you'll get the most out of the class if you can base it on your own research. It's a valuable opportunity to advance your scientific writing skills in a meaningful and practical way.

If not, you may need to put in some extra effort to keep up, but the material is very interesting and worthwhile. The primary project is a grant proposal, and you'll get the most out of the class if you can base it on your own research. It's a valuable opportunity to advance your scientific writing skills in a meaningful and practical way.

This course is really amazing – the professors are very passionate about subjects taught and encourage alot of great discussion during the class. If you aim to join a genetics lab, this course will definitely be very useful for you. Additionally, students are required to present one paper at the end of the course, after which professors provide very detailed and constructive feedback. That being said, students do have to put in quite a bit of effort to read the papers every week to truly engage in the discussions.

course_title: Genetics in Medicine - From Bench to Bedside 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. This class is truly one–of–a–kind and will expand your knowledge of genetic diseases a great deal. You will learn about all of the great experimental strategies that clinical researchers are deploying to address conditions like Huntington's Disease, X–linked adenoleukodystrophy, and Alzheimer's. As an undergraduate, getting to attend a class at MGH and hear from clinicians and scientists was a great treat. I would strongly encourage undergrads who did well in LS1B (and enjoyed it!) to take this class.
worse_comment: For any individuals who want to pursue a role within the broader medical field, but have never had the opportunity to work in a clinical setting, this class provides an incredible opportunity to understand a variety of genetic diseases through the patient's lens.

best_comment: This class is great for "big idea" scientists, who want to know how disease impacts the body and what that looks like. It provides a great launching pad to new questions. I was able to get something out of every class, even those of topics I wouldn't originally think I'd be interested in.  The course directors really care for the course and our learning, and it has been one of my favorite classes so far.
worse_comment: Excellent course on pathology! Hands–on labs expose you to interpreting gross specimens and stained slides. A different guest lecturer speaks every course. Minimal workload with three problem sets and a short final presentation on a topic of your choice. The course largely follows case studies from the perspective of a pathologist trying to diagnose a patient and provide a treatment plan.

best_comment: I would recommend this class if you are interested in delving into the clinical side of immunological research.
worse_comment: The course is very cancer immunology heavy

best_comment: This class doesn't have too many assignments from week to week with just a paper discussion every week. I think this is a class that you get what you put in. If you engage with the readings and lecturers, you'll be able to come away with a lot of cool insights into the immunology research done in the Harvard community. There is just one major assignment which is a grant–style specific aims page due at the end of the semester. This can feel a bit unapproachable if you don't have any experience with writing grants. I would start early so you can start brainstorming ideas and reading papers. You'll need to do a lot more reading than you think to land on a topic – if you found a lecture particularly interesting that is a good place to start. Do not hesitate to reach out to the course director if you need more direction.

course_title: Neuroimmune interactions in health and disease 001
best_comment: This is a fantastic course! Each class session starts with a lecture by a different guest speaker professor and then concludes with a paper presentation/discussion. The lectures by the guest speakers are all really interesting and each cover a different area of neuroimmune interactions in health and disease, together providing a varied and broad look into this area. The paper presentations are also interesting for reading in detail about particular examples of studies in the areas described in the lectures. Overall this course was very interesting and informative. Definitely a great course to take if you are interested in neuroimmune interactions in health and disease!
worse_comment: This class is an interesting overview for a few key takeaway points, but it is more of a seminar series than a rigorous course with expected high understanding of foundational concepts.

course_title: Microbial Sciences: Chemistry, Ecology and Evolution 001
best_comment: This course is not very easy to come to for most undergrads, except for those few who have taken OEB or microbiology classes before. There's a lot of new information to absorb each week, as the course is structured to have a different guest lecturer with a different expertise each week.  Also, you are expected to participate at least 2x a class (they count by ticking your name off next to your photo in the course roster), which is very hard to do if you are just learning things for the first time in the class. Weekly, you are expected to read two (usually dense/difficult) papers, and answer participation questions on them. One time during the semester, you are to present a paper to the class, a journal club of sorts. The semester paper is a research proposal focused in microbiology, but you have plenty of time to work on that and get plenty of feedback. Overall, I would recommend this course but would definitely suggest being mindful of how confident or willing you feel in wanting to learn so much on your own each week!

worse_comment: It’s gonna be hard and long, but it will payoff

best_comment: This class is super awesome! It is so interesting if you are genuinely interested in the topic of the course. The guest lectures are super fun and the courseload is definitely manageable!
worse_comment: The final grade all falls on the final project! I haven't written a scientific paper before so I'm not sure how it will be graded.

best_comment: This is a great course for those who want to ask questions about neural cell types and identities in their own work, or who are generally curious about how different cell types develop and are defined.

course_title: Poverty, Wealth, and Religion in the Middle Ages 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!! COULD NOT RECOMMEND MORE!!1) Prof. FitzGerald is so kind, and his knowledge on the subject is so incredibly deep. Each class we would pepper him with random questions on the middle ages, and he always had an informed answer 2) the material is super interesting, I KNOW IT SEEMS NICHE, but I feel like I have a totally new understanding of not only the Catholic church but religious history in general and how it interacted with the economy. You could almost call this course "The Economy and Religion in the Middle Ages" because you learn so much about how money and religion were intertwined. 3) It expanded by world view in a huge way...I am not religious at all, but many of my classmates were, and I think I grew a lot as a person and students listening and engaging with students who have very different approaches to the world than I do 4) You should expect to do 85%+ of the reading, but if you're someone who enjoys seminar courses, this is a great class for you. The entire time is spent debating topics related to the readings, and I think Prof. FitzGerald does an amazing job facilitating interesting discussion5) Prof. FitzGerald is SUPER supportive and engaging and interested, and I feel very lucky to have gotten to take a course with himTLDR: take this course, i know it seems random, but it is so interesting and I promise you will not regret it

course_title: Constitutional and Legal History of Medieval Continental Europe 001
best_comment: Professor Donahue has a truly unique expertise –– there really might not be anyone else alive who knows as much he does about this topic area (or at least it feels that way in class). Beyond that, he is also a very careful and talented historian, and he does a good job of breaking down his thinking process for the class, rather than just present his conclusions; I learned a lot from observing the way that he reached historical conclusions and from his critiques of historical theories that he thinks are incorrect or lack sufficient proof.  He also is very attentive to student interests: he builds every lecture around students' questions and devotes a truly unusual amount of time and care to giving feedback on papers. It's a manageable amount of work.That said, this class is not for everyone. Not everyone finds the minutiae of medieval legal rules interesting, and this class might be rather dry for such people, even if the big picture conclusions are interesting. The materials and recorded homework lectures are online (https://amesfoundation.law.harvard.edu/CLH/clhfas/lectures/index_lec_CLH.html); I'd recommend perusing them (especially the recorded lectures) to get a feel for the class before deciding if it's for you.

course_title: At Cross Purposes: The Crusades in Material Culture 001
best_comment: This is an incredible course *** very very strongly recommend! Professor Georganteli is such an amazing and lovely mentor and professor. She is so kind and knowledgeable and an important scholar in her field. This is both a fun and exciting and a very intellectually interesting course! The workload is super manageable and the trip to DC makes a huge difference in regards to our grasp on the content. Great senior spring course!
Pick your individual thesis advisor carefully, because there was no support from the CMES professors who oversaw this course.
worse_comment: The Middle East department does not welcome diverse points of view and the faculty do not care enough about their jobs to even read our work (which was the only requirement of this course from them).

course_title: Neuroscience of Music: Clinical Applications across the Lifespan 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!! First and foremost, Dr. Maria Pranjic is just the most wonderful teacher: she is so incredibly versed in neuroscience of course, but as a musician herself she brings a unique and holistic perspective to this course (which has made it such an incredible experience).  She is kind and cultivates community, as well as making sure class runs efficiently and seriously – I have gone from essentially a neuroscience beginner to generating multiple projects and a final paper within one semester because of her investment in my learning. Secondly, this topic is so very important, and Harvard having this discipline (music/arts/creativity and the brain) as a course in the MBB department is absolutely essential. Come prepared to work hard and you will reap the benefits of this amazing course! I sincerely hope the MBB department will continue adding and supporting more courses like this one (for everyone's sake, but selfishly so I can take them too!) :)

This was one of the most interesting courses I’ve taken at Harvard! Dr. Milberg is a true expert in neuroscience, and his personal experience with some of the patients discussed in class makes the lectures especially engaging. The second half of the course (where students present on landmark cases) is particularly fascinating. You gain a much deeper understanding of patients you may have only briefly encountered in introductory psychology courses.That said, the first portion of the course could benefit from a bit more structure and clarity. I understand it’s challenging to condense an entire neuroscience curriculum into just a few weeks, but it might help to focus primarily on the most essential concepts (such as brain areas and their functions) that are necessary for understanding the cases. Providing more visual materials (maybe through slides or supplemental readings) would also be helpful, especially since students come into this course with varying levels of background. Lastly, a short 5–10 minute break during the two–hour lectures would go a long way since maintaining focus through dense material can be quite tough.Overall, it’s an excellent, low–workload class led by a fantastic professor!
best_gem_comment: Take this class for sure if you’re thinking about doing a MBB secondary (or concentration). It’s definitely a gem. Professor Milberg is great, full of knowledge, and super chill. Loved it!

course_title: Functional Neuroimaging of Psychiatric Disorders: Insights into the Human Brain-Mind 001
best_comment: Amazing class with great discussions! You will learn about what neuropsychiatry itself is, and the current advances in the field as well as the history of how this field emerged. Be prepared to share your thoughts on the readings.
Take this class. Dr. Ed is awesome and the kindest professor. The topics are super fascinating and the class is very chill workload. You will learn a lot and do very well.

course_title: Translational Neuroscience: Limits of Adaptation from Extreme Environments to Clinical Practice 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE! It is incredible if you love space, space medicine, and/or astronomy. Also, if you like emergency medicine or any thing else extreme, this course will cover it!

course_title: Translational Neuroscience: Limits of Adaptation from Extreme Environments to Clinical Practice 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE! It is incredible if you love space, space medicine, and/or astronomy. Also, if you like emergency medicine or any thing else extreme, this course will cover it!

course_title: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Genetics, Genomics, and Evolution 001
best_comment: Ls1b is pretty solid! It is a bit of a travesty that Andrew Berry will no longer be teaching the course, as he kind of made it what it was. But honestly, I personally thought the class was deeply interesting, and a lot less rigorous than Ls1a, but I am also not a pre–med like I am sure a large portion of the readers of this Q–report are, so I may not be the right person to ask. You absolutely do not need to have taken Ls1a to do well in this class –– LPSA (or neither!!!) is totally fine, as not much background is really needed for the course. But a background in Ls1a definitely does help for the first 6 or so lectures. I found the class to be nowhere as conceptually challenging as Ls1a, but still deeply interesting. Most importantly, to me at least –– if you are not good at focusing on the lectures, it is sorta fine, because they kinda are hard to listen to and focus in on for the whole time. And it is really fine overall ––– Section has incredible reviews of the learned content, there are like a million office hours, and they always post the lecture slides and deeply, deeply useful lecture notes THAT I STRONGLY RECOMMEND YOU USE TO STUDY FOR PIES!!! The pies also were honestly not too bad, and I think it was super helpful to have those smaller tests that helped you review and ultimately made sure you aren't totally cooked for the final. Overall, take Ls1b! I think its pretty solid and is super interesting if you are into genetics, ecology, and/or evolution.
worse_comment: This is nothing like LS1a. SO expect a lot of new things that disguise as familiar things like the PIES. You have to be very very quick with the time, there is not enough time on the exam, infact a lot of people did not finish the final as well. A lot of information dump is done in every lecture ––– the most helpful resource is reading the lecture notes! They are insanely helpful and saved me. ANother resource I recommend for studying that helps for PIEs is the Lowdown videos as well as Practice Problems. The main problem with the course is that the exams are nothing like the psets, I was great with the psets but on the exams, I struggled! The only way to get a sense of what type of questions the pies would have is practice problems. Make sure you don't fall behind on information, try to pay attention! Labs are a little unhelpful cause they dont have a lot of problems on section worksheet. ALSO, if you ahve heard ls1b has insane cutoffs for an A like 96, i assure you, it does not. tl;dr : Start for PIEs early like actually early. Keep working, keep on track, read the lecture notes and do the practice problems, go quickly through the pie and the exam, expect exams to much longer than the practice ones.

Most importantly, to me at least –– if you are not good at focusing on the lectures, it is sorta fine, because they kinda are hard to listen to and focus in on for the whole time. And it is really fine overall ––– Section has incredible reviews of the learned content, there are like a million office hours, and they always post the lecture slides and deeply, deeply useful lecture notes THAT I STRONGLY RECOMMEND YOU USE TO STUDY FOR PIES!!! The pies also were honestly not too bad, and I think it was super helpful to have those smaller tests that helped you review and ultimately made sure you aren't totally cooked for the final. Overall, take Ls1b! I think its pretty solid and is super interesting if you are into genetics, ecology, and/or evolution.
worse_comment: This is nothing like LS1a. SO expect a lot of new things that disguise as familiar things like the PIES. You have to be very very quick with the time, there is not enough time on the exam, infact a lot of people did not finish the final as well. A lot of information dump is done in every lecture ––– the most helpful resource is reading the lecture notes! They are insanely helpful and saved me. ANother resource I recommend for studying that helps for PIEs is the Lowdown videos as well as Practice Problems. The main problem with the course is that the exams are nothing like the psets, I was great with the psets but on the exams, I struggled! The only way to get a sense of what type of questions the pies would have is practice problems. Make sure you don't fall behind on information, try to pay attention! Labs are a little unhelpful cause they dont have a lot of problems on section worksheet. ALSO, if you ahve heard ls1b has insane cutoffs for an A like 96, i assure you, it does not. tl;dr : Start for PIEs early like actually early. Keep working, keep on track, read the lecture notes and do the practice problems, go quickly through the pie and the exam, expect exams to much longer than the practice ones.

best_comment: (apologies for length) Congrats on finishing LS50a, or hello if you're a prefrosh! If you're deliberately reading this Q, you either are contemplating this course sequence or staying in LS50b/dropping to LS1b. I hope the following information is helpful in guiding your decision, and once you make it, do not look back because the "grass is always greener on the other side."tldr: I was considering the switch to LS1b. I am glad I stayed in this course because of the community (I met some of my closest friends) and niche expertise of the professors (they are truly cool people and robust researchers). With that said, if you have a gut feeling that you should switch to LS1b, do it; we had one person switch due to different STEM interests and she was happy with her decision at the end of the semester. If LS50 had a toxic or competitive student environment, I would’ve undoubtedly done LS1b with Math 21a this semester.First, I will go into some of the positives about LS50. I believe this course has an amazing community that cannot be seen in many other classes except maybe Math 55. It’s a mix of trauma bonding at 3 am, learning about each other while psetting, going for late night Felipe’s/El Jefe’s runs together, etc. As people start to form smaller subgroups this semester, I’ve met incredible friends who I hope to stay close with for the rest of my life. You can also learn lots from your peers, as many LS50ers are RSI, Regeneron STS, SSP, and ISEF alums. The course assistants (CAs) and teaching fellows (TFs) are also remarkable; they genuinely care about you and your success, which is important for a class like Life Sciences 50.Academically, the professors are all very supportive and interesting people who have done cutting–edge research. LS50 will expose you to a diversity of scientific disciplines, which can help you decide on a future concentration. While a lot of ppl think they have a good idea coming in, by the end, many of my peers’ academic trajectories changed. Some switched from Neuro to Chem/Physical Bio; some dropped premed; some leaned more into HDRB. For the lab component, take advantage of this opportunity! Kevin was a joy to work with and compared to other courses, you spent most time actually *doing science* rather than spending hours on pre–labs and busy work. Note on the professors: Andrew is hilarious and is truly an inspiring scientist on yeast genetics. Emma is like an LS50 mom and was a gem to have. Cara is very clear and an amazing person to talk to about comp bio interests. Ben, while sometimes overloading lectures, is a cool person and great to know. Michael is also hilarious, and while his expectations are sometimes too high, he can explain things remarkably well.On the flip side, there are some IMPORTANT things to keep in mind. While it gets better after the first midterm, there’s still a very strong mathematical emphasis in the course. Overall, I liked the content of LS50b more but it’s a lie to say that it’s traditional bio/chem in the second half of the semester. I included a few notes below:– You WILL learn linear algebra in two weeks, but some of the hardcore material is honestly too much if you don’t have a *strong* mathematical foundation. It sometimes took a toll on both the physical and mental health of people I was close with in the class, including myself. No pset should cause people to pull multiple all–nighters or feel any negative thoughts; however, the tight–knit community allowed us to support each other during rough patches. This may be controversial among course staff but after talking with peers, lots of stat mech and dynamical systems could be replaced with more niche bio topics that set us up better for orgo (like Chem 20 – which you shouldn’t take with LS50b!), SCRB 10, etc.  Yes, we’re at Harvard; yes, this course is voluntary; yes, we’re supposed to be “the brightest future for science”; nonetheless, we are 18/19–year–olds figuring out our identities and the course expectations were too intense at times.– The rumor that every individual who takes this course gets an A and will get into PRISE/research village program is false. Out of the ~40 students, 15–17 will get an A; 15–17 will get an A–; and about 7–9 will end with a B+. I would assume it’s possible to get lower if you slack off significantly or cheat on exams. While participation in class is important (DON’T BE SCARED TO ASK QUESTIONS DURING LECTURE IF YOU TAKE LS50), your grade is basically dependent on the 3 midterms. You should get above the median on 2 out of 3 if you want an A, which is not always doable without serious dedication or being an inherently gifted mathematician/budding biologist with an innate understanding of chemistry. Practice problems are critical versus passive studying, though the quantity of practice problems were sometimes lacking.– I don’t necessarily regret taking LS50 and I know the course staff gets frustrated when students only think about grades, but it’s possible to be intellectually curious AND care about grades. LS50 may have prevented certain fellowships later on in college (lots of students get As broadly due to easier intro courses/grade inflation), and it’s unlikely that one can make the Phi Beta Kappa GPA cutoff with A–s or B+s (it counts for 2 classes each semester), even with straight As for subsequent semesters. There is no shame in taking LS1b. Since LS50 is mostly quantitative, it’s hard to say that I am less prepared for graduate school in biology/chemistry or even medicine in the future just because I struggled with topics like stat mech and Markov chains.– Students from amazing STEM magnet, international, or private schools have a clear advantage and it at times disadvantages those from under–funded or STEM–lacking high schools. I feel like there is a general correlation between getting an A in LS50 and doing Olympiads in HS, attending magnet schools that teach linalg/orgo, not being first–gen, etc. Though I want to avoid making generalizations, and if you devote sufficient time, anyone can succeed!– Some weeks feel quite disjointed and comparable to academic whiplash with topics alternating on different days. I don’t think it’s an issue per se, but it sometimes makes reviewing material challenging. I think this was expected going into the course. Also, I wish the course staff did more direct Python instruction or a spring workshop, since many of the PSET Colabs would take hours on end.Take everything with a grain of salt. By the end, if you accept the challenge, you will truly embrace the class motto “By all means necessary.” Otherwise, please be sure to enjoy your freshman year at Harvard—it’s a pretty special time!
worse_comment: Unless you hated LS50a (or realized that LS50 doesn't make sense given your expected concentration), you should continue to LS50b. In my year, only one person dropped—and it was because she was a prospective BME concentrator who was only taking LS50 for the life sciences credit.
