While a lot of ppl think they have a good idea coming in, by the end, many of my peers’ academic trajectories changed. Some switched from Neuro to Chem/Physical Bio; some dropped premed; some leaned more into HDRB. For the lab component, take advantage of this opportunity! Kevin was a joy to work with and compared to other courses, you spent most time actually *doing science* rather than spending hours on pre–labs and busy work. Note on the professors: Andrew is hilarious and is truly an inspiring scientist on yeast genetics. Emma is like an LS50 mom and was a gem to have. Cara is very clear and an amazing person to talk to about comp bio interests. Ben, while sometimes overloading lectures, is a cool person and great to know. Michael is also hilarious, and while his expectations are sometimes too high, he can explain things remarkably well.On the flip side, there are some IMPORTANT things to keep in mind. While it gets better after the first midterm, there’s still a very strong mathematical emphasis in the course. Overall, I liked the content of LS50b more but it’s a lie to say that it’s traditional bio/chem in the second half of the semester. I included a few notes below:– You WILL learn linear algebra in two weeks, but some of the hardcore material is honestly too much if you don’t have a *strong* mathematical foundation. It sometimes took a toll on both the physical and mental health of people I was close with in the class, including myself. No pset should cause people to pull multiple all–nighters or feel any negative thoughts; however, the tight–knit community allowed us to support each other during rough patches. This may be controversial among course staff but after talking with peers, lots of stat mech and dynamical systems could be replaced with more niche bio topics that set us up better for orgo (like Chem 20 – which you shouldn’t take with LS50b!), SCRB 10, etc.  Yes, we’re at Harvard; yes, this course is voluntary; yes, we’re supposed to be “the brightest future for science”; nonetheless, we are 18/19–year–olds figuring out our identities and the course expectations were too intense at times.– The rumor that every individual who takes this course gets an A and will get into PRISE/research village program is false. Out of the ~40 students, 15–17 will get an A; 15–17 will get an A–; and about 7–9 will end with a B+. I would assume it’s possible to get lower if you slack off significantly or cheat on exams. While participation in class is important (DON’T BE SCARED TO ASK QUESTIONS DURING LECTURE IF YOU TAKE LS50), your grade is basically dependent on the 3 midterms. You should get above the median on 2 out of 3 if you want an A, which is not always doable without serious dedication or being an inherently gifted mathematician/budding biologist with an innate understanding of chemistry. Practice problems are critical versus passive studying, though the quantity of practice problems were sometimes lacking.– I don’t necessarily regret taking LS50 and I know the course staff gets frustrated when students only think about grades, but it’s possible to be intellectually curious AND care about grades. LS50 may have prevented certain fellowships later on in college (lots of students get As broadly due to easier intro courses/grade inflation), and it’s unlikely that one can make the Phi Beta Kappa GPA cutoff with A–s or B+s (it counts for 2 classes each semester), even with straight As for subsequent semesters. There is no shame in taking LS1b. Since LS50 is mostly quantitative, it’s hard to say that I am less prepared for graduate school in biology/chemistry or even medicine in the future just because I struggled with topics like stat mech and Markov chains.– Students from amazing STEM magnet, international, or private schools have a clear advantage and it at times disadvantages those from under–funded or STEM–lacking high schools. I feel like there is a general correlation between getting an A in LS50 and doing Olympiads in HS, attending magnet schools that teach linalg/orgo, not being first–gen, etc. Though I want to avoid making generalizations, and if you devote sufficient time, anyone can succeed!– Some weeks feel quite disjointed and comparable to academic whiplash with topics alternating on different days. I don’t think it’s an issue per se, but it sometimes makes reviewing material challenging. I think this was expected going into the course. Also, I wish the course staff did more direct Python instruction or a spring workshop, since many of the PSET Colabs would take hours on end.Take everything with a grain of salt. By the end, if you accept the challenge, you will truly embrace the class motto “By all means necessary.” Otherwise, please be sure to enjoy your freshman year at Harvard—it’s a pretty special time!
worse_comment: Unless you hated LS50a (or realized that LS50 doesn't make sense given your expected concentration), you should continue to LS50b. In my year, only one person dropped—and it was because she was a prospective BME concentrator who was only taking LS50 for the life sciences credit.

LS50 will expose you to a diversity of scientific disciplines, which can help you decide on a future concentration. While a lot of ppl think they have a good idea coming in, by the end, many of my peers’ academic trajectories changed. Some switched from Neuro to Chem/Physical Bio; some dropped premed; some leaned more into HDRB. For the lab component, take advantage of this opportunity! Kevin was a joy to work with and compared to other courses, you spent most time actually *doing science* rather than spending hours on pre–labs and busy work. Note on the professors: Andrew is hilarious and is truly an inspiring scientist on yeast genetics. Emma is like an LS50 mom and was a gem to have. Cara is very clear and an amazing person to talk to about comp bio interests. Ben, while sometimes overloading lectures, is a cool person and great to know. Michael is also hilarious, and while his expectations are sometimes too high, he can explain things remarkably well.On the flip side, there are some IMPORTANT things to keep in mind. While it gets better after the first midterm, there’s still a very strong mathematical emphasis in the course. Overall, I liked the content of LS50b more but it’s a lie to say that it’s traditional bio/chem in the second half of the semester. I included a few notes below:– You WILL learn linear algebra in two weeks, but some of the hardcore material is honestly too much if you don’t have a *strong* mathematical foundation. It sometimes took a toll on both the physical and mental health of people I was close with in the class, including myself. No pset should cause people to pull multiple all–nighters or feel any negative thoughts; however, the tight–knit community allowed us to support each other during rough patches. This may be controversial among course staff but after talking with peers, lots of stat mech and dynamical systems could be replaced with more niche bio topics that set us up better for orgo (like Chem 20 – which you shouldn’t take with LS50b!), SCRB 10, etc.  Yes, we’re at Harvard; yes, this course is voluntary; yes, we’re supposed to be “the brightest future for science”; nonetheless, we are 18/19–year–olds figuring out our identities and the course expectations were too intense at times.– The rumor that every individual who takes this course gets an A and will get into PRISE/research village program is false. Out of the ~40 students, 15–17 will get an A; 15–17 will get an A–; and about 7–9 will end with a B+. I would assume it’s possible to get lower if you slack off significantly or cheat on exams. While participation in class is important (DON’T BE SCARED TO ASK QUESTIONS DURING LECTURE IF YOU TAKE LS50), your grade is basically dependent on the 3 midterms. You should get above the median on 2 out of 3 if you want an A, which is not always doable without serious dedication or being an inherently gifted mathematician/budding biologist with an innate understanding of chemistry. Practice problems are critical versus passive studying, though the quantity of practice problems were sometimes lacking.– I don’t necessarily regret taking LS50 and I know the course staff gets frustrated when students only think about grades, but it’s possible to be intellectually curious AND care about grades. LS50 may have prevented certain fellowships later on in college (lots of students get As broadly due to easier intro courses/grade inflation), and it’s unlikely that one can make the Phi Beta Kappa GPA cutoff with A–s or B+s (it counts for 2 classes each semester), even with straight As for subsequent semesters. There is no shame in taking LS1b. Since LS50 is mostly quantitative, it’s hard to say that I am less prepared for graduate school in biology/chemistry or even medicine in the future just because I struggled with topics like stat mech and Markov chains.– Students from amazing STEM magnet, international, or private schools have a clear advantage and it at times disadvantages those from under–funded or STEM–lacking high schools. I feel like there is a general correlation between getting an A in LS50 and doing Olympiads in HS, attending magnet schools that teach linalg/orgo, not being first–gen, etc. Though I want to avoid making generalizations, and if you devote sufficient time, anyone can succeed!– Some weeks feel quite disjointed and comparable to academic whiplash with topics alternating on different days. I don’t think it’s an issue per se, but it sometimes makes reviewing material challenging. I think this was expected going into the course. Also, I wish the course staff did more direct Python instruction or a spring workshop, since many of the PSET Colabs would take hours on end.Take everything with a grain of salt. By the end, if you accept the challenge, you will truly embrace the class motto “By all means necessary.” Otherwise, please be sure to enjoy your freshman year at Harvard—it’s a pretty special time!

course_title: Experimental Research in the Life Sciences 001
best_comment: This class is amazing and fulfills research requirements for MCB, etc. It is structured as once a week whole group meetings, with the rest of the class operating through planning  within the research groups. You get to work around your group's own availability and delegate your work (and how much time you need to spend in the lab to complete your experiments) on your own and it's great. Please do not take this course if you are going to not participate in your group, because your grade really is just dependent on showing up, learning, and a final grant proposal paper. You will not get an A if you cannot even do that and show up, plus it drags your team down! Overall, very light load, and very great introduction to research. My TF was lovely and is a very accomplished researcher, and Alain is also a sweetheart and very passionate about his students. the projects were very interesting and I learned so much about lab work, given I had zero lab exposure prior. Must take!!

Background: I took this class as a sophomore who took the LS1 series, MCB 60, and CHEM 17 before this and CHEM 27 concurrently. This class was so fun, but it was pretty hard for me without the LS50 primer in stat mech. I feel like my brain is bigger now than it was at the beginning of the semester. MCB 65 was the class that finally got me to learn the amino acids, structural biology lab techniques, and how to be kind of good at using PyMOL. It did take a lot of work to keep up with everything, but the grading isn't insane if that helps, and they're nice about giving out opportunities for bonus points. LPS assignments (PSETs) are due every ~2 weeks and they're pretty big. I'd recommend getting started with each question as soon as you learn the relevant material so you aren't staying up until 4 the night before they're due. The two midterms and final are tough, but they give you a cheat sheet and a bunch of review material to work with, and I felt like I got the hang of it by the end of the semester. There aren't really free points (even attendance is marked for correctness) but as long as you're willing to commit I think the experience is worth it. The community also rocks. It's a small enough and hard enough class that you kind of have to make friends with everyone else. The lecturers are also so cool. Monique is honestly just incredible I love her so much. Max is good when he's lecturing about things he cares about. The TFs were also super solid, very knowledgable about the material and happy to help. Guest lecturers were hit or miss, but some of the opportunities (tour of a crystallography lab, computational protein design) were super super cool. This is my favorite MCB class I've taken so far. It took full commitment at some points (RIP my CHEM 27 grade) but if I could go back in time I would take it again.
worse_comment: I found the course really difficult. Lab every week is a killer. Thankfully we had the GOAT TF George. Other than that .............. study a lot because there's a lot of material. The LPS assignments are killer and take a long time to complete, 6+ hours at least unless you work with others. They are also pretty strict about following the rules so read the instructions of every assignment carefully

best_comment: **If you're interested in cancer bio, this is a perfect intro class, with wonderful and very understanding faculty. The PSETs are very manageable if you are paying attention in class and going to section and they have plenty of office hours to help you do them. Also just getting a PSET buddy helps a lot. They really focus on you learning the content so there are workshops each class to go through some problems in kinda breakout rooms, which honestly does let you ask some questions that you're afraid of asking during lecture. Section is super chill and the part of the class that will most take up your time is reading papers, which are not easy, but the staff goes over them in class and section to make sure you're understanding them and extracting the main points so that's great. Not having a final is wonderful and the exams are very fair, not easy but fair. You do need to study for them to remember everything during lecture or about a specific gain of function or loss of function mutation. Overall, super recommend this class for those interested in cancer bio and HIGHLY recommend it for those who need intro MCB credits.
worse_comment: TLDR: If you're looking for a course to deeply explore cancer biology, especially from a molecular and mechanistic standpoint, this class may not meet your expectations. The material remains fairly general, and the lectures can be difficult to follow. However, if you're seeking a lighter intermediate–level biology course that’s less demanding in terms of content depth, this class might be a suitable option. Just be aware that the structure and clarity of the course may not be as strong as in other MCB classes.The course was unstructured and lacked rigor, particularly when it comes to teaching the molecular mechanisms underlying cancer biology. Currently, the content tends to remain at a very surface level—for example, pathways are often described in vague terms like “promotes growth” without deeper explanation of the molecular players involved or how these pathways are regulated. I found it difficult to follow the material during class, often leaving lectures more confused than informed. One recurring issue was a lack of preparation; lectures frequently felt like loosely organized commentary on the slides rather than a guided explanation of complex processes. While Professor Kunes is clearly a kind and well–meaning instructor, he did not seem fully confident in presenting up–to–date cancer biology content, and sometimes responded to student questions with “I don’t know” or misunderstood the question entirely. This undermined the learning experience.The Wednesday workshop sessions also felt less effective than intended. Although the goal of incorporating active learning is appreciated, the execution could be improved. Many discussions were repetitive and often lacked clear direction, and the practice of having each group present the same concepts led to redundancy rather than reinforcement. A more focused, instructor–led review or structured literature discussion might be more valuable in that time.Finally, several students experienced unnecessary stress due to grading inconsistencies or errors.

best_comment: To future students taking FAS–MCB 68, be prepared for a challenging but rewarding experience. The course provides a great balance of theory and hands–on learning, especially through the lab sessions where you’ll work with advanced microscopy tools like confocal and fluorescence microscopes. These tools are key to understanding cell biology at a deeper level, so make the most of your time in the lab. Stay engaged with the material, ask questions when you’re unsure, and take advantage of office hours and peer discussions. The course is fast–paced, but it’s also a fantastic opportunity to develop skills that are essential for future research. Don’t be afraid to troubleshoot and experiment—it’s all part of the learning process!

best_comment: Great class if you can find a lab that you enjoy (does not need to be strictly MCB – mine wasn't)!

course_title: Creativity, Innovation, and Entrepreneurship in the Life Sciences 001
best_comment: *******Alain is an incredibly lovely person and the speakers he brought in every week were truly very helpful and insightful about venturing into biotech and all the different ways in doing so. I highly highly recommend  this class if you are interested in biotech and want dedicated time to listen to speakers, create a project, and have the support of a very lovely professor in doing so and understanding if this is for you.

a good systems–level neuro class for concentrators who don't really like overly molecular/cellular neuroscience. first half of the course is a little dry, but learning about the different animal models later on was pretty interesting. florian is a great lecturer! assignments are mainly the matlab assignments and quiz readings. matlab is very doable for beginners with step–by–step instructions and lots of resources available for help (office hours, matlab guides). quiz readings requires significant prep with really understanding the papers. although this was definitely annoying in terms of how much time i had to spend on reading the papers, i will admit this definitely improved my skills at understanding dense scientific literature efficiently and effectively. if you like learning about systems neuro and reading scientific literature/want to get better at reading the literature, this course could be a good fit!
worse_comment: The reading assessments and final exam can be difficult so prepare for them.

best_comment: a good systems–level neuro class for concentrators who don't really like overly molecular/cellular neuroscience. first half of the course is a little dry, but learning about the different animal models later on was pretty interesting. florian is a great lecturer! assignments are mainly the matlab assignments and quiz readings. matlab is very doable for beginners with step–by–step instructions and lots of resources available for help (office hours, matlab guides). quiz readings requires significant prep with really understanding the papers. although this was definitely annoying in terms of how much time i had to spend on reading the papers, i will admit this definitely improved my skills at understanding dense scientific literature efficiently and effectively. if you like learning about systems neuro and reading scientific literature/want to get better at reading the literature, this course could be a good fit!

best_comment: Great class overall getting some hands on worked with cell patching. Really get a good understanding of neurons and how they function. Really enjoy the assignments that get you to do readings but not overly strenuous. Psets although look long are very manageable and reinforce learning really well. Professors and TFs are great, not the largest class so you get to know them more personally which is nice. Very well balanced class, highly recommend as a Neuro class.

MCB 125 is a class that made a comeback for the Spring 2025 term following it being last offered two years ago in Spring 2023. The structure of the class is very forgiving, with Problem Sets accounting for 75% of your overall grade while Participation counts for the other 25%. As a result, this means that there are no other assignments, exams, or projects within the course.The benefit of this structure is that MCB 125 is relatively easy to balance alongside your other classes, even if taken as a fifth course. There are only 6 Problem Sets throughout the semester, with them being spread out every other week. To be completely honest, most of us don’t even start the Problem Sets until the night before it’s due, meaning that we go through ~12 hours of misery in that moment before returning to a non–chalant, calm schedule again. However, if you would like help, the Office Hours for this class are the biggest highlight, with many of the TFs being extremely sweet and very accessible for questions.However, I think the biggest downside of this course relates back to the lecture component, which was often very unengaging. Although Professor Dulac is without a doubt extremely qualified to lecture on the content, her lectures are sometimes a little boring, which sometimes leads to students becoming very bored in class – occasionally even falling asleep. Combined with the fact that attendance is not accounted for within the course, this has resulted in student attendance dwindling as the semester progressed, with only 1/3 to 1/2 of the students attending lecture on a regular basis.The one warning I will provide future enrollees is that the grade cut–offs are not predetermined or announced to the class ahead of time. As of right now, the averages on PSETs have included the following: 96% (PSET 1), 95% (PSET 2), 96% (PSET 3), 97% (PSET 4), and unknown for PSET 5/6 since it is due during reading period. This means that all students have been doing very well in the course, which has made many of us anxious on how final letter grades will be determined. At this point in time, it is unclear if there will be an unreasonably high cutoff, which is still TBD. As a result, I would highly advise any prospective enrollees to check with former students in the coming semesters on a more accurate perspective on how finalized grading is determined. As a whole, given how MCB 125 comes with exams or projects outside of the six PSETs spread out across the semester, this makes it a relatively rewarding and relaxing class. Despite the lack of engagement, I think that MCB 125 remains a strong pick for anyone looking for a great class to balance alongside a busy semester.
worse_comment: Unless you are incredibly strong with biology, I don't really recommend this course. Professor Dulac has been one of my weakest lecturers and since everything can be very experiment/biology heavy, it can be difficult to follow at times. Having it be only a PSET class is very helpful though but they can be nit–picky with the grading at times.
best_gem_comment: Take it! the course load is pretty light if you manage your time well. definitely a hidden gem

course_title: The pharmacy of life – exploring the function and biochemistry of natural products 001
best_comment: All the feedback being given must be taken with a grain of salt because the TFs and CAs were very aware all throughout of the semester of how much our feedback as first time class takers would influence the course's overall structure. Kudos to them for being very open minded about it and really wanting students to give their feedback. They adjusted PSET length mid–semester which was very fair and they were all overall very open to suggestions even within the course's syllabus. Overall, great teaching coming from Ryan, Hisham, and Jaime.Grading scheme: Loved that there were no exams, making the class very enjoyable and light. Especially if you want to explore something so nuanced and difficult like natural products, not having exams was great. The part about graded on effort I thought was a bit inconsistent with some of the grades I had friends getting given we did the PSETs together and put in the same effort. I think you have to be very clear if it is graded on effort or correctness and if its by effort, have very good feedback so that student understands they got the point for doing the question but have room to understand where they can grow. Also grading highly varied among CAs which is always difficult to understand and unfair, so finding a way to make that more standard is essential, especially if taking the effort–based route because then it just doesn't make sense if the same effort was placed on all PSETs that they wouldn't receive the similar grades.PSETs: The exposure to Pymol and Alphafold is super fun and those PSETs were very enjoyable, whereas the others just seemed very long and tedious. I feel like there are better ways of engaging with the course content than those 10 page PSETS. They did slowly change this up during the semester and condensed into more thought out questions which was great (perhaps just not the last PSET that had 20 pages and most people just dropped it especially because of final project presentations and other finals). I honestly think having more Pymol and Alphafold PSETs would've been a super enjoyable route and very rewarding too building those skills nowadays. Lectures: They leaned much more towards chemistry than bio which would make sense given it says pharmacy in the name of the course but I expected a perhaps more higher overview of the content on the chem side. A focus on understanding why certain plants are explored, their compound effect on the body, classes of plants to explore, etc was what I expected vs learning about terpenoids etc. I think these kinda do walk hand–in–hand so I'd just add that Chem27 is also a pre–req for the class because then the chem part isn't overwhelming and taking away from the experience, despite not having Chem27 hindering my experience completely.  Some of the first PSETs had questions more focused on the chemistry side that which is what we learned in Chem27 4 weeks later or something.Final Project: Super enjoyable putting into practice everything you learned in class and analyzing something of your choice. Highly recommend taking their early deadlines seriously and really planning out what you want to talk about vs last minute cramming because this is meant to be enjoyable and you understanding how your favorite natural product's mechanism and its 3D structure.
worse_comment: It's a really fun class that covers a lot of natural products and molecules! The psets can be long, but if you get started on them early during section and over the weekend, you can do it. The final presentation is chill and low stress, but you should start early to get feedback and fix anything you need to.

course_title: Experience-Based Brain Development: Causes and Consequences 001
best_comment: a generally good neuro class for those who prefer reading scientific literature over the more traditional lecture–discussion model. every section is a paper discussion led by a student. this course definitely sharpened my scientific literacy skills in terms of reading papers effectively and efficiently, as well as how to facilitate a discussion around it. as long as you do the weekly paper readings, this class is highly manageable. lecture content is pretty interesting if you are into critical periods or topics around it. that being said, course structure could have been a lot more organised. canvas organization started off poorly (assignments posted irregularly, wrong deadlines on assignments, a mix of email and canvas communication) but got better over the weeks, and i hope it starts that way for future semesters. assignments were posted pretty late, but as long as you did the reading notes on another doc you can just copy paste it in. course readings came out very late the first few times, but got better after student feedback. i hope they continue these improvements, but in case they do not and go back to the same structure they had at the start of the course: (1) read the syllabus early and often. all dates, deadlines, and expectations are there, and the course staff expect you to know it. the class structure can be weird and assignments WILL sneak up on you if you do not keep track of them. (2) advocate for better systems – ask for a sign–up sheet for paper presentations, for papers to be uploaded at the same time weekly so you can plan ahead, for your reading grades, etc. they seem to expect the students to either have every deadline in their mind without reminders, which i suppose is a fair assumption, but it couldn't hurt to have some earlier nudges for a midterm proposal rather than on the day of.  the course staff are relatively accessible and supportive, but it definitely took a few requests for these changes to be implemented. would recommend for those with a strong interest in critical periods and those who enjoy/want to get better at reading scientific literature, but this course was definitely frustrating at first for students who value organized course structures and frequent communication about deadlines. as mentioned, i hope this improves because the course content was genuinely interesting, and all my frustrations were purely logistical. but in the event that these problems persist, as long as you keep an eye on that syllabus (literally pin it on your wall or something) you should be fine.

To be brutally honest, I had a very mixed experience with this course. I enjoyed reading the papers and learning the content, but the volume just felt overwhelming and consequently took away from the course.  That being said, I have faith that Craig will take our feedback into consideration and will make the course a lot more manageable. Therefore, I strongly recommend this course. The summaries are graded very harshly, but they ultimately did help me improve. The papers, while high in volume, had a great distribution and were super interesting. The presentations, journal clubs, and discussions were all great (though probably could have been reduced to journal clubs and presentations), and I enjoyed preparing for and participating in them.
worse_comment: Take this course if you like a discussion–based cancer biology course. The majority of the semester will be spent reading, discussing, and presenting recent literature. You'll learn quite a bit about cancer mechanisms, factors or events that accelerate/promote tumorigenesis, immunotherapy, personalized therapy, cancer monitoring and tracking, cutting edge technology, etc through these papers. Assignments mainly involve creating scientific summaries and questions for assigned papers and preparing for journal clubs, discussions, and presentations. Overall, it's different from a typical biology course and I quite enjoy taking this course.

course_title: Interplay between Viruses and their Hosts 001
best_comment: This class is super chill overall–––highly recommend it if you are looking for a manageable upper level MCB course during a busy semester. The weekly workload is just reading a (relatively more complex) research paper and writing a 500–word summary for it. Sometimes it is a bit tricky deciding what to fit into your summary, but it is excellent practice for being concise and getting the broad picture when discussing a complex topic. There are not too many instructions for these assignments, so you have a lot of freedom in terms of how you approach your work. This could be helpful but it can also be confusing exactly what is expected of you. But I would say they are super chill graders, so if you put in decent effort and show you are doing your best to understand and grow, you'll be fine. Besides, you can always reach out with questions and they are usually very fast at answering emails. The quizzes during every class can sound daunting but usually they turn out fine. Just study your materials a bit before class and it shouldn't be a problem. The final presentation at the end of the semester, like all other assignments, were pretty flexible and you are not given that many instructions. So overall, I would just say give all assignments your best effort–––participate in section–––and you will do more than fine. The lack of directions sometimes can feel overwhelming at first, but I think that is supposed to help you and not hurt (or restrict) you too much.  Lastly, the lectures can be very fast–paced and confusing sometimes. The slides could have been more clear and informative for someone who does not know that much about viruses and HIV (the main virus we talk about throughout the semester). A lot of the times, I had to do more research after class to clear up what was discussed during class, but overall, no big problems.

course_title: Brain Invaders: Building and Breaking Barriers in the Nervous System 001
best_comment: The content was really interesting. I loved the applications and case studies we explored. I definitely learned a lot. The exams can be a little difficult, so make sure to study well for them. It's a ton of memorization, don't wait till last minute. I felt like the write–ups and presentation were graded pretty harshly. There weren't many instructions on the write–ups and the grading was mainly subjective. I didn't like that aspect of the course and wish they were more transparent/had a set standardized rubric. That being said, I really enjoyed the discussion aspect of the course and learning more from my peers about the papers they presented. The studies were really fascinating. I also gained a lot of critical thinking skills and research design/methodology skills (which isn't necessarily a huge emphasis of the course) through reading the papers and critically analyzing them.  I recommend taking this class although it is not a gem or an easy A. Laura and Brendan were great instructors and really helpful!

MCB 188 is a wonderful class about Chromosomes led by Professor Nancy Kleckner. Nancy is one of the most knowledgeable people within the field and is very evidently passionate about the field, making for interesting lectures.At times, Nancy can come off as very short due to her direct way of giving feedback (including interrupting students in the middle of presentations) but you will learn over time that she does not mean this in a bad way. Instead, she is merely old fashioned, and wants to see her students do the best they possibly can. Although this may come as a shock at first, you will soon learn that she is actually one of the biggest advocates for her students and an empathetic person, even if this does not immediately shine through.For grades, Nancy is very kind, often telling students to just try their best and to not worry about the end grade. Within the course, participation accounts for 50% of your grade, while the other 50% comes from an end–of–semester research project where you must propose an experiment to answer an interesting question in the field of chromosomes, completed through a 3 page research proposal and 10 minute presentation. Throughout the process, Nancy is very supportive and offers a lot of assistance to students that need it. Although her feedback will be very direct, it is also extremely well intentioned and helps a lot in refining ideas.As a whole, if you are able to take feedback well, MCB 188 is a good course and a relatively easy one in terms of the workload. If you genuinely put in effort into your end–of–semester project and your presentations throughout the semester, you will undoubtedly succeed.

course_title: Foundations of Systems Biology and Biological Engineering 001
best_comment: ***prof cluzel is so kind and knowledgeable! the content itself is very interesting and insightful (kind of ls50–core), but the assignments are very straightforward and approachable. class was part lecture part doing out derivations on the whiteboards which i found to be really fun. cluzel has a ton of interesting anecdotes and perspectives and is just overall a great guy to talk to and get to know.

This course is a good way to fulfill the Stat Mech requirement. The teaching staff is great — Prof Nelson and Richard are so kind, and Richard's sections are super excellent.  The midterm was quite challenging, and the final exam was even more challenging, so those are definitely the toughest parts of the course, but the psets were totally manageable, and the class overall was great.

course_title: MCO 101: The PhD Journey - Navigating Towards Success 001
worse_comment: Don't recommend

best_comment: Background: I took this class as a sophomore who took the LS1 series, MCB 60, and CHEM 17 before this and CHEM 27 concurrently. This class was so fun, but it was pretty hard for me without the LS50 primer in stat mech. I feel like my brain is bigger now than it was at the beginning of the semester. MCB 65 was the class that finally got me to learn the amino acids, structural biology lab techniques, and how to be kind of good at using PyMOL. It did take a lot of work to keep up with everything, but the grading isn't insane if that helps, and they're nice about giving out opportunities for bonus points. LPS assignments (PSETs) are due every ~2 weeks and they're pretty big. I'd recommend getting started with each question as soon as you learn the relevant material so you aren't staying up until 4 the night before they're due. The two midterms and final are tough, but they give you a cheat sheet and a bunch of review material to work with, and I felt like I got the hang of it by the end of the semester. There aren't really free points (even attendance is marked for correctness) but as long as you're willing to commit I think the experience is worth it. The community also rocks. It's a small enough and hard enough class that you kind of have to make friends with everyone else. The lecturers are also so cool. Monique is honestly just incredible I love her so much. Max is good when he's lecturing about things he cares about. The TFs were also super solid, very knowledgable about the material and happy to help. Guest lecturers were hit or miss, but some of the opportunities (tour of a crystallography lab, computational protein design) were super super cool. This is my favorite MCB class I've taken so far. It took full commitment at some points (RIP my CHEM 27 grade) but if I could go back in time I would take it again.
worse_comment: I found the course really difficult. Lab every week is a killer. Thankfully we had the GOAT TF George. Other than that .............. study a lot because there's a lot of material. The LPS assignments are killer and take a long time to complete, 6+ hours at least unless you work with others. They are also pretty strict about following the rules so read the instructions of every assignment carefully

best_comment: Be prepared to spend a very long time reading the papers for this course. Additionally, your proposals will be judged very harshly despite the fact that you don't have much time to design them, so start thinking very early on about your topic and aims. Honestly, don't expect to get any praise in this class, it definitely trains you in a serious and intense way.
Enjoy :)

course_title: Foundations of Tonal Music I LEC
best_comment: Take this class!! It was lots of fun, and definitely very friendly to beginners. The teaching team is also outstanding for this course. Liam is an excellent lecturer, and my TF Sara was also wonderful. You get the chance to write a few songs in the class, which was honestly such a fun learning experience. The final exam was also very reasonable, and the teaching team provided lots of support and resources leading up to it (although in my opinion the course is already taught extremely well so there was really no need to study much!) I had such a wonderful experience in this class so you should totally consider taking it if you were ever interested in learning more about music!

This class was a wonderful opportunity to be able to compose your own piece for the Parker Quartet, an amazing professional group. The class itself made a great environment for composing, which I’d never done before and found very rewarding. There were some logistical difficulties where the instructions for assignments were not entirely clear but I know Fabian mentioned some improvements for last year. I didn’t find the lectures super interesting but I understand that it could be difficult to meet everyone’s musical interests. Workshopping people’s compositions in section was my favorite part rather than practicing ear training but again I think it depends on what people want to get out of the class.

Take this class! It does an incredible job of cultivating a motivated community in music at Harvard. The rehearsals are rigorous, and you will need to spend time outside of class to practice the high level of music that the orchestra plays. However, it is incredibly rewarding, both musically through Fed's leadership and musical expertise, and also through the friends and community that you build through weeks and weeks of practice, rehearsal, and concert!
I love Collegium so much! You won't regret joining. It is so fun to sing cool music with such a talented group of students and the social community is amazing.
Join the Harvard Glee Club! It is truly the best space on campus. You will meet your best friends, sing the best music, and have an unparalleled community. You will not regret it!
worse_comment: If you've watched dead poet's society, this is the closest you'll get to that vibe at Harvard

best_comment: RCS is the most amazing community and I've made some of my best friends at Harvard in this choir! It's also great that students studying Music as a primary or secondary concentration can apply choir to their departmental requirements.
Absolutely join. How good the class is depends on your interests. Take a section you are genuinely interested in.

TAKE THIS CLASS!!! HRO is a major time commitment but it is so worth it. Fed has a really deep appreciation for the music we play and its significance, and it's really interesting to get to know more of his thoughts and ideas about why the music is so important, and why he feels that it is worth the amount of time we spend to play any given piece and engage with it intellectually. Taking Music 107 really adds another layer of engagement and understanding to the HRO experience, and getting the letter graded credit means you can prioritize it as a class (I took 3 classes one semester and used Music 107 as my fourth class) and really give it the time it deserves instead of relegating it to the bottom of the priority pile alongside other extracurriculars. As someone who hasn't taken other music classes, the readings can be hard to understand at times, and make me aware of my lack of background knowledge, but keeping with it and wading through it really leads to me learning a lot. Be prepared to engage with music that is hard, technically, musically, in terms of musical and historical significance, because if you do you will come away with a much better understanding of that music, as well as music history and regular history overall. I would 100% recommend.

You should definitely  take this class if you're in choir. It improved your voice, your confidence, your professionalism while singing and you get to learn from some of the best! I personally worked with Carley DeFranco and I couldn't recommend her more: she was encouraging and so tentative to my way of singing and my preferences, while also providing a lot of advice from her experience.
HJO is such an awesome group!

course_title: Cuban Music Through The Lenses of Six Selected Composers LEC
best_comment: This course provided an excellent overview of Cuban music from the classical era to the 1960s, and I greatly appreciate the specificity in which all the genres were discussed. The presentations from guest lecturers on danzón and mambo allowed for lively discussion among the students in the class, and listening exercises during lecture provided each student with an opportunity to explain key elements in the musical atmosphere of each song. The composition–based assignments were truly outstanding, and I was able to grasp the rhythmic and harmonic foundations of Cuban music through these assignments. This course changed me by exposing me to such diverse genres of Cuban music and giving me the opportunity to perform pieces associated with these various styles. What a wonderful, enlightening course!

course_title: Musical Analysis, Composition, and Interpretation in the Classical Style SEM
best_comment: Take this class!! It is so so worth it. I was a bit apprehensive before I took it because I wasn’t sure if I remembered enough theory, but the teaching staff does a great job engaging everyone and making sure everyone is on board. We cover so much music and spend most of the time listening, writing, and analyzing music. I looked forward to class every week and absolutely loved the lectures and sections. The final composition was incredibly rewarding and it was amazing to hear our own pieces performed by the Parker Quartet.

This class was really cool! But it was not really what I expected. Chaya is a very modern composer (she has music online you can listen to for a sense); super atonal, and she is all about getting you out of the box. People in our class had really different music backgrounds, and it was so fun seeing what that meant for everyone. This isn't a class that will refine your understanding of super technical aspects of composition, (harmony, voicing, whatever), it's much more about the broad, artistic aspects of what you're writing. Very little direction is given because Chaya and Ali want you to just write what you're going too write, which can be scary or it can be super fun.Anyway take it if you want to just write a lot and take a pretty chill class and hear what other people are writing

course_title: Advanced Ensemble Workshop for Composers, Performers, and Improvisers: Project Development STO
best_comment: As someone who has always found it difficult to go the extra mile and create music, this course gives you excellent resources, wonderful peers, and a supportive teaching staff to help you make a creative product. I definitely learned much more about my composing style and what I can improve upon in the future for actual musical projects. Additionally, the recording studio is brand new and absolutely fantastic. 10/10 would recommend.

TAKE THIS CLASS!! Best music class I've taken at Harvard. It's a beautiful synergy of learning a new music language (Max MSP) and also becoming better as a musician and performer itself. Hans deeply cares about his students and will give back the energy that you give to him. Victor was an awesome TF as well and made sure to spend hours of time with multiple students outside of class to get our Max patches sounding great.

This class is a great way to continue being involved with music at Harvard with peers who probably also did music at a high level before Harvard. The one thing I will say is: do not underestimate the amount of time you have to put into the class. Of course, it is possible to breeze through by barely rehearsing, since the only mandatory thing is a 1 hour weekly coaching (and if your group wants to do this class this way that's totally valid). But after taking this class 4 times, I have realized most groups do actually want to sound good by the final concert, and are pretty serious about rehearsing. For my group, we had regular weekly rehearsals but also extra rehearsals for the performance classes, the final jury, and the final concert, and all that rehearsal time builds up—our group also had extra coaching sessions (so more time again). So ultimately whether this class is a 5th class gem or a pretty substantial class in itself really depends on how serious your group is about sounding good and rehearsing a lot (and note how much your group cares could change DURING the semester). As for the new policy removing pre–formed groups (starting Fall 2025), I understand it may be unpopular—but I agree with the decision. (For context, the status quo is that if you have a pre–formed group, you essentially get into the course automatically, without much consideration to the individual level of the players, and people who applied individually despite essentially being professional–level musicians have gotten rejected due to pre–formed groups having priority). I don't think this is fair, especially for students with professional–level training/performing experience. I think the audition process should be merit–based and not based on social connections and ultimately, whoever is a better musician gets to take the course. Moreover, yes, it is nice to play with your friends, but I think the purpose of a class like this should be personal and musical development. I think playing with people you don’t know—especially ones at a similar level—can actually be a better means to achieve this goal and can challenge you in different and productive ways. Of course, it works when a pre–formed group is compatible, but I believe that the overall pre–forming process often results in several unbalanced groups with players of different levels, resulting in a worse 189 experience for people in these unbalanced groups. I've also seen a fair amount of politicking with the pre–forming process e.g. people trying to “lock in” players early, or abandoning one group for a better one mid–process, which can get messy. I think the staff have a good idea of which players are similar in ability and compatible with others and will ultimately create more balanced groups, resulting in a better overall 189 experience for everyone. The counter of course is that this assumes the staff know better than the students which musicians will be more compatible with each other, which might be difficult in a 10–minute audition. BUT, at least they get to hear everyone directly and assess musical levels side–by–side and for me, that puts them in a better position than students to create balanced, compatible ensembles. Also, stepping back a bit, I don't think the policy is unreasonable—at chamber music festivals the norm is for the organizers/coaches to assign the groups, and in the industry groups are often pieced together last–minute and musicians often have no say in who they play with.Aside from this digression, this is a brilliant course that any classical musician at Harvard should consider taking! The Parker Quartet is amazing and the course is a huge value–add for the overall music environment and music community at Harvard.
worse_comment: It can be great, but be careful about scheduling. It can be really frustrating to deal with schedule total incompatabily.

course_title: Music of the Last Ten Years 001
best_comment: This class is a wonderful opportunity to meet other people, discuss interesting ideas, and expand your listening and thinking!

course_title: Age of Empires: Violence, Ideology, and the Making of Ancient Near Eastern Societies 001
Introduction to the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament 2: Latter Prophets and Writings 001
best_comment: If you are at all interested in the Hebrew Bible / Old Testament, please take this class. Prof. Teeter is so knowledgeable and is so skilled at drawing out the rich tapestry or literary art and meaning in these texts. He is a pioneer in his approach to reading the Hebrew Bible, and it is a privilege to learn from him. You should consider taking this course even if you have already learned the Old Testament in a personal religious context. As an evangelical, I grew in my faith and appreciation for God's Word through this text. You may not agree with everything Prof. Teeter or your classmates say (you will agree with a lot of it though!), and it will be time well spent learning about and engaging with these ideas.
worse_comment: Take the class if interested in Hebrew Bible beyond source criticism.

course_title: Social Archaeology of Iron Age Ancient Israel 001
best_comment: No matter what your research interests are, whether religious or purely archaeological – or both– , the knowledge about the Iron Age Levant that you’ll gain in this class will be truly fascinating.

Professor Madi brings great enthusiasm to the flsssroom. As long as you meet it with a genuine desire to learn and sincere effort, you will do well. He really makes sure you are speaking, this is a great class for Arabic. Take it!
worse_comment: Submit the homework on time, do your corrections, and don’t be afraid to make mistakes!

best_comment: a lot of homework, assignments, and quizzes, but once you have a good routine it's not a problem.  It is straight forward and if you put in the work and do all the homeworks properly, you will do well on the quizzes and assignments and get a good grade.
worse_comment: Take the course if you are motivated to learn Arabic enough that you can look past a poor textbook and assignments.

best_comment: This class is challenging but incredibly rewarding. Stay consistent with the vocabulary and grammar practice, participate actively in class, and you'll be amazed at how much you can learn in just one semester.
worse_comment: I would not recommend this course due to the excessive work and focus more on fusha rather than a balance between speaking and writing. The textbook was also not helpful and often made topics and concepts more difficult and complex than they needed to be.

best_comment: This course is a fantastic continuation of AA that continues through Al–Kitaab 1 and covers a bunch of different grammatical forms and cultural topics, as well as a ton of vocab and listening. Definitely try not to get behind on assignments––the daily homework assignments are manageable, but can quickly get out of hand if you miss one. Otherwise, this course is definitely "the more you put in the more you'll get out"––if you show you care and give effort, the progress you can make in Arabic is great.

Incredible class, especially if you have Ustaaz Cozzens. The in–class activities actively pushed us to speak and think, and I was able to build my confidence a lot through both drills and informal conversations. They also do a good job to make sure native speakers and first–time learners alike got to be challenged in their own way, and we were all able to learn from each other and hear different dialects. The assignments all felt meaningful, and was never superfluous grunt work.  I didn’t just learn Arabic—I learned how to learn Arabic.For those on the fence about whether or not to take it, you should! It won’t feel like too much time. Took this as an elective—couldn’t recommend it more.
worse_comment: Solid class — you’ll learn a lot, and each individual assessment is fair in its own right. The grading is fair and the feedback is helpful. Be warned, this class is going to be more annoying than you think. It’s not the assignments are hard per se, but you will regularly have 3–4 separate homework assignments every single day. That might not sound like much, but believe me it’s annoying. Don’t be scared off from taking the class because of all of the busy work. But it is a lot.

best_comment: It was difficult but rewarding. I'm really excited to continue with Arabic at the next opportunity.
Take, It's worth it and you will enjoy having these preceptors. They are so nice and helpful.

Aya is hands down the best Arabic teacher I've ever had in the department. She is not only thoughtful, kind, and caring towards students, she is also an excellent teacher. Arabic is very demanding work and time wise, and Aya was both kind and professional when it came to being sympathetic to students and helping them do well. If she's teaching an Arabic class, I recommend that students try their hardest to be in her class. Madi was also a wonderful TA. He taught us very interesting things about Egypt during his sessions and is likewise very knowledgable about the language and kind. They are a great team and Harvard is very lucky to have them both.
This is a lot of work. You have to be committed to doing your work every day or you will fall behind. But for good students who are passionate about Arabic, this is a really effective course.

The professor is very thorough and rigorous in his approach to the class, in that we approached the topic from many different angles giving students a much more robust and nuanced understanding of the topic. Professor is incredible – very passionate about making us great scholars and just more informed people on a very important topic. And he is obviously incredibly expert. Fundamentally changed how I understand Islam in all honesty. We talked about its origins as a religious reform movement as opposed to a discrete new faith, which fundamentally changes my understanding the religion and the following course materials. Students from all backgrounds religious cultural and intellectual should take this class. Really an incredible exemplar of what the humanities can do in the classroom.

course_title: The Modern Middle East, Real and Imagined: An Introduction 001
best_comment: Do the readings carefully and take notes on them to help guide discussion in section.

course_title: Shi’a Islam and Politics in the Middle East 001
best_comment: This was an excellent course, and Dr. Sagha is a very knowledgeable and enthusiastic teacher. You will learn a lot about transnational Shia political movements and how they are transforming the modern Middle East.

course_title: Regional Order, U.S. Wars, and the Politics of Iraq and Afghanistan 001
best_comment: AMAZING COURSE PLEASE TAKE IT IM SO SERIOUS . literally the best course and my first ever middle east focused class. He gives amazing feedback on your essays even if you aren’t confident in your writing skills (i’m a cs major btw and haven’t written an essay in 3 years)

course_title: Colonization and Decolonization in the Maghrib and Egypt (19th-20th c.) 001

course_title: Historical Background to the Contemporary Middle East: Religion, Literature and Politics 001
best_comment: This is an excellent course that I’d recommend to NELC or non NELC concentrators. You get a great sense of the topics available within NELC and the workload is reasonable. Dr. Shahvand is also amazing and the nicest guy, and his personal story is super interesting as well. Great course!!

Persian is such a beautiful and rich language, you should definitely take this class if you are interested in learning more about it. This being said, this class is a good amount of work considering it is an introductory language, so be prepared to put the time and effort in that is needed to succeed!
If you have any interest in Persian/Farsi, I highly recommend taking this course!

What a wonderful time!! Turkish is such a fun and interesting language to learn, and Meryem Hocam is such an enthusiastic and clear instructor who cares so much about your individual learning. It is so cool to have walked into this class (starting with Turkish AA in the fall) not understanding a single thing to now having built a very solid foundation. Over the course of this class, you will encounter many new grammatical structures via chalkboard diagram (and learn to enjoy this process!), gain exposure to Turkish music + culture, and learn many things about your fellow classmates through discussions and creative assignments (like poems and stories)! Having very friendly and dedicated classmates makes this class even more awesome. Take Turkish, you will DEFINITELY love it!!

I definitely recommend taking this course in both junior spring and senior fall if you know that you'll be doing a thesis because it's a great way to earn credit hours (and an easy A) for just working on your thesis. It's also a flexible but efficient way to be held accountable to make sure you're not falling behind and that your research is thoroughly planned and executed. Neuroscience advisors also give you feedback early on (during the summer before senior year), so that's really helpful.

I definitely recommend taking this course in both junior spring and senior fall if you know that you'll be doing a thesis because it's a great way to earn credit hours (and an easy A) for just working on your thesis. It's also a flexible but efficient way to be held accountable to make sure you're not falling behind and that your research is thoroughly planned and executed. Writing a thesis can be daunting, but it all depends on who your PI/grad advisor is. The experience can vary widely based on how invested they are in you and how well your thesis aligns with their current research. Overall, highly recommend.

Writing a thesis can be daunting, but it all depends on who your PI/grad advisor is. The experience can vary widely based on how invested they are in you and how well your thesis aligns with their current research. Overall, highly recommend.

course_title: Alzheimer’s Disease: Causes and consequences of brain degeneration 001
best_comment: This class is a must–take for anyone interested in neuroscience, medicine, or aging and memory. It does such a good job of combining scientific inquiry with a deep sense of empathy and ethical reflection. The readings are so interesting and often challenging, but the classroom environment makes it easy to ask questions and explore ideas and grow. Ted is an outstanding instructor. He is thoughtful, kind, and it is clear that he is deeply invested in his students’ learning. He does an incredible job of encouraging inclusive discussions where every student’s perspective is valued. I came away from this course not only with a better understanding of Alzheimer’s disease, but also with a clearer sense of why this field matters and how I might contribute to it in the future.

course_title: Sleep Talk: Unraveling the Mystery of Sleep 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!! The work load was very manageable, and I was never stressed about my grade. Professor Cunningham is also such a great professor– you can tell that he cares about his students and tries his best to help everyone in the course succeed but he's also a chill, funny guy haha. He's also very accommodating and understanding. The course itself is interesting imo, sleep is important in our daily lives, so I'll definitely be applying what I've learned going forth. I think that the structure and assignments of the course are also valuable in the sense that they help you improve various scientific journalism and research skills.

This is a great course! There is a lot of flexibility in what you can explore for your final project too!

a good systems–level neuro class for concentrators who don't really like overly molecular/cellular neuroscience. first half of the course is a little dry, but learning about the different animal models later on was pretty interesting. florian is a great lecturer! assignments are mainly the matlab assignments and quiz readings. matlab is very doable for beginners with step–by–step instructions and lots of resources available for help (office hours, matlab guides). quiz readings requires significant prep with really understanding the papers. although this was definitely annoying in terms of how much time i had to spend on reading the papers, i will admit this definitely improved my skills at understanding dense scientific literature efficiently and effectively. if you like learning about systems neuro and reading scientific literature/want to get better at reading the literature, this course could be a good fit!
worse_comment: The reading assessments and final exam can be difficult so prepare for them.

best_comment: a good systems–level neuro class for concentrators who don't really like overly molecular/cellular neuroscience. first half of the course is a little dry, but learning about the different animal models later on was pretty interesting. florian is a great lecturer! assignments are mainly the matlab assignments and quiz readings. matlab is very doable for beginners with step–by–step instructions and lots of resources available for help (office hours, matlab guides). quiz readings requires significant prep with really understanding the papers. although this was definitely annoying in terms of how much time i had to spend on reading the papers, i will admit this definitely improved my skills at understanding dense scientific literature efficiently and effectively. if you like learning about systems neuro and reading scientific literature/want to get better at reading the literature, this course could be a good fit!

best_comment: Great class overall getting some hands on worked with cell patching. Really get a good understanding of neurons and how they function. Really enjoy the assignments that get you to do readings but not overly strenuous. Psets although look long are very manageable and reinforce learning really well. Professors and TFs are great, not the largest class so you get to know them more personally which is nice. Very well balanced class, highly recommend as a Neuro class.

Great class overall getting some hands on worked with cell patching. Really get a good understanding of neurons and how they function. Really enjoy the assignments that get you to do readings but not overly strenuous. Psets although look long are very manageable and reinforce learning really well. Professors and TFs are great, not the largest class so you get to know them more personally which is nice. Very well balanced class, highly recommend as a Neuro class.

Neuro 120 was an awesome , seminar–like class! Every lecture, students had opportunities to jump in the conversation and ask questions. We also had two very interesting guest lectures. For me, the final project was my favorite part of this course. Not only did my partner and I absolutely crush the final project but it was super fun discussing our ideas and thoughts with Dr. Penikis, the section leaders, and our classmates! I feel like we were able to contribute significant analysis with our final project while utilizing a lot of the concepts that we learned throughout the semester. The PSETs and assignments were difficult at–times but I felt that this difficulty was necessary for adequate retention of knowledge. Also, I'd say Dr. Penekis is a great lecturer and is really geared towards students (unlike other busy professors). The content of the class was amazing as well: got a very holistic, comprehensive views on specific parts of computational neuroscience (neural networks, UMAP, PCA, spectral analysis, LIF, functional connectivity analysis, etc).

MCB 125 is a class that made a comeback for the Spring 2025 term following it being last offered two years ago in Spring 2023. The structure of the class is very forgiving, with Problem Sets accounting for 75% of your overall grade while Participation counts for the other 25%. As a result, this means that there are no other assignments, exams, or projects within the course.The benefit of this structure is that MCB 125 is relatively easy to balance alongside your other classes, even if taken as a fifth course. There are only 6 Problem Sets throughout the semester, with them being spread out every other week. To be completely honest, most of us don’t even start the Problem Sets until the night before it’s due, meaning that we go through ~12 hours of misery in that moment before returning to a non–chalant, calm schedule again. However, if you would like help, the Office Hours for this class are the biggest highlight, with many of the TFs being extremely sweet and very accessible for questions.However, I think the biggest downside of this course relates back to the lecture component, which was often very unengaging. Although Professor Dulac is without a doubt extremely qualified to lecture on the content, her lectures are sometimes a little boring, which sometimes leads to students becoming very bored in class – occasionally even falling asleep. Combined with the fact that attendance is not accounted for within the course, this has resulted in student attendance dwindling as the semester progressed, with only 1/3 to 1/2 of the students attending lecture on a regular basis.The one warning I will provide future enrollees is that the grade cut–offs are not predetermined or announced to the class ahead of time. As of right now, the averages on PSETs have included the following: 96% (PSET 1), 95% (PSET 2), 96% (PSET 3), 97% (PSET 4), and unknown for PSET 5/6 since it is due during reading period. This means that all students have been doing very well in the course, which has made many of us anxious on how final letter grades will be determined. At this point in time, it is unclear if there will be an unreasonably high cutoff, which is still TBD. As a result, I would highly advise any prospective enrollees to check with former students in the coming semesters on a more accurate perspective on how finalized grading is determined. As a whole, given how MCB 125 comes with exams or projects outside of the six PSETs spread out across the semester, this makes it a relatively rewarding and relaxing class. Despite the lack of engagement, I think that MCB 125 remains a strong pick for anyone looking for a great class to balance alongside a busy semester.
worse_comment: Unless you are incredibly strong with biology, I don't really recommend this course. Professor Dulac has been one of my weakest lecturers and since everything can be very experiment/biology heavy, it can be difficult to follow at times. Having it be only a PSET class is very helpful though but they can be nit–picky with the grading at times.
best_gem_comment: Take it! the course load is pretty light if you manage your time well. definitely a hidden gem

best_comment: This class is super awesome! It is so interesting if you are genuinely interested in the topic of the course. The guest lectures are super fun and the courseload is definitely manageable!
worse_comment: The final grade all falls on the final project! I haven't written a scientific paper before so I'm not sure how it will be graded.

course_title: Experience-Based Brain Development: Causes and Consequences 001
best_comment: a generally good neuro class for those who prefer reading scientific literature over the more traditional lecture–discussion model. every section is a paper discussion led by a student. this course definitely sharpened my scientific literacy skills in terms of reading papers effectively and efficiently, as well as how to facilitate a discussion around it. as long as you do the weekly paper readings, this class is highly manageable. lecture content is pretty interesting if you are into critical periods or topics around it. that being said, course structure could have been a lot more organised. canvas organization started off poorly (assignments posted irregularly, wrong deadlines on assignments, a mix of email and canvas communication) but got better over the weeks, and i hope it starts that way for future semesters. assignments were posted pretty late, but as long as you did the reading notes on another doc you can just copy paste it in. course readings came out very late the first few times, but got better after student feedback. i hope they continue these improvements, but in case they do not and go back to the same structure they had at the start of the course: (1) read the syllabus early and often. all dates, deadlines, and expectations are there, and the course staff expect you to know it. the class structure can be weird and assignments WILL sneak up on you if you do not keep track of them. (2) advocate for better systems – ask for a sign–up sheet for paper presentations, for papers to be uploaded at the same time weekly so you can plan ahead, for your reading grades, etc. they seem to expect the students to either have every deadline in their mind without reminders, which i suppose is a fair assumption, but it couldn't hurt to have some earlier nudges for a midterm proposal rather than on the day of.  the course staff are relatively accessible and supportive, but it definitely took a few requests for these changes to be implemented. would recommend for those with a strong interest in critical periods and those who enjoy/want to get better at reading scientific literature, but this course was definitely frustrating at first for students who value organized course structures and frequent communication about deadlines. as mentioned, i hope this improves because the course content was genuinely interesting, and all my frustrations were purely logistical. but in the event that these problems persist, as long as you keep an eye on that syllabus (literally pin it on your wall or something) you should be fine.

course_title: Brain Invaders: Building and Breaking Barriers in the Nervous System 001
best_comment: The content was really interesting. I loved the applications and case studies we explored. I definitely learned a lot. The exams can be a little difficult, so make sure to study well for them. It's a ton of memorization, don't wait till last minute. I felt like the write–ups and presentation were graded pretty harshly. There weren't many instructions on the write–ups and the grading was mainly subjective. I didn't like that aspect of the course and wish they were more transparent/had a set standardized rubric. That being said, I really enjoyed the discussion aspect of the course and learning more from my peers about the papers they presented. The studies were really fascinating. I also gained a lot of critical thinking skills and research design/methodology skills (which isn't necessarily a huge emphasis of the course) through reading the papers and critically analyzing them.  I recommend taking this class although it is not a gem or an easy A. Laura and Brendan were great instructors and really helpful!

I loved this class. It is definitely a lot of dense readings, but I think over the semester it teaches you how to engage and efficiently read primary literature. Sometimes it seems daunting, but once you go to lecture Randy does a great job teaching. I found myself really engaged throughout the 2 hour lecture. The assignments can be nerve–racking and there are some in–class quizzes, but if you go to office hours and/or book times to meet with Randy or Emma, they are super helpful. I think you get what you put into this class.
worse_comment: All undergrads, please listen: be very careful with this class. Only take if you are very experienced with neuroscience. There are many postdocs, grad students, etc. in this class, despite it being offered in FAS as an undergrad course. If professor disagrees with topic, student is given poor grade.The class lacks any structure for assignments:– Doesn’t give page length for several papers, or any guidance on assignment; student can meet with professor to gain clarity, but this is not acceptable;– No rubric for paper or how grading would be conducted, along with no structure given about assignments in syllabus;– The final paper is due BEFORE reading period which collides with many undergrad students' midterms, which is literally against the rules by the dean.

course_title: Biology and Evolution of Invertebrate Animals 001
best_comment: Very good course. Not too difficult if you keep on top of studying the new content every week, but it's easy to fall behind and cramming is basically impossible since it asks you to know a lot. There is very little required work outside of class every week, so use that time to consistently review content. Cassandra and Bronwyn are great – don't be afraid to email them your questions and especially head to their office hours before exams. The trip was super fun –– very unique for Harvard classes. This is not your typical beach bum vacation, though –– if you don't enjoy science and labwork, you won't enjoy the trip or get nearly as much out of it as you should. The trip is to collect animals to study in lab, so it is rewarding if you're passionate about the subject matter and like applying what we learn to real specimens, but not if you're looking for a free beach vacation. That being said, we got 2 nights to explore the town/city, but otherwise you can't leave the base at night. Overall it's a very fun and rewarding class, but they make you work for it. Don't do it if you're only loosely interested in it or because you want a free trip –– do it because you're actually interested.

This is a really excellent course here. The teaching staff is awesome ( and do a wonderful job lecturing), field trips are a great opportunity to get off campus ( and also very fun), lab is really just getting to see how cool plants are, and the assignments are not terribly stressful. This has made this class a wonderful science class to take at Harvard. The organization and course format is very well done, making this a great class for students. The content is also very interesting. As a side note: I took this class with OEB 103 and found this class and OEB 103 to go hand and hand. What I learned in OEB 103 was incredibly helpful for this class and vice versa. If you are thinking about taking both classes, they both inform and help each other. It was a great plant semester.
worse_comment: This is easily the most fun I've had in a Harvard class over the past four years. I came from a completely unrelated major and stumbled upon this course in the catalog basically by chance. If you like plants in any capacity whatsoever, take this class! If this class fulfills a requirement for you but you think you hate plants, take this class anyway!

course_title: The History and Evolution of Life on Earth 001
best_comment: Both professors are good lecturers and are engaged with the class. If you're interested in OEB, it's probably a good introductory class to the history of life. I had literally zero OEB knowledge going in which made some of the content basically roll off me because I had no background/frame of reference for it. The class isn't too difficult or time consuming—there's no pset, just lab assignments that are sometimes basically a pset. Labs were hit or miss. Some involved looking at cool fossils, and some were mostly googling what the differences between two random extinct plants are. I discovered about halfway through the class that I am not a history of plants and animals enjoyer, which unfortunately led to me going "why do we care?" about a lot of the later content (which is mostly that) despite the lectures being good. So if you're considering taking this to fulfill an EPS sub–discipline requirement, I'd recommend thoughtfully assessing how much the evolution of life actually interests you.
worse_comment: This class is interesting, and it is a pretty decent balance between biology and EPS. The work load is fair and the teaching staff is supportive, but make sure you stay up to date on the lecture notes and actually attend class. If you don't, thdings can start becoming a lot because such a large time span is covered. While the midterm and final are fair, they can become difficult if you do not spend enough time reviewing. Overall, this is a good course that teaches you a lot about how the Earth has evolved and changed over time. It is not super easy or super hard, but it requires consistent attention and effort to thrive.
