best_comment: hi plant enthusiasts! take this course if you are ready for a challenge! Chuck and Ryan are amazing, but only take this class if you can handle intense exams and so much information you'll feel like your brain will explode. and you love plants a LOT. I learned so much and really enjoyed the course, but it was hard! I've gained such an appreciation for the plant world and I'm sure you will too. Just stay positive and study hard!!!
worse_comment: Take itttttt but also be prepared to really work ur ass off, it's drinking water out of a fire hose but u sort of trauma bond with ur classmates and Ryan is a goated tf.

course_title: The Fishy Aspects of the Human Body 001
best_comment: This class is really interesting, and the TF + Professor Pierce are super passionate which shows through the class discussions, curated labs, and interactive website. I'd recommend – it's fun!
great class if you want to gain a good neuro background

I loved this class!! AMAZING professors and TFs – some of the more quantitative topics can get a bit complex, but you learn a lot all the different methods/models in population genetics. Can't emphasize enough how great the teaching staff is – they're incredibly passionate about the subject, but are also super compassionate and the psets/exams feel very relevant and reasonable for the class.

I loved this class!! AMAZING professors and TFs – some of the more quantitative topics can get a bit complex, but you learn a lot all the different methods/models in population genetics. Can't emphasize enough how great the teaching staff is – they're incredibly passionate about the subject, but are also super compassionate and the psets/exams feel very relevant and reasonable for the class.

course_title: Terrestrial Carbon and Nitrogen Cycling – Current Dynamics and Future Changes 001
Microbial Sciences: Chemistry, Ecology and Evolution 001
best_comment: This class was really fun and a good way to spend my Friday mornings. We read some really interesting papers and the rotating weekly speaker setup gave us the opportunity to hear from so many amazing microbiologists/adjacent–scientists.

course_title: Topics in Organismic and Evolutionary Biology 001
best_comment: Bring Tupperware. But, in all seriousness, this is a very helpful course for those who have not taught before, and feel free to ask questions about asking questions.

course_title: Self and World: Early Modern Philosophy 001
best_comment: This is a class that deserves the Harvard name. It has seriously set my standards for every other class. My think is substantially clearer. (I will be changing my concentration as a result) I am not exaggerating: if you want to *learn* here, take this class.The reason is two–fold: the nature of the topic and the class itself. THE TOPICWe have NOT solved what these early modern writers were discussing. We have, in fact, made little progress. We've tried to ignore metaphysical questions as if they cease becoming relevant. But ignoring something does not make it go away, and serious problems with current scientific research and the general "misinformation" and extreme political polarization can be traced back to this.  It's insane and fascinating.The writers in this class invite you into the conversation. The works of the early modern period are IDEAL for beginners because a) you'll need to know something about Aristotle for any of them be intelligible  (+1 classic!) b) much of what they started continues today (+1 modern!). It's a 3 for 1 deal. You WILL see the same ideas discussed now, even if using different language (it's about the *substance* not the *word* people!). Things will make more sense, you will be able to *formulate your own thoughts* on them and assess where we simply do not know the answer.  (what is a scientific "law"?)THE CLASS1) Teaching approach. Hands down.  – Working through the arguments of the text. This is so important. We learn the PROCESS the writers used and NOT "Oh Descartes though this".  When you go through the actual steps, the conclusion stop appearing mystical or like the result of revelations—though they still remain impressive. Finally: the historical context and the "raw materials" they were working with makes it click into place. I can confidently reconstruct most of the arguments we tackled now (which will make me very fun at parties).– Questions in class: Prof Simmons would ASK THE STUDENTS TO CLARIFY THEIR QUESTIONS so she answer it meaningfully and have students engaged in a conversation (wild!).  We use clear terms (insane!) She was also able to judge when a question would steer us off the main topic too much. – Relevant section topics. People were not just talking past each other (a miracle!).– Format Prof. Simmons using chalk is the right move. We are actually thinking through ideas instead of going through a prepared presentation. – I guarantee every other response raves about Prof. Simmons, so—yes, what they said. 2) Workload– Short assignments: these were the perfect balance of challenging and doable. The key part is that they had PURPOSE. The canvas page clearly states what skill each assignment targeted, and it was clear to judge where you fell short and see improvement throughout the semester. Many of my friends complain about busywork or vague assignments where they feel lost, this class is free of that. –  The questions for the final are released beforehand so you can prepare them together. Great discussions – The amount of reading is very manageable. There mix of required (og works) vs optional reading (secondary sources)! You do have to actually read the original works (if you don't want this bit, do not take the class. Full stop.)3) THE OTHER STUDENTS <This class attracts curious interesting  smart people who actually want to be there. I have formed the most actual friendships out of this class than any other, to the point where altered the trajectory of my social life here. We don't have shallow conversations and respect each other's ideas. It's great.
worse_comment: This is a fun class if you have some experience in philosophy and if you do all the readings. If you skimp on the readings, the lectures will be pretty much unintelligible, but the readings themselves can be kind of difficult and time–consuming. Grades can be a little discouraging but you do learn a lot and it's a solid introduction to metaphysics.

best_comment: If you're really into moral/ethical philosophy, I think you will absolutely love this class. If you're only kind of interested like I was/am, you'll have a good time, but things can get a little boring. The class is VERY formulaic week to week: you read a few texts, Seth explains them in lecture, and you discuss them in section. There is very little throughout the semester to break up this routine, which can make the whole course just blend into one big blob of philosophy. That being said, I still give this class a very positive review. Seth is very intentional with what/how he teaches, and it's obvious that one of his goals is for each of his students to leave his class as better people. He's also just a cool dude, and makes the whole class a super chill vibe. I also really like how major assignments are structured. You have to write two ~1500 word essays which are based more on your own thinking and perspective than a standard research paper. They were overall really enjoyable to write, and the grading is pretty friendly if you do a good job. Great class! If you're looking for a fun elective which is easy, but not a joke, and you want to learn something along the way, this is an excellent choice.
worse_comment: This course had great readings and fascinating discussions about human ethics, but I couldn't help but feel that it was quite disorganized.

best_comment: Dr. Martel is an excellent instructor. If you are lucky enough to take this tutorial on pragmatism, you are in for a treat. I may be a little biased because I already like pragmatist philosophy, but the readings are a good selection that keep you interested. Pragmatism is deeply ingrained in Harvard history, and this unique class puts it into perspective. You can choose to focus your writing on more theoretical or more "applied" philosophy, which I liked because I do not find the latter that interesting. Either way, Dr. Martel gives feedback that constructively makes you a better philosophy writer. Discussion in class was focused on understanding the material and common objections, all of which feel well–covered by the end.

This was my favorite class this semester! We essentially used the theme of dialogues as an excuse to dip our toes into a variety of subfields in philosophy. Moreover, Quyen Pham was one of the best philosophy section leaders I've ever had. She created a very friendly atmosphere, and I always looked forward to class.
worse_comment: this course will help you learn how to identify and reconstruct arguments. however, if you have already taken some philosophy courses (especially any advanced ones), this course probably won't add much to the skills you already developed in previous courses. the content can be interesting sometimes, but it's not ideal if you're looking for more ethics–oriented or highly applicable philosophical ideas – sometimes it gets kind of abstract and you might wonder what's the point of discussing that. with that said, Philosophy Through Dialogue goes through philosophers of different epochs and that are quite foundational to continue studying philosophy if you're concentrating in it (basically, helped you get broader foundations in philosophy). in terms of assignments, they're doable and not a ton of effort, but can be a little annoying doing 5 response papers + final paper, especially because it's all the same: identify argument, reconstruct argument.

best_comment: Highly recommend taking this class or any class with Mariana!! She's so brilliant and yet so kind. She can quote Plato from memory and is continually saying the most fascinating things. And she does so while maintaining a warmth that made the class something I looked forward to every week.

Unfortunately this class probably won’t get offered again since Professor Moran is leaving, but it was really excellent! Wittgenstein is such a fascinating and important figure, and this class did a great job giving a nuanced view of his thinking. Moran’s lectures were super thorough and methodical, Emily did a great job in section, and the selection of readings was excellent. It was a bit more challenging and work–heavy class, but extremely rewarding.
worse_comment: Everyone, everyone, everyone should take this course before they graduate. Wittgenstein's relevance to your thinking and your doing will be pressed upon you no matter your background.

course_title: Current Topics in Philosophy of Language 001
best_comment: This course fundamentally changed me as a student. My writing is a lot more precise and crip than it was before. Moreover, the practice of writing a term–paper is something that every student should experience. With this in mind, I truly think that every philosophy concentrator should dabble in philosophy of language at least once during their time at Harvard. To be clear, this course is not easy. The readings are not the most intuitive but make sense with time and many office–hour conversations. So, you absolutely need to advocate for yourself when you are confused and need clarification. Fortunately, Professor Nickel is one of the most kind and dedicated professors that I know. That being said, he is ALWAYS happy to touch base and guide you towards where you need to be. He makes it clear through his actions and words that he wants every single student to succeed. Plus, he's super funny and approachable. TL; DR: TAKE THIS COURSE. This is one of the few seminars that is going to stick with me for years to come.

If you have a chance, TAKE THIS CLASS.  I can not tell you exactly what you will learn, since the course is improved upon each semester, but I can tell you that it will be fundamentally fascinating. We spent the first half of the semester essentially rederiving linear algebra, and the second rederiving all of the axioms of quantum mechanics, all from base principles with very little prior math knowledge needed. Readings included many paper from the original proposal/formulations of quantum mechanics, and section/OH helped a lot with interpretation, so that prior philosophy knowledge requirements were also minimal. Though I took the course as Phil 151, there was a fairly even distribution of people who took it as a physics course, and one could consistently rely on others who had more experience in either physics or philosophy for perspective. The class is small (30ish people), competitive to get into (because the subject and professor are both well liked by students), and takes all years/levels of experience (everything is self contained/taught within the course). This is also a wonderful class for a more logical/formulaic philosophy experience and a more questions/interpretation–based experience physics. I would definitely recommend attending section/OH if possible, the material is fascinating and teaching staff are very willing to discuss related topics. The course generally follows the professors own formulation of quantum mechanics, has no exams (only a final essay), and has only one pset a week (with a reading section and a very straightforward math section). Overall, I had a wonderful time in this class and would absolutely choose to take it again. I seriously can not overstate how interesting and welcoming this class is!TLDR; Best class, heavily consider taking it

In my opinion, great course. I saw reviews saying lectures are dry. Sure, but any class has dry lectures. If you are interested in this topic and philosophy, especially the metaphysical side, this is a great course. You won't think lectures are dry, you will have tons of fun with the content and the assignments are great, useful –– no busy work. It will hone your philosophy skills well. (my thoughts)
worse_comment: not sure I would recommend thisclass, interesting subject matter but lectures are pretty boring and mostly just recap readings. Sections were very helpful, though. The papers weren’t too bad – three six–pagers, which felt much less stressful than having one big final paper.

best_comment: You will likely learn to love this topic by the end of the course and develop a genuine interest in the topics covered. Professor Siegel does an outstanding job in facilitation and the course really feels engaging throughout the whole class period.

This class is absolutely wonderful! Zoe is one of the best professors I have had here at Harvard. Not only is she super funny, but she knows her philosophy so well and does a great job breaking it down during lectures. Zoe's lectures are super engaging– she is very bubbly and enthusiatic, and she always have activities during lecture! One thing I would say about this class is it's super important to stay on top of the readings. The reading summaries (while they may annoy you in the moment), will be your absolute best friend when it comes to that final! This is a class both undergraduates and graduate students can take, and I highly recommend it as an undergraduate myself– what I will say is that the readings are very complexed, so you have to be committed to sitting there and putting in the effort to understand. Zoe and Jing Hwan are fantastic and are readily available, which is great. The two papers are very short (1500 words), and make sure you come to class to get your participation points! Overall, this has been one of my favorite classes, and I'm really going to miss it!

Great class, run very well as a group discussion. I don't have as much to say about Jeff because of the structure of the class (where most of the time, students were discussing), but he was a very good facilitator, put together a very good group of readings, and generally structured the discussion very well, as well as helping with the final paper. I would very much recommend if you find modern meta–ethics at all interesting.

This is one of the best Harvard courses I have taken so far. As a STEM concentrator without any background in political philosophy, I learned extensively about theories of social justice and how to apply the theoretical concepts to understand current political issues. Professor Stanzcyk is among the smartest and kindest people I have met. His lectures are extremely well–structured, and his wit and clarity fill everyone with engagement and willingness to participate in the discussion. Outside of class, he always makes himself available to the students. The other teaching assistants were also invaluable and very considerate. I would enthusiastically recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn about theories of social justice (with an emphasis on Rawls) and immerse in a semester of thinking about pressing political issues. The course does not require a considerable time commitment as the readings are brief and engaging. Moreover, there are only four writing assignments, no midterms, and no final exams. It is an excellent opportunity to expand your knowledge, meet one of the most incredible Harvard professors, and have enough time to read about topics that interest you.

This was a phenomenal class. As a phil concentrator who hadn't really taken a lot of upper level phil courses, I was so engaged throughout the entire semester and felt genuinely interested in a topic I had very little background knowledge of coming in. I will leave this with a nuanced perspective on punishment and criminal justice, and I recommend it to anyone without reservations. The most special part of the class is that almost everyone will do the readings and show up prepared to discuss them which in turn makes conversations really insightful and productive, and Professor Shelby does a great job of guiding discussions. As well, I got really into the topic of my final paper which, if you're taking it for phil 98 requirement like I was, gives you a great opportunity to write  about a topic of your own choosing.
worse_comment: Professor Shelby is such a good professor. He is very knowledgeable about the topic, and allows us to engage with him on a personal level. This course has absolutely changed how I think about punishment. It changed how I approach conversations dealing with punishment, and has really  made me reflect on my own beliefs about prison. Only think I would say is this course is meant for philosophy students and people who have an extensive background in the area. You will struggle if you have not taken courses in the department, because it is quite highly philosophical.

best_comment: I cannot stress this enough: TAKE ANY AND EVERY CLASS WITH PROF. MATHERNE. She is a genius, incredible lecturer, and conversations with her in office hours are invaluable.  I don't even study philosophy, but I wish I did after taking her class. Do not make the mistake I did and wait until your senior year to take a course with her. Take one as early as possible. And then another. And then another. For practical information about this course: One of the reasons why this class was so great, was that everyone was so bought in that class participation was actually very productive, which allowed the 40–person class to feel like a community by March. This class is not a gem. I spent a good amount of my time reading every week, because you are practically reading one Austen book every 2 weeks, on top of philosophy readings. If you are going to take this class, know that you will have to commit to doing all of the readings in order to get the full experience of this course. This is not to scare anyone off – Prof. Matherne is so accessible with explaining philosophy and making it comfortable for anyone, no matter their experience, to participate in class – HOWEVER I would recommend that you do not take this class as a buffer/light workload class during a heavy semester, but as a class you expect to devote about 5–10 hours of intentional reading to each week. The more you have the time to  engage with this course – doing all of the readings, supplemental readings, going to office hours, thinking about it in your free time – the more you will get out of it. You also shouldn't worry about papers. They are very clearly structured for you (similar to other Matherne papers, if you've taken a course before) so that you know exactly what is expected to do well. There are also multiple interesting prompt options, so if you want to avoid writing about the complicated mess of Mansfield Park, you can do that. Final thoughts: This class is for people who wonder, "What makes philosophy, philosophy?" This isn't a phil course where a philosopher's work is reconstructed neatly by the professor, but one where the concept of philosophy is called into question. The project of understanding Austen as a philosopher is very alive and in process, so you may find yourself strongly disagreeing with a lecture from Prof. Matherne, or questioning if Austen is really a philosopher at all. This is the heart of what makes this class great. I was pushed to critically think in ways that I hadn't been these past four years, and you will feel so fulfilled by the end. I also now can say that I've read all 6 Austen novels!
This was a really fantastic graduate level metaphysics class! I enjoyed the relaxed class environment and appreciated studying the way in which metaphysics interacts with other areas of philosophy.

Professor Stanczyk is an attentive and thoughtful instructor. He makes an effort to include participants in discussions and is generous with his time in answering your questions outside of class. I would highly recommend this course.

course_title: Electromagnetism, Circuits, Waves, Optics, and Imaging 001
best_comment: If you are looking at this, you are probably debating whether to take PS3 or AP50B. I'm here to tell you to take PS3! I couldn't be more glad that I decided to take PS3. PS3 has given me the physics knowledge and intuition to approach real world situations and understand them (such as how a wireless charger works). You will leave PS3 with an in–depth understanding on everything from circuits to induced current to light and waves. Don't get me wrong: PS3 can be challenging at times, and its certainly more challenging than AP50B. But the course is still manageable and the course staff are incredibly supportive and passionate. Regardless, what you should understand about PS3 is that it can be a challenging course that will require studying, but that studying will be well rewarded by the scientific knowledge you will gain. The course staff are kind and entertaining (thanks Louis and Steve), and are always interested in making the course better. You are at college to learn right? So, pull the trigger and take PS3 and you won't be disappointed!
worse_comment: Take AP50b if it is possible. Class is not very helpful, it is hit or miss how good your section is helpful. Homework is not too bad but exams are terrible. First one seemed really unfair and it was hard to tell what was and was not on the exam.  I sat down for the final and could not believe I was expected to do things that were not on any practice problems or homework for over half the exam. This is my definitely my least favorite class I have ever taken
best_gem_comment: sneaky hard. definitely harder than ps2. but louis is such a gem and all of the course staff try to make sure you understand what is going on if you just ask.

course_title: Electromagnetism, Circuits, Waves, Optics, and Imaging 001

course_title: Mechanics and Statistical Physics from an Analytic, Numerical and Experimental Perspective 001
best_comment: Okay, so here’s the deal. I took this class coming off of AP Physics 1, and honestly, I wasn’t sure what to expect. I’d learned the basics, but I was looking for something that would push me further without turning into an all–consuming nightmare. Physical Sciences 12a totally delivered on that. It’s not just a repeat of high school physics—it’s a chance to build on what you already know, dive deeper into some cool stuff like fluid mechanics, and leave with a stronger understanding of physics than you walked in with.It’s also just a great course if you want to understand physics but not dive into the deep end. For someone like me, who’s not majoring in physics but needs a solid foundation for engineering, this class was perfectPros:A Real Review That’s Actually Helpful:Coming from AP Physics 1, I thought I knew the basics. Like, I knew how to do some basic mechanics, forces, and energy problems. But when I jumped into 12a, I realized that there’s a level of depth I hadn’t even touched yet. This course didn’t just breeze through what I already knew—it helped me really understand it. Fluid mechanics was a whole new world for me, and I got to see how the math and concepts actually fit together. Honestly, I walked out of this class with a much better grasp of physics than I had going in.Demos & Labs: Total Game Changer:Let’s be real, I didn’t expect the demos to be as entertaining as they were. They were straight–up cool. We didn’t just watch some pendulum swing back and forth—these demos brought the physics to life in ways that made everything feel real. And the labs? They weren’t just a way to pass time. I actually enjoyed them. I got to team up with people, test out theories, and see how physics works in the real world. It wasn’t some dry, boring “let’s just get this done” experience—it was genuinely fun. Plus, the labs were a good way to meet people, so there’s that bonus.Stars System: Not Perfect, But Solid:I was a little skeptical about the Stars system at first, but once I got into it, I saw how it helped me stay on top of the material. The idea is simple: prove you know your stuff, earn a Star. It gives you smaller, more manageable goals to work toward instead of one big exam stress fest. Now, I’m not gonna lie, the Stars system can be intense. If you mess up even a little bit, you miss the Star. But there’s a silver lining: if you miss a Star, you can meet with the course leadership to show that you’ve got a handle on the material. It’s kind of like an insurance policy—you get another shot to prove you know your stuff. This kept me from panicking about exams and helped me focus on actually learning.Incredible Support from the Course Leadership:One of my favorite things about this class was the course leadership. They weren’t just checking boxes—they actually cared that you understood the material. Any time I had a question or felt like I was falling behind, they were there to help. It wasn’t some generic “go to office hours” vibe; they’d actually meet with you one–on–one, break down concepts until they clicked, and make sure you were on the right track. It was refreshing, especially in a course that’s got some heavy material.Confidence Boost Like No Other:Before this course, I felt like I understood physics, but not in the deep way I wanted to. After 12a, though? I felt like I could actually do physics. The new material, like fluid mechanics, was challenging, but the course gave me the tools and understanding to tackle it head–on. By the end of it, I was ready to keep going with physics. If you’ve taken AP Physics 1 or have some basic understanding and are worried about taking that next step, this course will give you the confidence you need to keep pushing forward.Shoutout to the CAs:Alright, let’s talk about problem sets. They’re no joke. But what made them manageable was the support I got from the CAs. Seriously—if you’re struggling, get to office hours. The CAs (NeNe, Rohil, Will, Tyler—you guys are the real MVPs) were always ready to break things down and explain stuff until it clicked. It made those PSets way less stressful, and honestly, I probably wouldn’t have made it through without their help.Cons:9 A.M. = No Fun:We all know how it goes—9 a.m. is way too early for anything. Especially when you’ve been pulling late–night study sessions, dealing with other classes, or just living your life. Getting up for this class felt like an Olympic sport in itself. Don’t let the early start fool you—if you’re not a morning person, prepare to drag yourself out of bed.Stars System (Again):As much as I loved the Stars system, it’s not all sunshine and rainbows. There were times where I felt like the smallest mistake—something minor—would cost me a Star. And that little bit of stress over missing Stars can get to you, especially if you're someone who’s a little on the perfectionist side. It’s a great system in theory, but it can sometimes feel like you're walking a tightrope.Coding Projects (Sigh):Okay, I get it—coding is part of the physics game now, and I see the value of integrating it. But honestly? The coding projects were a bit of a headache. It wasn’t a huge deal since they’re not on the final, but they still felt like extra busywork. They weren’t terrible, just kind of annoying.PSets Are Time–Consuming (But What Else Is New?):Let’s face it—problem sets in any physics class are going to take time. These were no exception. Some weeks, I’d be buried in them for hours. It’s manageable, but if you’ve got a packed schedule, they can start to feel like a never–ending cycle. Again, office hours help, but they do take up a good chunk of your time.
worse_comment: This course teaches more than other introductory physics courses, but the format of the course is terrible. The CS and statistics are not well integrated with the physics.

It was refreshing, especially in a course that’s got some heavy material.Confidence Boost Like No Other:Before this course, I felt like I understood physics, but not in the deep way I wanted to. After 12a, though? I felt like I could actually do physics. The new material, like fluid mechanics, was challenging, but the course gave me the tools and understanding to tackle it head–on. By the end of it, I was ready to keep going with physics. If you’ve taken AP Physics 1 or have some basic understanding and are worried about taking that next step, this course will give you the confidence you need to keep pushing forward.Shoutout to the CAs:Alright, let’s talk about problem sets. They’re no joke. But what made them manageable was the support I got from the CAs. Seriously—if you’re struggling, get to office hours. The CAs (NeNe, Rohil, Will, Tyler—you guys are the real MVPs) were always ready to break things down and explain stuff until it clicked. It made those PSets way less stressful, and honestly, I probably wouldn’t have made it through without their help.Cons:9 A.M. = No Fun:We all know how it goes—9 a.m. is way too early for anything. Especially when you’ve been pulling late–night study sessions, dealing with other classes, or just living your life. Getting up for this class felt like an Olympic sport in itself. Don’t let the early start fool you—if you’re not a morning person, prepare to drag yourself out of bed.Stars System (Again):As much as I loved the Stars system, it’s not all sunshine and rainbows. There were times where I felt like the smallest mistake—something minor—would cost me a Star. And that little bit of stress over missing Stars can get to you, especially if you're someone who’s a little on the perfectionist side. It’s a great system in theory, but it can sometimes feel like you're walking a tightrope.Coding Projects (Sigh):Okay, I get it—coding is part of the physics game now, and I see the value of integrating it. But honestly? The coding projects were a bit of a headache. It wasn’t a huge deal since they’re not on the final, but they still felt like extra busywork. They weren’t terrible, just kind of annoying.PSets Are Time–Consuming (But What Else Is New?):Let’s face it—problem sets in any physics class are going to take time. These were no exception. Some weeks, I’d be buried in them for hours. It’s manageable, but if you’ve got a packed schedule, they can start to feel like a never–ending cycle. Again, office hours help, but they do take up a good chunk of your time.
worse_comment: This course teaches more than other introductory physics courses, but the format of the course is terrible. The CS and statistics are not well integrated with the physics.

course_title: Mechanics and Statistical Physics from an Analytic, Numerical and Experimental Perspective 001
best_comment: Okay, so here’s the deal. I took this class coming off of AP Physics 1, and honestly, I wasn’t sure what to expect. I’d learned the basics, but I was looking for something that would push me further without turning into an all–consuming nightmare. Physical Sciences 12a totally delivered on that. It’s not just a repeat of high school physics—it’s a chance to build on what you already know, dive deeper into some cool stuff like fluid mechanics, and leave with a stronger understanding of physics than you walked in with.It’s also just a great course if you want to understand physics but not dive into the deep end. For someone like me, who’s not majoring in physics but needs a solid foundation for engineering, this class was perfectPros:A Real Review That’s Actually Helpful:Coming from AP Physics 1, I thought I knew the basics. Like, I knew how to do some basic mechanics, forces, and energy problems. But when I jumped into 12a, I realized that there’s a level of depth I hadn’t even touched yet. This course didn’t just breeze through what I already knew—it helped me really understand it. Fluid mechanics was a whole new world for me, and I got to see how the math and concepts actually fit together. Honestly, I walked out of this class with a much better grasp of physics than I had going in.Demos & Labs: Total Game Changer:Let’s be real, I didn’t expect the demos to be as entertaining as they were. They were straight–up cool. We didn’t just watch some pendulum swing back and forth—these demos brought the physics to life in ways that made everything feel real. And the labs? They weren’t just a way to pass time. I actually enjoyed them. I got to team up with people, test out theories, and see how physics works in the real world. It wasn’t some dry, boring “let’s just get this done” experience—it was genuinely fun. Plus, the labs were a good way to meet people, so there’s that bonus.Stars System: Not Perfect, But Solid:I was a little skeptical about the Stars system at first, but once I got into it, I saw how it helped me stay on top of the material. The idea is simple: prove you know your stuff, earn a Star. It gives you smaller, more manageable goals to work toward instead of one big exam stress fest. Now, I’m not gonna lie, the Stars system can be intense. If you mess up even a little bit, you miss the Star. But there’s a silver lining: if you miss a Star, you can meet with the course leadership to show that you’ve got a handle on the material. It’s kind of like an insurance policy—you get another shot to prove you know your stuff. This kept me from panicking about exams and helped me focus on actually learning.Incredible Support from the Course Leadership:One of my favorite things about this class was the course leadership. They weren’t just checking boxes—they actually cared that you understood the material. Any time I had a question or felt like I was falling behind, they were there to help. It wasn’t some generic “go to office hours” vibe; they’d actually meet with you one–on–one, break down concepts until they clicked, and make sure you were on the right track. It was refreshing, especially in a course that’s got some heavy material.Confidence Boost Like No Other:Before this course, I felt like I understood physics, but not in the deep way I wanted to. After 12a, though? I felt like I could actually do physics. The new material, like fluid mechanics, was challenging, but the course gave me the tools and understanding to tackle it head–on. By the end of it, I was ready to keep going with physics. If you’ve taken AP Physics 1 or have some basic understanding and are worried about taking that next step, this course will give you the confidence you need to keep pushing forward.Shoutout to the CAs:Alright, let’s talk about problem sets. They’re no joke. But what made them manageable was the support I got from the CAs. Seriously—if you’re struggling, get to office hours. The CAs (NeNe, Rohil, Will, Tyler—you guys are the real MVPs) were always ready to break things down and explain stuff until it clicked. It made those PSets way less stressful, and honestly, I probably wouldn’t have made it through without their help.Cons:9 A.M. = No Fun:We all know how it goes—9 a.m. is way too early for anything. Especially when you’ve been pulling late–night study sessions, dealing with other classes, or just living your life. Getting up for this class felt like an Olympic sport in itself. Don’t let the early start fool you—if you’re not a morning person, prepare to drag yourself out of bed.Stars System (Again):As much as I loved the Stars system, it’s not all sunshine and rainbows. There were times where I felt like the smallest mistake—something minor—would cost me a Star. And that little bit of stress over missing Stars can get to you, especially if you're someone who’s a little on the perfectionist side. It’s a great system in theory, but it can sometimes feel like you're walking a tightrope.Coding Projects (Sigh):Okay, I get it—coding is part of the physics game now, and I see the value of integrating it. Some weeks, I’d be buried in them for hours. It’s manageable, but if you’ve got a packed schedule, they can start to feel like a never–ending cycle. Again, office hours help, but they do take up a good chunk of your time.

best_comment: PLEASE DEAR STUDENT TAKE THIS CLASS.  If you want an answer to the question "what were your top 5 most favorite classes you took throughout all college?" this should be top 3, if not the first.  This class is MIT's equivalent of "how to build almost everything", and you're not missing out by not taking the MIT version: this is seriously one of the best courses offered here.My background: CS/Econ.  Almost no 'building–hardware' experience but wanted to explore that.You get to work with a small group of people, which I think really adds to the vibe.  The staff and teaching fellows are super fun to hang around and are very easy to ask questions to.  What's kind of funny is that the lab is in the science center (SC 102) and visitors will come by to look in at the work you're doing.  Feels like you're on display, which some may not like, but I actually loved it because it felt cool to show off what you've been working on![What I Learned]The course site essentially describes all of this, but I'll put it here:– Microcontroller programming– CNC Milling (wood, acrylic, foam)– Laser Cutting (wood, acrylic)– Metalwork– Circuitry fundamentals (capacitors, resistors, breadboards)– Inputs/outputs you can attach to the circuit (servos and other actuators, stepper/DC motors, Piezo buzzers, RFID scanners, light displays, and so much more)– Circuit board fabrication (PCBs)– Radio communication (wired, wireless, Bluetooth)[Typical Week]– You'll be given a project to work on Tuesday, then have until the following Thursday to complete it.– If you don't complete it to the level you desire, you're free to redo it or continue on it until the end of the semester, but I advise just moving on and focusing on the next weekly task, then go back to that one at the end, that way you're not feeling lagged behind by any means.– The workload each week is not the same.  Some projects will take longer.  Of all the weeks, I think the heaviest weeks are: kinetic sculpture, radio communication, and machine building (robot machine).  Those weeks take about 10 hours.Again, PLEASE TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU WANNA DO HANDS ON WORK.  This stuff is so fun.  I know I say 10 hours for the worst weeks but honestly it does not even feel like 10 weeks, it's more like "an hour of work here" and "two hours of work there", what's nice is you can basically come in any time with a buddy and they have so many office hours it's quite ridiculous, there's never a shortage of that.  You'll do awesome!!

TAKE IT! TAKE IT! TAKE IT!!!!!! This was the best STEM course I took at Harvard so far. I highly suggest taking 15a instead of 12a if you are truly interested in learning how Physics works. The material is awesome, the lectures are great and the labs are super manageable. I loved it!
worse_comment: This class is not super interesting. I didn't really get an intuition for why these physics concepts occur (which might be my fault, but still). If you are coming to this class out of a curiosity for physics, you should probably take physics 19.

best_comment: Take this course if you really need to satisfy the Electromagnetism requirement. Carlos is a good professor, though their lectures can sometimes leave you desiring a little more. The textbook is honestly not the best in my opinion. I found it more useful for review rather than actually using it to study. Referring to it after completing a problem set and going over lecture notes is honestly more useful, in my opinion. The lab component of this course is also alright. It is a lot better than the mechanics labs we had to do. Office hours and sections will be a must if you struggle a bit in this course. The CAs and TFs will definitely help you get back on track as long as you are willing to put in the effort. As a student who had little to no experience with Electromagnetism (beyond AP physics 2 and what I learned in Physics 19), I'd say the content can be challenging, but it certainly is not difficult at all to grasp once you get some practice in. I don't recommend taking this course as your first physics class, you should take some level of a mechanics course before taking this class. Also, if you feel very confident about your math skills and are considering taking 153 over this course, don't feel afraid to shop it. Though I did not mind my time in 15b, a part of me does wonder if I should have considered shopping 153.  You should be familiar with some multivariable calculus for this class, but it's not essential. I took 22b alongside this course, and honestly, you can get by without having learn multivar/currently in the process of learning it.All in all, this is not a bad course. Some lectures did feel rushed at times, others felt like they didn't go fast enough, but most of the time, the content was taught fairly well, in my opinion. Though Carlos could be confusing at times, it seems like they do care about what they are teaching. They always took questions and did their best to make sure students were engaged and learning.  However, I do feel a little disappointed in the course. As exciting as some of the material could be, it honestly often felt more like math–bashing than actual physics. The class has its moments (especially with the demos done during lecture), but personally, I was hoping for a little more rigor, especially with some of the proofs done in class. I feel like I learned more about how to solve physics problems than actual physics. To summarize, don't feel afraid to shop the course, and it's a decent way to get the Electromagnetism requirement out of the way, and its not a bad introduction to the field, especially if you plan to take Electrodynamics the following spring.
worse_comment: I would say only take this course if you have to. It is a frustrating experience, especially if you have no previous E&M background. The organization of the course was not good, students had to remind through slack that the materials were posted, and this was especially bad close to the exam season. The lectures were not the most effective, even if the material was interesting. The course needs a lot of restructuring, because it is frustrating and hard to take. The exams were not fair taking into account no extra practice materials were provided to understand what was going to appear in the course. E&M is a cool subject, I just wish it was presented better.

best_comment: Take this class to learn a lot about waves and a good bit of math too!  I took 21b concurrently, which is totally doable since most of the necessary math is taught during lecture or can be learned as you do the PSETs.  You also don't need to have taken 15b, although the EM–wave content near the end of the course will probably be easier if you have. Overall, PSETs and exams were very fair and not too painful. Content–wise, the first half was a little dry, but not as hard, while the second half was much more interesting in my opinion but conceptually required more effort. Definitely go to office hours if you have any questions at all about the PSETs, which you probably will because the PSETs did not always align or seem entirely relevant to what we were learning in class, but they were still figure–out–able with office hours and not too long, which was nice. My biggest (and one of my only) complaints about this class is that section could be massively improved. I think it would be better if students were guided through the section problems during section, or, at the very least if they could check their solutions to the section problems against a detailed answer key to make sure they leave section with an understanding of how to do all of the problems. I often left section feeling much more confused than when I arrived because I would leave with a whole list of problems I had no idea how to solve, and solutions would not be posted until over a week after the section. Thankfully, section is optional so you can just skip it if it is as bad as it was this semester! Lab, on the other hand, is not optional, but really not bad at all! Actually pretty fun and there is a lot of support!
worse_comment: u have to take it. just pay attention and don't fall behind. huth's notes are handwritten and hard to follow so I would take this class with morii who has typed notes and provided handouts to follow along each lecture.

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE. . It's my favorite course I've ever had at Harvard. If you're trying to decide, this is your sign. TAKE IT. But on a more serious note, if you're wondering what this course is like, it really is a physicist's math course. It's all about giving you the tools to solve problems. In a typical math course, we learn techniques and kind of problems, but there's a lot of theory and explanation surrounding it. It's not that the course fails to give you a solid theoretical grounding, but it's less concerned with rigor, giving you enough of an intro to understand the motivation behind a formula without exhaustive justification of our methods. But because of this, you can cover SO MUCH. For example, I took Math 113 and learned wonderful things, but in terms of how to solve actual problems in the field, a week of this course taught me 80% of a semester of Math 113. And the math is SO relevant for a physicist. I was taking 143A at the same time and often I'd learn a subject in 106 then have to apply it or derive it in 143A a week later. And the course is really fun. interesting lectures cool problems. In summary the course A. Will teach you a lot. B. Is super relevant to physics. C. Is really fun. TAKEITTAKEITTAKEITTAKEITTAKEIT

This class is a great option to take.  It's heavily lab/building–based, with less emphasis on lectures and assignments, and contains a wide range of interesting content from PID control and Arduino programming to signal processing and filtering techniques.  The grading isn't too stressful either, as the exams also involve a lab/circuit construction component.  Overall, would recommend for anyone interested in laboratory circuitry, general circuitry principles, signal processing basics, Arduino, etc.

If you have a chance, TAKE THIS CLASS.  I can not tell you exactly what you will learn, since the course is improved upon each semester, but I can tell you that it will be fundamentally fascinating. We spent the first half of the semester essentially rederiving linear algebra, and the second rederiving all of the axioms of quantum mechanics, all from base principles with very little prior math knowledge needed. Readings included many paper from the original proposal/formulations of quantum mechanics, and section/OH helped a lot with interpretation, so that prior philosophy knowledge requirements were also minimal. Though I took the course as Phil 151, there was a fairly even distribution of people who took it as a physics course, and one could consistently rely on others who had more experience in either physics or philosophy for perspective. The class is small (30ish people), competitive to get into (because the subject and professor are both well liked by students), and takes all years/levels of experience (everything is self contained/taught within the course). This is also a wonderful class for a more logical/formulaic philosophy experience and a more questions/interpretation–based experience physics. I would definitely recommend attending section/OH if possible, the material is fascinating and teaching staff are very willing to discuss related topics. The course generally follows the professors own formulation of quantum mechanics, has no exams (only a final essay), and has only one pset a week (with a reading section and a very straightforward math section). Overall, I had a wonderful time in this class and would absolutely choose to take it again. I seriously can not overstate how interesting and welcoming this class is!TLDR; Best class, heavily consider taking it

This was an amazing class. If you are considering physics at all, take this!!! Eslam is an amazing professor and he is super kind and super willing to accomodate to each students needs. I have nothing negative to say about this course. Seriously just an amazing class.
worse_comment: I really disliked this class. The lecture style was proof/derivation based and there was no emphasis on building intuition or how to apply concepts to problems. There was no mention of how these concepts are applied/why they matter in the real world. It was entirely demoralizing and a massive time suck. Don't take it if Khalaf teaches it. 21B is definitely required.

best_comment: Physics 153 with Girma is an incredible experience. Although Girma is not the clearest of lecturers, this is compensated by his boundless enthusiasm and love for electrodynamics which he radiates (no EM pun intended) at every lecture! Girma is a very accessible instructor whom you can ask any question without fear of judgment, and it was always a pleasure to attend his office hours during which I gained a lot of physical insight. The subject–matter of the course — electrodynamics — is an extremely beautiful subject, and knowledge and mastery thereof is crucial to any budding theoretical physicist. Unfortunately, we did not cover the entirety of Griffiths in sufficient depth due to temporal constraints — which is a shame — but in future renditions of the course, this can be easily remedied by adding a third lecture every week. In terms of prior background and preparation, 153 is a self–contained course that builds up the theory of classical electrodynamics from scratch, so you really do not need a ton of prior knowledge in EM (contrary to what the course prerequisites might say). That being said, such knowledge is useful insofar as it makes the fast pace of 153 more manageable. Personally, I came into the class with only AP Physics C and physics 19 under my belt and did just fine (incidentally, this just goes to show that physics 16 really is unnecessary for more advanced courses like 153). If you're considering taking 153, my suggestion would be to study chapter 1 of Griffiths over winter break if you have never seen multi–variable calculus before. If you have time, you should also take a look at chapters 2 and 3 just so that you don't get lost in the first few weeks. To end this QGuide, I'd like to give some advice on how to get the most out of 153 during the semester. Besides going to all the lectures, I strongly recommend that you read Griffiths (by read, I mean read it religiously). Due to lack of time, I did not read Griffiths in its entirety, which in hindsight I regret given the phenomenal amount of physical insight that this book contains. I think the best strategy is to read Girma's lecture notes before coming to lecture to get a brief overview of the material that will be covered (otherwise, you will easily get lost, because oftentimes Girma skips a lot of the mathematical steps and refers you to the lecture notes), and then after lecture you can read the corresponding sections/chapters in Griffiths to solidify your understanding. I cannot stress the importance of doing this, because with the take–home format of the exams, it is very easy to get away with fragmented understanding of the material, whereas what you should be aiming for is a robust grasp on electrodynamics. TL;DR: Fantastic course, beautiful material, wonderful instructor. Not a lot of background is required. Just read the first chapter(s) of Griffiths over winter break, and make an effort to read the textbook throughout the semester to get the most out of this course.
worse_comment: I would describe this course as a mathematical methods course for physics. A lot of very bashy problems, but useful and worth taking. I would not recommend taking this course under Girma if you have the choice, he is not a great lecturer. Despite many promises, it was not clear.

best_comment: Nice one.Do not listen to the naysayers in the Q, let me provide you with a defense of this wonderful course. First of all, the teaching staff: Professor Schwartz is deeply passionate about the material and teaching as such. He truly wants you to understand statistical mechanics and how to apply it to whatever interests you. He is also accessible outside of class and will explain concepts to you. He is very knowledgeable in many areas of physics and thus a great teacher for this course. The only criticism I have is that the lectures can be somewhat hard to follow at times due to notation inconsistent with the lecture notes or minor notational mistakes. Further the lectures do not comprehensively cover the lecture notes. This is, however, despite what the naysayers falsely have proclaimed, proclaim in this Q and will proclaim ad infinitum not an issue as you have the SUPERB LECTURE NOTES to rely on. They provide detailed derivations of the material and are more than comprehensive.With regards to assignments, the course is relatively easy. There are weekly PSETS that (once again ignore the naysayers) are easy to do with the lecture notes and support from your friends: ChatGPT and Gemini. Yes you heard correctly: generative AI is allowed and its usage is even encouraged in this glorious class. This is part of professor Schwartz's educational doctrine, which I'm very much in support of. Ample extra credit opportunities (such as tempering chocolate) give you a chance to make up for any minor mistakes that happened. Lastly there is a take–home midterm and final, which by their very nature are easy to do. Overall I'm very happy to have taken the course as a Chemistry major over the alternatives the Chemistry department has to offer. There are no pre–requisites. I have not taken any quantum or any proper mechanics. High–school math and physics is all you need, anything else can be learned along the way. The course covers many interesting topics from the basics of stat. mech. over tedious thermodynamics (my hatred has only increased) to interesting applications in semiconductor physics and astrophysics. Once again do not listen to the overly critical voices in this year's Q. From first–hand knowledge I can attest that many of these naysayers did not read the lecture notes or attend lectures, which indeed causes a challenge in understanding the material.
worse_comment: Very bashy. Unsure if this is just physics as a whole or a problem with this particular class.

best_comment: This course takes a lot of time (8 hours of classes a week ends up feeling much longer than you expect) but is worth it. You'll become comfortable with basic lab techniques and get a feel for doing data analysis and writing papers. Joe and Jieping will be your best friends at the end of the semester. 2 very important recommendations: make sure to come into the class with a lab partner that you know you work well with, and always start the papers early – they take a LOT of time.

course_title: Introduction to Quantum Materials and Devices 001
best_comment: This is a great class where you learn a lot about many topics in condensed matter. It's especially great if you want to learn more about experimental condensed matter. Professor Westervelt is great and the guest speakers are amazing!

This course is a good way to fulfill the Stat Mech requirement. The teaching staff is great — Prof Nelson and Richard are so kind, and Richard's sections are super excellent.  The midterm was quite challenging, and the final exam was even more challenging, so those are definitely the toughest parts of the course, but the psets were totally manageable, and the class overall was great.

This was the greatest course I've taken, or will ever take, at Harvard. Jordan has set the new standard for teaching 210, par excellence. His deep understanding of general relativity, combined with his philosophical perspective, created a class where I did not merely learn how to compute a bunch of metrics, but to ponder the deep mystery of space and time. Jordan declared his thesis statement at the beginning of the first lecture: Einstein's theory of general relativity gives the definitive explanation of the nature of space and time, a question which had provoked thought for millennia. He developed this thesis throughout the semester. It is my understanding that by the end of February we had covered what past renditions of 210 take the entire semester to do. Despite this, Jordan's lectures felt appropriately paced and incredibly insightful.I especially appreciate how the second half of the course was devoted to topics and applications in GR. Jordan's conjuring of the Ghosts of Universes Past, Present, and Yet–to–Come in the series on cosmology was particularly beautiful. The final lecture may have been the greatest of them all. What I will remember most from this course are the parting words Jordan left for us at the end of the final class. He shared two quotes, one from Einstein and another from Wittgenstein, which were a fitting chiasmus to his opening remarks at the start of the semester. General relativity provides an outlet for wonder more than anything else. It is a theory of singular beauty, yet one which retains a quality bordering on the mystical a century after its inception. That space and time so desperately want to be equals yet are forever distinguished by a single minus sign really makes you wonder. The curvature of spacetime flies in the face of common intuition. Plato writes that what distinguishes knowledge from mere belief is the ability to peer into the realm of Forms and see the underlying, unchanging nature of things. This class teaches you knowledge of the real nature of space, time, matter, and indeed the universe itself. I looked forward to this class every Monday and Wednesday, and hope to cross paths with Jordan again in the future, if our world lines intersect. The Physics Department has done a great job at hiring new faculty in the past few years. It would be a honest shame, and Harvard's loss, if they can't keep Jordan around.

course_title: Introduction to Classical and Quantum Black Holes 001
best_comment: Take it! Strominger is a great lecturer, you'll finally understand BHI colloquia by the end of it, and psets are hard but interesting. Ahmed is also super open to questions and good at explaining.

Physics 212 is one of the most useful classes I've taken. It didn't just teach us theory; it also taught us how to apply what we know in research projects. There are also pretty cool statistics and their applications in cosmology. The first half of the semester involved weekly PSets which were pretty chill. I've definitely had harder PSet classes before. However, I think the main challenge of this course is the final project at the end. You have to put a lot of work to make something worth sharing in the span of 4–5 weeks. Cora and Prish were extremely helpful though! You basically get feedback from experts in the field which pushes you to grow a lot as a researcher. Overall this class was very fulfilling and it's one of those classes I would regret not taking.

Going to office hours and interacting with teaching staffs and peers are very helpful. Take detailed notes and make sure you understand/remember the derivation, even though derivation is not emphasized in the class.

230 has some really interesting material and could be enjoyed by somebody who puts the time in. Lectures are three hours long on fridays and are entirely chalk talks with some pretty in depth derivations. Problem sets are very bashy but sometimes interesting and are always quite long. Final projects are fun.
worse_comment: The goal of active matter is to find emergent behavior in systems with external energy input, kind of like temperature as an emergent property of quantum mechanical systems with lots of particles. The interesting part is how you handle external energy inputs, which takes the problem away from traditional stat mech and leads to interesting SDEs, fluid mechanics, and high (4th, often) order nonlinear PDEs. The problem sets are essentially linear stability analysis over and over on different biologically–relevant systems, which can be tedious but worth doing if your research is on these higher order equations. You get out of this course what you put in; you might learn some rote mathematics if you only do problem sets, but the lectures are necessary to really understand why the problems matter.

best_comment: Jackson is a hard book, but this class is overall manageable and Sonia does a great job of lecturing. Overall very reasonable.

This course takes a lot of time (8 hours of classes a week ends up feeling much longer than you expect) but is worth it. You'll become comfortable with basic lab techniques and get a feel for doing data analysis and writing papers. Joe and Jieping will be your best friends at the end of the semester. 2 very important recommendations: make sure to come into the class with a lab partner that you know you work well with, and always start the papers early – they take a LOT of time.

This was a great class. Vishwanath is a fantastic lecturer and very willing to answer questions. I found the pacing a lot calmer than 251a, but the material we covered (especially quantum information) was still very fascinating. The lecture notes were a real highlight of the course for me; they were very organized and worked through the material thoroughly. Would definitely recommend taking this class!
worse_comment: The first unit on quantum computing was neat. After that the class became rather dull as we covered various methods in perturbation theory and scattering. The problem sets are straightforward, the in class midterm was very easy, and the take home final was more annoying than difficult. The lecture notes are very detailed, which is nice. Overall, 251b is a lot of nuts and bolts stuff every physicist should see at least once, but it's not the most exciting material in the world.

best_comment: The details of this course will probably vary a lot depending on the professor teaching it. However, I imagine broad similarities will remain––namely, this course is going to be more difficult than 253a by a good margin, and you will understand less than you did in 253a by a good margin. However, I found that by the end of 253b, I definitely understood some of the material in 253a a lot better, so you get that I guess. We had biweekly problem sets this year, but don't let that fool you into thinking that this course is not much work––the problem sets were sometimes devilishly difficult, and took us countless hours to solve. The final presentations were fun and good way to finish this kind of course. If you are going into theory/want to develop a good understanding of QFT, you should definitely take this course, and there aren't many alternatives, but know what you're getting into when you enroll.

I thought this class is great in terms of content; however, I would caution students on taking a course in quantum info before this one as it is very fast–paced and foundational concepts are not covered in detail.  This class is the theoretical CS version of quantum info and a strong background in linear algebra and modular arithmetic would be helpful to have. Overall, this class did not take too much time out of my schedule and I thought the concepts and topics were pretty interesting!
worse_comment: Come prepared with questions to class if you have been confused about a topic, even if it’s from previous lectures.

course_title: Statistical Mechanics of Spin Glasses and Neural Networks 001
Modern Atomic and Optical Physics I 001
best_comment: This course is amazing for people with strong background in quantum mechanics who wish to learn more about AMO. Yelin is flexible and very kind as a teacher, and the teaching staff was also wonderful. I'd say that the course is structured in a very manageable way despite the difficulty of the material.

Great course. Prof. Ham is a great lecturer, it's clear he cares a lot, puts a lot of effort into his presentation of the material. Very relevant to modern condensed matter, covers material at a very comfortable pace –– not too slow or too fast. Was a lot of fun, highly recommend.

course_title: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: This class is SO great. I made so much progress on my manuscript, and I learned a ton about how to write a good scientific paper. Beyond just the paper, I grew as a person and a scientist. Suzanne and Jenny are great professors for this class, and the students in the class are wonderful and open about their struggles and experiences as we all wrote papers together. I couldn't recommend it more!

course_title: Quantitative Research Methods in Population Health Sciences II 001
best_comment: Use your resources! Use your professor and TF office hours, ask questions as they come up, be proactive, USE A TUTOR and ask them questions if you want more one–on–one help

course_title: Quantitative Research Methods in Population Health Sciences II 001

People say this course is worse in the Spring, but I actually really enjoyed Prof. Pinker's lectures. He was by far my most interesting lecturer this year. I recommend attending lectures, it just helped with my buy–in for the course but they do upload recordings before the midterm and final, respectively. I attended every lecture and section and don't regret it – If you do that and do basic route memorization before each assessment, you'll end with an A.My foolproof way of studying before the midterm and final was going over the relevant lecture study questions (they're reused in the FRQs) and then just hand writing down terms I didn't feel familiar with over and over again until I memorized them. People told me this was worse in the Spring but I found the format super straightforward and doable. The most hours I put into this course was only the 2 days leading up to the midterm or final (6 hrs studying combined in the respective 2ish days leading up to the exam) and then the biggest time sink by far was the 10 page research paper, which I did very late (don't recommend) – took 8–9 hours in 2.5ish days.
worse_comment: The exams will be very difficult, and if you don't enjoy a lecture style class, you might not enjoy the course overall. However, the base knowledge in psychology I got from it was incredibly helpful.

best_comment: People say this course is worse in the Spring, but I actually really enjoyed Prof. Pinker's lectures. He was by far my most interesting lecturer this year. best_comment: Definitely one of the more challenging foundational psych classes available but also one of the most fulfilling if you enjoy academic rigor and learning new things. I would honestly say this is one of the more difficult non–PSET classes I've taken overall as a student at Harvard simply because of the depth and technical details of the materials we learn as it is a bit neuroscience heavy at the start of the course–– but this is not to say at all that I would not recommend the course. As someone who enjoys an easier class here and there, I would still recommend this class to any psych student interested in cognition / language acquisition because I honestly learned so so much in this course that I don't think I would have been able to get in such depth elsewhere in the courses I've already taken. Absolutely fantastic class and the structure/organization is so clear and upfront. I absolutely applaud Dr. B and Srijani (one of my fav TFs of all time!) for their hard work this semester. I have honestly never seen a TF work harder than Srijani. Love them both! They are also both very fair and empathetic educators, which makes me respect this course even more. They are understanding of any unique circumstances you face while ensuring they accommodate you in a fair manner for all students in the course. This course has transformed the way I perceive everything in my everyday life and I highly recommend if you have the bandwidth to put in the effort and learn!

this is an amazing class! as someone who has been planning on going into clinical psych since before college, I was excited to finally be able to take this class once the spring semester started, but I recommend this to anyone interested in psychology and anyone in general as well since you learn a lot about mental illness, which is something that affects all of us in one way or another! Dr. Shingleton is an amazing professor and the TFs are all great, and we had some great guest speakers particularly with Dr. Abigail Judge, so this class does a great job at drawing in other sources of outside knowledge! The actual assignments are fairly straightforward, the CI submission each week are easy and not time consuming at all, and the midterms are more chill than I was expecting as long as you use their key concepts and terms guides. The memoir responses are interesting as well and not very complicated, just make sure you note down page numbers for examples of each question as you read so you save time later on.
worse_comment: I think that there were a few things that I was dissatisfied with from just like a how–should–we–approach–and–talk–about–psychology perspective, but as a course I don't think there are any standout issues.
best_gem_comment: This course is truly a gem. If you are interested in psychology, take this course. I loved attending lecture and section. The tests are very fair. It's a lot of memorization but if you studying, you will find the exams to be very easy. Another bigger aspect of you grade is the memoirs and papers. The memoirs are honestly so interesting. I loved this course. Dr. Shingleton and the rest of the teaching staff is amazing. They are so approachable and helpful.

course_title: Contemporary Issues in Psychology: Intensive Cross-level Analyses 001
best_comment: I absolutely loved my Sophomore Tutorial! Your experience depends a lot on how engaged other people are in the section, as well as who teaches your section. I was lucky on both counts, the people in my section were very engaged and contributed to discussions in a valuable manner. The person teaching my section, Jada, was an absolutely wonderful TF and a great person in general. I absolutely appreciated all of the diversity in the materials she included in the syllabus, as well as how she centered some discussions around her own work. The work she does on stigma is also very related to my interests and I will actually be working with her this summer!

course_title: Contemporary Issues in Psychology: Intensive Cross-level Analyses for Cog Neuro and Evo Psych 001
best_comment: PSY 975 is a requirement for the CNEP concentration. Pray you have a solid instructor who sets a firm but kind tone for the class and gives timely feedback. Regardless, it is a great deal of work (writing intensive!), so buckle up.
worse_comment: Do not take this course. It made me want to not concentrate in CNEP.First, the instructor is very hostile. She would constantly target one student and would argue with a student in front of the rest of the class until she got it her way. She also would refuse to change her very unfair grading, never communicate assignment expectations beforehand, was very unapproachable, etc. She used AI to generate feedback on assignments and made it very difficult to ask for help. The class discussions were fun because of the other students. However, she would cut off discussions and not let students ask questions whenever she felt like it. However, she would waste time on things that were so minute just because she didn't want to "lose the argument." Second, the grading is incredibly harsh. We had rubrics for assignments, but they were so broad. She also refused to give us an annotated rubric that marked where we got points taken off, which made it so difficult to know what to improve on. We also never received grades for the majority of the assignments we submitted, so you will never know where you stand grade–wise as she never returned anything. The feedback on assignments was basically the bare minimum, and for the final essay, she gave us our feedback a couple days before the deadline. When we had asked for our feedback on our drafts before it was due, she said, "I don't know if I can get it back to you before the final draft deadline, but I guess I can try. I will let you know," which is just ridiculous. Third, you will never feel that you are improving because (1) you don't get grades back on 75% of your work, (2) you barely get any feedback, (3) her grading (if we do get it back) is unnecessarily harsh, (4) she barely tells you what you are doing wrong, (4) she plays favorites, etc. The instructor truly does not care about the students in the course, and you can tell.All in all, I dreaded coming to this class and it made me rethink my concentration. I realize that it is all due to the instructor and not the subject itself, so I stuck with it. But you shouldn't have to feel this way so please, for your mental health and GPA, do not take this course. The instructor will make you feel stupid, attempt to embarrass you in front of your peers, make you cry over the lack of feedback, etc. Run away.If you really want to be a psych concentrator, take 971 and not 975. I heard it's nice over there because the grading is reasonable, you actually learn, and the instructors don't make you feel like dropping out.

best_comment: This is an excellent and super interesting course! Course content and material is the strength of this class, and Professor Davis's enthusiasm makes every class engaging.
worse_comment: I was not satisfied with this class. Dr. Davis has certain views, which she imposes upon the class. Her lectures are long tirades about material that is irrelevant to the readings, giving the appearance that she is often unprepared for class and is just "freestyling" it. She often complains about how much other stuff she had to do as an excuse for her inability to return assignments on–time. She is often three to four assignments behind in terms of grading, meaning students don't receive the feedback they need to improve on their future work. The readings are unnecessarily long compared to the amount of time she spends engaging with them. The mock trial is a cool concept but isn't very successfully implemented. That said, it's not a ton of work as a class.

best_comment: This is an excellent and super interesting course! Course content and material is the strength of this class, and Professor Davis's enthusiasm makes every class engaging.
worse_comment: I was not satisfied with this class. Dr. Davis has certain views, which she imposes upon the class. Her lectures are long tirades about material that is irrelevant to the readings, giving the appearance that she is often unprepared for class and is just "freestyling" it. That said, it's not a ton of work as a class.

best_comment: I LOVED this course! It's a fantastic way to learn about different mental health treatments and particularly how different techniques are employed by clinical psychologists. Lectures were always so interesting, with a solid mix of open discussion, group turn–and–talk, and listening. Each class opened with a mindfulness activity which was really enjoyable (and educational), we got to hear from some featured speakers, and lots of the slideshows included engaging video examples of psychologists working with patients. Prof Santucci is phenomenal. She creates a safe space for discussion, asks great questions that make us think, and delivers the content in really accessible ways. Her kindness and compassion in her teaching made all the difference, too. Workload–wise, she kept assignments to a minimum; this class is really feasible while still feeling like you're getting the most out of your learning. The final presentation/paper are very open–ended (picking any everyday behavior to treat), so personalize it and have fun with it!
