This was a pretty solid course, especially for its first year being offered. I really appreciated how flexible the professor was and how responsive he was to student feedback (seriously, Prof. Knutsen was awesome and so understanding!!). The guest lectures were engaging and easily one of the best parts of the class. I also really liked the anti–stigma campaign proposal project. It felt meaningful and gave us a chance to apply what we were learning. As for cons, the class felt a bit dry at times. The readings toward the end of the semester became repetitive and less interesting. It did not feel like we explored many new or challenging topics in the emerging field, and there was not much critical discussion about the material. This is not entirely the professor's fault, as this seems to be a common issue across most courses in the psych department. Seminars often lack deeper intellectual engagement or space for real dialogue. There was also a lot of time spent on lecturing. While I understand that some students requested this format early on, I personally found it ineffective. It took time away from discussion and made class feel more passive. Discussions themselves were usually slow, and it seemed difficult for the professor to get students to engage.  Still, I think the topic is interesting and the professor is committed to improving the course, so with a few changes, I'm sure this class will become much more engaging and effective in the future.

This was a pretty solid course, especially for its first year being offered. I really appreciated how flexible the professor was and how responsive he was to student feedback (seriously, Prof. Knutsen was awesome and so understanding!!). The guest lectures were engaging and easily one of the best parts of the class. I also really liked the anti–stigma campaign proposal project. It felt meaningful and gave us a chance to apply what we were learning. As for cons, the class felt a bit dry at times. The readings toward the end of the semester became repetitive and less interesting. It did not feel like we explored many new or challenging topics in the emerging field, and there was not much critical discussion about the material. This is not entirely the professor's fault, as this seems to be a common issue across most courses in the psych department. Seminars often lack deeper intellectual engagement or space for real dialogue. There was also a lot of time spent on lecturing. While I understand that some students requested this format early on, I personally found it ineffective. It took time away from discussion and made class feel more passive. Discussions themselves were usually slow, and it seemed difficult for the professor to get students to engage.  Still, I think the topic is interesting and the professor is committed to improving the course, so with a few changes, I'm sure this class will become much more engaging and effective in the future.

I highly recommend this course for any student interested in better understanding gender dynamics and women’s experience through a psychological lens. At times the class is a lot of work, but the community and quality of instruction absolutely make it worth it! Dr. Noll is truly one of the most kind, thoughtful, and engaging professors I have had in all my time at Harvard.

course_title: Stress & Cognition: Implications for Empowered Learning 001
best_comment: Nancy is a great prof and very caring about her students. The class gets along super well and we have had such a great semester together. There is very little stressful work throughout the semester and Nancy is super accomodating to any issues a student may face during the semester. if you want to know more about anxiety and performance, and you want a relaxed elective – this is for you.

course_title: Fact or Fiction? Mythbusting Pseudoscience in Psychology 001
best_comment: This course was fantastic from start to finish! It's very well organized and straightforward. The professor is wonderful and very approachable. The course expectations are clear. Discussions were excellent and illuminating. There is a fair bit of group work and presenting that was actually a big plus for the class. It felt like a graduate level class. Highly recommend!
best_gem_comment: GEM!! HIGHLY RECOMMEND!! prof singh is a wonderful lecturer and is so knowledgable. the class is super interesting + fun and teaches you a lot abt pseudoscienceassignments: short and easy:) as long as u follow the prompt and rubric (like every other class) you'll get a good gradefinal group project: there's no need to stress abt the final group project –– prof assigns your groups (based on a previous assignment) and gives you plenty of time to work of them in–class

course_title: The Mind-Body Connection: Exploring the Intersection between Psychology and Physical Health 001
best_comment: Hello chat, this class was pretty good. I would recommend it if you want a class that helps you discuss about relationship between the mind and the body. The relationship is evident and in this course we really discuss about that and how we see it in our daily lives. The workload is reasonable. Dr. Mark Blanchard is also very accessible. I was engaged the whole time throughout the course and I really enjoyed the special guest because it allowed me to learn about a subfield of psychology that I never considered until then. I will say to study for the quizzes to do well, but they are moderately okay. Some of the articles were very science–related but he went over them over lecture so that was helpful. The readings findings were very interesting though, I am glad in regards to what he chose for us to read. I am also glad he took into considerations our student feedback because he made the course more engaging with active discussions, which helped with my learning. This course great overall.

Tanya is the best professor! She is super knowledgeable and passionate about the subject and about teaching, and she is also super flexible and kind and really cares about students understanding the material more than being tested!

The course content is very interesting but felt a bit dry at times. But I loved the assignments, a lot of room to explore things that interest you: e.g. we had to go watch a sports event/live performance and write about it! also the quizzes were pretty fair, i would not label them as quizzes though that was a bit misleading on the first one, it's definitely an exam and you have to prepare a decent amount. If you take notes in lecture and skim the abstracts of the readings then you are set. I would highly recommend the class, there is no section and most of the assignments are open to write about whatever you please! The professor is also super kind and willing to answer any questions you may have and give helpful suggestions on the assignments.

This is an amazing course! Chloe is a fantastic lecturer, and this is easily one of the courses that I've enjoyed most as a graduating senior. I would 100% recommend this course to anyone (PSY or non–PSY) who is interested at all in drugs, addiction, pharmacology, or anything to do with psychology. If you've ever read PIHKAL, imagine that, but taught through a super amazing lecturer. 1000% RECOMMEND!!
best_gem_comment: GEM!!! prof chloe is such a great lecturer and the topic matter is super interesting. it does get a little neuro–y at times but nothing goes unexplained. the weekly quizzes are easy as long as you go to class and pay attention to lecturethe 3 papers are a little different from your usual psych papers, so they were fun and easy to write

best_comment: I highly recommend this class! It had great discussions and various perspectives to addressing culture. Great psych elective to take.

I loved this class. It is definitely a lot of dense readings, but I think over the semester it teaches you how to engage and efficiently read primary literature. Sometimes it seems daunting, but once you go to lecture Randy does a great job teaching. I found myself really engaged throughout the 2 hour lecture. The assignments can be nerve–racking and there are some in–class quizzes, but if you go to office hours and/or book times to meet with Randy or Emma, they are super helpful. I think you get what you put into this class.
worse_comment: All undergrads, please listen: be very careful with this class. Only take if you are very experienced with neuroscience. There are many postdocs, grad students, etc. in this class, despite it being offered in FAS as an undergrad course. If professor disagrees with topic, student is given poor grade.The class lacks any structure for assignments:– Doesn’t give page length for several papers, or any guidance on assignment; student can meet with professor to gain clarity, but this is not acceptable;– No rubric for paper or how grading would be conducted, along with no structure given about assignments in syllabus;– The final paper is due BEFORE reading period which collides with many undergrad students' midterms, which is literally against the rules by the dean.

course_title: Decisions Big and Small: The Cognitive Science of Making Up Your Mind 001
best_comment: This is the best class I took at Harvard. The professor is EXCELLENT. His lectures are engaging and inspiring. He knows a lot about the topic and is very organized, his lectures are structured and very interesting and interactive. The topics are great – it covers everything about decision–making. This class really changed my way of thinking. I would STRONGLY recommend that anyone who is interested in decision–making takes this course. Professor Ullman is the best, his class is more complete and deep than many HKS and graduate courses I took about decision–making. The course work is easy and the final project is really fun because you can choose what you want to do (movie, song, paper, etc.). This class is just one of the most inspiring I ever took and Prof. Ullman one of the best and smartest people I have met.

Take take take! This course topic is so interesting, the assignments were all fair, and Dr. Phelps is a wonderful, accommodating teacher. There are four essays, each about 2–3 pages, and they can be revised based on Dr. Phelps' feedback. The final project is creative (I made a video, lots of people made podcasts or presentations), which is super fun and made me even more engaged in my topic. You read papers for each class, and then get to hear from the first authors as guest speakers during class, which was a super cool opportunity. Highly recommend!

i really enjoyed this course. professor vu is wonderful. lots of super interesting readings, class discussions, and takeaways that i can apply to my every day life. i took the happiness gened and would recommend this class to anyone interested in those kind of topics.

course_title: Safeguarding the Self: Groups, Identity, and Psychology of Self-Defense 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Honestly feels like we just get to talk about things and share life experience all the time. The workload isn't bad because Prof. Vu gives you feedback on the essays before submitting and the rest is just making sure you do the discussion posts. As long as you keep up with it you'll be fine. There are also 2 extra credit opportunities as well. Prof. Vu is also really sweet and cares about the topic. Honestly, as long as you show up prepared and ready to talk you're gonna have a lot of fun in this class.

course_title: Family, School, and Society: Shaping the Developing Child 001
best_comment: This class is fantastic. It provides a deep dive into how different environmental factors influence the development of the child, and it emphasizes how interactions between these factors have different effects. Professor Lewin–Bizan is an incredible and kind, compassionate professor and makes the class very welcoming and open for discussion, even on hard topics. The class was also very enjoyable, as we had cool lectures  and discussions. I enjoyed the book presentation the most. For the book club midterm, my assigned book was one of the best books I’ve read and provided really interesting insights into foster care and child psychology more broadly. If you’re at all interested in child development, the role of social/systemic support networks, and/or parenting, then this class will be especially enjoyable and interesting for you!! I think everyone should take this class and can take something away that’s useful and applicable to everyday life.

course_title: Little Choices, Big Consequences: The Developmental Foundations of Choice 001
best_comment: Unfortunately, Shalini is leaving, but she was the absolute best. The concepts in this course are fundamental to how we make decisions, and understanding their development is also crucial. I'm hoping to apply what I know now into my own personal life. As far as the content goes, you'll learn interesting things like counterfactual thinking, theory of mind, free will, and episodic thought. Overall, a great class, not too much work, and you get out what you put in.

course_title: Mental Time Travel and the Human Mind 001
best_comment: This class was incredibly interesting! The discussions are very in–depth and enlightening. Dr. Gautam is very kind and compassionate, provides interesting lectures and discussions, and has a very impressive background! I would take this class if you can.

AMAZING CLASS! BEST CLASS I HAVE TAKEN HERE SO FAR. Very easy to do well –– the assignments are straightforward with rubrics provided, the instructor is very available to meet and provide support or feedback, assignments and exams directly relate to what is being learned in class. Just pay attention in class (and do readings for extra knowledge), do the assignments, participate in section, and review the notes before the exam and you will do absolutely amazing in this course.

This is a super fun course! Ryan is very chill and friendly, and the class size is small so there are lots of chances for interaction/participation, which made the learning better. He's really organized on Canvas, so all the slides, assignments, and readings are already organized into modules at the start of the semester (chances to get ahead). One fun thing is you get to take different personality tests throughout the semester and compare them. The reading assignments help to make reading dense papers easier, then you discuss them in class. Ryan is funny and shows fun videos during class as well to supplement the slides. It's not a difficult class, and the exam is open book online. So the course is really what you make of it. I recommend asking lots of questions and talking to Ryan after classes to learn more about the material. He definitely is well–versed in the field. Take this course!!

course_title: Situational Superpowers: Investigating Interactions between People and Contexts 001
best_comment: PSY 1711 is a fun discussion–based course, and Ryan is a great professor. A different student leads classroom discussion every week, and it was a fun way to learn the material. Ryan is clearly very passionate about personality psychology, which added to the energy of the class!

This class is super interesting. Definitely not super work intensive, but Professor McNally has a great wealth of clinical experiences and adds awesome anecdotes to all of the content covered. A great class to take if at all interested in the topic. There is a lot of content, but the exams are very fair and I feel like I took a lot away from my experience in this class.

This was an awesome course! The workload was super manageable and the lectures were interactive and highly rewarding. Sometimes you walk away from a class with just a few takeaways, but with PSY 1814, I feel like I have built a strong foundation in understanding how trauma and PTSD present and are treated. Nick is great and is an entertaining lecturer – highly recommend!

course_title: Broken Brains: Mechanisms and Markers of Mental Illness 001
best_comment: Professor Piccolo is a delight! He generates excitement about the topics and creates a really open learning space where students help lead the discussions. We're able to learn a lot from each other in this course –– especially because students have the opportunity to teach the class for one week. You get to learn about different mental illnesses of focus each week; the class emphasizes some underlying neuroscience, but there's also a lot of discussion about wider social connections and human experiences. The larger assignments will take a good amount of effort, but they're paced out well enough that by finals period, you'll likely have nothing to worry about. A very feasible and enjoyable class!

course_title: Introduction to Statistics for the Behavioral Sciences 001
best_comment: Hey chat, there is going to be a new professor so I don't know how helpful this description may be. The course was okay. The weekly PSETs were not bad. I got a decent score on them and I went to office hours to ensure I actually understood what I coded. This year they added oral exams to ensure we were learning but they were highkey scary. However, I think most people did okay. There are a lot of opportunities to improve your grade in the course though so that was okay. I was able to show that I am actually learning and improving in the course. The project aspect is nice. We get to basically apply all the skills we learned throughout the year and present a research project for others to see. Grace was really understanding and willing to help anyone understand topics. She was extremely kind and welcoming, wanting to get to know every student in her class. Hopefully, her life post teaching PSY 1900 is great!
worse_comment: the first two units are fine but once you get to the third unit, your grades start to drop because the content gets a lot more difficult and overall the class has a lot of busy work.  the class is not as easy as people say.
best_gem_comment: This class is a pre–med req gem because you can get a good grade with the extra credit.

best_comment: It was good. you don't learn all that much but you have to take it. Midterm was chill, average was like a 85 but she bumped it up to like a 89. So super chill. Don't even sweat. Also minimal class time, which is great. Super great time.

course_title: Applied Statistical Data Analysis in Psychology II 001
best_comment: You should definitely take this course. It introduces state–of–the–art statistical techniques that are only going to become more important in psychology. Patrick is a fantastic instructor—you’d be very lucky to learn from him.

Coming into the semester, I did not have much experience with developmental psychology specifically, but the people in the lab met me where I was at, and I was able to learn a lot in the process. It's been a great first–hand experience at research and I would definitely recommend taking this course!! The people in the lab alone are great and on top of that it's a great experience with psychological research!

This is the easiest psych class out there. You literally do no work except write a paper at the end which is so chill and you're basically guaranteed to get an A on. Dr. McNally is also a very funny guy. If you want to do actual research, you'll need to ask for it in this class, or take a different lab class, but if you also just want an easy class where you do no work, join this lab. It's fire.

course_title: Laboratory Research on the Biopsychosocial Effects of Stigma 001
best_comment: love the topic, lab members, and research—would always recommend.
This is a class everyone should be required to take. Take this class to improve your writing and feel competent about writing research reports and grants.

course_title: Introduction to Quantum Information Science I 001
best_comment: I thought this class is great in terms of content; however, I would caution students on taking a course in quantum info before this one as it is very fast–paced and foundational concepts are not covered in detail.  This class is the theoretical CS version of quantum info and a strong background in linear algebra and modular arithmetic would be helpful to have. Overall, this class did not take too much time out of my schedule and I thought the concepts and topics were pretty interesting!
worse_comment: Come prepared with questions to class if you have been confused about a topic, even if it’s from previous lectures.

course_title: Quantum and Classical Electromagnetic Interaction with Matter 001
best_comment: Take the class if you want to learn the basics of AMO physics, and want to be on track to take a more advanced courses in AMO.

Beautiful and rigorous deep dive into modern electronic structure theory. Professor Lee is such an amazing and engaging lecturer, and for each class skillfully weaves physical intuition, mathematical rigour, and computational insight in a way that makes even the most abstract ideas feel tangible.  A special shoutout to TF Jinghong Zhang, who through every single section brought absolute clarity to all course materials. Consistently the highlight of my week, carefully constructed, conceptually elegant, and often more enlightening than any textbooks. His teaching elevated the entire experience and is truly the gold standard for a TF. Amazing course offering with no counterpart at MIT. For any cross–registering MIT students and absolutely for Harvard students, if you are interested in development for any production–level electronic structure code, this class is a MUST–TAKE. However, the difficulty of this class cannot be understated, especially towards the end for the final project, where you will get hands–on experience benchmarking real quantum chemistry methods with the legendary software Q–Chem.  The workload ramps up quickly, and the conceptual load is heavy, but the intellectual reward is immense. You’ll walk away not just understanding modern electronic structure theory, but truly thinking like a quantum chemist.

I highly recommend this class for anyone who wants to learn about state–of–the art qubit platforms. And as compared to 260, this is more relaxed and takes a hardware–focused approach. The workload is quite manageable. You get to learn from a professor who is extremely up–to–date on the field as well as an impressive set of guest lecturers who work on different platforms.The lectures are fast–paced confusing, though because the class tries to cover an immense amount of material, and it doesn't help that Giulia generally doesn't provide lecture notes or any supporting material.

Great course. Prof. Ham is a great lecturer, it's clear he cares a lot, puts a lot of effort into his presentation of the material. Very relevant to modern condensed matter, covers material at a very comfortable pace –– not too slow or too fast. Was a lot of fun, highly recommend.

This class will do so much for you, not only academically, but also encourage personal growth. I feel like many of the readings had me think about how I would intentionally like to engage with the Western medical system. The various texts talking about Pacific Indigenous approaches to well–being demonstrated care that recognizes the humanity and dignity of a person. It was particularly the section on motherhood that caused me to reflect on how my mother was treated in American hospitals and how I would like to be treated when the time comes for me to have babies.

This is a great class!! I loved discussing ethical issues from a Christian perspective, especially with such a wide variety of students and it was different from the conversations I usually have with my (Christian and non–Christian) friends. I appreciated how tolerant and thoughtful everyone in this class is. Many different perspectives were brough to the table and carefully considered, whether we agreed or disagreed. Everyone was also so friendly, an added benefit!I would 100% recommend this class to anybody, it's definitely my favorite class that I've taken here

TAKE THIS COURSE! I know it's optional for secondaries but you would do yourself an injustice by not taking this class. It's an absolute gold mine. You'll meet really amazing people with such niche interests and you'll have a blast talking to them about religion. Tbh I was scared about this class because I didn't think I was interested enough to do well. But turns out I liked it way more than I thought I would. It's a great course, the reading material is great, and Dr. Lamberth is so passionate and wonderful. She is so knowledgeable and excited and it's so fun to talk for hours with her and your peers every week.

course_title: The Conduct of Life in Western and Eastern Philosophy 1
best_comment: Professors Unger and Puett are absolutely amazing, and I really think everyone should take one of their classes at least once. I came into class without a background in philosophy, but they explained concepts so interestingly and powerfully and were very supportive of all students' learning. Essays were very reasonable and a joy to write and think deeply about. This class truly transformed my perspective on the conduct of everyday life and introduced me to so many fascinating Western and Eastern philosophers I will have to read more about in the future.
best_gem_comment: This course changed my life for the better and I am forever grateful. One of the most important decisions I made as an undergraduate was taking this course. Professor Puett is an absolute gem––– equal parts brilliant, kind, and open minded.

course_title: The Conduct of Life in Western and Eastern Philosophy 1
best_comment: Professors Unger and Puett are absolutely amazing, and I really think everyone should take one of their classes at least once. I came into class without a background in philosophy, but they explained concepts so interestingly and powerfully and were very supportive of all students' learning. Essays were very reasonable and a joy to write and think deeply about. This class truly transformed my perspective on the conduct of everyday life and introduced me to so many fascinating Western and Eastern philosophers I will have to read more about in the future.
best_gem_comment: This course changed my life for the better and I am forever grateful. One of the most important decisions I made as an undergraduate was taking this course. Professor Puett is an absolute gem––– equal parts brilliant, kind, and open minded.

best_comment: One of my favorite courses ever at Harvard. I am so thankful something like this is offered. I felt like I grew so much intellectually yet also as a human being. That is rare in my undergraduate experience. I am so thankful for Dr. FitzGerald and for this wonderful course. 10/10 recommend.
worse_comment: Pay attention to the posture of the students as they approach debate/analysis, as they really influence the environment of the class and its quality of discussion.

course_title: Racial Liberalism and the Ethics of Law and Justice 1
best_comment: This class will definitely challenge how you view and engage with theories of race. The thinkers are so nuanced and many of the readings will disrupt traditional frameworks. Even more, the focus on sacred texts (Bible and Constitution) opens so many questions about the socio–legal construction of race.

course_title: Bhagavad Gita and Its Greatest Commentary 1
best_comment: I really enjoyed this course and the critical conversations that we had in class. I think the whole group was very knowledgeable about the subject matter and I was grateful to have the opportunity to learn from my peers and Professor Clooney (who has so much wisdom on this topic). I also think the Gita is such a fascinating text and as someone who grew up hearing whispers of different parts, it was really meaningful to properly dissect and compose the meaning behind the texts. For all those reasons, I would definitely recommend taking the class. The one caveat is that the papers were a bit difficult to write and I wish there was more guidance (ie. a rubric) on how to write them properly.
worse_comment: Tough grading

best_comment: I enjoyed this class! I found the workload super manageable and the assignments were good, I especially liked doing a creative final project. I do think it would be quite overwhelming and difficult if you knew nothing about Christianity (they say you need no background to take this course). Prof. Bazzana was super welcoming and kind, and I enjoyed the laid–back vibe of Gio's section. The primary source readings were super interesting, I looked forward to doing them each week. Definitely more high–level than into the weeds. Would recommend!

course_title: Beginning French I: Cross-Cultural Encounters in French 001
best_comment: This was a very useful and dense course without being demanding. The instructors really care about the students understanding the content. With minimal effort, you can perform well in the class. With some additional effort, you can really excel and learn enough basics to get around a french–speaking country.

course_title: Beginning French II: Paris in Virtual Reality 002
best_comment: If you’re considering taking this French class, I would say go for it—even if you’re a bit nervous or didn’t take French recently. This course is a great beginner–level introduction that offers a lot of accessible resources. One of the best parts was how it combined language learning with immersive cultural experiences. We explored Parisian life through VR and AI, which allowed us to virtually visit places like the Louvre, the Eiffel Tower, Musée d’Orsay, and Centre Pompidou. We also learned about Paris’s history and its innovation zones, which made the language feel alive and connected to real people and places. The mix of YouTube videos and interactive content made the class engaging and dynamic. Overall, the course offers a holistic approach to French—covering vocabulary, grammar, slang (like Verlan), and deeper cultural understanding. It’s more than just language; it’s about fully immersing yourself in French culture, which I think is essential to learning any language well.

course_title: Beginning French II: Paris in Virtual Reality 003
best_comment: Take this class! Wonderful teaching because you'll likely be in a section with only 10 other people, so your TF will really get to know you. Great engagement with language, and I loved the virtual reality portion of the class, where you get to use the VR headsets in Cabot Library to see the scenes of Paris yourself.

course_title: Intensive Beginning French: Parisian Culture & Life 001
best_comment: I took this course out of necessity for my language requirement, but rather than a nuisance like so many other students describe the language requirement at Harvard, I ended up looking forward to this class each day. Meeting five days a week is very time intensive, but it unintentionally causes you to learn French through constant engagement. Plus,  spending time with the same people everyday creates a great learning environment where it feels like by the end of the semester you are taking a class with your friends rather than people you met less than two months ago. I appreciate the approach this class takes at language learning; rather than just drilling language through writing and speaking exercises, you learn through learning so much about French history, art and culture. I went into this course admittedly unexcited, but left feeling like I had taken a language, art history and culture class all in one. I would recommend this course to anyway trying to get their language requirement over or just looking for an intro French course at Harvard. Also huge shoutout to Agnes, this course would not be what it was without her. Out of my previous three years at Harvard, she is far and away the most thoughtful TF I have ever had.

course_title: Intermediate French: Francophone Culture in Local Communities 002
best_comment: This class is great! I had a wonderful instructor who explained trickier grammar rules in an easy to understand manner. Daily practice/homework helps make the quizzes very fair.

course_title: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World 002
best_comment: French 30 is a good course for fulfilling the language requirement if you have some level of French background (the levels of speaking especially were widely varied within my section so don't be worried if you are not the best at speaking). I personally did not find the actual contents of the course very interesting, but you do learn a good amount of necessary grammar, some of which will likely be review from previous courses, but in much greater depth. The assignments for this course are not very heavy, but they do have a quick turn around (usually 3 or 4 days) for the podcasts and articles/redactions. The exams were fairly simple, all focused on grammar and writing; as long as you pay attention during class and practice the grammar you will do great on this component. I don't feel that this class vastly improved my French when it comes to speaking (which was my main goal going into it), but it was overall helpful as a refresher for the French that I had learned prior.
worse_comment: Don't take it. The class structure sucks, the assigments are poorly developed and there is not consistent work structure

course_title: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World 003
best_comment: This class is a great way to continue to learn and practice French. Esteban was a great TF and assignments were graded so quickly! Would definitely recommend.

course_title: Advanced French I: The Contemporary Francophone World Through Cinema 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. I have met one of my current closest friends through this class but I have also learned so much. Dr.Brisson is one of my favorite instructors I have ever had the privilege to work with and she is truly such a passionate, brilliant, and understanding professor. She provided us with many opportunities such as meeting the producers or even the authors of certain films we watched and she always makes every class very engaging and interesting. She has helped me improve my French writing and speaking skills and she is always very understanding of outside circumstances or stresses of being a Harvard student in general. I took this class to fulfill my language requirement but it has inspired me to continue and pursue a French citation in hopes to study under Dr.Brisson as well. The work load can be at times plentiful but it is never busy work and again Dr.Brisson is very understanding and is always willing to accommodate with her students. This course also does not just focus on one French dialect or culture making it even more enjoyable as you get familiar with so many different cultures and backgrounds. Overall, this has been one of my favorite classes I have taken at Harvard and highly recommend anyone to take it. Dr.Brisson is a wonderful and passionate instructor who truly loves what she does and the course material is very interesting and captivating.

course_title: Advanced French II: Justice, Equity, Rights, and Language 001
best_comment: Overview I enjoyed French 50, though I personally preferred French 40 (which focused on films). This course explores language and rights, and the shift in topic made it feel a bit more intense.Structure & WorkloadSmall class size (14 students) = highly interactive discussionsNo exams, just 5 short vocab quizzes (lowest dropped)3 main writing assignments—each with a pre–write, in–class draft, revision, and oral activityFinal project: create a manifesto on a social issue of your choiceDossiers are back (thanks to Dr. Turman), which makes the class feel familiar if you’ve taken French 20What to ExpectTight deadlines: pre–writes and Dossiers are due before in–class draftsFeedback comes within a week, and you’ll have another week for revision + an oral submissionQuizzes often fall between drafts and revisions, so time management is keyFinal Thoughts This class is more demanding than earlier French courses, especially with back–to–back deadlines. Balancing it with heavy STEM classes (like orgo and stats) was tough, but I gained confidence in both my writing and speaking skills—and that made it worth it.

course_title: Exploring Sustainable Practices in French Industry: Fashion, Cuisine, and Music 001
best_comment: If you absolutely love French, fashion, or cuisine, take this course. If not, prepare to make a class that you are not passionate about your entire life while taking this class. This is really hard work with what feels in the moment like little reward. If you truly want your French to get better, it absolutely will in this class and so it’s super worth it to lock in and grind it out. If you don’t really care, stay away from this class because it can be soul crushing.

course_title: Exploring Sustainable Practices in French Industry: Fashion, Cuisine, and Music 002
best_comment: I really loved the class overall and learned a lot about French history and culture while also learning more grammar and solidifying my previous knowledge. I think that I mainly improved my speaking skills a lot and felt more comfortable conversing by the end. If you feel like you have a solid basis but don't think you are at a "proficient" level yet, this is the course to take. Dr. Turman is AMAZING and very kind and fair, and is always willing to answer questions and let you ramble on in French even when what you are saying isn't perfect. I think she has a lot of passion and enthusiasm for the class which definitely translated to good conversation and fun vibes. There is A LOT of homework which is mainly writing answers to a bunch of questions in response to a reading or a video. This class will push you in the best ways!

Take this class. Professor Kim is a genius, the class is so engaging, the readings are meaningful and take some time but very worthwhile. My favourite class I took this semester by far and it's nice that you do not have to worry about your grade it is more about engagement.

course_title: Beginning Italian I - Parliamo Italiano! Pathways to Italy 001
best_comment: I initially was nervous to take this course as I have always disliked languages and was upset about the language requirement. I SHOULDNT HAVE BEEN!!!! This class is amazing. So fun and Becky is the best teacher. I came to look forward to it every morning and I actually know a lot of Italian now. I love to show off to my friends. You have so much fun in this class. You design your dream house or dream party or dream trip – just in Italian! TAKE IT!!
worse_comment: Take it when they stop doing VHL assignments.

course_title: Beginning Italian II - Parliamo Italiano! The Art & Craft of Italy 001
best_comment: Professor Tragni is AMAZING. She is so funny and excited about teaching Italian. She genuinely cares about her students and how well they are grasping course materials. Professor Tragni is reachable almost always and encourages participation and engagement. She truly made the class enjoyable.

course_title: Beginning Italian II - Parliamo Italiano! The Art & Craft of Italy 002
best_comment: It is a very good course and I recommend trying it.

course_title: Intensive Beginning Italian: Gateway to Italy 001
best_comment: This is a great class to take, and I definitely recommend it, especially because Professor Linsky is always willing to help and provides strong support throughout the course. That said, it’s important to understand that ITAL 15 is truly intensive. On top of the regular assignments, be prepared to spend extra hours practicing, attending office hours, or seeking tutoring, particularly if you don’t have a background in Romance languages. Staying motivated every single day is crucial, because it’s very easy to fall behind, and once you do, it can be hard to catch up. Overall, the course is rewarding and well–structured, but it's a significant commitment. Make sure you have the time and energy to stay on top of it from start to finish.

course_title: Intermediate Italian: The Colors of Italian Pop Lit 001
best_comment: This class is absolutely incredible! I was lucky enough to experience it with Elisa (who I also took Italian 10 and 11 with), and she is absolutely amazing. She creates such a great vibe in class and is so supportive in your Italian journey. The grading is very generous, so you don't even really have to think about your grades. It is a lot of work though. The assignments are plentiful, and it's tough to get a lot out of them if you don't put a lot of time into them. They are fun though, just make sure you have a decent amount of time to put into it.

course_title: Upper-Level Italian: Italiano in Verde: Sustainability Issues in the Italian Classroom 001
best_comment: Take this course!! There is still a significant work load but it will improve your writing and research skills and you'll even get to go to an anmial sanctuary and make sustainable food and encounter sustainability up close and personal! Lucia is lovely and a wonderful instructor who is flexible and kind.

course_title: Advanced Italian II: Advanced Written Expression - Writing for Social Justice 001
best_comment: This is a really worthwhile class if you’re looking to improve your Italian and talk about meaningful topics. You’ll do a lot of speaking and discussion, which can feel intimidating at first, but it really helps your confidence. The topics are super relevant (things like feminism, social justice, Italian culture today, etc etc) so it’s not just textbook stuff.Professoressa Chiara Trebaiocchi is great. She’s really understanding and supportive, but she also expects you to put in the effort and will definitely push you to get better. The workload can be a lot at times, so just stay on top of things and don’t leave stuff for the last minute. If you’re willing to participate and put in the work, you’ll get a lot out of this course.

course_title: The Cosmos of the Divine Comedy 001
best_comment: This class was absolutely transformational, and among my favourite classes I’ve taken at Harvard. Dedicating a whole class to focus on Dante’s masterpiece was definitely a special experience as we could really deeply understand Dante’s purpose and stories. Originally involved with politics, Dante was sent into exile from Florence, upon which he turned to Christianity and realised the corruption within politics and the Church at the time. In a way, the Comedy has been a way for Dante to not only comment on each of the particular deficiencies within society at the time, but also discover the areas in which he falls short, in doing so, commenting on the human condition and exploring what transcends the physical world. Almost all those mentioned in Inferno lived around 200m away from where Dante lived, or they were political or biblical references.This class taught me a lot about the power of storytelling. I had already been interested in literature in classical antiquity, and noticing the intertextuality here with Virgil was magnificent. I think I came to appreciate how literature can preserve stories from thousands of years ago, and it was such a pleasure and privilege to study such a text with such an incredible teaching team and wonderful peers. At the end of the day, this was a course about what it means to live a fulfilling life, close to God, taking in the beauty of humanity’s power for rationality and faith. Literature doesn’t just preserve stories; it preserves humanity itself.The seminars were quite long – nearly 2.5 hours total, so it was slightly hard to fully engage sometimes. But the final project was deeply, deeply fulfilling, and Ambrogio CP is just so open–minded and brilliant of a thinker. He’s deeply introspective and a very critical thinker, so learning from him was such an incredible experience. You really have full creative autonomy in this class and the ability to really engage with medieval literature – this was easily my favourite class this semester.

course_title: Beginning Portuguese for Spanish Speakers I: Português Beyond Portuñol 001
best_comment: Dear future students, enroll and join this course with excitement! I honestly had the best experience ever. Everyone in the Portuguese department is amazing! On the first day of POTUG10S, I was so scared because my professor started talking to us in Portuguese. However, the language is similar to Spanish, so learning Portuguese isn't that bad. After that my professor spoke in Portuguese a lot and we hardly had any questions. THEY ARE THAT GOOD! I hope Harvard recognizes the importance of this department. I really enjoyed getting the opportunity to learn a new language and about its history and culture. EU AMO PORTUGUÊS! I LOVE PORTUGUESE! It's one of the best classes at Harvard. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE TAKE THIS CLASS! The work load is manageable and the course is very well structured. I learned a lot in this course and believe others should take the time to learn from it. Additionally, the Portuguese department is very great at helping students connect to opportunities in Brazil to help with their Portuguese immersion. You can't go wrong by adding this class to your schedule. MARCIA YOU ARE AMAZING! THANK YOU TO MARCIA, JACKY, AND CRIS FOR WHAT YOU DO!

course_title: Beginning Portuguese for Spanish Speakers II: More SAMBA, less Salsa! 001
best_comment: The class is engaging, fun, and I can tell that my Portuguese improved even more. Just make sure you go to your 4 events outside of class early so you don't have to worry about them later, but the language tables are an easy, low–stress way to get that done. Marcia is the best and you will not regret taking the course with her. There really isn't anything else to say; anyone who has ever taken Portuguese with Marcia all agree that she is amazing, she deserves all of the praise she receives and is the reason why many students have such great things to say about the Portuguese department.

course_title: Literature and Urban History: Views from Brazil and the United States 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. If truly has the most interesting readings I have ever read for any class. If you're even remotely interested in Brazilian history, urban history, urban literature, or 19th–century literature, take this class. The weekly discussion posts are super chill. The midterm paper had very interesting prompts to choose from and you receive solid feedback. Final paper also gives you ample space to branch out a bit. Cant stress enough how amazing the readings are and discussions in class! The profs are amazing.

course_title: Literature and Urban History: Views from Brazil and the United States 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. If truly has the most interesting readings I have ever read for any class. If you're even remotely interested in Brazilian history, urban history, urban literature, or 19th–century literature, take this class. The weekly discussion posts are super chill. The midterm paper had very interesting prompts to choose from and you receive solid feedback. Final paper also gives you ample space to branch out a bit. Cant stress enough how amazing the readings are and discussions in class! The profs are amazing.

This course is incredible. The profs are so caring and enthusiastic and you will learn so much. I took this course with a background in science/ecology and loved the opportunity to study the environment in a new way. The more you put in (with office hours, time on the creative project), the more you'll get out of the course.

This course is incredible. The profs are so caring and enthusiastic and you will learn so much. I took this course with a background in science/ecology and loved the opportunity to study the environment in a new way. The more you put in (with office hours, time on the creative project), the more you'll get out of the course.
only take if actually interested in film or else it will be boring

course_title: Critical Archives in Theory and Practice 001
best_comment: Rather theory–heavy but always interesting, and class discussions are great!

This class is incredible. The professors are so wonderful and smart, hearing them speak is probably the best part of it. They really foster an open and safe environment where people can feel comfortable speaking on difficult topics. The class was very warm and felt almost like a family. It’s a great class.

This class is incredible. The professors are so wonderful and smart, hearing them speak is probably the best part of it. They really foster an open and safe environment where people can feel comfortable speaking on difficult topics. The class was very warm and felt almost like a family. It’s a great class.

course_title: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World I: Histories, Cultures, and Traditions. 001
best_comment: Spanish 10 is really fun!! There is a significant amount of work (quizzes, homework etc.) but you get a lot out of it, I was amazed by how much I learned this semester from the class, from knowing zero Spanish to being able to hold a veryyyy basic conversation/ write a very basic essay. I had a lot of fun in class and I learned a lot. The conversations in class were always really fun and engaging too.

course_title: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World II: Social, Cultural, and Sustainability Topics 001
best_comment: This course is designed to foster growth among beginner Spanish speakers! The course staff is so supportive, and truly wants to see you grow throughout the semester! I definitely recommend meeting one–on–one with you TF to look over projects and reports, that way you can get feedback prior to submitting assignments!

course_title: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World II: Social, Cultural, and Sustainability Topics 002
best_comment: I really enjoyed this class, and will be taking Spanish 20 next semester even though I only planned to fulfill my language requirement. I was surprised that I enjoyed this class, because I didn't like Spanish 10 very much. This class is very similar to Spanish 10, but I had a better idea of what I was getting into, and I did a bunch of Duolingo over winter break. That helped a lot I think, and I recommend doing the same if you are worried.

course_title: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World II: Social, Cultural, and Sustainability Topics 003
best_comment: More manageable than Spanish 10. Alejandro was a great teacher and was very encouraging. Certainly learned a lot of Spanish within a semester.

course_title: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World II: Social, Cultural, and Sustainability Topics 004
best_comment: This class is great if you've taken Spanish in high school or Spanish 10, but make sure to refresh your Spanish before you take it because they don't go over simple phrases, numbers, colors, clothing etc. that is all expected for you to know. The tests are pretty challenging, especially the writing portions. The projects are great to help your grade and engage with the material. Talk Abroad is also great for practicing your Spanish with a native speaker, and you only have to submit a report about the conversation you had. Class three times a week is a lot, but it's definitely necessary because you need to be consistently conversing in Spanish to really get good at it. Overall, be prepared to put in the work, but your Spanish will improve a lot.
worse_comment: This class is very teacher–dependent. Depending on who leads your section, the difficulty of the class and grading changes. I did not have a great experience in this course, but others I know did.

course_title: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World II: Social, Cultural, and Sustainability Topics 006
best_comment: Don’t underestimate this class—it’s about more than just learning Spanish. You’ll gain insight into culture, identity, and global perspectives, all while forming real connections. Treasure the relationships this small class size allows you to build with both your instructor and your peers—it makes all the difference.
worse_comment: This is definitely a step up from Spanish 10. There is a large focus on "sustainability." The grading is harsher in this course than in Spanish 10, and more work outside of class.

course_title: Introduction to the Spanish-speaking World II: Social, Cultural, and Sustainability Topics 007
best_comment: You can easily receive an A– in the course. But, I know you want that A. I would recommend to really put A LOT of time in this course. I mean understand spanish syntax before coming to this course. I also recommend to have a GREAT relationship with your teaching staff. You could work very hard, with the possible harsh grading, and still come short by like 0.2% of an A. So having that relationship could give you the ability to speak to them and possibly give you some remorse.

I really loved Spanish 15! It's a little intensive in terms of time, but most of the time class was a joy and I loved the environment we had. It was very supportive and we got to talk about some really interesting topics — learning about Latinx and Hispanic culture, getting to know more about Boston and immigration across the world. It was enriching and I always left class with a smile on my face!9am everyday sounds hard but it's really not, and helps you get a good sleep schedule. I think the immersion made it way easier for me to learn Spanish because I would be using it practically everyday, and when we had breaks, e.g. Spring break I could feel the struggle a little to get back into the rhythm. Profesor Israel, and our TF Ceci were just wonderful! They brought so much energy everyday to class and were so supportive and wholesome :) we really got to know them – and each other in class – and so it felt a lot less formal, and it was never intimidating to speak in class. I had a great set of classmates and honestly learned so much from them — even if we were speaking broken Spanish. Be prepared to do lots of daily readings on Canvas, but they're short and the quizzes are manageable. The class is definitely a commitment, but it's really worth it! The assignments don't take all that much time if you're engaged in class and help reiterate and store knowledge. Before every exam there's generally a study guide and so you'll be super prepared and have good expectations for what's to come.

The class is great, truly! If you want to learn Spanish fast, go for it.That said, there are a few things you should know: this class meets every day at 9 AM, and you're only allowed three absences and three late days. For me, that wasn’t nearly enough. Thankfully, there are opportunities to earn extra credit.One of the things I loved was the grade distribution, it felt fair and balanced between exams and participation.Just a heads–up: you'll need to manage your time well. The exam and final project are scheduled back–to–back, so exam week can get pretty intense and time–consuming.Best of luck! <3

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 001
best_comment: IF YOU HAVE JOSE DE LEON, DO NOT HESITATE TO SWITCH SECTIONS. On my first day of class, my class could immediately tell that he was going to be very rude and mean. The next day, over half the class switched to a different section. However, I wanted to give him the benefit of the doubt and I stuck it out. Worst decision of my life. Not only is he an incredibly harsh grader, but he also makes the classroom a terrifying environment in which to speak another language. And I am someone who genuinely wanted to learn Spanish before this and was considering concentrating in it or doing a citation, but he has stamped all of the love for learning another language out of me. I am also not someone who typically feels this strongly about teachers or dislikes people easily. He is truly awful. I also didn't even learn much. However, I absolutely loved Spanish 11 and I think I would have loved Spanish 20 as well if I was smart enough to switch sections when I had the chance. I've heard great things about the other teachers, so I would definitely say to still take the course if you're interested in learning some Spanish.
worse_comment: If you  are not secure with your Spanish  knowledge from High School, do not start with this course. Start with Spanish 11. This is not a beginner course. The readings are long and you need an hour minimum to complete them.

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 002
best_comment: This is a pretty fast course with 4 exams containing essay components and 2 presentations. Definitely not a cake walk for the language requirement, but a little  I'd say 2–3 years of some form of experience would be helpful –– Spanish 11 can serve as a good introduction for those without much. The readings can be pretty long at times, but just make sure you understand the main ideas of them before the next class. I found a lot more success when I developed some sort of routine for practicing the language, combining course materials and assignments with sources outside of the scope of the class to practice vocabulary or different grammatical structures. Duolingo is free, I'd definitely try it out! As far as the class itself, it's solid but can be a lot of work at times.

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 003
best_comment: Spanish 11 was a wonderful class and I recommend you take it to fulfill your language requirements
worse_comment: – Personally don't feel like I've grown as a spanish speaker and this class is way too much work but you'll get through it!!

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 004
best_comment: TAKE WITH GABRIELLA DUMANCELA!! She is by far the best professor that teachers Spanish20 (coming from someone who had to switch sections!!). She creates such a lovely learning environment and is very receptive to feedback and gracious as to how much work this class is. Spanish20 is very difficult in terms of workload and a lot of the assignments felt like busywork. The course really picks up during the end, really the last 2 weeks of class so be weary!

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 005
best_comment: This class's content is laid out very well with a calendar on the home page of the canvas course. Take advantage of it as it will help make scheduling plans for when you plan to complete certain assignments. You should make sure to develop a study habit as that will make learning vocab and conjugation structures easier, but also because the homeworks are automatically graded, so if you do them late you automatically get a penalty. It's only 10% per day, and TFs can give back points at their discretion, but it's just easier to get in a habit of doing them. My TF, Jorge Arteta, is GREAT and really understanding, which is great when you are struggling with a concept since he really tries to help you understand!

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 006
best_comment: Spanish 20 is a significant leap from Spanish 11, so be warned going into this course. Readings will be multiple pages, tests will require short essays, and grammar will become more complex as the year progresses. Make sure to dedicate more time for this course than what is required in 11.

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 001
best_comment: This class is awesome. I imagine your experience will depend on your section leader, but Ruy was an amazing teacher. The written and oral exams are both very fair; they give you an opportunity to show what you know, which is what exams should do. The most important thing is to try to actively participate and class and exercise your speaking skills, because i feel that's much more important than writing or reading skills at a beginner/intermediate level.

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 002
best_comment: This course is participation–heavy (as opposed to assignments outside of class) and mainly reinforces the grammar concepts learned in Spanish 20. The structure of the course is paced well,  and there is opportunity to have fun with the presentations and other projects. l

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 003
best_comment: This was my first Spanish course at Harvard. I think that it was fun and engaging, and I think my Spanish definitely improved a lot just from all of the writing and speaking, but it was a bit tedious at times just because of the readings, but that's a given. I took AP in high school and took this over 40 to see what it would be like. Overall, this an extremely well structured class, and if you have previous experience in Spanish and put the work in, you will definitely be successful. Gaby was a lovely prof that wanted everyone to succeed.

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 004
best_comment: If you're placed into Spanish 30, definitely take it. I placed into 30 as an incoming freshman and didn't take it until second–semester sophomore year so I was nervous (especially since this was my first Spanish class at Harvard), but I'm so glad I took it. It's definitely a lot of work (homework nightly, reading, vocab/grammar review, and class three times a week), but class was always engaging and fun, and if you're serious about getting better at Spanish, definitely take this class. Alejandro was an amazing teacher and stickler for grammar (which is better for you in the long run), and always made class super fun. This class forces you to speak in Spanish all the time, so you'll definitely improve your speaking skills.

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 005
best_comment: Great course! You will get a lot of speaking practice which is awesome! Gaby is incredible. The course focus is on art, music, culture, etc. Not a huge workload but you often need to read or listen to something to prepare for class and in class you will be expected to discuss and engage with that materials so it’s helpful to show up ready! Very fun course, great start to my day everyday and I really got to know my classmates and teacher and really appreciated this component.

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 001
best_comment: This class is SO MUCH FUN. The analysis of visual art, film, articles, and literature is a lot of fun and an amazing way to interact with Spanish language and cultures.

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 002
best_comment: This is an objectively easy class to get a good grade so long as you participate in discussion (a lot) and do all of the assigned prep for class. There is great potential to learn a lot from this class, including historical knowledge of Latin America as well. I would highly recommend this class to anyone interested in improving their knowledge of the Latino world, but I will say that I gained a lot more speaking skills in Spanish 30.
worse_comment: Watching the movies is a pain and honestly more work than Spanish 30 –– but in class time is relatively low stress and comittment.

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 003
best_comment: I highly recommend taking this course. The tests are easy and the workload is extremely light given that you just watch movies for homework. Professor Natalie is super sweet and kind. She gives great feedback and is the best professor.

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 004
best_comment: This is one of my favorite classes at Harvard. Xiomara is such a kind and wonderful person and instructor, and the way she conducts the class creates such a great environment to have important discussions. It would take me a long time to write everything I love about this class, I just recommend you take it.

course_title: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance 001
best_comment: This class is a fun course. Rehearsing plays in Spanish is a very fun way to practice Spanish. You probably don't want to take this class with José as your section leader.  He is never on time to class, doesn't print out the class materials for his students, never responds to his emails, is very strict, picks on particular students, and rarely gives As on assignments. That being said, he is also probably one of the best teachers in the spanish department and has improved my spanish so much over the semester.

course_title: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance 002
best_comment: Very laid–back, Ruyman is the best TF!! He made the class so chill and was really focused on your improvement rather than perfection of the language. Your grammar will improve through the written assignments, while the performance assignments will help your ability to improv in Spanish. Do not be intimidated by the plays you will have to do. Your classmates help you through!

course_title: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance 003
best_comment: LOVED THIS SPANISH COURSE. Your conversational skills will improve way more in this course than in Spanish 20–40. Super fun. If you're lucky, you get Natalie as a TF; she's amazing.

course_title: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance 004
best_comment: Take this class!! Spanish 40 was really meh for me but Spanish 50 is phenomenal. For exams, you write and act out your own play with a group. This intimidated me at first but it's actually SO MUCH FUN– I've never ever acted before and I'm really really glad I got the opportunity to try it out in a low–stakes setting while generating whatever hilarious story I wanted. The homework is around 10 questions, takes maybe ten minutes. There are points where you suddenly have to read an entire act of a play in two days but if you look ahead and plan for it then it's not a big deal. Super chill, super fun, highly recommend. And I got to interact with other students without that stifling awkwardness that sections usually have. My section only had 8 students and every TF is phenomenal anyway.

Take this class!! Be prepared to be challenged, to grow as a human being, and form lasting relationships with those around you. You should know that Spanish 59 is a very time–consuming course. Between three hours of volunteering a week (for me, this was really five hours including the commute time) and several hours of preparatory coursework (1–2 documentaries and several readings a week), it can sometimes feel like you are actually taking two separate classes at once. All that said, the workload is certainly not a reason to skip out on taking this class. If you know what you are getting into, manage your time, and schedule your semester well, you are set to have a fantastic experience.  Profe Fajardo is an incredible professor who cares deeply about her students, their backgrounds, and their lives, and she facilitates active and engaging conversations with ease, even when some of the course materials (documentaries/readings) are a bit entry–level or bland. But more than the in–class experience, what makes Spanish 59 special is a structured opportunity to be immersed in community work in the Boston and Cambridge area. I worked with La Colaborativa in their Economic Development department, and I enjoyed the work so much that I hope to return as a volunteer next year.

course_title: Spanish for Latino Students II: Connecting with Communities 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS PLSSSSS!!!!!!! It is a wonderful and insightful class that teaches essential history about what it means to be Latino or of Hispanic descent in the U.S. Even if you don't identify as this one, this course teaches you important history that anyone would benefit from learning. In addition, the community engagement component of the class is very engaging and fulfilling! It gets you out of the Harvard bubble and allows you to explore more of Boston and its surrounding communities.

This class was a fun and interesting introduction to public health topics in Latin America! It was super interesting getting to learn about specific examples public health across countries and historical eras in Spanish, and Profe Gutierrez is so knowledgeable and amazing at facilitating discussions and making you think critically about course materialGetting to research and present different public health topics that you can choose was also a great way to dive deeper into personal interests, and it goes without saying that my command of Spanish improved so much over the semester

Without a doubt, take this course if you can. You don't have to be pre–med to enjoy or learn from it (however, if you are, it definitely is an added bonus as you're more likely to engage deeper with the ideas discussed). You'll be learning about public health issues through weekly readings but a majority of the "learning" experience comes from the classroom discussions. Wilnomy was an amazing section leader who facilitated the class in such a lovely manner that made coming to Spanish61ph one of my highlights of the day. You'll become a more confident speaker and better writer along the way.

This was a good Spanish class! It was smaller than most, but I think this made for better connections and discussions. Weekly workload was manageable, and assignments were generally flexible and enjoyable. Wilnomy is a great TF – funny, helpful, and accessible!

course_title: Tales of Two Spains: A Survey of Spanish Modern Literature and Culture (18th to 21st centuries) 001
best_comment: This is such a great class! The professor is super dedicated, and the topics are super interesting, especially if you’ve had past interest in politics and Spanish literature. The workload is not too bad, and the in–class essays are very fair.

Highly highly recommend! Daniel is a super fun professor and he's very supportive and creative in the way he teaches the class. I never realized that you could learn so much about a language, the culture, the politics and the people in just translating 8 sentences from english–>spanish and spanish–>english. Love how this class is structured like a workshop than a class.

course_title: The Conservative Imagination in Latin America: Figures of a Dynamic Tradition 001
best_comment: Alejandro is amazing! He is super nice and plans each session very thoroughly so that most of the time, we still have stuff to talk about before the two hours are over. The readings are very challenging for people whose Spanish is relatively weak, but you will get better, I think, if you try to read and understand even portions of them thoroughly. It helps to be interested in the topic of Latin American conservative thought in the 18th and 19th centuries, but if you take it to get better at Spanish then it's also great practice with tough literature.

course_title: Tobacco and Sugar, Seminar in Caribbean Counterpoints 001
best_comment: I would emphasize that this class has very unique class structure. It is all about having every person in the class share one idea, one question, one reflection repeatedly throughout the seminar –– but without ever exchanging ideas or thoughts between each other. This means everyone will always participate multiple times –– which holds you accountable, in part, to the extremely long and difficult readings (sometimes running up to 100 pages of Spanish literature a week) –– but there is never any actual dialogue or conversation (because it is just going around sharing one thing per person), so the analysis is irritatingly minimal. Be prepared to spend at least 30 minutes total every class going around the room reflecting on what it was like to hear your classmates ask questions about the text, or what it was like to share a connection with the text with your peers. Doris will also not really lecture about any of the works; the emphasis is just hearing how your peers reacted to it for two hours each week.

course_title: Why Women Kill: Representations of Gender in Modern and Contemporary Latin America 001
best_comment: I had a great time in this class! Alejandra is always an amazing and thoughtful professor and the course material was very interesting. It was fun to read/watch about such a wide variety of women killers, and it's such a rich and nuanced topic. The reading load is definitely on the heavier side, but there are great films/books/stories to learn from in the syllabus.

TAKE THIS CLASS!!! If you are at all interested in Russian, take this class absolutely!! Pastushenkov is such an amazing teacher and makes it so worth it to get up every day. Don't feel horrified by the M–F 9am schedule – it gets you into a great routine and gets your day started early. I made such strong relationships with all the other kids in my class – by the end of the semester, we were doing study sessions together in the library and hanging out outside of class. I learned more Russian than I thought was possible in a few months, and I am already enrolled in the Intermediate for next semester. This is an incredibly engaging and rewarding class. Make sure you have the time to commit to the courseload, though – they don't call it an intensive for nothing. It is the effort and time of two classes, that's why it's 8 credits. Make sure you are committed to spending the time to doing homeworks and studying for the tests, because it doesn't just pay off in grades, it pays off in how much of the language you actually end up learning.
worse_comment: It's not a joke. This class will consume your life. I am talking 15 hours a week outside of class. It is hard because it is a non–stop uphill battle that only slows down long enough to trick you into thinking you're not completely overwhelmed. You will have fun, but it will also be the only thing you have time to do outside of classes.

best_comment: If you've already taken RUSS AA, this class is pretty similar, just building on what you know; I imagine I don't need to sell you too much on taking AB. Jemma is a great TF; she's is always very encouraging and tries to make the lessons fun. As long as you stay on top of the homework, nothing in this class should be too hard. The essays might seem intimidating, but armed with a dictionary they're not so bad. This semester, you actually get to read some real book chapters/poems/stories written by actual Russian authors, which is pretty cool. N.B. for undergraduates: if you perform well enough over the year, you can be nominated to participate in the New England Olympiada of Spoken Russian (info online) or be granted an Behr Award with a cash prize, if you want extra motivation to make your Russian even better.

This class is amazing. It's definitely a lot of work but I felt like I had a lot of support and was able to make progress in learning the language. The course staff is amazing, supportive, and always available for help.

This class is amazing. It's definitely a lot of work but I felt like I had a lot of support and was able to make progress in learning the language. The course staff is amazing, supportive, and always available for help.

Loved this class and our group so much, spending two semesters together. Veronika Egorova is a great instructor and a great person, and I would highly recommend taking anything with her! It was great getting to practice my Russian with our group and also just grow closer to my heritage, especially in these challenging times. Assignments and grading are fair and very flexible with varying levels of Russian proficiency, and I could always tell how much Veronika Egorova was invested in our own personal, individual growth. Take this class if you ever get the chance!!

Ok, so this is what you expect it follows the standard Russian language track from what you’re used to and in that sense you probably don’t need to read the q at all.  But I want to say this, perhaps because I think it’s important to realize the goals the pedagogy of the class is aiming to satisfy:Ability to present in a professional controlled environment on select topics in RussianAbility to write (albeit limitedly) in Russian on demand without mistakes in case and phrasingAbility to write professionally in a controlled environment with a dictionary on select topics in RussianIf that’s appealing to you or necessary, I think the class is good and will make better at those things if you take it seriously, and you only get out as much as you put in in those regards.  I wanted to become a better Russian speaker over the course of my Russian education at Harvard, and in this class I did improve in that from the simple fact that we did speak Russian every day.  But the class has a variety of levels and I will say there was a lot of anxiety on my part going to the speaking days because of the weird question and answer aspect of it for whatever film we had that week which usually involved very weird things you probably couldn’t watch in public.That is to say, I think that the course could benefit a lot by building up everyone’s speaking ability a lot more and emphasizing this.  At the end of the class during the presentation many people simply memorized or read directly from flash cards, and in section you will find many people who stammer to get their Russian out; I get it! It’s hard and you have to warm up, but the environment focused around these movies and topics aren’t helping for functional fluency so much as they are for the highly limited vocabulary we learn.  And when your goal is that level of functional fluency or maintaining that, the lack of speaking practice can be really frustrating.In sum, don’t expect to change dramatically as a speaker and section can sometimes feel limited or awkward since at this point functional fluency or like quick and rapid use of Russian is sometimes limited. And the vocab topics are kinda small and not frequently used in usual conversation.Also the project, this was way too convoluted and crazy.   I think an oral exam on a chosen topic of Russian where you’re grilled on questions would be far better for students.  These projects just seem like a huge waste of time when something like that can be both more challenging But, I do think the class has a lot of strengths:The teachers:Veronika and Liya are both excellent and care about students. I think that they are both very kind and funny and supportive and I’m privileged to have learned from them since they’re both so knowledgeable.The students:So fun and you’ll make lots of friendsDaily meeting:Nuff said it’s the hallmark of the dept and for a good reason!Course quizzes and exams:Always extremely fair and fairly forgiving and they make you  actually think on your feet for the writing which is good.But yeah, as much as I love the Slavic department, I feel the need to write this to emphasize that I feel like speaking takes a back seat which is a tragedy since Russian is so fun to actually speak! And I think that the majority of the students want to speak better and listen better more than they want to be able to write essays and movie reviews.  But maybe that’s just me.
worse_comment: GOATed Harvard Russian department strikes again.
