best_comment: Definitely a very challenging course. This class also follows the textbook pretty strictly which I personally don't know if I liked, but it does help provide structure. Liya is a fantastic instructor and is very responsive!

Definitely a very challenging course. This class also follows the textbook pretty strictly which I personally don't know if I liked, but it does help provide structure. Liya is a fantastic instructor and is very responsive!

course_title: Fourth-Year Russian: Russian Media and Popular Culture 001
best_comment: This is an amazing course and you should most definitely take it! Because of its smaller class size and more section–like nature, you will get plenty of practice speaking Russian in an academic context with both your professor and peers. You will also get very well acquainted with popular Russian culture and will get to explore the film, music, and literary scene from the 90s up until the present day.

course_title: Introduction to Slavic Literatures and Cultures 001
best_comment: Kremer is awesome and truly an expert in Slavic literature. I really enjoyed the diverse range of reaings in this class, and and very satisfied with the amount of history, literature, and arts consumed. Would definitely recommend this course, even if you're not a Slavic concentrator

This was among the best courses I've taken at Harvard and I strongly recommend taking it. Prof. Buckler and Nadia really deeply cared about everyone in the class – they went out of their way to learn everyone's names in the first few weeks of class, and the vibes were always incredibly friendly and collegial, especially in section. If you've ever considered reading War and Peace or been daunted by the size, this is your perfect chance to take it with friendly and supportive teaching staff and peers to really enhance your experience. None of the assignments are particularly daunting (there's just two short response papers, an oral exam, and an open–nended final project), and Prof. Buckler and Nadia are super interested in helping you and making sure you do well on those assignments. The depth of Prof. Buckler's knowledge of War and Peace, and of Russian literature more broadly, is staggering, and it was a truly awe–inspiring experience to sit in lecture and listen to her speak about it. My one warning would be: be prepared to do ~120 pages of reading every week, consistently, because you don't want to fall behind on the reading. I would recommend carving out several 1–hour slots throughout the week to sit down and read.
worse_comment: Absolutely take this class! One cannot ask for a better facilitator with which to read Tolstoy besides Professor Buckler.

course_title: Communism and the Politics of Culture: Czechoslovakia and the Cold War in Eastern Europe 001
best_comment: This class is great, and you will learn in depth about communism in Czechoslovakia. Professor Bolton is amazing and wants everyone to succeed. With that being said, the reading is very heavy, so do not take this class if you already have a hard semester.

If you are interested in the topic, definitely take it. Though I did want more a more non–silent film heavy syllabus (we only got post–wwii for the final two weeks which kinda bummed me out). Don't take this class if you are not actually interested or curious to become interested cuz nothing stinks more than a tuition–paying Harvard student in class goofing off on their laptop when they are in the middle of an opportunity for great learning and intellectual enrichment. It's definitely a good intro film course for those who have not taken any and want to because it covers a lot of basic concepts of film theory that are useful in all other worlds of film and visual art (though maybe start with a less specific class like AFVS 70 just to get a wider range of films).

TAKE THIS COURSE!!! If you are reading this, you might be deciding between some other courses related to Soviet or post–Soviet culture, mostly focusing on Russian thought.  But this course is your chance to learn more about works that survived heavy censorship and are in the process of being rediscovered (I mean, your final project might turn out to be a great contribution to restoring one of such works). Professor Tokarskyi is one of the most approachable professors I have ever had!! If not for his office hours, I don't know how I would survive the course (I'm a STEM concentrator), and here I am considering a secondary in Slavic Studies.

I LOVED Social Studies 10B. Though I liked 10A a lot, the content of 10B was even more interesting to me, and I had a great time diving into the texts each week. I would leave lecture each week feeling so happy about my decision to concentrate in Social Studies, and I truly felt like this class pushed me as a thinker, writer, and student! I highly encourage you to make the most of 10B –– there are not many courses like it that you'll encounter while at Harvard, and you will absolutely get out what you put in. Additionally, I can't say enough about Joan, my tutorial leader. She is possibly the best teacher/mentor I have ever had in my entire life. I felt extremely challenged in her tutorial in the best way possible, and I learned so much not just about social theory, but also about the basics of writing an effective paper and more. And she's just so lovely and cares about her students so much! The other folks in my tutorial were also wonderful! I really believe this concentration attracts amazing students, and I felt so lucky to be able to study with them. I can't recommend 10B enough, and I am so grateful to have taken it!
worse_comment: Take this course. You will be pushed; you will be frustrated. But you'll walk away with an inability to look at life the same way you did before. That's a rare thing, and how often do you get to experience that?

best_comment: I LOVED Social Studies 10B. Though I liked 10A a lot, the content of 10B was even more interesting to me, and I had a great time diving into the texts each week. I would leave lecture each week feeling so happy about my decision to concentrate in Social Studies, and I truly felt like this class pushed me as a thinker, writer, and student! I highly encourage you to make the most of 10B –– there are not many courses like it that you'll encounter while at Harvard, and you will absolutely get out what you put in. Additionally, I can't say enough about Joan, my tutorial leader. She is possibly the best teacher/mentor I have ever had in my entire life. I felt extremely challenged in her tutorial in the best way possible, and I learned so much not just about social theory, but also about the basics of writing an effective paper and more. And she's just so lovely and cares about her students so much! The other folks in my tutorial were also wonderful! I really believe this concentration attracts amazing students, and I felt so lucky to be able to study with them. I can't recommend 10B enough, and I am so grateful to have taken it!
worse_comment: Take this course. You will be pushed; you will be frustrated. But you'll walk away with an inability to look at life the same way you did before. That's a rare thing, and how often do you get to experience that?

best_comment: I LOVED Social Studies 10B. Though I liked 10A a lot, the content of 10B was even more interesting to me, and I had a great time diving into the texts each week. I would leave lecture each week feeling so happy about my decision to concentrate in Social Studies, and I truly felt like this class pushed me as a thinker, writer, and student! I highly encourage you to make the most of 10B –– there are not many courses like it that you'll encounter while at Harvard, and you will absolutely get out what you put in. Additionally, I can't say enough about Joan, my tutorial leader. She is possibly the best teacher/mentor I have ever had in my entire life. I felt extremely challenged in her tutorial in the best way possible, and I learned so much not just about social theory, but also about the basics of writing an effective paper and more. And she's just so lovely and cares about her students so much! The other folks in my tutorial were also wonderful! I really believe this concentration attracts amazing students, and I felt so lucky to be able to study with them. I can't recommend 10B enough, and I am so grateful to have taken it!
worse_comment: Take this course. You will be pushed; you will be frustrated. But you'll walk away with an inability to look at life the same way you did before. That's a rare thing, and how often do you get to experience that?

best_comment: This course is fantastic!!! Matt is such an incredible teacher. I literally have never had an instructor at Harvard that has cared more about their class or students than Matt. On every assignment he gives way more feedback than you could have expected, he's always incredibly available and helpful when you meet with him, and makes a methods course as engaging as possible. He is incredibly well versed in a wide range of literature, and gave me so many great suggestions about scholarly schools to look at that might be helpful to apply to my research context. If you put in the work, engage in the classes, and do a good job with the scaffolding assignments, this can be such an incredible course for building to your thesis.
worse_comment: Take this class! If you are hesitating between this class and other methods classes, DON'T, and just take this one. You will not regret it!

course_title: Making Sense of Methods for Theoretical and Historical Research 001
best_comment: This course is great! You're exposed to some great authors, work on assignments that help your senior thesis take shape, and have terrific mentors in Dr. Harpham and Dr. Greenberg.However, I'd tell future students that this isn't a course solely devoted to hammering out the details of your senior thesis, nor is it merely a course in theoretical and historical research methods. These two projects operate in parallel, and careful thought is required to integrate the two such that they inform each other. Class meetings are more devoted to discussing the course material (e.g., methodological debates, interpreting readings, etc.). Office hours with your instructors will be more helpful in having the course content bear meaningfully on the direction of your senior thesis.Because this course is made up of fellow Social Studies concentrators, I'd encourage students to learn about their classmates' projects, the research methods they'll employ, and the topics they're curious about. It'll broaden your intellectual horizons and make for a more fun semester!

course_title: Making Sense of Methods for Theoretical and Historical Research 001
best_comment: This course is great! You're exposed to some great authors, work on assignments that help your senior thesis take shape, and have terrific mentors in Dr. Harpham and Dr. Greenberg.However, I'd tell future students that this isn't a course solely devoted to hammering out the details of your senior thesis, nor is it merely a course in theoretical and historical research methods. These two projects operate in parallel, and careful thought is required to integrate the two such that they inform each other. Class meetings are more devoted to discussing the course material (e.g., methodological debates, interpreting readings, etc.). Office hours with your instructors will be more helpful in having the course content bear meaningfully on the direction of your senior thesis.Because this course is made up of fellow Social Studies concentrators, I'd encourage students to learn about their classmates' projects, the research methods they'll employ, and the topics they're curious about. It'll broaden your intellectual horizons and make for a more fun semester!

course_title: Democracy in the Trenches: Journalism and Lawyering in India and the US 001
best_comment: This was the first time that this class was offered, and Vatsal did an excellent job creating its structure and generating very important and engaging conversations in class. I think this sort of theory in action seminars should become more of the norm, especially when we can converse so deeply with media professionals and try our hand at media production. The class also attracts students who want to be dedicated, and the learning lab component was a huge plus (although after the first 2 times, the sessions weren't really helpful, but were a great resource regardless!) HIGHLY RECOMMEND if it is offered again (and hope it is!)

A fantastic course with a truly meaningful final project. The final is what you make of it, it has a lot of creative freedom, with great encouragement from the course to engage in valuable academic inquiry. The course material comes together well at the end for a valuable understanding of how we conceptualize the space we exist in and how our definitions and understanding of land are extremely valuable to our history and how we function in the world. I recommend this class to students in any field, STEM, social sciences, or humanities. Of course a social science background is helpful, but I believe the format and content of the course could be really valuable to someone from a different field wishing to gain perspective. I highly recommend this course.

If you're interested in learning more about the law and its operations very broadly, this is a great course to take! Terry is a wonderful instructor who spends a lot of time and effort curating a reading list that covers a broad range of topics and perspectives. The midterm and final papers aren't too bad, having very broad prompts that allow students to pursue whatever topics interest them most. At times, discussion could get a bit challenging because of a lack of structure within course sessions, but most of the time, discussions were great! This is a very good junior tutorial to take, I recommend it strongly.
A really great course overall– Will is a great teacher and great at facilitating discussions. Good readings and great for a small group!
worse_comment: This course is truly about fascism and the study of fascism. It can feel niche at times, but it is super timely and allows for students to reflect on political theory more broadly while questioning how political theory might grapple with political arrangements that are violent, prejudiced, unhealthy, or just undemocratic.

best_comment: This course was really a mixed bag for me. Samuel was a really nice professor and the feedback he gave me on every assignment was always careful, detailed, and helpful for the final paper. Also, the guest speakers he brought in were really powerful and informative; specifically, we focused a good amount on the Tibetan and Hong Kong diasporas, who are really good case studies for the themes we discussed. However, I think our discussions in class were always a bit lackluster; maybe it was the morning time slot of the class, but I don't think a lot of us were engaged in the readings or in the discussion itself. I also think the themes of the class kept reverting back to the questions/debates surrounding "transnationalism," which personally did not compel me. Sadly Samuel is leaving Harvard, but he was a genuinely nice scholar and professor, and I hope that future iterations of this seminar may work better for others.

This is a fantastic tutorial for you if you're interested in postcolonial studies, empire, or anything related to it. The readings were very well selected and covered a range of interesting topics, my only complaint is that I wish I had done them more closely. Yasemin is such a lovely tutorial leader: She is very kind, warm, and totally brilliant. If you're interested in leftist thought, I would highly recommend this tutorial!

This class is an excellent tutorial. I would just make sure that you have a real interest in urban studies and/or anthropological methods (ethnographies, etc), as that would allow you to get the most out of the course, but it is still meaningful nevertheless. Dr. Guan is a kind and great instructor. The readings can be long but the class is dedicated to discussing the readings, so even if you can't finish/understand them on your own time, class discussion will help you get the most out of them.

course_title: Critical Theory of Knowledge, Technology and Power 001
best_comment: This is a great junior tutorial to take. Bo–Mi has been teaching it for many years, so the syllabus and her pedagogy are quite refined. Our class had very good theoretical discussions that Bo–Mi also did her best to orient toward praxis, which I really appreciated, and she also led every week with a meditation. Support for the term paper was well structured, and discussions with her were always generative. I only wish that there was more guidance about methodology specifically, because "doing" critical theory can be quite slippery.

A truly amazing class, one of if not the best classes I've taken at this school. It is structured so intentionally with interesting readings and amazing conversations that always felt like they ended too early. Classes are structured around number premise summaries of the arguments of the texts we read which makes for deep and meaningful engagement with the ideas presented. There is such a intellectual diversity in the texts that I also really appreciated, forced me to really clarify my intellectual and moral convictions. Adaner is such an amazing professor—one of the best I've had here—his feedback is thorough, he is kind and flexible, and he does so much to foster curiosity in and outside of the classroom. It really feels like Adaner is invested in and curious about his students intellectual development in a way I have never experienced from a teacher. This class was one that I was always excited for throughout the week, and I really enjoyed the conversations we'd have after class during coffee chats. The only thing is that there aren't really any assignments related to the final paper so the potential to procrastinate your paper till the end of the semester is present—good be helpful to set up some intermediate deadlines with him for feedback and accountability. Definitely wish I went to more office hours. Going to miss this class!

course_title: Climate Justice: The Politics of Decarbonization 001
best_comment: This is a wonderful class! Dr. Masin–Peters does a great job facilitating discussion, the readings are interesting and enjoyable, and weekly written assignments are useful in fleshing out your thoughts ahead of class. If you are looking to gain a better understanding of the current academic conversation around political theory and climate change, especially if this is something you are considering writing your thesis about, I highly recommend this class!

If you're interested in why mental health or mental healthcare in the USA is the way it is, then you need to take this class. Matt is an AMAZING professor – he brings a wealth of experience from both psychiatry and econ, and he's great at using that experience to facilitate a class discussion. He's also genuinely interested in supporting students and genuinely concerned for our well–being. The syllabus is awesome, but also manageable; I took the class as a non–concentrator and was able to keep up pretty well in discussions despite not having seen most of it before. It was really cool to put "canonical" authors like Durkheim, Foucault, and Fanon in conversation with more modern authors who focus on mental health, like Arthur Kleinman, Anne Becker, Case and Deaton, and Thomas Insel. One caveat I would mention is that if you're more interested in social theory than you are in mental health, this class may not be for you. We talked about some pretty heavy topics every class (especially suicide), and it can burn you out if you're not prepared to engage with it. As someone who's kind of obsessed with the social environment surrounding mental illness, this was one of my favorite classes I've taken at Harvard, and I loved talking with other people who think about it as much as I do, but it might not be everyone's cup of tea. If it is your cup of tea, though, it's a really good one.

Jeff is great!! He is very accommodating and is willing to meet outside of class. The classroom atmosphere was positive and conducive to learning. That said, I would recommend this class to students with at least some coding background. The pacing of this course is challenging if you do not have any coding experience. Personally, I found this class useful because I learned a new coding skill – how to analyze survey data in R.  However, I think the course would benefit from focusing on either beginners or those with prior coding experience, rather than trying to accommodate both.

This is a required course and you can't really get out of it, but it can definitely still be enjoyable. The discussion posts are nice to reflect and test your understanding about theory. I wish that I went to more office hours with Emma to talk about the parts of text theory I was confused about. Would highly recommend office hours to go over the writing prompt (midterm & final). The reading guides are super useful so use those!!
worse_comment: You have to take this course if you're a Sociology concentrator—if you're not, there are better, more applicable/relevant electives to take.To be frank, this course was a LOT of work and stress. The readings often felt inaccessible, and the Discussion Posts just felt unnecessary. However, the course staff are great! Shai is a fun instructor, and Emma is a PHENOMENAL TF! I think the staff is what makes this course even remotely bearable. Don't be afraid to meet with them if you're struggling at all!Ultimately, my advice is to not go into this course expecting much. While learning the theory was very interesting, it also felt pointless and was very taxing. I will note that I hate doing dense, hard–to–understand readings, which this course had a lot of, so my feelings are very biased and personal. I think this course is a necessary evil, and I will never blame the teaching staff for the ills of theory and how concentrations are designed here.

best_comment: This course was great! Rachel is an attentive and passionate professor. She really cares about us as students and always steps in to provide great feedback and insights.
worse_comment: Professor Meyer is a very helpful instructor with both knowledge of the subject and the tools to help you be a better researcher. The readings are fairly light, but the main thing to worry about is your research project itself

course_title: Junior Tutorial: Social Ties and their Consequences 001
best_comment: As far as sociology concentration requirements go, this is a super fun one to fulfill, especially if you have a topic you enjoy. I would say to stay on top of the readings, and always remember you have less time than you think you do to wrap your head around the concepts and arguments you want to make, complete interviews, do an elaborate literature review, and write 25 pages. To that end, start early, and make life easier for yourself later. also, choose a topic you genuinely are interested in, because you will get to know it well throughout the semester. If you have a chance to take a Junior Tutorial with Joey, definitely do it. He is great, and if you need any accommodations of any kind, he will make sure you have what you need and will always be open to feedback if things need to change throughout the semester.

I really enjoyed this class and highly suggest it. I will say, sometimes it feels like a high school class (mandatory attendance with no exceptions – no phones etc.), but I think it was effective in getting people to participate more. There wasn't a class I felt like i didn't learn, or that I felt dragged on. I appreciated how faced faced it was, and if you figure out how to more effectively read papers the assigned reading isn't as bad as it may seem.  This class really changed the way I think about the world, and I appreciate how they brought real world topics into discussion, it made me feel a lot more connected to what was going on around me. I would take this class a thousand times again and if you have any questions about the why behind the bigger issues affecting us then this class will make you more equipped to keep asking and understanding those questions. BE PREPARED this class has a lot of lectures that go very fast so find ways to keep up. Overall, this class if fairly material heavy.

I really enjoyed this class and highly suggest it. I will say, sometimes it feels like a high school class (mandatory attendance with no exceptions – no phones etc.), but I think it was effective in getting people to participate more. There wasn't a class I felt like i didn't learn, or that I felt dragged on. I appreciated how faced faced it was, and if you figure out how to more effectively read papers the assigned reading isn't as bad as it may seem.  This class really changed the way I think about the world, and I appreciate how they brought real world topics into discussion, it made me feel a lot more connected to what was going on around me. I would take this class a thousand times again and if you have any questions about the why behind the bigger issues affecting us then this class will make you more equipped to keep asking and understanding those questions. BE PREPARED this class has a lot of lectures that go very fast so find ways to keep up. Overall, this class if fairly material heavy.

TAKE THIS CLASS!! This was by far my favorite class this semester. Big concepts like power and the state can feel so confusing but this class breaks things down incredibly well. Mandic is the best and is the most engaging lecturer I have ever had. The coursework is super manageable and tests are fair. This being said the section lead is super important. Kyle––who unfortunately is not staying at Harvard––was 2025 TF and was wonderful. He perfectly balanced Mandic's teaching style. Mandic can get a bit too exited and forget to go over some concepts from class but Kyle always regrounded us and made sure everything made sense.
worse_comment: Definitely take this, though the need to attend every single class for fear of falling behind is scary a bit. I missed a few classes but had no problem catching up due to the teaching staff's care and availability via email.

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Easily one of the best courses that I have taken here. Professor Cross is fantastic and creates a really great classroom community. She has put a lot of thought and effort into this class and it really shows. I learned so much from this class about inequality in the world we live in. If you are remotely considering this class for any reason, take it. All of the assignments and readings are truly worth your time. you Make sure to do all of the readings– class discussion revolves around them, but they are also really interesting and will teach you a lot. I would also recommend doing your eResponses earlier in the semester so that you're not cramming them in at the end!

Professor Dromi is the best! He is a great guy, and I would recommend any student should take a course with him. He is always passionate about his teaching subjects, and he is friendly to converse with.

This course is great but the content is nothing ground breaking and pretty straight forward, super athlete heavy. Don't take this if you want something intellectually stimulating. Though guest lecturers were very interesting and sections were engaging. The workload is manageable, the final project is a group paper.
best_gem_comment: This is an AMAZING course!! You really only have to show up and listen, and it's all super interesting material...especially if you're an athlete or a big sports fan. Definitely recommend for anyone looking for a gem.

best_comment: A great course! I really liked the assignments: they connected well to what we were learning in class and spread out nicely throughout the semester so it was never too overwhelming. You definitely get what you put in—you don't *need* to do a lot to succeed in the class but the readings and course materials are actually really interesting and applicable especially if you are interested in pursuing sociological research more broadly so I definitely recommend you to stay engaged with the course! Dr. Fairchild and the teaching staff are all very knowledgeable, kind, and supportive.
worse_comment: ONLY TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU NEED TO. Worst class I've taken at Harvard – I literally learned nothing yet suffered from harsh grading on assignments that were incredibly boring. Awful teaching team that was cold and not approachable at all. Genuinely dreaded this course every week.

best_comment: Professor Lei is such an incredible teacher – she is very kind and approachable and so dedicated to teaching and supporting students. She explains concepts very clearly and made the class so interesting. Yinan (the TF) is also so sweet and runs section really well – very organized and thorough. The assignments and reading were very engaging and a good level of difficulty.

course_title: Race and Ethnicity in Global and Comparative Perspective 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!! This is arguably the only course at Harvard where I received the academic experience I've been searching for. I enjoyed learning about race and ethnicity (my understanding of which has completely transformed) through several distinct, interesting cases across time and space. Ellis made it a point to apply what we learned to contemporary society, which I found especially valuable. Moreover, he managed to create a laidback (but still engaging) environment that always invited discussion, which I really did appreciate. I will admit that the readings could feel a bit dense at times, though I was taking this course with other courses with very dense readings. I think every student should take this course for how transformative and applicable it is—if you have the space, take this course, and if you don't, make the space!

This course was so eye–opening! Prior to enrolling in this course, I had no idea what mixed methods research was but this course gave me such a great overview of the importance of mixed methods research, what goes into creating a robust mixed methods research proposal, and general criticism in the field. This course is super helpful for creating a thesis proposal as well because we really get into the weeds of designing a robust proposal. I highly recommend this course because we also delve deep into coding exercises for qualitative interviews and it's also helpful to hear from lots of experts in the field about the importance of mixed methods research.

FYRE CO CHAIR CERTIFIED: This class is extremely interesting! There is so much opportunity to relate to what the course is teaching because you yourself were once a kid too! This class did so much to validate me and my childhood experiences. This course is in the  top 2 of my favorite courses I have ever taken at Harvard, and I am a computer science major! The content was extremely interesting and relevant , but Dr.Daniel is also just an excellent, super eloquent, intelligent lecturer ––– She should be a professor !!!! Harvard do better. This course is not difficult, but its not unchallenging either. You usually have to read 60 pages a week, which is so fair, and the readings are always super relevant to what is taught in the course. You get a really good survey of the sociology of childhood and how its changed throughout history. The written assignments are fun and 4–5.5 pages which means you're not slapping on words to a google doc trying to get to the page limit. The final exam is also super fair, although you did need to study to do well. It was very much like an AP exam. I think the most challenging part of this course to me was being able to identify social constructions of children while reading or consuming media. This definitely came with practice for me. To me its analogous to trying to correct an essay but your brain keeps autocorrecting any errors you come across. Overall such a wholesome course! I was never bored, and I was always excited to come to class.
worse_comment: If you have not taken a sociology course before, then this class may be up your alley! The first six weeks or so are spent on social constructions, so if you have some background in sociology or adjacent fields, that might feel a little repetitive. Also, keep in mind that there is a sit down final, which feels a bit unnecessary given the content.

course_title: Popular Culture and Social Theory: Critiquing Society through Television, Literature, and Comedy 001
best_comment: MY FAVORITE CLASS THIS SEMESTER – professor is awesome, content is genuinely interesting, and honestly I would describe this class as fun. Definitely would recommend.

TAKE TAKE TAKE this class. You will love it so much. The topics are fascinating and the lectures extremely engaging. The teaching staff is very passionate about the subject, and actively incorporate feedback from the class to ensure an open learning environment. What I especially liked about this course is how much the teaching staff genuinely cares about the students and issues studied. Prof. Mandic and Achraf are the most involved educators I met here at Harvard both in the classroom and beyond, through  the programs they organize or the opportunities they promote to students in section. The Refugee Fieldwork Program offers a possibility for students to deepen the knowledge accumulated in this course while serving communities in need for it over the summer. Only a human who cares deeply about both the topic, not just as something he teaches, but as a part of society he lives to shine light upon would be so invested to create an opportunity like this at Harvard for undergraduates. I cannot imagine a class more worth taking here than this one. You will learn so much about various aspects of forced migration and gain a deep understanding of how different asylum systems work. You will begin to see the issues surrounding forced migration from multiple perspectives and be encouraged to think about feasible solutions to address them. The assignments are super fun and engaging, and quite flexible in the way that you can research deeper the topic in the class that you are most intrigued by, while also being held to the academic standards of how Achraf would call it, "the next big thing". This is an amazing class and my favorite one at Harvard so far (convinced me to do sociology), so TAKE IT!!!!!!

This is a really great class! It is pretty light, I never really stressed about the class and the reading load was pretty light (50 pages/week max) compared to other classes. It was a pretty chill class I could have on the back burner for a lot of the semester, and the final paper affords a ton of flexibility which is super nice. The grading is fair to easy, with a ton of participation. Overall, I came away with some knowledge of some interesting case studies and having had some interesting conversations. Don't take this class if you are looking for something revolutionary or life–changing––the concepts are pretty intuitive––but take it if you are looking for a more chill, fun course that is still interesting! Professor Swindle was awesome, he was super sweet, invested in his students, and passionate. By the end of the semester, you will have gained knowledge about interesting cases and topics such as gender and economic inequality in South Korea, rising homophobia around the world, and redlining, as well as general themes that string these topics together. I took this class as a freshman and it is definitely appropriate for freshmen and/or people who are not in the social sciences. You will also get to know the other students well, as there are many projects and group in–class activities which are fun!
worse_comment: Very interesting class, the professor is very enthusiastic about the topics. Weekly writing applications are a bit annoying to prepare for but otherwise low workload.

course_title: Incarceration and Inequality in the United States 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! I know its not offered next year, but this class will probably go down as my most favorite class I have taken at Harvard. Each week, the convos were so interesting and I left knowing so much more and more able to ready my own argument. Everyone in the US should honestly take this class. Cannot recommend it enough

Take this class! It is definitely not a gem, Professor Halford is a tough grader, but it is a really interesting course and you will learn a lot! Come prepared to read and write! The subjects you discuss in this class are very interesting which makes the class better as a whole! It was a new class this year and I imagine it will get better and better over time.

I recommend this course! I learned a lot of different statistical methods including, poisson regression, ordered logistic regression, multinomial logit models, bootstrapping, a general overview on causal inference, inverse probability weighting, and difference–in–differences. In this course, you will complete problem sets in RStudio to better solidify your knowledge of the concepts. The course readings can be challenging, but the material is important and Xiang's lectures, lecture slides, and sample code are helpful. If you are hoping to increase your statistical skills, I definitely recommend taking this class!

I learned a lot from this course, and I definitely recommend it. Chris is a phenomenal professor who clearly cares about his students and goes above and beyond to support them. Be prepared to read and write reflections on your reading on core classical social theorists. Class is very engaging and helpful to solidify core concepts.

I definitely recommend this class! You will learn a lot and read many important readings. You will get various ways to assess and deepen your understanding of the material, including leading class discussions, class conversations, reading responses, and a final paper of your choosing. Christina is additionally a phenomenal professor who goes above and beyond to support her students. I definitely recommend this class!

Elementary Tagalog has been one of the best experiences of my college career so far. This course gave me so much room to grow in my language proficiency and connect with my culture while meeting peers who were trying to do the same. Ate Lady is one of the most caring, engaged educators at Harvard, and taking any class with her is a privilege. I look forward to continuing to learn Tagalog because of the passion and enthusiasm she shows for her work. If you have ever wanted to learn the language and learn more about the Philippines while you're at it, this is the best place for you.

This is such a great class!! Even if you're not a heritage speaker and/or got bumped up from intermediate, you will do well. Ate Lady makes sure that all students feel comfortable speaking and gives lots of support and guidance.

Richard ji is the best. His self–deprecating humor and Socratic disposition made this class genuinely entertaining. His care for his students is also evident, both at a human level and with regards to learning the curriculum. Going to class felt like hanging out with friends and having fun; by the end of the course I'd say that we as students had formed a nice little community. 10/10 would recommend.

This class is an absolute GEM!!!! Take it, Hajnalka Ji handles this subject with so much depth and care, and you're in good hands with her. She cares a lot about the subject as well as the health of her students, and isn't too strict. This class builds a lot on 101A, so the grammar and logic based approach to the Hindi/Urdu language she begins there is supremely helpful (not that you can even recieve credit for this course without 101A). In terms of coursework, its workbook exercises, one weekly assignment, and some Urdu practice. Easily manageable, and you should basically treat this class like a PSET–based one, because that's basically what it is. Not to say that the class is hard: the grading is SUPER lenient, and you have as much time to finish classwork as you need, although you really should try to get it in weekly. There's only one final, but it's only 30% of the grade and you'll get plenty of time to practice and learn the language. The only bad part of this class is having to do the conversations in the workbook (1 per unit), but that's tedious, not hard. Other than that, the class environment is super welcoming and great. You'll get plenty of time to talk about what interests you, and you're allowed to bring food to class as long as you are clean about it. Hajnalka is super understanding of student's circumstances as well, she's really knowledgeable and smart too.
best_gem_comment: This class is an absolute GEM!!!! Take it, Hajnalka Ji handles this subject with so much depth and care, and you're in good hands with her. She cares a lot about the subject as well as the health of her students, and isn't too strict. This class builds a lot on 101A, so the grammar and logic based approach to the Hindi/Urdu language she begins there is supremely helpful (not that you can even recieve credit for this course without 101A). You'll get plenty of time to talk about what interests you, and you're allowed to bring food to class as long as you are clean about it. Hajnalka is super understanding of student's circumstances as well, she's really knowledgeable and smart too.

best_comment: take this class if you are at all interested in learning hindi/urdu better! this gives you what it takes to comfortably understand the langauge and begin to engage in a meaningful way. keep yourself disciplined with assignments.

course_title: Bollywood and Beyond: Commercial Cinema, Language and Culture in South Asia 001
best_comment: A truly enjoyable class! Set aside a regular time each week to watch the movie with friends and it'll be so much fun. Richard ji's passion about South Asian culture really shines when he discusses movies, so be ready for the 2.5 hours to go by in a flash.
Take this course! It's a great language, a great class, and it has a great instructor with great vibes

course_title: Introduction to Statistics and Data Science 001
best_comment: This class is hard. Listen to what everyone is telling you. The problem sets are A LOT and challenging, but if you go to office hours, you can get it done and understand it pretty well. I only got through this course because I BUSTED my a** going to min. 3 office hours a week (coming from someone who had no coding / stat experience) and I'm still pretty sure I failed the final LOL. The lecture goes really fast and is super hard to follow, but James and Mark both were so willing to stay after class and explain things to me (because I'm slow). That, I really appreciated. And I can tell how much they both love this course and topics. The OH and TFs were also amazing and I credit them for being able to get through this course.The midterm wasn't bad but the final....no words. I felt so overwhelmed and unprepared for it because the second half of the course goes by so quickly. Be ready to commit a large amount of time and effort to this class and collaborate with peers!
worse_comment: *PSA that they'll probably change this course next semester, because it seems like they have taken to doing that*It seems that a decision was made — unannounced, as far as I can tell, before the semester or at the start of the course — to pivot this course from focusing on how to use R, with some instruction in the fundamentals of statistics, to focusing on the fundamentals of statistics, with some instruction in how to use R. That's a fine choice, in my view, and very possibly even the right one, given the advent of LLMs that can help you figure out how to do relatively simple programming, which is all most people in the course will ever need to do with R. My major problem with this course — and it was a ~really~ major problem for me — was that it was totally inconsistent in aligning policies, practices, and assignments with this (seeming) emphasis.In lecture, we almost exclusively learned about statistics, with only very brief discussion of how we apply the concepts from lecture in R. If you consult the lectures slides, most of which ran between 40 and 60 slides, you’d find that perhaps four or five contain any code whatsoever, and after the first week or two, we received zero instruction in how to code ‘well’ — good syntax, in–line commenting, etc.I found it confusing, then, that our problem sets were ~exclusively~ in R, often involving only relatively trivial applications of the math we learned in lecture. For most problem sets, I spent substantially more time trying to figure out how to do something in R than considering how to solve the problem. There’s nothing per se wrong with that, but it was clearly out of step with the lectures, and as such it created lots of confusion, frustration, and discouragement for students, and less learning than a different approach might’ve.I was especially frustrated when the midterm rolled around, because it was exclusively pen–and–paper math with no coding in R. That’s fine and probably actually good for a class focusing on statistics — I learned a lot from it and found it rigorous — but it was the first time we’d been asked to apply stats concepts flexibly in complicated scenarios, which the problem sets basically did not have us do. I was really frustrated studying for the midterm, for this reason, and I did well, but many of my classmates did not.The final exam, perplexingly and with no real warning, changed the focus yet again. It was divided into two halves — one in R, one on paper — and the computer section was dramatically harder than the paper math section. In significant part, the computer section was much harder because we had hardly been taught how to code by the course and had never had to code without access to lecture notes, office hours, and LLMs that can advise on programming basics, so many students simply couldn’t execute certain things in R. Meanwhile, the paper section was almost trivially easy, much easier than the midterm, and only required about half the allotted 90 minutes. There were also some more run–of–the–mill problems that bear noting. In particular, I found lectures did not add much value over reading the slides, though I attended almost all lectures. There was, in my opinion, too little elaboration about some really key concepts (we never received explanation about what a t–distribution is, even though t–distributions followed us through like half the course). There was also a lot of unintroduced math terminology that I have to imagine confused people who have taken little–to–no college math, which is many people in this course. Finally, I really think well–known courses owe it to students to announce that they’re changing their focus when they are: I would probably have taken this course anyway if I knew it was going to emphasize statistics more heavily, but that probably wouldn’t have been the case for some others.
best_gem_comment: Take this class if you want a gem that fulfills your scientific reasoning requirement. It's so chill and the content is basically the same as AP stats.

course_title: Introduction to Statistics for Life Sciences 001
best_comment: I enjoyed this class! It was on the harder end of moderate and the easier end of difficult. I would recommend it but be ready to put in the time and effort it requires.Julie (the prof) is awesome! She brings baked goods and other treats to class very often and the class events at the end of the semester were fun too.The class starts off pretty straight forward but gets considerably more complicated towards the end, so make sure that you keep up with content and go to office hours regularly to clarify any confusion. The psets take a long time (like 6–10 hours depending on how comfortable you are with stats), so get started early, and make sure you can make it to office hours to ask questions before it's due.
best_gem_comment: Julie is such a gem, so kind and helpful, super responsive and helpful. This class is kinda difficult but she helps you through it. would reccomend just for her

course_title: Introduction to Data Science for Sports Analytics 001
best_comment: The course content is pretty interesting if your interested in sports like I am. Make sure that you've taken at least Stat 100 (or something equivalent) and have pretty good R and general stats knowledge. The only downside was the organization of the course. Psets were often released late and there were times that the TFs did not have the full solutions to the psets, making it difficult to help us. Also, pset grades were given back to us very late. This was the first iteration of the course, which I believe explains all those issues, as Kevin had to make up all the material from scratch as the class moved along. Kevin is a really cool teacher, and he presented the information well. We also get into some ML concepts towards the end of the class, which was pretty cool. I am very confident that the next iteration of the course will be great, since all the psets will have been made already, which should fix most (if not all) of the organizational issues. Overall, I still enjoyed my time taking this class, and if I could go back in time I would definitely do it again!
worse_comment: The Good: –Introduction to Elo and BT models–Good coverage of interpreting logistic regression modelsThe Bad (and there’s a whole lot of it):–Mixed effects models were not explained very well. Generally the slides don't match up to what is said in lecture. Overall slides should be self containing and explanations should be made around those slides.–Very poor turnaround time where I still don't know how I did on 2 of the 5 of the HWs.–TFs need to be held accountable. As a stats concentrator who has taken lots of stats classes in FAS, this was the most unaccountable set of TFs I have ever encountered in the department. They were not held accountable, and I think it’s absolutely unfair to take a class and not even get feedback on a subset of assignments I did. Those TFs should have been replaced during the semester. We got feedback about our final project 48 hours before the due date. That is unacceptable, and I don’t expect any apologies but the lack of oversight and accountability with zero implications on the TFs is not acceptable.

course_title: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001
best_comment: 209b is really fantastic, and the topics we discuss feel very relevant and current. I had mixed feelings about 209a, but I really enjoyed 209b. I'd say that while the general workload of the homework is roughly the same in 209b as in 209a, I found the homework in 209b to be more interesting and enjoyable to complete. I believe that 209a and 209b truly built the foundation for the SM in Data Science program, and I'm glad I took both. Pavlos, Chris, and Nitesh are all fantastic instructors, and I am grateful that I had the opportunity to learn from them.
worse_comment: You can learn a lot from the class but the experience is not easy.

best_comment: If you're reading this, you probably have to take this course; there aren't really any alternatives. Here are my thoughts on the course:– The material is incredibly interesting, more so than STAT 110 in my opinion. This course is also much less crowded than STAT 110, so the office hours are less hectic. If you liked intro–level stats (e.g., AP Stats), you'll be able to prove/better understand some cool results you may have seen before. You'll also be introduced to new concepts that are really cool.– Both professors are very passionate about the topic, and it shows through lecture. But I think the majority of the learning is done in section (since the TFs often explain things the best in m opinion).– If you're wondering what background you need, I think it's a strong understanding of probability from STAT 110 and single–variable calculus (chain rule, product rule, and Taylor series). Also, a surprising amount of algebra shows up, so get comfortable with solving systems of equations, isolating variables, etc. (and don't forget your log rules)!– Finally, this course is notorious for being difficult and time–consuming, but you'll be able to survive! Especially with the right approach.Here's my advice on how to survive:– Find a good section TF. I actually went to 2 sections most week because I felt like I didn't learn much in lecture.– Find good OH, and keep a routine. Start early to avoid the Thursday rush.– Find good p–set buddies. They can save your life, especially with the code. Related, it's a blessing that ChatGPT is allowed, but sometimes, it gets the code wrong, so be ready to debug and work through the process with some prompt–engineering.– For the exams, do EVERY practice exam as that gives you the best sense of what to expect. They're hard, so don't be discouraged if you don't understand a question at first!Wish you the best of luck with the course!
worse_comment: if you are taking this im so sorry. if you are taking this with two other pset classes like i did... you can do this...i will be honest this course is horrible at times. it will make you feel stupid and question your place in statistics. but if you like it even a little keep going. the moments where it's fun make the course. the teaching staff with exceptions may not be welcoming. they will often say comments that make you feel horrible about yourself and like you don't belong, but as a first gen student please know that there is often a certain type of student that goes into this class with confidence, and just because it's not usually us doesn't mean it's never us. be that student. read that freaking textbook, do section practice problems weekly, not just in the month leading up to the final, and study your ass off. it's not impossible, just insanely difficult. stick through it––through the people who make you feel stupid and through the test that wasn't designed for you. if i can do it (i did horrendous in stat 110 but am also horribly stubborn) you can do it. do it imperfectly, do it wrong. just try and you got this.
