course_title: Introduction to Bioinformatics and Statistical Genetics 001
best_comment: Great course and James is awesome. He really cares about making sure you actually understand what's going on –– a classmate & I once spent probably 4 hours in his office hours, and he patiently helped us through the material the entire time. Also such a cool and fun guy!! Very passionate about his field and has lots of fun stories whenever you chat with him. Very rewarding and cool class and I really felt like I learned new things!!!
worse_comment: This course is forgiving schedule wise, but the problem sets can be daunting. If you’re not well–versed with R or struggle with concepts from Stat 110 or 111, expect to spend a lot of time at office hours.

best_comment: Stat 117 was fantastic!!!! Definitely my favorite elective course I've taken. The discussions we had in class were always thoughtful, engaging, and nuanced, which were made possible because of our incredible professor! Dr. Parmigiani has put so much thought and care into the semi–flipped structure of the class, as well as the class notes and materials for each lesson, and his extensive experience in this field adds so much depth to our discussion. All the homeworks and projects contribute uniquely to our understanding of the material––the homeworks do an awesome job helping us to digest the material, and then the projects give us the opportunity to take our understanding and innovate on it even further. Overall, this class is very, very well–designed and has taught me so much about biostatistics as well as a general intuition around how to handle data and use it to the best of our ability!

Tracy is a very kind and understanding professor with really helpful office hours. The psets aren't bad and the quizzes are helpful to stay on top of material. At times the course is very equation focused and doesn't always make clear the purpose/application of the theories behind them.
worse_comment: Worthwhile class in Stat. Not a crazy workload, but topics/exams sometimes difficult.

best_comment: 141 offers a good mixture of theory and application in spatial statistics and is not the most stressful class. Alex is a great instructor and very knowledgeable on the topic and provides a lot of help in office hours to make the course more accessible. One of the reasons I took this class was because of how highly–recommended Alex was as a professor, and he did not disappoint here. The course was very organized, and lecture notes and assignments were always available on time, and assignments were handed back in a timely manner. In fact, the final exam was graded within 24 hours of its due date. However, the level of math is greater than comparable 100 level courses and may be a bit daunting, so if you don't have a strong math background at the level of Math 112 you may get a bit confused early on in the course, though Alex will do his best to explain these complicated topics at a more simple level since students in the class came from all different backgrounds, ranging from undergraduate sophomores to biostats PhD candidates. The TF, Sarika, was also great, though I'm not sure if she'll be the TF in the next iteration of this class in 2027.The content itself is somewhat hard to motivate, and I felt that I wasn't able to really grasp what was going on or see why it was important. Spatial statistics is still a somewhat esoteric field, though its application to economics is growing. However, it's rooted in geology and mining and so is still largely associated with those fields, though Alex does do a good job of applying it to many different areas. Still, it didn't feel like I was learning as much useful information as I was in my other stats classes, though that may have just been due to the level of math and theory in this class being greater than in other stat courses.I think this course would make a lot more sense to take with a time series background, since it really just extends the concepts from time series (such as autoregression) to multiple dimensions. So taking a class like STAT 171 or 131 before this would be very helpful as well.This class has 7 psets (including a short one due the first week of class), due roughly every other week. The class is split into 3 units (point processes, lattice processes, and geostatistics), so each unit has a theory pset followed by an application pset, so the class keeps a good balance between the two. Alex has "numerical examples" available on Canvas that help a lot with the coding (R) psets, and office hours are provided throughout the week to help with these assignments. They are graded generously as well and are worth 65 percent of your grade.The course has no midterm and has a take home final exam, for which office hours are still provided if you need assistance. The take home exam is very reasonable and no more difficult than the psets, so if you understood what you were doing on the psets you'll be fine for the final.Overall, this class probably won't be the most stressful for you due to its pset/exam structure and may be a more chill way to learn about these extensions of linear modeling. However, you might want to take a look into what spatial statistics covers to tell if you'd enjoy taking this course and to tell how much you'd take away from it.

STAT 149 is a very well–organized and straightforward class that I would recommend to any stat concentrator or secondary. I'll discuss the pros and cons of this class, and why you might (not) want to choose it over 139/244. This review will be quite long but should answer basically any question you have about the course and be sufficient to decide whether it is a course that you'd like to take.Required preparation: You can do well in this class even if your only preparation is STAT 110. We do use likelihoods and MLEs quite a bit throughout the class, so 111 would definitely be helpful, but is not completely necessary. Presumably you're taking this class if you're a stat concentrator though, so you will have probably taken 111 anyway. Lastly, 139 is by no means needed for this class, hence why 149 can substitute for it in the modeling requirement for the stats concentration. I think around half of the people in 149 this semester did not take 139. However, I would strongly recommend taking 139 as well if you plan to take this course, as it really does not make conceptual sense to learn basically every type of generalized linear model except for a standard linear regression with normally–distributed errors (which is the focus of 139). This course will also be far more satisfying having completed 139 and you will be able to more clearly see why we are doing certain things. Some topics are also retaught from scratch from 139, so you'll be slightly ahead having completed that before this course.Content: The course covers different generalized linear models (e.g. logistic regression, Poisson regression, multinomial regression) as well as some extensions beyond these models, including some more ML–related topics (smoothers, GAMs, decision trees) and related non–GLMs (negative binomial, beta–binomial, proportional odds). The theoretical basis for this class is rooted in exponential dispersion families (essentially NEFs if you remember those from 111), and their log–likelihoods/MLEs. We touch on topics such as model selection, diagnostics, and missing data methods as well.Course structure: Mark is a great professor and is very well–organized. Lecture notes are well–written and contain basically everything you need to complete the homeworks and do well on exams. If you don't want to attend a 9 AM lecture twice a week, the lecture notes (or the Panopto recording) are entirely sufficient. In fact, you can complete nearly everything on the homework assignments solely with the lecture notes (and associated R script provided on Canvas). Lecture notes and homeworks will be posted far in advance in contrast to some other stats courses where homeworks are released late or not at all. There are office hours and sections provided, though sections were sparsely attended since the lecture notes are so well–written and self–contained, and since the course enrollment was relatively small. If you come to lecture or watch the recordings, you will probably not need to go to section.Homeworks: There are 6 regular homework assignments throughout the semester, due roughly every other week on Monday. As I mentioned, they can be completed basically with just the lecture notes. They are mostly applied and in R, though there will occasionally be more theoretical questions. However, these assignments are very straightforward and should not require that much stress or time. Mark guides you through the applied problems and so you'll almost never have to look up an obscure command to do something. These assignments should take no more than 2 or 3 hours if you're referring to the lecture notes for guidance.Mini–projects: In addition to the 6 regular homeworks, there are also 3 "mini–projects" which are really just additional psets, but the mini–projects have you explore one dataset 3 times throughout the second half of the semester to implement tools as we learn them in class. So in reality this class has 9 homework assignments, but these mini–projects are slightly shorter than regular homeworks and usually due in the weeks in between the due dates of two homeworks. They also only start in the second half of the class, following spring break and the first midterm.Exams: This class has 2 exams: a midterm and a final. However, it's more accurate to describe them as Midterm 1 and Midterm 2, as they are both the same length (75 minutes). Midterm 2 is notably not cumulative which is why it is still only 75 minutes long (though still held during finals period), though in reality you learn so many more things in the second half of the class that it not being cumulative doesn't really change anything, and you will still need to have a strong understanding of many of the concepts from the first half anyway. The exams are not really that tricky and mostly test interpretation of model outputs and related concepts. There are some theoretical concepts covered on exams, though no more so than computing a log likelihood or an MLE. However, there are some more obscure formulas required to complete certain parts that are not provided to you, so it's a good thing that you're allowed to bring in a cheat sheet for the exams. Make sure that you make a good cheat sheet or you may lose out on a large number of points because you didn't have the right formula written down on your cheat sheet (i.e. Newton–Raphson or an F test statistic). Exam averages hovered around 70 percent, not too much different from 110/111, though the exams in this class were definitely far easier and more predictable than those. If you take the practice exams, review the lecture notes, and make a good cheat sheet, you should be fine.Grade distribution: About half the class gets a final grade in the A range, and about half in the B range. But again, if you put in a decent level of effort and stay on top of the class, you should be able to get an A range grade. Mark is very fair in how he determines and curves grades, so it is really only if you are unable or unwilling to dedicate enough time and effort to the class (which is again, far less than 110/111) that you would do worse than you'd have liked to.Overall workload: I rarely spent more than 2 or 3 hours each week outside of class on 149. Homework assignments were very straightforward and could be quickly completed using the lecture notes. This workload increased the weeks of the two exams, though you probably don't need to do much more than review the lecture notes and homeworks, make your cheat sheet, and complete the practice exams.Now that I've summarized the class, I'll address whether one should take it over 139 or 244.139  vs 149: 149 is essentially an extension of 139 and allows for far more flexibility in modeling than what 139 does with OLS regression. That being said, 149 can reasonably be taken without any knowledge from 139 and is actually an easier/less time consuming class than 139 (you can verify this by comparing Q guides). So if you just want to get this modeling requirement out of the way and maybe if you have a very busy fall schedule, 149 may be preferable. But if you want to have a complete, widely–applicable knowledge base of understanding, you'd be best off taking both 139 and 149. While there are some redundancies between the two, taking both gives you basically everything you need to statistically model basically anything. Another little–discussed note of importance is that 149 is approved as an Econ elective (as of Spring 2025) while 139 is not, which may be of interest to Stat–Econ double concentrators.149 vs 244: 149 is a very applied class and does not get too much into the weeds of the more theoretical concepts. It is mainly focused on interpreting results and choosing the appropriate model. While this means 149 is very applicable, if you're more theory–oriented you may want to take 244 instead, which combines 139 and 149 into one graduate–level class heavy in linear algebra, calculus, and proofs. It also meets the modeling requirement, but does not cover all of the application discussed in 139 and 149. So I'd recommend 244 only if you're more interested in the theory (and perhaps going for advanced course track honors/concurrent masters). Though you can of course take 139/149 and then take 244 as well if you'd like, which is what I plan to do.Overall, you should consider taking 149 if you want a low–stress yet extremely useful class where you'll learn a lot without having the class feel like a burden on your schedule.

this class was pretty interesting and the concepts are definitely really useful if you want to do anything related to markov chains in the future. I would say that the lectures weren't the strongest part, because concepts were actually taught in a quite confusing order and halfway through the course I stopped relying on lectures at all and started just reading the textbook because the key ideas weren't distilled clearly at all (in lecture it felt like everything could possibly be a side tangent and the super key ideas weren't emphasized so it would all jumble together sometimes). The psets are manageable towards the end they just became textbook problems which are significantly easier, and there are lots of office hours and support. I will say that sometimes it was hard to get a clear gauge on what the exams would be like, because there would be challenging content in lecture, then easy things on the psets, and then medium questions on the section notes, and then really hard practice exam problems so it was unclear what we should be preparing for and what the expectations for the exam actually were. Also the practice exam solutions were released pretty late and then the solutions themselves had lots of mistakes and also were written with little to no explanation and clarification. The textbook is great though and the information is interesting, I just think there could be a better way to manage the class and make it more enjoyable for students.
worse_comment: vignette that sums up this year's iteration of stat 171: the final exam had "spring 2022" as a footer and the section handouts had outdated course staff contact information as a subject stochastic processes is very interesting – learning about markov chains and poisson processes in more depth and branching out (pun intended) to topics like branching processes and brownian motion was a very fun sequel 110 lectures and the textbook were pretty straightforward and exam grading was fairly generousok now onto the qualms: im not sure if this year was a one–off in terms of who's teaching, but all of the section materials and practice exams were from last year which meant they tended to be significantly more difficult and/or not super relevant to what we were learningnevermind the fact that practice exam solutions were ... not comprehensive at all (eg putting true false answers with no explanation...) and VERY delayed (the solutions to the final which was at the end of exam period were released THE DAY BEFORE as a handwritten running–off–the–page set of pages)also for the psets like 80% of the questions were "do this textbook problem" which i guess is fine but 1) sometimes the book had typos and 2) you could at least provide the problem in the pset itself?? and more generally i wish the pset problems made us think more bc half of them were basic computation problems and then the exams were harderit's just tiny details like this that made me disappointed in how all the supplemental parts of the class were run bc the content is fascinating and lectures were good but dealing with everything else was mildly infuriating sometimes

best_comment: This is a super well–taught, fun course. Causal inference is super important, but I feel like the first time I learned it (in stat 111), I came away super confused about the concepts. Susan is such a wonderful professor. A lot of the derivations we do in class are honestly super cool. While you won't have to remember most of them for the exams, they really provide motivation for what we do in the class. And the exams are way more conceptual than the lectures would suggest. Definite recommend.

This course was interesting but covers a lot of material the overlaps with other courses. If you have already taken STAT at the level of 139/149 and CS at the level of 181, it might just be best to choose a different course. For me, a lot of the material overlapped with things I’ve learned in other courses, but the psets were pretty fun stat problems and I really enjoyed the final project (implementing ML solution to applied paper) and midterm presentation (teaching a mini–lecture on a stat research paper). This class did do something the other courses didn’t, however: it helped to give more insight into stat research. Pragya always gave us papers to read for more information on certain topics and is incredibly involved in the stat research scene.tldr; materiał repeats from other courses like STAT 139/149/109a and CS181, but gives nice introduction to stat research
worse_comment: I appreciated the course content, but I found the course staff disorganized, unhelpful, and sometimes rude, which made it difficult to engage fully. In my experience at Harvard, I’ve rarely encountered this level of frustration, which was quite disappointing.

best_comment: This was a great follow–up to 210! I really enjoyed the material, and the homework problems were fun, especially the extra credit problems. Mark is a great teacher too.

I originally told my friends that I would joke around and put nothing but “Gem” on my Qguide review, but as the only undergrad in the course this year (now Pragya knows exactly who is writing this so I better watch what I say), I feel like I should accept at least a little bit of responsibility and give an actual review for any undergrads who are thinking of taking this course. So here are my thoughts (mostly for undergrads, PhDs are welcome to skip this essay as you are forced to take this class):My preparation: I am a junior who took Math 25A/B, Stat 210, and 211. I had not taken Stat 212 or any other math course before taking 213. I don’t think a deep understanding of measure theory is really needed for this course, but I’m sure it helps if you have one.Material: 4.6/5. The material is very foundational and if you are very interested in statistics (which you probably are given you are reading the 213 Qguide in the first place), you will love it. The course is broadly divided into three parts: estimation (the longest one comprising most of the semester), hypothesis test, and Bayesian inference (which lasts for about a week).Starting with estimation, the first few weeks on the unit can be rather dry. In the words of Pragya herself, she doesn’t exactly like the material in these weeks due to them feeling more analysis–y than statistics–y and I completely agree; the number of assumptions in some theorems is so large that they become a pain to check through whenever you are working on homework. I don’t think these weeks were bad by any means, but they were definitely not the best either.These problems mostly end by the time we discuss QMD, which may seem like the bashiest, why–does–this–exist definition when you first learn them, but you will quickly learn how useful they are for the rest of the semester; it’s actually astonishing how much QMD gets used as the most important assumption in so many theorems despite how ugly the definition is. So the estimation unit is basically divided into two halves: the first half which is dry and the second half which utilizes QMD. So if you have hatred for analysis, you may not like the course at the beginning, but I do promise that it will get better as it goes on.For the hypothesis test unit, Pragya does a great job at explaining why we should test the asymptotic power of different hypothesis testing methods using an alternative that gets harder and harder as the sample size increases. The motivation is great, and using LeCam’s Third Lemma to get results for this is pretty satisfying. The one issue I had however is that we don’t exactly derive many ways to get the asymptotic power under the alternatives in class nor in the notes. For example, for the Likelihood–Ratio Test, we learned about the asymptotic distribution of the test statistic under the null, but we didn’t really discuss what happens under a sequence of alternatives except in the problem set where we did it only for the Gaussian case. It would have been helpful to better integrate the measure theory that came before this because as it stands, it doesn’t feel like I learned that much about how to find the power under sequences of alternatives. Nonetheless, a great unit; also extending the idea of a most powerful test to an asymptotically most powerful test was very interesting.Finally, for the Bayesian unit: It needs to be longer. One week of Bayesian statistics that virtually only aims to prove the Bernstein–von–Mises Theorem really doesn’t provide much at all for Bayesian statistics. I do get that this is supposed to be a foundational course and statistics began mostly from a frequentist perspective, but I definitely think that as a class that is supposed to prepare PhDs for research, it should give a wider view of Bayesian inference. This may be difficult to do since the material is pretty packed already, but I definitely think that the estimation unit was too long and some parts of it (example: perhaps proof of asymptotic normality of MLE? It is an important result but the proof was long and felt unmotivated for the most part.) can be cut to give some more room for Bayesian stuff. I enjoyed what existed of Bayesian inference in the course nevertheless.Lectures: 4.8/5. Pragya is a great lecturer and makes it incredibly obvious that she knows what she is talking about. She also occasionally makes jokes that integrate into what she was talking about perfectly, which gives the lectures a little spark that I’ve only seen Pragya be able to accomplish. The only complaint I have is that the lectures can be a bit dry sometimes (especially in the estimation unit), but this mostly just occurs on topics that are dry in the first place.Problem Sets: 4.3/5. There are biweekly problem sets, and there are 5 total with one drop. Let me make this clear: Unless you are more of a math major than a statistics major (even then I feel this may apply), Stat 213 is NOT easier than Stat 211. The problem sets are less of “find the one hard–to–see trick” that Stat 211 often employed. The difficulty of Stat 213 homework comes from the difficulty of the material itself (not to say Stat 211 had easy material, but it was definitely easier than 213). Stat 213 material is packed and we don’t go over applications to all of the theorems; these applications are moved to the problem sets, and this can make the homework very difficult. This isn’t really problematic, but just something you should be aware of going into this course. As for grading, I would sometimes lose points for “formality,” but I’m not sure exactly where the formality points lie as they can be very subjective and the staff solutions can seem short and less formal as well. Another thing to be aware of.One thing I should mention though: I utterly failed to befriend PhD students in this class, so I basically worked on the problem sets alone. I’m sure the homework is a lot easier if you are less introverted than me and actually get to know some PhD students lol.However, one big problem that makes my opinion of problem sets be lower than it deserves: The first two problems in the fourth assignment were in the section notes. I didn’t realize this, so I basically had to solve this from scratch. This leads to two outcomes, both of which are problematic: 1. Someone who didn’t read the section notes tries to solve the problem. Then they are disadvantaged by those who did read it. 2. Someone who did read the section notes copies the solution. Then they are disadvantaged by the fact they didn’t really learn from the problem. Either way, this is a problem; I strongly believe that no problem presented in section should be on the homework. These two problems weren’t exactly the hardest problems in problem sets so it isn’t as bad as it could have been, but something to keep in mind for the course heading forward.My advice for undergrads: TL;DR: If you are in the following set, I would recommend taking the course:{Took analysis} \cap (({Interested in stats} \cap {Took measure theory}) \cup {REALLY interested in stats}) \cap {Have time for this course}. I was in the {REALLY interested in stats} set and not in the {Took measure theory} set (which made it more challenging for me), and I have no regrets about taking this course. It’s very foundational and the material is legitimately interesting. I still love the way sequences of more difficult alternative hypotheses were presented as well as how much QMD can be used for good results. If you really love statistics, I can’t see yourself not enjoying this course. So unless you think this course will be too much of a hassle with your schedule, take it! I would also recommend taking it your sophomore/junior year as it can be difficult to manage this your senior year especially if you want to write a thesis. But definitely have a Plan B in case you find this class to be overwhelming.And be warned: There are 24 hour take–home midterm and final, and those are brutal.That concludes my essay. Hopefully any undergrads reading this found it helpful.For Pragya: Thank you for a great semester! I’m sure I wasn’t the most talented undergrad you’ve had during your time teaching this course (I would actually bet I’m the least talented undergrad you’ve had in this course lol), but I truly enjoyed Stat 213 and the material was so interesting. I got a lot out of this class, and I hope you continue to teach Stat 213 as you are amazing!
worse_comment: If you want to learn M and Z–estimation theory, local asymptotics, local testing, etc., and why they're useful, this class is a good excuse to do so.  Do note that you will mostly be teaching yourself these materials as the professor's presentation and TF were not particularly helpful. For the poor STAT department students who have to take this class as part of their qualifying exam material, my sympathy goes out to you. Also something is seriously wrong in the STAT department that the gender breakdown of this class was over 20 male students with only 3 women taking the class...  Speaking to some of the students about it, people told me that many people warned them not to apply to the Harvard Statistics department as a woman.  I didn't see gender discrimination that I noticed occur in this class, but do be warned that if you're a woman or non–binary, you will be one of very very few people who are not men in this class.

best_comment: I recommend you take this course if you are interested in reinforcement learning. The lectures cover complicated content, but Professor Murphy is enthusiastic and helpful, and the course does not have that much homework, beyond daily class quizzes (less work than they sound) and a final project. Holistically, if you are a grad student and reinforcement learning is even remotely relevant to you, I strongly recommend you take this course. You will learn a lot and still have time for research.
worse_comment: Start the project as early as possible. I was still generating results the day the paper was due and that could have been avoided.

course_title: Deep Statistics: AI and Earth Observations for Sustainable Development 001
best_comment: A really nice opportunity overall. Take this course if you're interested in ways Data Science and geospatial data can be used for humanitarian interventions. Great concepts learned in general about Data Science that are widely applicable. Also, the chance to learn about all of these from Xiao–Li is such an amazing opportunity – he has lots of experience and he is very interested in helping the students succeed and be more interested in the high–level view on Data Science too. As you'll find out if you take the course, there isn't ever any free lunch. In anything. The grading can be maybe just a bit harsh, especially on the project, so do make sure you start it early and ask for feedback from the teaching team. The written feedback is always extremely extensive on all the assignments and they will help you a lot with any questions you have.
worse_comment: Do not take it. The work is not much, but the material is beyond boring. Assignments are overly long (at least there are only 3 of them), and the project expectations are vague.

course_title: Building a Human Body: From Gene to Cell to Organism 001
best_comment: Great class! I took this as a pre–med without LS1B or SC10, and it was fine. Amazing course staff and an AMAZING lab – you will never think about planaria the same again (such a FUN time in this lab). Very informative and relevant course, it felt useful and the grading/ assignments are fair and helpful (nothing felt like busywork). Would highly recommend.

course_title: Building a Human Body: From Gene to Cell to Organism 001

TAKE THIS CLASS! No assignments, lectures are super interesting, and sections are engaging. I am a CS person so was quite apprehensive going into this class, but I found it easy to participate and the course is perfectly designed to give you a nice intro to a philosophy–esque course. Professor Imparato is SO AWESOME and he truly cares about each and every student. Definitely take advantage of his meals and office hours! He is sooooo amazing.
worse_comment: Do all the readings with an open mind and ready to disagree (and agree). Prof. Imparato will introduce philosophical theories, but you do not have to agree with all of them. He does this to provide you with the tools to shape your moral argumentation and there will be theories you support and believe in while there will be some you will disagree with (often times using the theory you agree with to argue against the one you disagree with).

best_comment: As an HDRBer, this is the BEST COURSE I'VE TAKEN AT THIS SCHOOL!!! Please take it. Reproductive biology is such a niche, underfunded, understudied sector of science, and Kara is the most knowledgeable person you could find about this topic. She does a great job of breaking down content in a way that is palatable, but also leaves you wanting to know more. I have learned so much in this class, from experimental techniques, developmental pathways, and even socioeconomic factors about reproductive biology – things like misogyny in science, to intersex/transgender healthcare, and more. If you haven't taken SCRB 10/SCRB 50, the first couple of weeks are a great crash course for experimental design, which is important for PSETs. Lecture is much more informational (but still very interesting!). PSETs are very manageable, as long as you take the time to show up to office hours (there is no collaboration with peers allowed, only TFs/Kara). The TFs were also both very amazing, approachable, and dedicated people! Lastly, if youre reading this lottery ASAP for the course – it's very hard to get into, so if you demonstrate interest early, you have a higher chance of getting into the class earlier. The majority of the class was juniors/seniors, and they are from a good mix of backgrounds (mostly premed, but not all HDRB). There also are some grad students, too, which provides a wonderful light to the course in terms of experience and interest!

course_title: Epigenetics and Gene Regulation of Human Development and Disease 001
best_comment: This is an excellent class. Jason is a total trailblazer and brilliant. Emily is absolutely fantastic, a great instructor, knowledgeable, and super helpful. What's an extra plus is you also gain a bunch of computational skills through the project + practicals, and these carry with you beyond the class!
worse_comment: Problem sets (and final) are hard and not conceptual like the lectures. Make sure you go to class and lab. However, this will not be enough to know how to answer the psets and final.

course_title: A World of RNA: An RNA-centric view of life 01
best_comment: If you have a strong interest in RNA biology, take this class. Ryan is an expert in his field, which makes his lectures jam–packed and informative. However, if you have only a mild interest in the topic or are taking it as a requirement, I would consider taking another class. Lectures are dry and opportunities for active learning/student participation is negligible.  Sections are standard for SCRB classes: present a paper cogently.

course_title: Stem Cell Therapeutics: Exploring the Science and the Patient Experience 01
best_comment: This is a great class to learn about super interesting research from leaders in the field, and the patient perspectives are amazing! Because there are so many topics covered (it was generally divided by organs/diseases,  like brain, cardiovascular, diabetes, embryos, etc) , it means there's something for everyone. The paper also talks about some social/public policy concerns that have arisen with stem cell therapy, like equitable access, non–FDA approved therapies in the Caribbean, 'my sister's keeper'–esque family planning with IVF, and more, so it's not just hard science 24/7 which I appreciated. The weekly paper write–ups are graded semi–harshly with the goal of helping you refine your analysis of papers—I actually feel like I improved a lot in this aspect over the course of the semester and my grade was generally fine. The professors are both very well–connected in the medical/research/pharma world so the guest speakers are highly credentialed and super interesting. The con of this is that the professors are really busy and your actual learning (weekly paper roundtables, advice on your proposal) are all directed by a TF. It's harder to build a relationship with the professors. The patient stories are incredibly moving and diverse, and something that you'll really only otherwise get in medical school 'patient as professor' sessions. Take this class for a great survey in stem cell research!

I enjoyed the opportunities that this course brought to us as students.  Many of our guest speakers were fabulous, but that was definetly the highlight of the course.  In terms of work and growing a venture I would say this course is a bit rigid and sometimes seemed like it was assigning certain work and making certain rules (like the complicated late policy and attendance quizzes) just to be annoying.  This course seemed to baby it's students in a somewhat patronizing way. Overall it was a good experience, but I hope that things get improved for next year
Sam is awesome! You're gonna write a play. Whether it's good or bad doesn't matter, but it's still gonna be super fun. :)

This course is a requirement, so you have to take it at least twice. This past semester was the best implementation I've seen of the production studio model, but it wasn't without flaw. Email ahead to ask what the deal with auditions is, because oftentimes they're deceptive (e.g. completely "informal" but absolutely define your experience of the course including whether you sing in your own range, whether you play your preferred gender, and whether you have substantial material to memorize / a decent sized role). If they ask you to cold read in a table read format "just to hear it as a group," be sure to ask whether you are being officially seen for a role (because this is likely the only acting audition you'll get). If you do/don't want a lead, tell the course staff early so that more folks can be more matched to their time commitments. If you're an experienced performer, you will probably not learn from the present model of the course. If the show seems to deal with problematic content in any way shape or form, trust me, wait for another one to come around in a different semester (handling sensitive content is a continual challenge for TDM). If you get a light–hearted, fun script with lots of roles, you have literally no idea how lucky you are. Email ahead to check what the deal is if you're not sure. The department is not normal about conflicts, but your stage managers often are. Email them personally well in advance and ask permission (do not be sneaky or rude, you make us all look bad). If they don't reply, assume it's a no and show up. Continually show the course staff more grace than the department is willing to show you. The course staff is not responsible for the structural issues of the course itself. They are doing their best to accommodate everyone's needs, and they are often as confused and frustrated with the situation as you are. Oftentimes, they are industry professionals who care about meeting students and forging meaningful connections. Be five minutes early for everything, show up off book before they ask, get into costume and mic immediately, and demonstrate with your actions that you're ready for a bigger challenge (if enough of us do it, they might finally listen).Brisa, Stew, Sam, and Rachel are amazing course staff. You will be very lucky to work with them if any of them are involved again.
worse_comment: The lack of norming around valuing people's time and showing up on time was a deterrent to the process. The lack of norming around presence of mind in class sessions and some people (read: more than appropriate) on their laptops doing work for other things while we were having devising discussions was a shame.

If the show seems to deal with problematic content in any way shape or form, trust me, wait for another one to come around in a different semester (handling sensitive content is a continual challenge for TDM). If you get a light–hearted, fun script with lots of roles, you have literally no idea how lucky you are. Email ahead to check what the deal is if you're not sure. The department is not normal about conflicts, but your stage managers often are. Email them personally well in advance and ask permission (do not be sneaky or rude, you make us all look bad). If they don't reply, assume it's a no and show up. Continually show the course staff more grace than the department is willing to show you. The course staff is not responsible for the structural issues of the course itself. They are doing their best to accommodate everyone's needs, and they are often as confused and frustrated with the situation as you are. Oftentimes, they are industry professionals who care about meeting students and forging meaningful connections. Be five minutes early for everything, show up off book before they ask, get into costume and mic immediately, and demonstrate with your actions that you're ready for a bigger challenge (if enough of us do it, they might finally listen).Brisa, Stew, Sam, and Rachel are amazing course staff. You will be very lucky to work with them if any of them are involved again.
worse_comment: The lack of norming around valuing people's time and showing up on time was a deterrent to the process. The lack of norming around presence of mind in class sessions and some people (read: more than appropriate) on their laptops doing work for other things while we were having devising discussions was a shame.

course_title: Sophomore Tutorial: Foundational Concepts in Theater, Dance & Media 001
best_comment: The community fostered in this course was one of the highlights of my semester. Every week I was in awe of my classmates' creativity, ideas, and the connections everyone would find between our different readings. I loved how many different types of artists I was exposed to throughout the course of the semester. Also, the New York trip is great!! Overall, I think this is a class where you get out of it what you put in. If you truly engage with the materials and your classmates, you will learn a lot, but it's up to you to really put in that work.

This is one of the most fabulous courses at Harvard! Johnny and Wes are an AMAZING teaching duo, and I think I can speak for my entire class when I say that this class was the highlight of the week. So fun to act in such a safe environment. Definitely ideal if you have some performance experience (in any capacity), but they make it open to all. 11/10. AMAZING. BEAUTIFUL. PERFECT CLASSS!!!!! A TREASURE

This is a great class for working through a lot of monologues and scenes! Marcus gives great feedback and really helps you grow as an actor through the specific monologues and scenes that he helps you curate for yourself. Marcus and Alex are also so great at suggesting monologues and scenes that they think would be good for you and easy for you to connect with.

Take this class. Whatever you do, take this class. Even if you're not an actor and you haven't acted since that required middle school play take this class. You will be transformed! If you're worried about the audition, don't be. As long as you try your hardest and express your interest in the essay that you write to apply to the class, things will work in your favor. Secondly, buy in. I found that I had a great time despite being nervous very often because I had bought in. I wanted to be an effective actor. I wanted to leave the floor knowing that I was believable. Remo will give you so many suggestions and so much advice and you should treat them like gold. Don't hesitate to push back if you have doubts or questions though, he will gladly talk you through his reasoning and incorporate your reasoning as well. Oftentimes you might have an instinct that he didn't think of. I became a more confident person because of this class. I want  to engage with Shakespeare more because of this class. I gained new friends because of this class. I probably got through my thesis because of this class. (It was really great to take a creative and expressive  class in the midst of a silent laboratory semester) I wish I could put into words how I feel about this. I took this class in my senior spring – it was my first TDM class – and that's to say it's never too late to jump in! Although I did wish I had this experience earlier (so if you are an underclassman thinking about taking this class, do so. If you've applied before and didn't get in, apply again.) Loved this class, probably the best one I took at Harvard.

This is a really great class! I found it helpful to be taking this class in conjunction with another acting class because I found that I had another space to practice the techniques that I was learning here. Memorization is a solid component of this course, so I would greatly recommend being on top of your deadlines for your presentations as all of that memory work will be done outside of class.  In general, not much class time is spent going over deadlines, so be sure to check on Canvas and be aware of when different journals and reflections are due!
worse_comment: Take this class! Put in the work and explore you will not only have fun but also grow and develop in myriad ways.

best_comment: This class is awesome and pushed you out of your comfort zone in unconventional ways. It is so much fun. You wouldn't understand just how much fun it is unless you took the class. We learn tai chi, yoga, cartwheels, headstands as well as more technical theater strategies like character archetypes, mask work, and grid work. Professor Simpson cares more about effort and attitude than he does about your actual execution of the physical work (as in... you don't actually have to execute a full–blown headstand in order to do well in the class). He also ensures a comfortable and safe environment conducive to this type of learning. Take this if you want to become a better actor or director because it will help hone your eye for body language and teach you new ideas about how to use movement to tell a story. Take this if you don't want that and you just want to be more in tune with your own body and have fun. This is an excellent class if you want something less reading/writing heavy, or as a 5th if you're feeling especially gungho one semester. Pete, the professor, is the longest–running blue man group member, and he is just such a cool guy and you cannot help but be inspired by his passion for the work and inspired by his attitude when it comes to theater and different approaches to storytelling.

As a non–TDM concentrator who wanted to explore this space, Shira's class was possibly one of the best places to do that and I'm very thankful I got to enrol in this course! Granted, at times the discussion felt a bit harder to follow because fellow TDM concentrators had a much more vast arsenal of knowledge regarding shows but the course was crafted in a way that is non–exclusionary, and Shira is very skilled and inclusive in engaging and facilitating sharing. It's an incredible safe space to explore your artistic visions, but definitely be ready to commit some time to figuring out rehearsals and getting your actors + props + venues sorted out earlier. That was usually quite difficult, so seek help from your friends and fellow coursemates, and get creative!

TAKE THIS COURSE. As a very very heavy stem person i was worried i wouldn't fit in in this course, but it truly is made for everyone and all experience levels. I felt a lot of freedom to explore theater and drama, and felt it was a really safe place to try new things! I'm very personally glad I took this course, and really grateful to David and Elinor for putting on this course!

This class is incredible! Laura is a fantastic teacher who is incredibly knowledgeable about the field (and so accomplished with her own research!) Each week, you will learn about a different choreographic lineage and the class covers a multitude of different dance styles and genres. The workload is incredibly manageable with weekly readings/videos and the assignments are super fun–you get to attend free live performances and write about what you see. I would definitely recommend this course to both TDM concentrators and anyone with an interest in dance–it is an incredible opportunity to learn about how to study dance as an academic discipline.

course_title: Playful Bodies: Transforming Materiality through LUDUS & Butoh 001
best_comment: One of the best classes I have ever taken. Every single session was an ecstatic transformational practice of becoming, beyond all expectations of the known reality. It was joyful and profound. If you are willing to push yourself, physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually, this class will reward you thousandfold with some of the coolest experiences and explorations through movement, from flying on the hands of others, to hatching from the egg of who you thought you were, to sprouting from the earthy seed of yourself.

Please take this course!! Jeffrey Page is one of the best professors. He will definitely push you (the warm–ups will be intense, but as someone trying to get in shape, they are doable), but it is so worth it. Learning about the history behind the dances we learn, as well as choreographing our own dances at the end of the course, really gives you a greater appreciation for the arts. Also, the live drummers at every other class really brings the class and the dances we are learning to life. Highly recommend!!

Professor Howze is deeply caring and an expert in his field and the arts. I loved the broad approach he took to playwriting and the various multimedia art forms he incorporated in to the syllabus. It is clear he cares about the individual growth of his students greatly and it was a privilege to learn from him!

This class is super fun to meet new people interested in podcasting. You will be connected with professionals who are very knowledgable of the industry and who can give helpful feedback. It can feel a bit disorganized at times but communication and asking questions will be super helpful in getting assignments done.

course_title: Intersections: Theater, Democracy and Civic Practice 1
best_comment: This class is truly what it says it is—a deep dive into the intersections of theater and democracy. It is almost all conversation though, in a circle for two hours, which can feel a bit repetitive every week, but the content of those discussions are incredibly rich. The insights peers provide are so interesting to hear, and always leave my head spinning in the best possible way. It mentally and emotionally stimulates me constantly, but people don't really take notes so its hard to remember it all afterward. Dayron and Leah are great and so encouraging! Their presence is a radiant one in the classroom, and they are supportive. I LOVED watching performances with the class! It was my favorite part, to actually see theater happen in front of our eyes after speaking about it. It grounded the course more for me.
You won't ever regret taking this class, and that's a promise!

course_title: Collective Freedom Dreaming: Engaged Pedagogy and Radical Love as Praxis 001
best_comment: If this class is ever offered again (which it should be), I HIGHLY recommend that you take it. It's the best and one of the most important classes I've taken at Harvard, and I learned so much about myself, past freedom dreams of my ancestors, and how to cultivate my freedom dreams today.
worse_comment: This class is a part of history that, unfortunately,  future students at Harvard will not have the privilege of experiencing.

course_title: Tutorial - Junior Year: Research and Methods 001
best_comment: This was just a fantastic pre–thesis–writing exprience, and definitely gave me more of a handle on both what I want to spend the next year of my life writing about and how I'll go about doing it. Professor Mitra is so incredibly supportive and kind and brilliant–––she will definitely push you to think and grow, and you will definitely thank her–––and Jelani is the same. I'm very grateful that I got to learn from them both :)

This is a wonderful class that anyone can and should take who wants to learn more about or engage more deeply with Black feminist theory. Professor Perry is lovely and so is Imani. The mix of undergraduates and graduate students expands class perspectives and has a unique way of enriching discussions. The assignments allow you to reflect deeply on course themes without feeling burdensome. This class was truly always the highlight of my week.

course_title: Women's Voices in Asian and Asian American Literature 001
best_comment: Take the course! One thing to note, while it is implied, but not explicitly, stated the course is very East Asian centric. So, if you're looking for a course about the broader Asian female diaspora, this may not fit. Nonetheless the course was super interesting, extremely manageable, and Dr. Choi is a great professor to have. You'll have reasonable weekly readings, with a short written assignment (~2 pages) every few weeks or so, culminating in a creative final project that you can really make your own. I loved getting to meet the other students in such an intimate setting and listening to all of their thoughts and final projects at the end of the semester. Readings consist of many seminal works by traditional and modern Korean, Japanese, and Chinese women as well as thought–provoking films. Awesome class, would definitely take it again. I took it as a 5th class and it did not add much to my coursework, and Dr. Choi is always great at checking in to make sure everyone isn't overwhelmed and engaged. She does a great job at engaging even the quieter students and making sure everyone feels welcome and included. Loved this course.

course_title: Leaning In, Hooking Up: Visions of Feminism and Femininity in the 21st Century 001
best_comment: When the past Qguides said everyone should take this class, they were absolutely right. Unfortunately, I don't think you'll be able to do that anymore, because I  think this is the last year it's being taught. That being said, this course dramatically transformed the way that I view the intersection of misogyny, gender, capitalism, class, racism, and more. I have begun to see the signs everywhere, baked into our daily lives and routines. This course should be mandatory as part of a liberal arts education. There were weekly reading discussion posts that were very fun to create and read from others. There were a lot of readings to base it on and a lot was expected from us when writing them, but they did a good job at pushing us to think about the bigger picture/outside the box. The assignments were also very fun and reasonable. There were 2 visual and language analysis papers and a final creative project or policy reform paper. Dr. Thompson and Vanessa are some of the best thinkers I've met at this school, and having a conversation with them will leave you feeling so fulfilled but also craving even more knowledge and justice. They have left such an impact on me, and I will be forever grateful I took this course.
worse_comment: It is a REAL shame this is not being offered again. It is very upsetting.

course_title: Gender, Race, and Poverty in the United States 001
best_comment: This is a great class. Dr. Mtshali is very talented and knowledgeable about the root causes of poverty and how it intersects across different groups. The concepts you will learn in this class apply to so much of what you see in the news everyday and made me a much better consumer of information.

course_title: Love's Labors Found: Uncovering Histories of Emotional Labor 1
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. I genuinely got the most out of this class than any other class I have taken at Harvard. I'm so serious. Professor Light is so so so incredible and genuine and gives amazing feedback and advice academically, but also cares so much about her students and gets to know everyone personally. The material was all very interesting, and while you should definitely prepare to do a lot of reading, as long as you keep up, it's not incredibly difficult. Class discussions were so interesting and really expanded my perspective.  I can't say enough amazing things about this class. Best part of my year!

TAKE THIS CLASS NOW! Best class I have ever taken at Harvard hands down. Roberto is excellent and such a thoughtful human; he is extremely knowledgeable not only about this topic but all the interdisciplinary approaches that come with it. He gave us such amazing feedback and really championed our intellectual pursuits and contributions. Taking this class was such a blessing and absolutely changed the way I view medicine and many of the political movements of today. It was truly the transformative experience Harvard advertises!
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! I learned so so so much from both Roberto and the other students in this class. I have never taken a class like this before.

best_comment: You NEED to take this class. It has the best syllabus and structure I've ever had, with regular engagement with Harvard institutions like the Peabody Museum and Harvard Art Museum, as well as the authors of some of the papers we read. This was an incredible class and I learned so much about the various ways in which colonialism has shaped institutions here and around the world.
